column2: OTTAWA--It was only in the last few years before the war that Canadian resort hotels began to take seriously to the idea that this great north country had as much to offer in the way of snow, sunshine, winter sports and especially skiing as Switzerland, and that here ...

Etchings and engravings by old and modern masters owned by Harold Greenhill of Chicago, Samuel Strauss of New York and ethers will be auctioned next Tuesday and Wednesday evenings at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.

Etchings and engravings by old and modern masters owned by Harold Greenhill of Chicago, Samuel Strauss of New York and ethers will be auctioned next Tuesday and Wednesday evenings at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.

A last-minute British attempt to resolve Hindu-Moslem differences to pave the way for Indian independence ended in failure last week. Tomorrow in New Delhi a Constituent Assembly will open to draw up an Indian constitution. But the Moslems, representing almost one-fourth of India's population (400,000,000) will not be present.

FARM, aquarium and menagerie meet today in the clouds. C-47 and C-54 aircraft that once carried Presidents and Prime Ministers to peace conferences are now flying race horses, cattle, live lobsters, anteaters and boa constrictors.

OTTAWA, Dec. 7--Canada is doing her utmost to try to meet all requests for relief of the food shortage in Alaska, it is stated here.
EVERY newspaper man is known to have the first draft of a novel, play or story tucked away in the bottom drawer under the scrawled notes for the defense in yesterday's possible libel suit.

Major changes in national housing policies and regulations are awaited eagerly by home builders and realty men following President Truman's acceptance last week of the resignation of Wilson W. Wyatt, National Housing Expediter.
John L. Lewis unexpectedly called off the soft coal strike yesterday afternoon. It was indicated that there would be no further interruption of production between now and April 1, 1947. [1:8.]

WELLESLEY, Mass., Dec. 7 (AP) --Miss Emilv Greene Balch. 79year-old Nobel Peace Prize co-winner, "fought' for peace through two World Wars with the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom and will give her $17,000 award to the group.

One of the most significant facts of recent American economic history was the action of the National Association of Manufacturers at its annual meeting here last week in breaking with its past and adopting a liberalized policy on labor, fiscal and other national problems.
WITH the publication of these writings covering little more than a decade in the early career of Dylan Thomas, it becomes clear that the great tradition of English poetry, already ...
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8--A stiffening of employer resistance to collective bargaining and to union activity was revealed today in a report of the National Labor Relations Board for October.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP)-- Congressmen expressed determination today to proceed with new labor legislation but indicated that John L. Lewis' surrender had pulled a last-minute safety valve against an explosion of drastically punitive measures.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 8 (AP)-- Bullet Bob Waterfield led the Los Angeles Rams to a high-powered 38-17 victory over the Green Bay Packers before a closing day crowd of 46,838 today in Memorial Coliseum.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8--With reserves reduced by the mine strike, the Solid Fuels Administration announced tonight a somewhat eased but still rigid rationing of soft coal and coke until stockpiles are replenished.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 8 (AP)--Slammin' Sam Snead of Hot Springs, Va., who dominated the $10,000 Miami open golf tournament from the start, won the $2,000 first prize today with a seventy-two-hole total of 268, twelve strokes under par.
Men's clothing manufacturers have done a good job in holding prices down on seasonal and spring lines since decontrol, market sources claimed over the week-end.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses embarked upon a controversy yesterday with Kesbec, Inc., over the company's announced refusal to vacate two gasoline stations it operates on the Henry Hudson Parkway on Dec. 31 to make room for a higher bidder.
The United Seamen's Service, which operates facilities for seamen throughout the world, announced yesterday the beginning of a drive for $1,500,000 to complete its budget requirements for 1947.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 8--The average coal miner is "in the hole" to the extent of $682 in lost wages as a result of the two strikes called by John L. Lewis this year. Average total earnings for the year are expected to be about $2,432.
The Whitney Museum will open tomorrow its 1946 annual exhibition of contemporary American painting, the outstanding event in a week of many exhibitions.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 8--By a roll-call poll, the New Jersey State Industrial Union Council, CIO, in the final session of its two-day convention in the Hotel Essex House here today voted 1,054 to 320 for a strongly phrased antiCommunist resolution.

ATHENS, Dec. 8--Greece requires considerable economic and financial assistance to maintain her progress toward recovery, King George II said today. He added that his country asked such aid so it might contribute to world peace. He described Greece as "a bulwark of peace and democracy in the Balkans."
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 8--As the vanguard of the country's 400,000 soft coal miners started back to work, a strong possibility developed tonight that the strikers would escape most of the $5,000,000...
FOR three successive seasons Lou Little has been bellowing as loudly as his surgically muted vocal chords would permit that Earl (Red) Blaik has been the Coach of the Year.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 8-- Paramount has purchased "Angel Face," a screen story by Charles Schnee about a show girl with a calculating heart that belies her beauty, as a vehicle for Paulette Goddard.
Home-made cookies may answer the problem of what to give ceritain people on your Christmas list even though sugar is scarce and the pre-holiday schedule leaves little time for baking.
Sheriff John J. McCloskey announced yesterday a general reassignment of his administrative assistants in charge of county divisions of the Sheriff's Office in order to fill the vacancy caused...

BASLE, Switzerland, Dec. 8-- The permanent committee to raise funds for the Weizmann Institute of Scientific Research in Rehovoth in Palestine will be established in Switzerland, the leaders of Swiss Jewry and the American Committee of Friends of that institute decided today at a luncheon.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 8--Precipitating another governmental crisis, Premier Ismail Sidky Pasha submitted his resignation to King Farouk today. There was no announcement from the Palace whether or not the King had accepted it.
Another strike by New York Harbor tugboat workers threatened last night as union members voted to authorize their leaders to call a walkout.

For his violin recital at Carnegie Hall, last night, Isaac Stern had arranged a noble schedule, which veered from routine program-making by the placing of two Bach concertos, with orchestral accompaniment, on the list.
LONDON, Dec. 8--The public demand for currency is attracting considerable attention again because of the approach of...

Maintaining that the oil of the Middle East "is inextricably bound up with the question of Palestine, and, consequently, of Zionism," Harold L. Ickes, former Secretary of the Interior, yesterday deplored American-British political moves that have prevented a Jewish commonwealth in Palestine.
LONDON, Monday, Dec. 9--Expressions of relief over the ending of the coal strike in the United States were combined with castigations of John L. Lewis in British press comment today.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 8--The commercial treaty between Argentina and Chile, described in some circles as the most important made in Latin America in many years, will be signed in a few days, according to Senator Jaime Garcia Moreno, chief of the Chilean mission here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8--Miss Yolanda Bernabe, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Rafael Bernabe of San Juan, P.R., was married here tonight to Dr. Jorge Alberto Montealegre, member of the Nicaraguan delegation to the United Nations, in St. Matthew's Roman Catholic Cathedral by the Rev. William F. Strickler.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8--The coal miners' strike, now ended, but which led to the embargo on general railroad freight, failed last week to have any effect as a pricemaking influence on grams on the Board of Trade here, as food and feed were exempted from the provisions governing the movement of freight.

AMSTERDAM, Netherlands, Dec. 7 (Delayed)--That any re-establishment of European enterprise in the Netherlands Indies--especially within the Republican boundary-- was fraught with great odds was the main topic of a speech by Pieter Honig, submanager of the Department of Economic Affairs of the Dutch Indies, here this week.

The outstanding fact in the bituminous coal drama is childishly simple. President Lewis of the United Mine Workers endeavored to force his will on President Truman of the United States. Mr. Lewis failed, and on Saturday had to admit his failure.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8--Cash lard developed a decidedly weak undertone here last week, declining 2 cents a pound, and the refined product, which sold as high as 55 cents after the price ceiling was lifted, declined as much and was traded in around 25 cents at the close of the week, with Backers inclined to press offerings in order to prevent accumulation of supplies.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Dec. 8 (AP) --Omaha was selected for the 1947 meeting and Willard N. Greim of Denver was re-elected president for a third term at the closing session of the fifty-eighth annual convention of the National A.A.U. today.
CHICAGO, Dec. 8--The volume of business reported by linen supply firms has increased about 15 percent over a year ago, with a large part of the upturn taking place during the last three months,...

HACKETTSTOWN, N.J., Dec. 8--Three remaining trustees are giving their unused eighty-eightyear-old church in the village of Vienna for removal six miles to the campus here of Centenary Junior College for women. It will become a lecture and recital hall.

After a year and a half of public and private debate, the Big Four Powers have at last agreed on the final text of the five peripheral European peace treaties and are now starting work on what is the central problem of both European and world peace--the treaty with Germany.

RYE LAKE, N.Y., Dec. 8--A $350,000 Navy air transport, purchased from the Federal Government for $350 by the North Castle Youth Council, a small group of parents, arrived at the Westchester County airport here this afternoon to serve as a clubhouse and aviation...
The soft-coal strike is over, but its effects will be felt for some time. The 3,000,000-ton stockpile frozen by the Government when the strike began has shrunk to 450,000 tons.

After an ownership of several months, Fischer-Landis, Inc., operators, have sold the nine-story apartment building at 106-10 East Eighty-fifth Street, near Park Avenue, for cash above a first mortgage of $131,500.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP)--Republican Senate leaders confront tomorrow the job of parceling out the fruits of victory, commmittee assignments, without nearly enough choice spots to meet demand.
A confused and leader-less General Assembly is now muddling through to its end. It appeared last night that the end probably would come late in the night of Dec. 17.
With the termination of the coal strike, which came with such dramatic suddenness on Saturday, the nation can once more breathe freely again.
CEDARHURST, L.I., Dec. 8-- Stanley W. Pearson Jr. of Germantown Cricket Club won the Gold Racquet today at the Rockaway Hunting Club.

Three hours after she had taken a sleeping tablet, Mrs. Evelyn Morgan, 34 years old, of 277 Park Avenue, was found dead yesterday on the floor of the living room of her apartment.

There is no chance of beginning commercial operation of Idlewild Airport, in Queens, by June 1, as scheduled, unless there is an early settlement of the labor dispute over the pulling of telephone cables on the site, City Construction Commissioner Robert Moses said yesterday.

With the beginning of normal competition seen for the coming year manufacturers with "reputation" names are making strong efforts to make available the new products with distinctive features heralded during the war years, a round-up of industrial opinion by the Brand Names Foundation, revealed over the week-end.

Current schedules of Government surplus sales include fixedprice offerings of 8,400 large canvas duck shields and 50,000 mosquito bed nets, it was announced over the week-end by Frank L. Seymour, regional director of the...

Foreign Minister Molotov of Russia told the United Nations General Assembly, in a session that lasted until early today, that the plan to include in the proposed troop census armed forces stationed at home was not acceptable...
Foreign maritime interests are profiting by a bilateral treaty that permits their operation of airlines and bars American shipping companies from similar pursuits, it was charged yesterday.
An interesting program of vocal music was offered yesterday afternoon at Times Hall by Irene Beamer, contralto, of Massilon, Ohio, at her debut recital in New York.

STEPHEN SPENDER, of Auden, Spender, Lewis and MacNeice, the quartet of English poets who rose to prominence in the Nine teen Thirties, went to Germany and France in the summer and autumn of last year on official business of a curious kind.

PARIS, Dec. 8--As the Electoral College chose most of the members of the Council of the Republic today, it became clear that this second Chamber of Parliament under the new Constitution would be constituted on almost exactly the same party lines as the directly elected National Assembly.

MOSCOW, Dec. 8--As the first year of the current five-year plan draws to a close, housing and industrial reconstruction, which dictate the speed of industrial recovery, are being vigorously attacked...

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 (AP)--The fastskating Montreal Canadiens exploded for three goals within five minutes of the second period to clinch a 5-3 decision tonight over the last-place Chicago Black Hawks in a National Hockey League match 2. A capacity crowd of 19,215 saw the game at the Stadium.
WARSAW, Dec. 8--Seven British soldiers are being held by the Polish police as a result of a drinking fracas in Praga, a Warsaw suburb, Friday night.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 8--India's Constitution-making Assembly will convene tomorrow with the avowed intention of charting the future of an independent nation. It will meet in the face of many doubts and difficulties.
With the exception of flurries, occasioned by the retailers' desire to get in merchandise on order before the rail embargo went into effect last Friday, the wholesale markets last week were fairly...

NANKING, Dec. 8 (U.P)--Gen. George C. Marshall will return to the United States for consultation with President Truman as soon as the current Chinese National Assembly session ends, Chinese newspapers reported today.

The United Nations stands in urgent need of a spiritual philosophy to give it unity of purpose and to encompass "the legitimate aspirations" of all peoples, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell declared yesterday morning in his sermon at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 8--Capitulation of John L. Lewis in the coal strike has turned the leadership on second-round wage increases over to the Congress of Industrial Organizations, where,...

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Dec. 8--Twenty-three German doctors and scientists, including one woman, will go on trial tomorrow in Nuremberg on charges of murders and atrocities committed in medical experiments in concentration camps.

Paul Brown's Cleveland Browns, Western division champions, made the All-America Conference 1946 farewell to the metropolitan scene a record-breaking performance as they ran wild against the Brooklyn Dodgers at Ebbets Field yesterday for a 66-14 victory before a slim crowd of 14,600.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Dec. 8-- Ed Raymond, with his Plight, John Nichols at the helm of Gusti Barton's Yiff N'Yiff, and Bob De Coppet with his wife in Zotom, made a three-way battle for top honors in the seventh championship regatta of Larchmont Yacht Club's winter sailing program today.

In a gesture of international understanding, two foreign groups on the staff of the United Nations sent gifts yesterday to help start the thirty-fifth annual appeal of the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund conducted by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

TUPPER LAKE, N.Y., Dec. 8 (AP)--Edward S. (Tex) O'Reilly, who as a soldier of fortune fought under eight flags and in many parts of the world, died today in the Veterans Hospital at Sunmount. His age was 66. He was the subject of Lowell Thomas' book "Born to Raise Hell."

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Dec. 8--The public schools of this city, attended by 9,000 children, will be closed tomorrow because of a threatened teachers' strike, it was announced late today by Grover C. Haberlin, chairman of the Pawtucket School Committee. The population of the city is 75,000 persons.

Leaders of the Liberal party have decided to seek an informal enrollment of at least 25,000 members and an organization in every Assembly district in the State in preparation for functioning as a legal political party, it was learned yesterday.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 8--The great bulk of agricultural legislation promised by President Miguel Aleman in his inaugural address has already been submitted to Congress and is expected to be passed by the end of the year.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 7 (Delayed)--Patriarch Gavrilo, head of the Serbian Orthodox Church, visited Marshal Tito yesterday afternoon for a "friendly conference."

Sale of surplus chemical plant sites would bring a return of little for no net salvage value to the government, it was disclosed here over the week-end by O.F. Sieder, chairman of the advisory board on Utilization of Surplus Industrial Facilities of the Office, Chief of Engineers, United States War Department.

The marriage of Miss Irene Demuth Steckler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip H. Steckler of 791 Park Avenue, to Larry Wolf Jacobson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Jacobson, also of this city, took place yesterday afternoon in the Harmonie Club, 4 East Sixtieth Street.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 8--Sorrowing families and friends gathered at mortuaries and hospitals today to claim their dead and to give comfort to the injured, while city, county and State authorities ordered investigations of the Winecoff Hotel fire disaster.
After-ski fashions for fireside lounging or active games will be gay, warm and a bit more feminine this winter.
People used to say to Laurette Taylor, "Oh, I saw you as Peg"--meaning the title role of "Peg o' My Heart." A good many had done so, and would never forget it.
It would be an added tragedy if shock and horror were the only aftermath of the Atlanta hotel holocaust.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8--The question whether foremen and supervisors shall be classed as employes under the Wagner Act for the purpose of collective bargaining, presumably will be placed on the Supreme Court's calendar tomorrow for later argument and decision.
Currently "only one legitimate Broadway play is fit to be seen by everybody and anybody," the Right Rev. Joseph F. Flannelly, administrator of St. Patrick's Cathedral, declared yesterday.

With all major contentious issues on the minor European peace treaties resolved, the Council of Foreign Ministers will enter the sixth and, it is planned, final week of its New York session today with...

ZURICH, Dec. 8--After several weeks of deadlock in the SwissArgentine financial negotiations, an agreement has been reached permitting repayment of the Argentine 4 per cent tax-free State loan floated in 1933. The purpose is to enable foreign-owned peso balances in Argentina to be unfrozen.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (U.P.)-- President Truman had a "very pleasant" chat with British Foreign Secretary Bevin today during an hour-long social call that naturally turned to foreign affairs, the White House said.

The annual report of GraysonRobinson Stores, Inc., operator of a chain of women's apparel stores, mailed to stockholders yesterday, disclosed a net income of $1,169,355 for the year ended on Sept. 30, last, after deducting taxes and all charges.

Leaving no stone unturned, William Cahn, producer of "Toplitzky of Notre Dame" (it's his first attempt in the musical comedy field), has been making strenuous efforts to improve the George Marion Jr.-Sammy Fain-Jack Barnett show in the hinterland since it first scampered across the stage in Boston on Oct. 31.
Dorothy Eustis, comely young pianist from Seattle, gave a recital last night at Town Hall, where she made her New York debut in 1943.

BOSTON, Dec. 8 (AP)--Set afire by Cal Gardner, who turned in the three-goal "hat trick" in less than six minutes, the surging New York Rangers defeated the Boston Bruins, 6-4, in a lively National Hockey League engagement tonight before a packed 13,900 crowd in the Boston Garden.
The pulse of national sentiment over the coal strike and the institution of a railroad freight embargo was registered on cotton prices last week.

Euthanasia is "the basest of tyrannies" and its advocates are potential "murderers," Msgr. Robert E. McCormick, presiding justice of the ecclesiastical tribunal of the Archdiocese of New York, declared yesterday.

ROME, Dec. 8--Speaking in Milan today, Premier Alcide de Gasperi painted a hopeful picture of the Italian situation but made it clear that for some years, Italy would have to lean heavily on the United States.

ATHENS, Dec. 8 (AP)--The Greek Army heightened today the intensity of already large-scale mopping up operations against Leftist bands in Macedonia, and moved new units into Western Thrace to protect Greco-Turkish highway and rail traffic, army and press reports said.

NEWARK N.J., Dec. 8--Miss Jane Elizabeth Ball, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James T. Ball of this city, has chosen Dec. 27 for her marriage to Stephen Horner, son of Mrs. Louis J. Homer, also of Newark, and the late Mr. Horner.

BOSTON, Dec. 8 (AP)--Using every possible scoring method, the Philadelphia Eagles soared to a 40-14 victory over the Boston Yanks in their final National Football League clash today before a 29,555 crowd at Fenway Park. It was the Eagles' fifth triumph in a row over the Yanks in three seasons.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8--Nations that divert to their armies manpower that could be producing the necessaries of life will not get relief supplies from the United States, Dean Acheson, Acting Secretary of State, said tonight.

Changes in advertising display material are becoming increasingly manifest as a result of modern retail store design, it was asserted over the week-end by C.L. Vanderbogart, president of the Point of Purchase Advertising Institute...

Jennie Tourel, mezzo-soprano, had contrived an unusually interesting program for her recital at Town Hall yesterday afternoon, and in the course of its varied offerings accomplished much that was highly meritorious, vocally and from the interpretive angle.
The Giants are the Eastern champions of the National Football League for 1946.

The international executive board of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, its bargaining position greatly improved with the termination of the soft coal strike, will assemble here this afternoon to define its demand for a new round of wage increases for 850,000 union members.

DETROIT, Dec. 8 (AP)--Marching to two touchdowns and a field goal in the first 5 minutes of play, the Chicago Bears, western division champions of the National Football League, smothered the Detroit Lions, 45 to 24, today in their final game before the EastWest championship play-off next week.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 8--While the steel ingot rate for the country will not bounce immediately back to pre-strike levels, authorities here believe that it will be somewhat higher than it would have been if the order for the coal miners to return to work had not been given by John L. Lewis.

VIENNA, Dec. 7 (Delayed)-- The completion of denazification, a prerequisite to the end of the occupation, is being held up primarily by Russia's effort to perpetuate in Austria the institution of the concentration camp.
LONDON, Dec. 8--The increasing gravity of the shortages in coal, electricity and gas in Britain is weighing heavily again on the financial and industrial world. While no hard and fast rationing...

The Boston Celtics are made to order for Stanley Stutz. The exRhode Island State sharpshooter made this fact obvious last night as he paced the New York Knickerbockers to a 62-to-44 triumph over the Hub team before 10,652 persons at Madison Square Garden.

Western Auto Supply Company reported total November sales of $11,067,000, an increase of 58.7 per cent. Retail sales were $6,392,000, up 72.7 per cent. For eleven months retail sales were $50,960,000, a gain of 90.7 per cent.
This year's supply of candy canes for the city's Christmas trees may be smaller than last year's, a survey of confectionery industry leaders indicated yesterday.
Mayor O'Dwyer and a group of his friends, it was learned yesterday, have started a fund to brighten the declining years of a Jewish girl who became the wife of one of Ireland's outstanding patriots.

LONDON, Dec. 8 (Canadian Press)--Strengthened provisions to insure that companies do not make large appropriations to "hidden reserves" are included in the New Companies Bill that has had its first reading in the House of Commons and now is published in detail.
Learned children of the new atomic age displayed complex scientific knowledge yesterday that gave adults pause at the opening of a city-wide School Science Fair in Madison Square Garden.
R.S. Perry, president of Maxson Food Systems, Inc., in a letter mailed to stockholders yesterday said the company has engaged in extensive research in the preparation of precooked frozen foods, in...

Since the number of fires caused by Christmas trees and decorations increases each year, protective measures for handling these extra fire hazards were released yesterday by the National Board of Fire Underwriters.

SASKATOON, Sask., Dec. 8-- Flames which swept in a matter of seconds through the Barry Hotel early today killed eleven persons and injured eighteen in the most disastrous fire in the history of Saskatchewan, Canada's great grain-growing Province in the prairie West.

DETROIT, Dec. 8 (AP)--Trailing for 16 minutes the Toronto Maple Leafs exploded for four goals in the third period tonight to overcome a 4-1 deficit and beat the Detroit Red Wings, 5 to 4, to maintain their National Hockey League lead.
Mayor O'Dwyer issued a proclamation yesterday urging the people of the city to support generously the $12,000,000 campaign of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies.

KENT, Conn., Dec. 8--The engagement has been announced of Miss Mary Fisher Humphreys, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James P. Humphreys of the Kent School, this community, and Mantoloking, N.J., to Carl Jenkinson, son of Mrs. Edward Jenkinson of Ocean Grove, Mass., and the late Mr. Jenkinson.

Railroad operations were increased sharply yesterday, primarily in moving mountains of lately embargoed freight, and thousands of workers in every major industrial area of the nation prepared to return to jobs interrupted by the coal strike.
The New York Rovers had little trouble defeating the Quebec Aces in the feature game of the matinee double-header at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

Hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers will have to find some other way to get the family wash done when 4,000 Chinese hand laundries shop accepting soiled clothing today, though they will keep their shops open until next Monday.

Loaded with hundreds of toys contributed by children of his congregation, a minister in Forest Hills, Queens, set out yesterday with his 10-year-old son on a 300mile drive to the Pennsylvania coal fields to take Christmas gifts to miners' children.
A closed conference was held at Flushing Meadow Park yesterday between officials of the United Nations and representatives of Mayor O'Dwyer as New York made an eleventh-hour
Universal Bible Sunday, sponsored by the American Bible Society, was observed yesterday in churches in New York City.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., Dec. 8-- Jersey City's Giants upset the Akron Bears, 14--13, today at Roosevelt Stadium to capture the American Football League championship before a crowd of 17,000 fans.
BERLIN, Dec. 7 (Delayed)--An unofficial survey conducted with the help of the Board of Health disclosed today that 2,571 patients in city hospitals were suffering from hunger edema.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 8-- Members of the United Mine Workers in this area were urged over the radio today by William Mitsch, president of the union's District 20, to return to their work as soon as possible.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 8 --Asserting the interests of the United Nations over colonial governments, the Trusteeship Committee reversed the action of a subcommittee on three proposals today.

Without increase in subscription costs for one year beginning Jan. 1, the United Medical Service will extend benefits about twenty-two per cent to 325,000 members enrolled in its surgical plan, Rowland H. George, the president, announced yesterday.

TOKYO, Dec. 8--Almost half the people of Japan are able to live today only by throwing overboard their accumulated savings or selling on the black market the best of their personal belongings, it is indicated in a nation-wide public poll that the newspaper Asahi will publish tomorrow.

SHAWBRIDGE, Que., Dec. 8-- The snowclad hills of this picturesque French-Canadian hamlet, gateway to the popular Laurentian ski lands, teemed with activity this Sabbath Day.
The Kearny Celtics defeated the New York Americans by 2 to 1 in an American Soccer League fixture in Sterling Oval, the Bronx, yesterday. At halftime, the teams were deadlocked at 1--1.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 8 (AP)-- San Francisco's Forty-Niners, combining a clever passing attack with a smashing ground offense, scored a 48-to-7 rout over the Los Angeles Dons in an All America Conference game today before 25,000.

TEHERAN, Iran, Monday, Dec. 9 (U.P.)--Iranian troops will march shortly on the rebellious border province of Azerbaijan, according to a proclamation by Premier Ahmad Ghavam broadcast today over the Tehran radio.

Intersectional college basketball games fill the bill in the fourth of the series of twenty-eight doubleheaders to be presented at Madison Square Garden, as City College clashes with Montana and St. John's meets Nevada tonight at the Eighth Avenue arena.

WARSAW, Dec. 9--Vice Premier Stanislaw Mikolajczyk's Peasant party issued an elevenpoint election manifesto today calling for the restoration of civil liberties and the subordination of the security police to the elected representatives of the people.

Upon detecting mechanical failure in the engines powering a fleet of D-18-C Beechcraft airplanes, Empire Airlines, operating between key cities of New York, announced last night that it had suspended operations.

MELBOURNE, Dec. 9--Walter Pate, captain of the American Davis Cup team, announced today that he would not protest the method John Bromwich uses to dispose of an unserved ball when the first is in play.

Despite strike-imposed delays in the reconditioning and modernization of the Matson liners Lurline and Mariposa at the United Engineering yards at Alameda, Calif., the vessels should be ready for entry in the Pacific Coast-HawaiiAustralia service by May, 1947.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 8 --An American proposal, aimed at getting a sufficient number of trusteeship agreements approved to establish a Trusteeship Council, was approved tonight by a trusteeship subcommittee.

LAC BEAUPORT, P.Q. Dec. 9. --Lac Beauport, with its matchless setting and diversified facilities, which have transformed this quaint French-Canadian settlement into a well-known ski-land, already is covered under a deep white mantle, with more snows today adding to the fifteen-inch depth.

At a six-hour meeting here yesterday during which directors of Jack Heintz Precision Industries, Inc., of Cleveland, reconciled their differences with William S. Jack, the company's president, the board granted the president's request for a one-year's leave of absence, effective immediately.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9--The test case whether foremen shall be allowed to join unions and bargain collectively with employers under the National Labor Relations Act will be reviewed by the Supreme Court.

The Club Car, private membership dining and drinking place in the old four-story former George Warren mansion at 924 Fifth Avenue, near Seventy-third Street, was taken over by three hold-up men at 9 A.M. yesterday.

The Broadway engagement of "The Playboy of the Western World," starring Burgess Meredith, will end its run at the Booth Theatre on Jan. 4, it was announced yesterday by Theatre Incorporated, the sponsor.

Notre Dame earned its position as the No. 1 college football team of 1946 by the infallible method of combining the nation's most powerful offense with the stubbornest defense seen on any gridiron during the season just closed.
The Duke of Windsor presented a check yesterday afternoon to the Salvation Army in the office of Commissioner Ernest I. Pugmire, national commander, at 120 West Fourteenth Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9--Delivery of natural gas from the Little Inch pipeline probably will start in Ohio tomorrow, the Interior Department said tonight. It reported that the gas, which started to move through the pipeline last week, had reached the Ohio area east of Cincinnati.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9--The Columbia Gas and Electric Company and its subsidiary, the Manufacturers Light and Heat Company, jointly requested today that the Securities and Exchange Commission permit Manufacturers Light to issue before Aug. 15, 1948, $7,000,000 of 3 1-3 per cent installment promissory notes.
Reflecting the strength in stocks and in other commodities, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 45 to 65 points yesterday.

The Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association abandoned the Vanderbilt racing rules which it had been using for the last three years in favor of the more universal North American Yacht Racing Union rules at its annual meeting at the New York Yacht Club last night.

O'Connor, who will retain his post with the Sox, was placed at the head of the newly-organized five-team league at its first annual meeting.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 11-- John Frederick Van Name of 20 North Broadway, this city, executive officer of R.T. Wilson Co., private bankers at 512 Fifth Avenue, New York, died today in the White Plains Hospital at the age of 85.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11--Aggressive exploration for new sources of petroleum in domestic regions, as well as increased oil imports to conserve reserves, were urged today by Ralph K. Davies of the Department of the Interior.

The Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, CIO, announced yesterday that it had contributed the first $100,000 toward the $1,000,000 Sidney Hillman Foundation to be established as a memorial to the late labor leader.

Paced by co-captain Tony Karpowich, who scored nineteen points, the Fordham Rams successfully launched their basketball season last night by downing Iona College of New Rochelle, 64--51, at the Rose Hill gymnasium before a crowd of 3,500.
BOULDER, Colo., Dec. 11 (AP)-- Steve Bradley, former Dartmouth College skiing star, has been appointed coach of the University of Colorado ski team.

Manufacturers and importers of ash trays, vases, novelties and other giftware have received telegraphic withdrawals of nearly all cancellations from retailers received during the coal strike, it was learned yesterday.

Capt. Ernest F. Floege, who in 1944 received the Distinguished Service Cross from Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower for his work in organizing the French Maquis, arrived at LaGuardia Field yesterday aboard an American Overseas Airways plane from London.

HOLLYWOOD BEACH, Fla., Dec. 11--Leading the field of twenty three for the women's team-of-four national bridge championship at the close of the first session of thirty boards today were two teams in a tie.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 11--On the first ballot, after eight minutes of deliberation, a jury of five women and seven men decided today that Edmund Wilson's "Memoirs of Hecate County" was not a salacious book.
The first shipment of 1,000 musical tops labeled "Made in Germany" has been placed on sale at G. Schirmer, Inc., stores, it was announced yesterday.

LONDON, Dec. 11 (AP)--Mrs. Charlotte Cameron, noted explorer, lecturer and author, died today in a London nursing home.

The closing and critical days of the General Assembly have now settled down into a duel between Foreign Minister Molotov and the young and coming Attorney General of the United Kingdom, Sir Hartley Shawcross.

The temperature graph began a descent toward something like December's normal yesterday and, though today will be on the mild side, tomorrow will be much colder, even wintry, the Weather Bureau predicted last night without a single "if."

Church World Service, 37 East Thirty-sixth Street, representing the American Protestant churches, made public yesterday an appeal from major voluntary international organizations participating in relief activities for aid to combat threatened starvation in Europe, and lack of clothing and medical care.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Dec. 11--Louis Dempsey of 155 Center Avenue, this city, former vice president of the Butterick Publishing Company of New York, died today at the Harlem Valley State Hospital in Wingdale, N.Y. His age was 76.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 11 (AP)--Glenn Dobbs, former All-America halfback from Tulso, Okla., and picked as the top-ranking All-America Football Conference professional player this year, has signed a fiveyear contract with the Brooklyn Dodgers, Vice President Bill Cox disclosed today.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday that rights to subscribe to its fifteen-year 2 per cent convertible debentures, due on Dec. 15, 1961, will expire at 5 P.M., next Monday.
A party marking the tenth anniversary of the first appearance of Elsie the Cow in advertisements of the Borden Company was held yesterday afternoon in the Hendrik Hudson Room of the Roosevelt Hotel.
Possibility of a general upward revision of interest rates on special interest accounts by the large commercial banks was foreseen her yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP)-- Secretary of Commerce W. Averell Harriman described general living conditions abroad today as what "would in normal times be considered a terrific disaster." He urged the American Red Cross to take leadership in "international human sympathy."

Plans for eighteen new buildings estimated to involve an expenditure of $5,827,950, were filed with the Department of Housing and Buildings in Manhattan during November. A hospital to cost $2,900,000 and a library to cost $1,500,000 led the list.

Blended whiskies on the Christmas market are still selling at approximately the same prices that prevailed under Office of Price Administration ceilings, retail liquor dealers reported yesterday, but a 10 to 15 per cent increase is just around the corner.

Isidore Goldenberg has purchased from Mardon Homes, Inc., a vacant plot, 142 by 100 feet, on the northerly side of Elvira Street, near Reads Lane, Far Rockaway, Queens, for improvement with three one-family houses.

The Brooklyn Postoffice stood ready yesterday to handle an anticipated 20 per cent increase over 1945 in volume of mail for the Christmas holiday period. Details of the intensive preparations to handle a record mailing were made known by Postmaster Edward J. Quigley.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11--Paul Porter, who resigned as Price Administrator after the Office of Price Administration had been shorn of most of its powers, was appointed today to head a United States economic mission to Greece. He will have the rank of Ambassador.

A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Frank H. Platt 2d of Greenwich, Conn., on Dec. 3 in the Harkness Pavilion, Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. Mrs. Platt is the former Miss Audrey Achelis, daughter of Mrs. Frederic G. Achelis of Greenwich. The child will be named Richard Booth.

A group of downtown business men and public officials met yesterday afternoon in the office of City Controller Lazarus Joseph to organize a campaign to raise $350,000 to build a downtown synagogue in the City Hall area.

Clarence H. Low, president of the board of visitors of Rockland State Hospital, was re-elected president of the Association of Boards of Visitors of the Mental Hygiene Institutions of New York State, at the association's annual meeting yesterday in Brooklyn State Hospital, Albany and Clarkson Avenues, Brooklyn.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11--Prof. Charles Merriam, one of the leading American authorities on government, said today that the United States needed to drop its "short-sighted patchwork" of conflicting local, State and Federal taxing programs and adopt a unified system which should be planned as a national whole.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11--Frank J. Wilson, chief of the United States Secret Service, will retire Dec. 31, the Treasury Department announced today.

Henry C. Brunie, president and chairman of the Empire Trust Company and prominent in financial, industrial and welfare activities here, was elected president of the Greater New York Fund at a meeting of the board of directors yesterday.

Dr. Basil G. Bibby, dean of Tufts College Dental School, was elected president of the Pan American Odontological Association last night at that organization's tenth annual meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

John W. Crowfoot, formerly chief industrial engineer of Schick, Inc., Stamford, Conn., has been advanced to plant manager.

Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, asserted last night that the General Motors Corporation could reduce prices, increase wages and still have net earnings greater by $100,000,000 next year than the peacetime profit record of $500,000,000, established in 1941.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11 (U.P.) --Irving Crane of Livonia, N.Y., won the world pocket billard championship tonight by defeating Andy Ponzi of Philadelphia, 125-- 97, in ten innings.

Mayor O'Dwyer, three Borough Presidents and five members of the City Council, including its President, Vincent R. Impelletteri, are to appear as prosecution witnesses in the next few days in the trial in General Sessions of Oscar Waters, 55-year-old Harlem politician.

TOKYO, Dec. 11 (AP)--Lieut. Gen. Kyoji Koizumi, 61 years of age, former commander at Sendai of the Second Division, committed suicide by slashing an artery with a cooking knife today. He had been reported despondent over Japan's defeat.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11--The Congress of Industrial Organizations laid the foundation today for its impending wage demands in the mass production industries by releasing a report which stated that "total corporate business can support a 25 per cent increase in wages."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP)-- Funeral rites of the Greek Orthodox Church were held today in the Washington Cathedral for Cimon Diamantopoulos, Greek Ambassador to the United States, who died Friday night in New York.
Forty additional items have been removed from the Positive List of commodities under export control, L.L. Horch, New York regional director of the Department of Commerce, announced yesterday.

The Anglo-Chilean Nitrate Corporation reported yesterday for the twelve months ended with last June a distributable net profit of 757,989 compared with 627,166 for the preceding twelve-month period.
BERLIN, Dec. 11 (AP)--Col. Peter P. Rodes of Lexington, Ky., has been appointed Director of the Office of Intelligence, the American Military Government announced today.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 11 (AP)-- Arthur Graham Hill, who broke and trained Alsab for racing, died here yesterday at the age of 54.

A propeller-tip landing brought seven passengers and five crew members safely to earth at La Guardia Field yesterday, after the retractable wheels of a huge fourengine Boeing Stratoliner had jammed in their sockets during a flight from Chicago.

Miss Margaret Madonna Miller of Sheridan, Ind., and Roscoe Turner, former speed flier and three-time winner of the Thompson Trophy race of the National Air Races, obtained a marriage license yesterday afternoon at the Municipal Building. Mr. Turner. an aviation executive of Indianapolis, married Carline Stovall in September, 1924. They were divorced on Dec. 5.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11-- President Truman will talk to the nation in a Christmas Eve address to be broadcast over all major networks.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11-- Pickets and policemen clashed again tonight, the second time in three days, when striking employes of The Philadelphia Record attempted to halt delivery of the newspaper's morning editions.

The New York State Banking Department, which has been conducting studies of the strength and weaknesses of the Legal List and recently indicated the possibility that the existing statutory requirement of earnings would disqualify several railroads presently included in the list, acted yesterday to remove $92,400,000 of Erie Railway obligations.

Independent furniture stores will be forced to increase markups of certain merchandise because of higher delivery costs resulting from railroad rate increases and those impending for motor carriers, a traffic executive disclosed yesterday.
The Paulist Choristers, who formerly gave annual concerts under their founder, the Rev. John J. Finn, last night returned to the concert stage after an absence of almost ten years.
ATHENS, Dec. 11 (U.P.)--Two American foreign correspondents, who had been reported seized by guerrillas in northern Greece, were reported tonight to have reached the town of Trikkala, safe and sound.

The District Attorney's office of Kings County announced yesterday the arrest in New Orleans of Alfred F. Isola, alias Al Russo, 44 years old, of 222 Pennsylvania Avenue, Brooklyn. He was charged with defrauding veterans and their brides.
CHICAGO, Dec. 11--The 1947 Midwinter Sale Book being mailed this week by Aldens, Inc., to nearly 2,000,000 customers features elimination of "not available" items and no increase in prices ...

NEWARK, Dec. 11--Consumer credit volume may surpass the previous all-time peak early next year and by mid-1947 approximate $12,000,000,000, compared with the present level of $8,700,000,000, Duncan M. Holthausen, economist of the Federal Reserve Board, said here today.
The contract for the construction of the new ranch store of Lord Taylor in the town of Eastchester, Westchester County, has been awarded to the George A. Fuller Company.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11--The United States Gypsum Company of Chicago filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 399,477 shares of $20 par value common stock.

The disaster in the Amsterdam Avenue tenement was not caused by an explosion in the adjoining icehouse, but was attributed to the weakening of roof beams in the abandoned plant, Chief Fire Marshal Thomas P. Brophy asserted last night in a special report to Mayor O'Dwyer.

BENNINGTON, Vt., Dec. 12-- As two Connecticut detectives delved into the mysterious disappearance of 18-year-old Paula Welden from Bennington College, Gov. Mortimer R. Proctor twice telephoned the State's Attorney here today asking that he be kept fully informed of all developments.

H. Struve Hensel, former Assistant Secretary of the Navy, declared last night that if the features of the so-called "Eberstadt plan" for integration of the services were put into effect even such major issues between the Army and Navy as control of airpower could be worked out by a National Security Council.

Details of a $20,000,000 apartment house development projected for the Riverdale section of the Bronx were learned yesterday with the filing of plans for twenty-four six-story and penthouse buildings.

Charley Fusari will risk a consecutive winning streak of fortysix professional fights when he tackles Charley (Chuck) Taylor, sturdy welterweight from Coalport, Pa., in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight. The Irvington, N.J., gladiator is the 5-to-9 favorite to extend his list of victories at Taylor's expense.

The one-point edge that Long Island University held 22 seconds before time ran out at Madison Square Garden last night appeared ready for the scrap heap when Blake Williams of Oklahoma A. and M. drew a foul shot. All Williams had to do was sink the point to send the contest into overtime.

The two insurgent groups in Tammany took control of the Tammany executive committee yesterday by endorsing Carmine Di Sapio, a leader of the First Assembly District and a member of the so-called Italian group, for Commissioner of the Board of Elections to succeed S. Howard Cohen.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12--The sixth session of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration Council met intermittently today as a subcommittee of ten countries struggled with a Soviet proposal for rigid country-bycountry completion of all programs in $626,000,000 worth of future shipments.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12--Dr. Luis W. Alvarez, 35 years old, a physics professor at the University of California and an amateur pilot, has won the Robert J. Collier Aviation Trophy, the War Department announced today.

Higher prices, running from 10 to 15 per cent, will be general on men's branded shirt lines after the first of the year, it was learned yesterday. For the last ten years at least, a contribution of $3,000 has been given annually to the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund. The donor always insists on remaining anonymous, preferring to be known only as "A Friend."

At least $24,000,000 must be raised in the January, 1947, March of Dimes campaign for the National Foundation of Infantile Paraly-, sis, Basil O'Connor, president of the foundation, asserted last night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Racing's river of gold flowed in record proportions during 1946, a nation-wide United Press survey showed yesterday, with the total mutuel handle throughout the country approaching two billion dollars for the first time.
A seventy-five-foot Christmas tree will sparkle at Rockefeller Plaza today at dusk. Ultra-violet light will bring to life 800 gaily colored plastic globes which ornament the stately Norway spruce.

Directors of the National State Bank of Newark, N.J., adopted yesterday a resolution authorizing, the payment of a 100 per cent, stock dividend to shareholders, increasing the capital of the bank to $1,000,000. The United Automobile Workers, CIO, presented to the automotive industry last night a pyramid of four wage-increase demands for 1947, reaching a capstone figure of more than 30 cents an hour, or about $624,000,000 a year for 1,000,000 workers.

Rickenbacker, American air ace of the first World War, told the Executive Club today that it was time to close the door of immigration to Communist "agents of hate," who, he said, "leak into this country without the type of screening that ordinarily sifts good citizenship material from bad."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12--President Truman created by Executive Order today a new Office of Temporary Controls to preside over the liquidation of remaining wartime economic restraints and direct the country's return to the free enterprise system.
Most of yesterday's reviews on "Land's End," which arrived Wednesday night at the Playhouse as its fourth tenant of the season, weren't encouraging from the boxoffice viewpoint at all.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 12 (AP)--Big Wash, 4-year-old gelding that had launched his Florida campaign with an impressive victory on the second day of the meeting, scored another smashing conquest in today's Hidden Spring Purse, witnessed by a crowd of 8,274 that bet $521,009 on the eight races at Tropical Park.

ALBANY, Dec. 12--Organized taxpayers of the State gave their approval today to an announcement by Governor Dewey that the tax reduction authorized by the 1946 Legislature, with a resultant saving of $122,000,000 to taxpayers, will be continued in 1947.

The Keswick Corporation, a subsidiary of the Maryland Casualty Company of Baltimore, has sold the sixteen-story apartment house containing eighty suites at 51 West Eighty-sixth Street to Samuel Silk in a deal negotiated by Albert M. Greenfield Co., brokers.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 12 (AP)-- Cuba's national director of sports, Luis Orlando Rodriguez, said today that Baseball Commissioner A.B. (Happy) Chandler had jeopardized the good-neighbor policy by slamming the door against efforts to establish a four-nation baseball federation that would include Venezuela, Mexico and Cuba.

VIENNA, Dec. 12--Doubt is being expressed here that the Austrian Parliament can be forced to accept the 200 Allied amendments to the denazification law that will come before the Allied Council for final approval tomorrow. In general the amendments would remove all discretion from the Austrian Government.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP)-- Conflicting testimony came from rival radio companies today on whether color television is ready for the public.

LONDON, Dec. 12--Warning that civil strife that may lead "to an awful abridgment of the Indian population" was a hazard in Britain's efforts to settle the Indian problem, Winston Churchill, Opposition leader, today attacked the Government's negotiations on Indian independence.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12--An immediate Treasury Department investigation "into the startling allegations" contained in the Robert R. Nathan report to the Congress of Industrial Organizations that business could support a 25 per cent rise in payrolls was urged today by Senator Edwin O. Johnson, Democrat, of Colorado.

Three armed youths wearing Eisenhower jackets staged three hold-ups in widely separated sections of the Bronx within an hour last night, escaping with cash totaling $1,381. A victim of one robbery was shot in the right heel when a thug fired his pistol, apparently through nervousness.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12--The Army and Navy, with the approval of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, have agreed on a world-wide command set-up for the United States armed forces that provides unified command in the various theatres of operation from Germany and the Mediterranean to the Far East, it was learned today.

The all-United States team of amateur hockey players which is scheduled to sail tomorrow aboard the Queen Elizabeth for an elevenweek tour of Europe, assembled in New York yesterday. The team, composed of members of the Amateur Hockey Association of America ..

ATLANTA, Dec. 12--Emory Burke, president of the anti-Jewish, anti-Negro Columbians, Inc., obtained warrants today against Dr. James H. Sheldon, administrative chairman of the Non-Sectarian Anti-Nazi League, and two of the league's undercover agents.

The city Health Department is considering the feasibility of giving free physical examinations and laboratory tests to qualify New Yorkers for jobs, it was disclosed yesterday. This would be done wherever a prospective employer or licensing Government agency required proof of physical fitness.

The National Conference of Christians and Jews honored Irving Berlin, Spyros P. Skouras and Robert E. Sherwood yesterday for contributions they have made in the theatre world that have advanced the aim of the conference to eliminate religious and racial frictions.

The United Nations General Assembly called last night for the withdrawal of the chiefs of diplomatic missions from Madrid, denounced the Franco Government as Fascist and asked the Security Council to take up the case again if the Spanish dictatorship remains in power.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12--President Truman refused today to reveal his attitude toward John L. Lewis of the United Mine Workers and gave as the reason that no one should attempt to influence the courts on pending litigation.

BASLE, Switzerland, Dec. 12-- The first major uproar occurred in the Zionist congress tonight when the Revisionist delegates took offense at an alleged slight by a Labor party member. They kept up the commotion for twenty minutes until the chairman restored order.

HARTSDALE, N.Y., Dec. 12-- John F. Kraushaar, owner and formerly manager of the Charles W. Kraushaar Art Galleries, 32 East Fifty-seventh Street, New York, died today in his home, 130 Caterson Terrace, Hartsdale. His age was 75.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 12 (AP)-- It was tough going today for the favorites on a Fair Grounds track made heavy by early morning rain, and the outsiders took a majority of the races.
LONDON, Dec. 12--British doctors rejected today the Labor Government's plan for free medical service, part of Britain's all-inclusive scheme of "cradle-to-grave" social security.
PARIS, Dec. 12--Leon Blum, veteran Socialist leader who opposes a merger with the Communists, was called on by the National Assembly today to try to form a Government acceptable to it.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12--During the week ended Dec. 11, member bank reserve balances increased $257,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12--"We will have no peace in the world until we have economic security throughout the world," Secretary Lewis B. Schwellenbach told the Labor Department's new Joint Trade Union Advisory Committee on International Affairs today.

LONDON, Dec. 12 (AP)--The British Lawn Tennis Association opened the door today for professional athletes in other sports to participate in amateur tennis tournaments, such as its own Wimbledon championship.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 12 (AP)--The Venezuelan Government announced today the rounding up of the last rebels in yesterday's sunrise revolt, ending the third attempt on President Ramon Betancourt's 14-month-old revolutionary regime.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Dec. 12--Trains on the Harlem division of the New York Central and on the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroads were delayed as long as an hour during the commuter rush this evening by a fire in a small tool shed. The fire occurred beside the New York Central tracks near the main station here.
LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Dec. 12 --The fifty-four member nations were informed today of the estimated percentages of the 1946 and 1947 United Nations budgets that they would be expected to pay.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 12 (AP)--Federal District Judge George H. Moore today ordered a five-year plan of court-supervised operation for the St. Louis-San Francisco (Frisco) railway be put into effect on Jan. 1, ending its 14-year-old receivership.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12.--The Administration set to work today to revamp the Federal housing program. The new plan will supplant the veterans emergency housing program directed by Wilson W. Wyatt, former national housing expediter.

BERLIN, Dec. 12--A drastic 35 per cent slash in United States Military Government personnel has been ordered as part of a twofold policy of reducing expenditures and handing over more responsibility to the Germans, it was learned today. Thirteen per cent of this cut must be effectuated before Jan. 1.

Bells are a part of our countryside tradition. From white-spired churches in small villages bells toll the hours through the repeating seasons. From May to September cowbells send notes from upland pastures; farm dinner bells peal the news of high twelve to men in the fields.

MADRID, Spain, Dec. 12--In its first plenary session since midsummer, the Spanish Cortes (parliament) voted tonight a new coinage, to be stamped "Francisco Franco, by the grace of God Caudillo of Spain," as a further endorsement of the chief of the Govment.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12--President Truman today appointed nine of the country's most eminent scientists and engineers to advise the recently appointed Atomic Energy Commission on technical aspects of the new source of power.

Robert J. Smithdas, 21-year-old freshman at St. John's College, Brooklyn, cannot see the academic illustrations of his professors nor can he hear their discourses. Yet, despite this dual physical handicap, he was cited yesterday on the Dean's Honor List with a general ...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP)-- Twenty-four members of the new labor-management-government assembly for the Middle Atlantic States were named today by Edgar L. Warren, director of the United States Conciliation Service.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 12--Karl Meredith Anderson, formerly managing editor of The San Francisco Chronicle, died here last night at the Sanitorium of the Brothers of St. John of God after a long illness. His age was 63.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Dec. 12--The value of knowing the right people was demonstrated today by the New York Giants. Except for their widespread and intimate acquaintanceship they would have been forced to go through their workout for next Sunday's National Football League championship play-off with the Chicago Bears in the rain at the Polo Grounds.

SEATTLE, Dec. 12 (AP)--An air search of Upper Nisqually Glacier on 14,408-foot Mount Rainier was called for today in attempts to find a Marine Corps transport plane missing two days with thirtytwo men, but winter storms may delay such efforts for days.

British-American economic policy designed to restore Germany's, economy falls down badly by neglecting measures to open up trade between Germany and the Netherlands, it was charged yesterday by Dr. Eelco N. van Kleffens, ...
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12--Average primary market prices were unchanged for the week ended Dec. 7, as lower prices of agricultural commodities balanced increases in all other major commodity groups.

"The Bells of St. Mary's" was voted the best motion picture of 1946 in the annual poll conducted among the Young Reviewers of the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures, it was announced yesterday. Youth groups affiliated with the board, comprising school children from 8 to 18 years old all over the country, cast their ballots in the voting.
The United States should contribute food to needy European countries only on a "direct delivery" basis, Senator Kenneth S. Wherry of Nebraska declared here yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12--Grain prices were on the upgrade again on the Board of Trade today, paced by wheat. The latter was bought by cash interests, mills and commission houses and closed with gains of 1 1/8 to 2 cents a bushel. Corn rose 5/8 to 1 cents and oats were up to 1 cents. Barley futures closed unchanged.

Lumber industry leaders yesterday expressed "serious doubt" th payment of a subsidy of $16 thousand board feet to producers of bevel siding, now being considered by the National Housing Agency, will result in appreciably greater output.
A move to increase interest in the steeplechase phase of horse racing was launched yesterday with the organization of the National Hunts Race committee at the Waldorf Astoria yesterday.

The vast army of ski enthusiasts who had hoped to enjoy the sport early this season must defer their plans for another week at least. For reports from the Northeastern snowbelt yesterday were most discouraging. They told of rain, overcast skies and no snow.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12--The United States has been pressing for a dozen first-rate military and naval bases in the Philippine Republic for mutual defense and Manila has found these proposals unacceptable in some details as they stand, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12--The effort by Representative W. Sterling Cole of Bath, N.Y., a respected member of Congress, to undo that part of the Reorganization Act which merges the two armed services committees of the House will, of course, draw support from some quarters.

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Elizabeth, carrying a record post-war list of 2,294 passengers, among them diplomats. Government officials and war brides, docked at Pier 90, North River, at 1:30 P.M. yesterday after a stormy crossing from Southampton.
CHICAGO, Dec. 12 (AP)--Big Nine athletic directors today unanimously supported a ban by the National Federation of High School Associations against allstar and out-of-season prep athletic contests.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12 (AP)--A committee of the American Bankers Association called today for the elimination of Government controls over consumer credit in the interests of making available "goods which can now be purchased only by the top level incomes."
JERUSALEM, Dec. 12--An Arab general strike throughout Palestine has been called for Monday in protest against the Salame abduction by Haganah, the Arab Higher Committee announced tonight.

For the first time in nearly a decade, payment of Christmas bonuses to employes is under consideration by several commercial banks here, and some have already scheduled such payments, it was learned yesterday.

A banking syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., won yesterday the award of an issue of $10,000,000 of Chicago Sanitary District 2 per cent construction bonds due in 1966 and callable after 1949.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12--The United Mine Workers of America asked the Supreme Court today to broaden consideration of its appeal from contempt convictions so, as to decide on such major aspects of the controversy as the applicability of the Norris-La Guardia and the Clayton Acts and four amendments to the Constitution.

The New Jersey deer season is scheduled to get under way on Tuesday, and if the hunting pressure is comparable to that encountered during the upland game season in that State, the deer kill should establish a new record.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Dec. 12--At the gates to the toy factories this Christmas season German manufacturers in the United States zone have hung out "off limits" signs that apply equally to American soldiers and German would-be purchasers. Almost all their wares are earmarked for export.

The Bronx police announced last night that a 9-year-old boy had confessed to setting the five-alarm fire last Monday night that destroyed the south wing of Public School 2, Third Avenue between 169th and 170th Streets, the Bronx.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 12-- The American Farm Bureau Federation, winding up its annual convention here today, called for the immediate undertaking of studies looking to development of a permanent agricultural program corrective of "the basic causes of disparity between agriculture, labor and industry."

WARSAW, Poland, Dec. 12-- President Boleslaw Bierut and Marshal Michael Rola-Zymierski, War Minister and commander of the Polish armed forces, head the Democratic bloc's State list for the elections. Jan. 19, as announced today.

Directors of the Association of American Railroads at their annual meeting held here yesterday elected R.V. Fletcher as its president. A former vice president, he had served as acting president since the death on Nov. 12 of J.J. Pelley, president since 1934.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 12-- Paramount today signed Phyllis Calvert, British stage and screen actres, to make six pictures for the studio, the first to be the film adaptation of Yolanda Folders' new novel, "Make You a Fine Wife."
Seven players from the National Football League and four from the All-America Conference constitute The Associated Press 1946 All-Pro team, it was announced yesterday.

The Simba Dress Company, represented by Daniel Katz, attorney, has purchased the two-story building on a plot about 38 by 117 feet at 8402-4 Eighteenth Avenue, Brooklyn, through Slomka Brothers, brokers.

Commercial, industrial and agricultural loans by the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System during the week ended on Wednesday, rose $59,000,000 to a new high level of $3,778,000,000, it was announced yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
Ben Howe, former chairman of the City Fusion party, died yesterday in his home at 76-12 Thirtyfifth Avenue, Jackson Heights, Queens. His age was 78.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 12--Three prosecution witnesses tore into Ward Beecher Caraway's defense when the trial was resumed in County Court today after Judge Henry J.A. Collins had ruled against a mistrial on a technicality raised yesterday by defense counsel.

LONDON, Dec. 12--Lord Burghley, son and heir of the fifth Marquess of Exeter, married Mrs. Diana Mary Forbes, a widow, and the daughter of the Hon. Arnold Henderson, this afternoon in the St. Marylebone registry office, London. Only a few friends were at the ceremony.

A brilliant gathering of New York's fashion-wise public thronged the halls of the Costume Institute of the Metropolitan Museum of Art last night for a preview of the opening of the Institute, on the ground floor of the north wing of the museum. The collections will be open to the public today.

Mme. Nikolai V. Novikov, wife of the Soviet Ambassador to this country, told 600 American women yesterday that the women of her country hope for a "deepening" of international understanding in the years to come.
Howard S.Gans, a retired lawyer, died yesterday in his seventy-fifth year at his suite in the Ritz Tower Hotel. He had been an invalid since he suffered a heart attack two years ago.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 12 --Premier Constantin Tsaldaris of Greece appeared before the United Nations Security Council today to warn that the "state of undeclared war" in the Balkans was reaching its most acute phase.

The H.J. Heinz Company of Pittsburgh has sold its warehouse at 23-23 Borden Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, to S. Posner Sons, paper distributors, who are now in the Bohack Terminal in Maspeth. The C. Grant Keck Organization was the broker in the transaction.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP)-- Calvin K. Snyder of the National Association of Real Estate Boards said today that tenants would accept rent increases up to 15 per cent if they received a year's lease. He told the complaint subcommittee of the Senate Small Business Committee that his organization had put the question to its member boards in 157 cities in thirty-six States.

In a joint statement issued yesterday by the presidents of the Illinois Power Company, the North American Light and Power Company and the North American Company, parent of the first two companies, it was disclosed that all claims of Illinois Power against the two others and all the counterclaims asserted against Illinois Power had been settled.
TOKYO, Dec. 12--Supreme Allied Headquarters has moved to prevent "non commercial" and propaganda publications and other information media from reaching the Japanese, it was learned today.

Scenes reminiscent of London, Coventry and other war-bombed cities of Europe were enacted on a very small scale early yesterday, when the weakened roof beams of an abandoned ice-house gave way, catapulting one wall into an adjoining six-story tenement house.

The Big Four Council of Foreign Ministers completed drafts of the minor European peace settlements yesterday and formally ended its New York session. The Council will next meet in Moscow on March l0 to formulate peace terms with Germany and Austria.

George Szell, now the conductor of the Cleveland Symphony Orchestra, appeared as guest leader of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall, with Claudio Arrau as soloist, in an all-Beethoven program.

The Maritime Commission yesterday offered for sale a large number of LSM's (Landing Ship, Medium) and LCI's (Landing Craft, Infantry). The former are pricefixed at $40,000 each while the latter are listed at $10,000 each. Both groups have been declared surplus and assigned to the commission for disposal.
MIAMI, Fla.., Dec. 12 (AP)--The Miami Seahawks and Brooklyn Dodgers wind up the All-America conference pro football season here tomorrow night in the Orange Bowl Stadium.

PARIS, Dec. 13--Premier Leon Blum said tonight after a long day of consultations with all parties that the time was near for a decision regarding the new Government. It is hoped the Cabinet will be formed by Sunday and presented to the Assembly next week.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 15--The Yugoslav Government made it clear tonight that it would press territorial claims against Austria. It said it "intends to secure the freedom of Carinthia within the framework of the Federated People's Republics of Yugoslavia and help Austria along the road to true democracy."

BERLIN, Dec. 15--The youth discussion groups sponsored by the American Military Government to foster a democratic spirit in Germany still have a long, hard road to travel before young Germans even comprehend the meaning of freedom or democracy, otherwise than as theoretical concepts, to judge from a typical meeting I attended yesterday.
FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Dec. 15--Plans for Christmas parties for some 500,000 German children are already afoot and American troops have assumed the Santa Claus role in a bid way.

Lorih W. Stunbaugh, 44 years old, impeccably garbed and an admirer of expensive Oriental rugs, was held without bail in Felony Court yesterday for grand jury action. Saturday night, the court was told, he was caught in the Metropolitan Museum of Art with a seventeenth century Turkish prayer rug hidden under his coat.
Many Christmas parties will be given this week for orphans, crippled children and hospitalized service men and veterans, together with choral programs for shut-ins and the public.

Good Neighbor Building, Inc., sold the vacant plot at the northeast corner of the Avenue of the Americas and Fifty-second Street in the Radio City area to Grove Properties, Inc., controlled by Robert and Edward H. Benenson ...

WICHITA, Kan., Dec. 15 (AP)-- Police were investigating today a report of the abduction of four stereotypers at The Wichita Eagle after an augmented picket line of striking members of the American Newspaper Guild, CIO, last night delayed publication of the newspaper's Sunday editions for twelve hours.

DUBLIN, Dec. 15--Ireland these days is like a green oasis in a troubled world, but one whose fertility is literally drying up. The Irish ship of state--to change the metaphor--is sailing politically through calm waters, but several storm signals are out because economically the situation is potentially very serious.
In its third try to get full bids on 18-ounce serge for the coming year's needs the Army still is shy about 4,000,000 yards of the 10,700,000 yards sought, it was learned last night.

MELBOURNE, Dec. 15 (AP)-- American Davis Cuppers put in a hard three-hour practice before a large crowd at the Kooyong courts today with the workout featured by Frank Parker's split with Jack Kramer in a two-set match.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 15--There no longer is the slightest doubt that the absence of ex-President Lazaro Cardenas from the inauguration of President Miguel Aleman has caused more discussion than any other aspect of the occasion.

STUNNED, disbelieving and rocked emotionally to their very depths, the New York Giants took to the field against the Chicago Bears at the Polo Grounds yesterday with the battle for the championship almost an anticlimax. The revelation of the attempted bribery with a gambling coup as its objective knocked the ...

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 15-Steel output throughout the country last week advanced 10 points, to 71 per cent of rated capacity, as steel mills put units back into operation at a rapid rate. Indications are that production this week will take another jump and that within ten days or so it will approach the pre-coal-strike level of 91 per cent.

We commemorate this week the 155th anniversary of the American Bill of Rights--that assertion of freedoms hastily added to our original Federal Constitution in order to placate the great number of Americans who feared the excesses of even a republican form of government.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 (AP)--Better distribution of meat supplies next year will give urban consumers more meat, John Holmes, president of Swift Co., one of the nation's largest meat packing companies, predicted today in his annual report to stockholders.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15--Some important Middle Western business leaders would be willing to settle the current wage demands with increases of 7 to 10 per cent, if that would prevent a second round of major strikes, it has been learned on informed and responsible authority.

Details of what promised to develop into the first major "scandal" to touch professional football were disclosed yesterday with the arrest of a "fixer" who admittedly attempted to bribe two of the leading players of the New York Football Giants to "throw" the playoff championship game with the Chicago Bears.

Miss Joan Winifred Sher, daughter of Dr. Maurice Arthur Sher and Dr. Frances Kardons Sher of Brooklyn, was married to Dr. Norman Balfour Kanof, son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Kanof of Arlington, Va., last night in the Roof of the Pierre by Rev. Dr. Louis I. Newman.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 15 (U.P.)-- Police were put on the alert throughout Palestine today as the Arabs staged a two-hour general strike in protest against a Jewish underground raid last Wednesday on the Arab village of Salame and the kidnapping of the chieftain's son and cousin.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Dec. 15-- Casualties ranging from disabled boats and one capsizing to a crew falling overboard marked the eighth and final fall series regatta of the winter sailing program at Larchmont Yacht Club today. Twenty-three of the interclub dinghies, second largest turnout of the season, showed up for the seven races.

The answer to organized racial hatred and intolerance lies in educational programs, Christian Westphalen, director of the Greater New York Area of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, declared yesterday.

ALBANY, Dec. 15--The American Veterans Committee adopted today a resolution condemning the action of President Truman in lifting most of the curbs which the group said had been designed to assure adequate housing for veterans.

The General Assembly of the United Nations drove through to the conclusion of its plenary session early this morning and adjourned. The closing address mas made by its president, PaulHenri Suaak. [1:8.]

Freddie Metcalfe's New York Rovers went "gunning" yesterday and brought down the Baltimore Clippers, 3 to 2, in the Eastern Hockey League clash that featured the amateur twin-showing at Madison Square Garden.

Church and State gave farewell tribute yesterday in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine to the Right Rev. William Thomas Manning, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of New York, sixteen days before his retirement at the year's end.
