Not only was there a $974.10 daily double pay-off, largest of the local season, but nary a favorite had won when T.D. Buhl's Crack Reward could only run third for the talent in the sixth and featured event, which was captured by H. H. Hecht's Sophocles.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19--Peace between labor and management in the meat packing industry throughout the country became a virtual certainty today as Armour Co. became the third of the big four packers to sign a new contract with the United Packinghouse Workers of America, CIO.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19--The united front of the nation's softcoal operators was shattered tonight when the Northern Appalachian group, representing 60 per cent of the nation's tonnage, offered to negotiate an agreement with the United Mine Workers at once.
CHICAGO, Dec. 19 (AP)--Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 19 (AP)--The Davis Cup matches between the United States and Australia, starting a week from today, have been marred by a controversy arising over the Americans' privilege of playing in whatever tournaments and exhibitions they please in this country once the international series is decided.

The hour came yesterday for Columbia's famous sun dial. For thirty-two years the seven foot granite sphere was a dominating feature of the Columbia campus, situated midway between old South Hall, now the Butler Library, and the Low Memorial Library. Yesterday, reluctantly, university of- ...

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 19 --A sharp difference of opinion developed tonight between the Canadian and United States delegations to the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission over the demand by Bernard M. Baruch for immediate acceptance of the basic principles of the United States plan for internationl atomic control.

The Park Department has erected in parks throughout the five boroughs twenty-one Christmas trees that will be lighted daily at 4:30 o'clock. Christmas parties with carol singing and special games will be given in Manhattan at the Roosevelt Playground to- ...

American companies with subsidiaries or interests in Brazil should assist in the development of trade and technical schools there to dispel the idea that Americans are in Brazil solely to exploit the country's resources, Father Roberto Saboia Madeiros, founder and director of the School of Industrial Engineering in Sao Paulo, stated yesterday.

Embarking on the last phase of a fact-finding survey, the American Academy of Pediatrics announced yesterday that temporary shelters and institutions giving long-term care to children will be studied by academy members in every State.

NEWARK, N. J., Dec. 19--The hold-up murder of Mortimer Bateman, 46-year-old delivery truck driver last Tuesday, was solved today, Police Chief Philip Sebold announced. Two men were arrested and made confessions, he said. One of the prisoners was a co-worker of the victim at the Wigler Baking Company.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19--The opponents of consolidation of Congressional committees made new and defiant challenges today as both sides marshaled for a struggle of great importance to the future of proposed unification of the Army and Navy.

Normal service was restored yesterday at 152 Safeway stores in the metropolitan district after 1,000 striking clerks and butchers had voted unanimously to ratify an agreement providing wage increases of $10 to $16 a week.
BERLIN, Dec. 19--The four occupying powers are cooperating to make Berlin's Christmas relatively comfortable, if not merry, Col. Frank L. Howley, deputy United States commandant here, said today.

MUNICH, Germany, Dec. 19-- Dr. Karl Scharnagl, Oberbuergermeister of Munich, appealed to citizens of Munich today to refrain from demonstrations against the "wave of requisitions of homes which is getting into full swing a whose extent exceeds our fears." In a statement published ...

Mayor O'Dwyer indicated yesterday that he was ready to support Frank J. Sampson for leader of Tammany to succeed Edward V. Loughlin by inviting Mr. Sampson to attend a private pre-Christmas party for political leaders,

The United States Treasury's large debt retirement operation at the beginning of the week was reflected in dominant fashion in the statement of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System for the week ended on Wednesday, and released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

CHICAGO, Dec.19--Heavy hedging sales against large purchases of cash corn for deferred shipment from the country resulted today in a moderate decline in futures on the Board of Trade, closing trades there being 3/8 to 3/4 cent a bushel lower than yesterday.
TOKYO, Dec. 19--Soviet Russia has agreed to repatriate 50,000 Japanese a month from the areas it controls.
The year was a surprising one to sports fans and experts alike and the experts had a terrific time deciding which was the most surprising event of 1946.

OMAHA, Dec. 19 (AP)--The Union Pacific Railroad announced today that it has ordered 64 Diesel-electric passenger, freight and switching locomotives at a cost of $22,000,000--the largest Diesel order in railroad history.

While yesterday's reports were better than those of a week ago, conditions for skiing are generally poor. There are forecasts of snow tomorrow and Sunday. If the expected fall is of any consequence record throngs will descend upon the skilands for the Christmas holidays.

The Delphine Realty Company bought the six-story eighty-threefamily house at 3235 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, from the 3235 Concourse Realty Corporation. The property, assessed at $385,000, was sold subject to a first mortgage of $364,233 and a second ...

A program to help the young people of Harlem by providing better social services for their parents and grandparents was announced yesterday by the Salvation Army, which will convert its Servicemen's Club of 224 West 124th Street into a community center.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19--During the week ended Dec. 18, member bank reserve balances increased $38,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.
LONDON, Dec. 19--Prof. Johan J. Smertenko of New York, vice president of the American League for a Free Palestine, was barred from Britain today.
The Metropolitan Golf Association re-elected Percival E. Furber of the Wee Burn Country Club as president for the second time at its annual meeting yesterday at the Hotel Commodore.

LONDON, Dec. 19--The text of the new agricultural bill conferring wide powers on the Government over farm land and farmers, guaranteeing in return stable prices, fair wages and decent living conditions, was published today.

LONDON, Dec. 19--The new Noel Coward operetta, "Pacific 1860," opened at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane, tonight. The double occasion of a Coward premiere plus the re-opening of London's oldest theatre after its war service as ENSA headquarters, brought out a glittering and enthusiastic audience.

SUCHOW, China, Dec. 19--The grand canal and wheat fields of North Kiangsu Province, now in Central Government hands after one year under full Communist control, constitute a unique laboratory for comparing the respective approaches of the Reds and the Kuomintang to the omnipresent land problem that provides the economic content of the current civil war.

Two days after Christmas, a motherly woman with pretty, brown eyes--who can be seen almost any day experimenting with color film in Central Park--will take off by plane for the heart of the Belgian Congo.

An informal canvass of members of the Board of Estimate and other key city officials failed yesterday to uncover any enthusiasm for the Port of New York Authority's $191,000,000 plan for financing, completing and rehabilitating Idlewild Airport and La Guardia Field.
MOSCOW, Dec. 18--The new treaty between the United States and China was denounced here today as one that returns China to a "semi-colonial condition" and economic dependence upon the United States.

A Christmas bonus of more than $500,000 is being distributed to house employes of William R. Warner Co. and Richard Hudnut, it was announced yesterday by Elmer H. Bohst, president. Employes with at least five years of service will receive a month's salary, and those with less service, from one to three weeks' pay.

A new Maryknoll Junior Seminary for candidates from the Atlantic seaboard outside New England will be opened in September of next year at Lakewood, N.J., it was announced yesterday. It is the result of the purchase by the Catholic Missionary Society of the Newman School there, with all its buildings, equipment and grounds covering 173 acres.

Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday the appointment of a special committee, headed by Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander, to submit recommendations for methods of easing the flow of all types of traffic in the five boroughs.
The road home will be heavily traveled again this year by New Yorkers seeking to spend the Christmas holidays out of the city with families, relatives and friends.

Recommendations of domestic machine tool manufacturers have been disregarded by the War Assets Administration for adoption of a new policy on surplus sales abroad, Tell Berna, general manager, National Machine Tool Builders Association, disclosed yesterday.
A maritime dispute involving questions of manning was in the making last night as seamen on at least two American ships refused to sign on and heavy cargoes including relief shipments were delayed.

New York State's "life" raft rent control law will be extended for at least one more year without major changes, it was announced yesterday by Assemblyman D. Mallory Stephens after a meeting here of the joint legislative committee on rent control, of which he is chairman.

The Boston Red Sox, who finished first in the American League standings, quite appropriately were the top fielders in their loop, as revealed by the averages just released. Their mark was .977, which, coupled with the percentages compiled by the seven other clubs, was sufficient for the league to equal its own defensive play record mark, .973.

Mayor O'Dwyer made his Christmas party debut yesterday at a celebration given by the American Women's Voluntary Services to 375 youngsters from Public School 405 of the Children's Center at 1 East 104th Street.

Henry A. Wallace, new editor of The New Republic, disclaimed personal responsibility yesterday for a recent item concerning Bernard M. Baruch's purported role in the coal strike. At the same time, he gave his implied support to the magazine's reporter responsible for the story.

LONDON, Dec. 19--Indignation about the continued existence of 1,000,000 displaced persons in Europe and about the treatment of Poles in the British zone of Germany was expressed in the House of Lords today.

We in New York have much reason to be grateful for William Thomas Manning. He has not failed in his long service here to take a position on large issues, nor feared to make that position known even when it meant embroilment in controversy. He made no small plans.

The days before Christmas may mean a slowing down of business in the entertainment world, but you could not prove it by the turnout for the season's first performance of Puccini's "La Boheme" at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. The theatre was packed as solidly as if it were an opening night. Obviously there has been no decline in the appeal of "La Boheme."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19--The Veterans Administration moved today to eliminate "obliging" appraisers of veterans' housing who have been putting, for purposes of GI loans, inflated values on property being purchased by former service men.

Maintaining its unbeaten status, the City College basketball team outsped Bowling Green of Ohio and recorded a 52-45 victory, its seventh in a row, before 17,126 fans at Madison Square Garden last night. The visiting Falcons, finding it difficult to break through ...

Governor Dewey solicited yesterday the interest and support of all New Yorkers in the campaign of the New York Heart Association to raise $500,000 early next year for the fight against heart disease, "the greatest single killer of mankind today."

CLEVELAND, Dec. 19--Definite usefulness for streptomycin, latest of the so-called "miracle drugs," is in the treatment of tuberculosis, it was stated today by Dr. Horton C. Hinshaw of the Mayo Clinic, at Rochester, Minn.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19--A recommendation by the House Campaign Investigating Committee that the new Republican-controlled Congress continue and complete its inquiry into the re-election of Representative Vito Marcantonio in New York's Eighteenth District was indicated today.
LONDON, Dec. 19--British Foreign Secretary Bevin, exuding optimism and Christmas cheer and talking of peace on earth, arrived in Southampton this evening on the Queen Elizabeth.

It has been estimated that the recent increase of 17 per cent in general freight rates granted by the Interstate Commerce Commission will mean an addition of about a billion dollars a year in revenues for the railways on the basis of current traffic volume.

Investigation and study of ancient refuse heaps in the Viru Valley of Peru have brought to light eight separate civilizations in, the area, the first dating back almost 2,000 years, Roland Collier, Chicago Natural History Museum archaeologist, said yesterday.

The Elnor Realty Corporation has purchased the property at 91 Main Street, White Plains, N.Y., containing four stores and six apartments, together with an adjoining lot facing Hamilton Avenue, from the Rezlab Realty Corporation. The property is assessed at $100,000. Ellis Ellis were the brokers.

Dr. John R. Mott, president of the World Alliance of Young Men's Christian Associations, who recently was named co-winner of the 1946 Nobel Peace Prize, received messages of greeting from seven chiefs of state at a testimonial dinner last night at the Hotel Roosevelt.

ONE of the longest, most scholarly and ambitious of this season's biographies is Carola Oman's 748-page "Nelson."* An intelligent and scrupulously exact book it is, too, a precise and meticulous account of everything worth knowing about England's greatest naval hero, who in so many respects was heroic in an extremely un-English fashion.

Lew Fonseca, who these dozen years has been grinding out baseball motion pictures in order that the game's millions of addicts may relieve its great moments, has added another masterpiece to his memorable collection with his latest production, "The World Series of 1946."

FOR a good many years the experts have been saying that Sugar Ray Robinson is the best fighter, pound for pound, in the beak-busting business. For years they have been hailing him as the "uncrowned champion." But before the clock strikes midnight in the old church tower tonight, Sugar Ray should have left his past behind him and be acknowledged as the welterweight champion of the world.

PARIS, Dec. 19--The Government announced today its decision to send increased food supplies into the Saar to help maintain vital coal production there. At the same time it said special precautions were to be taken to prevent this food from filtering into the rest of the French zone.

Calling for a reversal of the American Federation of Teachers' no-strike policy, the New York Teachers Guild went on record yesterday as favoring the strike technique as a last resort to obtain salary increases.

Fred Winkleman, 70-year-old pensioner, was shot and killed last night in his third-floor apartment at 1708 First Avenue, in the East Harlem section, by a young many who surrendered to police a few minutes after the shooting.

Graduate nurses on the staff of New York Hospital, Sixty-eighth Street and the East River, will keep abreast of new nursing techniques next year through a plan for in-service training to begin Feb. 1. Virginia M. Dunbar, dean of the Cornell University-New York Hospital School of Nursing and direc- ...

ABERDEEN, Md., Dec. 19-- Eighty-four persons had an unprecedented brush with swift death tonight when two Miami-bound airliners collided above here in midair, but the pilots landed both ships safely and no one, incredibly, was even noticeably scratched.

The International Ladies Garment Workers Union, AFL, which is seeking employer-financed pension plans for all its 350,000 members, decided yesterday to set an example for industry by establishing a retirement fund for its own paid officers.

ATHENS, Ga., Dec. 19--Ending a three-week investigation, during which about 100 witnesses were questioned, a Federal grand jury today reported inability "to establish the identity of any persons guilty of violating the civil rights statute" in the shotgun lynching of four Negroes near Monroe, Ga., in Walton County, last July 25.

TORONTO, Dec. 19 (AP)--The Toronto Maple Leafs increased their National Hockey League lead to three points over the idle Montreal Canadiens tonight by defeating the Detroit Red Wings, 3--1.
CHICAGO, Dec. 19--Thirty-five years ago the Sisters of Mercy in Chicago treated a penniless stranger kindly and nursed him back to health. Today they computed this kindness had brought them $620,000.

A woman walked into the Times Tower yesterday as she has done in years past during the holiday season. She headed for the counter and gave the clerk a small envelope, two by two and a half inches in size. "This is for the Hundred Neediest Cases," she said quietly, and walked out.
LONDON, Dec. 19 (AP)--Seventytwo American school teachers, spending a year in Britain under an exchange plan, were received by Queen Elizabeth today. They were presented by Lady Astor.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19--James A. Oscar Waters, 58-year-old Harlem politician, was convicted last night on two of four counts of grand larceny by a General Sessions Court jury, which returned its verdict to Judge John A. Mullen at 10 o'clock, after four and a half hours of deliberation. Waters was remanded to jail for sentence Jan. 14.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 19--A study of 9,000 automobile accidents on 4,000 miles of highways in ten States indicates that "controlled access" express highways are essential to safety, David Baldwin of the National Safety Council reported today.

The Board of Estimate appropriated yesterday $12,733,600 for rehabilitation work on the city subway system. At the same time it approved the contracts recently awarded by the Board of Transportation under which the work will be done.

The Borinquen, after a gallant Army career that started just three and a half weeks after Pearl Eiarbor, is now undergoing reconversion, preparatory to resuming her peacetime New York-Puerto Rico run, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19--The United States in the projected negotiations next spring with eighteen countries for reduction of tariff and other trade barriers will seek the elimination of tariff preferences that we have long given Cuba, the State Department announced today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19--The National Labor Relations Board ruled today against the J.I. Case Company, Racine, Wis., in a dispute which provoked the longest, large strike still in effect in this country. The walkout began the day after Christmas, 1945.

ROME, Dec. 19--Vatican preoccupation over the future of the Catholic Church in Italy was considerably allayed today after a subcommittee of the Constituent Assembly approved an article reaffirming the validity of the Lateran Treaty of 1929 as the basis for relations between the Vatican and the Italian State.

In reply to James A. Farley's call for a reorganization of the Democratic party in State and nation as a prerequisite to a Democratic victory in the Presidential election of 1948, Edward J. Flynn, Democratic National Committeeman and Bronx leader, declared yesterday that Mr. Farley was politically dead and asked why the party should resurrect him.

The annual report of the Liquid Carbonic Corporation, to be issued to stockholders today, shows for the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30 a net profit of $1,256,926 after taxes and all charges, equal to $1.38 each on 728,100 shares of common stock outstanding. This compares with $1,522,585 or $1.91 a share on same basis for previous fiscal year.
SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 19 (AP) --Australia defeated England in an international cricket match for the second time in recent weeks today, winning by an innings and 33 runs.

NANKING, China, Dec. 19 (AP)-- President Truman's reaffirmation of American policy toward China evoked pleasure in Government circles tonight, but a Communist spokesman said the United States should cease "confining itself to lip service to peace."

PARIS, Dec. 19--Prof. Paul Langevin, one of the foremost French physicists, died early this morning at the age of 74. Until his illness a few days ago, he had been active as a teacher, researcher and adviser to the French Bureau of Atomic Energy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19--The National Federation of Telephone Workers asserted today that it would serve on the telephone industry next month demands for a wage increase of $12 a week and nine other contractual improvements. Word was received here yesterday that the Rev. Dr. George Whitefield Mead, a Presbyterian minister for fifty-two years, died at his home in Asheville, N. C., on Wednesday, at the age of 79.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan yesterday sought to bring to trial today Alvin J. Paris in the alleged attempt to bribe two stars of the New York Football Giants to "fix" the championship play-off game with the Chicago Bears. The game was won by the Chicago team at the Polo Grounds last Sunday.

In the reorganization of The New Republic that culminated in the appointment of Henry A. Wallace, former Secretary of Commerce, as editor of the liberal weekly, there was a shake-up among the higher editors, it became known yesterday.

Christmas dinner may still seem remote, but in the food markets of the city prices have already been set for the holidays and stocks laid in for those who do their grocery-buying early. WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP)--A record 1947 wheat crop that would create a surplus where an acute shortage existed a year earlier was indicated by an Agricultural Department report today on farmers' winter wheat-planting operations.

Although the international fishing contest is not novel, British and American tuna teams having competed in Nova Scotia prior to the war, the British challenge to American fly fishermen for a competition next May is one we shall find it rather difficult to ignore.

A joint meeting of the lawyers' advisory committee of the United States Trade-Mark Association and the trade-mark committee of the New York Patent Law Association, to consider proposed amendments to the Lanham Trade-Mark Act, failed to reach agreement yesterday.

The marriage of Miss Constance Steuer Epstein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Epstein of Carlton House, this city, and Lake Placid, N. Y., to Arthur Naitove, son of Mr. and Mrs. Moses Naitove of New York and Hewlett Bay Park, L. I., took place last night in the Crystal Garden of the Ritz-Carlton. There was a festive air yesterday afternoon on the fifth floor at Lord Taylor's where the annual Young New Yorker Christmas party took place.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19--President Truman today named a ninemember commission to investigate and submit recommendations on a system of universal military training. Representative of educators, the clergy, industrial management and the legal profession, the group has been called to meet with the Chief Executive tomorrow morning at the White House for its first session.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19--A charge that Senator Theodore G. Bilbo, Democrat, of Mississippi took a 66-year-old drug addict's life savings in return for securing for him an ordinary narcotics permit, at no expense, unexpectedly prolonged today the series of hearings on his case before the War Investigating Subcommittee. It had been expected they would close today.

The Rev. Thomas Yeoman Williams, Congregational minister and specialist in labor relations, died yesterday in the Queens General Hospital, Jamaica. He would have been 62 years old today.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Dec. 20 (AP) --Police Chief Fred G. Brown, who headed this community's police force for thirty-one years and was a former president of the New York State Association of Police Chiefs, died here today in St. Luke's Hospital after a long illness.
Rising to an all-time record for dollar volume of sales, Christmas trade here is showing a gain of about 25 per cent over last year.
Lumber production last week way 30.6 per cent above a year ago. Shipments were up 26.1 per cent and orders 41.2 per cent, according to reports received yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

ATHENS, Dec. 20--An informed source said today that Allied military authorities had received confidential reports that large numbers of Yugoslav troops were massed at Bitolj [Monastir] and Skoplje along the Vardar River route to northern Greece.
Thousands of French children who almost forgot that there was such a thing as Christmas in the war years will he happier next Wednesday because of gifts sent by American Aid to France, Inc.

Carl J. Hambro, president of the Norwegian Parliament and a former president of the League of Nations, declared yesterday that the old League could have accomplished more as a mediator of world problems than the United Nations organization.

Phoenix, Ariz., announced yesterday that it would receive bids on Jan. 15 for an issue of $9,600,000 of water revenue, airport and sewer bonds dated Jan. 1, 1947, and due Jan. 1 from 1948 to 1977. Interest must not exceed 3 per cent.

Stanley Chapple, conductor of the St. Louis Philharmonic and Grand Opera Company, departed from La Guardia Field yesterday on a British Overseas Airways plane for London, where he will conduct the British Broadcasting Company ...

WARSAW, Poland, Dec. 20-- Stanislaw Mikolajczyk's Peasant party has been prevented by terror, ruses and chicanery from filing its lists of candidates in about one-third of Poland's fifty-two electoral districts, the party's headquarters reported today as the deadline for filing was reached.

By a vote of three to two the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court yesterday enjoined the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York from dispossessing seventy tenants of the nine-story Ziegler building, 512 Fifth Avenue at Forty-third Street.

ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 20--Cornell, runner-up the last two seasons in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League, started its 1946-47 campaign by overwhelming Yale, 64--41, here tonight.

The two Southern storms which were bringing precipitation to the North Country last night were mild compared to the storms of cheer and gaiety that emanated from Northeastern ski circles. While the combined effects of the snowfalls are not to be felt generally ...

SHEBOYGAN, Wis., Dec. 20 (U.P.) --Senator-elect Clifford W. Krueger may have some trouble getting seated when the State Legislature convenes Jan. 8. He was notified ...

The City Council approved yesterday without change the capital budget of $236,662,602, as adopted on Dec. 4 by the Board of Estimate. The budget now goes to Mayor O'Dwyer for certification and becomes effective on Jan. 1.

MOSCOW, Dec. 20--Work on the reconstruction of the Dnieper Dam is entering the decisive phase with 1,200 collective farmers from the Zaporozhe oblast [district] helping complete the largest single piece of reconstruction in the Soviet Union.

NANKING, Dec. 20 (AP)--The United States and China today signed a commercial air transport agreement giving the United States pickup and discharge rights at Shanghai, Tientsin and Canton and China similar rights at Honolulu, San Francisco and New York. It conforms with the 1944 Chicago civil aviation code.

DETROIT, Dec. 20 (U.P.)--The Ford and Hudson motor car companies announced today week-long holiday shutdowns, affecting 102,000 workers across the country, because of critical metal shortages. Both will lose four days of production.
Judge Franklin Taylor reserved decision in Brooklyn County Court yesterday on a motion by Assistant District Attorney Solomon A. ...

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Elizabeth Helen Davidson, daughter of Mrs. Archibald Robert Davidson of Dongan Hills, S.I., and the late Mr. Davidson, to Terence Riley Thompson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gustave Riley Thompson of Grasmere, S.I.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 20 --Mrs. Josephine Sykes Morgenthau, widow of Henry S. Morgenthau Sr., financier and Ambassador to Turkey, was held today by Supreme Court Justice Frederick G. Schmidt to be mentally incompetent to handle her own affairs.
District Attorney Frank Hogan succeeded yesterday in keeping in the City Prison five of the six alleged narcotic peddlers arrested in East Harlem last Tuesday.

WOODRIDGE, N.J., Dec. 20-- The Wright Aeronautical Corporation distributed 41,800 checks today to present and former employes representing the final adjustment on the company's wartime production bonus.

Oliver M. Sayler, business agent of the Association of Theatrical Agents and Managers, was reported yesterday to be in a fair condition at the Murray Hill Hospital, Mr. Sayler, who is 58 years old, was stricken earlier this week with pneumonia, and taken to the hospital on Thursday.

Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Deering of Saco and Biddeford Pool, Me., have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Susan Dabney, to James Jourdan Ford, son of Mr. and Mrs. Summer Ford of 133 East Eightieth Street and Norfolk, Conn.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP)-- A portrait of Owen J. Roberts, former Supreme Court Justice, was presented to the court today by Edward L. Stokes of Philadelphia.

The parents have had their vacation while paid teachers wrestled with their problems. Now these same problems come home to be with father and mother in what is for them the most pleasant week of the year, even if it cannot quite accurately be called a vacation. WASHINGTON, Dec. 20--Governor Dewey was accused today by Representative Thomas A. Jenkins of Ohio of attempting to gain domination over Congress by endorsing Representative Charles A. Halleck of Indiana for House majority leader.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP)-- Albert M. Day, director of the Fish and Wild Life Service, said today that never before has there been so many hunters to shoot at so few ducks.

MUNICH, Germany, Dec. 20 (AP) --Gen. Joseph T. McNarney, United States commander in Europe, was reported today to have ordered a sharp reassessment of the ejection of Germans from their homes to make room for the dependents of American service men.

Ray Robinson, the great little Negro fighter, who has been the "uncrowned" champion for the past several years, last night fought his way to the world welterweight title recently vacated by Marty Servo.
The Rev. John Francis Saunders, pastor of St. Cecelia's Roman Catholic Church, Brooklyn, died on Thursday in the rectory of the church, 84 Herbert Street. His age was 58.
Pre-Christmas travel in and out of New York was developing late yesterday to the proportions of the usual holiday rush, spokesmen for the railroads and bus lines reported.

Now that trays are being made of materials varying from transparent plastic to a heavy gauge of magnesium developed during the war, several new designs are available for use at holiday entertainments.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 20--The weather again was the main topic, of conversation here today as the New York Yankees and Cleveland Browns went through their next to last workouts before Sunday's play-off game for the All-America Football Conference championship to be staged in the spacious Cleveland Stadium on the lake front.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20--President Truman compared today the unfitness for military service of nearly a third of the nation's youth with conditions leading to the decline and fall of the Greek and Roman empires and called it "a terrible reflection on a free country."

The District Attorney's office was charged yesterday by defense counsel in General Sessions Court with attempting to "railroad" Alvin J. Paris, 28-year-old Broadway playboy accused of attempting to bribe two members of the New ...

TOKYO, Saturday, Dec. 21--A death-dealing earthquake, followed by a seven-foot tidal wave, struck southern Japan early today and first United States Army reports indicated that at least 1,000 Japanese had perished.
FREEPORT, L.I., Dec. 20-- Gerald Anthony Combs, 4 years old, was drowned this afternoon in a canal while at play behind his home at 174 Garfield Place.

The Grace Line's Santa Clara, eighth of nine new combination passenger-cargo vessels, will leave today on her maiden voyage to the Caribbean. The ship sails from Pier 58, North River, at 5 P.M., with a capacity list of passengers and a full load of cargo.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Dec. 20--Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Kenyon Bronson Conger Jr. of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Anne Ganter, to Lieut. Dwight Comber Burnham, USA, son of Dr. and Mrs. Silver C. Burnham of Macomb, Ill.
NANKING, Dec. 20--The Truman statement on China drew few approving comments from Government officials and newspapers today but continued to stir critical reactions in Communist quarters.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20--Conversations looking to a renewal of normal commercial relations between Italy and the United States will be held here early next month during an official visit of Premier Alcide de Gasperie.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20--An improved means for detecting and measuring the thickness of ice formation on aircraft has been developed by William A. Malthaner of Summit, N.J., whose invention was one of 394 for which patents were issued this week by the United States Patent Office.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art's medieval branch in Fort Tryon Park, the Cloisters, specially decorated for the holidays, will present recorded programs of medieval music daily from Dec. 24 through Jan. 5 with the exception of Monday. Some of the recordings on Christmas Day will be broadcast at 1 P.M. over WNBC.

Manhattan's talented young basketball team, held in check during the first half by Brooklyn College's hustling courtmen, cut loose with a withering second-half drive to outscore the Kingsmen, 67 to 55, at the Brooklyn College gymnasium last night before a full house.
AMSTERDAM, Dec. 20--The second chamber of the Netherland Parliament today approved the Cheribon agreement between the Dutch Commission General and representatives of the Indonesian Republic.

The Rutgers wrestling team beat New York University, 25--3, in the Education Gymnasium yesterday. The visitors won five of the six events. N.Y.U. forfeited two bouts and won only in the 128pound class, in which William Raschbaum beat Robert Fisher through a decision.
The New Republic, liberal weekly edited by Henry A. Wallace, issued yesterday a "public announcement of the roster of editorial and business executives" of the magazine.

NANKING, Dec. 20 (U.P.)--Overcoming stubborn opposition from Rightist elements, the powerful steering committee of the National Assembly voted today to retain the clause in the proposed constitution that asserts China's "respect" for the United Nations Charter.

Margins for trading in raw hide futures contracts, for hedging transactions and for straddle deals on the Commodity Exchange, Inc., will be cut in half, effective Monday, it was announced yesterday by the organization's board of governors.

ROME, Dec. 20--The Cabinet Council decided today to appropriate 350,000,000 lire ($1,500,000) to build a factory in Rome for the production of penicillin. Machinery has been supplied by the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, and Italian technicians have been trained in the United States.

RANGOON, Burma, Dec. 20 (Reuters)--Three thousand Burmese students today marched through Rangoon's main streets, shouting slogans such as "Down With British Imperialism," "Withdraw Foreign Troops Immediately" and "Set Up a National Government."

LONDON, Dec. 20--The machinery set up to deal with miners' grievances under Government ownership of the mines is so complete that "there can be no justification for any stoppage in the coal fields," Will Lawther, president of the National Union of Mine Workers, said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20--Imports to the United States from Japan and Germany during the period of occupation are to be sold at American price levels and not at prices based on the costs of manufacture, it was learned on official authority here today.

News designed to brighten the holiday season for thousands of employes came yesterday from brokerage firms, banks, industrial concerns and other businesses with announcements of the distribution of millions of dollars in Christmas bonus payments. Many other yearend payments have been reported previously.
Howard J. Rose of the Princeton Club and Walter D. Hoag Jr. of the Yale Club came through the semi-finals yesterday in the National Squash Tennis Association's scratch tournament at the Harvard Club.

Dr. George Baehr, president of the New York Academy of Medicine, has been elected a director of the Milbank Memorial Fund, it was announced yesterday. The fund is carrying on a program of research in various fields of public health.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 20 --The Atlantic City Hotel Association has launched a five-point program designed to minimize fire hazards here.

James A. Farley replied yesterday to the statement of Edward J. Flynn, Democratic National Committeeman, who declared that Mr. Farley was "politically dead" in comment on Mr. Farley's call for a reorganization of the Democratic party in State and nation.

Christmas bells jingled merrily all over the city yesterday. With Christmas week just around the corner, carol singing echoed from wreathed windows of settlement houses, institutions and clubs where there were gift-laden tables and sparkling trees.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20--Raymond M. Foley, the new National Housing Administrator, was reported by authoritative sources today to be urging upon President Truman a reversal of the Administration's endorsement of the bi-partisan Wagner-Ellender-Taft long-range housing bill.

Jersey City and Staten Island placed third and fifth, respectively, yesterday in the twenty-fourth annual fire prevention competition among more than 1,600 United States cities. It is conducted jointly by the National Board of Fire Underwriters and the National Fire Protection Association.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 20 (AP)-- The lamp from the United States Supreme Court desk of the late Justice Louis D. Brandeis was lighted again today at the quarters of the Brandeis Lawyers' Society.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20-- Spokesmen for the motion-picture industry promised a House subcommittee today to improve the quality of films shipped abroad by a self-imposed system of selection.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (U.P.)-- Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican, of Wisconsin, demanded tonight that President Truman state which emergency war powers the Administration wants to retain.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP)-- The mint announced today that a medal has been struck in honor of John W. Snyder, making him the sixteenth Treasury Secretary to be so recognized. There have been fifty-two Secretaries.

HAVANA, Dec. 20 (AP)--Dr. Randolph Manning, chairman of the foreign relations committee of the United States Football Association, returned to the United States today after attending the first North American soccer congress.

The Belgian War Relief Society, Inc., of the U.S.A., to be dissolved Jan. 31, 1947, will equip a hospital to be erected in Bastogne by Belgians as a memorial to American soldiers killed there, Maj. William Wickham Hoffman, president, announced yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 20--A possibility that the Metropolitan Opera Association, starting at an undesignated date, may make an annual fall tour of the West Coast, giving a series of performances in San Francisco and including the Northwest, resulted from a conference here today.

Holders of the common and preferred stocks in the General Motors Corporation for the fourth quarter of 1946 numbered 430,384, highest in the history of the corporation, it was announced yesterday. This total compares with 128,874 holders in the third quarter of this year and with 425,657 in the fourth quarter of 1945.
CHICAGO, Dec. 20--The Franklin Association, bargaining group for 600 Chicago area commercial printers, increased today its wagerise offers to Local 16, International Typographical Union, AFL.
SCIO, Ohio, Dec. 20 (AP)--L.P. Reese, who was on poor relief fourteen years ago, distributed tonight $705,000 to the 827 employes of his Scio-Ohio pottery in a surprise Christmas bonus.

A 13-year-old Harlem boy armed with a loaded .32 caliber pistol and a large penknife was captured by detectives a few minutes after he had held up a teacher in Public School No. 85, 2400 Marion Avenue, the Bronx, yesterday morning, and taken a purse containing $10.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Dec. 20 (AP) --Christmas cards, reproduced from the Colgate University Steward's Journal, mailed by President and Mrs. Everett Case, revealed these prices of food in December, 1846: Choice beef, 3 cents a pound; fresh pork, 5 cents a pound; butter, 12 cents a pound, and sugar, $20.48 per 238-pound barrel.

Enrollments for the daytime nurse's aide class of New York Chapter, American Red Cross, 315 Lexington Avenue, are now being accepted, the organization announced yesterday. The class begins Monday, Jan. 6, at 2 P.M.

To pay income taxes due the Federal Government, the Longchamps Restaurant chain has authorized the sale at public auction of its reserve real estate, consisting of four investment properties in Manhattan, it was announced yesterday.

Col. William D. Carroll, a retired painting contractor, who had been prominent in civic affairs for years in the Bronx, died on Thursday in his home at 281 East 169th Street, the Bronx. His age was 96.

In memory of Miss Henrietta Szold, founder of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, who would have been 86 years old today, the Jewish Agency for Palestine announced yesterday establishment of an annual grant in her memory to the Children's Foundation of the Holy Land.

PARIS, Dec. 20 (AP)--French band leaders joined in protest today against anything that looked like an invasion by American musicians.

SAN PEDRO, Calif., Dec. 20 (U.P.) --A round-the-world voyage of an American merchant ship that took five years was completed here today by the American President Lines' 16,000-ton passenger liner President Polk.

The Army transport General Harry Taylor, her decks lined with 2,014 troops happily contemplating the prospect of Christmas at home, tied up at Pier 11, Staten Island, at 9:30 A.M., yesterday after a twelve-day voyage from Leghorn, Italy, and Casablanca.

LONDON, Dec. 20--In the three months ending Sept. 13, England and Wales had the lowest infant mortality rate over recorded, 35 in 1,000 live birth. These statistics, issued by the registrar general today, show a decrease of two infant deaths per 1,000 live births from the same quarter last year, which was the previous lowest.

The International Paper Company yesterday raised the price of kraft container board to $100 a ton, effective Jan. 1, from the present $84 a ton which has been in effect since Dec. 1, and represented an increase of $10 a ton over the old price. The company said the increase was necessitated by higher costs of production. Other major producers made no immediate move to increase prices.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Dec. 20-- Two girls, trapped in their thirdfloor tenement home at 209 Ninth Street, this city, burned to death today in a three-alarm fire that left forty-two persons homeless.

BERLIN, Dec. 20--In a dispatch to THE NEW YORK TIMES from Berlin yesterday it was stated that 72,000,000 tons of foodstuffs had been shipped into Germany from the United States since the beginning of the occupation. This was an error: It should have said $72,000,000 worth of foodstuffs.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP)-- The Civil Aeronautics Board opened an investigation today in the collision of two Miami-bound airliners whose pilots' skillful handling of the damaged ships averted injury to eighty-five persons aboard them.

HANOI, Indo-China, Dec. 20-- Fighting between French troops and forces of the Viet Nam Republic raged today at the edge of the Annamite section of Hanoi, part of which was in flames. The European section was held under French control. Viet Nam attacks were repulsed.

DALLAS, Tex., Dec. 20 (AP)-- Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, warned today against starting a fight to break up labor unions. He stated that such a move would unify all unions and would mean a Labor Government.

Winter tried yesterday to make a white-cloaked debut two days ahead of schedule but the "comingout party" was not a complete success. While wet flakes of the season's first major snowfall coated suburban areas, sleet turned into slush in most of the city and preholiday traffic was disrupted and clogged.

The City College swimming team scored its first victory of the season last night by defeating Manhattan, 41 to 33, in the Beavers pool. Joe Fruin of the Jaspers was the only double winner, capturing the 220 and 440-yard free style events.

LONDON, Dec. 20--The British newspaper man who assaulted Philip Piratin, Communist member of Parliament, in the precincts of the House of Commons yesterday was T.D. Lucq, a press association reporter, it was learned today.

ALBANY, Dec. 20 (AP)--The Civil Service employes Association, Inc., of New York, received today final approval of the Labor Department to extend its membership to eligible workers of all local political subdivisions in the State, including school teachers.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 20 --The United Nations Atomic Energy Commission today approved the basic points of the United States plan for international atomic control to the extent that it is found to be in conformity with the General Assembly's disarmament resolution.

OXFORD, Ohio, Dec. 20--Dr. Fred C. Whitcomb, professor emeritus of Industrial Arts Education at Miami (Ohio) University, died last night at Fort Hamilton Hospital, Hamilton. His age was 76.
Yale's wrestling team won its second consecutive Eastern Intercollegiate League match by defeating Columbia, 16 to 14, on the Lions' mats yesterday.
Max Rosen, New York violinist, who had not been heard in recital here since 1944, appeared again at Carnegie Hall last night. The weather was unpropitious for either audiences or strings.

The trio leaving Minneapolis is Bill Lillard, infielder; Bill Lefevbre, pitcher, and Bill Barnacle, utility man. In return the Millers will get Art Fowler, a right-handed pitcher, and Larry Higgins, third baseman.

How to set holiday tables "American style" will be demonstrated for foreign brides of former GIs this morning at 10 o'clock in Macy's basement home center. Four Christmas time settings will be shown by Sally Larkin of H.B. Humphrey Company of Boston.
LONDON, Dec. 20--Appointment of A.V. Alexander as Minister of Defense under the new set-up enacted by Parliament has been formally approved by King George VI, it was announced today.

Following a sharp rally in old crop months, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned rather dull yesterday, lost most of the gains and closed 9 points higher to 3 points net lower.

As has been their custom for the last thirteen years, a group of students from the Horace Mann School for Boys in Riverdale came to THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday to offer their annual gift to the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund.

ROME, Dec. 20--Russia has obliged the Italian Government to eat humble pie and to apologize profusely for a confidential police circular in which it was suggested that the Soviet Union was organizing subversive activities in Italy.
Private sale to insurance companies of $25,000,000 of debentures of the Celanese Corporation of America and $25,000,000 of debentures of the Household Finance Corporation was announced yesterday.

Police protection was promised yesterday to two women who said they had received threatening telephone calls since they filed taxpayer suits to prevent the city from paying retroactive wages to transit workers.

Dana M. Albaugh has been made permanent chairman and budget secretary of the Foreign Department of the American Baptist Foreign Mission Society in a reorganization of the foreign secretarial staff, it was announced yesterday at Baptist headquarters, 152 Madison Avenue.
The New Jersey deer hunting has improved considerably since the opening day in several areas, and some of the hunters are now convinced that the reported abundance of deer this year was not a myth.

James Harrigan, sponsor and former principal of the McKee Vocational High School at St. George, S.I., died at Fort Lauderdale, Fla., on Thursday of a heart ailment after a long illness, according to word received yesterday by his sister, Mrs. Nell Hyde of 257 Bement Avenue, West New Brighton, S.I. His age was 74.

MANILA, Dec. 20 (AP)--United States Ambassador McNutt and President Roxas today began a series of talks preparatory to the resumption of negotiations for Philippine sites for United States military bases. Aides said Mr. McNutt would present requests for definite bases and a quick decision.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP)-- The Bureau of the Census reported today that 7,782,862 running bales of cotton from the 1946 crop were ginned prior to Dec. 13.
TOKYO, Dec. 20--It is becoming increasingly evident that the purge of business executives is the most unpopular move that the occupation authorities have sponsored so far.

Approval was given yesterday by Judge Vincent L. Liebell in the United States District Court to the plan of the Electric Bond and Share Company for retirement of its preferred stocks.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20--The United States, in a sharp reversal of its original policy, today swung to the support of a two-price system for the disposal of world food surpluses.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20--Clarence G. Sheffield, president and a director of the Julius Garfinckel Co. department store here, died in a hospital early today after a brief illness. His age was 61.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20--Jozef Winiewicz, Minister Counselor of the Polish Embassy in London and in recent weeks a member of the Polish delegation to the General Assembly of the United Nations in New York, is expected to be appointed Ambassador to the United States, it was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20--Revolutionary changes in the size and armament of the United States Army infantry and armored divisions, which will greatly increase, firepower, shock effect and maneuverability, were announced today by Gen. Jacob L. Devers.

TORONTO, Dec. 20 (Canadian Press)--B.L. Anderson, secretarytreasurer of the Canadian Golf Association for twenty-five years, died yesterday at his home in nearby Richmond Hill. His age was 68. He had been in ill health since his retirement a year ago.

The Loewy Construction Company, Inc., of New York City, has been awarded a contract for the metal work and rolling mill installation for a $2,500,000 plant to be erected in Bombay, India, for a large financial group of Indian industrialists.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 20-- Miss Anna Drew Scott of 554 Westminster Avenue, principal of Carteret High School, Carteret, N.J., since 1922, and the author of several children's books, died today in her home after an illness of three months. Her age was 47.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20 (AP)--Johnny Bratton, 19-year-old Chicago Negro, was awarded an unanimous decision over Willie Joyce, veteran lightweight contender from Gary, Ind., at the end of their blistering ten-round battle in the Chicago Stadium tonight. Joyce weighed 136 pounds to 138 for Bratton.

Handy Harman, local bullion dealers, lowered the price of silver yesterday an additional cent an ounce to 85 cents. On Thursday the firm reduced the price 1 cent an ounce to 86 cents.

Members of the police, Army and Customs Service have combined forces to rid the Brooklyn waterfront of river pirates, hijackers and petty thieves who are responsible for $1,000,000 thefts annually from piers in the East River.

The National Association for American Composers and Conductors presented a concert last night at Times Hall celebrating the seventy-fifth birthday of the late Henry Hadley.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (U.P)-- The Agriculture Department estimated today the 1947 spring pig crop at 53,000,000 head, compared with 52,574,000 in 1946, but officials said the estimate was "disappointingly small."

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 20-- Henry J. Kaiser raised the price of basic steel products from his Fontana plant $7 a ton today and sharply criticized major producers for advancing prices on "highly finished and fabricated" steel products without a corresponding increase in the three basic products: structural shapes, plate and carbon bars.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 20 (AP)--Glenwood Farm's Eire, who had shown stopping tendencies in his first three starts here this winter, only to develop surprising gameness with a hard-earned triumph over the 2-to-5 shot, Westminster, in his previous race, displayed another courageous effort to win today's Rataplan Handicap at Tropical Park.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP)-- Mickey Vernon, first baseman of the Senators, whose .353 batting average topped the American League this year, has weighed in with a $25,000 salary demand for 1947. "Ridiculous," said President Clark Griffith. "He never hit .300 in his life before last season." Vernon's 1946 contract called for $9,000, to which Griffith added an unspecified bonus.
TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 20 (AP)-- The New Jersey Racing Commission today received applications for 1947 dates from the State's three tracks, but took no action.

Bids for the construction of Jacob Riis Houses, public low-rent housing development in Manhattan's East Side, were opened yesterday by the New York City Housing Authority. The low bids totaled $11,601,699, enough to confirm expectations of serious difficulty in financing the project.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 20 (AP)-- Argentine Foreign Office sources said today that Argentina and Russia would sign a treaty of friendship commerce and navigation "some time during the first two weeks of January."

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 20--The CIO United Steelworkers of America called formally on the Aluminum Company of America today for a "substantial" pay increase for 20,000 employes.

Miss Marjorie Corbin has been appointed sales and promotion manager of the pattern division of the Butterick Company, Inc., it was announced yesterday. Constance Caroline, Lady Auckland, widow of the sixth Baron Auckland, died here on Tuesday. A daughter of the late Benno Hart of San Francisco, she became the second wife of the Baron in 1939. CHICAGO, Dec. 25--Sydney G. McAllister, who rose from office boy to president of the International Harvester Company, a position he held from May, 1935, to May, 1940, died late today at the Huntington Hotel, Pasadena, Calif. He was 67 years old.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 25-- John J. Egan, Connecticut's Labor Commissioner, has accepted a new wage formula for beauty shop employes and will submit it to a public hearing in the State office building here Jan. 14.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Dec. 25 (AP)--Fire swept the attic of the Town Hotel tonight, critically burning a roomer identified as Frank Kubik and causing damage estimated at $1,500 by Assistant Fire Chief John R. Barron.

YONKERS, N.Y., Dec. 25--Mrs. Mary McDonald Murray, widow of John J. Murray, died Tuesday at 40 Belmont Terrace, home of her daughter, Mrs. John D. Reilly, whose husband is president of the Todd Shipyards Corporation of 1 Broadway, New York. Her age was 80.

CHICAGO, Dec. 25--Mabbett K. Reckord of suburban Wilmette, general director of the Illinois Children's Home and Aid Society, died today at the home of friends in suburban Winnetka of a heart attack. He was 50 years old.
CATSKILL, N.Y., Dec. 25-- Harold Platner, district attorney of Greene County, died of a heart attack last evening at his home here. He had been in poor health recently. His age was 47.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 25 (AP)--The toys her parents bought for Virginia Zimmer for her first Christmas were never opened for the 10-month-old girl. She died in a hospital today. Mr. and Mrs. Sylvester Zimmer went ahead with plans for Christmas for two other older children.

CAMDEN, N.J., Dec. 25 (AP)-- Thomas H. Miller, 71 years old, chief engineer at a Philadelphia department store for more than 30 years, was found dead of gas fumes in his home today, Joseph Inglesby, Camden County coroner, said. The coroner listed the death as accidental and said Miller, who retired about a year ago, apparently had not lighted properly the gas burners on his kitchen stove.

Arriving a day later than expected, a tired but happy group of GI brides and their infants landed yesterday at La Guardia Field from London by Pan American clipper. They joyously exclaimed that it was a wonderful Christmas present.
INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Dec. 25 --President Truman returned home today to enjoy a family Christmas holiday.

WARSAW, Dec. 25 (AP)--The newspaper Robotnik reported today that authorities had found a new Nazi mass-burial ground near Bydgoszcz, where 1,000 Poles had been interred.

MADRID, Dec. 25--Sir Victor Mallet, British Ambassador to Spain, left for London by air this afternoon in fulfillment of the United Nations decision to withdraw the heads of diplomatic missions from Spain.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Dec. 25 (AP)--Bright sunshine, a warm sea and a lazy surf attracted gay thousands to the beach today for sun and surf bathing. Lifeguards estimated the throng at about 15,000 on public beaches, and the private beaches of hotels, Cabana clubs and ocean-front estates accounted for nearly that many more. The air temperature was 76 and the water 72.

MACON, Ga., Dec. 25 (AP)--A house detective said tonight that a spectacular early morning blaze that destroyed a wing of the Lanier Hotel and sent seventy-five guests into the streets bore "evidences of arson."

Mr. and Mrs. John Sloane of 48 East Ninety-second Street, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Grace Elsie, to Cyrus Roberts Vance, son of Mrs. J. Carl Vance of Clarksburg, W.Va., and the late Mr. Vance.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Dec. 25 (AP)--The insurance office of the Secretary of Agriculture, Clinton P. Anderson, was looted of $196 last night. Police reported that the burglar scaled the building, slid down a telephone pole and entered a second story window. Efforts to force a wall safe were unsuccessful. The money was taken from a desk.

CHICAGO, Dec. 25 (U.P.)--Walter Biruk, 36, operator of a women's clothing store, sent Joseph Stalin three pairs of nylons for Christmas.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP)-- The War Assets Administration announced today that the Des Moines ordnance plant, which was built by the Government at a cost of $31,667,000 and which employed 20,000 workers during the war, has been put up for sale or lease.
First-nighters will be on hand for two Broadway openings this evening, "Beggar's Holiday" and "Toplitzky of Notre Dame," at the Broadway and Century Theatres, respectively.

Willys-Overland Motors, Inc., reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $402,901 for the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30 last, giving effect to a $854,410 Federal tax credit resulting from a loss carryback to 1944.

DENPASAR, Bali, Dec. 25 (AP)-- The second step in the formation of a United States of Indonesia was taken here yesterday when the Provisional State of East Indonesia was proclaimed in the name of Queen Wilhelmina of the Netherlands.

YONKERS. N.Y., Dec. 25--Ten members of United Nations delegations were dinner guests in private homes here today. They then were entertained at the Julia Dyckman Andrus Memorial Home for children at 1156 North Broadway, Yonkers.

HONOLULU, Dec. 25 (U.P.)--The University of Utah football team drubbed the Hawaii All-Stars, 40 to 6, at the Honolulu Stadium this afternoon.

NORTH PATCHOGUE, L.I., Dec. 25--Rock, a German shepherd dog, is fast becoming acclimated to his new surroundings in this country, following the pup's reunion with his master, Richard W. Mayer, 19 years old, formerly of the Army Air Forces.

NANKING, Dec. 25--In a Christmas Day conclusion to its long, arduous labors, the National Assembly today presented a new permanent Constitution to China.
Adequate stocks of almost all foods, and new shopping conveniences are in prospect for 1947, John A. Hartford, president of the Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company, said yesterday.

William S. Bruno, exporter, has purchased the residential property at 48 Mulberry Road, Woods of Larchmont, in New Rochelle, N.Y., from Miriam G. Abrams. Raymond D. Porter was the broker and the Home Title Guaranty Company insured the title.

The Navy's expedition to the Antarctic, which has just started, replaces fleet maneuvers in Arctic waters that had been scheduled for this winter.

LONDON, Dec. 25 (Reuters)-- London's first winter season of promenade concerts in fourteen years will open at the Royal Albert Hall on Monday, Jan. 6 and continue for twelve days, it was announced today. This year's concerts will be given by the British Broadcasting Corporation's Symphony Orchestra with Basile Cameron and Sir Adrian Boult as conductors.

WARSAW, Poland, Dec. 24 (Delayed) (AP)--Ten American wives who were separated from their husbands before and during the war, and thirteen children left by plane for Berlin today en route to the United States to rejoin their spouses.

New York University, upset by Oregon on Monday, will seek to redeem itself at the expense of Colorado, another of the holiday visitors from the Far West, at Madison Square Garden tonight.
JERUSALEM, Dec. 25 (U.P.)--Assassins believed to be members of the secret Arab army killed another wealthy Arab landowner, Emir Mohammed el Saleh, in full daylight in Haifa today.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Dec. 25 (AP)--Winifred Clark, a waitress, found a handbag today and turned it over to the manager of the cafeteria where she works. The owner was traced through a cabana card found in the purse, along with $4,000 in jewels. When the bag and jewels were returned, the owner gave Miss Clark a crisp five-dollar bill.

UTICA, N.Y., Dec. 25--The Rev. Matthew J. Lawlor, pastor of St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church for the last twelve years, died today in St. Elizabeth Hospital after a brief illness.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (U.P.)-- United States industry largely has completed reconversion from war to peacetime production and if given the opportunity it is geared to turn out a record volume of goods for civilian use in 1947.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 25 (AP)--Joe Carter paced Florida Normal College to a 33 to 6 victory over Morris College of Sumter, S.C., today in the Tropical Bowl football game.
LONDON, Dec. 25 (Reuters)-- The Iranian Government has decided to introduce compulsory primary education for children between 7 and 11 years of age, the Teheran radio reported today.

MANILA, Thursday, Dec. 26 (AP) --The Netherlands Consulate asked the Philippine Government today to help in a search for twenty-five Dutch East Indians, en route to Mindanao from the Netherlands Indies, who were reported overdue in four small boats and presumably were lost at sea.

The Maritime Commission has one new, unassembled diesel electric crane barge for sale at $74,160, it was announced yesterday. Constructed of five-sixteenths of an inch steel plate, this thirty-ton whirley crane barge is 112 feet long and has a 935-ton displacement. Complete equipment includes anchors, pumps, windlass, safety devices, floodlights and diesel lighting system.

BUFFALO, Dec. 25 (U.P.)--The Buffalo Courier-Express said tonight that the price of the paper would be advanced from 3 to 4 cents a copy, beginning Monday. The price rise was attributed to increasing production costs.

WESTFIELD, N.J., Dec. 25-- Mr. and Mrs. Harold S. Thompson of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Virginia Ruth, to Thomas S. Meiss, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Meiss, also of Westfield. The bride-elect served as a cadet nurse during the war. Her fiance, a former lieutenant in the United States Marine Corps Reserve, is a senior at Cornell University.

The Brooklyn Bureau of Social Service, 285 Schermerhorn Street, appealed yesterday to the public for used but serviceable radios for the blind or seriously handicapped. The bureau emphasized that the radios would link home-bound persons with the rest of the world. Radios may be sent to the bureau's headquarters.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Dec. 25 (AP)--Mildred Gillars said today that she had become "Axis Sally" because the German radio gave her "the outlet for the dramatic expression I had always sought."
The Coast Guard reported yesterday morning that the 7,261-ton British freighter Vancouver had canceled an SOS sent out when fire started in her engine room.

BOSTON, Dec. 25--Dr. George Klemperer, retired University of Berlin Professor of Internal Medicine and noted in Germany for his research in cancer and metabolism, died yesterday at the Massachusetts General Hospital.

Members of the police river front squad of Brooklyn, newspaper reporters and neighbors of Leroy C. Metzger, his wife, and four children, of 226 Fifty-first Street, played Santa Claus roles yesterday for the unemployed father and his family.

A call for "pioneers in American Judaism" comparable to pioneer youth in Palestine was issued yesterday by Rabbi Moshe Davis, Dean of the Teachers Institute and Seminary College of Jewish Studies of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America.

BOSTON, Dec. 25 (AP)--After racing off to a four-goal lead, the fast-skating Chicago Black Hawks defeated the Boston Bruins, 5 to 3, in a free-shooting National Hockey League clash before 13,900 fans tonight at the Boston Garden. George Gee and Alex Kaleta each scored twice for the victors.

HAMLET, N.C., Dec. 25--Dr. Ambrose W. Gallagher, formerly of Scarsdale, N.Y., died yesterday at his home here. The physician leaves a widow, the former Miss Elizabeth Corcoran of New York; two daughters, a son, and a brother, Dr. Leo J. Gallagher of New York.

Beginning Jan. 1 the Scandinavian Airlines System will add another round-trip flight between New York and Copenhagen, Oslo and Stockholm, it was announced yesterday. The new flight will make four round trips weekly operated by the airline.

Effective Jan. 1, licensed and unlicensed merchant seafarers who serve a maximum of eight months (240 days) a year aboard this country's merchant vessels shall be eligible for one month's refresher training in the United States Maritime Service, according to an announcement yesterday by the USMS New York enrolling officer.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP)-- Industry and Government officials tonight forecast record-smashing construction activity in 1947, the Department of Commerce predicting nearly $22,000,000,000 worth of building of all kinds.

Dr. Sarah Gibson Blanding, president of Vassar College, has joined the advisory board of World Federalists, U.S.A., 31 East Seventyfourth Street, which is seeking to change the United Nations into a world federal government, it was announced yesterday.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 25 (U.P.)-- Former Representative Dave E. Satterfield Jr., Democrat, of Virginia, was in critical condition in a Richmond hospital tonight after suffering a heart attack. Mr. Satterfield, who is 52, resigned from Congress two years ago to accept executive directorship of the Life Insurance Association of America.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 25 (AP)-- Gene Petty, outfielder of the Richmond Colts of the Piedmont League, who had a brief fling in the infield as a first baseman during the 1946 season, today was given permission to make a deal for himself.
ROME, Dec. 25--Pope Pius today left aside for a few hours the heavy cares of his office and spent a quiet Christmas with members of his immediate family.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Dec. 25-- President Mariano Ospina Perez has signed the measure providing for the installation of a special radio station to broadcast the sessions of both houses of Congress.
Paul Draper and Larry Adler last night opened their sixth annual season at the City Center, and the performance was, as always, a highly entertaining and artistic one.
MOSCOW, Dec. 25 (AP)--The presidium of the Supreme Soviet announced today that the city of Pillau in what was formerly German East Prussia had been renamed Baltiisk.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 26 --Universal-International today signed Dan Duryea to a seven-year exclusive contract and announced that his First picture under the arrangement will be the screen version of Dorothy B. Hughes' recent novel, "Ride the Pink Horse."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26--The Investment Bankers Association of America tonight "strongly" recommended to the Federal Reserve Board that present restrictions on margin trading in listed securities be modified to facilitate the distribution of new security issues.

Cracks in the high price structure for many cost-of-living items suddenly appeared in major cities across the country yesterday. One of the sharpest breaks came in the New York and Chicago wholesaled butter markets.

Drastic modification of China's present international trade policies, tariff concessions on American export products and a lowering of United States tariff barriers on noncompetitive Chinese commodities was urged in a brief submitted yesterday to the Committee for Reciprocity Information.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26--Professional operators dominated the grain markets on the Board of Trade today. Pressure was put on oats and they closed to 7/8 cent a bushel lower than on Tuesday, leading the decline.

The confusion as to the number of European refugees admitted to this country this year is cleared up in a statement issued by Dr. Leland Rex Robinson of the American Council of Voluntary Agencies for Foreign Service.
Manufacturers of knitwear are looking forward to a heavy volume of business in 1947 both for underwear and outerwear, according to trade leaders yesterday.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 26 --The "last preliminary" obstacle facing United Nations delegates prior to tomorrow's big showdown fight on the Baruch atomic plan was cleared easily and amicably today.

Net income of the Marathon Corporation, paper manufacturer, for the year ended with last October was $2,734,034, equal to $1.91 each on 1,300,000 shares of common stock outstanding, more than double the $1,360,437 earned in the preceding fiscal year, the report disclosed yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dee. 26--Seismic sea waves, scourge of shore and island dwellers for centuries, soon may lose some of their terrors, scientists assembled for the annual meeting of the Geological Society of America said today at a press symposium in the Stevens Hotel.

MONTREAL, Dec. 26 (AP)--The Montreal Canadiens scored their second victory of the season over the Toronto Maple Leafs here tonight, defeating the National Hockey League leaders 4--1. In their three previous meetings each team won once and tied.

After two rounds of the national intercollegiate championship tournament sponsored by the United States Chess Federation at John Jay Hall at Columbia University yesterday, players representing Brooklyn College and City College were heading the list of thirteen contenders.
City detectives thought yesterday that they had caught up, in the arrest of Raymond Dolsen, a sign painter, with a new twist in hotel robberies.

The National Lawyers Guild charged yesterday that the program for new labor legislation proposed recently by the National Association of Manufacturers constituted a "blunderbuss" effort to destroy the effectiveness of unions and to "emasculate" existing Federal labor laws.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange opened yesterday 11 to 18 points higher than Tuesday's final quotations and closed 35 to 53 points higher on active months.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26--Rejection of a protest of the Soviet Embassy alleging that two Russian citizens were attacked by American military police in Shanghai on Sept. 23 was indicated at the State Department today.

SHANGHAI, Friday, Dec. 27 (AP) --The Shanghai press reported today that the death toll in three Christmas Day airliner crashes here had reached sixty-seven but that a fourth plane that had been missing with ten persons aboard was safe.
PEIPING, China, Dec. 26--It is learned here on high authority that the principal Kuomintang strategy for the coming winter months has now been firmly fixed.

MELBOURNE, Friday, Dec. 27 --The powerful United States tennis team of Jack Kramer and Ted Schroeder regained the Davis Cup today with a straight-set, 6--2, 7--5, 6--4, victory over the Australians, Jack Bromwich and Adrian Quist, in the doubles.

ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 28 (AP)-- True to expectation, Calumet Farm's Armed and King Ranch's triple-crown champion, Assault, drew top weights today for the tenth running of the Santa Anita Handicap, with $100,000 guaranteed the winner, on March 1.
WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 26 (AP) --Detective Thomas B. Conaty Jr. 30, was fatally shot today while questioning two youths on a midtown street.
WARSAW, Dec. 26--The Polish Cabinet has broadened the facilities for private enterprise with a decision to allow up to 200 workers per shift in certain undertakings.

Detectives seeking to question two brothers about a series of liquor store holdups shot and seriously wounded the elder one yesterday in his apartment at 73 West Ninety-sixth Street, after he had drawn a toy automatic pistol.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 26 (AP)-- Determined that New Year's shall not bring a repetition of the Christmas automobile accident toll of seventy lives in California, authorities took steps today to stop the drunken driver before he gets behind the wheel.

Patient burglars during the early hours of Christmas Day thoroughly ransacked the duplex apartment of Moss Hart the playwright, and his wife, the former Kitty Carlisle, the actress, at 4 East Sixty-fifth Street.

"The Best Years of Our Lives" starts a sixth week today at the Astor... The Children's Film Library programs, consisting of a feature film revival and selected cartoons and short subjects, will be shown at 9 A.M. tomorrow at the RKO Fordham, Midway, Kenmore, Madison.

PARIS, Dec. 26--Premier Leon Blum's Socialist Government indicated a cautious attitude today toward the demands of the French General Confederation of Labor that the minimum living wage be made at least 84,000 francs yearly.
Heralded by a biting northwest wind, a cold snap that originated in the Great Lakes area reached New York City last night and sent the temperature dropping swiftly.
PARIS, Dec. 26--The Council of the Republic will meet tomorrow to elect its president and other officers as its last official act this year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26--The Big and Little Inch pipelines, put to temporary emergency use Dec. 5 to alleviate the strike-caused coal shortage, are now delivering more than 75,000,000 cubic feet of natural gas daily to Midwestern and Appalachian areas.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 26 (AP)--Two bands of armed Jews robbed two diamond factories forty miles apart almost simultaneously today and made away with nearly $107,000 in diamonds, cash and bonds, police reported.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26--A deep and bitter division based directly on 1948 Presidential politics has developed among House Republicans over the selection of a party leader in the new Congress, it became apparent today.

ATLANTA, Dec. 26 (AP)--First returns from a poll of the Georgia Legislature showed heavy support tonight for M.E. Thompson, Lieutenant Governor-elect, to become Governor in place of the late Eugene Talmadge.

FORCE, Pa., Dec. 26 (AP)--The three northwestern Pennsylvania villages the coal-mining inhabitants of which went on strike for five months in 1945 against what they called "intolerable" sanitary conditions are well on the way to becoming healthful, independent communities.

No appreciable reduction in wholesale prices of upholstered furniture is expected during the first quarter of 1947 despite the excess of supply over demand and reluctance of retailers to buy before liquidating inventories, buyers and manufacturers said yesterday.
Members of the Boaard of Educaton, at a regular meeting yesterday at school headquarters, 110 Livingston Street, Brooklyn, voted to raise the salaries of their confidential secretaries.

Holding the present 15 per cent tax on pari-mutuel betting to be "prejudicial to first-class racing," the New York State Racing Commission yesterday called for the prompt restoration of the 10 per cent levy that formerly prevailed here.

LONDON, Dec. 26 (Canadian Press)--The Wolverhampton Wan derers today rose to the heights before a roaring crowd of 50,000 soccer fans to defeat Sunderland, 2--1, in the English League's first division for the second time in two days. The Wanderers have a fourpoint lead in the division.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Dec. 26-- Miss Elna Anida Mayer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kurt Arnold Mayer of Great Neck, was married here tonight to William Judson Boone, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Louden Boone, also of Great Neck, in St. Paul's Episcopal Church.

TOKYO, Dec. 26 (U.P.)--British planes and one destroyer were pressed into service today to rush winter clothing to disaster victims on Shikoku Island after an emergency request from Col. Frederick Porter, senior military government officer there.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 26 (AP)-- Cancellation of plans for her 100th birthday party today did not disturb the small cheerful woman in the hospital bed, as she glowed visibly because she received a congratulatory message from Pope Pius XII.

BOSTON, Dec. 26--A new synthetic chemical said to possess "high efficacy" in the treatment of allergic conditions, especially hay fever and hives, was exhibited here today at the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science by Ciba Pharmaceutical Products, Inc., of Summit, N.J.
Leopold Stokowski began a fourweek engagement as guest leader of the New York PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall.
