SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 26 (AP) --Fullbacks exchanging positions with quarterbacks presented a picture of mild confusion to onlookers today as the Eastern Squad rushed through practice for the East-West Shrine charity football game here next Wednesday.
About seventy years ago a medical clinic was opened in a small private house in East 116th Street. Its usefulness grew until it occupied a row of several houses.
Wendell L. Willkie, former Republican Presidential candidate, who died Oct. 8, 1944, left a gross estate of $849,316, and after payment of debts and administration expenses a net estate of $559,992.
BERLIN, Dec. 26--The Russians are making the best progress of all four powers in eliminating unemployment in their zone, according to official figures made available today.

There will be no oil shortage for 1,000 years and today the American oil industry--ready to solve all labor problems by union-management cooperation--is devoting record 1947 budgets to research for development of new products and improvement of old.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26--Consumers in this country spent $127,000,000,000 for goods and services in 1946, the Department of Commerce reported today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP)-- A member of the Senate War Investigating Committee said tonight that the subcommittee which investigated Senator Theodore G. Bilbo's relations with war contractors has drafted "a very tough" report.
PARIS, Dec. 26--Gen. Otto von Stuelpnagel, the first military governor of Paris under the German occupation, who was recently arrested in the French zone of Germany, was brought here tonight.
A woman whose fiance was killed when he went to the rescue of comrades in the battle of Okinawa yesterday sent her gift to the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund.

Directors of the Corn Products Refining Company declared yesterday a dividend of 75 cents a share on the common stock, payable on Jan. 25. The company has paid 65 cents quarterly since October, 1942, when the rate was cut from 75 cents.

A trucking terminal, a business structure in the Times Square area and varies small apartment houses were among the Manhattan properties passing to new owners in mild realty activity reported yesterday.

BERLIN, Dec. 26 (AP)--A FrenchAmerican dispute over the Saar widened today, the United States declaring that Paris already regarded the area as a unit apart from its occupation zone in Germany, and demanding again an explanation of recent actions there.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26--Six Norwegians will set sail in February from Ilo, Peru, on a balsa wood raft, bound for Tahiti, 4,000 miles away.

TOKYO, Dec. 26--The extraordinary session of Japan's ninetyfirst Diet, called a month ago to implement the new Constitution by the necessary legislation, ended this morning with the reading of the Imperial termination rescript by Premier Shigeru Yoshida and with the bulk of its task completed.
New expansion plans to meet growing demand of a "buyer's market" will be pushed rapidly in 1947 by the Carborundum Company, Niagara Falls, company officials disclosed here yesterday.

Edward J. Reilly, veteran BrookIyn criminal lawyer, who was chief of defense counsel at the trial of Bruno Richard Hauptmann for the kidnapping and murder of the Lindbergh baby, died Christmas night in Kings County Hospital of a cerebral thrombosis. His age was 64.

Considerable confidence in favorable retail trade prospects at least through the pre-Easter period of 1947 will swell buyers' arrivals in the wholesale markets here during the next three weeks, it was reported here yesterday.
Snow conditions continue to improve in the Northlands and reports last night indicate that the sport will be better this week-end than last. Snow fell on many of the areas Christmas Day.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president emeritus of Columbia University, characterized as "grotesque" yesterday the charges of discrimination in the selection of students for post-graduate study leveled recently against the university.

The spirited patterns with which American Indians adorned their utensils and clothing enliven a new type of painted furniture decoration by Aly Richter, New York designer.
An increase of 876,000 barrels was registered in the nation's gasoline stocks last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 26 (AP)--The Texas-owned stable of T.P. Morgan, which is faring well at the current Tropical Park meeting since shipping down from New York, put over another winner today when False Move carried the white and green silks to victory in the Melton Purse.

BERLIN, Dec. 26 (AP)--American occupation authorities had under study tonight a directive to prohibit the private importation of cigarettes into Germany by American personnel as a means of stamping out the "cigarette standard" on the black market and safeguarding the German economy.
About the time the countryman can smell snow in the air and December has drawn its gray brush over the land an old friend turns up to offer advice, solace and information.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26--President Truman arrived here at 7:15 o'clock tonight, his trip home for Christmas at an end.

RANGOON, Burma, Dec. 26 (London Times Dispatch)--Burmese reaction to Prime Minister Attlee's invitation to send a delegation to London to discuss granting independence to Burma on the same terms as India has not been entirely favorable.
BROOKLINE, Mass., Dec. 26-- Miss Lucy Tappan Poor, a daughter of Henry Varnum Poor, editor and economist, died here on Monday in her home at 10 Upland Road after a year's illness. Her age was 91.
DETROIT, Dec. 26--The automobile industry's curtailed Christmas week production was reduced further today as virtually all car makers reported heavy post-Christmas absenteeism.

Miss Marian E. Gillespie, journalist, radio artist and writer of lyrics, died yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospital. Her age was 57. She was one of the early members of the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers.

A city marshal evicted yesterday Fred Daab, a tailor, and his family from their apartment at 350 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn. During this action 2,500 persons gathered in front of the building, protesting vociferously, some even carrying furniture from the street back into the apartment.

PARIS, Dec. 27--Gen. Otto von Stuelpnagel, dread German Military Governor of Paris during the occupation, never was listed as a war criminal, it was discovered after his transfer here yesterday from Germany, where he recently was apprehended.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27--An outlay of $125 a person was made this year for clothing, compared to an average expenditure a person of $115 in 1945 and of $65 in 1941, the Department of Commerce estimated today.

MOSCOW, Dec. 27--The realloration of specialists, such as engineers and technicians, to meet the shortage of such workers in the Urals, Siberia and other Eastern industrial areas is forecast by a recent decision of the Central Committee of the Communist party.

PARIS., Dec. 27--Auguste Champetier de Ribes, member of the Popular Republican party, today was elected President of the newly created Council of the Republic over combined Socialist and Communist opposition in the Upper House, which replaces the old French Senate.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 27-- Two youths, both with records of several arrests for juvenile delinquency, were killed this morning when their stolen automobile, driven at eighty miles an hour, crashed into a gaslight lamp post here. The youngsters had been chased for more than a mile by a motorcycle policeman.
SRIRAMPUR, India, Dec. 27 --Mohandas K. Gandhi, who is bald and does not smoke or play cards, opened a Christmas package from the Friends Service Union last night.

PARIS, Dec. 27--Colonial revolt has spread to southern Indochina, taking a toll of twenty-four civilians killed, French dispatches reported today. Both sides took an increasingly uncompromising stand in the fight of the Viet Namese, which came into the open at Hanoi in the north on Dec. 19.

CAMDEN, N.J., Dec. 27--Six women members of the American Newspaper Guild who were arrested on charges of distributing circulars without a city permit were freed today by Police Court Judge Mitchell Cohen.

Cotton prices in the domestic market last week backed and filled within a trading range of about 100 points. Relative firmness in the early part of the period gave way to an easier trend toward the close of the week.

Just as if Madison Square Garden were a big chicken coop, 2,000 hens laid 500 strictly fresh eggs yesterday as judging of new poultry and pigeon winners continued at the five-day Poultry Show.

City College chess players, winning two matches in the fifth and sixth rounds--both against the two teams representing New York University --yesterday wrested the lead from Brooklyn College in the national intercollegiate championship tournament at John Jay Hall, Columbia.

Rodriguez Flores, Chilean chess expert, suffered another defeat yesterday in the championship tournament of the Marshall Chess Club at the hands of Larry Evans, youngest of the competitors.

Harry M. Pearson, vice president of W. J. Sloane, dealers in floor coverings and furniture, has been elected a member of the board of directors, it was announced for publication today by W.E.S. Griswold Jr., president. Mr. Pearson joined Sloane in 1933 as a member of the sales staff of the contract division and was named manager of the division in 1937. In 1944 he was elected vice president.

Thomas F. McMains, traffic superintendent for the New York area of the Western Union Telegraph Company, has been appointed assistant vice president of the traffic department, it was announced yesterday by E.R. Shute, vice president of the department. Henry A. Stockdale, acting traffic superintendent in Atlanta, succeeds to the post formerly held by Mr. McMains.

MADRID, Dec. 29--Premiums on compulsory health insurance will be raised on Jan. 1 to allow fuller health service for workers, according to a decree published today.

The memorial to former Gov. Alfred E. Smith will be completed in time for dedication in the fall of 1948, together with the Governor Smith State Housing Project in the lower East Side near Oliver Street, it was announced yesterday.

Frank T. Ward, Thomas J. Hackett and Frank E. Seeney have been elected vice presidents, Walter Farrington has been elected treasurer, and George Cermak has been elected general auditor of the Third Avenue Transit Corporation, it was announced yesterday by Victor McQuistion, president.

BERLIN, Dec. 29--The first four-power inspection of the progress of the elimination of Germany's war potential, as provided in the Potsdam agreement, will begin on Jan. 6 simultaneously in all zones, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP)-- The State Department was notified late today that Secretary of State Byrnes, en route back to Washington by plane from Charleston, S.C., had landed at the naval air station at Patuxent, Md., not far from here. His plane had been unable to land at either Richmond or Washington because of overcast weather, it was reported.

YOU just go around asking fellows embarrassing questions but Bucky Harris must have had at least a modicum of regret at the news that Billy Evans had been appointed vice president and general manager of the Detroit Tigers.

Melvin J. Fox has been appointed executive director of INDUSCO, the American Committee in Aid of Chinese Industrial Cooperatives, 425 Fourth Avenue, it was announced yesterday. Chinese industrial cooperatives were founded in 1938, the committee said, to provide productive relief and consumer goods for refugees. The American committee was set up in 1940 to aid this work. INDUSCO is a cooperating agency of United Service to China, now conducting a campaign for $8,000,000.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 29 (AP)-- Final matches of the Sugar Bowl tennis tournament, scheduled for today, were postponed until tomorrow because of rain.

BERLIN, Dec. 29 (AP)--Berlin newspapers reported today the return of 500 German Army veterans, most of them invalids, from eastern Germany in the first release of German war prisoners by Poland. BERLIN, Dec. 29--One of the few bright spots in the military governor's bi-monthly report, made public today, was a discussion of the education program in the American zone.

ATHENS, Dec. 29 (Reuters)-- Two Greek soldiers were killed and seventeen were injured when a truck carrying army reinforcements to the village of Terpilon, in the Kilkich area north of Salonika, struck a land mine today. CHICAGO, Dec. 29--Government orders for an undisclosed amount of cash lard came into the market last week with Jan. 2 the last day for packers to make offers. The bids are scheduled to be opened Jan. 7.

Prof. Frank Clifford Stockwell of Stevens Institute died yesterday morning in his home, Alexander House, Castle Point, Hoboken, N.J., at the age of 63. The National A.A.U. ice hockey championship will be held at the Providence Auditorium, Providence, R.I., March 21 to 23, it was announced yesterday by Daniel J. Ferris, secretary-treasurer. The election of Alexander Kartveli as a director of the Republic Aviation Corporation was announced yesterday. He has been vice president and chief engineer of Republic Aviation since its formation in 1939. MEXICO CITY, Dec. 29--After three, and a half years the camp established in Mexico for Polish war refugees is rushing to wind up its affairs. By Tuesday the last of the 1,434 persons who have been sheltered there will be on their way to an independent life.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 29 (AP)-- Florida A. M. and Wiley College of Texas, two of the nation's top Negro football teams, battled to a 6-6 tie last night in the first "Angel Bowl" game before a crowd estimated at 12,000 at Wrigley Field.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 29 (AP)--The Nordberg Manufacturing Company, of Milwaukee, Wis., has purchased the Busch-Sulzer Brothers, Diesel Engine Company, of St. Louis, for an undisclosed amount, a spokesman for the Busch-Sulzer firm announced today.

Two Pacific Coast teams, Southern California and the University of California at Los Angeles, steam into Madison Square Garden tonight to battle Long Island University and New York University in the collegiate basketball twin-showing.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Dec. 29--Frederick W. Schneider, retired electrical engineer snd instructor, died here last night in his home at 55 Howard Parkway, at the age of 71.

PARIS, Dec. 29 (AP)--French dispatches from Indo-China quoted the secret radio of the Viet Nam Government tonight as saying that Premier Leon Blum of France had offered "to re-establish the situation in Indo-China on a basis of Franco-Viet Nam agreements."

The Metropolitan Opera Association will present for the first time "The Warrior," a new American opera by Bernard Rogers and Norman Corwin, on Saturday afternoon, Jan. 11. It will be on a double bill with the new English version of "Hansel and Gretel."

The National Foreign Trade Council has urged the United States to insist upon the establishment of conditions in other countries essential to the expansion of international trade on a multilateral and non-discriminatory basis.
Bob Hope, screen and radio comedian, was cited yesterday as "a great healer" of wounded American soldiers by the 7,000 physicians who are members of the Phi Delta Epsilon Fraternity.

CHAMBERSBURG, Pa., Dec. 29 (AP)--Surplus motor vehicles valued at $5,325,000 will go on sale to authorized veterans tomorrow at the Letterkenny Ordnance depot, the War Assets Administration announced today.
SUN VALLEY, Idaho, Dec. 29 (AP)--The skiing Indians from the University of Utah retained their lead in the fifth annual intercollegiate ski meet after the slalom event today.

LONDON, Dec. 29--Broken by the Christmas holiday, the past week has been very quiet in the stock markets here but they made up in cheerfulness what they lacked in business.

Miss Jeanne Josephine Kahn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Kahn of Brooklyn Heights, was married yesterday afternoon in the home of her parents to David L. Barnett, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob L. Barnett of Savannah, Ga., by the Rev. Dr. Ira Eisenstein. Matthew M. Levy was his nephew's best man.

MOJI, Japan, Dec. 29 (AP)--Japanese customs and port officials reported today that since June they had confiscated 1,000,000 yen worth of contraband goods and seventy-nine vessels trying to land smuggled supplies.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 29. (AP) --Robert L. Morrison, former area director here of the War Manpower Commission, accepted the city managership of Knoxville yesterday. His acceptance of the post, paying $10,000 a year, was announced by Mayor Edward L. Chavannes after a telephone conversation with Mr. Morrison, who is visiting relatives in North Carolina. Mr. Morrison succeeds William B. Lockwood, who resigned Dec. 10.

C.R. Smith, chairman of the board of American Airlines, Inc., and president of American Overseas Airlines, predicted yesterday that 1947 would be a happier one for the nation airlines and their passengers.

A special sale of prepared and packaged photographic chemicals, including developers, fixers, bleaches and fixing baths, is among the surplus sales events for this week announced over the week-end by Frank L. Seymour, regional director of the War Assets Administration.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Dec. 29 (AP)-- Edward G. Daniels of Teaneck, N.J., vice president and treasurer of Lobdeil Co., New York investment bankers, died in his hotel room here today. His age was 50.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29-- Regulation A under the Securities Act, which eliminates the necessity of registering securities in most cases where the offering does not exceed $300,000, has been amended by the Securities and Exchange Commission so as to make it available to certain guarantees of foreign governments.

The Cunard White Star liner Mauretania, which made only three voyages before she was converted for transport duty during the war, will resume commercial service early next year, it was announced yesterday.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Dec. 29-- Miss Gloria Piccione, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gary J. Piccione of this place, was married here this afternoon to Dr. Joseph Francis La Barbera, son of Frank La Barbera of New York and the late Mrs. La Barbera, in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. John Leonard.

BERLIN, Dec. 29--A gloomy picture of the German food situation is painted in the bimonthly food and agriculture review of the United States Military Government for September and October, made public today. Far from improving, the situation has grown worse since the period covered by the report.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Dec. 29-- Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John S. Brayton of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Dorothy Gifford, to Douglas Shallcross Brown, son of Dr. and Mrs. Russell C. Brown of Ridgewood, N.J.
11 A.M.--Atomic Energy Commission meets in public session to discuss and vote on its report to the Security Council.

A benefit concert will be given at Town Hall on Saturday, Jan. 11, at 11:30 P.M. by an Emergency Committee of the Arts formed for Sydenham Hospital, with Paul Robeson as chairman and Eric Berney, president of Keynote Recordings, as co-chairman.

Frank R. Brodsky has been appointed as the new director of advertising for the Pepsodent division of Lever Brothers Company, it was announced over the weekend by Henry F. Woulfe, Pepsodent president. Mr. Brodsky became associated with Pepsodent in 1945 after serving for sixteen years as advertising manager for the Elgin National Watch Company.

The Rev. Dr. Joaquin F. Garcia, chairman of the department of philosophy of St. John's College, Brooklyn, has been elected president of the American Catholic Philosophical Association, it was announced here yesterday.

Since the Swedish American Line resumed commercial passenger service on the North Atlantic last March the company's ships have carried 31,532 passengers between the United States and Europe, it was announced yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29 (AP)-- Three new district offices will be opened next month by the War Assets Administration in Trenton, N.J.; Wilmington, Del., and Harrisburg, Pa., to coordinate the certification of veterans for surplus property purchases, the WAA said today. B.C. Tucker, regional chief of the WAA Veterans' Division, said certification could be obtained either in person at any of the new offices, at the regional offices here, or by mail.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29--The resignation of Isadore G. Alk, chief counsel of the Treasury Department Foreign Funds Control Division, has been accepted by Secretary John W. Snyder, it was announced today. Mr. Alk will resume his private law practice in Washington.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP)-- Members of the American Battle Monuments Commission plan a personal inspection of sites for permanent cemeteries for America's war dead in foreign lands.
Music publishers used to tell Carrie Jacobs Bond that her songs were "too plain" and would "never sell." This was a mistake.

KANSAS CITY, Dec. 29 (AP)-- Mrs. Claude Wilbur Norris, 30 years old, became a grandmother today. Her daughter, Mrs. Armon D. Hartlieb, 16, gave birth to a six-pound, thirteen-ounce girl. Mrs. Norris was married at the age of 13 to Claude W. Norris Sr., who now is 36.

Giuseppe Diamauro, 58 years old, a longshoreman employed by the United Fruit Company, was bitten on the wrist by a scorpion yesterday while unloading tobacco from the S.S. Carrillo at Pier 3, the Battery. Diamauro, who lives at 118 Sackett Street, Brooklyn, was taken to Beekman Hospital when his wrist began to swell.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 29 (AP)--Princeton and Clarkson Tech hockey teams battled to a 4-4 overtime tie in the second of a series of matches tonight. Princeton won the opening match last night, 4--2. The final game will be played Tuesday night.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 29 (AP)--The proceedings of the Venezuelan Constituent Assembly were broadcast to the people of the nation yesterday during an eighthour session devoted to a discussion of charges that political prisoners had been tortured.

PARIS, Dec. 29--French troops in Indo-China today succeeded in establishing contact with two isolated garrisons to the northeast of Hanoi, while uncertainties continued in Viet Nam factions with regard to reported overtures of peace.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 (U.P.)--American children would not play hooky so much if their teachers would try to look pretty and stop playing favorites, an educator said today. The youngsters were more interested in being treated as equals than in receiving praise from their teachers, he said.

BASLE, Dec. 29 (AP)--Dr. Sneh said tonight that the Jewish Agency's executive would act in accordance with a resolution of the Zionist congress to shun the Palestine conference "under existing conditions."

The pay rises granted this fall to New York City employes, including transit workers, teachers, nurses and others, run to something more than $60,000,000, and now some logical consequences need to be considered.

The wholesale markets last week were in the midst of an in-between-the-holidays lull, according to the market reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.
YONKERS, N.Y., Dec. 29--A two-alarm fire caused by the explosion of an oil stove in a taxicab office at 7 Wells Avenue at 5:57 o'clock this morning compelled ten families to leave their homes.

The capture of a hold-up suspect, wounded in a pistol duel with a grocery store owner, led yesterday to the round-up of two alleged confederates. The three men, the police said, admitted ten robberies in recent weeks including that of the Club Car at 924 Fifth Avenue, where $9,100 was taken.

Today, as is our custom at the end of the year, we present the recipes printed in this column in 1946 that were the most popular. Our decisions are based on readers' comments and their requests for additional copies.

Leonard Weissbein, Abraham Lincoln High captain, was undefeated in ten bouts as he won the annual scholastic invitation foil competition staged by the Mercado Fencing Club at Boys Welcome Hall, Brooklyn, yesterday.

Joseph Pizzi, 12-year-old New York-born accordionist, gave a recital at Town Hall yesterday afternoon, playing numbers by RimskyKorsakoff, Liszt, Chopin ("Minute" waltz) and Waldteufel. Several of his arrangements of folk-songs and other music were made by his teacher, Pietro Frosini.

A conference on ways to provide more music for small communities that hear little of the classics was held yesterday afternoon at the Juilliard Concert Hall, 130 Claremont Avenue. It was sponsored by the Alumni Association of the Juilliard Graduate School.

ROCKY HILL, N.J., Dec. 29-- Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Henry Young Jr. of Riverdale Farm, this place, of the engagement of their daughter, Ethel Roberts, to F. Somers Ritchie Jr., son of Mrs. Morris P. Skinner of Montclair.

HAMMONTON, N.J., Dec. 29-- Squads organized by the State Department of Conservation and Development, aided by local fire companies, succeeded today, after working since Saturday, in coping with the first major outbreak of forest fires in the Hammonton area this season.

ALBANY, Dec. 29--On the eve of Governor Dewey's inauguration for a second term, a sixty-nine point Democratic legislative program for the 1947 session of the Legislature was announced today by Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State Chairman.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Dec. 29-- Nassau County detectives were seeking today to find a diamond brooch containing more than sixty diamonds lost here by Mrs. Charlatte N. Quesenberry of 135 Hampton Road, Garden City, early this morning. Detective Andrew O'Connor said the brooch was valued at $1,200.

MANILA, Monday, Dec. 30 (AP)-- Quezon City, an outlying suburb of Manila, has been selected as site of a new national capitol of the Philippines by a committee of Congressmen appointed by President Manuel A. Roxas, Presidential Secretary Juan C. Orendain announced today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 29 (AP)-- A fire originating in trash and paint on a terraced burned out a main-floor banquet hall of the historic Fairmont Hotel on Nob Hill before dawn today.

Former Park Commissioner Walter Herrick cut his scalp last night when he fell as the result of a fainting spell while entering a drug store at 876 First Avenue, according to the police. Store employes assisted him until an ambulance took him to Midtown Hospital. Mr. Herrick's condition was described as not serious. He is 60 years old and lives at 10 Mitchell Place.

BRIDGETON, N.J., Dec. 29-- Edward L. Gray, who under the name of Grabowski won all-American football honors a few years ago, and his wife, Carolyn L., were killed today when their car crashed into a tree in this community.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Dec. 29 (AP) --The Charlotte Observer said tonight that A.L.M. Wiggins of Hartsville, S.C., a former president of the American Bankers Association, will be appointed "within the next few days" to fill O. Max Gardner's post as Under Secretary of the Treasury. Mr. Gardner is the new Ambassador to Great Britain.

Publication of revised report No. 40 on the Panama Canal and its ports, one of a series covering the principal ports of the United States, was announced yesterday by the Board of Engineers for Rivers and Harbors, War Department.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 29 (AP)-- Steel producers will enter 1947 with heavy order backlogs because of various disruptions and raw materials shortages throughout this year, the magazine Steel reported today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29--The official radio voice of the United States will begin speaking Russian about Jan. 15, officials disclosed today. This will be in line with State Department plans for a far-reaching information program designed to jump Soviet censorship and go directly to the Russian people.

Ten years after the Federal oldage insurance program went into effect to free aged men and women from the need for public charity, there are twice as many persons receiving old-age relief as there are drawing monthly insurance payments from the Social Security Administration.

John Askling has been appointed index-editor to Dan Golenpaul's "Information Please Almanac for 1947," which is edited by John Kieran. Mr. Askling is index consultant to the Grolier Society and the Americana Encyclopedia.

Taking the lead with a brace of goals in the first period, the New York Rovers outscored the Washington Lions in the Eastern Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon. While a crowd of 11,517 fans looked on, the local athletes handed out a little more than they took in a rough battle, and skated off the ice the winners by the score of 6 to 3.

The Carnation Company, through Kidder, Peabody Co., has sold $5,000,000 of nineteen-year 2 5/8 per cent debentures, due on Dec. 1, 1965, to a group of institutional purchasers, it was announced yesterday.

Serge M. Rubinstein, international financier and alleged draft dodger, was accused yesterday with members of his family and their corporate interests with having benefited by nearly $1,400,000 through the "wrongful transfer" of assets of the Panhandle Producing and Refining Company.

Price advances during 1946, according to a statement issued over the week-end by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, exceeded those of any year since the First World War. Retail food prices, this report notes, increased 34 per cent during the year and the prices of family living essentials 18 per cent.

Unemployment insurance payments throughout the nation have dropped more than 50 per cent since the beginning of the year, an analysis of figures of the Social Security Administration indicated yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30--A.L. M. Wiggins, who built a national reputation in banking on "hometown" success in Hartsville, S.C., was designated today by President Truman as the next Under-Secretary of the Treasury.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30--The National Association of Manufacturers today denounced as "an economic absurdity" the Nathan report for the Congress of Industrial Organizations which contends that wages can be increased again without again raising prices.

A fashion show keyed to the midwinter needs of the college girl and the one who either spends the season in town or flits away to a resort was presented in Altman's Young Colony Shop yesterday afternoon to a customer audience.

Wooden barricades began going up yesterday around plate glass windows in the Times Square area. While workmen hammered away, city officials announced their plans for protecting life and property tonight against over-exuberant New Year's Eve revelers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30--To hasten the return to "more normal lumber production and distribution," controls over housing construction lumber, millwork and hardwood flooring were relaxed today by the Civilian Production Administration Section of the Office of Temporary Controls.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30--The historic will of Congress to favor small, family-size farms over large "monopolistic" holdings in developing the public domain in the West is being carried out with remarkable success on millions of acres now being reclaimed by Federal irrigation projects, the Interior Department reported today.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 13 --The following statement was made by Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet representative, before the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission today:

COTUIT, Mass., Dec. 30 (AP)--A committee report sharply criticizing Russia was declared "unbelievable" today by Representative Charles L. Gifford, Republican, of Massachusetts, a member of the special House Post-War Committee on Economic Policy and Planning.

PARIS, Dec. 30--A reported exchange of messages between Premier Leon Blum and Ho Chi Minh, President of the Viet Nam Republic, relating to a truce in IndoChina was denied in official circles here today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30--The new Senate Republican majority, with Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio and Midwestern colleagues settled easily at the controls, organized "harmoniously and in good temper" today for the Eightieth Congress.
BERLIN, Dec. 30--The Allied Control Council announced today that it had legally stripped Germany of the power to prepare for war.

ENNIS, Ireland, Dec. 30 (U.P.)-- The pilot and co-pilot of the TWA Constellation plane that crashed early Saturday near Shannon Airport, said today from their hospital beds that the flight had been normal up to the moment the big craft struck the ground and burned.

ABOARD MOUNT OLYMPUS, Dec. 30 (AP)--Two United States Martin Mariners soared over uncharted and unclaimed Antarctic lands today, beginning for the Navy's expedition the huge task of photographing the South Polar continent.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30--Speculative operations in the grain markets on the Board of Trade today were at a relatively low ebb. Brokers kept close to shore as the result of the approaching holiday and the desire to await new developments, especially in regard to the box car situation.

Reduction of the present 20 per cent Federal excise tax on cosmetics to 10 per cent by July 1, either through direct action by Congress or declaration of official termination of the war emergency, is anticipated in the toilet goods industry, it was reported here yesterday.
LONDON, Dec. 30--Britain is waking up to the fact that not only the export drive but the whole progress of recovery has been brought to a halt because of the coal shortage.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 30--The following are the recommendations of the report of the Atomic Energy Commission to the Security Council:

First details of the contents of the voluminous diary of former Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. were made public yesterday, disclosing "inner history" of the first two years of the Roosevelt Administration.

A trio of comparative newcomers in the managerial field has snagged the much-sought-after acting services of James Mason, Britain's popular screen "menace," for a Broadway stage appearance this season.

Buyers of infants' and children's wear in the metropolitan area are showing greater interest than ever in the spring line displayed by 160 manufacturers at the Metropolitan Juvenile Style Mart in the Hotel New Yorker, according to M. Gold-blatt, director.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 30 --With the Soviet Union and Poland abstaining, the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission approved today a plan for international atomic control conforming ...

Work on the comparatively few new merchant and naval vessels still uncompleted, combined with limited reconversion and repair work, will provide limited activity well into 1947 for the private shipbuilding industry.
ELSA TRIOLET is the wife of Louis Aragon, French poet and novelist, former Dadaist, Surrealist and for the last ten years mili tant Communist.

TOKYO, Dec. 30--Japan's first calendar year under Allied occupation is ending with an impressive record of accomplishments in the field of political democracy. Economic recovery, upon which the functioning of democracy must rest, however, has been woefully slow.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30--Senator Chapman Revercomb, Republican, of West Virginia, warned against upsetting present nationalorigins quotas in a 59-page report on the possible admission of displaced persons that he filed today with the Republican Steering Committee.

ALBANY, Dec. 30--Few, if any, changes will be made in Governor Dewey's official family at the start of his second term as the State's Chief Executive on New Year's Day, it was indicated tonight as he completed the draft of his inaugural address.

As spokesmen for the city's real estate interests joined yesterday in opposing the threat of a possible thirty-point increase in the city's basic tax rate, the Medical Society of the County of New York called upon the city to enlarge the public health budget for the next fiscal year.

During the past year many complaints have been received from anglers and hunters charging that the various State fish and game agencies have failed to meet the requirements of the sportsmen, and that despite the clear handwriting on the wall these agencies were unprepared for the rapidly increasing popularity of hunting and fishing.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30--The Department of Agriculture asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to institute a general investigation of the revenue needs of motor carriers.

Designed for South America and sunny Southern climes, a collection of "Clipper Cruiser" fashions was presented by Russeks Fifth Avenue yesterday at the St. Regis. For boarding tha Clipper and sightseeing upon arrival, suits in paletoned gabardines and combinations of dark and light colors were favored.

BOSTON, Dec. 30 (AP)--Two expatriate American newspaper men --Robert Henry Best, 51 years olds and Douglas Chandler, 56, were indicated today by a Federal grand jury on charges of treasonously selling out to the Nazis by serving as their radio mouthpieces during the war.

MOSCOW, Dec. 30--The reported presentation of a Russian ultimatum to an American courier vessel at Dairen was denied today and described as "the invention of an American correspondent" in a dispatch from the Manchurian port in today's Pravda.
LONDON, Dec. 30--The Postmaster General, the Earl of Listowel, has rejected the claim of the National Union of Post Office ...

After a day-long session here yesterday, a continuation of lengthy meetings in Washington on Friday and Saturday, directors of Transcontinental Western Air, Inc., adjourned late last night until this morning.
The Madison Square Garden Poultry Show named yesterday four "grand champion" chickens and one "best in show" pigeon as winners for 1946. The show will close tonight at 8 o'clock.

A surprise farewell party was given yesterday in the executive offices of the Children's Aid Society, 105 East Twenty-second Street, by thirty-three staff members in honor of Miss Helen Baxter, who is retiring after nearly thirty-nine years of service.
Investigations by the Agriculture and Justice Departments into the recent rigging of New York butter and milk prices were coordinated here yesterday at a meeting of Federal officials.

The Democratic vote in the last election fell off most sharply, and with the most costly political effect, in the twelve Eastern States, a recapitulation of the vote, compiled by The Associated Press, showed yesterday.
Highly selective trading interspersed with late sales for tax purposes, kept the stock market on an irregular course yesterday although the price index showed a slight gain.

THE old year will be busy packing his bags today and getting ready to make a rapid dash for the exit. Few persons bother to give him more than a casual glance as he departs. Instead, they tingle with anticipation as they await his successor, the brash little fellow who bounces in with so much hope and so much promise.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 30 (AP)-- Charles Wakefield Cadman, composer of "The Land of the SkyBlue Water," "At Dawning" and other popular musical numbers, died this afternoon at the age of 65. He suffered a heart attack three days ago.

The United Nations Atomic Energy Commission has approved by an overwhelming majority the principles of the American plan for the prohibition and control of the bomb and has recommended these principles to the Security Council as a basis for its work in preparing an international atomic disarmament convention.

The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, in its annual statement for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31, last, issued yesterday by Harvey S. Firestone Jr., president, disclosed a net profit of $27,682,877 after all charges including $11,119,063 for depreciation and $71,499,280 for taxes and after adding ...
Keen price competition is expected to be the biggest problem for food retailers during 1947, according to a year-end survey just completed by the New York State Food Merchants Association, Inc.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 30-- Artists Alliance, the new Lester Cowan-Mary Pickford company, has signed Leonard Bernstein, conductor of the New York City Center Orchestra, to write the ...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30--The political fate of Senator Theodore G. Bilbo of Mississippi was confided today to the new Republican Steering Committee of the Senate. The committee will consider tomorrow what action, if any, should be taken to keep Mr. Bilbo out of the eightieth Congress.
A Soviet Embassy employe has quit his post in Mexico, with the statement that most Russians hate the Soviet regime, according to information made public here yesterday by a New York lawyer.

BOSTON, Dea. 30--Isolation from the plasma of various species of animals, including human plasma, of a fat-soluble fraction that appears to play a major role in providing animals with resistance to some serious bacterial infections, including malaria, typhoid ...
A chill northwest wind and temperatures in the upper twenties gave New York a cold snap yesterday but clear skies and a bright sun dispelled the week-end murk.

WARSAW, Dec. 30--The Polish Government denied officially today charges that members and supporters of Vice Premier Stanislaw Mikolajczyk's opposition Peasant Party had been tortured by the security police.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Dec. 31 (AP)-- Dixie Tighe, correspondent for The New York Post, died here today in the Forty-ninth General Hospital, where she had been under the care of General MacArthur's personal physician.

LONDON, Dec. 30--One thing of note stands out in the British critics' annual list of the year's best movies, according to a survey made today. With European countries filling the first half a dozen places, Hollywood has been practically eliminated.

MELBOURNE, Dec. 30 (AP)-- Walter Pate, United States team captain, locked the Davis Cup in the vault of his Melbourne hotel tonight and said he would stay close by it until he landed the world's big tennis trophy safely in New York in mid-January.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30--Representative Harold Knutson of Minnesota suggested today the possibility of a 100 per cent windfall tax on any money which workers may win in portal-to-portal wage suits.
LONDON, Dec. 30 (U.P.)--A spokesman for the Jewish Agency for Palestine said tonight that David Ben-Gurion, chairman of the Agency's executive, would come here on Wednesday in an ...
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 30 --In marked contrast to the serious tone of the Atomic Energy Commission meeting today, Andrei ...

LONDON, Dec. 30--The flogging of a British Army major and three sergeants by terrorists in Palestine stirred widespread indignation here today. The Dollis Hill Synagogue was set afire in an outburst of anti-Semitism.

After a series of conferences last night, Mayor O'Dwyer's Conciliation Committee announced at 10:15 o'clock that "satisfactory progress" had been made in its efforts to avert a strike of tugboat workers.

After L.I.U. had bowed to Southern California, 49--40, in the opener, the New York University basketball team went out on the Madison Square Garden floor and handed U.C.L.A. a 66-49 defeat last night to give the local representatives an even split against the invaders from the Pacific Coast.

The United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, third largest CIO union, filed retroactive portalto-portal pay suits yesterday in behalf of 250,000 workers employed by seven of the country's largest electrical and metal manufacturing companies.

Somewhat like Major Joppolo in his effort to do a kindness for Italian townsfolk in "A Bell for Adano," a British officer of the Allied Military Government took the first steps here yesterday to obtain hardy chickens for the people of Trieste, Italy.

Bonds called before maturity for payment in December totaled $104,106,000, the smallest amount for any month since February, 1945, and the lowest total for any December since 1942. Prepayments of bonds last month compared with $180,555,000 redeemed in the preceding month and $591,704,000 in December, 1945.

The President's proclamation on the cessation of hostilities will result in major reductions in liquor prices when its tax implications become effective on July 1, liquor men said yesterday. But there is always the possibility that new tax levies may be made by Congress, they warned, because liquor represents the Government's principal source of commodity tax revenue.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 31-- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer today announced the assignment of character players to two important roles in the forthcoming screen versions of "The Hucksters" and "Cass Timperlane." Edward Arnold was named to play Dave Lash in "The Hucksters," with Clark Gable, Deborah Kerr and Adolphe Menjou, and Mary Astor was assigned to the role of Queenie Havoc in "Cass Timberlane," with Spencer Tracy.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 31--The Securities and Exchange Commission today set Jan. 8 for a hearing at its office in Cleveland to consider applications of the Cincinnati Stock Exchange to extend unlisted trading privileges to the common stocks of the following companies:

While the victors of the Second World War are still debating and disagreeing on their plans for their own armament reduction, they have reached perfect accord on at least one disarmament project--that for their former main enemy, Germany.

ALBANY, Dec. 31 -- The new State health program, which goes into operation tomorrow, will mean an increase of $8,000,000 in State aid to New York City in 1947, according to the budget estimate of the State Health Department. The increase in State aid for up-State communities is estimated at $2,090,000.

Supplies of softwood lumber will move more rapidly from mills to industrial users as a result of recent revision of the lumber limitation order L-359 by the Civilian Production Administration branch of the Office of Temporary Controls, it was learned yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31--President Truman in a surprise proclamation terminated formally the period of hostilities in World War II as of noon today.
Eight new public health records were set by New York City in 1946, Health Commissioner Israel Weinstein pointed out yesterday in his annual report to Mayor O'Dwyer.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 31 (AP)-- Football stars, fresh from college gridiron triumphs, will clash here tomorrow in the annual East-West game played for the benefit of the Shriners' crippled children's hospital.

The report of Robert R. Nathan, consulting economist for the Congress of Industrial Organizations, that general wage increases of 21 to 25 per cent can be made out of corporate profits without raising prices or productivity, would cost the Federal Government $2,200,000,000 annually in reduced yield on corporate taxes if the plan were carried out, according to the National Association of Manufacturers.

PEARL HARBOR, Dec. 31-- Creation of a unique joint command set-up in the central Pacific modeled along the lines of the Joint Chiefs of Staff in Washington was announced last night by Admiral John H. Towers, commander in chief of the Pacific and commander in chief of the Pacific Fleet.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31--The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 24, the Federal Reserve Board announced today:

The progress made in 1946 along the road to permanent peace was hailed yesterday by Clark M. Eichelberger, director of the American Association for the United Nations, in a New Year's message to the local branches of the organization, which is a successor to the old League of Nations Association.

HELSINKI, Finland, Dec. 31-- Moscow has in principle promised Finland transit privileges through the Porkkala enclave and the Saima Canal, ceded to the Soviet Union by the armistice, as Premier Maono Pekkala announced today.

Brought over from London, "Love Goes to Press," a distaff version of the Fourth Estate's "The Front Page," will be examined tonight at the Biltmore. To jog the memory of sentimentalists, may we remind them that the cozy house built by the fabulous Chanin Brothers during a high, wide and handsome era and now owned by Warners and George Abbott, came of age Dec. 7.

ALBANY, Dec. 31--Thomas E. Dewey, whose re-election last month by a record-setting majority put him in the vanguard of Republican Presidential possibilities in 1948, was sworn in informally tonight for a second four-year term as Governor in New York State.

Form Newspaper Ad Agency J. Robert York has resigned as Western manager of the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association, to become managing director of a newly organized advertising agency specializing exclusively in newspaper advertising.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 31--A member of the Political Action Committee for Palestine, which recently requested through Representative Joseph Clark Baldwin of New York, that Irgun Zvai Leumi cease terroristic acts, condoned today Sunday night's kidnapping and whipping of four British soldiers.

The southeast corner of Tenth Avenue and Twenty-seventh Street has been a pretty busy location for just about a year, but what had gone before was as nothing compared to the events of yesterday morning. Yesterday sixteen families moved into the twelve-story building put up on the site by the New York City Housing Authority, as part of the John Lovejoy Elliott Houses.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 31--Two former American Embassy officials were mentioned in an espionage trial that opened today in the Serbian Supreme Court.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) --Following is the text of President Truman's listing of laws which expire immediately, in six months, or at some other specified date under his proclamation ending hostilities in World War II (about 5,000):

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 31 (AP)-- The Sugar Bowl football teams came to town tonight, ready to show 73,000 observers tomorrow the comparative merits of Georgia's T-formation, featuring All-America Charlie Trippi, and North Carolina's single-wing, starring the sensational freshman, Charlie Justice.

LONDON, Dec. 31--The "Britain Can Make it" exhibition, arranged by industry here to furnish visual proof of its ability to compete in export markets, closed its doors today after a three months' "run" it the Victoria and Albert Museum.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Dec. 31 --Posters in streets and announcements in Communist newspapers gave the people of Budapest today their first official information--if it could be called that--of the arrests of army officers and RightWing members of the Small Holders' party during the last two weeks.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31--When the President, by proclaiming today the official end of World War II hostilities at noon, automatically terminated or specifically limited the lives of fifty-one statutes and restored to Congress the powers in them that were on indefinite loan to the Executive, he was following the precepts of his own political philosophy and also giving the Republicans a lesson in practical politics.

Longchamps is prepared to close its entire chain of restaurants next Monday if it fails to win an extension of its liquor license beyond that date, E. Allan Lustig, secretary of the concern, announced yesterday.

Cities that have within their boundaries large racial and cultural minorities not yet absorbed into community life were urged yesterday to promote small group and residential block organizations to encourage responsible community leadership.

New York's City Hall is a rugged testing ground for the man who sits in the Mayor's chair. William O'Dwyer has stood up well, in general, to the trial of his first year in office, a year which in some respects offered unusual difficulties. His administration has been devoid of scandal, achieved a reputation for honesty, and given the impression of serious-minded effort to govern well and humanely.

Six basketball authorities, representing coaching, officiating and sportswriting at Mexico City, arrived here yesterday for a ten-day study of American court methods and will make Madison Square Garden their first official stop tonight. They will be among the more than 18,000 persons present when L.I.U. clashes with Brigham Young and C.C.N.Y. takes on Oklahoma University.

BIRMINGHAM, England, Dec. 31 (U.P.)--A window in the Zionist center was smashed today by a brick thrown by one of three men who escaped in an automobile, according to the Birmingham Zionist Council. A spokesman attributed the incident to "repercussions of recent publicity against Palestine."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 31 --The United States proposed today that the United Nations Security Council give first priority in consideration of disarmament to the United States plan for international atomic control, which was approved unanimously yesterday by the Atomic Energy Commission.

One-third of this country's imports are now coming from South America along the six important sea lanes that link the two continents, according to a statement yesterday by the American Merchant Marine Institute.
Watch Night services were held last night in churches throughout the city, with many men in uniform among the worshipers.

Business leaders of the New York Board of Trade expressed a general optimism as to business conditions in 1947 but saw a number of major problems in the year ahead, according to statements released yesterday. H. L. Brooks, president, stated that the new year will be one of great decisions and must be approached in a spirit and atmosphere of mutual understanding.

TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 31 (UP)-- Mohammed Ali Homayundjah, the new Foreign Minister, said today that Russia had sent Iran a second "friendly note," asking about the status of the fifty-year SovietIranian oil agreement.

MOSCOW, Dec. 31 (AP)--D.V. Postnikov, assistant chairman of the Committee on Physical Culture and Sport of the U.S.S.R., said in an interview with The Associated Press today that the Soviet Union favored participation in inernational games.
Tenants or prospective occupants became the owners of several Manhattan buildings in deals reported yesterday.

"The new international significance of the treatment of racial and national minorities by the United States" was the "most striking development" in this country last year, the American Civil Liberties Union declared yesterday.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange ended the year with a flood of liquidating orders, and final prices were 17 to 36 points net lower than the day before.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- President Truman today wiped out the "GI Brides Act" and another law which made it easier for servicemen to bring alien brides home and have their children, born overseas, become United States cititzens.

WOODBURY, Conn., Dec. 31-- Francis Mairs Huntington Wilson of this place, former Assistant Secretary of State and well-known writer on international politics, died today in the New Haven Hospital at the age of 71.

LONDON, Dec. 31--The Honorary Order of Merit, one of Great Britain's highest honors, is conferred on John Gilbert Winant, the United States' wartime Ambassador in London, in the New Year's honors list.

DETROIT, Dec. 31 (AP)--Chevrolet Division of General Motors Corporation has unfilled orders on hand for more than 1,000,000 cars and trucks and looks to the year ahead with "sober optimism," according to T. H. Keating, general sales manager.

If the American people, including both management and labor will pull together 1947 "should be one of the best years we have ever had," it was declared yesterday by Earl Bunting, president of the National Association of Manufacturers.
LONDON, Wednesday, Jan. 1-- Britain's coal fields, the major natural resource of the nation, passed from private hands into Government ownership last midnight.

College athletic officials from all over the country will assemble here next week for the forty-first annual convention of the National Collegiate Athletic Association. The annual meetings of the American Football Coaches Association, the College Physical Education Association and the American Association of College Baseball Coaches will be held concurrently.

The Metropolitan Opera Association celebrated New Year's Eve last night with a far from happy opera. It was Verdi's "Rigoletto" presented for the first time this season, with Lawrence Tibbett making his seasonal bow in the title role.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The Republican Steering Committee of the Senate, which will decide majority policy there for the next two years, decided unanimously today to seek to prevent Senator Theodore G. Bilbo, Democrat, of Mississippi, from sitting in the upper chamber.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday that it has decided not to offer at competitive sale the $13,000,000 of 2 3/4 per cent convertible debentures not subscribed for by stockholders out of an original preferential offering of $343,087,700 which expired Dec. 16.

Indications that 1947 may be one of the biggest peacetime construction years on record, with twice as many homes completed as in 1946, are seen by L. M. Cassidy, vice president for sales of the JohnsManville Corporation. He also predicts a better value for the home builder's dollar in the spring and summer of this year.

California School District An issue of 5490,000 of school bonds of Palo Verde Unified School District, Riverside County, Calif., was awarded yesterday to Barkus, Kindred Co. and associates at a bid of 100.60 for 3s. The issue will come due on each Feb. 1 from 1948 to 1972.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31--The following table shows how President Truman's proclamation will affect excise taxes beginning July 1:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31--Republican leaders gravely saluted today President Truman's summary surrender of many wartime powers, but pledged the new Congress to thrust into the whole subject with the objective of removing many more emergency controls.

New York sent the old year out last night with pre-war din. Times Square's canyons echoed to the most tremendous blast of revelers' horns and bells since 1940. The crowds generally, though, tended to think twice before they spent, and drinking did not reach predicted heights.

Holidays Cut Buyers' Total Visiting buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday totaled sixty-two compared with 184 in the preceding week and 119 in the corresponding week last year, according to the lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

ATHENS, Dec. 31--King George's New Year address to the people, published tonight, describes the country as "hit by injustice and mourning the victims of internal strife." He said, however, that there were cheerful prospects for 1947 because of the interest taken by other nations in Greece's welfare.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31--Representative Clarence J. Brown of Ohio withdrew tonight from the increasingly bitter race for the majority floor leadership of the House of Representatives in the new Republican-controlled Congress.

The avalanche of retroactive portal-to-portal pay suits that is sweeping down upon employers throughout the nation might have been averted if Congress had heeded a recommendation made by the Wage-Hour Administration in 1944, legal authorities pointed out yesterday.

PARIS, Dec. 31 (U.P.) -- French troops have beaten off attacks by the Indo-Chinese Viet Nam rebels on the big port of Haiphong and the town of Bacninh, nineteen miles northeast of Hanoi, the capital, French official dispatches said today.

Tugboat operators and workers here are now closer together than at any time in the past two months of negotiations, with a settlement held likely at a meeting scheduled for tomorrow afternoon, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31--President Truman's proclamation ending war hostilities was preceded by a few minutes today by Government seizure "lock, stock and barrel" of the valuable West Virginia properties of the Carter Coal Company, which from now on will be operated for the Government's own account and at its risk.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 31 --The state of the world leaves no room for "easy optimism," but the work of the United Nations during he last year has laid a solid foundation for the building of the peace, Secretary General Trygve Lie declared today in a New Year's message.
Industrial leaders greeted with enthusiasm here yesterday the Presidential proclamation ending the period of hostilities.

A show-down in the long-considered proposals by the board of directors of Transcontinental Western Air, Inc., for alleviation of the airline's serious financial ills is forecast for tomorrow when Howard Hughes, the principal stockholder and opponent of suggested financial remedies, is expected to meet the directors for the first time.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31--The Department of Agriculture said today that a hearing on all fluid milk prices in the Northeast will be held here "early in the week of Jan. 6."
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 31--Registration statements covering 912,464 shares of common and 25,000 shares of preferred stock were filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission today by three companies.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 31 (AP)--A fast, tricky Rice Institute football team and the Tennessee Volunteers, noted for their alertness, will meet in near midsummer weather in the Orange Bowl tomorrow before a capacity crowd of 38,000.

A propaganda effort helpful only to the Soviet Union and harmful to the United States is under way throughout Latin America through formal channels of the Communist party, including its newspapers and radio stations. It is aided by the activities of PanSlav movements, "front" groups and, to some extent, by the official information service of the Latin American Federation of Labor (CTAL).
WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Jan. 1--At midnight last night the destinies of America's atomic energy production passed from military to civilian control.
Joseph W. Frazer, president of the Kaiser - Frazer Corporation, predicted yesterday that the nation "should get the 5,000,000 automobiles it needs in 1947," if it is kept free of serious strikes.

A year of abnormal price movements was completed yesterday by the stock market, with a belated and conservative rally. The year was the first one since 1941 for prices to show a recession although volume for the twelve months was one of the largest in the last nine years.

LONDON, Dec. 31--Labor in Britain is solidly behind the nationalization program because it believes it presages an era in which the people will have a voice in the operation of major industries here, George Thompson, president of the Trades Union Congress, said today.
TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 31-- Simplicity will mark the inauguration Jan. 21 of Alfred E. Driscoll of Haddonfield as Governor of New Jersey.

SINGAPORE, Dec. 31--Neutral observers arriving in Singapore from Batavia report that the situation in Java has seriously deteriorated since the departure, on Nov. 30, of the last of the British Army units. These had served as a buffer between the Dutch and the Indonesian Republicans.

GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 31-- Burglars who moved with the legendary soft-footed silence of Santa Claus and then reversed the jolly fellow's role by using a sled to haul away rather than leave riches, entered the home here of Bernard F. Gimbel, New York department store executive last night.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 31--The creation of the Preparatory Commission of the International Refugee Organization was made possible today when Liberia became the eighth United Nations member to sign the IRO Constitution.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The tragic death of Alexander H. Pekelis in the plane crash on the Shannon highlights the fate of honest European intellectuals through the last thirty years.

PARIS, Dec. 31--The withdrawal of the French garrison at Phulangthuong to the stronger position at Bacninh, northeast of Hanoi, was announced today by the French staff in Indo-China. The garrison, which had been isolated for two weeks, had been rescued by the advance of a reinforcement column from Haiphong.

PARIS, Dec. 31--Already beset by pressing wage demands from labor in general, the French Government was confronted today with strong expressions of dissatisfaction from its own employes with plans to readjust salaries.
Joseph Stack, militant vice president of the National Maritime Union, CIO, notified his colleagues yesterday that he was resigning.

PARIS, Dec. 31 -- The most striking move yet made against the rising spiral of inflation in France was announced by Premier Leon Blum tonight when he told the country that the Government had decided on a general 5 per cent reduction of all prices effective on Thursday.
ROME, Dec. 31--At the end of a seven-hour session of the Italian Cabinet this evening a communique indicated sharp differences between the Premier and Socialist and Communist members of the Cabinet.
HOUSTON, Tex., Dec. 31 (AP)-- Continued rain and near-freezing temperatures today emphasized the favored position of Georgia Tech for tomorrow's Oil Bowl game with St. Mary's of California.

NEWARK, Dec. 31--State troopers escorted three automobile loads of "relief workers" into the Stateseized Public Service gas plant at Harrison at 2:30 A.M. today. The move was executed so swiftly that eight sleepy pickets were unaware of what was happening until the cars were inside the plant.

LONDON, Dec. 31--Virtually every section in the stock markets today finished the year in style. Dealings started for the new account, and with buyers ignoring the shortage of industrial coal prices finished well up.

ABOARD MOUNT OLYMPUS, at Sea, Dec. 31--Five ships of the United States Navy's Antarctic task force today nosed into the loose fringes of the ice pack, the last barrier that bars them from their goal--Little America.

BOSTON, Dec. 31--The $1,000 prize of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, awarded for a noteworthy paper presented at its annual winter meeting, was divided this year among two teams of scientific workers.

In every age and every country there has been some holiday set aside to celebrate the New Year. We hope no ethnologist will arise, out of the depths of his knowledge, to state that there is a remote island or an isolated mountain valley where this is not so; or that there have been tribes and even whole civilizations, long since died out, in which it was not so.
BOSTON, Dec. 31 (AP)--Mayor James M. Curley tonight asked the Rev. John J. Cavanaugh, C.S.C., president of Notre Dame, to replace Army with Boston College on the Irish football schedule.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31--Ernie Adamson announced tonight his resignation as counsel to the House Committee on Un-American Activities, a position which would end on Friday anyway.

BERLIN, Dec. 31--Among the peculiar by-products of the German political reorientation resulting from the defeat of Hitler, one of the most peculiar is a book of political nursery rhymes just issued by the Socialist Unity party [SED] here.

DALLAS, Dec. 31 (AP)--The Cotton Bowl dug out from under a heavy snow today and gave promise of a dry field at game time tomorrow, but it was just the kind of weather Coach Bernie Moore of Louisiana State feared for the clash with Arkansas--freezing, numbing cold to which the Ozark Razorbacks aye much more accustomed than the Bayou Tigers.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 31 (AP)--Showing the benefit of having one recent race over the track, the Oran Lodge Stable's Dance Team, a 25-to-1 shot in the field of 12, surprised most of 10,012 fans by winning the Isinglass Purse at Tropical Park today.

Verdict of Time Prof. Carlos Baker's brilliant comment on the four volumes of Thackeray letters in THE TIMES Book Review last Sunday naturally does not suffer from the fact that his views are strongly shared by this department.
Two restaurants ended the year on a sour note as hold-up men escaped with $326, in addition to carting off thirty cases of liquor in a station wagon shortly after midnight yesterday.

Expansion of the efforts of the Better Business Bureaus of the country to conserve and protect consumer buying power accumulated through savings during the war years is embodied in plans for 1947, according to H. J. Kenner, general manager of the Better Business Bureau of New York City, in his year-end statement.

NANKING, Dec. 31--His policy of continuing to attempt to settle the dispute with the Communists through political means was reiterated by President Chiang Kaishek in a New Year's broadcast, made public here tonight.

TOKYO, Dec. 31--Gen. Douglas MacArthur in a year-end statement on the occupation's progress declared today that Japan had made "major advances" toward the establishment of a liberal social system. He gave high praise to a great majority of Japanese leaders for this "exemplary approach to the realism of Japan's problems."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31--The Department of Justice, the Chesapeake Ohio group of railroads, Otis Co., and a group of fortysix railroads desirous of purchasing the stock of the Pullman Company for about $40,000,000 filed briefs with the Interstate Commerce Commission today.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 31-- New Hampshire University's skiers established themselves as one of the nation's top teams by gaining an overwhelming margin in the second day of the Lake Placid Club Sno Birds' twenty-sixth annual college ski competition.

Alvin J. Paris, the novelty salesman who is accused of trying to "fix" the New York Giants-Chicago Bears professional football game for the benefit of a gambling syndicate, will go on trial tomorrow morning in General Sessions Court on an indictment charging attempted bribery.

Mrs. Mary Berkeley Finke, loan officer and manager of the women's department of the Industrial Bank of Commerce, 56 East Fortysecond Street, retired yesterday after twenty years of service with the bank. She will continue to act as a consultant on budgets and family income problems.

Supporters of Governor Dewey were the losers in a fight to keep the annual Lincoln Day dinner of the National Republican Club on a strictly local basis, it was learned yesterday. As a result Harold E. Stassen of Minnesota, the only avowed Republican presidential candidate to date, probably will be the principal speaker at the affair.

The angler and hunter, who is normal in other respects, despite some opinion to the contrary, probably will prove this normality today by drawing up a list of resolutions, but he will keep only those which he finds to be convenient or pleasant during the next twelve months.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 31 (AP)--Supporters of North Carolina State and Oklahoma began arriving in increasing numbers tonight on the eve of their New Year's Day football game in the Gator Bowl.

SHANGHAI, Dec. 31--The student protest against the alleged rape of a Peiping girl student by a United States Marine on Christmas Eve spread to Shanghai today. Divided sentiment among university undergraduates kept the antiAmerican demonstrations from assuming major proportions.

Action to evict the Soviet Russian consular staff from its imposing white granite consulate at 7 East Sixty-first Street was undertaken in Federal Court yesterday by the mansion's owner, Mrs. Ruth Pratt, former member of Congress, who heads the Women's National Republican Club.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The omission of a Canadian interview in your round-up of world living conditions seems to me to call for some explanation, particularly since THE TIMES is one of the few, if not the only, American newspaper which maintains a full-time resident correspondent in Canada.

Miss Helen Theis, 24 years old, a pretty brunette who hid her horse race bookmaking in a veritable rabbit warren in the Harlem apartment she called the Donna Reigh Kennel Club, gasped and reached for support yesterday in the Gamblers Court when Magistrate Robert F. Mahoney sentenced her to a thirty-day workhouse term after fining her $100.

WHEN I consider how my life is spent Swimming against a mighty tide of books, In peril grave of being overcome By ink and paper, glue and countless words, My lot seems hopeless and I mourn my fate. Were it not better done as others use To dig the useful ditch, to practice law, To mend the leaking pipe, to soothe the sick,

BERLIN, Dec. 31--The Soviet Union is fast moving toward a point at which it can be expected to agree to the unification of Germany at the Foreign Ministers' Conference in Moscow in March, provided a reasonable economic concession is received in return, in the opinion of highly placed United States Military Government officials.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31 (U.P)--Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in at least eight cities were reported attempting tonight to trace a $75,000 emerald ring, missing since an airliner on which it was shipped was forced down at Moline, Ill.

Concluding a year which showed a sharp contraction in new bond financing and a marked increase in stock flotations, public offerings of new securities in December were smaller than in the corresponding month, of 1945.

On Oct. 14, last, when he addressed the nation by radio to announce the removal of price ceilings on livestock and food products, President Truman declared: "I have directed all the agencies of government to cooperate in speeding [other decontrol] plana to an extent compatible with our economic security."

The national junior indoor tennis championship is certain to remain in Brooklyn. This was determined yesterday at the Fourteenth Regiment Armory, Brooklyn, when Sidney Schwartz and Leonard Steiner, both residents of that borough, emerged triumphantly from their respective semi-final round encounters and made possible an allBrooklyn final at 1:15 P.M. today.

The most comprehensive effort yet undertaken to bring together the viewpoints of unions, employers and economists on proposals for revising laws regulating labormanagement relations is being made by the labor committee of the Twentieth Century Fund, it was learned yesterday.
City and State mediators brightened the advent of the New Year for New York's 7,750,000 residents yesterday by winning union agreements to defer three threatened strikes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP)-- The Treasury announced today the unblocking of United States located assets of persons in China, The Netherlands East Indies French Indo-China, Turkey and non-European colonies and territories of liberated countries.

The final decree determining the Government's nine-year-old antitrust suit against the major motion picture producers and distributors was issued yesterday afternoon by the special statutory court composed of United States District Judges John Bright and Henry W. Goddard and Judge Augustus N. Hand of the Circuit Court of Appeals.

A shot from a sawed-off shotgun concealed in a gaily wrapped Christmas package made to look as if it held a camera critically injured a Brooklyn woman on the crowded Times Square station of the BMT at 9:45 A.M. yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31--So far as the Army and Navy are concerned, spokesmen indicated today. President Truman's proclamation will have little major effect. The great body of wartime emergency measures pertaining to them remains in effect.

The 22,900-ton President Cleveland, the first of two large passenger liners under construction by the Maritime Commission for the transpacific trade, will be delivered to the American President Lines on April 1, it was announced yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 31--Argentina took virtual control of all grain marketing today. Under a decree issued by the Ministry of Industry and Commerce, the Government was appointed sole internal buyer and, by implication, exporter of all bird seed, oats, barley, rye and sorghum.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31--The Tennessee Valley Authority, now producing and selling electricity at the rate of more than 12,000,000,000 kilowatts a year, is doing a bigger post-war business than it did even at its wartime peak.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 31 (AP) --The University of California at Los Angeles Bruins remained firm favorites tonight to defeat the fighting Illini from the University of Illinois as champions of the Pacific Coast and Big Nine Conferences went into seclusion on the eve of their battle in the Rose Bowl tomorrow.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31--Announcement by President Truman that hostilities had ended, which will bring to an end many Government emergency powers within six months, failed to have much effect today as a price-making influence in grains on the Board of Trade.

TOKYO, Dec. 31--Premier Shigeru Yoshida, in a New Year's message to the Japanese people which is probably the strongest utterance of his long political career, today lashed out at the tactics of Japanese Left Wing and labor groups and threatened Japan with a loss of Allied sympathy should these disruptive maneuvers continue.

MOSCOW, Dec. 31--The establishment of a "permanent" American base in Antarctica is connected with United States efforts to strengthen its position in the field of atomic energy, says an article in today's issue of Red Star, the Army's newspaper.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31--By a vote of two to one the National Labor Relations Board ordered the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation today to bargain with an affiliate of the United Mine Workers of America (AFL) having supervisory officials among its members.

MINDEN, Germany, Dec. 31-- In another maneuver designed to spur the Ruhr's coal output, German economic advisers proposed an "incentive plan" today to the British authorities. They asserted it would raise production 20 per cent within a month and 30 per cent at the end of two months.

Dodd, Mead reports that Mrs. Mary L. Jobe Akeley, explorer and author of books of African adventure, has departed for Leopoldville, in the Belgian Congo. The Belgian Government has commissioned her to make a survey of wild-life sanctuaries and national parks in the Belgian Congo.

An appeal to Congress to have the reduction in Federal "nuisance" taxes effective immediately rather than on July 1 was seen as a possibility in trade circles here yesterday on the ground that the late date may cause many consumers to postpone purchases of high cost unit items.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31--President Truman's proclamation ending hostilities will reduce consumers' taxes by about $1,500,000,000 annually, beginning July 1. Excise levies on a score of "luxuries," including liquor, furs, jewelry and night clubs, will automatically revert to peacetime levels on that date, as provided by the Revenue Act of 1943.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The House Campaign Expenditures Investigating Committee, dissatisfied with the necessarily limited nature of its inquiry, refrained today from any recommendation as to the right of Representative Vito Marcantonio to be seated in the new Congress.

VIENNA, Dec. 31--Whether Austria will be able to obtain a peace treaty she can accept probably will become evident in actions or hints from the Kremlin within the next ten days before the Big Four deputies convene in London. The only acceptable treaty for Austria will be one that restores her political and economic independence.

MOSCOW, Dec. 31--The economic union of the United States and British zones of occupation in Germany violates the Potsdam agreement and is contrary to the Soviet view that Germany should be treated as an economic and political unit, according to Izvestia, Government newspaper.

Exchanges Closed Today The nation's securities and commodities exchanges will be closed today in observance of New Year's. Canadian markets and London exchanges also will close for the holiday. Most domestic exchanges curtailed hours yesterday or introduced festivity to the waning trading moments of 1946.
LONDON, Dec. 31--The Air Ministry summed up its report on British weather during 1946, issued today, with these words: "Dull, wet and cool." As an epitaph for the year just ending, it serves.
