More than eight hours after a four-alarm fire had burned out the upper floors of a seven-story loft building at 749 Broadway, near East Eighth Street, last night, two firemen remained trapped early this morning in the ruins of the lower part of the structure.

BERLIN, Dec. 31--On the eve of the official economic unification of the British and American zones tomorrow, it was disclosed today that the United States and Britain were prepared to prime the pump of German industry with a vast import program capable of raising exports from western Germany to $1,900,000,000 annually by the end of 1949 so that at least the AngloAmerican-controlled portion of the country would be able to pay its own way.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31--"With God's Help," said President Truman's proclamation ending hostilities and relaxing Government controls, "this nation and our Allies * * * wrung final and unconditional surrender from our enemies. * * *"

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 31--The normally mild and taciturn former schoolmaster, Premier Mahmoud Fahmy Nokrashy Pasha, made so unexpectedly vigorous a demand upon the British Government in the Chamber of Deputies tonight that even his most bitter opponents wrung his hand in congratulations and a patriotic demonstration broke out there.

This is a column of "honorable mentions." It is a discussion of outstanding food products introduced in 1946--not all of them, of course. We gave them a welcome when they first appeared, and we remind you of them now so that you may continue to find them of help during 1947.

DETROIT, Dec. 31--The United Automobile Workers, Congress of Industrial Organizations, in a surprise move, directed today that each of its more than 800,000 members donate one dollar to an "international strike fund" by Feb. 1, 1947, or face automatic suspension for noncompliance on March 31.

A father who already had sent one gift to the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund in memory of his son lost in action June 20, 1943, aboard a Flying Fortress, yesterday gave a second donation of $5. He explained:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31--"With God's Help," said President Truman's proclamation ending hostilities and relaxing Government controls, "this nation and our Allies * * * wrung final and unconditional surrender from our enemies. * * *"

Two Brooklyn officials of the Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators and Paperhangers, AFL, were indicted yesterday by the Kings County grand jury on a charge of extorting $3,500. Arraigned before Judge Franklin Taylor, the pair pleaded not guilty and were released in $10,000 bail each to await trial.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 31--The normally mild and taciturn former schoolmaster, Premier Mahmoud Fahmy Nokrashy Pasha, made so unexpectedly vigorous a demand upon the British Government in the Chamber of Deputies tonight that even his most bitter opponents wrung his hand in congratulations and a patriotic demonstration broke out there.

This is a column of "honorable mentions." It is a discussion of outstanding food products introduced in 1946--not all of them, of course. We gave them a welcome when they first appeared, and we remind you of them now so that you may continue to find them of help during 1947.

DETROIT, Dec. 31--The United Automobile Workers, Congress of Industrial Organizations, in a surprise move, directed today that each of its more than 800,000 members donate one dollar to an "international strike fund" by Feb. 1, 1947, or face automatic suspension for noncompliance on March 31.

A father who already had sent one gift to the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund in memory of his son lost in action June 20, 1943, aboard a Flying Fortress, yesterday gave a second donation of $5. He explained:

A father whose son was killed on Saipan sent a gift yesterday to the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund of THE NEW YORK TIMES. The letter accompanying the donation read: "I would like to make a contribution of $10 toward your Hundred Neediest Cases Fund 'in memory of my son, Corp. William A. Hartman, USMC, who made the supreme sacrifice on Saipan Island.'

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Dec. 31 (Delayed)--Lack of confidence in the future of Europe has infected a people as steady as the Dutch to the extent that 2,000,000 of them--22 per cent of the population --wish to leave Holland forever and seek better fortune elsewhere.

LONDON, Jan. 1 (Reuters) -- Scots roared with holiday enthusiasm to a full football schedule today with top excitement when the Rangers, Division A leaders, were held to a 1-1 draw by their ancient enemy, Celtic.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 1--Despite an unusually high percentage of changes in key personnel of the Securities and Exchange Commission, including the resignations of two commissioners and the death of a third, the year 1946 proved to be one of the most significant in the history of the commission.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Jan. 1 -- Jocular but politically uncommunicative, Mayor Frank Hague parried questions from reporters today as he shook hands with 3,000 well wishers at his annual New Year's Day reception in City Hall.

Leonard Steiner, 18-year-old senior at Brooklyn Tech, is the new national junior indoor tennis champion. At the Fourteenth Regiment Armory in his home borough yesterday he defeated the defending titleholder, Sidney Schwartz, also a Brooklynite, 6--3, 6--8, 6--4, 7--9, 6--0, in the title round.

"It would seem logical to expect that during the coming twelvemonth the seven-eighths of 1 percent one-year rate for Government debt will be sustained, and the long-term 2 1/2 per cent rate as well," according to a year-end survey of the Government bond market by Malon S. Andrus, vice president of C.F. Childs Co.

DETROIT, Jan. 1--The four international officers of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, joined today in issuing a statement defending the collection of portal-toportal pay claims in the automotive industry as an exercise of a worker's right under the Wage and Hour Act.

Early resumption of international travel is necessary to the world's well-being, Lord Hacking, chairman of the British Travel Association, declared yesterday when he arrived here on the Queen Elizabeth.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1--A bill which would sweep away all portal pay suits and would in fact nullify the claim of pay for travel and make-ready time in industry was made ready today by Representative Clare E. Hoffman, Republican, of Michigan, for introduction in the new Congress.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1--In terms of service it is an unusually youthful group of Senators who, headed by Mr. Taft, form the steering committee on policy which will outline the legislative program of the new Senate majority.

The singers set for both principal roles in last night's "Il Trovatore" at the Metropolitan Opera House became indisposed yesterday, so there were two substitutions. Kurt Baum sang Manrico in place of Jussi Bjoerling and Regina Resnik sang Leonora in place of Stella Roman.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Jan. 1--Under conditions befitting its name, the sixteenth annual Frostbite regatta was held today on Manhasset Bay. Two races were sailed in the snowstorm with the thermometer at 28 degrees.

The nation's economical capacity for producing new aluminum is four times as great as in the highest pre-war year, and amounts to more than a billion pounds yearly, according to George R. Gibbons, senior vice president of the Aluminum Company of America.
ALBANY, Jan. 1--Starting his second term as Governor, Thomas E. Dewey asserted today that he will devote his administrative efforts to advancing the dignity, liberty and security of the individual.

BERLIN, Jan. 1 (AP)--The American Military Government soon will announce for the United States zone of Germany a law requiring dissolution of all enterprises employing more than 10,000 persons, it was learned from a high official source today.

The year 1946 turned out to be one of May-and-December disillusionment for the market for new capital, but out of the ups and downs came a new understanding and basis for cooperation between securities dealers and the Securities and Exchange Commission.

PARIS, Jan. 1--The French Press Agency reported today that French forces had overcome another rebellion in Indo-China, this time in Western Cambodia at the opposite extremity from strife torn Tongking in the North.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 1--One of the outstanding collections of handwoven rugs to be seen in this area is included in the exhibit of arts and crafts from the Cranbrook Academy of Art, Bloomfield Hills, Mich., that opened today at the Newark Museum.

With many evidences last year that arbitration was on the march throughout America and the world, its future prospects are brighter than at any time in history despite the turmoil and confusion that greet the New Year, it was declared yesterday by R. Emerson Swart, president of the American Arbitration Association.

Nearly a million Jews in foreign lands were aided in 1946 by the Joint Distribution Committee, which spent $58,500,000 in carrying out the organization's most ambitious and extensive relief program since its founding thirty-two years ago, Edward M.M. Warburg, chairman, announced yesterday in a year-end review.

WELL, things are getting back to normal gradually. It seems like old times to see a new historical novel by Kenneth Roberts, author of "Northwest Passage" and "Oliver Wiswell" and "Rabble in Arms" and the rest. "Lydia Bailey"* is his first in some six years. It is an entertaining chronicle of strange and familiar adventures, battles and incarcerations and pursuits, stratagems and scandals and shenanigans, all strung on a mildly preposterous plot.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 1 (AP)--The thrills were plentiful at Tropical Park today as the new year of racing began, one of the morning program highlights occurring in the featured Dade County Handicap, when the Frances Stable's Tarpan survived a four-way nose finish to return $21.90 for $2.

Halloran General Hospital on Staten Island, one of the largest and most modern Army medical institutions in the United States at which 162,252 wounded and ill soldiers of World War II received treatment, was transferred yesterday to the Veterans Adminsitration.

Mutual savings bank deposits, approaching 17,000,000,000 as the new year begins, are at the highest point in the 130 years of these institution's service to the nation, according to a year-end statement by A. George Gilman, president of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks.

The task of maintaining productive employment stability at its highest possible level requires continuous cooperation between Government, business, agriculture and labor, effected through appropriate institutional arrangements, it was stated in a report made public yesterday by Winthrop W. Aidrich, president of the International Chamber of Commerce.

Last year was eventful for the cotton industry, with a short crop and heavy demand both here and abroad. In the effort to catch up with a long-deferred civilian demand for cotton goods, the heavy cotton surplus, which has been a problem for many years, virtually was eliminated.

The nation's rubber manufacturing industry, vastly expanded since 1941 to satisfy military demands, met the test of even greater peacetime needs in 1946, hanging up new records in every branch of production. For the first time in history, annual rubber consumption topped the million-ton mark.

Under the assumption that much of the post-war price inflation is past and that any "virulent" inflation psychology is improbable, the First Boston Corporation concludes in a study of business requirements and interest rates that the following fundamentals are essential if a major depression is to be avoided:
SINGAPORE, Jan. 1--Anthony Brooke, former Rajah Muda of Sarawak, arrived here from Hong Kong today to press his campaign for a re-examination of Sarawak's cession to the Crown last June.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 1--Gov. Walter E. Edge served notice tonight on the 400 striking production workers at the Harrison gas plant of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company that the arbitration panel would not take up their case until they returned to their jobs.

The can manufacturing industry enters the year with a demand that is undiminished from 1946 and has ample manufacturing capacity to meet this demand but the ability to supply depends upon the amount of tinplate the mills can produce, it was said yesterday by D.W. Figgis, president, American Can Company.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1.--Keen Johnson, Under Secretary of Labor, said tonight that he had no fear that wage and salary increases achieved through genuine collective bargaining would bring on an economic slump.

THIS will have to start off with an apology. It goes to the clever H. I. Phillips of the neighboring Sun Dial for supplying the idea. This is his tune with different lyrics, the musical accompaniment to a slightly foggy view through a crystal ball. What does the future year hold in sports? Ah! That's a question. Gather round, kiddies, and we shall see what we shall see.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 1 (AP)--A United States Army officer was beaten on the head with bamboo canes, an attempt was made to disrobe his girl companion and an Associated Press photographer, seeking to film the incident, received a black eye from Chinese students today in a continuation of anti-American demonstrations.

The Panama liner Cristobal, now undergoing the final stages of reconversion at the Todd shipyards. Brooklyn, after long service as a troopship, will be completed in mid-January and make her first post-war trip in the New YorkCanal Zone service on Feb. 5, it was announced yesterday.

Beardsley Ruml, chairman of the board and a Class C director of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, has resigned from both posts, it has been announced. Mr. Ruml, who is also chairman of the board of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., took the action because of "the demands on his time from other public activities," it was said by Reserve Bank officials here.

PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 1 (U.P.) --Illinois, with its fleet, pony backs putting on one of the greatest offensive displays ever seen in the Rose Bowl, raced to an easy 45-to-14 victory over the University of California at Los Angeles today before 90,000 fans in the annual New Year's Day football clsssic.

An outstanding demand for paper products will present the industry during 1947 with one of its most productive years, according to Alexander Calder, president of the Union Bag Paper Corporation, in his year-end statement.
The following is the fifth of a series of six articles by a NEW YORK TIMES correspondent on communism in Latin America. The concluding article will appear tomorrow.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Jan. 1 (AP)-- The Pepperdine College Waves from Los Angeles came from behind in the second half to blast Nebraska Wesleyan University's Plainsmen today, 38--13, in the first annual Will Rogers Bowl football game before 800 chilled fans.

The new year got off to a bad start early yesterday for three women who were carried off in their own automobile by a well-groomed young gunman, robbed of furs and jewels valued at $15,000 and left standing coatless on the sidewalk in the pre-dawn cold.

The food industry is approaching the new year with a large package of troubles engendered by inability to effect a smooth transition from war to peacetime conditions, by growing production surpluses in most lines and by abnormal continuing shortages in such essential items as sugar, fats, oils and soap.

Governor Dewey's inaugural address yesterday dealt, as it was appropriate that it should deal, with the broad purposes of his second term in office. There will be time enough for details when he sends his annual message to the State Legislature a few days from now.

LONDON, Jan. 1--First indications of a possible settlement for troubled Palestine came today when a British official source promised "full and serious consideration" of proposals to divide the Holy Land into independent Jewish and Arab states.

Predicting that 1947 would see an end of indiscriminate buying by the public, Benjamin H. Namm, president of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, said yesterday that retailing had a "supreme opportunity to lead the way in re-establishing a normal consumers' market."
LONDON, Jan. 1--Considerable confusion about the significance of President Truman's announcement of the end of hostilities prevails in Britain.
JERUSALEM, Jan. 1 (U.P.)--Tension approached the breaking point in Palestine tonight as the Irgun Zvai Leumi announced that it would resume attacks on communications and military transport.

Working under a nine-State alarm the police searched the city yesterday for some trace of Al Rocco, who is accused of masterminding a bizarre shooting plot to inflict injury or death upon his former wife while she unsuspectingly walked a subway platform in Times Square.

Such economic vicissitudes as strikes in blue-chip industries, material shortages and inability to produce for an unprecedented demand were reflected last year in the erratic behavior of securities traded on the great New York exchanges.

More babies born than during any previous year, a new all-time low in infant and maternal death rates, a decline in tuberculosis--it is with the publication of such facts on the city's health during 1946 that Commissioner Israel Weinstein of the Department of Health ushers in the new year.

Ending the first full calendar year of peace, the textile and apparel industries looked upon 1946 as a year of record output in a difficult transitional period. If production is the key to a prosperous economy, manufacturers of soft goods contributed more than their full measure, it was pointed out.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: THE TIMES is to be commended for its service in drowning an extreme and unsound argument raised in opposition to a program of peacetime military training. Young men who have matured in the environment of good homes and healthy associations can gain much from such an experience in establishing a firm sense of values.

The outlook for business generally in 1947 is good and department store sales during the first half should continue somewhere near the present high levels, according to Jack I. Straus, president, R.H. Macy Co., Inc.

Despite temporary setbacks that may delay the attainment of full production and distribution, the C.I.T. Financial Corporation looks for a real increase in the use of consumer credit this year, it was declared in an annual statement by Arthur O. Dietz, president of the corporation and its affiliates.

BOSTON, Jan. 1 (AP)--Scoring twice within one minute and thirtynine seconds, the Boston Bruins regained the National Hockey League's victory road by forging from behind for a 3-1 triumph over the New York Rangers tonight before a crowd of 13,900 at the Boston Garden.

LONDON, Jan. 1 -- An official denial was issued tonight of reports that the British Cabinet has discussed the possibility of marriage between Princess Elizabeth and Prince Philip of Greece or that the British Dominions had been consulted on the subject.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown, tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- The State Department today set early dates for hearings on a provisional charter for an International Trade Organization.
LONDON, Jan. 1 -- The War Office announced today the retirement of Maj. Gen. Sir Frederick E. Morgan, effective last Sunday. He has received the honorary rank of lieutenant general.

DETROIT, Jan. 1--The automotive industry, confronted with new wage demands and still perplexed by shortages of parts and materials, enters 1947 with an outlook "iffier" than that of a year ago, when the strike against the General Motors Corporation was at its height.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 1 (AP)--Oklahoma, mixing speed and power with deception, overwhelmed North Carolina State, 34--13, in the second annual Gator Bowl football game today.
A fatal stabbing, an attempted kidnapping, a knife and pistol duel and several incidents of disorderly conduct marked New Year's Eve and the early part of the new year's first day.
Transport and other shipping schedules still are subject to changes and frequently are incomplete. Dates are considered tentative.

With the demand three times the supply, current production of plastics is about double that of 1941, W. Stuart Landes, president of the Plastics Materials Manufacturers Association, reports in a year-end review of the industry.

Many homefurnishings items in extremely short supply at the beginning of 1946 moved into a partial or complete buyers' market during the year and a number of others are expected to strike a satisfactory supply-demand balance during 1947, trade leaders predicted yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In connection with F. Rothgiesser's letter concerning the treatment of exGerman Jews in Holland, published in your issue of Dec. 12, I would like to point out that the situation described therein unfortunately does not apply to Holland alone.

BERLIN, Jan. 1--Dining out in Berlin is a major adventure in these days of disintegration and foreign occupation. Always known to epicures as the home of bad food badly prepared, Berlin today at first glimpse gives the impression that there is no dining out at all--only tawdry night clubs and cabarets.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP)-- Any idea occupation troops might have had about getting home early because of President Truman's proclamation of the end of hostilities was dashed tonight by the War Department.

Retail trade in 1946 reached record levels in dollar volume that may not be exceeded for some time to come. Stiff price advances during the year held the gain in unit turnover of merchandise to small proportions. As 1947 arrives a stiff price shakedown appears in prospect, which may be well under way by July 1, when war excise taxes are cut from 20 to 10 per cent on furs, luggage, jewelry and toilet goods.

Today we deal with the abnormal diet, the one unusually low in calories and carbohydrates, which is necessary for diabeties and which is often difficult for them to maintain, particularly in a household where the other members can eat pretty much what they please.

TORONTO, Jan. 1 (AP)-- Outscoring their opponents in the second period, in which all the goals were tallied, the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight defeated the Detroit Red Wings, 2--1, in a National Hockey League game before a crowd of 12,791.

Savings banks here, along with banks generally, had during 1946 a prosperous year. Deposits continued to rise and while the withdrawals increased at an even more rapid rate, there is no indication that it will exceed deposits in the near future.
ROME, Jan. 1--Albania openly accused the United States Government of interfering in her internal affairs by promoting sabotage activities, it was learned today.

Stabilization of commodity prices and of labor relations so that management and labor can come to agreement in providing greater efficiency in production are the principal factors in the continuing prosperity expected this year by leaders in American business and foreign trade, the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., said yesterday.

Record backlogs and firm orders for durable goods, equipment, tool and machinery lines now on hand point to 1947 prospects for stabilized production at a high level, with the major trend of increased productivity in evidence as assurance of a strong upward surge of this field of business.

An offer intended to heal the split within the Consistory of the Collegiate Reformed Dutch Church or the City of NEW YORK, the governing body of the five Collegiate Reformed churches here, will be made by the majority at a meeting tonight, it was learned yesterday.

Working capital of $250,000 will be lent to the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York, 425 Avenue of the Americas, without interest by the Rockefeller Foundation, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Willard C. Rappleye, chairman of the board of the plan.

Dancer-Fitzgerald-Sample, Inc., headed the list of agencies that bought time from the American Broadcasting Company, Inc., in 1946, spending a reported total of $4,076,892, according to Charles E. Rynd, vice president and assistant secretary of ABC, yesterday.

Despite the fact that fewer than 31,000 new students were admitted to the nation's 1,300 schools of nursing during last year as compared with the quota of 40,000 set by nursing and hospital officials, hope for improved enrollment during 1947 was expressed yesterday by Miss Edith H. Smith, chairman of the National Nursing Council's committee on careers in nursing.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 1--A possibility that the two local daily newspapers might attempt to resume publication within a few days, through a separate agreement with their pressmen, appeared today. The papers have been shut down for more than seven weeks by a dispute with their employes in five mechanical and craft unions.

Mme. Rosika Schwimmer, a vice president of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom, told The Associated Press yesterday that she was working as ardently for a permanent peace as an aftermath of World War II as she did after the conflict of 1914-18.

The American Gas Association, trade organization of the $5,000,000,000 gas industry in the United States, reported yesterday that new records were established in 1946 in all categories, except industrial sales, which leveled off from wartime peaks, reflecting general unsettled business conditions.

LONDON, Jan. 1--A fuel crisis that threatens to close cotton mills, electrical equipment plants and other industrial units in the northwest still gripped Great Britain today. The Government, which took formal title to all the nation's coal fields today, inherited along with the industry the present coal difficulties.

Numerous changes in the partnerships and key personnel of Wall Street brokerage firms become effective today. Announcements of reorganizations have been published previously within the past month, but additional changes were disclosed yesterday.

Long-standing reports that Dore Schary would take charge of production at the RKO Radio Pictures studios in Hollywood were confirmed yesterday with the announcement by N. Peter Rathvon, president of RKO, that Mr. Schary had signed a five-year contract as executive vice president in charge of production.

The pent-up demand for rubber products is of such proportions that shortages will continue for many months despite the fact that the industry is expected to repeat, or better, this year its record performance of 1946, Herbert E. Smith, president of the United States Rubber Company, said yesterday.

For the first time since 1941 the trend of the stock market, as measured by The New York Times index pictured here, was decidedly downward. The market started off well enough despite a wave of real and threatened strikes.

MOSCOW, Dec. 30 (Delayed) -- The sprightly doings of a rural prosecutor who stole a cow, had it turned into bologna, on which the members of the local executive committee munched, and then told them, "You ate the cow with me, so we are all guilty," gave Moscow a laugh today.

Corporate net income in 1946 reached the highest level in the history of the nation despite the fact that about one-third of the year was beset by nonproduction occasioned by strikes. The results of industrial manufacturers as a whole in 1947 may surpass even this impressive showing, providing further disruption of the national economic situation does not take place.
WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 1 (AP) --The new year found Mr. and Mrs. Howard Smithan and their two small daughters still living among packing cases in the stock room of OPA headquarters here.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Jan. 1--A major factor in preventing the desperation of 500,000 displaced persons in the United States zone from swelling into violent trouble this winter will be the progressive shifting of responsibility for camp administration to the refugees themselves.

Although the nation's railroads moved in the last year the greatest volume of traffic for any peacetime year, their net earnings dropped to the low level of the depression years of the early Nineteen Thirties. Increases in wages and higher costs of materials and supplies without commensurate increases in charges for transportation services, accounted for their poor showing.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 1-- Lying beside a police squad car in a thinly settled suburban section, Detective Chief O. N. Martin and his assistant, Lieut. O. F. Deubler, were found shot dead this morning.

Business forecasts for 1947 are on the "iffy" order, to use the word coined by the late President. If serious labor troubles are avoided in the immediate future, it is possible that a serious business setback may be avoided. A certain amount of shakedown this year, however, seems to figure in most calculations.

Hundreds of callers were received yesterday by Cardinal Spellman at his residence, 452 Madison Avenue. The New Year's Day reception, the first held by the Cardinal since his elevation to the Sacred College, followed the custom observed for many years.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1--The Chamber of Commerce of the United States forecast today a "middle-of-the-road" course for the Eightieth Congress which convenes on Friday and listed fiscal policy and labor legislation among the top-ranking issues awaiting action.

ALBANY, Jan. 1 -- Representativeelect W. Kingsland Macy, president of the National Republican Club, described as absurd today reports that Governor Dewey had sought to keep the club's annual Lincoln Day dinner on a strictly local basis.

Uncertainties about pricing policies and general economic conditions on which, prices must be based are now a major concern of executives at all levels of business, from manufacturing to retailing, companies surveyed by the American Management Association reported in a study prepared in connection with the AMA Marketing Conference to be held Jan. 9 and 10, at the Hotel Commodore.
EL PASO Tex., Jan. 1 (AP)-- The Cincinnati University Bearcats swept to three last-half touchdowns today to defeat Virginia Tech, 18 to 6, in the Sun Bowl's twelfth annual football game.

PARIS, Jan. 1--To prepare the ground for the Government's decree tomorrow that will order the general 5 per cent reduction in prices, Premier Leon Blum opened a campaign tonight to mobilize the "irresistible power of public opinion" behind the Government's move.

MELBOURNE, Jan. 1 (Reuters) --The England team gave the best display of the tour today--the first day of the third cricket test match. Although losing the toss and also their two opening bowlers, Bill Edrich and Bill Voce, through injuries, England dismissed six Australians for 255 runs.
PARIS, Jan. 1--The first French reinforcements, including the First Regiment of the Foreign Legion, landed in Indo-China today.

CARTERET, N.J., Jan. 1--Taking control of borough affairs today for the first time in twelve years, Democrats lost no time in ousting seven patrolmen and demoting four superior officers who won appointments and promotions during the last days of Republican control.

There were many disappointments in 1946, a year that was ushered in with great promise. It was the first full year of peace, after six years of production for destruction, and it found labor and management entering a period where the law of diminishing returns operated against both.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1--Secretary of State Byrnes conferred for an hour and twenty minutes today with George S. Messersmith, United States Ambassador to Argentina. Mr. Messersmith said afterward there had been no specific discussion of this country's policy toward Argentina.

United World Films, Inc., the non-theatrical motion picture company established recently by Universal Pictures, Inc., has bought control of Castle Films, one of the oldest and largest producer-distributors of 8mm and 16mm movies, it will be announced jointly today by Eugene W. Castle, founder and president of Castle Films, and Matthew Fox, board chairman of United World.

The United States Treasury's debt-retirement operations dominated last year's developments in the money market, leaving unsettled the general adjustment of the monetary arrangements set up during the period of war financing. The completion of the latter period was marked by the Victory Loan Drive which, exceeding all expectations, enabled the Treasury to undertake its huge retirement program.

The first British racquets team to come to the United States since 1930 arrived yesterday on board the Cunard liner Queen Elizabeth. The team is here for an extended tour which will take it to Chicago, Montreal, Philadelphia and Tuxedo for all the important tournaments of the season and an international team match to be played at the Racquet and Tennis Club Jan. 31.

The seller's market in the machine tool industry is over and competition is now active, Robert M. Gaylord, president of Ingersoll Milling Machine Company, Rockford, Ill., declared in a year-end review and forecast statement released for today.

The electrical manufacturing industry faces an optimistic outlook in 1947, qualified only by the possibility of major labor disturbances and some materials shortages, according to R. Stafford Edwards, Norwalk, Conn., president of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association, following a survey of the NEMA board of governors.
LONDON, Jan. 1 (Reuters) -- Results of soccer matches played in Great Britain today follow:

DALLAS, Tex., Jan. 1 (AP)--Arkansas Razorbacks balked three drives inside their ten-yard line and gained a scoreless tie with the power-laden Louisiana State Tigers today in the eleventh Cotton Bowl classic.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 1--An Irgun Zvai Leumi terrorist who took part in the April 23 raid on the Ramat Gan police headquarters during which, it is believed, fifteen of his companions were killed, was sentenced to death by hanging by a British military court today.

Isaac L. Asofsky, executive director of the Hebrew Sheltering and Immigrant Aid Society, condemned yesterday a report of George Meader, Senate War Investigating Committee counsel, on displaced persons in Germany.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1--President Truman has been requested to incorporate in his economic message to Congress four proposals designed to improve labor-management relations, it was learned today.

A few winding alarm clocks designed for living rooms are beginning to appear in New York stores. Since electric clocks work only on alternating current, these new models should interest families living in buildings that have direct current.

The metalworking industry in the United States--primary metal producers, manufacturers of fabricated metal products and the machinery, electrical equipment and transportation equipment industries --last year pushed production to a peacetime record of $43,189,000,000, which is 122 per cent above the 1939 volume of $19,455,000,000, according to Steel Magazine.

Ida McGuire, film bit player, flew here yesterday from the West Coast to appear at the trial of Alvin J. Paris, scheduled to start today. The actress had been described by the District Attorney's office as one of four witnesses who were at a party at which Paris allegedly tried to "fix" the championship play-off game between the New York Football Giants and the Chicago Bears.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 1-- Mervyn Leroy's first directing assignment under his new contract with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer will be the screen version of Sholem Asch's novel, "East River," which the studio bought last August for a price that may reach $225,000, depending on sales of the book.

As the new year gets under way it is becoming evident that in contrast to 1946, which demanded attention for a vast variety of problems in the international field, 1947 is more likely to be dominated by one central problem on which the final solution of all others depends.

The post-war improvisations in international commerce that have carried United States foreign trade to record levels since V-J Day will push it to even higher peaks during 1947, foreign trade experts stated in estimating the coming year.
Most branches of the non-ferrous metals industry expect--or hope-- that 1947 will be a record year.

MADRID, Jan. 1--New talks among all the opposition parties in Spain except the Communists have led to a definite agreement among them to work for the restoration of the monarchy. Prince Juan is at present being consulted in Lisbon about the possibilities and the best time for acting, according to a source that is usually sound.

Generally speaking, business for the twenty-three Broadway attractions that gave holiday matinees yesterday was fair. A survey of the box-offices revealed that five shows played to standees, while three had capacity houses. Trade for the rest ranged from one-third of capacity to almost sold-out.

The nation's steel industry, traditional barometer of domestic industrial activity, enters the New Year resolute but apprehensive. With post-war demand for its products only partly satisfied during the last twelve months, the industry is poised for a record production year for peacetime, favorable revenues, satisfactory earnings and price stabilization unless costs, strikes, material shortages and other handicaps prevent maximum operations.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 1-- St. Lawrence University of Canton, N.Y., a comparative newcomer to major intercollegiate competition, surprised in the Lake Placid Club Sno Birds college week program by winning the Harding Trophy, symbolic of the team prize, as the twenty-sixth annual games ended today.

A warning that the recently announced Federal housing program may encourage the erection of high-priced rental units in this city but will not help in alleviating the shortage of apartments for low and middle income groups was sounded yesterday by the Citizens Housing Council of New York, which asked the support of all groups behind a program of Federal, State and municipal action to speed new construction this year.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 1--The United States was likened to the "British imperialists" of 1925 and the Japanese aggressors of 1931 by 5,000 university students today. They marched through downtown Shanghai carrying tissue - paper banners, chalking anti-American slogans on streets, walls and vehicles, and shouting: "Get out, GI!"

The degree of uninterrupted production at reasonable prices and Government legislation and action such as to foster these essentials will determine both sales and profits for the department store industry in 1947, Harry H. Schwartz, president of the National Department Stores Corporation, declared yesterday in a year-end statement.

ALBANY, Jan. 1--Colleges and universities of New York State shattered all records in 1946 in bringing full-time enrollment to 180,811, an increase of 76 per cent over highest pre-war figures, the State Department of Education informed the Board of Regents today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1--A new high in number of Republican women holding seats in State Legislatures was announced today by Mrs. Jane Hamilton Macauley, assistant chairman of the Republican National Committee and director of its women's division.

The utility industry had a record year in 1946 and expects a better one in 1947. Gross revenues of the power companies rose about $100,000,000, but most of this gain was absorbed by payroll, the item that is now the largest in the list of utility expenses.
PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 1-- Dr. Chalfant Robinson, professor emeritus at Princeton University and one of the nation's leading palaeographers, died at his home here last night at the age of 75.

MOSCOW, Jan. 1--The Soviet Union enters the new year confident that its representatives in international affairs will win new and greater successes over the reactionaries of the West in pursuit of a democratic peace and international collaboration.

Lumber production for the current year will equal or surpass the 34,000,000,000 board feet estimated for 1946 by the National Association of Lumber Manufacturers, R. E. Broderick, executive secretary of the Northeastern Lumber Manufacturers Association, predicted yesterday.
TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 1 (AP)--University of Delaware's hard driving Blue Hens inaugurated the Cigar Bowl today with a 21-7 victory over Rolling College of Winter Park, Fla.

BOMBAY, India, Jan. 1--This uneasy country entered the new year today with a note of anxiety dominating its political outlook pending the meeting of the Congress party's general committee, which starts Sunday in New Delhi.

The new Congress, convening tomorrow at the beginning of a new year that starts more auspiciously than any since 1939, will bear the burden of shaping in general outline the post-war defense pattern of the nation.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Jan., 1--The United States must reduce its tariffs unilaterally, on an entirely different basis from present policy, or "give up its dream of leadership in world trade," Dr. Stephen Enke of the University of California at Los Angeles, told the conference of the Pacific Coast Economic Association yesterday.
Americans bought more insurance in 1946 than ever before, investing in $18,000,000,000 worth of life insurance alone and spending heavily for other forms of insurance protection.

Members of three city departments and the District Attorney's office were investigating yesterday the four-alarm fire that swept the upper floors of a seven-story loft building at 749 Broadway, near East Eighth Street, on New Year's Eve.

"No Peace for Asia," by Harold Isaacs, an account of the post-war political and military situation in Indo-China that gives a background to the present conflict between the French Government and the Viet Namese, has been scheduled for publication on April 8 by Macmillan.

Being in an irreverent frame of mind, Martha Gellhorn and Virginia Cowles have started debunking war correspondents in "Love Goes to Press," put on at the Biltmore Theatre last evening. That should be a fruity field for postwar debunking, since it bred more overnight experts than any other department of journalism and raised up a crop of demons for personal service.
SOUTH HARWICH, Mass., Jan. 1--William Read Hersey, music critic, author and teacher, died of a heart attack today at his home here. His age was 64.

In sharp contrast with the optimistic forecasts of a year ago, business and industry enter this year facing an uncertain and confused pattern despite the nation's basically sound economy and unfilled wants for consumer goods, it was said yesterday by the National Conference of Business Paper Editors.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 1--The Right Rev. Henry St. George Tucker stepped down today as Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States and retired to his Richmond home in Three Chopt Road, where he plans to devote the future to study and writing.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1--The Republican majority in the Senate will stop Senator Theodore G. Bilbo, Democrat of Mississippi, "at the door" when he seeks to take the oath of office for his third term on Friday, Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio indicated today.

Low-priced stocks, rather than the pivotal industrial favorites of other years, were the most active issues on the New York Stock Exchange in 1946, as they have been in the last few years. Of the twenty stocks with the largest dealings in the year, only one closed the period above $20 a share; eight were below $10 a share.

The year that has just passed was singularly successful for the communications industry. More persons were served, more plants were built and the greatest number of technological developments were introduced during 1946 than in any other year of the industry's history.

FORT WORTH, Jan. 1 (AP)-- Arkansas Agriculture, Mechanical and Normal College from Pine Bluff, Ark., punched across a thirdquarter touchdown today to score a 7-to-0 upset over Lane College of Jackson, Tenn., in the first Cattle Bowl game for Negro colleges.

LEWES, Del., Jan. 1--A funeral service for Mrs. Nettie W. Marshall, widow of Dr. Henry Marshall, will be held here tomorrow. Daughter of the late Henry C. and Mary A. Witmar of Lancaster, Pa., Mrs. Marshall died Monday at the age of 67.

A year of good business with no let-up in the demand for goods was forecast for the retail field in a year-end statement issued yesterday by Bernard F. Gimbel, president of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., which operates department stores in New York, Philadelphia, Pittsburgh, Milwaukee; Saks - 34th Street and Saks Fifth Avenue with branches in Chicago, Detroit, Miami Beach, Palm Beach and Beverly Hills.

LONDON, Jan. 1--Defiantly claiming that Albania had only used her "legitimate rights under international law" in the Corfu channel mining incident, Gen. Enver Hoxha, Albanian Premier, in a New Year's broadcast over the Tirana radio today, accused Great Britain of having three times violated Albanian sovereignty "in a brutal manner."

The availability of revenue bond financing will permit during the next ten years the construction of major highways linking the two coasts of the United States as well as Canada and Texas, J.C.L. Tripp, president of Tripp Co., municipal bond dealers, declared yesterday in outlining the important part played by the investment banker in the organization of successful revenue projects.

The nation's $13,000,000,000 electric utility industry closed 1946 with a backlog of more than 60,000 pending applications for service because of material shortages and unavailability of ample skilled labor, thus indicating that 1947 will match 1946 in new customers added.

The 7,783-ton liner City of Athens, which was built in 1920 at Hog Island, Pa., and has seen service under several flags, arrived here yesterday with 291 passengers from Istanbul. She docked at Pier 13, East River.

The domestic petroleum industry has just completed the best year in its history. With no serious conversion problem and with an expanding civilian demand for its products, the earnings of the industry reached new peaks. Domestic crude oil production was the highest for any year.

One of the more tangible results of President Truman's proclamation of Tuesday terminating hostilities is that a number of wartime luxury taxes will come to an end six months hence. This is a fact which will now have to be taken into consideration by those who are urging an early, if not immediate, slash in individual income taxes.

ALBANY, Jan. 1--The text of Governor Dewey's inaugural address was as follows: Today we pledge anew our loyalty to the constitutions of our State and nation, and we take up the opportunities and burdens of a new term.
An experiment in airport operation that will be watched closely by small and large municipalities with airport problems will star this month at Willow Run Airport, outside Detroit.

ABOARD MOUNT OLYMPUS, it Sea, Jan. 1 -- In a maneuver unique in naval history, the Central Group of Task. Force 68 formed into a close column yesterday and plunged into the 300-mile Antarctic ice pack, led by the Coast Guard icebreaker North Wind flying the flag of the task force commander, Rear Admiral Richard H. Cruzen.

New Year's night found New York without an undefeated college basketball team as the C. C. N. Y. games, winner of its first eight games, bowed to a court-wise Oklahoma University five at Madison Square Garden last night, 55--52.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 1 (AP)-- Texas Sandman, a 55-to-1 outsider in a field of eighteen, today scored one of the biggest upset victories in Santa Anita's history to capture the $50,000 added San Carlos Handicap before a yelling New Year's Day crowd of 63,000 El Lobo was second and Fighting Frank third.

The domestic petroleum industry has just completed the best year in its history. With no serious conversion problem and with an expanding civilian demand for its products, the earnings of the industry reached new peaks. Domestic crude oil production was the highest for any year.

One of the more tangible results of President Truman's proclamation of Tuesday terminating hostilities is that a number of wartime luxury taxes will come to an end six months hence. This is a fact which will now have to be taken into consideration by those who are urging an early, if not immediate, slash in individual income taxes.

ALBANY, Jan. 1--The text of Governor Dewey's inaugural address was as follows: Today we pledge anew our loyalty to the constitutions of our State and nation, and we take up the opportunities and burdens of a new term.
An experiment in airport operation that will be watched closely by small and large municipalities with airport problems will star this month at Willow Run Airport, outside Detroit.

ABOARD MOUNT OLYMPUS, it Sea, Jan. 1 -- In a maneuver unique in naval history, the Central Group of Task. Force 68 formed into a close column yesterday and plunged into the 300-mile Antarctic ice pack, led by the Coast Guard icebreaker North Wind flying the flag of the task force commander, Rear Admiral Richard H. Cruzen.

New Year's night found New York without an undefeated college basketball team as the C. C. N. Y. games, winner of its first eight games, bowed to a court-wise Oklahoma University five at Madison Square Garden last night, 55--52.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1--The National Education Association today urged professional group action in obtaining pay rises for teachers while reaffirming its ethical code against teachers' strikes in a statement which one official called "among the most important in our ninety-year history."

BALTIMORE, Dec. 30 (AP)--The aircraft industry will continue in 1947 its relatively rapid rate of growth despite any temporary difficulties it faces and regardless of any handicaps imposed by economic or labor upsets in industry generally, Glenn L. Martin said today.
A trip to France in the summer of 1946 proved valuable to Carolyn Schnurer, who brought back many ideas that she has applied to a resort collection.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP)--Edwin G. Arnold, director of the Interior Department's Division of Territories, said today last summer's shipping strike halted Alaska's building program, forced rationing of hospital supplies, ruined many Alaska farmers and business men and robbed others of life-time savings.

OUDTSHOORN, Little Karroo, South Africa, Dec. 30 (Delayed)--Thousands of ostriches on farms in this area are being prepared for the visit of the British royal family early in the new year. After a preview today, this correspondent can assert that some of the younger birds are already suitable for royal inspection.

LANSING, Mich., Jan. 1--Kim Sigler, one-time Nebraska cowboy and prize fighter, was inaugurated today as Governor of Michigan a little more than nine months after he was dismissed in the midst of his service as a special prosecutor tracking down graft and corruption in high places.

Although gas range manufacturers have increased production more than 100 per- cent above prewar capacity, it will be some time before the industry can meet consumer demands, it was said yesterday by D.P. O'Keefe, president, Gas Appliance Manufacturers Assocition.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your Christmas Day editorial "Senatorial Nonsense" was excellent. Our people are today committed to the great and difficult "Odyssey of Peace," and as we chart our course and assess the adventure ahead, we shall all want to see our great ship of state piloted safely to port, avoiding both Scylla and Charybdis, as did that little vessel which good old Ulysses brought successfully home.

HOUSTON, Texas, Jan. 1 (AP)-- Georgia Tech took a four-touchdown lead and then held off a scrapping St. Mary's eleven today to defeat the Gaels, 41--19, as 23,000 fans braved freezing temperatures and a cold rain at the third annual Oil Bowl football game.

Despite increased costs of operation, banks last year generally had one of the most profitable periods in their recent history. With deposits at record high levels, commercial, industrial and agricultural loans, together with non - farm mortgage borrowings reached peak volumes.

One wishes that the Russians and others who are skeptical about the American atom plan would pay special attention to a ceremony which took place at the White House on the last day of the old year. At this ceremony the control of atomic energy and fissionable materials in this country passed from military to civilian hands.

Swearing in J. Raymond Jones, Tammany leader of the Thirteenth Assembly District, south, as deputy commissioner of housing and buildings, in a City Hall ceremony yesterday afternoon, Mayor William O'Dwyer took occasion to point out that he depended upon his appointees to give him a picture of true conditions in the city.

Transactions on the New York Stock Exchange in 1946 totaled 363,709,312 shares. This was the largest total since 1937, with the exception of last year, and compared with the record year of 1929, when the turnover was 1,124,990,980 shares.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1--The House Un-American Activities Committee, meeting in secret sessions for the second successive day, failed to agree today on whether its annual report should contain allegations of a national conspiracy to promote a Communist revolution.

One wishes that the Russians and others who are skeptical about the American atom plan would pay special attention to a ceremony which took place at the White House on the last day of the old year. At this ceremony the control of atomic energy and fissionable materials in this country passed from military to civilian hands.

Snow, low temperatures and biting winds chilled the reception to 1947 in New York yesterday, as part of wintry conditions prevailing in nearly all parts of the country except southern Florida and California.

The Friends of Jazz presented their first public venture last night at Town Hall. It was a jazz concert with a different twist. Instead of being an informal appearance of a number of popular instrumentalists, it was a dramatization of Milton "Mezz" Mezzrow's autobiography, "Really the Blues."
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 1 (AP)-- The Georgia Bulldogs found their scoring power late today to overtake North Carolina's Tar Heels and win the thirteenth Sugar Bowl football game, 20 to 10, in a dense fog.

The annual report of the Cudahy Packing Company, issued for publication today, disclosed a net income of $6,720,585 for the fiscal year ended on Nov. 2, last, after deducting $9,300,000 for taxes. This amounted to 1.92 per cent on each one dollar of sales.

ORLANDO, Fla., Jan. 1 (AP)-- A power-laden Catawba College eleven struck by land and by air with devastating results today to administer a decisive 31-6 trouncing to a previously undefeated Maryville College team in the inaugural Tangerine Bowl.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1--The Republican leadership in the Senate put down today the single revolt in the party's organization for the new Congress on that side of the capital.

Twelve new members were elected yesterday to the National Institute of Arts and Letters, it was announced last night by Douglas Moore, president. The election leaves only eleven vacancies among the 250 life memberships. The posts are bestowed in recognition of distinguished achievement to artists, writers and composers.

The National Maritime Union's internal dispute continued yesterday as Joseph Curran, president, and Joseph Stack, vice president, disagreed on whether the latter had announced his intention to resign his office.

LONDON, Jan. 2--As a result of British pressure, the French Government has convened a secret conference of United States, British and French officials in Paris to discuss means of stopping the flow of refugees from eastern Europe into France, it was learned today.

Reduced prices were posted in some retail liquor stores yesterday on rye whisky blends through a combination of three factors. They were the post-holiday slackening of demand, the likelihood of a reduction in whisky taxes and the return of Scotch in liberal quantities to store shelves.

Lutherans in Europe have definitely begun to look to Lutherans in America for world leadership, the Rev. Dr. F. Eppling Reinartz, new secretary of the United Lutheran Church in America, declared as he begun his new duties yesterday morning.

A singular collection of compositions old and young, by Spanish, Austrian, German-American and French composers, with Jacques Thibaud returned to us as soloist in the performance of the "Symphonie Espagnole," and a series of extraordinary interpretations by Leopoid Stokowski and the Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra made their concert last night in Carnegie Hall an altogether delightful experience.

Clearing-up operations after the first heavy, powdery snowfall of the year here will be completed tomorrow night if mild temperatures prevail, it was predicted last night after a fall of 1 to 20 inches had glazed the northeastern section of the country.

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 2--A survey showed today that the eight-month CIO strike at the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company plant in suburban West Allis has taken a total monetary toll of $36,484,511 thus far, and the end is not in sight.

Weather conditions that held up the arrival of out-of-State witnesses daused adjournment of the bribery case of Alvin J. Paris after a brief session yesterday. The trial of the alleged would-be fixer of the Giants-Bears professional football championship game will get under way Monday at 10:15 A.M.

Reflecting a strong trade demand for all active months, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday near the best levels of the day and 40 to 55 points net higher than on Tuesday.

Amputation of the left leg was performed yesterday on Miss Olga Trapani, 28-year-old victim of the "camera-gun" shooting plot that reached its culmination on Tuesday morning with a shotgun burst on a crowded subway platform in Times Square.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2--If Senators opposed to seating Theodore G. Bilbo of Mississippi as a colleague have a majority of the votes of those members present and constituting a quorum, they can oblige him to "stand aside" tomorrow with the support of numerous precedents.

Champion Paper and Fiber Company and Subsidiaries--Twentyeight weeks to Nov. 10: Consolidated net income $2,682,247, or $2.22 each on 1,102,000 common shares, compared with $1,193,352, or $1.53 a share, for 1945 period.

Two goals against them in twentythree seconds failed to bother the Toronto Maple Leafs in their National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. This brace of goals, coming in the second period, put the Rangers ahead by a point.

Those who have visited the Continent must admit that state control is a necessary requisite in Europe during the transitory period from war to peace, and a realistic American commercial policy must consider that European countries need foreign credits, it was said yesterday by Curtis Rosenberg, foreign law expert of Weil, Gotshal Manges.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Jan. 2-- Evidence is increasing that the Hungarian Communist - controlled military and civilian police organs, in their recent arrests of army officers and members of the Small Holders' party, have netted the not-yet-disbanded Right Wing of the Hungarian anti-German resistance movement.

LONDON, Jan. 2--The first business of the new year placed the stock markets today in a cheerful mood. The principal rises were in Argentine railway securities, gold-mining shares and selected industrials, while British Government stock improved on the coming closing of the "tap" loan.
ATHENS, Jan. 2--Military circles believe that the Left-Wing guerrilla attack on the Thessalian village of Ypati indicates that henceforward Greece's interior may be the main scene of bandit activity.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., Jan. 2 --A radical innovation in small transport planes, with two engines activating a single "pusher" propeller in the tail of the craft, was announced today by the Douglas Aircraft Company.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2--Senate Republicans decided unanimously today to keep Senator Theodore G. Bilbo, Democrat, of Mississippi, from taking his oath of office pending a full debate on the floor of the case or cases against him. The date of Jan. 14 was most frequently mentioned for starting the full-dress discussion.
LONDON, Jan. 2 (AP)--The statement of condition of the Bank of England for the week ended on Tuesday, issued today, follows in thousands of pounds:

The suave, smooth-talking thug Who kidnapped and robbed three women New Year's Eve on Park Avenue is believed to be the same man who last November did a similar job on four persons returning home from the Metropolitan Opera House, and may have been responsible for the robbery last August of three couples seated in a car on Fifth Avenue after leaving the Copacabana night club, the police said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2--Establishment of an independent commission with authority to discharge any Government employe "whose loyalty to the United States is found to be in doubt" was among eleven recommendations made today by the House Un-American Activities Committee.

Strawberries in January rate as an attractive purchase rather than as an extravagance this week-end, with one of the leading chain stores featuring them at a price below the average charged last June when native berries were in season. Coming from Florida, the strawberries are being sold for 29 cents a pint, a low price that was equaled only once early last summer.
Signing of Frankie Crosetti as player-coach was announced by the Yankees yesterday, removing Red Rolfe from the picture as a potential aide to Manager Bucky Harris.

CHICAGO, Jan. 2 -- Annual statements of Chicago's six major downtown banks disclosed today net income of the institutions last year was about the same as 1945 Three of the banks, including Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, reported slightly higher profits.

Reinvestment demand failed yesterday to appear in the securities markets except in scattered instances and, with no indication that the traditional new year rally was yet in the making, stocks turned to the lower side. The price trend throughout the initial session of 1947 was narrow and interest was light with weakest tendencies in the liquor issues.

CHICAGO, Jan. 2--Traders' views were mixed today as to the immediate trend of the grain markets and resulted in irregular price changes. There was aggressive buying of January and March corn by cash and commission houses, with January closing 2 1/4 cents up on the bushel and March 1 1/2 cents higher than on Tuesday.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Jan. 2-- On Saturday, this manufacturing center of 160,000 persons will complete 100 days without a local daily newspaper, to the vociferous dissatisfaction of public officials, business men and residents generally.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 --The State Department has received word that a sensational trial will open in Warsaw on Saturday that will involve directly British Ambassador Victor Cavendish-Bentinck in an alleged conspiracy to overthrow the Provisional Polish Government.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2--The Department of Justice is asking the Federal District Court in Detroit to intervene in the Mount Clemens Pottery portal-to-portal case as "a friend of the court" to help determine what amount, if any, is due the company's employes in retroactive wages.

A rising demand for loans from private sources and a substantial decline in the amount of bank credit used by the United States Treasury were listed as the outstanding developments in 1946 for the State banking system by Elliott V. Bell, Superintendent of Banks, in his annual report to Governor Dewey and the Legislature.

CALCUTTA, India, Jan. 2 (AP)-- Mohandas K. Gandhi, 77 and still weakened from a recent fast, set out today on a village-to-village walking tour through the paddy fields and betelnut groves of the Noakhali district in East Gengal, carrying his doctrine of ahimsa (non-violence) into the Moslemdominated area swept by communal bloodshed last October.

STOCKHOLM, Jan. 2 (U.P.)-- Swedish ice hockey fans and sports writers were bitter today over the ineptitude of a touring American amateur team, advertised as an All-Star U.S. sqaud which suffered 9 to 0 and 14 to 4 defeats in its first two games against firstrate Swedish teams.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Could you possibly divert a portion of your valuable space from comments about the "iron curtain" alleged to hang over Europe to the very real curtain that strangles, besmirches and mars the people and habitations of New York City?

LONDON, Jan. 2--British and United States plans for giving full representation to the smaller powers in working out the economic aspects of the peace settlement with Germany center on the Emergency Economic Committee for Europe, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 --The disposal of surplus property has been marked by "chaos and confusion" at a "stupendous, in fact prohibitive, cost," and with only a "minute" financial return to the Government, a special House committee investigating surplus disposition declared today.

Bankers Trust The Bankers Trust Company reported as of Dec. 31, 1946, total deposits of $1,390,589,699 and total assets of $1,565,363,449, compared, respectively, with $1,433,590,193 and $1,605,472,229 on Sept. 30. Cash on hand and due from banks amounted to $347,623,987, against $303,464,724; holdings of United States Government securities to $643,442,654, against $721,518,589; and loans and bills discounted to $500,097,811, against $499,778,925.

Anniversary Melon The board of directors of the Richardson Corporation of Rochester, N.Y., observed the company's thirtieth anniversary yesterday by creating the position of chairman of the board, increasing the common stock dividend and voting a substantial bonus for all employes.

The best skiing of the season thus far may be found this weekend as a result of the southwest storm of the last 24 hours that left new snow throughout the Northeastern United States and Canada. Yet skiers must watch the ski information tables closely, for rain has followed snow in many districts.

DETROIT, Mich., Jan. 2--In the same Federal district court where the Department of Justice seeks to play a further role in the portal-toportal wage issue, suits seeking more than $400,000,000 in such pay adjustments were filed today by the United Automobile Workers, CIO, against the "Big Three" automobile manufacturers.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court reserved decision yesterday after hearing argument on motions by the Longchamps Restaurants for a reversal of the State Liquor Authority's concellation of their liquor licenses and for an extension beyond Jan. 6 of a stay of execution of the cancellation.

Seized with a sudden fit of despondency early yesterday morning, James P. Eastman, 34 years old, of 307 East Forty-fourth Street, telephoned friends he had visited a few hours before and threatened suicide. Later he apparently took his own life by swallowing an overdose of sleeping tablets.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan 2-- Enterprise Productions borrowed Lilli Palmer, English actress, from United States Pictures today to play the leading role opposite John Garfield in "Body and Soul," which was previously titled "Burning Journey."

NEWARK, Jan. 2--Hope for early termination of the week-old strike of 400 workers at the Harrison gas works of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company rose tonight after a special mediation panel had disposed of a wage dispute that threatened to produce a similar tie-up at the company's Paterson and Camden plants.
CHICAGO. Jan. 2 (AP)--Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

The raising of $1,000,000 a year the next three years for world relief will be his immediate objective, declared Presiding Bishop Henry Knox Sherrill of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States, as he took over his duties at his office at 281 Fourth Avenue yesterday morning. The money is to be distributed in Europe and East Asia through Protestant inter-church channels.

Investment firms continued yesterday to rearrange their administrative staffs. In the many offices that have changed partners and executive personnel, the day was devoted to meeting the problems that such realignments create.

Howard S. Cullman of New York City was re-elected chairman, and Joseph M. Byrne Jr. of Newark, vice chairman of the Port of New York Authority by unanimous vote of the Authority commissioners at the annual meeting yesterday at 111 Eighth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The proposal by Northern and Western bituminous coal operators to make a separate agreement with the United Mine Workers of America will be discussed by the union's international executive board before it concludes its session on Saturday, it was reported today.

PARIS, Jan. 2--The American Federation of Labor will not establish its European office in Paris because the Communist-dominated French General Confederation of Labor has engaged in "mud-slinging attacks on the federation and its intentions."

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 2 (AP)--A crowd of 9,672 was treated to an exceptional number of photo finishes at Tropical Park today and one of them came in the feature when Mrs. D.B. Miller's Sky Skipper got the nod over Jake Freedman's Hay-Jay.

The first weekly evening clinic solely for examining persons for cancer, maintained by the New York City Cancer Committee, was opened last night at 338 Second Avenue. The new clinic will be open Thursdays, from 5:30 P.M. to 7:30 P.M.

The real estate securities market staged a recovery in December with an advance of 1.9 per cent for the best one-month gain since last May, according to Amott, Baker Co. Based on an index of 200 Eastern issues, the average price for a $1,000 bond was $730 on Dec. 31, compared with $717 on Nov. 30 and $658 at the beginning of 1946.

ALBANY, Jan. 2 -- Governor Dewey favors a one-year extension of existing State rent control laws, it was disclosed today. Unless renewed by the new Legislature which meets next week, they would expire on June 30.

BOSTON, Jan. 2--Robert Fiske Bradford, a direct descendant in the ninth generation of William Bradford, second Governor of the Plymouth colony, was inaugurated Governor of Massachusetts today, then warned that the State and local governments faced a deficit of $75,000,000.

An account of international developments during the war years has been written by Jan Ciechanowski, former Polish Ambassador to the United States, entitled "Defeat in Victory." Based on his personal notes, it traces the development of power diplomacy by Great Britain and the United States in the pursuit of agreement and unity with Russia.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The House Campaign Investigating Committee announced today, in a final report, that evidence indicating violations of the Corrupt Practices Act by about sixty unions and eleven corporations, mostly in the New York City area, had been turned over to the Department of Justice.

The National Academy at 1083 Fifth Avenue will open with a preview reception this evening the first part of its 1947 annual, which may be visited by the public beginning tomorrow. The second part of the annual, to be confined to work by members and associate members of the organization, is scheduled for March.

A final effort to restore unity in the Collegiate Reformed Dutch Church of the City of New York at a meeting of the Consistory or governing body of the five churches of the Collegiate group ended in schism at 12:30 o'clock this morning.

MOSCOW, Jan. 2--The latest of the long line of visitors who find New York is a nice place to visit but would not live there if you gave him the place is V. Poltoratsky, an Izvestia correspondent. Like some explorer back from darkest Africa, Mr. Poltaratsky is telling the Russians about our city, which he finds lively, noisy, extraordinarily dirty.

NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 2--The aircraft carrier Philippine Sea sailed from Hampton Roads at 12:48 P.M. today, to bear Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd to Antarctica for a rendezvous with the largest of the exploratory fleets he has yet led to the frozen continent at the South Pole.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 2 (U.P.) --The funeral W.C. Fields didn't want was held today with the comedian's friend, Edgar Bergen, delivering a brief eulogy in place of a religious service. Attending the brief rites at the Church of the Recessional in Forest Lawn Memorial Park were fewer than 100 persons.

Turkey will not even discuss common defense of the Dardanelles with Russia, according to Ahmed Emin Yalman, editor in chief of Vatan (Fatherland), second largest daily newspaper in Turkey. He arrived here two days ago from Istanbul to address the International Forum in Cleveland next week.

LONDON, Jan. 2--Criticism that duplication of command of Allied land forces during the planning for the invasion of France led to "overlapping and complications" was made in a dispatch from the late Air Chief Marshal Sir Trafford Leigh-Mallory that was published officially tonight.

Production of soft-surface floor coverings during 1947 will equal or exceed slightly the 1941 record of 78,000,000 square yards, an increase of more than 20 per cent over 1946 ouput, estimated at 58,000,000, F. I. Monahan, general sales manager of Mohawk Carpet Mills, Inc., predicted yesterday.

In an opinion written by Judge Learned Hand, the United States Circuit Court of Appeals held yesterday that District Judge John C. Knox erred in refusing last July to reopen the reorganization proceedings of the Equitable Office Building Corporation to consider a new refinancing plan that would have been underwritten by the City Investing Company.

Michael O'Higgins, Irish baritone, gave his first New York recital last night at Town Hall. With Stuart Ross at the piano, Mr. O'Higgins was heard in a program containing early classics, songs by Malshkin, Rachmaninoff and Merikanto, German Lieder by Schubert and Strauss, Irish lyrics by Aitken, Huggard, Larchet and Needham, and a final group of folk songs.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2--The Interstate Commerce Commission authorized today the trustee of the Pittsburgh, Shawmut Northern Railroad Company to abandon the entire railroad of that carrier. It consists of a main line extending southerly from Wayland Junction, N. Y., through Moraine and Prosser, N. Y., and Kasson and Paine.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 2--In what is believed the first action of its type, the Rockwell Manufacturing Company, one of many defendants in suits for portal-to-portal pay, filed a counter-action today, asking $15,000,000 for production it said was lost in slowdowns by workers.
ALBANY, Jan. 2 (AP)--Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein said today that a "double-barrelled" investigation of New York's wholesale butter market was under way at "full steam."

How Far Back? What many lawyers regard as the classic case in the history of portal-toportal litigation was a suit filed at the beginning of April, 1947, in the New York courts in behalf of A.B. Jones, an expert machinist for many years in the employ of the Diametric Vortex Corporation of that State.

The St. Louis-San Francisco Railway Company, which has been in bankruptcy fourteen years, was restored yesterday to private ownership when Frank A. Thompson, trustee, formally handed over the property to M.G. Roberts, vice president and general counsel of the newly reorganized company.

WARSAW, Jan. 2--Mass arrests of members of the oppositionist Polish Peasant party (PSL), intimidation of anyone and everyone who might be unwilling to accept Communist leadership and the ban on the candidacy of some Opposition leaders have reached such a point that voting on Jan. 19 will be meaningless.

New officers and directors of MacGregor - Goldsmith, Inc., and MacGregor Golf, Inc., subsidiaries of Sport Products, Inc., were announced yesterday as follows: For MacGregor-Goldsmith, Inc., W. C. Cowen, president; Richard W. Scallan, vice president; Philip H. Goldsmith, vice president and treasurer; C. V. Brasher, vice president, and George J. Brungs, secretary.

NANKING, Friday, Jan. 3 -- About 1,500 student demonstrators marched for three hours through the streets of Nanking today in protest against an alleged assault on a Chinese girl by an American marine in Peiping last week. The parade ended in a noisy assemblage at the United States Embassy to present a list of demands to Ambassador John Leighton Stuart.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your editorial, "Georgia's Political Tangle," in THE TIMES of Dec. 26 you state: "The situation turns the spotlight once more on the confusion that would follow the death of a President-elect. The nation now knows it was in grave danger of such an emergency after the last election of President Roosevelt."

MOSCOW, Jan. 2 -- Experts state that the drought of 1946 was worse than that of 1921, which led to famine deaths by the thousand, an article by Peter Kuzmin, chairman of the Saratov regional Soviet, revealed today.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 2-- Uranium, the element that ushered in the atomic age, as well as thorium, which can also be used for releasing atomic energy, are serving as the most reliable "cosmic clocks" for determining the age of the earth, it was reported here today at the Princeton bicentennial conference on genetics, palaeontology and evolution.

Rune Gustafsson and Haakon Lidman of Sweden, who are due to be cast in featured roles later in the campaign, may be among the spectators at the Seventh Regiment Armory tomorrow night when the 1947 indoor track season gets under way with the Grover Cleveland games.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP)--As threat of a filibuster developed tonight against the Republican plan to bar Senator Bilbo at the Senate's threshold. Senator Maybank of South Carolina said that, if necessary, he would read every line of the voluminous record of a Senate investigation into Mr. Bilbo's re-election.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: There was published in your paper a letter from Leslie Handler offering suggestions looking to the avoidance of liabilities under the Fair Labor Standards Act. I am writing to offer the other side of the picture as an item that THE TIMES should not overlook.

TOKYO, Jan. 2 (AP)--Japanese attorneys defending former Premier Tojo and twenty-six other former Japanese leaders against war crimes charges appealed through the Kyodo news agency today for public cooperation to help show "why we had to fight" the Pacific war.

PARIS, Jan. 2--Suggesting that before the end of this year the world might undergo a price slump like that of 1919, Andre Philip, Minister of Finance and National Economy, said tonight that this prospect had led the Government to begin its "fight for the reduction of prices."

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Jan. 2 --A fifteen-day extension has been granted to John D. Rockefeller Jr. on his option to purchase the $8,500,000 six-block tract on the East River as a future world capital of the United Nations, A. H. Feller, chief legal counsel, announced today.
MOSCOW, Jan. 2--The Cabinet has called for a clear improvement in the film industry, whose backwardness, according to the newspaper Culture and Life, "can no longer be tolerated."
