Helicopter mail service on an experimental basis will be started in Brooklyn on Monday, when the Postoffice Department will begin a series of landings in a vacant lot a short distance from the Borough Hall section, Postmaster Edward J. Quigley of Brooklyn, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan, 2 (AP)-- Three Government-financed apartment developments, one described by real estate men as the largest of its kind, were reported today to be in the process of sale to two Texas men for $43,600,000.
JERUSALEM, Jan. 2--Terrorism was resumed on a large scale in Palestine tonight with attacks in five cities. Casualties were undetermined late tonight, but they were not believed to be high.
The continuing growth of Communist parties in Central and South America poses a genuine problem for the United States' vital economic, political and military interests in the entire area.
Myron C. Taylor, President Truman's personal representative to the Vatican, emphasized yesterday the need for continued and greater relief to the Italian people.

Nine prisoners, one a murderer and another an Alcatraz alumnus, broke out of the City Prison in lower Brooklyn yesterday. They escaped, while on sick call, through one of the prison's ancient windows. Late last night all still were at large.

Seemingly since the very day 108 years ago when it began playing host to thugs, murderers and drunkards, the Brooklyn City Prison (Raymond Street Jail) has been the target of unremitting criticism from crime commissions, rand juries, civic groups and the icarcerated inmates.

BERLIN, Jan. 2--Two important decisions relative to the German peace treaty have been made by the United States and Great Britain as a result of the economic merger of their zones of occupied Germany, United States Military Government officials disclosed today.

LONDON, Jan. 2--The chances that the Jews as well as the Arabs will be represented when the conference, called by Britain to consider the Palestine problem, is resumed here, were declared about even in Zionist quarters tonight.

PARIS, Jan. 2--Marius Moutet, Minister of France Overseas, made a daring secret departure by air for bombarded Hanoi today coincident with a declaration credited to Ho Chi Minh, President of the Viet Nam republic, in favor of a negotiated peace in Indo-China.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Jan. 2 (U.P.)--Air Field Marshal Erhard Milch, Hermann Goering's righthand man in the German Air Force, was put on trial before a United States military tribunal today. He was charged with illtreating civilians in conquered countries, planning slave-labor programs and torturing and murdering concentration camp inmates and prisoners of war.

BERLIN, Jan. 2--A strong appeal for the abolition of occupation sector lines in Berlin, which make reconstruction "impossible" was made before the new city Magistrate today by Otto Ostrowski new Oberbuergermeister.
LONDON, Jan. 2--The repercussions of the coal shortage on British industry affected vital building-materials plants today, threatening serious curtailment of the new housing program.

A mortgage loan of $3,300,000 for ten years on the leasehold estate of 1785 Broadway, known as the General Motors Building, has been obtained by the Motors Realty Corporation, John H. G. Pell, president, from the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company of Newark, N. J. The financing was arranged by the Hammond, Harvey, Braxton Company, as broker.

ALBANY, Jan. 2--With the average automobile more than eight years old, Senator Thomas C. Desmond of Newburgh said today that he would introduce at the coming session four bills designed to promote safety on the highways.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The House Naval Affairs Committee reported today that the Navy had discriminated against reserve officers by using two sets of standards for disability retirement. It was charged that regular officers had received "overly liberal" treatment.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In his letter dealing with Czechoslovak minorities, Mr. Hrobak takes issue with the present regime, which is accused of being directed against the Slovak people.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 2--In a joint application, Gas and Electric Associates and its parent, General Public Utilities Corporation, applied today to the Securities and Exchange Commission for approval of a plan leading to the liquidation of the subsidiary.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2--President Truman accepted today the resignation of John G. Winant as representative of the United States on the Economic and Social Council of the United Nations.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 2--The Rev. Dr. M. Ashby Jones, retired Baptist minister and one of the South's leaders in the development of good-will among racial and religious groups, died here today at the age of 78.

Progress was reported last evening in the negotiations between tugboat operators and workers after a two-hour conference at City Hall before the Mayor's new emergency labor committee. However, details of latest offers by both parties were not revealed.

Indicating the general trend in year-end bank statements, resultant from the United States Treasury's debt retirement activities, the Dec. 31, 1946, statement of the National City Bank of New York, released yesterday, discloses a sharp drop in deposits and resources.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The year 1946, in which consumers established an all-time spending record, saw reconversion of industry from war to peace preparations virtually concluded, the Department of Commerce reported in a survey issued here today.

MOSCOW, Jan. 2--Workers in Leningrad industry were urged today to end the fines for spoilage and wastage, which in ten months of 1946 amounted to 85,000,000 rubles; to raise per capita production and to eliminate high labor turnover.

LONDON, Jan. 2 (Reuters) -- Under the wartime arrangements by which they were chartered, all of the 229 ocean-going cargo ships that Britain has under "bare boat" charter from the United States, and any ships similarly chartered by other Allies, must be bought outright or returned to the United States within six months of the declaration of the end of hostilities.
Henry Morgenthau Jr., former Secretary of the Treasury, has become the first general chairman of the United Jewish Appeal, which seeks $170,000,000 this year, the organization announced yesterday.

The 19,637-ton Italian liner Saturnia will be substituted for the Vulcania in the New York-Mediterranean passenger trade, effective on Jan. 13 when the former sails from Genoa, it was announced here yesterday by George C. Gaede, passenger traffic manager of the American Export Lines.

The three-story garden-type apartment house accommodating seven families at 2395 Palisade Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by the 2395 Realty Corporation, John P. Powers, president, to an investing client of Pross, Smith Halpern, attorneys.

The Eightieth Congress meets today with much important work to do and some doubt, which we hope will be happily resolved, as to its ability to do it. If the national legislature consisted solely of the two Houses of Congress the doubt would be less, though the position of the President this year would be trying, indeed.

The curiosity of three plainclothes men of Assistant Chief Inspector Frank Fristensky's new squad in East Harlem, which has been seeking clues in the Scottoriggio Election Day killing, was aroused at noon yesterday when they observed several men enter and leave the Jefferson Democratic Club on the ground floor of 411 East 100th Street.

Advertising dollars are being "wasted" in the campaign to promote the good-will of the public for business, partly by making the insertions in publications whose readers generally do not need to be convinced of business' side of the story, advertising spokesmen stated yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2--Admiral Byrd was quoted today by the Moral Rearmament Movement as saying that his program was a world force through which a "new spirit in human nature" could be created.

Most organizations affiliated with the National Education Association are company unions controlled by school administrators, Irving Kuenzli, secretary-treasurer of the American Federation of Teachers, charged yesterday.

Theodore Gilmore Bilbo, of Poplarville, Mississippi, comes to the door of the United States Senate today labeled with the charge, formally made by the War Investigating Committee, that he "improperly used his high office as United States Senator for his personal gain in his dealings with war contractors."

The nation's gasoline stocks last week increased sharply by 3,572,000 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the end of the week they amounted to 93,126,000 barrels, compared with 89,554,000 a week earlier and 96,198,000 on Dec. 29, 1945.
AMSTERDAM, Jan. 2 (Aneta) --The first session of the new year on the Stock Exchange revealed a quiet trading market and the price movement irregular.

As a result of the United States Treasury's action, drawing down its balances in the War Loan Deposits account, as part of its debt retirement policy, total resources of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York, as of Dec. 31, 1946 dropped about $1,000,000,000 from the level at the year's end in 1945, it was disclosed by the bank's statement of condition released yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP)--The Administration took another step in the direction of lowered trade barriers today by scheduling a series of open hearings on the proposed charter of the International Trade Organization.

Slawson Hobbs were the brokers in the sale of the five-story apartment house at 33 West Seventy -fifth Street by Mrs. T. G. Gunsinger to Dr. Ben Pine, who will use part of the building for his residence and dental offices.

The Faculty Athletic Committee of City College, after hearing testimony from Nat Holman, basketball coach, and several of his assistants, yesterday issued a brief resolution declaring that C.C. N.Y. felt "compelled to refrain from scheduling athletic contests with any team with which Everett Shelton is associated."

TOKYO, Jan. 2--Faced with chronic dislocation of Japan's key industries, the Government of Premier Shigeru Yoshida has decided to establish a Government corporation with sole authority to handle the distribution of coal, oil and chemical fertilizer, all on the list of extreme shortages, it was learned tonight.

Coincident with the release of its earnings for nine months, which more than doubled those of the previous year's period, the Grand Union Company announced yesterday the election of J. Spencer Weed as chairman of the board and of Lansing P. Shield as president.
Grant Chamberlain has joined Venus Foundation Garments, Inc., as assistant to the president. He formerly was with Abbott Kimball Company, advertising agency, and before that with Conde Nast.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 2 (U.P.)--England dismissed Australia for a first-innings total of 365 runs and then made 147 for one wicket before stumps were drawn today in the third cricket test match. England's spurt after losing the first two of the total of five matches gave it a good fighting chance to win this match, at least, and hope of final victory.
SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 2 --Clarence Bayley Riker, naturalist, explorer, exporter and drug manufacturer, died here today at his home, 432 Scotland Road, after a long illness. His age was 83.
The role of the New York Academy of Medicine in medical progress in the last 100 years was described last night by Dr. George Baehr, its recently re-elected president.

LONDON, Jan. 2 (AP)--David Ben-Gurion, chairman of the Jewish Agency Executive, said tonight he was sure that a Jewish state would be created in Palestine, now facing the possibility of what a British Government source said might be martial law and smallscale war.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2--During the week ended Dec. 31, 1946, member bank reserve balances decreased $391,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 2 (AP) --Scoring easily against a listless University of Rochester quintet, New York University rolled to a 61-31 conquest of the Rivermen before a crowd of 3,000 here tonight.
Six of the nine men, all ex-convicts, who fled the Brooklyn City Prison yesterday started their careers in crime as juveniles, police records showed.

Declaring administration of Section 102 of the Internal Revenue Code may impair the credit of small and medium-sized business, the tax committee of the New York Credit Men's Association will request the Internal Revenue Department to make a clear-cut statement of policy, Earl N. Felio, president, announced yesterday.

BERLIN, Jan. 2--In a highly unfavorable review of Richard Strauss' "Salome," as performed by the Berlin State Opera, The Tribune, a new Berlin newspaper, pays its respects to Strauss and Hans Pfitzner for making themselves available to the Hitler regime.

Coincident with the release of its earnings for nine months, which more than doubled those of the previous year's period, the Grand Union Company announced yesterday the election of J. Spencer Weed as chairman of the board and of Lansing P. Shield as president.
Grant Chamberlain has joined Venus Foundation Garments, Inc., as assistant to the president. He formerly was with Abbott Kimball Company, advertising agency, and before that with Conde Nast.

From the series of articles by Mr. Lawrence on the growth of communism in Latin America (the last article in the series is published this morning) there are perhaps two chief conclusions to be drawn. The first is that the United States is faced with a new kind of criticism and hostility on the part of fairly large and certainly well-organized minority groups in the countries to the south of us.

A visit with Uncle Dan, the old gunsmith who combines with this ancient craft a bit of tinkering, trading and philosophy, has never failed to be both interesting and profitable, despite the fact that we have never completed any "swap" with him on the basis originally planned.

Navigation and fishing, boat carpentry and diving will be taught to hundreds of young war victims in courses scheduled aboard the yacht "Marfa," a new training center set up in Marseilles by ORT, Organization for Rehabilitation through Training.

The first penicillin plant in China opened on Jan. 1 under American Bureau for Medical Aid to China auspices, Dr. J. Heng Liu, medical director of the bureau, announced yesterday at its headquarters, 1790 Broadway.

Record Buyer Influx Seen Advance indications point to a record influx of coat and suit buyers during January, according to resident buying offices yesterday. Arrivals will exceed those in January, 1946, by a large margin, it was predicted, because stores have shortened buying periods and generally held off on full requirements when the season's activity opened in November.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2--Senate Democrats, organizing for their minority role in the Eightieth Congress, which convenes at noon tomorrow, unanimously re-elected Senator Alben W. Barkley today as their floor leader.
ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 2(AP)-- Louis B. Mayer's vaunted Busher came back to the races today after an absence of nearly a year and a half and ran fifth in a six-horse field at Santa Anita Park.

Taking a page from the book publishing industry, which has found it profitable to issue reprints of popular periodicals, the Twentieth Century Sporting Club will present a program of encores at Madison Square Garden tonight. Three ten-round bouts will be offered, each one pairing gladiators who have shown against one another in the past.

Just before the turn of the century a 12-year-old boy named Melchior Pio Vincent Sardi perched precariously on top of a beer case in the sub-cellar of the Victoria Restaurant in London. He needed the beer case because he was too small to reach the high sink to scrub away at dirty dishes.

We print on this page today a letter from an indignant reader about New York's smoke problem. We share this reader's indignation and his belief that too little is said and done to mitigate this nuisance. Even in cities where smoke is worst it is difficult to rouse Government and the people to effective action.

Largely reflecting year-end repayments of indebtedness, the volume of commercial, industrial and agricultural loans of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System during the week ended on Tuesday night, declined for the second consecutive week, it was disclosed yesterday.

In an appraisal of the fundamental reasons for a prolonged boom, the National City Bank's monthly letter, released yesterday, cited three factors that "should give assurance against general or major liquidation."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2--Representatives Charles A. Halleck of Indiana and Sam Rayburn of Texas, respectively, will lead the Republican and Democratic parties in the new House of Representatives.

Seven hundred enemy aliens, including 305 Germans on Ellis Island, face imminent deportation as a result of a decision yesterday by the United States Circuit Court of Appeals. The decision sustained a ruling by District Judge Simon H. Rifkind, who last August dismissed a writ of habeas corpus in a test case involving Herman Schleuter, 31-year-old Queens bartender and member of the German American Bund.

A veteran who decided to give to the Hundred Neediest Cases the money he otherwise would spend for a New Year's Eve celebration sent $10 yesterday to the Fund. It was accompanied by a letter that said: "Enclosed you will find a check for $10 as an anonymous contribution in memory of the men who did not come back and the veterans still in our hospitals.

DURING the German occupation of Denmark a novel was published in Copenhagen with the unsuspicious approval of the Nazi censors. Since it was a quaint and romantic story of two innocent young girls and their mysterious adventures in the year 1840 it is hardly surprising that to German eyes it seemed unpolitical. It wouldn't be surprising if it seemed so to Danes or to Americans, either.

Kurt von Schuschnigg, last prewar Austrian chancellor, said in his memoirs, published today by G.P. Putnam's Sons, that the Italian foreign office had a pipeline into the British foreign office in the autumn of 1937 and for some time before and after.

The Tennessee Valley Authority was one of those great American enterprises which expanded with almost incredible speed to meet wartime requirements. On several of its new dams world's records were broken. Its new power flowed into Oak Ridge and helped to produce the atomic bomb.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The House Military Affairs Committee of the last Congress issued today a sharply critical report on United States Army occupation policies in the European theatre. The report cited in particular the Army's laxity in denazification, failure to promote the Government's foreign policy, and prevalence of blackmarket practices by the "vast majority" of the United States military personnel.

THIS bowl business on New Year's Day is getting sillier and sillier. It wasn't a bad idea in its original conception in that it was designed to decide the national intercollegiate football championship--and glorify California weather. The Rose Bowl game was not only the biggest game of the season but it also was the only game on that particular day.

The tenure of "Made in Heaven" at Henry Miner's will end Jan. 11. Starring Donald Cook, the Hagar Wilde comedy is a commentary on marriage and will have recorded a run of 100 performances (nine were paid previews) when it closes.

OTTAWA, Jan. 2--Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King will be among the first to receive Canadian citizenship papers at ceremonies that will begin tomorrow. The proceedings will be in accord with the Act creating Canadian citizenship, which became Valid yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The United States has made a third effort to induce Russia to adjust her Lend-Lease account of more than $11,000,000,000 with this country, the State Department said today.

The majority of the debutantes of this season attended last night the second and final Junior Assembly of the winter, which was given in its traditional locale, the main, ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. An all-white floral setting, instead of the pink-and-green decor that had been used customarily for the Assemblies, was effected for last night's fete.

The stock market remained yesterday in its operating area of the current week with little disposition among traders to alter holdings substantially. Prices received a slight lift during the afternoon to recover most of the morning inroads, but volume remained light.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Dec. 28 were 627,967 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 208,214 cars, or 24.9 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week; 121,990 cars, or 24.1 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year, and 43,091 cars, or 7.4 per cent, more than during the corresponding week two years ago.
Joseph B. Mayer, organizer and official of a number of traction and utility corporations at the turn of the century, will celebrate his ninety-ninth birthday today at his home, 270 Park Avenue.

A "victory dinner" to commemorate the adoption on Monday of the United States proposals by the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission was given last night at the Louis Sherry Restaurant, 300 Park Avenue, by Bernard M. Baruch, United States delegate and originator of the proposals.

As a cooperative gesture toward the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, Inc., the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York announced yesterday that it had made badly needed facilities in the Bronx available for dependent and neglected Protestant children for the next fifteen months.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Mr. Baruch was right to propose that the veto power should be eliminated with respect to punishing a violator of the proposed atomic energy controls, but he would be wrong to insist that his plan in its entirety ought to stand or fall on that issue.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission refused today to suspend tariffs filed with it by the Middle Atlantic States Motor Carrier Conferences carrying increases on motor carrier traffic between points in those States and between points in New England and Middle Atlantic States, as well as certain increases in the New York shorthaul area, effective on Jan. 6.

Store Gains Put at About 40% Retail trade here continued active this week, with the postholiday letdown not particularly marked. Department store sales were estimated at about 40 per cent ahead of the like period last year.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3 -- At the opening hearing before a three-man arbitration board hers today, the Air Line Pilots Association, AFL, submitted its proposed wage increase for pilots of Trans-World Airline Skymaster and Constellation planes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The Eightieth Congress was organized today with but seven women members, two of whom, Representative Mary T. Norton, Democrat of New Jersey, and Representative Frances P. Bolton, Republican of Ohio served as tellers in the speakership shift.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Robert M. Littlejohn, administrator of the War Assets Administration, indicated today that the Big Inch and Little Big Inch pipelines, when disposed of, would be used probably for the transportation of natural gas.

When a Russian newspaper correspondent goes home from a visit to this country he is not expected to report that life is better in New York City than it is in Moscow. As we understand freedom of the press in Russia he can write whatever he thinks is true but there are some thing's -- and this is one of them -- he must not think are true.

The possibility that 150 tenants of the Murray Hill Hotel, Park Avenue and Forty-first Street, who have been fighting eviction for nearly a year, would yet win Municipal Court permission to remain for an additional six months was seen yesterday by Gustave A. Gerber, their attorney.

ALBANY, Jan. 3 -- Governor Dewey will request an additional $25,000,000 appropriation for temporary housing from the Legislature when it reconvenes next week, it was disclosed today. The $35,000,000 voted for the purpose at the last session is said to be exhausted.

VIENNA, Jan. 3 -- Replacement of the present Allied Council for Austria by a civilian body with limited powers is understood to be recommended in the tentative United States draft of the peace treaty for Austria now being circulated among the four occupying powers.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 3 -- With deficiencies in the Red Bank Oil Company's annual financial reports virtually eliminated by recently filed supplemental information, the Securities and Exchange Commission ruled today that it would not require any further suspension of trading in the company's common stock of the New York Curb Exchange.

A banking group headed by Phelps, Fenn Co. received award yesterday of two issues of Minneapolis bonds aggregating $6,500,000. The winning group bid 100.3806 for $3,310,000 refunding bonds as 1.40s, and 100,4406 for $3,200,000 of various-purpose bonds as l 1/2s.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your recent editorial on the national debt you measure the seriousness of the debt by its relation to the national income, and show that the debt now "has almost doubled the national income in size."

The backlog of export cargo held in the Port of New York increased over the holiday season to nearly 12,000 carloads, more than it was at the end of the costly maritime strike last fall, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Department -store sales in the week ended Dec. 28 were 76 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. This large gain reflected in part the fact that Christmas fell on Wednesday and the week therefore included two days of pre-Christmas shopping instead of one in 1945, when Christmas fell on Tuesday.

Alfred Minutolo, Alcatraz veteran who led eight other prisoners in a break from Brooklyn City Prison on Thursday, was captured in a church in Montvale, N. J., a little after 8 o'clock last night. He offered no resistance.

While retailers expect a substantial share of increased sales early this year to come from major electrical appliances, a check-up yesterday showed that store stocks of this merchandise must expand sharply if the anticipated volume is to be obtained.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were moderately active yesterday, prices were steady and closing quotations were 16 to 31 points net higher than on Thursday.
Arthur J. Hocking has been appointed manager of sales promotion in the footwear division of the U.S. Rubber Company. He has been with the company since 1943.

Janos Scholz, 'cellist, gave a recital last night at Town Hall, for which he had arranged a comprehensive program, having as its principal offerings Beethoven's Sonata in A major, Op. 69; Schubert's Arpeggione Sonata, and, as a novelty, the "Sonata for 'Cello and Piano," by Mark Wessel, which received its first New York presentation.

The House Committee on Un-American Activities (successor to the old Dies Committee) has discarded some of the more sensational findings reported last week by its now-departed chief counsel, Ernie Adamson, but this caution has not restrained its recommendations in the matter of new legislation.
Several organizations sent their gifts to the Hundred Neediest Fund yesterday. Among them was the Radio Executives Club of New York, which gave $505.
HONOLULU, Jan. 3 -- Creation of a Hawaiian Area Command to implement Admiral John H. Towers' joint staff set-up in the Central Pacific wag announced today by Lieut. Gen. John E. Hull.

Mr. and Mrs. Walter Cooley Douglas of 277 Park Avenue and Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of Mrs, Douglas' daughter, Miss Sallie Cronkhite, to Trumbull Richard, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold C. Richard of this city and York Harbor, Me.

The Brooklyn College basketball team captured a thriller from John Marshall of Jersey City, 54--50, in an overtime battle that saw the lead change hands sixteen times before the Brooks came through with three consecutive tallies in the extra session to win their fourth in six starts on the Flatbush court last night.

Rises in minimum weekly wages from 20 to 55 cents an hour for service employes and from 30 to 85 cents an hour for non-service employes in the hotel and restaurant industries in New York State were urged yesterday by two American Federation of Labor representatives testifying before State Labor Department minimum wage boards.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In selecting a "new School Superintendent for New York City, confusion would be cleared up if all who want the choice to be made on the basis of educational qualifications and administrative ability would concentrate on a single candidate.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: According to the Moscow News as quoted in THE NEW YORK TIMES under the headline "Soviet Cites Gains in Reshaped Baltic," a certain Latvian bolshevik dignitary, Vilis Lacis (who at the time also paid lip service to the democratic government of President K. Ulmanis), promises for Latvia in 1950 electric power plants and visualizes other achievements of the Latvian "five-year plan."

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 3 (AP) -- With Warren Wright's sluggish Pot O' Luck failing for the second time at the meeting to get into the picture, Mrs. Lou Rabinowitz's Tel O'Sullivan easily captured today's featured Kirkconnel Purse before 9,254 sun-bathed fans at Tropical Park.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The newly elected Speaker of the House, Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr. of Massachusetts, pledged the Republican party today in his first speech from the dais to a course of conservatism. He promised reductions in Government spending and in taxes and, while his triumphant colleagues shouted their approval, he declared:

NOW here is that $64 question again: "Can we get along with the Soviets?" "Yes," says Maj. Gen. John R. Deane, USA, retired, who was head of the American Military Mission in Moscow, 1943-45, in his new book, "The Strange Alliance,"* a lively and revealing story of our somewhat frantic, frustrated and infuriated efforts at wartime cooperation with the Soviets.

Hamilton National Chattanooga The Hamilton National Bank, Chattanooga, Tenn., reported as of Dec. 31, 1946, total deposits of $123,492,918 and total assets of $130,167,596, compared, respectively with $123,880,703 and $131,026,054 on Sept. 30.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Jan. 3 -- The American businessman reading stories of the tremendous export program envisaged by military government officials as part of the economically unified American and British, zones would do well to think more than twice before attempting to book passage to Germany in the hope of getting in on the ground floor.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 3 -- Firemen fought the disastrous Winecoff Hotel fire with obsolete, handoperated ladders, "which are largely twenty-five years old and entirely out of keeping with modern fire-fighting equipment," it was charged today in special presentments by the Fulton County (Atlanta) grand jury.

Benjamin Parry, chief of the local Weather Bureau and a native of the skiing country around Fairhaven, Vt., recently told this correspondent that trying to analyze the elements was an abusive assignment, some being pleased at the results forecast and others displeased. Yesterday was an instance, a very distinct one, where an interpretation of skiing conditions in the Northlands was as confusing as the vagaries of the weather gods.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The text of retiring Speaker Sam Rayburn's introduction of his successor, Joseph W. Martin Jr., was as follows: We have come to the opening of the Eightieth Congress. During all of these years the House of Representatives has deserved and has had the respect of the thinking public of our country.

All foreign troops should be removed from Greece, in the opinion of Princess Irene, whose husband, Prince Peter, is first cousin of King George II of Greece. The auburnhaired, violet-eyed visitor from Cairo, where her husband is now supervising the closing of services used by the Greek Army for five years, side-stepped political questions for the most part in a mass press interview yesterday in the Ritz-Carlton.

MASTIC PARK, L. I., Jan. 3 -- Mrs. Emma Taylor, 66 years old, was found dead of coal gas poisoning, and her husband, Frederick Taylor, 62, and their grandson, Frederick Martin, 29, were unconscious from the fumes when police entered the Taylor bungalow on Prospect Place here this afternoon.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 3-- Liberty is the practical recognition of the great variety in human forms (polymorphism), J.B.S. Haldane, noted British geneticist, told the Princeton bicentennial conference on genetics, paleontology and evolution here tonight.

Charles Palmer, 24 years old, out of the Navy less than a month, inflicted serious knife wounds on his wife and her father during a family argument yesterday in their home at 50 Cabrini Boulevard, Washington Heights, and then shot himself fatally with an Army rifle.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Yale's Tony Lavelli rolled 24 points into the hoop tonight, but Baldwin Wallace snapped its four-game losing streak by handing the Bulldogs a 51-to-47 defeat in the first half of a basketball twin bill at the Arena.

Protestant Episcopal Church, schools showed increased enrollment instead of a decrease for the first time since 1939, according to statistics for 1946 appearing in the Living Church Annual for 1947, published this month. The total shown in the summary was 404,253, an increase of 9,797 over the 1945 report of 394,456.

The threat of an immediate strike by tugboat workers has been removed for as long as negotiations continue before Mayor O'Dwyer's emergency labor committee. As matters stood last night, following in all-day series of meetings, tug operators and workers were only a few pennies away from final settlement.

LONDON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Both Government informants and Jewish Agency sources predicted that Sir Alan G. Cunningham would ask for authority from the British Cabinet to launch an all-out offensive against Jewish underground resistance.

DUBLIN, Ireland, Jan. 3--Ireland, which during the worst stages of the war escaped having its bread rationed, is now, paradoxically enough, driven to ration its bread and flour. Sean F. Lemass, Minister of Industry and Commerce, made the announcement over the radio here tonight.

With the first crack of Starter Jack Lavelle's gun at the Grover Cleveland games in the Seventh Regiment Armory tonight, the barrier will be sprung on the 1947 indoor track season. Everything points to the coming campaign as the most notable since pre-war days.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The Republicans' long-heralded bill to reduce personal income taxes 20 per cent, retroactive to Jan. 1, was introduced as House Resolution No. 1 today, but with two new and unexpected features.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 3 -- Col. A. Roscher Lund, who directed Norway's intelligence service during the war, will bead the staff that is to accompany a Security Council investigating mission to the Balkans.

Indications regarding the outlook for small loan companies point to a rising volume of business for some time to come, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York says in the January issue of its Monthly Review of Credit and Business Conditions, released yesterday.

SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. John R. Hodge, commanding American forces in southern Korea, issued a statement today denying "assumptions" that the United States was working toward a separate government for its occupation zone.

Rhode Island State's exponents of total offense and Southern Methodist's quintet will be the visitors in tonight's intersectional college basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden. The highscoring Rams will engage St. John's after the Mustangs meet New York University in the opener at 8 P.M.

Twelve Liberty-type merchant vessels damaged beyond economical repair by enemy action or marine casualty have been offered for sale for scrapping purposes, the Maritime Commission said yesterday. Sealed bids are scheduled for opening in Washington on Jan. 29.
Part of the pennant hopes of the New York Yankees will be hospitalized next Monday when Joe DiMaggio enters a hospital here for an operation to remove a bone spur from his left heel.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 3 (AP) -- After the first round of the $10,000 Los Angeles open golf tournament today, former national amateur king Bud Ward, and professional Tony Penna of Cincinnati tied for the lead with twounder-par cards of 69.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 3 -- Milos Trifunovitch, 76-year-old Premier of the emigre wartime Yugoslav Government, today denied having ever written an intelligence report for the United States Embassy in Belgrade. He made the denial when he took the stand during the third day of the espionage trial here.

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- Pressure on the British Colonial and Foreign Offices to find a speedy solution of the Palestine impasse increased today following the resumption of terrorist activity in the Holy Land yesterday.
LONDON, Jan. 3--Although business in the stock markets tended to ease today, most sections finished the week on a good note.

Two California designers and a Danish architect received citations of merit yesterday from the American Institute of Decorators for creating the best designs in furniture, fabric and wallpaper introduced to American consumers during 1946, it was announced here Honored were Charles Eames of Venice, Calif., Dorothy Liebes of San Francisco and Bent Karlby of Copenhagen.

John Roy Carlson, author of "Under Cover" and "The Plotters," in which he discussed alleged subversive groups in this country, reported to the police early today that he had been attacked by three men late last night near the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

NANKING, Jan. 3 -- Student demonstrations were staged around the American Embassy again today. A delegation entered the residence of Ambassador John Leighton Stuart to protest against the alleged assault on a Chinese girl by a marine in Peiping and against the presence of United States forces in China.
PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 3 --Communities in Westchester County served by the New York, New Haven Hartford railroad prepared this afternoon to fight the application for commutation rate increases.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 3 -- When Garson Kanin resumes activities soon in the films as an independent producer, he will set up shop on the Universal-International lot. His first pictures, at least, will be released by that studio.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.1 per cent during the week ended on Dec. 28, as lower prices for agricultural commodities more than offset advances for several industrial goods. The index of primary market prices prepared by the Bureau of Labor Statistics declined to 139.6 per cent of the 1926 average, 0.4 per cent above a month earlier, and 30.5 higher than the corresponding week of 1945.

A work stoppage by union drivers has cut off supplies to about 5,000 manufacturing bakeries in New York City, Nassau County and parts of New Jersey and Westchester County since last Thursday, it was announced yesterday by Leon Jaffe, counsel for the Association of Wholesale Food Merchants, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Chester Bowles called tonight on American liberals to organize a progressive front, divorced from Communist influence, to work through the Democratic party "with all its faults."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: May I call attention to the action of Congress making Jan. 5 George Washington Carver national observance day. Most of our State Governors have already issued proclamations in honor of this fitting occasion. These official acts are of public interest not only because of Dr. Carver's long years of outstanding service but also because of his lowly origin and the unique character of his achievements.

Making the last stage of her journey by train from Chicago after a flight from the West Coast Ida McGuire, dancer and film bit player, arrived here yesterday to testify in the bribery trial of Alvin J. Paris that is scheduled to begin in General Sessions before Judge Saul S. Streit on Monday.

"The Negro Handbook, 19461947," edited by Florence Murray, a manual of statistics and general information about Negroes in America, will be issued by Current Books, Inc. A.A. Wyn on Jan. 20. Last published in 1944, it features a summary of the Negro's role in World War II.

Uncertainties of price trends on copper, lead and steel products, builders' hardware, plumbing and heating supplies and wage rates for both industrial workers and building trades are holding up stabilization of prices of industrial and commercial construction and thus forcing a continuation of cost plus building contracts, industry members disclosed here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The Federal Trade Commission transmitted to Congress today its annual report covering activities for the fiscal year ended June 30, 1946.

Formation of Dreyfus, Jacquin Co. as successor to the New York Stock Exchange firm of Lewisohn Co. was disclosed yesterday by Max Jacquin Jr., Lewisohn partner and former Stock Exchange official. The new investment firm will commence operations on Feb. 1.

The North American Conference on Church Architecture will meet at 10 A.M. today at the National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park South. Its session will be opened with devotions led by Dr. Deane Edwards, executive secretary of the Commission on Worship of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America.

The city is abandoning the old Wassermann test for syphilis and is introducing instead a new triple test series in connection with all syphilis examinations in the serological laboratory, Dr. Israel Weinstein, Health Commissioner, told a meeting of the New York City branch of the Society of American Bacteriologists in Hotel New Yorker last night.

Walter Blake, for the past eight years account executive handling Warner Bros. Pictures, Inc., for the Blaine-Thompson Co., Inc, will resign Jan. 17 to join the Los Angeles office of McCann-Erickson, Inc., it was announced yesterday. He will be an account executive at the latter agency, in charge of its motion picture business.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Jan. 3 -- Miles T. Thompson, division chief in charge of construction at the Western Electric Company's huge new plant at Winston-Salem, N.C., pleaded guilty today to a charge of conspiring to defraud the company.

MADISON, Wis., Jan. 3 -- Dr. Helen C. White, author and Professor of English at the University of Wisconsin, said today that the membership policy of the American Association of University Women, of which she is president, had been reaffirmed by the national board.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Congressional leaders acclaimed the importance of the medium of television in bringing to the American people first-hand views of their Government in action.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 3 -- A warning that failure to curb terrorism immediately would bring the reimposition of drastic government measures against the entire Jewish population went to the Jewish Agency for Palestine today following the attacks of yesterday and today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- An improvement in the rapid moisture conditioning of grain, particularly wheat for milling, has been developed by Elizabeth J. Sullivan of Minneapolis, Minn., to whom was issued this week Patent 2,413,472 on a process materially reducing the "tempering time" required.

A detective who surprised two 16-year-old boys in a hold-up last night in a Bronx liquor store shot and killed one of the youths, wounded another and was himself wounded in the exchange of shots. A third youth, also 16 and a member of the same gang, was seized a short time afterward in a neighborhood candy store.

TOKYO, Jan. 3 (AP) -- A former Kamikaze pilot who "naturally wanted to kill as many Americans as possible" during the war, is going to America for a college education offered by the parents of a United States Army private who was killed on Luzon.
John Powers, who celebrated his 100th birthday last Nov. 19 in Bellevue Hospital, was back in the institution last night for a physical check-up and a rest.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 3 (AP) -- Warning that racing prosperity which netted New Jersey $6,214,272 last year cannot long continue, the State Racing Commission said today it is opposed to increased taxation for the tracks.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- A comparison of the tax burden of a married person under 65 years of age, with no dependents, under present law and under HR1, the Republican income tax reduction bill introduced today, is as follows:

Dr. Stephen S. Wise, founder and former president of the Zionist Organization of America and for many years its official spokesman here and abroad, announced last night his severance from all official connection with the body.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The whole Eightieth Congress came to life at noon today, but the Senate stile the show with its contest over the seating of Senator Theodore G. Bilbo.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- In three separate opinions today the members of the National Labor Relations Board gave their views on he scope which the National Labor Relations (Wagner) Act permits in employer to take in "freedom of speech."

Officials of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America put forward yesterday as their principal objective in forthcoming wage negotiations the full recovery of an estimated weekly loss in real wages of $11.72.

A series of moves lies ahead by which 300 members of the congregation of St. Nicholas Church, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, their officers and minister, will proceed to formalize their secession from the Consistory of the Collegiate Reformed Dutch Church of the City of New York.

National Department Stores The directors of the National Department Stores Corporation declared yesterday a year-end extra dividend of 50 cents a share on the common stock, in addition to the regular quarterly of 25 cents, both payable on Jan. 15.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- International teamwork in health has come of age and no longer needs the stimulant of war, the Health Division of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration declared today in a final statement.

Despot's Foot Removed So this fortunate land begins the new year with the specter of military domination banished and the conscious life of the nation safeguarded against the fell influence of the "military mind."

The nine-State police search for the elusive Al Rocco, accused of master-minding the "camera-gun" shooting plot that resulted in his former wife's losing her left leg from a shotgun burst in a Times Square subway station Tuesday morning, remained fruitless yesterday.
Rain and heavy fog obscured the waterfront in the metropolitan area during the morning rush hours yesterday, resulting in delays to ferryboat commuters ranging from ten minutes to a half-hour.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Jan. 3 -- Gen. Paul Almassy, former chief of staff of the Hungarian army, was arrested last night. This was the latest development in the campaign of the political police department of the War Ministry and the Communist-staffed Ministry of the Interior against persons accused as members of an alleged conspiracy to overthrow the Government.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 3 -- Death came today for Alfred E. Herpin, a recluse who lived on the outskirts of the city and insisted that he never slept. He was 94 years old and, when questioned concerning his claim of "sleeplessness," maintained that he never actually dozed but merely "rested."

DETROIT, Jan. 3--Judge Frank A. Picard, in Federal District Court, granted today to the Department of Justice the right to file a brief for his consideration in a re-examination of his now celebrated portal-to-portal pay case, and was, himself, accused of assuming the triple role of jurist, witness and jury through a new approach to the case.

ROME, Jan. 3--Premier Alcide de Gasperi left for the United States by air today. He headed an official delegation that will confer with Washington officials. Dr. de Gasperi's daughter, Maria Romana, is a member of the delegation.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 3 (AP) -- The New Orleans Cotton Exchange has released a proposed threepoint program of the Exchanges here and in Chicago and New York to tighten rules of trading in cotton with a view to preventing price upheavals in the markets.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- President Truman was putting the finishing touches on his 1947 State of the Union message today, with plans to deliver it in person to an opposition Congress on Monday, Jan. 6, if the new Legislature is formally organized by that time.

Bank of Athens Trust The Bank of Athens Trust Company reported as of Dec. 31, 1946, total deposits of $24,070,969 and total assets of $26,690,851, compared, respectively, with $23,970,954 and $25,401,940 on Dec. 31, 1945.
Ship employers yesterday rejected demands of the National Maritime Union, CIO, for a 25 per cent wage increase as negotiations began on a reopening of the union's contract wage clause.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- An insurgent bloc of Democrats, demanding the seating of Senator Theodore G. Bilbo, Democrat, of Mississippi, threw the Senate into confusion right after the opening prayer of the session today and prevented the organization of the chamber.

On the Senate side no bills were introduced, and there may be none until Monday. Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio, who will be chairman of the Labor Committee, was working with Senators Joseph H. Ball of Minnesota and H. Alexander Smith of New Jersey on a labor bill which they will submit to the Republican conference before introduction.

The awards committee of the Jewish Music Council announced yesterday three prizes to be awarded in an effort to encourage composers to write musical works that will reflect the spirit and tradition of the Jewish people. These include:

BERLIN, Jan. 3 -- Infiltration of outstanding Nazis into the United States with the tentative promise of citizenship for themselves and their families was revealed today as one result of "Project Paperclip," which involves the transportation of technical experts to the United States.

The confusion that broke out in the Senate yesterday over the attempt to keep Theodore G. Bilbo of Mississippi from taking his seat must be of intense interest to any student of parliamentary proceedings. But the issue remains just what it was.

The winter furniture market which opens on Monday in Chicago will be characterized by the sharpest retailer selectivity since 1941, buyers and furniture buying office spokesmen said yesterday. It is understood that furniture stores, anticipating greatly increased quality supplies by late spring, are clearing out undesirable merchandise and will be extremely cautious in placing orders.

A specialist in the revival of musicals, the New Opera Company is contemplating a departure from its accustomed policy, it was learned yesterday. The group, of which Yolanda Mero-Irion is general manager, is planning to bring back "Topaz," the Marcel PagnolBenn W. Levy comedy, sans musical embellishments.
Ogden Mills Reid, editor of The New York Herald Tribune, died at 10:35 o'clock last night in the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center.

ABOARD MOUNT OLYMPUS, Jan. 2 (Delayed) -- The ships of the Central Group of the Navy's South Polar Task Force, including this flagship, were stalled today after penetrating fifty miles into the belt of pack ice that is probably several hundred miles wide.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 3 (AP)--H.L. Mencken, author, newspaper man and connoisseur of the end product of malt and hops, has in his safe deposit box an iron-clad contract guaranteeing him two cases of Canadian ale monthly for the rest of his life.

NEWARK, Jan. 3 -- Employes of the Harrison gas works of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company returned to work this afternoon, ending a ten-day strike that had threatened to shut off a major part of the gas supply in Essex and Hudson Counties.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 3 -- An office that has disbursed fifteen and a half billion dollars to soldiers and their dependents during the last four years is leaving Newark. Without delaying a single check, the Army's Office of Dependency Benefits is completing a move started on Nov. 1 to transfer the office to St. Louis.

PORTSMOUTH, Ohio, Jan. 3 (AP) --An hour of terror on a speeding Greyhound bus, in which two brothers went berserk, beat the driver and fired fourteen shots among the twenty-three passengers, was described here today.

An intensive police search of Manhattan's upper east side resulted last night in the capture of a young man who, the police said, admitted four hold-ups of persons in automobiles in the area that netted his jewels, fur coats and money of a total value of $100,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Though official confirmation still is lacking, authoritative sources indicated today that changes in the top European command had been decided upon, whereby Lieut, Gen. Lucius D. Clay would replace Gen. Joseph T. McNarney as United States Commander in the European theatre, and Gen. Mark W. Clark eventually would relinquish his Austrian command to Leut. Gen. Geoffrey Keyes.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 3 -- The United States, whose prestige in the Middle East probably exceeded that of any other foreign power during the war, recently has been subjected to persistent fault-finding and attack in the Egyptian press.
A wiry ex-Marine with a toy pistol lost a bitter hand-to-hand struggle yesterday to Dr. William Horowitz after he had attempted to hold up the dentist in his office at 780 Lexington Avenue.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Whisky, beer and wine sellers will get tax refunds on the stock they have on hand when lower tax rates on those beverages take effect July 1 -- if they do take effect.

Leslie Natter, 23 years old, of 134 Vernon Avenue, Brooklyn, was shot and killed at 4:30 P.M. yesterday by one of two thugs who made an unsuccessful attempt to hold up the R.N.R. Metal Products Company, toy manufacturer, at 2324 Dean Street, just off Rockaway Avenue, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- President Truman in a move to "bring the ever-present danger from fire home to all our people" will convene a national conference on fire prevention here within the next few months, the White House announced today.

Commodore Sir James G.P. Bisset, making perhaps his last voyage as a Cunard White Star Line skipper, was forced to delay the sailing of the Queen Elizabeth from Pier 90, North River, yesterday. Fog held the giant passenger ship to her berth long past her scheduled 3 P.M. departure.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Jan 3 -- This Connecticut Valley trading center, most of whose 160,000 inhabitants are thoroughly irked over the fact that they have had to do without local daily newspapers since Sept. 26, appeared today to be due for an indefinite prolongation of the dearth of local news.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: If your paper runs a "Brickbats and Bouquets" column, I think this letter may qualify for inclusion. I address you because you are the nearest counterpart in the United States of our own Times. I believe you enjoy the iame influential status in the newspaper world.

PARIS, Jan. 3 -- Speaking to the assembled Prefects of the whole of France tonight, Premier Leon Blum said the Government's purpose in decreeing the 5 per cent general price reduction now, and another on March 1, was to provoke a fall in prices of much greater proportions all along the line, including prices in the black market.

TOKYO, Jan. 3 -- The Soviet mission in Japan today requested the reasons for what it termed the "repeated postponement" of local elections for such offices as prefectural governors, prefectural assemblies and mayors of cities, towns and villages.
DETROIT, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Ernest R. Breech, executive vice president of the Ford Motor Company, predicted in a statement today that prices in general would come downward this year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Following is the text of the opening address by Joseph W. Martin Jr., as Speaker of the House: Ladies and Gentlemen of the House of Representatives of the 80th Congress: In assuming the duties of Speaker of this House of Representatives, I am deeply grateful to my colleagues for having bestowed this signal honor upon me.

ALBANY, Jan. 3 -- With the full support of Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, a commission established last year to determine the need for a State University will ask the Legislature for another year in which to pursue its study.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Apprehensions voiced yesterday by the British that President Truman's proclamation terminating the period of hostilities of the second World War would require them to return the 229 United States merchant ships they now were operating under charter were declared groundless today by Chester T. Lane, Lend-Lease Administrator.

A barrage of flying fists ushered in a new year in boxing at Madison Square Garden last night before a gathering of 12,987 fans, and when the punching was over Julio Jimenez, Mexican welterweight, Johnny Colan, Astoria light-heavyweight, and Joe Curcio, Newark (N.J.) middleweight, were the victors.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3 -- Facts and figures intended to show that labor unions, including the AFL and CIO combined, cannot and do not control elections were issued today after a survey by the Conference of American Small Business Organizations in Chicago.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Jan. 3 -- The United States zone of Germany is faced with the greatest industrial crisis since the beginning of the occupation, it was learned today. Atleast half the industries in the zone are shut down for lack of coal with little hope of reopening after the purposely extended Christmas holiday.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 3 -- Four prominent Egyptian politicians were quoted today as recommending that Egypt abandon treaty negotiations with Great Britain and seek satisfaction of her demands from the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The appointment of three expert industrial relations consultants was disclosed today by the United States Atomic Energy Commission, which took over from the Army on New Year's Day the job of developing the nation's atomic energy resources.

Team triumphs in the senior national indoor and outdoor track and field and the senior national wrestling championships marked a banner year in sports for the New York Athletic Club. The achievements of the Winged Foot athletes occupy a large section of the club's annual report for 1946.

Miss Evelyn Byrd Kobbe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Kobbe of 47 East Sixty-first Street, was married yesterday to Noel McVickar Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. McVickar, also of this city, in the chantry of St. Thomas Episcopal Church.

Newspaper Ads Up 41% Advertising in all New York newspapers last month aggregated 13,110,647 lines, compared with 9,278,584 in the corresponding month of 1945, or a gain of 41.30 per cent, according to a compilation of Media Records figures.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 3 (AP) -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower today asserted that he was a soldier and that mention of his name as a possible political candidate "is not good for the great organization I command."

GREAT NECK, L.I., Jan. 3 -- Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Arleigh Pelham of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Lillian Tyler, to Charles Gordon Robertson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles D. Robertson of Glen Cove.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3 -- Cash interests and spreaders were persistent buyers of January corn on the Board of Trade today and closing trades were at the top with a gain of 1 cent a bushel. The distant months were up 3/8 to 1/2 cent. Wheat dipped early but rallied to close with net gains of 1/4 to 5/8 cent.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Mr. Krock is entitled to his prejudices, in the same way that I am entitled to mine. However, in his column of Dec. 26 entitled "Even the Dissenters Didn't See It Coming," Mr. Krock permits his prejudices to outrun accuracy.

New Capital Market The holiday lull in the primary distribution of securities appears to be headed for some extension. While the respite from a busy and profitable December is not unwelcome, not all of it is voluntary. The week marking the end of the old year and the beginning of the new saw only one substantial flotation -- the $8,500,000 refunding issue marketed for the Sydney County Council by a Kidder, Peabody Co. syndicate.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The Eightieth Congress convened today, reflecting the Republican election victories of November in general but a Democratic one in Mississippi in particular.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Nine airmen of the Navy's Antarctic expedition are missing, overdue since Monday from a seaplane scouting flight. The Navy said here tonight that bad weather garbled the latest radio messages regarding the possible fate of the fliers.

About forty minutes north of Grand Central Station by commuting train lie the pleasant villages of Irvington, Tarrytown and North Tarrytown, looking out over the Hudson where that river widens into Tappan Zee, about three miles from shore to shore. Local pride burns hotly in each of these villages, which range in population from 3,272 to 8,804, for a total of about 18,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Here is the vote by which the Senate, on a motion by Senator Taft, today tabled motions by Senator Overton to allow Senator Bilbo to take his seat without prejudice and by Senator Taylor to bar the Mississippian: FOB TABLING -- 38

PARIS, Jan. 3 -- Bullets whistled over the heads of the official party as Marius Moutet, French Minister of France Overseas, was visiting beleaguered Hanoi today. The Minister escaped injury from snipers and returned tonight to Saigon without having seen Ho Chi Minh, Viet Nam President, who had indirectly solicited an interview.

MELBOURNE, Jan. 3 (AP) -- England's best cricket batsmen crumbled today before Australian speed and spin bowlers who retired nine while Holding the Britons to 351 runs in the first innings, fourteen short of Australia's modest 365.

Abundant quantities of both fresh and canned fruits fill the markets today, quite a reversal of the situation during the war and immediately thereafter, when the fresh products were expensive and scarce in some cases and the canned ones almost unobtainable.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (UP) -- Senator Bilbo, commenting on the day's happenings in the Senate, said: "This nincompoop Taylor stole the Republicans' show. The greatest joke of the Eightieth Congress is that a cowboy named Taylor stole the whole Republican show."

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Jan. 4-- Three men, each protesting that someone else should be punished for any crime that had been committed, were held here today by United States Commissioner M. Lester Lynch on a charge of smuggling $10,600 in diamonds from Belgium.

IN the eighteen years since Kenneth Roberts quit roaming the world as a magazine correspondent and settled at his home place at Kennebunkport, on Maine's coast, to work as a novelist, his position as a writer of American historical fiction has become just about as fit and strong as the frame of his most athletic hero.

The American Eastern Corporation's Gadsden, originally built as a Navy AK auxiliary but recently converted to the status of a "locomotive ferry," is playing an important role in the rehabilitation of France's railroad system, it was disclosed yesterday.

IN the seed catalogues just beginning to arrive, the listings that demand attention soon are those of seeds which need to be started early indoors. A few perennials can be counted in this group, if bloom is wanted during the first summer.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4--A drive to put into effect immediately most of the excise tax cuts scheduled for July 1 was launched today at the Capitol.

There's deep ice on the pond, a nip in the air, and a moon practically at the full. It's a night for skating, pond skating, with a bonfire on the bank and stout clothes to fend off the January wind, and older folk as well as youngsters on the ice.

THE Ship of Business last week entered the serene seas of what has been commonly described as a "favorable climate" when the Eightieth Congress, Republican-controlled for the first time in sixteen years, came into being.

MONTREAL, Jan. 4 (AP)--The Montreal Canadiens hammered the Boston Bruins, 4-1, before a crowd of 11,247 at the Forum tonight to move within 3 points of the first-place Toronto Maple Leafs in the National Hockey League race.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4--The Senate completed the job of organizing itself for business late today, thus clearing the stage for President Truman to deliver his annual State of the Union Message to a joint session with the House at 1 P.M. Monday.

NEW art books have piled up here at a terrific rate since our last previous survey of the situation in the issues of June 16 and June 23. I shall have to tuck them into odd nooks and crannies, as occasion permits, touching upon them a few at a time.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4--A group of 130 men and women committed to the propagation of liberal ideals and rejecting collaboration with Communists and their sympathizers established today a new organization called Americans for Democratic Action.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4--A crosssection review of 607,086 wartime courts-martial brought forth today recommendations for revision of the Navy Department's legal system and for stricter discipline of the American youth in the home.

AMONG things this department would like to see during this new year are: stabilized prices at Broadway theatres; premieres at which loudspeakers were not used to whip up crowd hysteria; father's and mother's day celebrations without movie publicity tie-ins;

Russia and the United States "came to a better understanding with each other" at the recent General Assembly session, Warren R. Austin, chief United States delegate to the United Nations, declared in a radio address last night.

NORTH or south, winter or summer, filters are an indispensable part of the photographer's camera kit. Snow exhibits its characteristic texture and flaky appearance when photographed through suitable filters, and white clouds are set off against a contrasting gray equivalent of blue sky.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 4 --The United Nations released today the text of a letter sent to Trygve Lie, Secretary General, by Secretary of State Byrnes, who as chairman of the Council of Foreign Ministers, has requested the Security Council to approve the establishment of a Free Territory of Trieste.

THE All-America Selections Committee has given seven prizes to new varieties of vegetables and flowers for 1947. These are the improved new varieties which lead the list of debuts for the year, although many other novelties will be found in the seed catalogues.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 4--Not man but rats, mice or some other humble and inconspicuous group of animals may be the ones to evolve into the higher forms that will dominate the earth in the inexorable process of evolution, Prof. Alfred S. Romer, noted Harvard paleontologist, declared today at the close of the Princeton Bicentennial Conference on genetics, paleontology and evolution.

WITH an introduction by Earl Wilson, who would have you think he is something of a bathroom fixture himself, this volume reprints short pieces, longer pieces, poetry, jokes, stories. So far as general literature is concerned, the bathroom has a connotation of Chic Sale, or passages in George Abbott's plays, but the sponsors of this new assembly fool you.

IN honor of the centenary of Thoreau's sojourn at Walden Pond, Edwin Way Teale, naturalist, author and photographer, has edited a new and appreciative "Walden." Provided with brief introductions to each chapter, illustrated with many related photographs and printed from large type, Mr. Teale's edition is an enthusiastic and lively contribution to the long shelf of editions of this great book.

Because of the vast amounts of money involved in the "portal-toportal" decision, income tax implications are important to the Treasury as well as to employers. Naturally the effects upon employers will be mitigated to the extent that such payments can be recouped by way of claims against income and excess profits taxes heretofore paid and by way of deductions from current and future taxes payable.

The four soloists and the eighteen -member mixed choir of the St. Nicholas Church, Fifth Avenue at Forty-eighth Street, agreed yesterday to ally themselves with the congregation in the controversy with its parent organization, the Consistory of the Collegiate Reformed Dutch Church of the City of New York.
Holding within a comparatively narrow range, cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange finished yesterday 14 points higher to 1 point lower than the day before.

The Florida fishing seems to be getting better every day, and although the big schools of sailfish have not as yet arrived in the Stuart-Palm Beach areas, the fishing guides there blame this tardiness on the weather.

With the Cleveland Browns placing four men on the first team and getting two on the second, the first official all-conference teams of the All-America Football Conference were announced yesterday by the circuit's office.

PROGNOSTICATION, always considered in order at this season, would seem to be even more appropriate than usual at the moment, for not only is a new calendar year beginning but a whole new period is being shaped.

TOKYO, Jan. 4 (AP)--Goaded by Soviet inquiries, the Japanese Government today ordered an extended purge of ultranationalists of the war era, but exempted high Government officials. The terms were drafted in such a way that the staff of an influential Leftist paper was subjected to screening.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Jan. 4-- The wholly Communist-controlled Hungarian Ministry of the Interior officially disclosed today a "dangerous and widespread plot against the security of the Republic." The Government said the plotters sought to return Admiral Nicholas Horthy to power.

On Dec. 11, 1946, the General Assembly of the United Nations unanimously adopted a resolution in which it defined genocide as "the denial of the right of existence of entire human groups" and called upon member States to legislate against it. The resolution was drafted by Prof. Raphael Lemkin of Duke University, an authority on international law, who served on the staff of the chief prosecutor of the United States during the Nuremberg trials.

To Elmore Harris, one of the shining lights of the 1946 season, went the honor of winning the first cup race of the 1947 indoor track campaign. The free-wheeling Negro tailor from the Bronx, who represents the Shore A.C., scored a smashing triumph in the Harry Hillman 600 at the Grover Cleveland games last night.

HER name was Josephine when William Bridges of the New York Zoological Park bought her in the Belgian Congo from a woman who had made a pet of her. Now she lives at the Zoo and they call her Billy (after Mr. Bridges), but, being a chimpanzee, she answers to neither name. She is 2 years old, gentle and amusing.

(Secretary, Local 802, American Federation of Musicians) ALTHOUGH I shall make every attempt to develop the following outline of union policy in a state of unemotional objectivity, I am afraid that somewhere I will surrender to the pleasures of righteous indignation.

ALTHOUGH Celia Johnson, winner of the New York Film Critics' award for the best performance by an actress 1946, has appeared in only four pictures, she is well known on the London stage. She was seen here briefly on Broadway, several years back, as Ophelia to Raymond Masy's Hamlet.

IT is not true to say that art and antiques dealers have the anti-social tendencies of highgrade horse thieves and grave robbers. That would be a libel on an ancient and honorable profession to which many honest and cultured persons belong.

PARIS, Jan. 4--The movement to lower prices by 5 per cent on all goods and services appeared to be gaining momentum today throughout France. More and more establishments, both commercial and professional, abandoned their original hesitancy and joined in the campaign.

TWELVE couples are represented by paintings or sculpture in the current exhibition, "Husbands and Wives," at the Laurel Gallery. Most of these artists are well known, including William and Marguerite Zorach, Kenneth Hayes and Helen Miller, Reginald Marsh and Felicia Meyer, John Sloan and Helen Farr, A.S. and Ada Baylinson, and Walter and Magda Pach.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 4-- With the new year, the International Refugee Organization, whose constitution was approved by the United Nations, is preparing to take over from UNRRA the complex problem of displaced persons in Europe.

LONDON. BRITAIN is a land where newspaper circulations often reach astonishing totals. This fact was emphasized recently when News of the World, a Sunday newspaper, announced a weekly sale of 7,412,383 copies.

ABOARD MOUNT OLYMPUS, in the Ice Pack Off Ross Sea, Jan. 3 (Delayed)--A heavy snowstorm and fog still prevented this morning the slightest search move for nine fliers lost since Monday on the Nevy expedition's scouting of Ellsworth Land, 1,200 miles east of here.

LONDON, Jan. 4 (Reuters)-- The Wolverhampton Wanderers' drive for their first English Football League championship rolled on today when they swept Blackpool, 3-1, before 45,000 fans in one of the feature games of the schedule.

With two more of the club's better players coming into the fold and Manager Melvin Ott reported due in town on Tuesday, affairs continue to hum at the winter offices of the Giants where the slogan seems to be "out of the cellar by opening day."

In the past the pupils of Joe Lapchick, St. John's basketball coach, always knew how to slow down and beat Rhode Island State, the team that feels it's in a slump, when--win or lose--it fails to ring up 100 points in a game. Four times previously.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Jan. 4 (AP)--Sixteen former officials of the German Ministry of Justice, many of them once connected with Adolf Hitler's ruthless "People's Court," were indicted today for war crimes and crimes against humanity.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4--Representative Harold Knutson presented the experience of the 1920's today in support of his thesis that taxes can be reduced without serious effect on government revenues.

TO THE EDITOR: In "Senator Ball Outlines a Labor Policy," the Senator states that we need better Federal mediation machinery, and couples this proposal with a recommendation of a sixtyday "cooling off" period, as outlined in the Case bill. * * *

"NO, you're too little." "No, you're too big," are explanations which bewilder little children and set older ones to wondering. "What size am I? When will I be right for everything?" For the 3 to 5 year olds "Linda Just Right" introduces a world which is "not too big or too little but just right."

FOR more than twelve years Kurt von Schuschnigg has been a world figure. Because he became Chancellor of Austria as the result of the murder of his predecessor, Dollfuss, by Nazis; because he was forced out of office when Hitler seized his country; and because he spent more than seven years as the prisoner of the Gestapo, he has been the beneficiary of international sympathy.

Virtual completion of the United States Treasury's current debt retirement program in the latter part of last year raises several question marks regarding developments in the money market during 1947, according to financial observers.

In a ten-point "Now, Let's Build America!" program, the National Association of Manufacturers asked the Eightieth Congress yesterday to take action to eliminate "the epidemic of strikes, labor monopolies, burdensome taxes and needless controls."

HOLLYWOOD. ONCE a year, by means of the annual Academy Awards for merit, the people of the motion picture industry bring to a crescendo their standard year-round pastime of discussing and judging each other.

As 17,000 policemen intensified their round-the-clock manhunt yesterday for the seven Brooklyn City Prison fugitives still at liberty, they extracted additional details of the nine-man jail break from the two prisoners returned to custody.
The United Nations made haste slowly on the long road to armaments control last week as the Security Council scheduled the first of a series of important meetings for Tuesday.

HERE'S the career girl observed with some intelligence and honesty, though rather tritely presented. Mona Biro had beauty, brains, shrewd instincts, plenty of drive and egotism. What she didn't have were family background, education, money, a masculine freedom of opportunity.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4--The Social Legislation Information Service, founded two years ago by forty national voluntary agencies, now needs 1,200 new subscriptions to make its work self-sustaining, Mrs. Eugene Meyer, the president, reported today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP)--The text of Secretary of State Byrnes' letter to Mr. Baruch follows: Referring to your note enclosing copy of your letter of resignation, I have today handed your letter to the President.

ERNEST TRUEX'S Androcles is that actor's latest addition to the bill of the American Repertory Theatre--to say nothing of his performance as an O'Casey drunk, a Barrie Scot, and an Ibsen homunculus, for the same acting group.

SKIERS are strange folks. They spend four to five months of the year zipping down the mountain sides and yodeling whenever the urge comes--and it comes often--and the remainder of the year they read avidly on the sport and reminisce on past events.

"HUMAN Dignity and the Great Victorians," by Bernard N. Schilling, although concerned with ponderous subjects such as the destiny of the human race, is a book written with something of the vitality of the great Victorian reformers whose views it summarizes.

DRAWING, for all its association with painting, is a distinct and separate art. Most great painters have been great draughtsmen and most great draughtsmen, great painters or sculptors. But drawing as an art has qualities and possibilities of expression entirely its own.

A 23-year-old former English war bride, blonde, stylishly dressed and soft-spoken, was locked up last night in the West Fifty-fourth Street police station on charges of having ransacked rooms in a halfdozen leading midtown hotels and escaping with jewelry, furs and clothing valued at $25,000.

Term II On the night of his election to a first term as Governor of New York in 1942, Thomas E. Dewey was asked if he thought he would make a good Governor. He replied: "I'll have to let the people decide that after four years." Two years later Mr. Dewey was the Republican candidate for the Presidency and was defeated.

LONDON, Jan. 4--Britain's biggest post-war merchant ship, the 15,000-ton Corinthic, nearing completion at Birkenhead, was threatened tonight first by fire in her hold and then by a serious list from the weight of water poured into her.

CHRISTOPHER LA FARGE, president of the Authors Guild, was "depressed," he writes, to note some possible reasons this department recently posed for the Guild's proposal of a new Basic Book Contract--for instance, that this was spade-work which (or so it was intended to suggest) some writers might consider long overdue.
