HONOLULU, Jan. 4--The United States Coast and Geodetic Survey issued today a general warning to residents of coast areas of the Hawaiian Islands of possible extremely high waves at about 1:15 A.M. tomorrow, the warning coming after damage of millions from twenty-four hours of battering by tremendous seas as the result of unusual winter storm conditions to the north.

All the business surveys and forecasts published at the beginning of the year agree that 1947 can be a good year of prosperity and full employment provided only that management and labor preserve industrial peace and avoid a repetition of the conflicts that distinguished 1946.
Department store sales by Reserve districts, as reported by the Federal Reserve Board, are listed in the following table which gives percentage comparisons with a year ago:

TO THE EDITOR: D.F., in his recent letter commenting on my article, "For These the War Is Not Over," appears to believe that our paraplegic patients (spinal cord cases) are heading for veterans' hospitals chiefly because of the difficulties met in finding adequate facilities for care in their own homes.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4--The rate of absorption of war surplus machine tools, the amount of export permitted and the rate of replacement of old equipment largely will determine the course of the machine tool industry this year, A.G. Bryant, vice president of the National Machine Tool Builders Association and vice president of the Cleereman Machine Tool Company, declared today.

MISS HOLLAND'S Manhattan might be any city on earth that would support a Waldorf -Astoria or a Coney Island. However, the characters in these short stories are not of the soil (with the exception of a maid from the British West Indies) but of skyscraper vintage.

First of a series of ten articles on recent developments in contract bridge bidding methods. OF all the bidding rules which have been promulgated in the seventeen-year life of contract bridge there has been least change in those dealing with opening bids.

Generally when musicians make successful debuts, they capitalize on their good notices to make a commercial splurge. It is their custom to strike soon again while the iron is hot. But Leah Effenbach, who gave a piano recital last night at Town Hall, took a different course.

THIS taut, continuously engrossing novel of an American bomber command based in England packs a solid impact from its first page. Covering only two days of a vital strike at the heart of Germany, told almost entirely from the nerve center of the commanding general's office, it never leaves the ground.

"Possibilities Unlimited," is the title of an organization in Cleveland as unusual as its name, for in its title this group has expressed its guiding philosophy. Composed entirely of amputees, this organization has a program that should serve as an inspiration for local posts of veterans' organizations and civic groups all over the nation.

COLERIDGE wrote "The Rime of the Ancient Mariner" in 1797, and some twenty years later he was not yet done with it. In 1817 he added the running gloss and the motto by T. Burnet, and revised some of the text. For those of us who lost intimacy with the poem in a classroom many years ago, this fact always comes as something of a surprise.

Louise Bernhardt, contralto of this city, made a deeply favorable impression at the recital she gave yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. Unusually handsome, and blessed with an engaging personality, Miss Bernhardt proved the possessor of an opulent voice of pronounced beauty of timbre, which she used with a warmth, intensity and expressiveness seldom approximated by singers of the younger generation.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 4 (AP) --The International Typographical Union, AFL, received today a management proposal for settlement of the two-month-old wage dispute involving two strike-bound daily newspapers of the Gannett group.

WALLINGFORD RIEGGER has been awarded a $1,000 commission from the Alice M. Ditson Fund of Columbia University to write a symphony. The composer says it will be more or less in the idiom of his "Dichotomy" that was written in 1932 and performed with notable success last September at the seventh Yaddo Music Period.
Odds and Ends Conscientious readers of the world news have by now learned the difference between our own domestic NAM and the Viet Nam which is fighting against the French in Indo-China.

The first "break" in the police search for Al Rocco, accused of masterminding the "camera-gun" shooting plot that resulted in his former wife's losing her left leg from a shotgun burst in a Times Square subway station Tuesday morning, appeared to have developed last night in a series of reports received at Police Headquarters.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4--Division in the ranks of America's liberal and progressive forces became sharp this week. Prominent exponents of the doctrines embodied by the New Deal made their choice between two camps which will vie for further influence in the social-political economic field.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4--Leaders of the Democratic and Republican parties are forming their battle lines and stocking their campaign arsenals with oratorical A-bombs in preparation for one of the bitterest mayoralty campaigns in Chicago's history.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4--Littleknown party groups called steering committees and conferences figured largely this week in the real work of organizing the new Congress, and it became apparent that the Republicans intended to make good use of these groups as the session goes on.

Officials of the Federal Housing Administration again are warning veterans to use caution against home-selling proposals which require substantial cash deposits for dwellings to be built "in the uncertain future." Recent disclosures in various parts of the country of plans whereby scores of veterans have lost their savings, the FHA said, "emphasizes the need for careful judgment in making any investment involving the building of a home at some unspecified date."

The text of the letter of resignation submitted yesterday by Bernard M. Baruch as United States member of the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission to President Truman: Dear Mr. President: I have the honor to inform you that the first phase of the work of the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission has been completed.

GOETHE had passed his eightieth year when he made the remark quoted by Eckermann which is at the top of today's Treasure Chest. It was one of those deeply suggestive observations sometimes made when a man questions what has come to be looked upon as a generally accepted truth.

NEW ENGLAND was the place of origin of a good many ideas, customs, standards and manners which became "American." And New Englanders, history demonstrates, have always been an adequately vocal people, writing much about themselves.
BLACKSBURG, Va., Jan. 4--Dr. Julian Ashby Burrnss, president emeritus of Virginia Polytechnic Institute, died early this morning after an illness of several months. His age was 70.

The combination of factors which determines the selling prices of homes shows no signs of a downward trend in the immediate or even distant future, according to A.B. Wolosoff, Long Island home builder whose construction activities during the past twenty-five years have ranged from single family dwellings to large garden-type apartment projects in New York, Virginia and Ohio.

TO THE EDITOR: The article, "165,000,000 Disks a Year," is quite comprehensive but it is strange that the author, Howard Taubman, does not mention the Columbia Phonograph Company or make any reference to the many and great contributions this company made to the sound reproducing industry.

LONDON, Jan. 4--On New Year's Day the new blue and white flag of the National Coal Board was raised at the pithead of every coal mine in Britain. It symbolized the end of private enterprise in coal and the beginning of the most ambitious business operation so far undertaken by a modern democratic state.

BCG (short for Bacillus CalmetteGuerin) is the name of a vaccine which was made available to the physicians and midwives of France in 1924 to confer immunity against tuberculosis. In 1929, when 270 German infants in a Luebeck hospital received the vaccine, the world was horrified to learn that 77 had died.

The heads of city departments and agencies were warned yesterday by Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson that it was "imperative" for them not to be "overoptimistic" about the city's financial outlook when they submit their requests for allotments in the 1947-48 expense budget.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4--There is an unaccustomed briskness, a hale, Rotarian sort of cheerfulness of demeanor of Republican Congressmen as they get their feet at last under the legislative banquet table from which they have been barred for fourteen dreary years.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 4--Ben Hogan took command of the $10,000 Los Angeles open at the midway point today when he tied the Riviera Country Club course record for this tournament with a score of 66 and a 36-hole total of 136, four strokes ahead of the field.

Financial markets in the opening days of the new year gave no indication of a change from the closing days of 1946. The customary year-end rally of securities failed to materialize and traders who acquired stocks in anticipation of such action began liquidating them last week.

THIS is the first season of my twelve as general manager of the Metropolitan Opera that we have had at our disposal a "Production Fund." This fund is a godsend to a management which would like to do new works, to re-study and dress up old ones, but which has been handicapped from the start by lack of money.

The Russell Sage Foundation recently announced the results of a poll in five hundred United States cities and towns in regard to preferences for memorials to the men and women who served their country in the second World War. The survey shows that communities favor "living" memorials in preference to statues and columns.

Although a large number of buyers are expected here this week, the anticipated "break" in the wholesale markets generally expected has failed to materialize, according to a market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co.

COME the revolution, come wars and cataclysms, come acts of God or uranium, and the chances are that the matter of Anglo-American relations will continue to be discussed on both sides of the Atlantic. Here is Mr. Thompson, who might be expected to have said his all in an earlier work, "I Lost My English Accent," back with further jaunty, sensible and occasionally unexpected observations.
GOP Takes the Reins The Seventy-ninth Congress passed into history last week; the Eightieth Congress took up the responsibility for framing the nation's policies.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4--James F. Byrnes, Secretary of State, has stressed the "relationship" of a universal training program to national security and the nation's foreign policy before a meeting of the President's advisory commission on universal training.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Jan. 4--Further indications that the Soviet Union is beginning to make effective and farreaching readjustments, political and military, in anticipation of the unification of Germany and the United Nations troop census have just been received from the Soviet occupation zone.

Ogden Reid fulfilled a high trust with great devotion. Under his father, Whitelaw Reid, he was trained to administer his inheritance long before he had any active newspaper experience. He was an athlete, an outdoors man by instinct. He might have preferred a future in some other field.
Private enterprise is ready to accept the challenge to solve the housing shortage, Henry J. Davenport president of the Home Title Guaranty Company, said yesterday.
As the first unit in what is planned eventually as an entire block of new apartments, a nineteen -story and penthouse building is rising at the northwest corner of Sutton Place and Fify-fifth Street.

EVERGREEN ground covers are the most conspicuous of the varied kinds now. Thyme in the stones of the path, dark myrtle in front of the foundation planting and under trees, and even grassy grape hyacinth leaves covering a patch of the border, help to add color to the winter scene.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4--The nation's railroads, striving to rebound from the detrimental effects of a herculean war effort while enjoying the beneficial ones, view the post-war world with a mixture of anxiety and optimism. There were considerably more grounds for optimism, at least with respect to the near future.

HOLLYWOOD. TARZAN, that hardyperennial muscle man of the jungles who has been diverting Americans-- and a good many others in the world--for thirty-odd years, is about to hit the movie screens with his twenty-third picture.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 (AP)--Grains moved ahead under persistent buying today on the Chicago Board of Trade, wheat, corn and oats all advancing more than a cent a bushel at times. Wheat closed 7 7/8 to 1 3/8 cents up. Corn was unchanged to 1/2 cent up and oats rose 3/8 to a cent.

The program initiated by the Institutional Commodity Services of New York Catholic Charities for the sanitary handling of food in the various institutions under their supervision, was commended yesterday by Dr. Israel Weinstein, Commissioner of Health, at the close of a course of study in this field by staff members of the institutions.

HAVANA, Jan. 4--President Ramon Grau San Martin last Thursday signed a decree regulating the operation of the Seatrain and Railway Car Ferry as port workers quit their jobs and marched on the Palace in protest against this type of transportation.
ATHENS, Jan. 4 (U.P.)--Fighting flared throughout Thessaly today as some 10,000 hungry guerrillas withdrawing from the northern frontiers sent out expeditions to get food.

Harold Hirsch Straus, a practicing attorney in this city for forty years, died early yesterday in his home at 71 East Seventy-seventh Street. He had been ill with a cardiac condition that recently was complicated with bronchial pneumonia. His age was 62.

With the holidays spent, the auction galleries are again holding their normal complement of sales. The Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, begin a busy week with the auction on Tuesday and Wednesday evenings at 8 P.M. of fine prints and drawings, Part One of the collection of Mrs. George, A. Martin of Cleveland.

Stock prices drifted narrowly in the first Saturday session of the year, closing mixed with liquor and specialties showing the strongest tone in the dullest session since October. Trading on the Stock Exchange dropped to the smallest volume since Oct. 26, the turnover being 300,000 shares, compared with 570,000 in the previous twohour period.

THE widespread curtailment of broadcasts by liberal commentators, chiefly because they have not been able to hold their sponsors, again has brought to the fore the question of whether opinions on current events should be broadcast on a commercial basis.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4--One reason for the "formidable Marxist infiltration throughout Latin America" is the "singularly inept and sadly ineffective nature of the State Department's Division of International Information and Cultural Affairs," Dr. Joseph F. Thorning, associate editor of The Americas, a quarterly review of inter-American cultural history, said here today after returning from an observation and lecture tour through Haiti, Cuba, the Dominican Republic and Puerto Rico.

To the Music Editor: I read with interest the article on Furtwaengler, written by Delbert Clark, in last Sunday's TIMES. I was chief of the Security Section, Counter Intelligence, Austria, and there are a few facts that I think we should know about this FurtwaenglerKarajan matter, and which I think would be of interest to your readers.

THIS season the National Academy decided to divide its annual into two parts. The first part, which became available to the public yesterday, is a semi-open show, some of the work juried, the rest invited.

MOSCOW, Jan. 4--A Yugoslav royal army, armed by the British and commanded by war criminals, exists in the British zone of occupation in Germany, a correspondent of Red Star, the Soviet Army's newspaper, charged today in a dispatch from Berlin.

THE classic job of armies is to fight, and strive as they will to master collateral activities, they sometimes fall short. This is notably true of our Army in respect to the mystic fields of public relations and censorship. Standard Army practice acknowledges that it takes at least several months of training to make an auto mechanic.

BERLIN, Jan. 4--Deputy Military Governor Lieut. Gen. Lucius D. Clay will announce next week his verdict on his sixty-day trial of German handling of denazification. He will make the announcement during the first meeting of the recently elected Minister-Presidents in the three States in the United States zone.

Many privately owned homes which were leased to the Federal Government during the war and remodeled to provide additional emergency dwelling units for war workers are being returned to the owners by the Federal Public Housing Authority ahead of the contract termination date.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4--Following is the labor program approved by the Senate Republican conference and drafted by Senators Robert A. Taft of Ohio, Joseph H. Ball of Minnesota and H. Alexander Smith of New Jersey: Report of Republican steering committee subcommittee on labor legislation.

Nathan vs. Robey The conflicting opinions of two men last week summed up the arguments of labor and industry in the debate over a "second round" of wage increases. The men were: Robert Roy Nathan, 36, native of Dayton, Ohio. Joined the Department of Commerce at 23; became deputy war mobilization director in 1944; left Government service late in 1945 to become a private economic analyst.

IT is not so much with physical aging that Dr. George Lawton is concerned, but with something that too few of us consider at any time, psychological aging. That there is a great field for such consideration seems amply proved by this volume, and by the author's previous book, "New Goals for Old Age," and his courses in the Extension Series of the Social Philosophy Division of Cooper Union.

ROME, Jan. 4--After smoldering for twenty-five years during the Fascist regime, anti-clericalism has flared up again in post-war Italy. The campaign against the Vatican and clergy has become so violent that the Pope recently saw fit to intervene personally.

TOKYO (By Wireless). ALONG procession winds down a Tokyo street, the marchers carrying red flags and caricatures of Japanese Cabinet members and singing a vaguely recognizable version of the "Internationale." A Japanese policeman heads the column in order to keep it clear of traffic tangles, and a whitepainted American military police jeep trails it.
THIS week will see the premiere at the Metropolitan of "The Warrior," opera in one act and four scenes, the libretto by Norman Corwin, the music by Bernard Rogers.

Ancient, fragile Chinese bronzes and luminous porcelains from famous collectors and dealers will be shown portrayed on canvas in an exhibition at China House, 125 East Sixty-fifth Street, from Jan. 16 to Feb. 28.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4--A panel of twenty-five labor relations experts to serve the Government as special conciliators in the "peaceful settlement of industrial disputes" was named today by Edgar L. Warren, Director of the United States Conciliation Service.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4--The Congress of Industrial Organizations accused employer groups today of inciting "wild propaganda" in connection with portal-to-portal wage claims.

Octavio Pinto, Brazilian composer, was acclaimed yesterday forenoon at the Young People's Concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall, Rudolph Ganz conducting. Before the performance of the orchestral version of his "Scenas Infantis" ("Children's Scenes"), Mr. Pinto was asked by Mr. Ganz to rise in his box, with his wife, Guiomar Novaes, the noted pianist, and Isidor Philipp, her teacher.

ONE year ago today, for the first time in mercantile history, a woman took over the presidency of an organization doing an annual business of $30,000,000. During the past year the organization's sales have reached $40,000,000.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 4--R.C. Ellsworth's Hubble Bubble burst forth in the stretch today to win the $50,000 added seven-furlong Santa Susana Stakes by four lengths from Charles S. Howard's Maharetta before 47,600 racegoers, at Santa Anita Park.

MRS. STEBBINS, who (with Richard Poate Stebbins) recently wrote a chronicle of the Trollope family, has apparently fallen in love with the Victorian world and would like to share her enthusiasms. The present book is composed of six somewhat disparate essays--four on eminent women novelists, one which is a kind of catch-all of lesser ladies, and one entitled "Homekeeping Hearts" which is a somewhat inadequate summing up of impressions.

PARIS, Jan. 4--An empire is a group of states united under a single sovereign power. There are empires in which domains are separated by sea. Other empires consist of contiguous land. Either kind of empire may endure for centuries, as did those of Greece, Rome, Spain and Portugal.

MELBOURNE, Jan. 4 (AP)--England's chances of winning the "ashes"--mythical prize of the world series or cricket--faded today as Australia's batters piled up a score of 293 for a loss of only four wickets before 72,000.

The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 provides no legal justification for employe compensation for "preparatory time" in companies and industries where such time is and has been taken into account in arrival at basic hourly wage rates, Elmer F. Andrews of the labor consultant organization bearing his name declared yesterday.

NANKING, Jan. 4--There is no direct evidence that Communists are leading the anti-American student demonstrations protesting against the alleged assault on a Chinese girl in Peiping by a United States marine. It seems fairly certain, however, that Communists were the strategists, although the leaders are students without known Communist affiliations.

Seven hours after one partner in a Brooklyn toy-manufacturing plant had been shot and killed and two others beaten in an unsuccessful hold-up attempt, two youths were trapped yesterday by the police as the suspects.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 4--Premier Mahmoud Fahmy Nokrashy Pasha again declared today that success of treaty negotiations between Egypt and Britain depended upon London's first, giving a satisfactory explanation of British policy in the Anglo-Egyptian Sudan.

THE relation between man and his language is theoretically one of the most mysterious and exciting things in his whole existence. Yet we tend to take language for granted, as we take other natural phenomena. Sometimes, as in the case of Marianne Hauser, it is the stranger in our midst who by fresh appreciation and response gives new value to what we have accepted without gratitude and used without relish.

Wagner's "Tristan und Isolde" received a performance last night at the Metropolitan that had the real throb of life in it to an exceptional degree. Astrid Varnay assumed the role of Isolde for the first time this season, and Set Svanholm was the Tristan, replacing Torsten Ralf, who had been scheduled to make his initial appearance in the part, but was indisposed.
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 4 (AP)--Calumet Farm's Armed drew top weight of 129 pounds for the $50,000 Widener Handicap at Hialeah Feb. 22, according to the weights released today.

A $10,000,000 housing program which will provide homes for 1,550 veterans and their families will be undertaken by the city of Boston, Mass., as a result of the recent passage of emergency housing legislation for that State, according to the Public Administration Clearing House.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4--The United States tonight accepted an invitation from Australia and New Zealand to attend a conference at Canberra on Jan. 28 to consider the establishment of a regional advisory commission for non-selfgoverning territories located in the Pacific south of the Equator and east of, but including, Dutch New Guinea.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Four fallacies on wages are now in fashion and should be scotched before they do any more harm. The damage they have already done is plenty.

RECURRING reports that the original plane of the Wright brothers will be brought back to the United States from England bring to mind at least two things. First, that airplane designers since the Wright brothers have deviated widely from the basic idea of aircraft, and, secondly, that there has been in recent years something of a trend back to first principles.

HONOLULU, Jan. 4 (AP)--Gigantic waves racing before a distant midocean storm caused lowland residents to flee today, recalling the disastrous seismic sea wave which killed 173 persons and injured 291 in the islands on April 1.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Two foul goals in the final two minutes of play enabled Brigham Young University to outlast a driving Temple Owl quintet, 57 to 55, tonight in the opening half of a basketball double-header at Convention Hall. St. Joseph's College defeated Utah State College, 52 to 48, in the second game before 5,200 fans.

DR. CURT SACHS, a wellknown German musicologist and art critic now in this country, shares his countrymen's passion for philosophical synthesis. He believes that, in studying the arts, one must consider them as a whole; that architecture, painting, music, sculpture and the dance are interdependent and always have been, for they all spring from one common urge.

Penrock's Prize Package, a solid black American-type cocker spaniel belonging to the Penrock Kennels of Mrs. Louis Hausman, New Canaan, Conn., won his breed's Futurity Stake in the American Spaniel Club's thirtieth national specialty show at the Hotel Roosevelt yesterday.

IN their annual pow-wow of palms-giving (which was accomplished without blows last week), the New York Film Critics voted sentiments which will not be admired in Hollywood. They showed a decided disposition toward foreign personalities and films as the most distinguished presentations on the screen in 1946.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Jan. 4 (AP)-- Canisius handed Cornell's tall basketball team its first defeat of the season tonight, 50 to 40, before 9,074 fans in Memorial Auditorium. The University of Buffalo whipped Carnegie Tech, 45 to 31, in the opening game of the double-header.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4--A warning that this country "can easily lose its leadership in scientific achievement unless it seeks and trains those who can maintain it" was issued today in the annual report of the National Education Association.

MOSCOW, Jan. 4 -- "Admiral Nakhimov," latest Soviet historical film, which has been revised, is a rich and colorful motion picture, which depicts the defeat of the Turkish fleet by the Russians at the Battle of Sinop and the defense of Sebastopol against the British and French during the Crimean War.
An agreement between tugboat operators and workers, averting a harbor-crippling tug strike here, was announced soon after 8 o'clock last night at City Hall.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4--The American Federation of Labor will request a conference with Secretary of State Byrnes soon in an effort to fight affiliation of German labor unions with the World Federation of Trade Unions, it was learned today.

ROME, Jan. 4--The impending arrival of Premier Alcide de Gasperi in Washington tomorrow will coincide with the close of the great reconstruction loan drive, which has been on for the last two months. It is believed that the drive has been successful, although not so successful as some had hoped.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 (AP)--Illinois Rose Bowl champions tumbled gleefully from their West Coast train today to a rousing welcome for their 45-to-14 rout of U.C.L.A.'s Bruins, whom the Illini generally rated as "'weaker than the weakest Big Nine team."

A FIRE in New York's theatre district brings Fire Marshal Ben Pedley to the scene. It is his business to find out what caused the fire and, if it proves to have been of incendiary origin, to track down the guilty person. Since a man is dead as a result of this fire, Pedley automatically becomes a murder investigator.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 4--Indications that the State of New Jersey will soon return to the Public Service Electric and Gas Company the five gas plants now under nominal State supervision were seen in a statement issued this evening by Gov. Walter E. Edge at his Princeton home.
ITHACA, N. Y., Jan. 4--Olaf M. Brauner, Professor Emeritus of Fine Arts at Cornell and well known as a portrait painter, died last night at his home here after a long illness. His age was 77.

BOSTON, Jan. 4--The Massachusetts Legislature will consider at this session a ten-year, $25,000,000 program to give Boston the most modern port facilities to help New England recapture its place in the shipping sun which appears brighter than ever for the postwar period.
A yield range of sixty basic points--about five times that registered for Treasury 2 1/2 per cent bonds after deduction for tax--distinguished the market for municipal bonds during the year.

The young year starts out as if it meant business. Oranges reach a dollar a dozen in Northern markets (4 cents at the grove), and rockets whoosh moonward at sixty miles a minute. The Republican Congress convenes with the watchword, "Cooperation, but they've gotta cooperate with us, you betcha!" and Labor rehearses a new song hit, "One good raise deserves another."

CHICAGO. THE premiere of an amateur -produced movie version of Shakespeare's "Macbeth" was recently held in the community house of Winnetka, wealthy North Shore suburb, and behind it is a story of artistic determination that war could not stop.
A warning that this country will have to spend more money for its schools if the free system of American public education is to be maintained came last week from the National Education Association.

In a thrilling battle that had the crowd of 8,000 in an uproar, Erasmus Hall High of Brooklyn topped a fighting Andrew Jackson High five, 36 to 33, in the feature game of the scholastic quadruple-header at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

Plans for Protestant churches to cost $650,000,000 are being drawn, it was learned yesterday at a meeting of the North American Conference on Church Architecture in the National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park South. One hundred achitects attended.

PARIS. EARLY winter is a busy time in French publishing circles. Editors are busy high-pressuring the juries of the four major literary awards, the Goncourt, the Theophraste Renaudot, the Femina, and the Inter-Allie, as well as a number of others of lesser magnitude, such as the Prix des Deux Magots and the Prix Paul Pelliot.

The shortage of textbooks, which plagues schools throughout the nation, win probably not be relieved until 1948, according to a survey recently completed by the American Textbook Publishers Institute.

PETER SCOTT, author-artist, well known for his books of beauty--"Wild Chorus" and "Morning Flight"--has fathered in this lavishly illustrated volume a history of British coastal forces in home waters during the whole span of the recent war.

Decentralized management has paid big dividends to American Brake Shoe Company, William B. Given Jr., president, disclosed here yesterday in describing effectiveness of their unique plan of "Bottom -Up Management." No longer an experiment, but a tested and successful group of established policies in all sixty American Brake Shoe plants, the methods place maximum responsibility for decisions upon foremen and superintendents within each of ten operating divisions of the company, Mr. Given explained.

Ray Robinson, world welterweight champion, will be seen in action in Madison Square Garden some time in March if plans announced yesterday by Matchmaker Nat Rogers of the Twentieth Century S.C., materialize.

IN 1944, while the Germans still occupied Denmark, a novel was published in Copenhagen with the title, "Ways of Retribution." It was an accomplished piece of story-telling, intricate in pattern, yet simply and luminously set forth.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 (AP)--Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 500 head (estimated); total not given. All types of offerings quoted nominally steady: top, $23.50: compared with week ago: all weights, barrows and gilts. $I higher: sows,

IT is not too late to make cuttings from shrubs in the garden. At this time of year, however, care must be taken to select the twigs to be used for this work on a day when the temperature is well above freezing, and preferably one which follows two or three other days of relatively high winter temperature.

New York becomes the capital of the world of intercollegiate athletics today as a four-day conclave opens at the Hotel New Yorker to consider the multiple problems of football, baseball and other sports in the period of the post-war boom.

On Oct. 29 President Truman appointed five civilians to membership on the newly created Atomic Energy Commission. The work these five men have to do is more important, in its present and future aspects, its domestic and international implications, than that of any other agency in this country today.

After a six-year lapse, while wars and other pressing interruptions made curtailing inroads on a nation's pleasures, the National Motor Boat Show will resume this week where it left off in 1941 and thus gladden the hearts of many thousands of men, women and small children who like to daydream in winter about their coming summer's fun.

"Much has recently been said about the great value that the atomic bomb discovery will be to the study of cancer, but does it really promise more than the discovery of other destructive forces?" Dr. Ellice McDonald asks the question in his last annual report as director of the Biochemical Research Foundation.

UNDER the auspices of eleven of the scientists who took leading parts in the development of atomic energy, WMCA this week will undertake an ambitious series of dramatic programs to "meet the need for public understanding of atomic energy."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (U.P.)-- Veterans measures were most numerous in bills introduced on the first day of the new Congressional session. Labor bills were second.

OTTAWA, Ont., Jan. 4--On New Year's Day the Canadian Citizenship Act came into force and henceforth every natural-born Canadian and all who take out naturalization papers will become Canadian citizens.

SNOW train service of the New York Central and the New Haven, suspended during the war and the subsequent shortage of rail equipment, will be resumed today if the skiing and the weather remain good in the Adirondacks and Berkshires.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Jan. 4--With the shore snow covered, the temperature below freezing but the bay free from ice, fifty-seven dinghies were out sailing off the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club today in the second session of the sixteenth annual frostbite regatta, which began the winter wind-jamming in 1932.

Dr. Clarence (Buddy) Combs and his Red Bank teammates packed too much punch for the Squadron A Freebooters in the feature of the indoor polo doubleheader at Squadron A Armory last night, and so the New Jersey trio rode to a 12-7 decision, after leading from shortly after the opening throw-in.

While uncertainties in the business picture are stressed, considerable confidence in the outlook for 1947 is shown in reports on local conditions in the Federal Reserve districts of the country. Employment continues at peak in most of the areas and barring further labor troubles production appears headed for new highs.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Allow me to thank the writer of the letter "The Struggle in India" in your issue of Dec. 22. The Rev. Lyons, has been in India for twenty years and therefore knows whereof he speaks. He has given a true picture and a fair estimate of the situation, placing the blame where it belongs for the tragic strife now in progress.

To the Screen Editor: PEOPLE are funny! They complain about all prices being too high, and yet few of them seem to care about the fantastic prices they pay every time they go to the movies. I've been grumbling about this condition for some time now.

Leaders in the public utility industry gave grave consideration last week to the long-term effect of the decisions of the Atomic Energy Commission on industry. In addition to the alleged predilection to nationalism of David E. Lilienthal, chairman, and other members of the commission, power company officials were fearful that the Government's atomic monopoly virtually assures its own continuation.

ESTIMATES of how many tourists will be out on the world's travel lanes this year and where they will go is still anyone's guess. While a recent survey discloses that 32,000,000 persons in the United States will have paid vacations in 1947, one travel official estimates that some 25,000,000 will go by automobile to points in the United States, Canada and Mexico.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan. 4--A record-breaking winter sports season, one that should dwarf by a wide margin any preceding campaigns in its thirty-five-year history, is being anticipated by the Bear Mountain-Harriman State Park for 1947.

DANCE photography is a cooperative enterprise between subject and camera man. So says Walter E. Owen, well-known dance and portrait photographer in New York, who entered professional photography from the ranks of the amateur.

WIDELY known for his wood sculpture, John Rood is making his first bow as a painter, at the Ward Eggleston Gallery. In a foreword to his catalogue Rood calls attention to the fact that he has been painting for twenty-five years and that palette knife rather than brush has been called upon.

SHOCK-- In the Ohio State Medical Journal Dr. Harry N. Holmes of Oberlin College publishes a paper in which he reviews the success which has attended the administration of Vitamin C in shock that followed operations, accidents and burns.

ROME, Jan. 3 (Delayed)--The extraordinary interest in Premier Alcide de Gasperi's trip to the United States, played up in the Roman press as the greatest political event here since the armistice, has resulted largely from its timing.

The opening event of what promises to be the most interesting racquets season in many years was held yesterday at the Racquet and Tennis Club as New York and Philadelphia met in the annual intercity doubles match.

"WHY do I send my child to kindergarten?" According to a new compilation of parents' answers the main ideas seem to be: getting a good health start; learning to get along with other children; sharing music, games and stories, and, in learning by doing, generally getting in step for the bigger adventure of living and learning that lies ahead.

RICHMOND, Jan. 4--Action of the Association of Southern Commissioners of Agriculture in demanding abolition of the Hull reciprocal trade treaties has been received with overwhelming disapproval by the press of the Upper South, which says these thirteen officials are misrepresenting the Southern farmers.

HERE is an informal and anecdotal chapter of dead history, rescued from oblivion by Commander Sawyer and the Naval Institute. "Sons of Gunboats" deals with that period when "manifest destiny" and westward expansion had resulted in Dewey's victory in Manila Bay and our conquest of the Spanish regime in the Philippines.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4--The United Nations has been operating for not quite a year. In this time the United States has distinguished itself by having more of its leading representatives quit their United Nations jobs quicker than those of any other country.

CORAL, GABLES, Fla., Jan. 4-- Westminster, winner of the 1945 Narragansett Special, today carried Art Rooney's Shamrock Stable silks to a smashing five-length triumph in the first division of the $30,000-added, mile-and-a-furlong Double Event before 12,526 racegoers who wagered $814,136, a new high for the Tropical Park meeting.

A large new terminal and warehouse building is destined to occupy the site of the old West Side carbarns of the Third Avenue Transit Corporation as the result of a new deal by which the Chanin interest are acquiring the property, it was learned yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4--Senate Republicans swung into action today on labor legislation.
YONKERS, N. Y., Jan. 4-Prank Yatsko, a veteran of the SpanishAmerican War and for years an attache of the Sokol Club, died here yesterday in his home at 433 Walnut Street. His age was 70.

THE helicopter is the aircraft that needs no airport. Its ability to rise and descend sharply--even vertically--means that it can operate on rooftops, parking lots, in small openings in wooded or mountainous areas. It can also "stand still" in the air, hovering over a given spot.

MICHEL VIGAUD is the alleged hero of this strange novel, which does its ritualistic dervish dance through the higherpriced salons, cocktail dens and cabanas of the Riviera, Paris and New York--in the equally ritualistic framework of two world wars.

WARSAW, Jan. 4--Vice Premier Stanislaw Mikolajczyk declared today that unless the Government bloc allowed his Polish Peasant party a "fair" number of candidates and safeguards for his count watchers, he would boycott the elections on Jan. 19.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP)--An estimated 1,000,000 new dwelling units were started in 1946, Frank R. Creedon, Housing Expediter, announced tonight, 200,000 short of Wilson Wyatt's goal.

A price war was begun yesterday among milk dealers serving retail stores, cutting rates paid by stores for milk in containers and bottles from 17 1/2 cents to 16 1/2 cents a quart and in a few cases to as low as 16 cents.

PARIS, Jan. 4--The sudden issuance of a circular requiring the permission of three ministries before films can be dubbed, has threatened American film companies in France with a new disruption of their business.

WASHINGTON. AT a recent dinner in Washington, attended by the President, a Republican favorite son from a large and important State made a political speech. Among those listening to him was a Federal jurist of Democratic antecedent, lately and specially in the public eye.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Jan. 4-- Turkey might trade her support for a Great Syria against the settlement of some of her problems with the Arab world, mainly the Hatay [Alexandretta] question--a subject of deep disagreement between Turkey and Syria.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4--The Soviet Embassy made a formal request to the State Department today for the apprehension and delivery "as a criminal" to the Soviet authorities of "Kirill Alekseev," former employe of the Soviet Trade Representative in Mexico, who fled to the United States two months ago.

Investment houses here are uneasy at the way in which private placements of securities have been dominating the issuance of highgrade issues in recent weeks. While inclined to regard the development as a passing one, securities distributors find it disquieting to realize, nevertheless, that since October there has been more than a score of such transactions, involving the direct sale to institutional investors of more than $400,000,000 of securities, most of them long-term industrial debentures.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Jan. 4-- Rudolph (Little Doc) Mobley, national ground-gaining king, dashed 34 yards for one touchdown and skipped 17 for another today as the Hardin-Simmons Cowboys finished the football campaign undefeated and untied with a 20-0 victory over Denver University in are first annual Alamo Bowl game.

HARVARD--U.N. Council The United Nations Council of Harvard University has been organized to carry out an educational program in support of the United Nations, both in the Yard and the Boston area. The council is planning a "political laboratory" drawing on the 1,500 foreign students in this area to study U.N. problems.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4--The text of President Truman's letter accepting Mr. Baruch's resignation: Dear Mr. Baruch: The Secretary of State has handed me your letter of resignation as the representative of the United States on the Atomic Energy Commission.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 4--The arrest of two brothers, charged with the beating of a witness in the recent Federal inquiry into Georgia's quadruple lynching, was disclosed today by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

Real estate today is a "premier investment," according to Charles F. Noyes, president of the Charles F. Noyes Company, Inc. He said that, with real estate selling for less than reproduction values in many cases, it offers a better return than many other securities.

TORONTO, Jan. 4--The New York Rangers strengthened their hold on fourth place in the National Hockey League when they blanked league-leading Toronto, 2-0, before 13,347 fans at Maple Leaf Gardens tonight. It was the first victory for the Rangers over the Maple Leafs in six starts this season, all previous meetings have

The year of reconversion has merged into the year of stabilization. The customary annual statements of business, labor and Government leaders last week have made it clear that the outlook for 1947 is one of uncertainty.

CRACOW, Poland, Jan. 3 (Delayed) --An overflow audience tonight heard the first performances in Poland of works by three American composers, as Franco Autori, permanent conductor of the Chautauqua Symphony Orchestra, led the Cracow Philharmonic Orchestra in the works of Norman Dello Joio, Samuel Barber and Aaron Copland.

Bernard M. Baruch and his five fellow members of the United States delegation to the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission resigned last night. The step came three days before the Security Council "showdown" on the Baruch plan for international atomic control.
HOLLYWOOD. WINTER means one precise thing to Jimmy Durante: New York. "In California you can look at the mountains, and very imposin' they are, but in New York you look down Broadway.

The new realty year starts in an atmosphere of optimism, based on the active business which was sustained through 1946 and the prospect that a further upturn in construction activity may be expected during the months just ahead.

"Lash for Lash" In Palestine last week Jewish terrorists renewed their assault on British authority; British authorities struck back. The uneasy quiet which had prevailed in the Holy Land for three weeks was succeeded by new acts of violence.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4--Senator Robert F. Wagner announced today that he would reintroduce his 1940 plan for a United States Mediation Board in labor disputes in the following statement: Effectiveness of Wagner Act in Achieving its Objectives

JACKSON, Miss., Jan. 4--If the United States Senate declines to seat Theodore G. Bilbo after he is tried by that body he can have the nomination again, if he wishes, or the Governorship, according to freely expressed opinion in Mississippi tonight.

THE first post-war calendar year brought a minimum of 2,312 major and minor varieties of stamps for collectors to covet. To this figure probably must be added several score of postal items issued abroad and en route to New York as 1947 dawned.

AN all-metal folding French camera called the Lynx II, making sixteen exposures on a roll of No. 127 film, is announced by its importers, J.L. Galef Son, Inc., 75 Chambers Street. The new camera, on which the availability date has not been set, features a focal plane shutter and offers the choice of two coated 50-mm lenses a fourelement Angenieux f/3.5 and a sixelement Berthiot f/2.8.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4--Under the necessity of an immediate operation on his jaw for cancer, Senator Theodore G. Bilbo, Democrat of Mississippi, voluntarily stepped aside today and broke the apparently irreconcilable conflict of views whether he should be permitted to take the oath of office.
Curtailment of this year's scientific and educational program of the American Museum of Natural History was indicated in its seventy -seventh annual report, made public yesterday.

AS the war ended, Morley Cooper and his wife, Madge, both old-timers in yachting, went again in search of a boat. This time they would cruise the intracoastal waterway, that generally protected small-craft water highway extending from New England to Key West.

First clues to possible changes in wholesale market conditions, expected to mark this year, are likely to become evident during the next three weeks when buyers from stores all over the country arrive here to complete their spring purchasing.

Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, CIO, charged yesterday that three other national officers of the union were members of the Communist party and had placed party interests before those of their labor organization.

IN our craze for what's quick and easy in cookey, we often do away with those civilized little touches that make a meal interesting, delivering it out of the something-you-must-eatyour-way-through category.

Arthur Koestler is a journalist and novelist who has been concerned with the undercurrents of European affairs since World War I. As a disillusioned Communist, he dramatized the Moscow treason trials in "Darkness at Noon." His latest book, "Thieves in the Night," deals with the present struggle in Palestine.

ALBANY, Jan. 4--An intensive State-financed effort to rehabilitate victims of cerebral palsy, who are estimated to number about 10,000 in New York State, will be urged upon the Legislature by Governor Thomas E. Dewey in his annual message.

A careful appraisal of the powers of the United States delegation in the coming eighteen-nation reciprocal trade agreement discussions in Geneva to negotiate changes in customs administrative law will be required as a result of a brief filed by the National Council of American Importers, Inc., foreign trade circles stated last week.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 4--A current Mexican weekly portrays on its cover President Miguel Aleman whooshing down from the sky in the garb of "Superman" and landing a cyclonic right on the jaw of the Mexican oil workers. Regardless of the point of view, there is no doubt that this adaptation of the familiar United States cartoon describes what has happened here.

HE certainly didn't seem to be marked for stardom. His hitting was woefully inconsistent and his throwing extremely erratic. But Manager Eddie Dyer of the Columbus (Ga.) team of the South Atlantic League was just as patient then as he is now. "Come down to earth," he good-humoredly told the 20-year-old outfielder. "You seem to think that your strike zone is over your head.

PRODUCERS, theatre operators and all those concerned with the general health of the fabulous invalid, were agreed last week that President Truman's proclamation reducing the tax on theatre tickets to ten per cent, or back where it was before the war, should prove a boon to the box office.

Atom and U.N. At Lake Success last Monday--sixteen months and twenty-three days after the atomic bomb burst over Hiroshima --the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission adopted a plan to control the atom.

ATHENS, Jan. 4--Press reports this afternoon that the King had asked former Premier Themistocles Sophoulis to form a government during a conference this morning were authoritatively dismissed as unfounded.

MOTEL is a fairly new word in the English language, being a Hollywoodian contraction of "motor hotel" and a synonym for "tourist court," which is itself only a decade or so old. The hardy perennial American motorist can recall the development in the Twenties first of tourist homes and then of tourist courts.
PARIS, Jan. 4 (AP)--Full-scale war in Indo-China was foreseen today when Marius Moutet, Minister for France Overseas, sent word that France would have to fight it out there.

IT has been through no accident of war or propaganda that Sergei Prokofieff's Symphony No. 5, Op. 100, has made its way into the repertories of America's symphony orchestras. Although it was written while the Soviet Union was at war, the symphony was not sold to the public as something that had to do with sieges or victories.
William Harvell LaBoyteaux, New York insurance broker and breeder of thoroughbred race horses, died of coronary thrombosis on Friday in his apartment at 610 Park Avenue. His age was 74.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 4--A call on religious and racial groups in the United States to unite in the fight to eliminate bigotry was made today by Supreme Court Justice Meier Steinbrink, of Brooklyn, at the opening session here of the First National Conference of the Joint Defense Appeal.
On this final Sunday of the thirty-fifth annual Christmas appeal conducted by THE NEW YORK TIMES, the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund stands at $377,995.85. This is a record amount for the date.

A 31-year-old prisoner made a spectacular escape from his escorting officer in the crowded lobby of Pellevue Psychiatric Hospital yesterday and disappeared into the labyrinthine maze of sub-cellars that provide an underground link to the vast hospital plant.

SO acute is the shortage of motor-vehicle batteries that automotive manufacturers, highway-safety organizations and motor touring groups are reemphasizing the need for strict conservation of the equipment now in use.
TO THE EDITOR: * * * In his article on "Labor's Responsibilities," Philip Murray makes the statement that "it [the Wagner Act] is already an equal law and ought not to be tampered with" Is it?

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 4 (AP)-- He Don't staged a rousing finish at the Fair Grounds today to win the featured Avoyelles Purse over a heavy track. He Don't, carrying the colors of A.H. Foster, ran the six furlongs in 1:17 and paid $27.80 for $2.

PARIS, Jan. 4--"Before there is any negotiation it will be necessary to get a military decision," Marius Moutet, French Overseas Minister, declared tonight in summing up his mission of inquiry in Indo-China.
TO THE EDITOR: * * * In his article on "Labor's Responsibilities," Philip Murray makes the statement that "it [the Wagner Act] is already an equal law and ought not to be tampered with" Is it?

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 4 (AP)-- He Don't staged a rousing finish at the Fair Grounds today to win the featured Avoyelles Purse over a heavy track. He Don't, carrying the colors of A.H. Foster, ran the six furlongs in 1:17 and paid $27.80 for $2.

PARIS, Jan. 4--"Before there is any negotiation it will be necessary to get a military decision," Marius Moutet, French Overseas Minister, declared tonight in summing up his mission of inquiry in Indo-China.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 4--New Orleans entered the New Year with its citizens divided on whether they like the government they're getting or whether they would favor the old machine rule, which they discarded with their votes in January, 1946.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 4--A fifty-acre estate valued at $500,000 in the near-by village of Leroy has been offered by Mr. and Mrs. Ernest L. Woodward to the University of Rochester as a rehabilitation hospital for victims of cerebral palsy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP)-- Representative Harold Knutson, Republican, of Minnesota, prospective chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, joined today the drive to cut wartime excise taxes immediately on furs, jewelry and luggage.
LONDON, Jan. 5 (AP)--The Arab League announced today that its member nations would be represented at the London conference on Palestine, opening Jan. 21.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Jan. 5 -- An energetic young man who seemed to be working hard last night in the interest of charity, as a self-appointed aide to the committee in charge of a church dance here, was being sought today by the police for having taken $1,000 of the proceeds.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5--The National Labor Relations Board today released figures for November pointing to these conclusions: 1. The percentage of votes cast in favor of collective bargaining by some labor organization diminished considerably as compared to the August-October figures.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5 -- Cash and commission houses were aggressive buyers of corn futures, especially the January, on the Board of Trade here last week. Hedges were removed against sales of the cash article to the Government, and as a considerable percentage of the local stock is owned by wet processors or sold for shipment it is expected that only limited amounts will be available for delivery on contracts.

Five hundred and thirty-two barbers and barber shop owners, accused of illegal activities or practices, are facing departmental trials and possible suspension or revocation of licenses, Commissioner Benjamin Fielding of the Department of Licenses announced yesterday.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 5 (AP)--Haganah, Jewish defense organization, in a broadcast from its secret transmitter today denounced Irgun Zvai Leumi and the Stern band, extremist organizations blamed for the latest outburst of Holy Land violence.

The search for Al Rocco, accused of planning the Ingenious "cameragun" shooting of his former wife, was pressed last night in the ice-sheathed Catskill Mountains. A friend, who allegedly did not know the "mastermind" was wanted, drove him there Saturday and was rewarded by having the suspect make off with his automobile, the police said.

Having won the first battle for a new world law to assure man's survival in the atomic age, Bernard M. Baruch has resigned from the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission, together with his aides, and has turned over the job of carrying on the good fight to the chief American delegate to the United Nations, Warren R. Austin.

Five persons were killed and ten others were injured early today when flames swept the upper floors of a five-story brick tenement at 167 West 129th Street, on the northeast corner of Seventh Avenue in Harlem.

"The Lost Week-End," Paramount's adaptation of the novel by Charles R. Jackaon, produced by Charles Brackett, directed by Billy Wilder and starring Ray Milland, was voted the best picture of 1946 in the twenty-fifth annual poll of film critics of the nation's newspapers, magazines, syndicates, wire services and radio stations conducted by the trade publication, The Film Daily.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 5 -- Ramon Beteta, Minister of Finance, has just announced that a national fiscal convention will be held here in March or April to overhaul the Mexican system of taxation. The system is known equally for the number of its levies and for the persistence with which the potential taxpayers evade them.

LONDON, Jan. 5--As the flag of the National Coal Board was unfurled over many mines today to celebrate the completion of nationalization on New Year's Day, warnings came from all leaders that a supremely difficult task lay ahead.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 5 (AP)--After leading for most of the game, St. Louis faltered in the closing minutes tonight and the New York Knickerbockers broke the Bombers' seven-game victory streak by winning, 59 to 57, in a Basketball Association of America League contest.

Bowling Green to Times Square Long ago--in the years just before our War of Independence and for some years afterward --New York's gayer night life centered about the lower end of Broadway, just above the Bowling Green.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 5-- U Aung San, vice president of the Burmese Executive Council and leader of the Anti-Fascist People's Freedom League, one of Burma's most powerful political groups, told a press conference here today that Burma's goal was "complete independence."

With only three minutes to go the New York Rangers held a nine-goal lead over the Chicago Black Hawks in their National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. Despite this insurmountable margin in favor of the home team, the capacity crowd of 15,925 fans did not make a single move to leave.
NEWARK, N. J., Jan. 6 (AP)-- Forty-six babies in the Babies Hospital were carried to safety by a score of student nurses when a fire

Karin Branzell, the eminent Swedish contralto, gave her third New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. Although her voice was not in its best estate, and proved less securely under control than at her previous appearances in the same auditorium, Miss Branzell used it with a sincerity of purpose and nobility of feeling that made much of her work deeply impressive, despite the unevenness of the vocalism.

NEW DELHI, India., Jan. 5-- The general committee of the predominantly Hindu Congress party, holding forth an olive branch of sorts to the Moslem League, debated today on a resolution "agreeing" to the British interpretation of the constitutional procedure that the Constituent Assembly should follow to placate Moslem objections.

Intensive Program for Schaefer The F. M. Schaefer Brewing Company's advertising program this year will be the most intensive in its history, it was announced over the week-end. It will feature a continuous schedule of large-space ads in daily newspapers and monthly page ads in color in all New York newspaper Sunday magazine sections.

LONDON, Jan. 5--A multi-party Parliamentary delegation that visited Greece last August got out its long - awaited report today. It recommends still further British civil commitments in Greece but a withdrawal of British troops.

A sharp drop in deposits and total resources, indicating the effects of the United States Treasury's debt retirement activities, was reported by the Chase National Bank of New York, in its condition statement as of Dec. 31, 1946, released for today.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 5--The Italian prisoners of war now in process of repatriation from South Africa apparently include a fair proportion of incorrigible Fascists, according to reports from Durban, the port of embarkation.

A "shocking indifference" and a "dearth of facilities" characterize the treatment generally available for alcoholics in New York City, according to a survey made by the committee on public health relations of the New York Academy of Medicine.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 5 -- Steel production last week advanced 12 points to 87 per cent of rated capacity and indications are that the rate may reach 90 per cent this week. All holiday and coal strike factors have been cleaned up, with the result that the industry is now in a position to forge ahead in an attempt to reduce substantial backlogs carried over from 1946.

HONOLULU, Jan. 5--Three military rescue planes and three surface ships were speeding toward Palmyra Atoll, 960 miles south of here, late today in desperate attempts to evacuate 108 persons who were reported trapped by a storm on tiny Cooper Island in the atoll.

Business and industrial leaders generally are just as much opposed as labor leaders to compulsory arbitration, and are getting worried, it was learned yesterday, over the strength this proposal for promoting industrial peace seems to have gained in public opinion and Congressional discussion of new labor legislation.

Manuel de Falla, the Spanish composer, who died in Argentina in November, was honored yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall by Leopold Stokowski and the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, who played his ballet suite, "El Amor Brujo," complete, with the four songs for contralto.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5--Hotpoint, Inc., formerly Edison General Electric Appliance Company, today announced new 1947 models in its washing machine, refrigerator and home freezer lines. The washers will reach the retailer in the second quarter of this year. The refrigerators and freezers will be in the hands of dealers by Jan. 15.

Demands for a comprehensive health, welfare and pension plan, as well as substantial wage increases, will be put before the country's four largest electrical manufacturers by the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, CIO.
BORDENTOWN, N.J., Jan. 5 -- Fighting ships that sailed the oceans in three major conflicts are going to their doom here daily to provide scrap steel for mill furnaces.

Only a small minority of business executives believe that a recession will occur during the first six months of 1947, a National Industrial Conference Board survey released for publication over the week-end disclosed. Virtually all of the executives queried look for a return of "normal competition" some time in 1947.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Premier Alcide de Gasperi of Italy arrived today to seek an American loan and post-UNRRA help for his riot-plagued country.
The averting of the threatened tugboat strike focused new attention yesterday on the success of Mayor O'Dwyer's plan for coping with labor disputes that menace vital services.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Jan. 5 (U.P.)--Karl Westphal, a former official in the German Ministry of Justice, hanged himself today in Nuremberg prison, where Hermann Goering and Dr. Robert Ley committed suicide.

ALBANY, Jan. 5--Industrial accidents in New York State reached an all-time high of 718;333 in 1946, a report by Miss Mary Donlon, chairman of the State Workmen's Compensation Board, stated today. The previous high was 717,029 at the height of the war-time industrial boom in 1944.

Prices of cotton in the domestic market last week fluctuated within a range of about 80 to 110 points for the most active deliveries. At the close of trading on Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net gains for the week of 23 to 48 points.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5--A group of distributors who in the past have supplied Navy stores protested today the Navy's new "socialistic" policy of dealing directly with manufacturers.

PARIS, Jan. 5--The French Petroleum Company is prepared to use all juridical means to protect its interests in Iraq under recent arrangements concluded by British and American oil companies concerning oil reserves in the Middle East.

Business in New York City should continue to be good during 1947, unless it is hampered by another round of labor disturbances, Thomas Jefferson Miley, secretary of the Commerce and Industry Association of New. York, Inc., said over the week-end on the basis of a recent survey.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Secretary of Labor Lewis B. Schwellenbach said today that the number of strikes decreased sharply as the year ended and the total was lower than at any other time since V-J Day.
Richard E. Anthony has been named general field manager of domestic soaps and household shortening of Lever Brothers. Leon L. Hopkins has been appointed assistant general field manager.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5 (U.P.)--The men who buy and sell butter predicted today that the price the housewife has to pay will keep on going down until probably the decline reaches as much as 20 cents in the next five months.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Brig. Gen. Robert Wood Johnson urgently called today for appointment of a commission of five civilians to plan the dispersion and protection underground of national defense industries for the age of atomic warfare.

The Federation Bank and Trust Company reported as of Dec. 31, 1946, total deposits of $35,274,886 and total assets of $39,756,147, compared, respectively, with $37,618,806 and $41,744,253 on Dec. 31, 1945. Cash on hand and due from banks amounted to $9,250,949 against $9,922,247; holdings of United States Government securities to $9,890,655 against $16,874,401 and loans and discounts to $11,668,949 against $9,400,785.
Rollo E. Falk has resigned as vice president in charge of manufacturing and a director of Revere Copper and Brass, Inc., as of Jan. 1, it was announced over the week-end.

LONDON, Jan. 5--In tribute to the late Ogden Mills Reid, publisher of The New York Herald Tribune, The Times of London in its obituary column today called him "One of the leading figures in American journalism."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5--A program to change the political complexion of the Federal judiciary was brought to the front today by Senator Alexander Wiley, Wisconsin Republican, who heads the new Senate Judiciary Committee.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5--The text of the statement on the federal judiciary made by Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin, chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, follows: Future Policy of Judiciary Committee.

Plans for world peace still are based on an "optimistic illusion" of the goodness of man, the Rev. Joseph M. Smith, a former missionary in the Philippine Islands, said yesterday in a sermon at the Park Avenue Christian Church, at Eighty-fifth Street.

The basic premises of a controversial wage report prepared recently for the Congress of Industrial Organizations by Robert R. Nathan were upheld yesterday by Dr. Isador Lubin, former economic adviser to President Franklin D. Roosevelt and President Truman, and by Henry A. Wallace, former Secretary of Commerce.

Greater need for specialized business credit this year is seen by William J. Drake, executive secretary, National Conference of Commercial Receivable Companies, Inc. The companies comprise old-line factors, who are particularly active in the textile industry, accounts receivable finance houses, operating on a non-notification basis, and the all-around commercial finance companies.

BATAVIA, Java, Jan. 5 (AP)-- Indonesian Premier Sutah Sjahrir announced today that street fighting had broken out in Palembang, center of American and Dutch oil refining interests in southeast Sumatra, and that the military situation there was "most serious."

SAGINAW, Mich., Jan. 5 (AP)-- A new wrinkle in portal-to-portal pay suits appeared here today as the Lufkin Rule Company announced that it wants the United Auto Workers, CIO, to pay back unearned money it said that workers received for time spent in quitting early to wash up.

TOKYO, Monday, Jan. 6 (AP)-- Former Fleet Admiral Osami Nagano, who gave the order for Japan's attack on Pearl Harbor, died yesterday in the United States 361st Station Hospital of pneumonia and a heart attack. His attorney, John G. Brannon of Kansas City, Mo., apprised the International War Crimes Tribunal, in which Nagano was on trial, of the death.

LINCOLN, Neb., Jan. 5 (AP)--An inquiry disclosing that a convict acquired a bank account of several thousand dollars in a year and a half has resulted in the discharge of Neil Olson as warden of Nebraska Penitentiary.

The drive of the Salvation Army to raise $1,000,000 for its 1947 operating fund was formally opened last night, with James A. Farley the principal speaker on a radio program that lasted an hour over WJZ and the American Broadcasting Company network.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 5 (U.P.)--The Miami Printing Pressmen and Assistants Union still held tonight a "continuous" meeting which started yesterday, leaving subscribers without regular Sunday editions of Miami's two daily newspapers.

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 5 (AP)-- Sheriff George Hanley said today that he would not permit a scheduled motorized parade of CIO sympathizers at the strikebound Allis-Chalmers plant Tuesday and declared he would call upon the Governor for troops or on the Regular Army if necessary to maintain order.

NANKING, Jan. 5--The inundation of vast stretches of Communist-controlled territory, inhabited by hundreds of thousands of people, is threatened by the proposed closing of the breaches in the Yellow River dike, near Kaifeng, Tung Pih-wu, chief Communist delegate in Nanking, charged in an appeal sent to Maj. Gen. Glen Edgerton, UNRRA director in China. His statement was released to the press here today.

Twenty-six newspaper editors and editorial writers from seventeen States and the District of Columbia will attend a seminar for editorial writers at the American Press Institute of Columbia University, Floyd Taylor, director of the institute, announced yesterday.

The Greyhound Corporation has made a tentative agreement to buy the minority interest held by the New York Central System in Central Greyhound Lines, Inc., which has been operating principally from New York to Chicago through New York Central territory, Orville S. Caesar, president of Greyhound, announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5 -- Reports that the Government was to expand its export program and expedite shipments of grain from the West and Southwest to Atlantic and Gulf ports led to fairly general buying of futures on the Board of Trade late last week. Corn led the advance, with the January delivery moving up over 4 cents a bushel, while cash corn went to a larger premium over the futures than for some time past.

SEATTLE, Jan. 5 (AP) -- The weather bureau here said today that a storm of gale proportions, carrying snow and rain before it, hit the Aleutian Islands between 1:30 P. M. and 9 P. M. (E.S.T.) yesterday and was decreasing in intensity late today north of St. Paul's Island in the Bering Sea.

A.D. Keller, chairman of the Radio Manufacturers Association, on behalf of the RMA export committee, has asked that foreign trade barriers be withdrawn or reduced "to the point where our manufacturers will have a fair opportunity to compete," it was announced yesterday.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Jan. 5--America's foremost threat to Norwegian supremacy in the forthcoming Olympic games, 23-year-old Artie Devlin of the Lake Placid Club Sno Birds, thrilled a throng of 7,000 that hugged the sides of Bear Mountain Hill today in the second annual Torger Tokle Memorial jump.
Mrs. Betty Margaret Pitt, former English war bride accused of ransacking rooms in leading midtown hotels, was held yesterday in bail of $10,000 for a hearing tomorrow in Felony Court.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Jan. 5 -- Only one man, the founder, of the Theodore Roosevelt Memorial Navy Associaition, made the group's twenty-eighth annual pilgrimage to the grave of Theodore Roosevelt in Young's Memorial Cemetery this afternoon.

SOUTHAMPTON, Jan. 5 (Reuters) -- Herrings -- thousands of them -- caused a slowing up of the 24,000-ton United States liner America on her latest voyage, her chief engineer, Patrick Brennan of Brooklyn, disclosed here today. The ship had to slow down to 19 knots, instead of her usual 23 or 24.

Corn Exchange, Philadelphia The Corn Exchange National Bank Trust Co. of Philadelphia, Pa., reported as of Dec. 31, 1946, total deposits of $258,438,783 and total assets of $282,406,078, compared, respectively, with $268,747,261 and $292,137,361 on Sept. 30, 1946.
Five recommendations for changes in the football rules, none of them of far reaching import, were adopted yesterday by the rules committee of the American Football Coaches Association.

A small boy whose father fought In World War H and whose mother, unable to care for him, sent him to an institution until the family could be together again, sent a gift of $1 to the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund yesterday to help other boys who are unhappy.

The Rev. Donald H. Spencer, associate minister of the Collegiate Church of St. Nicholas, sharply criticized yesterday the action of the Consistory, or governing body of the five Collegiate churches in the city, in supporting the sale of the St. Nicholas building over the objections of the congregation.

WARSAW, Jan. 5 -- Poland's Communist-dominated "democratic bloc" promised today to write into the Constitution--to be framed after the Jan. 19 elections--"a special recognition of the rights of the Catholic Church."

Prospects of the domestic airlines generally for 1947 are not favorable. As last year drew to a close, the factors that had made 1946 a dismal failure for most companies still pervaded the industry -- high costs and a continued downward trend in revenues and earnings.

It requires something less than an elephantine memory to recall those days, a few months back, when we were being told that unless the Office of Price Administration were continued with full wartime powers the country would find itself confronted with the prospect of uncontrollable inflation.

Kenneth Roberts, whose latest historical novel "Lydia Bailey" was published by Doubleday last week, is in Nassau at work on the beginnings of another novel. He plans to spend six months doing research in the West Indies on background for some of the characters who appeared in his "Chronicles of Arundel."

The resignation of Joseph Curran as co-chairman of the Committee for Maritime Unity will be discussed today at a closed meeting of the national council of the National Maritime Union in its headquarters at 346 West Seventeenth Street.

NANKING, Jan. 5 (AP)--The burning to death of a Polish Catholic priest and detention of a score of other priests and nuns by Chinese Communists at a mission near Singtai were reported today by the Polish Embassy.

The settlement at City Hall Saturday night of issues between local tugboat operators and union employes did more than avert a repetition of last year's critical tie-up in this port. It illustrated clearly that timely action by Federal and municipal officials can, if reason prevails, provide an answer to such labor-management rifts as paralyzed the nation's economy on so many occasions last year.
Three weeks after his indictment, Alvin J. Paris, designated by the prosecution as the "front" for a New Jersey bookmaking syndicate, is due to go on trial this morning on a charge of bribery.

A new passenger service to the Mediterranean will be started this month with the sailing of the 9,660-ton liner Olympia, operated By the newly organized South African Olympian Line, it was announced yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your issue of Dec. 10 Julius A. Bernstein repeated in your correspondence columns the substance of a letter he had received from "an institution in Palestine"; and, acting no doubt in perfect good faith, described in some detail allegations made in this letter about what would have amounted to scandalous behavior on the part of British troops in Palestine.

LONDON, Jan. 5--The British Government plans for the nationalization of railway and road transport have stirred up more controversy and wider opposition than any other Socialist measure put forward in concrete form to date.

Terming the 1946 epidemic of Infantile paralysis "appalling," Basil O'Connor, president of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, appealed yesterday to the public to contribute $24,000,000 to the annual March of Dimes drive, to be held from Jan. 15 to 30.

As a means of eliminating racial tensions and improving school and community relationships, the Board of Education has been asked to make budgetary provision for trained human relations counselors in the public schools, it was announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Inflation is exerting a two-arm push on relief costs, forcing more families on to assistance rolls and necessitating larger checks for their care, the American Public Welfare Association reported today.

After a lay-off for the holidays, the New Friends of Music resumed their concerts of chamber music late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. The program was made up of works by Schumann and two of the Slavonic masters, Smetana and Dvorak.

Dealers, distributors and exporters with no priorities required can select from large quantities of war surplus clothing, hardware, furniture, paper products, industrial supplies and miscellaneous materials in wide-open dealer sales now open at the Rome, N.Y., Army Airfield and the Schenectady General Depot, Frank L. Seymour, regional director, War Assets Administration, announced over the week-end.

A canceled note representing the last indebtedness of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and Ninetieth Street, was burned at yesterday morning's services. The church, which was opened in 1929 with obligations totaling $970,000, freed itself of all debt by the recent payment of the last note for $85,000.
