The New York Rovers faltered after building up a two-goal advantage over the Montreal Royals in the feature game of the hockey doubleheader at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon and had to be content with a 2-2 tie with the Northerners.

WASHINGTON. Jan. 5--Americans for Democratic Action, a new liberal organization stressing its rejection of Communists, ended its first meeting today by naming Leon Henderson, former Price Administrator, and Wilson W. Wyatt, who recently resigned as Housing Expediter, as temporary co-chairmen of its organizing committee.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Jan. 5-- The movements of prices of shares of stocks in Amsterdam reflect anxiety about the prospects of the economic recovery of Holland unless in the very near future the German market is made freely accessible again to private trading.

Appraisals of the assets of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation and reports on the results of ten months of operations by both Kaiser-Frazer and the Graham-Paige Motors Corporation have been sent to 36,000 Graham-Paige stockholders. On Feb. 5 they will pass on the merging of Graham-Paige automotive interests into the Kaiser-Frazer corporate set-up, as recommended by Graham-Paige directors.

"Scandalously irreverent," the modern age "mocks at divinity, belittles morality and scoffs at virtue," the Rev. William T. Greene of the staff of St. Patrick's Cathedral declared in a sermon at solemn mass there yesterday. Cardinal Spellman presided in the sanctuary.

The Bilbo compromise reached by the Senate late Saturday afternoon was really a victory for those who carried on the fight against seating the Mississippi Senator-elect. By the same token it was a surrender for those who insisted that he should be seated first and tried afterward.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 5 (AP)-- Battling to beat the setting sun Ben Hogan of Hershey, Pa., shot a one-over-par 72 to cling to a two-stroke lead as the third round of the $10,000 Los Angeles open golf tournament was completed late today before 10,459 fans thronging the Riviera Country Club course.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 5 (UP) -- Patrons poured from the Capitol Theatre tonight when a popcorn machine started a small blaze back stage and five fire trucks rushed to the scene, only half a block down Peachtree Street from the fire-wrecked Winecoff Hotel.
WASHINGTON, L. I., Jan. 5--R. F. De Coppet, last year's national champion skipper in Class B dinghies, today won the Frostbite Yacht Club's sixteenth annual regatta on Manhasset Bay.
Babe Ruth, baseball's famed Sultan of Swat, was reported in a "serious condition" last night at French Hospital and is to undergo an operation on his neck this morning.

BAMBERG, Germany, Jan. 5 (AP) --United States constabulary officers demanded today the dismissal of two United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration officials whom they accused of having attempted to "protect" operators of an asserted "Jewish black market" in the Landsberg camp for displaced persons.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 5 (AP)--Because of what it termed'the "insidious inroads" gambling has made on amateur athletics in re cent years, the Los Angeles Times announced today it will carry no wagering odds in its stories on amateur sports.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Rudolph Von Abele, in a letter to THE TIMES of Dec. 29, summarizes the breadth of the world federalist movement and calls upon the Government of the United States to assume the leadership in an attempt to attain a world government.

Herta Glaz, the Metropolitan contralto, was heard in a recital last night at Town Hall. The program consisted of early classics by Marcello, Scarlatti, Monteverdi and Legrenzi; the aria, "Deh, per questo instante," from Mozart's "Titus"; "Die Kraehe," "Fruehlingssehnsucht," "Wehmut," "An Ar Nachtigall" and "Die Junge Nonne"; items by Bax, Nin and Canteloube; "The Song of Khivria" from Mussorgsky's "Fair of Sorotchinski," and William Grant Still's "Songs of Separation."

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Jan. 5 --Thousands of trade members, including buyers, retailers and manufacturers, jammed huge Convention Hall here today for the opening of the housewares show. Held annually, the show this year is the largest ever presented. More than 580 manufacturers are presenting some 600 displays in an area covering approximately 140,000 square feet.

Policemen from four precincts converged on the Roxy Theatre a Fiftieth Street and Seventh Avenue yesterday afternoon after an unidentified woman telephoned that she was entering the theatre with one of the fugitives from Brooklyn City Prison.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5 (U.P.)--The largest variety of home furnishings since the pre-war days now is available, but refrigerators, washing machines and bedroom and dining room furniture still are scarce, industry spokesmen said tonight.
ATLANTA, Jan. 5 (AP)--If Herman Talmadge is elected by the Legislature next week as Governor of Georgia, he can thank the manager of a five-and-ten-cent store in Monticello, Ga.

The Burlington Mills Corporation, in its annual statement covering the fiscal year ended with last Sept. 28, issued to stockholders today by J. Spencer Love, president, disclosed an increase of 30 per cent in sales to a new high of $141,544,442, from the $108,199,846 volume of the previous fiscal year.

From tonight until Feb. 15 thrifty theatregoers have a treat in store for them at the City Center. During that six-week period the municipally-operated house will be heat to "Bloomer Girl" at prices from $1.20-$2.40 throughout the engagement, with Sunday afternoon and evening performances thrown in for good measure.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: If Easterners sometimes wonder why the West and South fly into what must seem to tie occasional frenzies of sectionalism, it might answer their inquiry to look into the current threats against our Columbia River power rates.

BUDAPEST, Jan. 5--The Communist party issued a warning in its organ today that the coming trial of the "Hungarian unity" plot conspirators was a sword hung over the heads of Communist enemies. After emphasizing that the investigation of the plot was continuing, Communist Deputy Joszef Revai stated in a policy article occupying half the front page of Szabadnep, Communist central organ.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 5-- Kirk Douglas, former Broadway leading man, has been selected by Dudley Nichols, producer-director, to play the role of Peter Niles in the film version of Eugene O'Neill's "Mourning Becomes Electra" at RKO-Radio.

Twenty-nine voluntary and official health agencies have joined the Health Council of Greater New York, Dr. I. Ogden Woodruff, the president, announced yesterday. The council, with headquarters at 137 Centre Street, is designed to coordinate health activities and to encourage broader public participation and support of public and private activities in the health field.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5--President Truman completed today the preparation of his State of the Union Message. Tomorrow at 1 P. M. he will personally deliver it to the Congress, jointly assembled in the House of Representatives.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP)--The United States plans to claim a big share of the 6,000,000-square-mile Antarctic continent, officials disclosed today. The strategy for clinching the claims will be considered upon the return of Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Jan. 5 --The sudden resignation last night of Bernard M. Baruch and all his United States associates from the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission is stirring considerable discussion in diplomatic crcles today.

ABOARD MOUNT OLYMPUS, in the Icepack off the Ross Sea, Jan. 5--A seaplane of the Western Group of the Navy's Antarctic expedition has made an exploratory flight--the first success for the group in five attempts--far over Wilkes Land, 1,000 miles west of here.
ROME, Jan. 5--The prospect of Italy's signing the peace treaty as finally framed in New York are considerably brighter today than some weeks ago.

Overseas radio telephone will observe its twentieth anniversary tomorrow, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday. As on the day the first service to London opened when Walter S. Gifford, president of A.T. T., talked with Sir Evelyn Murray, Secretary of the British Post Office, officials in New York and London will exchange greetings.

TOKYO, Jan. 5 (U.P.)--Gen. Douglas MacArthur voiced warm encouragement today to the Imperial Diet for having shown during the past few months "much promise of becoming a genuine agency of popular government."

A "favorable outlook for the investment market," with interest rates continuing with minor change, and with supply and demand factors approximating those of 1946, is predicted by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.

A parti-color cocker spaniel won best in show in the American Spaniel Club's national specialty for the first time in fifteen years when Ch. Downsbragh Sporting Print, owned by Mr. and Mrs. William W. Brainard Jr., of Far Hills, N. J., was put up at the Hotel Roosevelt last night.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5--Officials of the Office of Price Administration report that ceilings on apartments and homes are being raised at the rate of 20,000 to 30,000 a month.

PARIS, Jan. 5--Completing their surveys of the military and political situation in Indo-China, Maj. Gen. Jacques Philippe Leclerc today returned to Saigon from the fighting fronts in the north and Marina Moutet, Minister for France Overseas, left for an inspection tour at Dalat and the High Plateaus.

LONDON, Dec. 6--The stock markets here have started the New Year with all the appearance of a minor boom. The daily business turnover has reached the highest level since last May while the prices of industrial equities have soared to record levels.

The wholesale markets last week were in "the lull before the storm" as quiet reigned pending the expected influx of an unprecedented number of buyers into all markets this week, according to reports prepared especially for THE new york times by leading resident buying offices.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Jan. 5 -- Five-year-old Patrick Neary is in critical condition at Mountainside Hospital, Montclair, with burns suffered when a souvenir Hawaiian grass skirt he put on took fire. His mother, Mrs. Elva Neary, 27, of 96 Myrtle Street is also in the hospital with burns of hands and arms suffered in trying to beat out the flames.
Fun, Health, Education OPENS TONIGHT YWCA. Lexington at 53. WIck. 2-4500.--Advt.

BERLIN, Jan. 4 (Delayed) -- The questions whether any German representative would be consulted during the treaty discussions in Moscow and who if anyone on the German side would sign the treaty cropped up in military government circles today. This question arose after the formation of the state government in Greater Hesse, the last of the three in the United States zone to be organized.

The Metropolitan Fair Rent Committee, in a letter to Mayor O'Dwyer, made public yesterday, asked whether he was prepared to "urge justice for the property owners and advocate the necessary rent increase" required by soaring costs of operating and maintaining residential buildings.

A single 50-cent fee to cover both toll and parking charges will be placed in effect on the cause-ways leading to Jones Beach State Park next May, it was announced yesterday by Robert Moses, president of the Long Island State Park Commission.

A museum used to house a collection of curios in glass cases. Everything was dead, from stuffed elephants to insects impaled on pins. "Museum" and "mausoleum" were almost synonyms. Today the well-managed museum is a dynamic educational and research institution.

MOSCOW, Jan. 5--The major powers should not be regarded as "potential violators" of any convention governing the control of atomic energy, according to the Soviet viewpoint, expressed today in Pravda, official newspaper of the Communist party.

The influence of the holiday in mid-week and the need to balance out accounts of the old year, effected business in the foreign exchange market last week. Turnover was extremely light and price changes insignificant in size.

The action of Rabbi Stephen S. Wise, vice president and former president of the Zionist Organization of America, in severing last Friday all official connections with the organization he founded fifty years ago, was criticized yesterday by Daniel Frisch, chairman of the ZOA administrative council. The council is the supreme body of the ZOA between conventions.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $55,299,118,127. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows: Jan. 9 -- Discount bills ......... $1,306,438,000

DETROIT, Jan. 5 (AP)--Coming from behind with three goals in a wild third period marked by 30 minutes in penalties against Boston Defenseman Pat Egan for roughing an official, the Detroit Red Wings broke a home ice victory drought by whipping the Bruins, 3 to 1, tonight.

Under the sponsorship of the National Coordinating Committee, representatives of 190 Jewish organizations met at the Manhattan Center yesterday to demand entrance permits for 100,000 Jewish displaced persons into the United States. They adopted a resolution asking the President to initiate and Congress to enact all necessary legislation.
SHANGHAI, Jan. 5 (AP)--A Chinese airliner piloted by an American crashed near Tsingtao today. Unconfirmed reports said all forty-three persons aboard had been killed.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 5--Left Wing sources close to the Communists have expressed the opinion here that the Chinese Reds will not resume negotiations with the Government merely on the basis of a new democratic Constitution.

If the shape of things to come in the dance world during 1947 is in any way indicated by the first event of the new year, it should be a banner year, for Jose Limon brought his little company to the Belasco Theatre last night for its first Broadway appearance and covered himself with glory.

Rune Gustafsson, who has a 4:04.6 mile to his credit, and Haakan Lidman, Sweden's crack hurdler, arrived at La Guardia Field early yesterday aboard a Scandinavian Air Lines plane. Here to challenge this country's top trackmen, the Swedish stars came directly from Stockholm.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The Government's wartime regulation over consumer credit, which exceptionally was excluded from the general administrative decontrolling before and after the recent significant election returns, is still not affected by the President's "end-of-hostilities" proclamation.

ALBANY, Jan. 5--State expenditures for the next fiscal year are likely to rise $90,000,000 to $100,000,000 over this year's appropriations, putting the State budget at an all-time high of $650,000,000 and wiping out any future prospect of substantial annual surpluses at present tax levels, according to well-informed sources at the capitol.
RICHER dear plessure? Try PRINCE HAMLET all Havana Filler. 2--25c--Advt.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Jan. 5 (AP)--Capt. H.W. Hofmann of Flushing, N. Y., dashed 75 yards for a touchdown with a fumble in the last quarter today to give the United States Army Base team a tie with the United States Navy team in the fifth Lily Bowl football game.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- For a well-groomed, peacetime appearance, nine out of ten veterans would like to have at least one more suit. That is what the Labor Department said today.

PARIS, Jan. 5--Premier Leon Blum's far-reaching experiment with price cuts--on the success of which, some quarters feel, the fate of French finances depends--has begun when his Government has only eleven days to live and the country faces a prolonged governmental crisis after the impending series of elections.

Caught in a heavy snowstorm and with its gasoline supply virtually exhausted, a four-engined American Airlines plane that had left La Guardia Field at 5:26 P. M. yesterday for Los Angeles made an emergency crash landing at 10:10 P. M. at Cedar Beach, five miles east of Jones Beach, L. I.

Dr. John L. Childs has tendered his resignation as State Chairman of the Liberal party, it was learned yesterday. Acceptance by the party's executive committee is expected when agreement is reached on his successor.

ALBANY, Jan. 5--A drive for liberalization of the State Unemployment Insurance Law so as to increase the amount and duration of benefit payments was started here today by the Congress of Industrial Organizations of the State with the announcement of its 1946 legislative program.

The Federal Public Housing Authority in Washington announced yesterday that fifty-three Federaly financed housing developments used in eleven States during the war for war housing purposes, were being turned back to the purpose for which they were built, low-rental shelter for low-income families.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5--A broad export demand continues for lard and additional business was reported put through last week. However, stocks of lard in cold storage accumulated last month and are 17,936,000 pounds, a gain of 11,546,000 pounds compared with a month ago.

BRIDGETON, N. J., Jan. 50--The co-pilot and two passengers were killed and nineteen other occupants were injured tonight in the crash of a transport plane in a wooded area near the hamlet of Carmel, six miles east of here.

BATAVIA, Jan. 4 (Aneta)--The Indonesian Republican Government "does not mean to use force and never will agree to force," Republican Defense Minister Amir Sjarifoedin stated in a broadcast last night in which he explained that the broadcast on Dec. 26 in which General Soedirman, commander-in-chief of all Republican forces, had urged his troops to "continue the fight against the Dutch," had been "misunderstood by many as a call to battle."

Bond Stores, Inc., will add another link to its chain of clothing shops here as the result of a longterm lease it has just obtained on the property occupied at present under lease by Best Co. at 372-82 Fifth Avenue and 3, 5 and 7 West Thirty-fifth Street, two nine and twelve-story buildings at the northwest corner.
Random notes. Those planning a quail shooting trip to North Carolina during the month might find it profitable to take some fishing tackle along especially if you are going to shoot near the coast.

The stock market gave yesterday no worth-while reaction to President Truman's message to the Congress. The leading industrials responded quickly during the forenoon to replacement buying of limited proportions but generally shaded extreme additions in the afternoon.

City College and St. John's clash tonight in the feature contest of a college basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden, with L.I.U. opposing Utah State in the curtain-raiser. Nat Holman's Beavers and Clair Bee's Blackbirds are, it goes without saying, the favorites.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 6-- Merchandising on a short-term basis for the spring season in women's and children's coats and suits is unsound, Alexander Printz of the Printz-Biederman Company of Cleveland, and chairman of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board, told the three-day convention at the Hotel Biltmore here today. Mr. Printz' report because of his inability to attend was read by Milton Levy, counsel of the organization.

SEATTLE, Wash., announced yesterday that it would accept until Jan. 13 bids on two bond issues amounting to $8,361,000. One issue of $6,500,000 is designated as municipal light and power bonds. It will come due on Jan. 1, 1949 to 1967, or optionally on Jan. 1, 1952.

With many of the country's leading coaches on hand, Earl (Red) Blaik, famed Army mentor, was honored last night as the Coach of the Year at the twelfth annual award dinner attended by more than 250 persons at Leone's Restaurant.

Net assets of the Lehman Corporation were $101,993,012, equal to $52.39 a share on Dec. 31, Robert Lehman, president, told stockholders yesterday in a report covering the first six months of the fiscal year. This contrasted with net assets of $112,352,963 on Dec. 31, 1945.

LONDON, Jan. 6--A sudden strike of 5,000 London truck drivers today threatened to halt the distribution of food and other supplies in the metropolitan area, already suffering from breakdowns in transport and electricity in this winter's sharpest cold snap.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 6--Eastern Gas and Fuel Associates filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission several amendments to its plan of recapitalization providing, among other things, for a change in the allocation of the new common stock.

New York's garment markets received their first impact yesterday of what promises to be a record influx of out-of-town buyers, all seeking to determine the course of fashion merchandising for 1947. Transit delays and heavy hotel registrations kept many buyers out of the market in the morning, but the afternoon saw the majority busily engaged in making the first calls on heavy schedules.
The public in England expects an economic slump here by 1950, Patrick Gordon-Walker, deputy floor leader for the Labor party in the House of Commons, declared yesterday.

DON'T look now but the collegiate basketball season at Madison Square Garden already has passed the halfway mark and this is only the first week in January. There was a time when most college teams were just about beginning their campaigns now instead of wheeling into the homestretch. But the tendency in most sports of recent years has been to spread out the seasons in both directions until one overlaps the other.

College baseball coaches wrestled with the problem of professionalism yesterday. Meeting at the Hotel New Yorker, they sent a telegram to Commissioner A.B. Chandler and George Trautman, president of the National Association of Minor League Baseball Clubs, asking that organized baseball keep hands off college players and refrain from entering into contractual agreements with them until they have been graduated or left school.
TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 6--The resignation of Advisory Master John A. Matthews, Newark lawyer, was requested and received today by Chancellor A. Dayton Oliphant.

Mayor O'Dwyer continued yesterday to press for a complete reorganization of Tammany Hall, involving the replacement of Edward V. Loughlin as leader, the ouster of Clarence H. Neal and Bert Stand from key posts, and the setting up of a group of prominent Democrats to act in an advisory capacity to a new Hall leadership.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6--President Truman's message to the joint session of the House and Senate today was interpreted by Turner Catledge, assistant managing editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, in a broadcast over station WQXR tonight as a genuine bid by the President for cooperation toward the national good.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 6--The crash of the Chinese National Airways plane at Tsingtao yesterday, which raised to 114 the fatalities in four commercial plane crashes since Christmas Eve, has emphasized the hazards of flying in China in the absence of adequate safeguards against what wartime pilots called "some of the trickiest weather in the world."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6--The Supreme Court refused today to review a test case governing the basis for computing maximum rentals under the Emergency Price Control Act.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 6 (AP)--Elmo T., a New England campaigner flying the silks of Mrs. C. P. Amodie, made his first public appearance since Nov. 23 and captured the Posinatus Purse, first of the twin feature offerings at Tropical Park today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6--Evidences are beginning to appear that American critics of B.M. Baruch's atomic energy control plan, and of the tactics he employed in driving it through the U.N. Commission, will attempt to use his retirement as United States delegate to revise his plan downward.

The three sections of the President's message which seem certain to be examined most closely by the Republican Congress, whose cooperation he invites, are those dealing with foreign affairs, with fiscal policy and with labor problems. This is because time and events have made these three, today, the top Subjects of public interest and concern.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6--Labor leaders, with few exceptions, were chary today about commenting for publication on President Truman's labor proposals.

HONOLULU, Jan. 6--All the 108 naval and civilian personnel on Palmyra Atoll, 960 miles southwest of here were reported out of danger today after high tides had driven them to the highest ground on tiny Cooper Island, six feet above the surging seas, and caused radio appeals for aid to be sent early Sunday.

LONDON, Jan. 6--The stock markets here failed today to continue last week's advances. After the small week-end accumulation of orders had been dealt with business was flat--a condition for which the coal situation was blamed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6--With an amiability that took on a touch of crispness toward the end, President Truman appeared today before the first Republican Congress in sixteen years to urge a new legislative program upon a strikingly undemonstrative membership.

Alphonse Rocco, who masterminded the "camera-gun" shooting of his former wife a week ago, was shot dead early last evening in a wooded section of the Catskills near Gilboa by State police and New York City detectives.

One hundred and twenty-five fashion editors of leading United States and foreign newspapers were welcomed to the eighth annual press week of the New York Dress Institute by Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday at a luncheon in the Waldorf -Astoria Hotel.
BADEN, Germany, Jan. 6--The Saar question is a side issue with the Germans of the State of Baden in the French zone. Their main topic is the arrest of the chief surgeon of the Baden town hospital.

Preparations for the East River skyscraper capitol of the United Nations went into high gear here yesterday with the appointment of Wallace K. Harrison, co-designer of Rockefeller Center and one of the country's leading architects, as Director of Planning in the construction program.

ALBANY, Jan. 6--The hot lunch program in the schools of the State, threatened because Federal aid for the school year will be used up by Feb. 1, will be continued with $2,500,000 in State aid, it became known today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6--The Democratic steering committee left two Senate committee vacancies for Theodore G. Bilbo of Mississippi, who departed yesterday for New Orleans, where he will undergo an operation prior to returning to take us his fight for admission to the Senate.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6--The Republicans assumed firm control of the Senate today. With Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg of Michigan sitting as President Pro Tempore, they dealt gently but assuredly with the Democrats, as yet unaccustomed to their new status as the minority of the upper house.

TORONTO, Jan. 6--Major Benjamin H. Namm, president of the National Retail Dry Goods Association and chairman of the board of the Namm Store in Brooklyn, N.Y., presented here today a fourpoint "blueprint for freedom." for the United States and Canada.

The outlook for golf in 1947 is unusually bright. Every prospect points to continuation of the great growth of last year after wartime handicaps were removed-- growth in play for recreation, in competition, and in spectator interest.
Mayor O'Dwyer took a chest X-ray test yesterday at the New York City Veterans Service Center, 500 Park Avenue, to open a preventive drive against tuberculosis conducted by the Department of Health.

The city's program for rehabilitating unused tenements with $6,000,000 borrowed from the State moved forward yesterday. Under a condemnation order signed by Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin, the New York City Housing Authority took title to ten boarded-up buildings.

MELBOURNE, Jan. 6 (U.P.)--Australia ended its second innings today for a total of 536 runs in the third test cricket match. Leonard Hutton and Cyril Washbrook opened England as second innings with a great stand for 91 runs and provided the visitor with at least a chance of avoiding a humiliating defeat in the five-match cricket world series.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 6--The New Jersey Bell Telephone Company notified the New Jersey Board of Public Utilities Commissioners today that it sought an increase in tariffs so that its revenues would rise 17 per cent from residential users and 27 per cent from business subscribers.

A banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., received yesterday the award of an issue of $3,310,000 of equipment trust certificates or the Baltimore Ohio Railroad at competitive sale. The Halsey group bid 99.401 for 2s. Other bids ranged to 99.16 for 2s.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 6-- The United Nations Security Council, which has the responsibility for the next stage in the effort to achieve international atomic control, will meet here at 3 P.M. tomorrow, with Norman J.O. Makin, Australian Ambassador to Washington, presiding.

There were twenty-one deaths in 1946 attributable directly to football, Dr. Floyd Eastwood of Purdue University reported yesterday to the American Football Coaches Association and the National Collegiate Athletics Association, according to the United Press.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP)--The Association of American Railroads estimated today that in November, 1946, Class I railroads had a net income, after interest and rentals, of about $38,400,000, compared with $34,384,068 in November, 1945.

Twenty-nine thousand workers in three big woolen and worsted companies will receive a general wage increase of 15 cents an hour as a result of negotiations concluded yesterday by the companies and the Textile Workers Union, CIO.

The program for the establishment of Palestine as a Jewish state and the proposal to boycott the forthcoming London conference "under the present circumstances" were reaffirmed last nigh by leading members of the American Zionist delegation to the recent World Zionist Congress at Basle, Switzerland.

LONDON, Jan. 6--The British Government has again directed the attention of the State Department to advertisements in United States newspapers soliciting funds for the support of "terrorist" organizations in Palestine.

When a railroad goes into receivership or through recapitalization the policy ordinarily pursued is to revamp its financial structure in such a way that fixed charges will be reduced and it can keep out of the red ink even in times when business activity and traffic are subnormal.

Two of the Army's hardest assignments have been the command of United States Forces in Europe, held by Gen. Joseph T. McNarney, and the deputy command, held by Lieut. Gen. Lucius D. Clay. General McNarney has had to interpret and lay down policies. General Clay has had to administer them.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 6 (AP)-- Ben Hogan, the little Hershey, Pa., pro, captured the $10,000 Los Angeles golf tournament for the second time today, firing a last-round 72 for a 72-hole score of 280, a new tournament record for the Riviera Country Club course.

A motion calling for withdrawal of the National Maritime Union, CIO, from the Committee for Maritime Unity was discussed yesterday at a stormy three-hour meeting of the union's national council. The conference, held in NMU headquarters at 346 West Seventeenth Street, is due to resume today at 10 A.M.
BOSTON, Jan. 6--Robert H. Best and Douglas Chandler, American newspaper men accused of treason, were denied bail today in Federal court.

Lenore Lonergan has signed contracts to assume a major role in "The First Hundred Years," the William Cahn production of Patrical Coleman's play. The engagement is not her first adult role, the young actress having appeared in a grown-up part last season in "Brighten the Corner."

NEW DELHI, India. Jan. 6-- Storm warnings of an important cleavage within the predominantly Hindu Congress party's nationalist movement appeared today. The party's general committee, highest executive body, approved a resolution reluctantly professing acceptance of the British and Moslem League viewpoint regarding the Constitution-making procedure.

The city's milk industry, insisting that price cutting had been confined to a few distributors in the Bronx, said yesterday that a general reduction in costs to consumers would occur on Feb. 1. Until then there will be no price cut for most of New York's consumers of home-delivered or store milk, trade spokesmen declared.

MOSCOW, Jan. 6--An appeal to members of the Communist party, the League Communist Youth and party organization generally to purge "embezzlers and thieves" from retail trade organizations appeared in a front-page editorial in Pravda, the Communist party newspaper, today.

BERLIN, Jan. 6--Four inspection teams, each composed of American, British, Russian and French engineers, set out from Berlin today for the four zones to check the status of destruction or dismantling of German aircraft, armament and chemical explosive plants.
PARIS, Jan. 6--Marius Moutet, French Overseas Minister, returned to Saigon today. He has decided to cut short his mission of investigation in Indo-China and is expected to return to France tomorrow.

PARIS, Jan. 6--The General Director of the French Film industry today denied discrimination against American films in a recent circular that was protested by American film interests here and by the French dubbing syndicate. The statement indicated that the French decision was aimed at preventing the flooding of the French market by old, outdated films from the United States and would not be used to obstruct the dubbing of new films of primary importance.

DETROIT, Jan. 6--Increased efficiency in the operation of motor vehicles and new factors of "builtin" safety were emphasized today at the opening sessions of the forty-first annual meeting of the Society of Automotive Engineers.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6--Profitable operations in all by-products departments boosted Armour Co.'s net income in the fiscal year ended on Nov. 2 to a record high of $30,291,128, or $6.61 a common share, against $9,172,538, or $1.14 a share, in the preceding year, George A. Eastwood, president, said today.

BERLIN, Jan. 6--Lieut. Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Deputy Military Governor in Germany, said today after announcement in Washington of his appointment as European theatre commander in succession to Gen. Joseph. T. McNarney that he expected "no drastic changes" in the occupation policy.

Tony Janiro, Youngstown, Ohio, welterweight, and Tony Pellone of Greenwich Village were found fit yesterday at the State Athletic Commission for their ten-round battle Friday night in Madison Square Garden.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Tuesday, Jan. 7--Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty, Catholic Primate of Hungary, said today in an interview in the archiepiscopal city of Esztergom that Czechoslovakia had brought back what amounted to slavery and slave markets into the life of Europe.

Two to three times pre-war production levels in their industry were forecast for 1947 by members of the Safety Equipment Manufacturers Association attending their annual convention here yesterday at Hotel Roosevelt. Shortages of glass and scarce metals are expected to be overcome by midyear, they said.

ALBANY, Jan. 6--Governor Dewey has incorporated in his annual message to be delivered at the opening session of the Legislature on Wednesday a recommendation that emergency compensation being paid State employes to meet rising living costs be made a permanent part of State pay scales.

Mayor O'Dwyer asked all New Yorkers yesterday to support the $1,000,000 annual maintenance appeal of the Salvation Army as he received Commissioner Ernest I. Pugmire, Eastern Territorial Commander, at City Hall.

It is significant that Alcide de Gasperi, Premier of Italy, is in Washington not merely as a mendicant but at the express invitation of the United States. This indicates that our Government is prepared not only to explore the whole mounting Italian problem but perhaps to do something about it.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 6 -- A democratic coalition government is regarded as likely in Bolivia this evening as a result of a close Presidential contest in the first free elections that the inland South American country is said to have held since 1930.

January brings the weather for casseroles of hearty food, presented so hot the steam whiffs up when the serving spoon is inserted. It also calls for the simple fare that satisfies after a fortnight of plum puddings, oyster stuffings and fruit cakes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6--The Supreme Court overruled today an order of the Interstate Commerce Commission restricting the freight carrying operations of Seatrain Lines, Inc., between New York and the Gulf ports of New Orleans and Texas City.

One of the world's largest capacity tin dredges was launched yesterday by the Tampa Shipbuilding Company at Tampa, Fla., for use on Banka Island in the Dutch East Indies, it was announced yesterday. Officials of the Mining Equipment Corporation which has ordered eight of the dredges, stated that once they are in operation the tin-island group, second largest producer in the world, will surpass its pre-war production.

MOSCOW, Jan. 6--Suspicion and apprehension have been aroused throughout the world by "backstage" military and political activity on the part of Washington and London, it was stated today in an editorial in Pravda, official organ of the Communist party.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6--The White House announced today that Gen. George C. Marshall had been summoned to Washington to report on the situation in China, where he has been serving as President Truman's special envoy.

WARSAW, Jan. 6--A hint that Vice Premier Stanislaw Mikolajezyk's Peasant party (PSL) would eventually be outlawed throughout Poland was dropped by Communist Vice Premier Wladyslaw Gomulka in a campaign speech reported today.

Bank Report Acting to meet the requests of a number of its stockholders who asked that a report of the bank's operations be in their hands prior to the annual stockholders meeting tomorrow, the Manufacturers Trust Company has completed mailing of the report to about 30,000 stockholders, it was learned yesterday.

ROME, Jan. 6--A step designed to lead to the pacification of the Italians was taken in Rome this morning when twenty-five Partisans and twenty-five former members of the Fascist "Black Brigades" embraced each other before the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier in the first World War.
Nine helicopters took off from La Guardia Field yesterday carrying mail to thirty-nine communitie within fifty miles of New York and seven locations within the city.

First National, St. Louis The First National Bank in St. Louis reported as of Dec. 31, 1946, total deposits of $425,437,030 and total assets of $457,790,319, compared, respectively, with $425,172,302 and $456,214,491 on Sept. 30, 1946.

ALBANY, Jan. 6--An amendment to the State Constitution to provide a simplified and more expeditious method of removing or retiring judges of courts of record will be urged upon the Legislature by Governor Dewey in his annual message on Wednesday, it was disclosed today.

The text of President Truman's State of the Union message to Congress as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES was as follows: Mr. President, Mr. Speaker, Members of the Congress of the United States: It looks like a good many of you have moved over to the left since I was here last.

LONDON, Jan. 6 (Reuters)-- The United States delivered a belated Christmas present to British beachcombers along England's southeast coast today when cargo of cotton bales, flour and grapefruit from the American vessel Northeastern Victory, wrecked on Christmas Eve on the Goodwin Sands, drifted ashore near Deal, in the Dover area.

MUNICH, Germany, Jan. 6--As European thermometers fell today far below the freezing level, Allied Military Government officials here and throughout the rest of occupied Germany admitted they could do nothing to prevent further industrial shut-downs.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6--A proposal to modify the tax laws applying to proprietorships and partnerships was laid before Government tax experts today by F. N. Bard, Chicago business man.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 6-- Governor Earl Warren, the second Chief Executive in California's ninety-seven-year history to be reelected to a four-year term, took the oath of office today and, in his inaugural address, appealed to a joint session of the Legislature to "cooperate for the common good without regard to party, faction or personality."

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 6 (AP)-- Ageless Jersey Joe Walcott became one of the leading challengers for the world heavyweight title by outpunching Joey Maxim of Cleveland, in a sluggish ten-round bout at Convention Hall tonight.
LONDON, Tuesday, Jan. 7--Favorable comment predominated in the first British press comments today on President Truman's message on the State of the Union.

MUNICH, Germany, Jan. 6-- How closely political expression follows religious affiliation in Baveria is strikingly illustrated in three charts made available to THE NEW YORK TIMES by newlycreated Bishop Scharnagel of Munich. Bishop Scharnagel is the brother of the newly-elected Chief Mayor of this city and a close friend of Michael Cardinal Faulhaber.

There has been much talk for years of the taint of professionalism to intercollegiate athletics and particularly in football. Now the National Collegiate Athletic Association has the opportunity to do something about it.

Nazi party adherents are back in power in the American occupation zone in Germany because of inept administrative policies of United States military authorities, Capt. Harry N. Sperber, chief interpreter of German at the Nuremberg trials declared yesterday.
Hacksaw work on the bar that was bent last Thursday to let nine prisoners escape from Brooklyn's Raymond Street Jail began last August or in early September, it was learned yesterday.
Lyricisms were ignored yesterday by American poets and writers replying to a Moscow radio commentator who had asserted that the war writings of American and British poets were superficial.

Jacques Abram, up-and-coming young American pianist, undertook to play two concertos at last night's Carnegie Hall concert of the National Orchestral Association, Leon Barzin conducting, and he handled them both with the dispatch and brilliance of the accomplished virtuoso.

The Chicago Society of Artists has sent to the Riverside Museum at Riverside Drive and 103d Street an exhibition made up of watercolors, drawings and prints. The work is placed in the second-floor galleries and will remain on view through Jan. 22.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 6-- RKO today signed Raymond Massey to play Brig. Gen. Ezra Mannon in the screen version of Eugene O'Neill's "Mourning Becomes Electra," with Rosalind Russell and Kirk Douglas, which Dudley Nichols will produce and direct from his own screen play, starting March 10.

What was regarded as the opening gun in a campaign for the restoration of normal trade discounts to retailers was fired yesterday at a meeting of the vendors' relations committee of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at its offices here.

Thousands of floor covering distributors and department and specialty store buyers yesterday crowded into manufacturers' showrooms to view a large assortment of new spring patterns but failed to find any appreciable quantity of "free goods" over and above allotments made last month for the first half.

PARIS, Jan. 6--David BenGurion, chairman of the Jewish Agency's executive committee, expressed fear today that the terrorism sweeping Palestine would turn against the Jews themselves, in which case the Agency's defense force, Haganah, would have to be used.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 6 (AP) --A series of "single-package" prepaid medical and hospitalization plans, endorsed by the Connecticut State Medical Society will shortly be offered to the public by State licensed insurance companies, Dr. Cole G. Gibson, president of the society, announced today.

Immediate action to prevent crippling strikes and slashing of governmental costs to balance the budget are looked upon as the most urgent tasks for the new Congress, according to a survey of the opinions of country editors contained in the January issue of The American Press.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 6 --An incomplete list of members of the United Nations commission of inquiry to the Balkans, announced here today, indicates that the investigation team will be composed of men with varied backgrounds and experience.
MOSCOW, Jan. 6--Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery, Chief of the British Imperial General Staff, arrived today to "pay my respects to the Soviet Army."

CHICAGO, Jan. 6--Grain markets showed an irregular pattern on the Board of Trade today. Buying of wheat futures attributed to cash interests and mills lifted prices 3/8 cent to 1 1/4 cents, with the finish on the old-crop months about the top.
MOSCOW, Jan. 6--The other day a man named Poltoratsky jotted down for Izvestia a few of the inconveniences, disappointments and difficulties he had put up with during his recent visit to New York.

Gen. Robert Wood Johnson's advocacy of a national commission to plan "the dispersion and protection underground" of defense industries is a sobering reminder of some of the grim realities of atomic peace. The nature of atomic war has been brought to mind sharply enough by the destruction at Nagasaki, Hiroshima and Bikini.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6--The foretaste of President Truman's budgetary plans included today in his message to Congress indicated that he was standing firmly against quick and sharp reductions in income taxes, despite widening support in recent weeks for an early cut in Federal levies.
Henry A. Wallace, former Secretary of Commerce, expressed concern last night at what he described as the failure of people to exercise their freedom.

Second thoughts are sometimes better than first ones and our State Department has now sent formal notes both to Russia and to China regarding the recent incident at Dairen, in which a Russian military commander undertook to prevent three Americans from landing there and ordered an American Navy LC-3 to leave the port.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6--A fourman minority of the Supreme Court today accused a five-man majority of leaving a "cloud of doubt" as to what one who believes he holds a valid patent should do in granting licenses under it. This criticism came from three of the court's "conservatives," joined this time by Justice Stanley F. Reed.

LONDON, Jan. 6--The London bankers' support of the German financial system in the period between the wars was the direct result of pressure from the British Government, according to R. Olaf Hambro, chairman of Hambro's Bank Ltd., a leading acceptance house, in a letter in today's Times of London.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP)-- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, presiding officer of the Senate, said today that President Truman's message was "very constructive."

Directors of the North American Company announced yesterday that they have authorized the offering to common stockholders of rights to purchase, at $15 a share, the common stock of a subsidiary, the Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company, in the ratio of one share of Cleveland Electric for each five shares of North American common held.
Survivors of the two airplane crashes in New Jersey and Long Island Sunday night joined yesterday in praising the skill of their pilots in bringing the craft down through blinding snow.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6--President Truman called on the Eightieth Congress today in a 7,000word message on the state of the Union to outlaw jurisdictional strikes as "indefensible" and require "binding" arbitration of disputed labor contract terms.

A protest was lodged yesterday by the Port of New York Authority against a proposed revised rule published by the Eastern Rail Carriers operating to and from New York harbor. The revision would increase rail and water freight charges and interfere with the continuous movement or freight from point of origin to destination, the Interstate Commerce Commission in Washington was told.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6--Sears Roebuck Co. will begin distribution of its 1947 spring and summer general catalogue this week, the company announced today. The new book containing 1,250 pages is approximately the same size as last year.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 6--The United States Steel Corporation and the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, will begin negotiations in Pittsburgh for a new wage contract Thursday, Jan. 16, the steel corporation said tonight. The existing contract expires Feb. 15.
PEIPING, Jan. 6--Large bodies of Communist troops have been reported moving east during the past few days from Shansi Province toward the important north-south Peiping-Hankow railway.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A letter from a group of Protestant clergymen, in your issue of Dec. 28, who object to the presence of a United States envoy at the Vatican, concludes as follows: "We demand, furthermore, the cancellation of the status of the papal delegate at Washington, D.C."
CHICAGO, Jan. 6 (U.P.)--Buyer resistance to high furniture prices was reported today at the opening of the International Home-Furnishings Mart.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6--The right of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System to remove two directors of a national bank was sustained unanimously today by the Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas wrote the opinion, justifying the course of the Reserve Governors in ordering removal of John Agnew and F.O. Fayerweather as directors of the Paterson, N.J., National Bank.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Jan. 6--Necessity for modern, integrated furniture design, in the face of an approaching "buyer's market," was emphasized tonight by spokesmen for three facets of the industry at the third annual furniture forum here, held in connection with opening of the Grand Rapids January Furniture Market.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP)--A bill to end immediately the wartime excise taxes was introduced today by Representative Donald L. O'Toole, Democrat, of New York.

Untarnished and as pleasant as ever, "Bloomer Girl" came back to town last night after its triumphant tour across the length of the land. In this season of musical mediocrity, the Harold Arlen-E.Y. Harburg-Sig Herzig-Fred Saidy gem is a most welcome visitor.
Orders of Merit Hollywood producers, as reported in this paper a few days ago, are now looking forward with hearts more or less palpitant to the annual Academy Awards, the greatly coveted "Oscars."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6--Two measures were introduced in the Senate today to prohibit Federal courts from entertaining suits for "portal-to-portal" pay damages of the nature of those already filed throughout the country and now totaling more than $3,000,000,000.

A jury was chosen in General Sessions yesterday to try Alvin J. Paris on charges of offering bribes to two star players of the New York Football Giants to throw their play-off game with the Chicago Bears for the National Professional Football League championship on last Dec. 15.

In a press conference at the Brooklyn club's Montague Street offices yesterday Branch Rickey, Dodger president, revealed that the spring training plans at Havana include the Montreal club as well as the Dodgers.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I should like to say a few words on the debate which has been raging with regard to the "Voice of America."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP)--The Government-owned Big and Little Inch oil pipeline system, successfully converted to transmission of natural gas a month ago, may take on new supplies this week to reach a capacity output.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 6 --The Supreme Court of Serbia passed the death sentence today on three of eighteen accused of having disclosed state and military secrets to the United States Embassy in Belgrade. Five other defendants received prison sentences up to eight years.

BAMBERG, Germany, Jan. 6 (AP) --Joe Buda, Polish civilian official of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, denied today charges contained in a United States constabulary report that he had attempted to cover up "black-market activities" at the Landsberg camp for displaced persons.

ABOARD MOUNT OLYMPUS, Jan. 6--After being stalled for five days in the pack ice outside the Ross Sea, the ships of the Central Group of the Navy's Antarctic expedition broke loose early today. They are now headed south in the wake of the icebreaker, North Wind, bound for Little America.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Imagine my surprise, when I read my paper last night, to find a report to the American people by the National Association of Manufacturers that prices and business profits are too high; that for the good of the nation both should come down, instead of wages going up.

Store Sales Here Up 40% Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores increased 40 per cent last week, compared with the like week of 1946. The week, however, had five selling days against four last year. For the four weeks ended Jan. 4 there was an increase of 33 per cent.

TOKYO, Jan. 6--Efforts to expand Japan's oil production are being undertaken by the Japanese Government at the suggestion of Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters, it was stated today. A special committee for the Ministry of Commerce will check on oil exploration projects and set priorities in personnel and materials for those approved.

New York's public schools would get about $1,000,000 a year more in State aid if they could cut pupil absence 1 per cent. This was made known yesterday by a spokesman for the Board of Education after the publication of a report on pupil attendance in the junior high school division.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said yesterday that the young people of the nation, both North and South, had started on their way to bring equal rights to everybody, regardless of race, creed or color.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 6-- Close scrutiny of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad's application for a 20 per cent increase in commutation rates was ordered today by the Westchester County Board of Supervisors after some members had declared that the increase would jeopardize the county's growth and work a hardship on commuters of low income.

Staten Island's 180,000 inhabitants, many of them galled for some time by a suspicion that their problems are neglected by the more populous boroughs, reacted with unexpected fervor yesterday to the proposal that they secede from the city.

Longchamps Restaurants obtained yesterday a temporary order restraining the State Liquor Authority from closing at midnight the chain's nine restaurants and warehouses for violating the Alcoholic Beverage Control Law. The Appellate Division issued the order, which is effective until it hands down its decision reviewing the SLA ruling.
A gift in memory of a soldier killed on his first day of combat was received yesterday by the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund.

After opening yesterday 1 to 13 points higher than the Saturday's final prices, the cotton futures market broke sharply and closed barely steady 7 to 41 points net lower, with the most pronounced weakness in the distant months.

Rune Gustafsson and Haakan Lidman, Swedish track aces, who arrived here by plane Sunday, tried out their land legs twice yesterday. For Lidman, a top-ranking hurdler, it was not a new experience, he having toured this country with Gunder Haegg in 1945.

India has achieved all but technical freedom and Burma soon will be free, Dr. E. Stanley Jones, for many years a Methodist missionary in India, asserted yesterday as he left La Guardia Field aboard the DC-4 transport Taj Mahal, which is making Trans-World Airline's initial flight to Bombay.

TOKYO, Jan. 6--The previously announced Japanese Government plan to hold a series of local elections will be delayed by the new "purge" decision made public last week. The new housecleaning measures will ban even the rather distant relatives of politically objectionable persons from ever again seeking public office.

Results from a nation-wide poll of 800 retailers show that initial purchases of coats and suits thus far have averaged 58.8 per cent of planned business for the spring season, it was announced yesterday by Joseph Kraeler of the Joseph Kraeler-Frasca Company, manufacturers of coats and suits.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6--President Truman's message on the State of the Union was digested with unexpected warmth by the Republican-controlled Eightieth Congress today.

Sources close to developments in the long-discussed refinancing program of Transcontinental Western Air, Inc., declared yesterday that the situation would be brought to finality today at the fifth meeting within the last two weeks of the board of directors.

In his first annual report as president of the New School for Social Research, Dr. Bryn J. Hovde has presented an admirable picture of this institution and the work it has been doing since its inception a quarter of a century ago. Those who believe in an intelligent electorate have reason to be encouraged by the figures dealing with the adult education program.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6--Changes in the top command of the United States forces in Europe, predicted last week, were confirmed officially by the War Department today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6--The State Department announced today that it had requested the Soviet Union to turn over control of Dairen, Manchuria, to China immediately.

Three former soldiers have won the 1946 Abbey Scholarship Award, it was announced yesterday by the board of directors of the Edwin Austin Abbey Memorial Scholarship Fund for Mural Painting in the United States.

Tallying seven points in the last two minutes, Manhattan College defeated Iona College of New Rochelle, 69--62, in a thrilling basketball contest before a capacity crowd at the Riverdale gymnasium. It was Manhattan's eighth victory in nine starts.

A $200,000 glass-enclosed swimming pool will be erected on the grounds of the Bronx Veterans Hospital, Kingsbridge Road, as a permanent memorial to four Army chaplains representing the Protestant, Jewish and Catholic faiths. The four lost their lives when the transport Dorchester was sunk by a German torpedo off Greenland early in 1943.

The stock market stumbled again in the late afternoon yesterday after a show of strength in the forenoon. The intervening period was given over mostly to an irregular drift of quotations and, at the close, key issues showed losses of about a point, while the composite rate fell slightly more than 1/2 point.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7--A master bill to be used by House Republicans, with much Democratic support, in the effort to end portalto-portal back pay suits was introduced today with powerful assured backing.

The Advertising Federation of America will release to all daily newspapers with a circulation exceeding 5,000, insertions relevant to its campaign to promote public understanding of advertising, with the theme "Advertising, by Selling More Goods, Makes Your Job More Secure."

Lieut. Gen. Lucius D. Clay, deputy United States Military Governor in Germany, informed the State Department yesterday that no arrangement had been made or was contemplated for affiliation of German labor unions with the World Federation of Trade Unions.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7--Secretary of Agriculture Clinton P. Anderson disclosed today the Government hopes to retain 6,000,000 tons of sugar as this country's allocation for 1947. He estimated this is equivalent to eighty-three pounds per capita, which compares with a five-year low of seventy-three pounds last year and ninety-eight pounds in 1940

With the 'little fellow" entering business in large numbers, more than three-fourths of the wartime decline in the total number of companies has now been recovered, according to the National Industrial Conference Board in an analysis of business integration and concentration released yesterday.
SHANGHAI, Jan. 7--Some delay in the closing of the Yellow River gap near Kaifeng, where the Chinese blew the dike in 1938 to stall the Japanese advance, appeared likely tonight.

Bernard M. Baruch has urged Governor Dewey to establish a permanent board to study living costs as a means of preventing strikes by teachers and other public employes. In a letter to the Governor, made public yesterday, Mr. Baruch gave his support to the campaign of New York City's teachers who are demanding a minimum salary of $2,700.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The "personal statement on the situation in China," issued today by Gen. George C. Marshall, once again illustrates his unusual qualities and helps to explain, if explanation were required, his appointment as Secretary of State tonight and why he is rated in the forefront of world leaders by those with whom his work has been done since he was made Chief of Staff of the Army by the late President Roosevelt.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Jan. 7-- Senator Carl A. Hatch of New Mexico, in a radio forum here today on the topic "Do We Need New Labor Laws?", advocated compulsory arbitration when strike in key industries threaten national welfare.

PARIS, Jan. 7 -- The French Planning Council today unanimously adopted the Jean Monnet plan for modernization and equipment and made a recommendation to the Government for the immediate application of this four-year program for 1947 to 1950, inclusive.

The situation in Tammany Hall grew more confused yesterday when it became known that a petition designed to oust Edward V. Loughlin as leader was being circulated by a group of leaders other than those supported by Mayor O'Dwyer, who also has been seeking Mr. Loughlin's retirement.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7--Hearings will be held soon on the Government crop insurance system with a view to drastic, cost-cutting changes, Chairman Clifford R. Hope of the House Agriculture Committee asserted today.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Jan. 7 (U.P.)--Gen. Joseph T. McNarney said today that American forces in Germany would be reorganized, with the emphasis shifted to the military government side of the occupation, when Lieut. Gen. Lucius D. Clay succeeded him as American commander in Europe on March 18.

BOSTON, Jan. 7 (AP)--Elmore Morgenthaler, one of basketball's tallest players at 7 feet 1 inch, got out of bed with a doctor's permission and all he did was flip in 29 points as he led Boston College to a 61-50 victory over Brown University tonight at the Arena.

WILLIAM WISTER HAINES, author of "Slim" and "High Tension," served for thirty-three months as lieutenant on the staffs of the Eighth Air Force and the United States Strategic Air Forces, for the last eighteen months of the European war as a liaison officer assigned to the Royal Air Force. Few American writers were placed in quite such a strategic position from which to observe one of the most important and dramatic phases of the war.

The accomplishments of James Francis Byrnes as Secretary of State have been appraised variously by critics and admirers, but both have agreed that his policies of firmness and patience, evolved during his year and a half in office, have placed him well forward among international figures.

An eventuality that the industry hoped to avoid--additional rises in the prices of passenger, automobiles --materialized yesterday for the second time in two months. It is the development that automotive companies fear strongly, for they feel that prices now are perilously close to the point where a great portion of demand for their product will be driven from the market.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP)--The text of a statement by Gen. George C. Marshall on the situation in China follows: The President has recently given a summary of the developments in China during the past year and the position of the American Government toward China.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7--When President Truman asked Congress yesterday to name a Temporary Joint Commission "to inquire into the entire field of labor-management relations" he had one precedent (the only one in our history in the labor field) to go by-- President McKinley's "Industrial Commission," named pursuant to a Congressional Act of June 18, 1898.

Storm signals, warnings of the danger confronting intercollegiate football as a result of the increase in gambling, went up at yesterday's meeting of the National Collegiate Athletic Association at the Hotel New Yorker.

LONDON, Jan. 7--Continued uncertainty about the industrial coal position, together with a new truck drivers' strike, helped today to restrict business in the stock markets. With many buyers holding off, the only really active sections were those of gilt-edged issues and gold shares.

A major addition to the Fifth Avenue shopping district will be opened on Feb. 3, when Lane Bryant, a leading specialty store for women's fashions, maternity apparel and infants' wear, opens the doors of its modernized building at the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Fortieth Street.
Harry N. Wright, president of City College of New York, gave his formal approval yesterday to the break in athletic relations with the University of Wyoming.

The Edison Electric Institute, a trade association representing about 75 per cent of the $15,000,000,000 electric light and power industry, will distribute to its members today an exhaustive analysis of the Tennessee alley Authority. The Federal agency is charged in the study with operating at a loss of "almost $100,000,000" since its inception in 1934, and an "over-all deficit" of $8,041,000 for 1946.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7--A continued shortage of major articles of men's apparel and a decline in the supply of inexpensive feminine attire during 1947 was predicted today by Theodore G. Maynard, who is retiring from the Civilian Production Administration.

Fern Hammers, mezzo-soprano, from St. Louis, made her New York debut last night at Times Hall. In spite of certain strange inhibitions and a faulty production, which at times kept her at about a quarter-tone off pitch in a parallel line to the melody, Miss Hammers revealed a voice of color and expressiveness, and at times she did some singing that was good to hear.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (U.P.)-- Abbott and Costello, Thomas J. Watson and Deanna Durbin, a slapstick comedy team, an internationally known industrialist and a Hollywood songstress, tonight topped the Treasury's latest list of high-salary earners for 1944.

The hats that Lilly Dache presented yesterday afternoon at 78 East Fifty-sixth Street qualify as pretty. It was obvious that this well-known designer aimed to flatter her clients, not only in the matter of silhouette but color as well.

LONDON, Jan. 7 -- Prominently headlined stories of GI "brides of despair"--British girls "abandoned" by their American ex-soldier husbands in New York--appeared in most London newspapers today, with purported details of neglect by United States officials and mistreatment by the American people.

ALBANY, Jan. 7--Governor Dewey will call upon the Legislature tomorrow to make a thorough -going investigation of installment selling in New York State. Close associates said he was outraged at the "scandalous" credit terms exacted in time-selling agreements and would urge that the inquiry consider imposition of a ceiling on interest in such transactions.
The Prokofieff Fifth Symphony had a prodigious success last night when George Szell interpreted the work as guest leader of the Philadelphia Orchestra, in Carnegie Hall.

"High officials" of the Union Connecting Railroad, a one mile "O" gauge system, will meet today with representatives of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad, a 1,000-mile, Class I carrier, to sign a long-term lease for a new home in the latter's Hoboken, N.J., terminal.

With General Marshall's prospective appointment as America's new Secretary of State, the report which he has rendered on the situation in China becomes in effect his first pronouncement of both his views and his policies, applicable not only to China but to the whole world scene.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 7 (AP)-- L.T. (Buck) Shaw, coach of the San Francisco Forty-Niners of the All - America Conference professional football organization, announced today the suspension and fining of two of his players who participated as "ringers" in a game with a rival league team last Sunday.

The wages of 200,000 building trades workers in this city were stabilized yesterday to eliminate labor piracy and other elements of a chaotic wage structure that has kept many investors from risking capital in new building construction here.

Irately telling a defendant that the electric chair was too good for him, County Judge Lester W. Patterson in Bronx County Court yesterday sentenced a 21-year-old youth to the maximum sentence of thirty to sixty years in prison for first-degree robbery in an attack upon a woman.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The qualities that carried Gen. George C. Marshall through the most arduous service as Army Chief of Staff ever seen by an American officer may or may not serve him in good stead in his new assignment as Secretary of State. He is, primarily, an administrator of high order.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7--A sharp reduction in the areas to be granted Government assistance in obtaining materials and equipment was announced today by the Civilian Production Administration of the Office of Temporary Controls.
LONDON, Jan. 7 -- A Belgian trade delegation headed by Baron de Traux de Wardin is expected to arrive in London tomorrow to begin an important series of trade talks with the British Government.

Federal Judge Simon H. Rifkind held yesterday that longshoremen already receiving time-and-a-half pay for night and Sunday work were not entitled to additional overtime pay for hours worked on that basis in excess of forty hours a week.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Jan 7 (AP)--The Home Mission Council of North America reported today that nearly $6,000,000 was spent for social work during 1946 by its thirteen affiliated denominational boards.

An extra dividend of $1 a share was voted on the common stock of the Belding-Corticelli Company, Ltd., for payment on March 1. In July, 1946, directors increased the quarterly rate to $1.50 from $1. Shareholders received an extra of $2 in March of that year.

MANHASSET, L.I., Jan. 7-- Harry E. Winship, assistant treasurer of the Railway Express Agency since 1931, died last night in the Pennsylvania Station in New York as he was going to a Long Island train to return to his home here.

ALBANY, Jan. 7 -- Salary increases for the 72,000-odd public school teachers in the State will be the first major problem to engage the attention of the 170th session of the New York State Legislature when it convenes at noon tomorrow.

Enrollment under the medical and hospital care program to be offered to 175,000 city employes and their families under the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York in which the city will pay half the premium got under way yesterday at a luncheon at the Downtown Athletic Club, 19 West Street.

Books of the Dairymen's League Cooperative Association and the New York Mercantile Exchange were examined yesterday by agents of the United States Department of Agriculture. The Government has charged that the Dairymen's League and four of its officers rigged the wholesale butter market in violation of the Commodities Exchange Act.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (U.P.)-- Retiring Secretary of State Byrnes called it "a happy night." But many of the more than 1,300 diplomats from this and other lands disagreed and told him so.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 7 (UP)--England forced a draw in the third cricket test match today by remaining at bat all day, the final day of play, to make 310 runs for seven wickets in its second innings.
A women's blouse manufacturer was arrested yesterday charged with having concealed at least $200,000 of his income from the State tax authorities for the years 1944 and 1945.

Falling off of demand for spot cotton in the South, increased offerings at leading spot markets and lack of confidence in prices of some finished goods brought in heavier offerings of cotton futures yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

A novel about life in Russia behind the "iron curtain," "A Room on the Route," has been written by Godfrey Blunden, an Australian correspondent. The notes for the book were made during his fourteen months' stay in Moscow and were carried by him for three years, traveling through many countries.

Although the day was scarcely of a sort to inspire enthusiasm, Manager Melvin Ott appeared in on way depressed yesterday as he outlined the Giants' pennant prospects and their chances of climbing out of the National League cellar.
NANKING, Wednesday, Jan. 8 (AP)--Gen. George C. Marshall left by plane for the United States today bearing the unofficial best wishes of the Chinese Government in his new post as Secretary of State.

A copy of the first took to be printed in the English colonies in America, the Bay Psalm Book, the Puritans' original metrical version of the Psalms, will be sold at auction on Jan. 28 at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.
Youthful hats were presented by Laddie Northridge in his spring and summer collection at One West Fifty-seventh Street.

Housedress manufacturers should reduce the number of styles at a single showing and introduce new ones more often, Irwin D. Wolf, vice president of Kaufmann's Department Store, Pittsburgh, said last night.

LONDON, Jan. 7--A note from the Austrian Government asking that an Austrian representative be invited to state his country's views on the proposed treaty for Austria was received by the Foreign Office today.

Mrs. Norman S. Goetz was reelected president of the New York section of the National Council of Jewish Women yesterday at its annual meeting in the Temple Emanu-El Community House, 1 East Sixty-fifth Street.

Miss Helen Richey, veteran woman flier who served in the European Theatre during the war as an auxiliary and ferry pilot, was found dead at 7:30 o'clock last night in her one-room apartment at 400 West Twenty-second Street. Her age, according to available records, was 37.

The theme for the twelfth North American Wildlife Conference, to be held at San Antonio, Tex., on Feb. 3 to 5, will be "Americans, Wildlife and Their Land," and this session is expected to be one of the most interesting, and perhaps exciting, ever held.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (UP)-- The texts of Secretary of State Byrnes' letters to the President and of Mr. Truman's reply: Byrnes' First Letter April 16, 1946, DEAR MR. PRESIDENT: As you know, on April 1, 1945, I retired as Director of the Office of War Mobilization.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 7 (AP)--In response to a greater demand for low grade cotton, the spot market committee of the New Orleans cotton exchange has announced a revision of spot quotations, which traders say should induce farmers to sell this cotton at a better price.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP)-- Following is the text of identical notes on the forthcoming Polish elections that the State Department said today were delivered to the British Ambassador in Washington and, by Lieut. Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, Ambassador, to the Soviet Foreign Ministry in Moscow on Jan. 5:

DETROIT, Mich., Jan. 7--Preparedness for global warfare was emphasized as "imperative" by Maj. Gen. Lawrence C. Craigie of the Air Materiel Command in urging tonight an annual budget of $250,000,000 for an Army Air Force aeronautical research and development program.

A retrospective exhibition of paintings, collages and water-colors by the late Arthur G. Dove opened to the public yesterday at the Downtown Gallery, 32 East Fiftyfirst Street. The distinguished American artist died in November at the age of 66.

Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt, pioneer suffrage worker and a leader in the fight for international peace, will be 88 years old tomorrow. Fittingly, tomorrow also will mark the first anniversary of the first meeting of the United Nations General Assembly.

The New York Knickerbockers, who snapped out of their slump by defeating Detroit and St. Louis in road games last week-end, return to the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory after an absence of three weeks to meet the Toronto Huskies tonight.

Man's Mixed Diet We are not too far advanced into the new year to make all predictions and anticipations out of date. Hence we take the liberty of reproducing two headlines from the same issue of this paper a few days ago.

Walter S. Tower, president of the American Iron and Steel Institute, urged yesterday the scrap metal industry to concentrate on eliminating certain wartime "distortions" that have made scrap metal scarce and costly.

A more enlightened public opinion is vitally needed in this country, Lester Markel, Sunday editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, declared yesterday at the Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fiftyfirst Street.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 7--Two of Palestine's most fanatical underground organizations have agreed to declare a truce in the current war against the British, according to unconfirmed reports tonight from usually reliable sources here.
The elimination of corporate income tax on rental housing, as a spur to increased investment residential construction, was urged yesterday.

Strikes in 1946 were far and away the most serious in point of numbers made idle and production days lost in the history of New York State, preliminary data supplied by State Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi showed yesterday.

Net operating earnings of the United States Trust Company of New York during 1946 were $1,762,776, compared with $1,856,892 in the previous year, Williamson Pell, president of the company, disclosed yesterday at the annual stockholders' meeting--the first of such annual gatherings scheduled by banking organizations for this month.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 7 (AP)--The Glenwood Farm's heavily campaigned Eire, the only favorite to win on the eight-race card, was an easy victor in the featured Harinero Purse at Tropical Park today.
LONDON, Wednesday, Jan. 8-- News of the resignation of Secretary of State Byrnes was received with astonishment and regret in British official quarters today.

LONDON, Jan. 7--Hollywood has brought money into the United States at the expense of American prestige and reputation, Herbert Morrison, Lord President of the Council, told a meeting of British film exhibitors and their employes tonight.
Inquiry into last Thursday's break from Brooklyn City Prison, in which nine prisoners went free, focused yesterday on jail personnel. Nine men escaped by sawing a window bar in the jail's east wall.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7--When Senator Theodore G. Bilbo, Democrat, of Mississippi, returns to renew his fight for a seat in the Senate, he will find his case in the hands of a Republican-dominated Rules Committee, according to indications today.

The Port of New York Authority, through its chairman, Howard S. Cullman, made a new offer yesterday to the Newark City Commissioners to develop Newark Airport and Marine Terminal on a ninety-nine-year lease basis as distinguished from its purchase offer of last July, which was rejected by the city.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 7-- India's Communists, small in number in comparison with the large followings of the Congress party and the Moslem League, appear to be determined to seek a "popular democratic coalition" designed to oust the British from this country by force.

Edmund Kurtz, who relinquished his post as first 'cellist of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra several seasons ago to devote himself to a career as a soloist, gave his third New York recital last night at Town Hall.
