HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 7-- Leo McCarey announced today that Sinclair Lewis will arrive in Hollywood this week to write a photoplay for McCarey's Rainbow Productions under the title "Adam and Eve." McCarey closed the deal with Lewis by telephone, according to the announcement, and the novelist will leave for the West Coast immediately.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7--The United States Government has called on the Soviet Union and Britain "as a duty and a right" to associate with it in demanding that the Provisional Polish Government stop persecution and terrorism against the Peasant party and other democratic elements so there might be a free and fair election on Jan. 19.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7--The capital speculated tonight on the possibilities of a change in the United States' policy toward Argentina as an initial result of Gen. George C. Marshall's appointment as Secretary of State.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 7 -- The resignation of James F. Byrnes as Secretary of State leaves the entire question of an atomic accord open.

An 8 o'clock curtain is announced for tonight's premiere, "The Big Two," at the Booth. First-nighters are asked to cooperate by being in their seats at the designated time. On other nights an 8:30 curtain will prevail.

President Truman appealed yesterday to the American public to support tlie annual March of Dimes to begin on Jan. 15. He likened the fight against infantile paralysis to that against war and poverty. The Chief Executive said he would broadcast to the nation in behalf of the campaign on the night of Jan. 30. This is the sixty-fifth birthday anniversary of the late President Franklin D. Roosevelt, founder of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7--The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 31, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

The sound approach to the Federal tax problem is that nothing should be done about reducing taxes until the budget has been balanced beyond peradventure and until a real beginning has been made in reducing the present unwieldy public debt. Moreover, it would be a serious mistake to think that this generalization applies only with respect to corporate and individual income taxes.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 7 -- The United Nations Security Council postponed action today on the proposed statutes for the establishment of the international administration. of Trieste. This resulted from opposition by Australia, which contended that the Charter did not authorize the Council to assume this responsibility.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 7-- Twenty-four of the twenty-five countries that have submitted positive reports to the United Nations concerning their diplomatic relations with Franco Spain disclosed that they did not maintain ambassadors or ministers in Madrid.
OTTAWA, Ont. Jan. 7--Reviving the tradition of the great days of the English stage, Donald Wolfit opened a tour of Canadian cities here last night by presenting his Shakespeare company in "Hamlet."

Though it has long been known that Secretary Byrnes wished sooner or later to lay aside the duties of one of the most exacting of all offices in the Government, the news last evening of his resignation came without warning and with startling suddenness. There had been no reason to assume that he contemplated taking this step on the eve of the important Moscow conference on Germany.
NANKING, Jan. 7--General Marshall plans to fly from here to Honolulu to spend a few days there, where Mrs. Marshall has been wintering, and then continue with her to Washington.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Miss Marion E. Martin, who resigned from her position as assistant chairman of the Republican National Committee under pressure from high party officials, became a leading contender today for the vacancy on a Federal agency of the Democratic administration, the Federal Communications Commission.

PALM BEACH, Pla., Jan. 7--A stand to safeguard fair trade practices of the cloak and suit industry and to prevent a recurrence of trade abuses from which the industry has had virtually four years of freedom was taken today at the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board convention at the Biltmore Hotel.

WARSAW, Jan. 7--Poland's leaders are writing a virtual textbook for parties or persons who cannot see why their unpopularity with the voters should deprive them of the right to office and power. Figures are now available to illustrate the techniques.

The State put in its case against Alvia J. Paris yesterday in one crowded court day. Although the defense is scheduled to begin this morning, there is a distinct possibility the bribery trial will be cut short.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7--A number of procedural steps to facilitate greater production of rental dwellings were put into effect today by the Federal Housing Administration. The changes were designed to ease standards and cost estimates for insured mortgages processed by the FHA for rental projects.

Mrs. Betty Margaret Pitt, a 23year-old former English war bride, was held in $50,000 bail yesterday for the action of the grand jury at her hearing in the Felony Court on her alleged confession to the police that she had looted at least fifteen hotel rooms in the Fifth and Park Avenue district of $25,000 in jewelry, furs and other articles since last October.

ALBANY, Jan. 7--Oswald D. Heck became assured tonight of serving longer than any other Speaker of the Assembly in State history when he was nominated for re-election at a caucus of the enlarged Republican majority.

LONDON, Jan. 7--Revolutionary changes in the land-holding system in Britain were proposed in the Government's town-andcountry planning bill, published tonight. The scheme does not nationalize land, but in effect it nationalizes all profits from the development or improvement of any land, urban or rural, in England, Wales and Scotland.
Renowned English paintings on loan from King George VI and London museums arrived yesterday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art from Chicago under heavy police guard.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The community is to be congratulated that THE NEW YORK TIMES has called attention to the critical smoke situation in our city. From your interest and continued attention much good will result.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7--Gen. George C. Marshall, special envoy to China, whose appointment as Secretary of State was announced tonight, declared in a statement issued through the State Department today that the salvation of China "would be the assumption of leadership by the liberals in the Government and in the minority parties."
The 15,450-ton Atlantic liner Veendam, a pre-war transatlantic tourist favorite and one of the liners seized and used by the Germans in the war, will return to commercial service in February.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7--The appointment of Gen. George C. Marshall as Secretary of State is expected to lead to a reorganization of State Department personnel in the higher echelons, since they represent the official family of the head of the department.

Joe Louis, world heavyweight champion, will leave Jan. 26 for an extended tour of exhibitions in Mexico and Central and South America. The definite date for the titleholder's departure was announced yesterday by his manager, John Roxborough.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Jan. 7 (U.P.) -- Assistant Secretary of State John H. Hilldring said tonight that reluctance of the people to interest themselves in foreign affairs was jeopardizing the United States' program of International cooperation.

A survey of shoe distributors has revealed that current demand for better quality footwear at prevailing and even slightly higher prices is far greater than production, Irving E. Grossmann, first vice president, the Guild of Better Shoe Manufacturers, stated yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7--Congress set next Friday aside today for receipt of President Truman's annual budget message, with indications that it would cause the first major clash between the Democratic Administration and the Republican forces.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7--Secreary of State James F. Byrnes resigned tonight on the advice of his physicians and President Truman announced immediately that he would nominate General of the Army George C. Marshall to replace him.

The New York Life Insurance Company and the Continental Can Company have entered into an agreement involving an estimated $10,000,000 for the financing of Continental's expansion of its manufacturing facilities, it was announced yesterday by the two companies.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7--Mrs. Robert A. Taft, wife of the senior Senator from Ohio, today christened with Potomac River water the Baltimore Ohio's new streamliner, the Cincinatian.

Progress has been made in wiping out discrimination in more than thirty trade unions operating in New York State, Henry C. Turner, chairman of the State Commission Against Discrimination announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7--Liberal hedging sales and scattered liquidation developed today in the corn market on the Board of Trade. With stop-loss orders uncovered, the close on futures was at the bottom. Losses were 7/8 cent to 2 1/4 cents a bushel, the near deliveries leading.

MOSCOW, Jan. 7--The reconstruction of Soviet industry was virtually completed in 1946 and Soviet economy in 1947 must concentrate on the expansion of existing industries to meet the production goals of the five-year plan.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7--Six outstanding civilian scientists have been appointed as a scientific advisory group to the Policy Council of the new Joint Research and Development Board and are performing the unusual function of counseling the Army and Navy on strategic decisions.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 7-- Despite urgent week-end messages to London, United Kingdom representatives here today were still unable to say positively whether Britain would sign the constitution of the International Refugee Organization and accept her share in its operating costs.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The Eightieth Congress has been started most inauspiciously with the introduction of HR-1, the Knutson taxreduction resolution. Let us hope that the legislative record of the Congress will not follow this retrogressive pattern.

The twentieth anniversary of the first overseas radiophone circuit, which was opened Jan. 7, 1927, with a single talking channel between New York and London, was celebrated here yesterday by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

Progress has been made in wiping out discrimination in more than thirty trade unions operating in New York State, Henry C. Turner, chairman of the State Commission Against Discrimination announced yesterday.

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 7--James Dewey, Federal conciliator, who returned to Milwaukee yesterday after a recess in negotiations to end the 254-day Allis-Chalmers strike, today announced that he had conferred yesterday with company representatives and today with spokesmen for striking Local 248 of the United Auto Workers, CIO.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7--Only three sessions of the Senate a week, with two days devoted wholly to hearings and drafting of proposed legislation by committees, was planned today by the new Senate Majority Policy Committee, headed by Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio.

Defeated by Kentucky, Utah and Rhode Island State in its last three outings, the St. John's University basketball team last night at Madison Square Garden fashioned a tremendous upset by beating City College, 46--41. Everyone in the crowd or 18,467 thrilled to the magnificence of the Redmen's performance.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 7--Overruling the board of governors of the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., the Securities and Exchange Commission today ordered the group to readmit Lawrence R. Leeby Co. of Miami Beach, Fla., to membership in the NASD.

PARIS, Jan. 7 -- The French garrison at Namdinh, isolated since the beginning of hostilities in the Tongking area of Indo-China, was reached and reinforced today in a surprise parachute operation, official dispatches reported.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Jan. 7-- Aroused car drivers in the incorporated village of Great Neck Plaza, one of the nine home-rule municipalities on the Great Neck peninsula, have demanded a public hearing Jan. 15 on the reason why fines for traffic violations in the trading area have jumped from an average of $75 a month to $735 in December.

ATHENS, Jan. 7 (AP)--At least twenty-eight persons were reported today to have been killed in intensified fighting in northern and central Greece, and more than 150 persons were under arrest in connection with bloody political clashes in Athens over the weekend.

A FEW years ago there was a rather childish dispute between Alva Bradley, then the owner of the Cleveland Indiana, and Walter Briggs, the owner of the Detroit Tigers. Bradley insisted that he was paying his pitching hero, Bobby Feller, more money than Briggs was paying his current pitching star, the ineffable Bobo Newsom.

Jimmy Doyle, 150 1/2, Los Angeles, won an unanimous decision over Sal Richie, 150 1/2, East Side, in the main bout of eight rounds at the Broadway Arena, Brooklyn, last night. In the eight-round semi-final, Nick Kashuba, 157 1/2, Brooklyn, beat Antonio Carmona, 161, Puerto Rico.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 7 (AP)-- Harold Dade, a relatively unknown 23 - year - old 12 - to -1 underdog, pounded out an unanimous 15round decision last night to end little Manuel Ortiz' five-year reign as the world bantamweight champion.
Another sleepless week is in prospect for Artie O'Connor, who doubles capably as coach of Fordham's track squad and official handicapper for the Metropolitan Association of the A.A.U.

VIENNA, Jan. 7--An offer made by the Austrian Government to negotiate regarding forty-five of the 160 large scale industries in this country seized by the Russians as German external assets allocated to them by the Potsdam Declaration is understood to have been refused by Moscow as inadequate.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 7 (AP)-- Jacalitos, an 11-1 shot owned by W.H. Bishop, was awarded the featured Washington Purse at the Fair Grounds today after the judges had disqualified J.O. Hart's Angle Bar.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Riza Afshar, veteran Iranian politician, announced today the formation of a coalition on a platform of opposition to Premier Ahmad Ghavam's agreement to give Russia a huge oil concession in the North.

All fired up as a result of successive shut-out triumphs over Toronto and Chicago, the New York Rangers will tackle the Boston Bruins at Madison Square Garden tonight. A capacity throng of more than 15,000 is expected to be on hand for the face-off at 8:30 P.M.

A woman who has been sending 100 annually to the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund through an intermediary made yesterday her contribution to the thirty-fifth yearly appeal. The letter accompanying the gift read:

CHICAGO, Jan. 7--A group of men teachers who have threatened to close trade, vocation and high schools by a strike Thursday morning made preparations today to establish picket lines when the walkout begins. Representatives of parent and teacher organizations urged pupils to attend school, regardless of the effect of a strike.

Edward C. Werle, vice chairman of the board of governors of the New York Curb Exchange, has been nominated to be chairman for a year to succeed Edwin Posner, who has served as chairman and president pro tem for the last two years, it was announced yesterday.

Track and field athletics in this country is on the threshold of an era which is certain to produce more outstanding performers and thrilling racing than ever before witnessed in the history of the sport in the United States.

Legislation designed specifically to curb labor, reduce individual income and corporate taxes and prohibit portal-to-portal pay suits will be enacted by the Eightieth Congress, Ellsworth B. Buck, Republican Representative from New York's Sixteenth district, predicted yesterday.

An aggregate of $27,444,000 of temporary loan notes of eleven housing authorities was awarded yesterday at an interest cost ranging from 0.79 per cent to 0.90 per cent to bidders as follows: Chemical Bank and Trust Company, $12,747,000; Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, $6,539,000; Salomon Brothers Hutzler, $4,500,000; R.W. Pressprich Co., $2,000,000, and Bessemer Trust Company, $1,658,000.

The National Electrical Manufacturers Association, through its president, R. Stafford Edwards, yesterday called on Congress to outlaw all forms of "secondary boycott" of electrical products by labor unions as restraint of trade. In an interview here, Mr. Edwards said that the electrical industry and the public have been "victimized" for twelve years by the boycotts which, he estimated affect production and distribution of $500,000,000 in electrical products annually.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7--A group of men teachers who have threatened to close trade, vocation and high schools by a strike Thursday morning made preparations today to establish picket lines when the walkout begins. Representatives of parent and teacher organizations urged pupils to attend school, regardless of the effect of a strike.

Edward C. Werle, vice chairman of the board of governors of the New York Curb Exchange, has been nominated to be chairman for a year to succeed Edwin Posner, who has served as chairman and president pro tem for the last two years, it was announced yesterday.

MOSCOW, Jan. 8--Marshal Alexander Vasilevsky, chief of staff of the Soviet Army and several other marshals are to visit Britain this spring, it was learned tonight in the course of a talk with Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery of Alamein, Chief of the Imperial General Staff who is visiting here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8--When Gen. George C. Marshall arrives in Washington to take over his responsibilities as the fifty-first Secretary of State he will find on his desk the usual neat pile of resignations.
MUNICH, Germany, Jan. 8--In a modest house in the Bavarian village of Weilheim, near Munich, lives Admiral Nicholas Horthy, former Regent of Hungary.
The final figures on the New Jersey deer harvest brought the total to the record number of 3,030 for the five-day season, which passed the 1945 total by 326 deer.

TORONTO, Jan. 8 (AP)--The Toronto Maple Leafs crushed the tailend Chicago Black Hawks, 10-4, in a National Hockey League game tonight. A crowd of 12,059 saw the Leafs forge ahead and go on a scoring spree after trailing early in the second period.
A vivid picture of New York, its harbors, its skyscrapers, parks and streets was shown yesterday in oils, water-colors and drawings at the Associated American Artists Galleries, 711 Fifth Avenue.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 8 --A public hearing was conducted in the court house here today by the State Motor Vehicle Bureau to determine the cause of the accident of last Aug. 14 in which a sedan driven by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt was in collision with two other automobiles on the Saw Mill River Parkway in Yonkers.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 8 (AP)--Mrs. Mary Cruse, 41 years old, of 185 East Palisade Avenue, Englewood, N.J., died today in the Hospital of St. Raphael of injuries, received earlier this afternoon when an oil truck and a sedan were in collision at an intersection.
PARIS, Jan. 8--All officers and men of the French regular land and air forces were today placed on call for service in Indo-China upon order of the National Defense Ministry.

West Virginia's highly-regarded and undefeated basketball team will meet St. Francis, and N.Y.U. will clash with Duke in a court double-header at Madison Square Garden tonight. The visiting Mountaineers and the local Violets are favored to triumph.

LONDON, Jan. 8--A stiff program for keeping down wages, increasing the productivity of labor and continuing the fight against inflation was recommended to the Nationalist Joint Advisory Council by the British Government today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8--Senator Joseph H. Ball, Republican, of Minnesota, introduced a bill today to outlaw the closed shop and all its variations and modifications.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP)--The Commerce Department estimated today that 1,000,000 new permanent dwelling units will be started during 1947 and that about 900,000 units will be completed by private builders during the year. Last year 675,000 units were started and about 450,000 completed.

Directors of Transcontinental Western Air, Inc., held their second long conference yesterday with Howard Hughes, the airline's principal stockholder, in an effort to draft an urgently needed refinancing program, but the meeting was recessed again when the Hughes interests would not accede to the management's suggested plans.

The first of a series of special services for business groups was held yesterday morning at Trinity Church, Broadway at the head of Wall Street, in tribute to its 250th anniversary. The Rev. Dr. Frederic S. Fleming officiated.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8--Leaders of the Democratic and Republican National Committees made almost simultaneously today pronouncements vigorously denouncing the efforts and objectives of the other side. Little evidence could be seen of the cooperation which has been pledged in the past by the highest spokesmen for both the Democratic and Republican organizations.

After a lower opening, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned firmer yesterday and closed all about the best levels of the day up 17 to 30 points net. It began with losses of 2 to 9 points, influenced by some Southern selling liquidation and professional selling.

The steel, line-steel and tool industries have joined other American business groups opposed to reduction in United States tariffs on finished product imports, it became known yesterday. Briefs have been submitted to the State Department's Committee for Reciprocity Information, which will begin to take testimony on Monday in Washington.

A review of notes taken at the Sally Victor millinery showing, held yesterday morning, might almost make one think that they had been penciled at an international conference, so many were the foreign countries named by the designer in her lively comments.
The case of the Miami Theatre Corporation, which formerly operated a movie house at Forty-sixth Street and the Avenue of the Americas, produced two verbal explosions yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 8--Londoners with sentimental attachment to the flashing signs of Piccadilly Circus have nothing to fear from the new powers to control outdoor advertising contained in the Labor Government's Town and Country Planning Bill, it was officially stated tonight.

The National Arts Club at 15 Gramercy Park opened with a private view last evening its annual exhibition of work by painter and sculptor members. The exhibition opens to the public today and will continue through Feb. 7. Special programs are being arranged for each Wednesday evening at 8:30, and tea will be served in the galleries on Sundays at 3:30.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 8-- "Playback," a mystery-melodrama written for the screen by Raymond Chandler, has been purchased by Universal-International and assigned to Joseph Sistrom for production. The studio is negotiating with Chandler to write the screen play of "Playback."

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 8 (AP)--The Miami-owned Umpydan, packed down to 9 to 20, won the first division of the Tarcoola Purse at Tropical Park today. W. L. Huntley's 6-year-old gelding finished the six furlongs a length in front of T.D. Buhl's Detroit invader, Likeasnot.

BASTON, Pa., Jan. 8--Taking the lead in the first three minutes and never relinquishing it, Lafayette College defeated Columbia University, 52-43, tonight before 3,000 spectators, the largest basketball crowd in Lafayette's history. It was Lafayette's fifth straight victory of the season and fifteenth in a row since January, 1946, when Columbia was the last team to beat the Leopards.

The American Association for the United Nations, which is honoring Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt today on the eighty-eighth anniversary of her birth, will be joined by millions of Americans in extending praise and tribute to a truly remarkable woman. She has lived her rich and rewarding life in the midst of the great public controversies of her time.

Wool manufacturers are planning to absorb the wage increase which will go into effect on Feb. 1, it was learned yesterday. Although the 15 cents an hour rise, it was said, will impose a definite handicap on the industry, manufacturers are determined to keep the level of prices unchanged.

The gauntlet so often merely dangled in the faces of "non-conformists" in athletics, particularly football hit them full across the cheek yesterday when the National Collegiate Athletic Association, in its closing session at the Hotel New Yorker, adopted the set of six principles written by the Conference of Conferences, an N.C.A.A. offshoot, on Monday.

Mayor O'Dwyer conferred late yesterday afternoon with Frank J. Sampson and Carmine G. De Sapio, rival aspirants for the leadership of Tammany to succeed Edward V. Loughlin, but there was no indication of any immediate or early change in the organization.
Col. C.V. Whitney's great filly First Flight, winner of the Futurity and three other stakes last season, is the firm choice of John Blanks Campbell as the 3-year-old most likely to succeed in 1947.
POLA, Italy, Jan. 7 (Delayed)-- Pola offers the strange spectacle of a town that is being evacuated under the pressure, not of war, but of peace.

The liquor industry must reverse its present apologetic, fearful attitude toward the public and take a firm stand as a legitimate business, Representative Emanuel Celler said at the annual dinner of the Greater New York Wholesale Liquor Dealers Association, Inc., at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night.

ROME, Jan. 8--Pope Pius XII today urged members of the Roman aristocracy who gathered in the Hall of the Consistory for the traditional New Year's greetings to take an active part in public affairs, to fight anti-religious forces and to contribute to the establishment of a State based on Christian principles.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8--President Truman's first economic report appeared today to foreshadow collisions as well as the muchemphasized cooperation between the White House and Congress.

Stress Dress Brand Names In cooperation with the Brand Names Foundation, the National Association of House Dress Manufacturers, 1350 Broadway, has published a promotion manual for daytime frocks, it was announced last night at the annual banquet of the association at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

MOSCOW, Jan. 8--Russian views on the settlement of the German problem appear to have solidified around four fundamentals believed essential to a just peace for Germany. These factors probably will form the basis for Soviet policy during the forthcoming meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers here.

LONDON, Jan. 8--Bewildered by James F. Byrnes' resignation as Secretary of State and pleased but perplexed by the appointment of General Marshall, the British were trying hard tonight to grasp the full significance of a change that they consider an important world event.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 8--The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it had adopted a revised and simplified form S-1, covering the registration of securities under the Securities Act of 1933, which will become effective on April 1.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8--A program for checking inflation was submitted today to members of the retail furniture trade by Paul H. Nystrom, president of the Limited Price Variety Stores Association and Professor of Marketing, Columbia University School of Business.

MONTREAL, Jan. 8 (AP)--The Detroit Red Wings defeated the second-place Montreal Canadiens, 4-2, tonight for their third victory in seven games over Montreal this season. A crowd of 10,756 was on hand.

NANKING, Jan. 8--The triple impact of Gen. George C. Marshall's departure, his statement on the Kuomintang-Communist negotiations and the announcement that he was to be named Secretary of State has the Chinese capital's almost undivided interest today.

The first-night trail leads this evening to the Adelphi Theatre, where "a dramatic musical version" of "Street Scene" will be unfolded under the joint sponsorship of Dwight Deere Wiman and the Playwrights' Company. The curtain will rise promptly at 8:30 P.M.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8--In a gesture of national unity before the eyes of the world the Republican-dominated Senate unamimously confirmed today the nomination of General of the Army George C. Marshall to be Secretary of State.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Jan. 8 (AP)--The Christian Church must abandon class distinctions if it is to maintain "its traditional championship of human rights," a special committee of Protestant churchmen told the annual meeting of the Home Missions Council of North America tonight.
Conspicuously missing from the President's "State of the Union" message to Congress on Monday was any reference to the merchant marine.

ALBANY, Jan. 8--Introduction of bills seeking to eliminate discrimination in higher education and to raise requirements for political parties to achieve legal status promised today at the very start of the session to provide fuel for hot controversy in the Legislature.
Greater efforts to relieve the city of a damaging and growing smoke and soot nuisance were pledged yesterday by civic and business groups, a local utility and official municipal agencies.

Component branches of the theatrical industry yesterday afternoon outlined their first step at a closed meeting in the Hotel Astor to rally behind City Councilman Eugene P. Connolly's impending bill, which would "limit to some extent" the stage censorship powers of the License Commissioner.

PARIS, Jan. 8--James F. Byrnes' resignation as United States Secretary of State and the appointment of Gen. George C. Marshall to succeed him took the French Foreign Office by surprise. Officials there today reserved comment, pending receipt of further information.

Net current operating earnings of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York amounted to $18,073,753, equivalent to $20.08 a share in 1946, compared with $17,157,091, or $19.06 a share the year before, according to the annual report signed by Eugene W. Stetson, chairman of the board, and J. Luther Cleveland, president, and to be issued to stockholders today in advance of the annual meeting next Wednesday.

Trust the Broadway theatre to solve intricate problems with the greatest of ease! While Russian and American diplomats tremble over our jangled relations, two playwrights solve everything in the course of one evening by introducing a female American correspondent to a dashing Red Army officer.

Montreal Refunding Montreal has not abandoned its wish to refund dollar bonds in this market, but has given up the thought of effecting the refinancing through competitive sale, according to reports reaching the financial district yesterday.

Knopf reports that it will begin a series, under the general title "Western Americana," composed of new editions of outstanding books on California and the Far West. The aim is to make available a group of classic works of Far Western history that have long been unobtainable.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 8-- The Army basketball team successfully launched its season today by defeating Swarthmore College, 43 to 42, in a nip-and-tuck battle in the academy field house. Jim Rawers tapped in a rebound in the final seconds of the game to put the Cadets out in front.

The Boston Bruins caught up with the New York Rangers in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. Frank Boucher's Blue Shirts, winners of their two previous games by shutouts, went into reverse against the fast-skating Hub Sextet and absorbed a 3-to-1 beating.

ALBANY, Jan. 8--The text of Governor Dewey's message to the Legislature follows: In the year that lies before us we should see the completion of reconversion and the resumption of full peacetime production. If this should happily prove true our State of New York is in a position to contribute mightily and to share fully in the nation's progress.

City Fireman Wilbur Dodge, his wife Virginia, and their six children, ranging from 14-year-old Patricia to 13-day-old Virginia Ellen, were living in separate establishments yesterday after being evicted from their one-family home at 322 West 231st Street.

Corneille considered hot chocolate indispensable in writing his plays. Mme. de Maintenon used to serve it at her salons, and in the court of Louis XIV generally it was regarded not only as delicious, but chic as well. Nowadays it may have lost a bit of its fashionable quality, but it has gained a good deal in popular appeal.

WARSAW, Poland, Jan. 8--The central committee of Stanislaw Mikolajczyk's Opposition Peasant party [PSL] decided unanimously tonight to participate "actively" in the forthcoming Polish elections and to ask its supporters to boycott the polls only in the ten electoral districts where the party's lists have been Rejected.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 8-- Action on mill-manufacturers relationship matters highlighted the closing session today of the threeday meeting of the executive committee of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board at Hotel Biltmore.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8--The budget which President Truman will submit to Congress later in the week was written after the President had given stern orders to his department and bureau heads not to try to pry from Congress larger amounts than recommended for them.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 8 (AP) --An official of the Tennessee Valley Authority contended today that the Edison Electric Institute's statisticians employed "trick" calculations in concluding that the Government agency operated at an "over-all deficit" of $8,041,009 in 1946.

Flat denial that further price cuts are authorized in surplus machine tools now being sold by the War Assets Administration was issued here yesterday in an exclusive statement to THE NEW YORK TIMES by C. A. Barrett, director, metalworking division WAA, Washington, D. C. Recent reports which have caused industrial buyers to withdraw orders to await additional price cuts of 5 to 15 per cent, have been based upon misinformation, Mr. Barrett said.

The Dominion Securities Corporation, Ltd., announced here yesterday that the city of Montreal, Canada, has awarded an issue of $34,077,000 of serial debentures payable in Canadian funds and maturing from 1948 to 1969, to a syndicate headed by L. G. Beaubien Co., Ltd., and the Dominion Securities Corporation.

A sorry homecoming was in store for the New York Knickerbockers last night at the SixtyNinth Regiment Armory. Returning to the drillshed after a fivegame road trip, the local entrant in the Basketball Association of America dropped a 76-63 decision to the Toronto Huskies before 3,841 persons.

A 38-year-old thug, accused of striking a nurse on the head with a pistol yesterday, was described last night by the police as a former convict wanted by authorities as a fugitive in connection with two murders in two States.

Mayor O'Dwyer sent greetings yesterday morning from City Hall to Sir Bracewell Smith, Lord Mayor of London, over a new cable "teleprinter" system developed during the war. He received a reply within a few minutes.
LONDON, Jan. 8--With business showing some expansion, the stock markets here were firmer today after yesterday's slight dullness.

American business will contribute $100,000,000 of public service advertising dealing with current problems during 1947, T.S. Repplier, president of the Advertising Council, Inc., declared yesterday at a meeting of the group's public advisory committee in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP)-- Following are textual excerpts from President Truman's economic report to Congress today: To the Congress of the United States: As the year 1947 opens America has never been so strong or so prosperous.
The 2,400-ton Norwegian destroyer Bergen tied up at Pier 26, North River, yesterday after a stormy twelve-day trip from Oslo, during which she suffered some damage to hull and superstructure.

Mayor O'Dwyer and the Board of Estimate will not consider increasing the fare on the cityowned transit lines except as a last-ditch method of easing the city's financial position, it was indicated at City Hall yesterday.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 8--President Miguel Aleman yesterday showed a conciliatory attitude toward the oil workers' union. The workers' stoppage on Dec. 19 had given him an opportunity for a "crack down" that is generally agreed to have marked a shift in the balance of power in labor relations throughout Mexico and possibly in all Latin America.

GUAM, Jan. 8 (AP)--General Marshall sped toward Washington tonight in his special plane in high spirits but silent as to his course of action when he assumes his new responsibilities as Secretary of State.

More cargo is currently moving into the Port of New York by rail than can possibly be handled under present conditions, foreign traders said yesterday at a meeting of the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau at the Hotel Pennsylvania. A careful survey with the full cooperation of all agencies concerned with the port's operations was recommended as the first step in improving the situation.
The milk "price war" spread yesterday from the Bronx to Brooklyn and Queens, where scattered outbreaks of competitive undercutting saved housewives one and two cents a quart.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8--Completion of relief shipments to China, a $269,119,000 project, is the biggest job to be done in closing the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, Maj. Gen. Lowell W. Rooks said today in his first press conference as Director General.

Presenting his annual report in a new, condensed form, previously mailed to all stockholders in advance of the meeting, Harvey D. Gibson, president of the Manufacturers Trust Company, said at the annual meeting yesterday that its business loans during 1946 were $100,000,000 higher than in 1945.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 8 (Science Service)--Hundreds of thousands of Pacific island mosquitos, some of them potential disease carriers, have been coming to this country in tires and perhaps also in shell cases and amphibious vehicles returned from combat areas by the Army and Navy.

Alvin J. Paris was found guilty by a jury in General Sessions yesterday afternoon on both counts of the bribery indictment that charged him with having attempted to "fix" the play-off championship game between the New York Football Giants and the Chicago Bears on Dec. 15.

A further increase of 1,838,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end they amounted to 94,964,000 barrels, against 93,126,000 a week earlier and 99,393,000 on Jan. 5, 1946.

The stock market moved in a narrow range yesterday and closed mixed after moderate losses. Some of the leading industrials were able to show increases of approximately a point, but the trading pace was such that price alterations failed to reveal any true temper of the market.

The "ideal camp of tomorrow" was displayed yesterday at the twentieth anniversary celebration of the Jewish Vacation Association in the Harmonie Club, 4 East Sixtieth Street. Architectural blueprints lined the walls. A photo-mural made a vivid picture of the scale-model displayed on a table.

Fordham, making progress in its campaign to regain its pre-war status in basketball, fought off two second-half rallies by Brooklyn College to score a 58-to-52 triumph before 1,500 at Roosevelt Hall on the Kingsmen's campus last night.

One of the basic requirements for the solution of the problem of chronic alcoholism is the recognition on the part of the public that compulsive drinking is a definite disease entity for which adequate facilities for treatment and prevention must be provided, an all-day conference yesterday at the New York Academy of Medicine decided without a dissenting voice.

Gross operating income of The New York Trust Company for 1946 was $11,791,312, or $449,825 less than in 1945, John E. Bierwirth, president, reported yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders. Net operating income of $4,441,929 was $324,859 below the 1945 level, he said.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8--President Truman warned today that consumer savings had dwindled to pre-war levels and were no longer able to bolster the high demand for goods and services that would mean continued business prosperity.

PARIS, Jan. 8--The Cabinet discussed at length today the problem of wage demands of Government employes and their effect on public finances. While firm decisions were taken to aid the fight to cut prices and restore markets, the Cabinet was forced to postpone a ruling on wages until Saturday.

New capital totaling $1,000,000 is expected to be put into the business of Motty Eitingon, Inc., under an amended plan of reorganization, if negotiations under way are successful, it was made known yesterday at the meeting of creditors held by Referee Irwin Kurtz at the United States Court House.

A prize disposal pennant was awarded yesterday to the New York Regional Office of the War Assets Administration by Norman D. Cota, Philadelphia, WAA zone director for the Northeastern States, at a ceremony in the offices of Frank L. Seymour, regional director.

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 8--Federal Judge F. Ryan Duffy today denied a petition of the striking Allis-Chataiers Local 248 of the United Auto Workers, Congress of Industrial Organizations, for an injunction to block a collective bargaining election ordered by the Wisconsin Employment Relations Board.
MOSCOW, Jan. 8--Announcement of the resignation of United States Secretary of States Byrnes and the appointment of Gen. George C. Marshall as his successor was received with great interest in Moscow.

A six-inch "blind spot" on the left side of a Douglas DC-4 airplane, due to the cockpit roof support, was described officially here yesterday as a contributing cause of the collision between two Miami-bound airliners near Havre de Grace, Md., on Dec. 19.

Alice Howland, mezzo-soprano, who gave her second Times Hall recital last night, showed that she was a good program maker as well as an excellent artist. She dispensed with the classic Italian airs and the usual group in French, and confined herself to songs of three types.
ALBANY, Jan. 8--Governor Dewey asked the Legislature today to continue the State's rent control laws and to appropriate $25,000,000 more for veterans' emergency housing.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 8 (U.P.)--British police, in a pre-dawn sweep on the townships of Rishon-le-Zion and Rehoboth, south of Tel Aviv, arrested thirty-two suspected members of the militant "Black Squads" of the Irgun Zvai Leumi underground organization today.

Manila Rope Prices Raised Manila rope prices increased eleven cents yesterday. Prices paid by one large buyer jumped from 28.39 cents to 39.33 cents a pound. Buyers said when new prices were put in effect, deliveries being made to customers were called back for repricing on new invoices.

WESTFIELD, N.J., Jan. 8--Elmer Ellsworth Browning Jr., since 1937 plant-extension engineer of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, with headquarters in New York, died at his home here this morning at the age of 58.

STOCKTON, Calif., Jan. 8 (U.P.)-- Johnny Babich, 33-year-old former major league pitcher, today was named manager of the Stockton Ports of the California State Baseball League. It will be the first managerial job for Babich, who broke into organized baseball in 1932.

Charges that three of the four defendants in the Mergenthaler Linotype Company swindle case would not receive impartial treatment in a trial in the Kings County Court were made yesterday by defense lawyers in their arguments in the Brooklyn Supreme Court for a change of venue.

LONDON, Jan. 8 (AP)--A British Home Office official, told that Prof. Johan J. Smertenko planned to return to London, reiterated tonight that the American Jewish leader would be turned back from Britain if he attempted re-entry into the country.

HARTFORD, Jan. 8--James L. McConaughy, former president of Wesleyan University, was inaugurated Governor of Connecticut today and warned the General Assembly in his inaugural message that Connecticut must find new sources of revenue to avert a $13,000,000 deficit in the next two years.

BOSTON, Jan. 8 (AP)--Maurice R. Allen, Secret Service chief here, said tonight that Alfred B. Parkhurst, son of the assistant business manager of Harvard University, had admitted the theft of nearly $5,000 in veterans checks from Harvard mailboxes in the past six months.

STUTTGART, Germany, Jan. 8 --The German Council of States [Laenderrat] presented a strong appeal today to Lieut. Gen. Lucius D. Clay to help speed the return of nearly 5,000,000 German prisoners of war to their homeland.

ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 8--King Abdullah Ibn Ul-Hussein of TransJordan, on his arrival at Iskenderun today, confirmed rumors that a treaty of "friendship, brotherhood and reciprocal understanding" would be signed between his country and Turkey.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8--Elimination of labor-management strife, more equitable taxation and an increase in industrial productivity to reduce prices are among the keys to the solution of the dominant economic problems confronting the nation in 1947 and thereafter, it was declared tonight by W. Gibson Carey Jr., president of the Yale Towne Manufacturing Company.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Jan. 8-- Increasing stress was laid by leftwing circles here today on foreign connections in the alleged conspiracy to overthrow the present Hungarian Government.
The response to the thirty-fifth annual appeal for the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund conducted by THE NEW YORK TIMES neared yesterday the record set a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8--Premier Alcide de Gasperi of Italy announced at a news conference today that in his current conversations here he had received promises of wheat to tide his country over until the harvest in June.

Starting next Monday the Swedish American Line will have a passenger ship arrive here from Goeteborg every other week, it was announced yesterday. The schedule, which covers the next nine months, calls for arrivals in New York on alternate Mondays, at Pier 97, North River.

ALBANY, Jan. 8--Lee B. Mailler of Orange County, new leader of the Republican majority in the Assembly, underwent a baptism of fire today as he was required to answer Democratic attacks on Governor Dewey's annual message.

The decision of Marius Moutet, Overseas Minister, to return from IndoChina to Paris leaves the fate of the French Empire still in doubt. M. Moutet went out hopefully as an emissary of peace. He comes back disillusioned. In his opinion, though he does not close the door to negotiation, there can be no peace until French troops, guns, tanks and planes have put down the Indo-Chinese insurrection."

ROME, Jan 8 (AP)--It will be a long time before tourists board an Italian transatlantic liner for one of those champagne and masquerade ball pleasure cruises that made Italy's luxurious passenger fleet renowned before the war, and perhaps the day never will come again.

Will of the People As good an example of the genuine democratic temper as one could wish was furnished by Patrick Gordon-Walker, deputy floor leader in the House of Commons, now visiting this country.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8--President Truman sent to the Senate today a long list of nominations, Some were new, and the others formalized appointments he had announced during the congressional recess.

Edward Grant Barrow, rugged individualist who master-minded the Yankees into fourteen American League pennants and ten world championships, finally has severed all contact with the organization he helped weld into the greatest baseball empire the game has known.

The decay of morals in a neighborhood once redolent of lavender and old lace caught up yesterday with a 60-year-old woman whose memory was of better times. Mrs. Bertha Wurster Couch, daughter of the last Mayor of the old City of Brooklyn, was punched, bound with cord and robbed by a 16-yearold hoodlum who had gained her confidence by professing a real interest in the antique business Mrs. Couch runs for a living.

Governor Dewey's message to the Legislature yesterday, the first since he was returned to office for a second term, reports that the State is "in the strongest financial position in its history." The Governor is determined to keep it strong. He will resist efforts to raid post-war savings for pet projects, lest our house of government come "crashing down on the people's heads."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (U.P.)--The Congress of Industrial Organizations tonight prohibited State councils from making gifts or sending delegates to organizations other than a selected list of thirty-six groups as national headquarters speeded its anti-Communist program.

Mayor O'Dwyer and James A. Farley, former Postmaster General, joined with leaders in business and civic affairs yesterday in opening the annual campaign of the Greater New York Councils, Boy Scouts of America, for $1,000,000 in 1947.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8--Dr. Vannevar Bush, the new chief of Army and Navy scientific research, assailed today the "overexaggerated" warnings and descriptions of "push-button" warfare which some military prophets have put out for public consumption since the war ended.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 8-- Professor Norbert Wiener of Massachusetts Institute of Technology, one of the world's leading mathematicians, refused to address a symposium on calculating machinery at Harvard University today because, he said, the devices under discussion were "for war purposes."

Consolidated net earnings of A. G. Spalding Bros., Inc., for the fiscal year ended with last October, amounted to $1,469,935 after providing $164,060 for interest on the 5 per cent debentures and $1,315,531 for income taxes, Charles P. Robbins, president, reported yesterday in the annual statement to stockholders.
"The days have come and gone so fast that I find it hard to believe that fifty years have slipped by."

TOKYO, Jan. 8--The fate of Japan's silk industry now hangs in the balance. Also in the balance is the fate of the Allied program for Japanese economic rehabilitation for silk, which in one pre-war year produced $300,000,000 in foreign exchange but last year brought only $22,962,000.

International travel as a means of cementing friendship and assuring a world of peace should be encouraged through the elimination of restrictions and annoyances, Lord Hacking, British travel leader, declared here yesterday.

The City Planning Commission, at meeting held yesterday at City Hall, fixed Jan. 22 as the date for a public hearing on proposed zoning amendments intended to pave the way for suitable surroundings for the permanent home of the United Nations on the East River front between Forty-second and Forty-eighth Streets.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8--A Senate investigation into accusations that Government policy continues to "force" the settlement at 100 cents on the dollar of claims to portal-to-portal back pay on war contract work will be asked by Senator Homer Ferguson of Michigan.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: We found Dr. Howard A. Rusk's article on cerebral palsy extremely interesting. And we were surprised to note that the customary heading, "The Veteran," was omitted. We hope that this is an indication that the problems of the physically disabled will be dealt with regularly in your columns without any "armed forces" coloration.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 8--The Oro Yellowknife Gold Mines, Ltd., Toronto, Ont., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 2,000,000 shares of capital stock, $1 par value, that would be sold to the public at 60 cents a share through underwriters headed by Tellier Co. of New York.

WEEHAWKEN, N.J., Jan. 8-- Tongues of flame shot higher than the Palisades as a spectacular early morning blaze destroyed Pier 3 of the New York Central Railroad here today, and damaged the damage of about $3,000,000, was brought under control by midmorning, but flared up spasmodically through the rest of the day.

The outstanding fault of the Western powers in their administration of Germany is their failure to come to grips with the predominant problem of the re-education of the Germans, Miss Kathleen McLaugnlin, NEW YORK TIMES correspondent just returned from Germany, declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8--President Truman reported to Congress today that if the country was to continue enjoying its record prosperity through 1947, people had to get more for their money.

ALBANY, Jan. 8--Governor Dewey proposed today in his annual message to the Legislature that the State proceed with extreme caution in undertaking new financial commitments and that five so-called "emergency" taxes which have been part of New York's revenue structure for eight to twelve years be made permanent.

The piano recital presented by James Friskin last night at Town Hall was given over entirely to works by Bach. Featured on the comprehensive program was that monumental opus the "Aria with Thirty Variations," commonly known as the "Goldberg" set.

Aaron Copland's Third Symphony was played for the second time in this city by the Boston Symphony Orchestra, Dr. Koussevitzky conducting, last night in Carnegie Hall, and it was given a superlative performance. Heard for the first time by this writer, it impressed first of all by the complete sincerity and the genuinely symphonic conception of the music.

DETROIT, Jan. 8--Secretary of Commerce W. Averell Harriman said tonight that the extent to which socialization is expanded in Europe depends largely upon the international economic policies of the United States. He outlined conditions overseas in a speech at the annual dinner of the Society of Automotive Engineers here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8--Several aspects of the selection by the President of Gen. George C. Marshall as Secretary of State, including some of its history, are as follows: 1. Mr. Truman acquired his great respect for the General long prior to his assumption of the Presidency.

DOVER, Del., Jan. 8--Gov. Walter W. Bacon requested today that the Delaware Legislature give serious consideration to legislation providing for an "open shop" in this State as well as for provisions to permit workers to continue unmolested at their jobs regardless of any strike conditions.
A final resting place, perhaps, for soldiers who defended American soil from the time of the French and Indian Wars to the present has been authorized.
Small apartment houses and remodeled dwellings formed the bulk of East Side properties reported in new ownerships yesterday.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 8--The Netherland Commission General will sign its agreement with the Indonesian Republic as soon as the document is approved by the Republican "National Committee," which meets Jan. 27. A spokesman for the commission, which stopped at Singapore today en route to Batavia, said that the commission now had full powers to conclude the pact with the Indonesian Government headed by President Soekarno.

ROME, Jan. 8 -- The secession from the Socialist party of two minority groups that want Italian socialism to regain its full autonomy by drawing away from the Communists is expected at the twentyfifth Socialist party congress, which is to open here tomorrow.

Arnold Tucker, Army's brilliant quarterback, is the 1946 winner of the James E. Sullivan Memorial Trophy. This award is presented annually by the Amateur Athletic Union to "the amateur athlete who, by performance, example and good influence, did most to advance the cause of good sportsmanship."
Thousands of workers in midtown office and factory buildings had to climb to work yesterday as 500 elevator operators and other service employes struck for union agreements.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8--When President Truman's appointee as Under-Secretary of the Treasury is confirmed, the proper name of that official will be A. Lee M. Wiggins. Mr. Wiggins today asked that his name be so used.

BERLIN, Jan. 8--The British will accept the essentials of the impending United States zone decartelization law. At the same time they will begin next month some experiments in quasi-socialization of parts of the giant Ruhr steel works, it was reliably learned today.

TOKYO, Jan. 8--The establishment of a National Government for Japan by giving the Socialists equal representation within the Cabinet with the two present majority parties is today being discussed by administration leaders. A meeting has been held between Premier Shigeru Yoshida, leader of the liberal party, and former Premier Baron Kijuro Shidehara, Progressive chief, on this subject.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 8--The Egyptian flag was hoisted today over another major symbol of sixty-five years of British occupation of this country, marking one more step in the retirement of the British forces from the Nile Valley and Delta to the Suez Canal zone.

The Employment Act of 1946 placed a mandate upon the Federal Government to use all practicable means consistent with national policy "to coordinate and utilize its plans, functions and resources" for achieving the stated purpose of that Act--namely, maximum production, employment and purchasing power.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8--Rent control on accommodations for transients by hotels, motor courts and trailer camps will be removed on Feb. 15, the Office of Temporary Controls announced today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8--Corn futures, which broke 3 cents early this week, started upward on the Board of Trade today and finished 3/8 cent to 1 1/8 cents higher, January leading. There was no material pressure on the market at any time. Wheat was dull and finished 1/8 cent higher to 3/8 cent lower and oats were 1/8 to 1/2 cent higher.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9--Considerable progress has been made in the planning phases of development of rocket-assisted artillery shells, which would have incalculable effect in further revolutionizing warfare, Brig. Gen. Henry B. Sayler, Chief of Research and Development for Army Ordnance, revealed today.

The United Nations' East River site offers one of the great architectural opportunities of history. Wallace K. Harrison, just appointed as Director of Planning for the construction program, must be in a serious mood as he faces his new responsibilities. Those who know Mr. Harrison's record will not be worried about the results.

BERLIN, Jan. 9 -- All German war material in the four zones of Germany will have been disposed of or demilitarized by July 1, 1947, and the physical disarmament of Germany already is virtually complete, Maj. Gen. Robert W. Harper, director of the armed forces division of the United States Military Government, announced today.
LONDON, Jan. 9--Sir James Bisset, captain of the liner Queen Elizabeth and commodore of the Cunard White Star Fleet, has been retired, it was announced tonight.

Beginning again this year New York will have not one but its two traditional yachting seasons as in pre-war times, the summer period afloat, come next June, and the welcome mid-winter nautical excitement known as the National Motor Boat Show.

Much higher prices for hides originating in the Argentine are seen by importers and dealers here in the announcement this week that the South American Government will set high fixed prices on exports. Earlier in the week cables from Argentina stated that the Government had placed an export price of 49 3/8 cents a pound f.o.b. on frigorifico hides, but this was denied later.
For the second day in a row a midtown pawnbroker turned over to the police yesterday a man suspected as a jewelry thief. He had $25,000 worth of jewelry on his person when arrested.

Striking evidence that the potter's art is by no means confined to the making of decorative bowls and vases will be found in the exhibition of contemporary American ceramics opening today at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Large sculptures, framed enamel plaques measuring three feet square, humorous figurines, and a number of unusual utilitarian pieces lend considerable variety to the show.

DETROIT, Jan. 9--Warning against haste in enactment of anti-labor legislation George T. Christopher, treasurer of the Automobile Manufacturers Association and president of the Packard Motor Car Company, told the Society of Automotive Engineers tonight that industrial peace is through evolution, not revolution, with teamwork rather than dictatorship.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 9 (AP)-- The National Football League is advocating Federal, State and local legislation to make bribery of athletes a criminal offense, Commissioner Bert Bell declared today.
The possibility of an active smoke abatement campaign for New York City became more likely yesterday.

Dogs, cats, opossums, a leopard, a seal, rabbits, squirrels, white rats, skunks, turtles, guinea pigs, bats, frogs, lambs, turkeys, bees, goats, horses and birds were among the 267,248 animals cared for in 1946 in New York City and suburban Long Island by the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, it was reported yesterday by Alexander S. Webb, society president.

Add to the text of Elmer Rice's "Street Scene" a fresh and eloquent score by Kurt Weill and you have a musical play of magnificence and glory. Sung by a superb cast, it opened at the Adelphi last evening. Eighteen years ago Mr. Rice's ballad of a dingy side street in New York rose high above the horizon of the theatre, and it has always remained there as a cherished masterpiece.

Original illustrations by more than fifty well-known American artists were featured at the preview of the 1947 printing of "The Book of Knowledge" (published by the Grolier Society, Inc.) at the Biltmore Hotel yesterday. The exhibition, which will be open to the public today and tomorrow from 10 A. M. to 10 P. M., will move to Education Hall at the American Museum of Natural History for a month, starting Tuesday.

ALBANY, Jan. 9 -- With improved chances of success, legislators from the Bronx and Queens started a fresh campaign today to get equality of representation for their home boroughs in the Government of New York City.

CAIRO, Jan. 9--Emir Saud, heir to the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia and its vast oil resources, passed through Cairo tonight on his way to the United States for an official visit. His aim will be to consolidate friendly relations between the two countries.

Directors of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation declared yesterday a 15-cent quarterly dividend on the common stock, payable on Feb. 15. Shareholders received 10 cents each in April, July and November, last year. This is the first dividend declared by the board since the redemption on Nov. 15, 1946, of the corporation's preferred stock, which completed its refinancing under the integration requirements of the Holding Company Act.
Whether Charley Trippi, Georgia's All-American backfield star, will wear a Yankee uniform this year both on the diamond and gridiron is a matter that may be decided in a day or two.

The State of Mississippi awarded at competitive sale yesterday an issue of $5,000,000 highway bonds maturing Aug. 1 from 1964 to 1970 to a banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc. at an interest cost of 2.3658 per cent. Other bids ranged in cost to 2.41 per cent.

A ballot outlining the final offer of the tugboat operators went out yesterday to 2,800 members of Local 333, United Marine Division, International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, for acceptance or rejection. Votes are to be returned to Postoffice Box 43, Station P, New York City, before noon on Jan. 29.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9--Officials of two South American republics agreed today that Argentina did not constitute a threat to the peace of the Western Hemisphere. One of them even predicted that friendly relations would be established between the Peron Government and the United States before the end of this year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9--Arguments over the hotly-disputed question whether foremen shall be classed as employes under the National Labor Relations Act for the purpose of collective bargaining were heard by the Supreme Court today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The context of a story captioned "Sugar Curbs Stay, Anderson Asserts" appearing on Page 18 of THE NEW YORK TIMES of Dec. 28 confused my recent forecast on decontrol of sugar in 1947 with factors entirely irrelevant to my statement.

An organized band of suspected race track betting touts in recent months has been looting public telephones in the midtown district of large sums of money, it was revealed yesterday in General Sessions when one suspect had his bail fixed at $5,000 on a charge of violating Section 408 of the Penal Law by having a "false key in his possession as a burglar tool."

A pair of welterweights who are considered only about a year away from the top of their class will engage in the star bout at Madison Square Garden tonight. Tony Pellone, rugged warrior from Greenwich Village, will tackle Tony Janiro, smooth performer from Youngstown, Ohio, in a clash that is scheduled for ten rounds.

PARIS, Jan. 9--An extraordinary and gallant experiment in French politics is now drawing to a close. A week from today frail Leon Blum, who will be 75 on his next birthday, will give up the reins of Government and resign as Premier.

The 100th anniversary of the birthday of Jacob H. Schiff, banker and philanthropist who died in 1920, was commemorated yesterday in exercises held at the Straus Auditorium of the Educational Alliance, East Broadway and Jefferson Street.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 9--With "objectionable features" removed by amendment, the liquidation and dissolution program of the Engineers Public Service Company was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission as necessary to effectuate the purposes of Section 11 (b) of the Holding Company Act.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 9--One of the world's largest sugar refineries has recessed its operations for an expected two or three-week period of idleness, and resumption of work at other units has been delayed as the combined effects of the West Coast maritime strike and the walkout of 28,000 workers in the Hawaiian sugar cane industry are being felt in this area.

Walt Disney Productions had a net income of $199,602 after all charges in the fiscal year ended on Sept. 28, 1946, Roy O. Disney, president, reported to stockholders yesterday in his annual letter. This compared with $350,532 in 1945.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9--The "equal rights" amendment, providing that "equality of rights under the law shall not be denied or abridged by the United States or by any State on account of sex" was introduced today by Representative John M. Robsion, Republican, of Kentucky, and by Representative Fadjo Cravens, Democrat, of Arkansas.

This is the story of stubby, selfconfident Ernie Ayrhart and of the little cross-roads Canadian town of Campbellsford, Ont., and how $2,000,000 dug out of the frozen ground of northwestern Quebec changed the lives of both.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 9-- Greece, one of the worst sufferers of the war, is making rapid progress oward the development of an independent welfare program that will help solve her relief problems, according to an official report released here today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Jan. 4 were 687,428 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 59,461 cars or 9.5 per cent more than in the preceding week; 34,450 or 5.3 per cent more than in the corresponding week of last year and 4,030 or 0.6 per cent more than in the corresponding week of two years ago.

Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio called last night for a $3,000,000,000 to $4,000,000,000 cut in the Federal budget and temporary retention of corporation and wartime excise tax rates to allow a 20 per cent cut in personal income taxes.

Reflecting heavier sales of spot cotton in the South, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange lost early moderate gains yesterday and closed 3 points higher to 10 points lower than Wednesday's final levels.

Acting upon the suggestion of United States Attorney John F.X. McGohey, the Department of Housing and Buildings inspected yesterday five Harlem rooming houses, where the Federal Government charges more than 200 persons were crowded into seventy inadequately serviced rooms.

On the same day that President Truman submitted to Congress his first economic survey, based on the findings of his council of economic advisers, the British Government also issued a similar survey of the British economic picture. The Truman survey was issued by the President of a capitalistic country whom "Liberals" suspect of inclination to stray from the New Deal path.
MOSCOW, Jan. 9--Some idea of what is expected of Soviet playwrights and of their audiences was expressed today in a review of a new play by Vladimir Solovyov called "The Road to Victory."

Until this year, in the words of the La Follette Committee's reorganization report, Congress supervised "the world's largest enterprise without any coordination between its revenue-raising and appropriating committees." Of course every member of Congress knew that if we spent more than we took in the public debt would increase.

With a motorcycle escort clearing the way, Dr. Rudolf Nissen drove the eight miles from Manhattan Police Headquarters to Israel Zion Hospital in Brooklyn in nine minutes yesterday. There he performed an emergency heart operation on the son of a staff doctor.

MADRID, Jan. 9 (U.P)--Regulo Martinez Sanchez, a former priest and a leader in the Spanish Democratic Alliance, testified at his trial in Maria Cristina Barracks, today that the United States and British Embassies had offered moral but not material support to his organization in an anti-Franco movement.

The Western Union Telegraph Company reported yesterday that operations in the first eleven months of 1946 resulted in a deficit of $11,573,084, in contrast with a net income of $3,251,751 for the same 1945 period. About $2,100,000 of the deficit was due, according to the company's statement, to the strike early in 1946.

Domestic steel mills turned out 66,363,848 net tons of steel in 1946, which was greater than the production of any year prior to 1940, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. Output in December fell sharply to 5,700,997 tons from the November total of 6,409,675 tons.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Jan. 9--A pessimistic analysis of the situation in the Netherlands published in the conservative Elsevier's Weekblad has received serious consideration in diplomatic quarters.

Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, national Selective Service Director, paid tribute last night to 600,000 Jewish war veterans, asserting their records are "typical of America's participation in World War II."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9--During the week ended Jan. 8, member bank reserve balances increased $318,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. Additions tomember bank reserves arose from increases of $282,000,000 in Reserve Bank credit and $2,000,000 in gold stock and a decrease of $203,000,000 in money in circulation offset in party by increases of $8,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks, $10,000,000 in Treasury cash and $151,000,000 in non-member deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts.

The permissive order from the Civilian Production Administration that permits a beginning of construction on the $5,000,000 truck terminal in lower Manhattan near the Holland Tunnel is first-class news for New York City. This Port Authority project has been in blueprints for many months, awaiting the war's end and then the availability of materials.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 9-- Michael Curtiz today signed Michael North, formerly Ted North, to play the leading male role in "The Unsuspected," replacing Dana Andrews, who withdrew from the film two weeks ago because he felt that his part would be subordinate to the character role assigned to Claude Rains.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9--Former Secretary of State Cordell Hull offered his congratulations to Gen. George C. Marshall, hailing his appointment as Secretary of State and praised the services of the retiring Secretary, James F. Byrnes. The messages were sent to them from the United States Naval Hospital in Bethesda, Md., where Mr. Hull is a patient.

MUNICH, Germany, Jan. 9 -- Thirteen key officials have been removed from the Bavarian Ministry of Economics in the start of a thorough housecleaning of Nazis in the bureau. The removals will continue until the Ministry is cleared of its pro-Nazi taint, Rodulph Zorn, new Social Democratic Economics Minister, declared.

Following the 1946 pattern, the State Racing Commission announced yesterday that it had given permission for 189 days of competition at the New York tracks this season, with the meets listed in the same order and for the same number of days as last year.
Automatic Canteen Company of America--Quarter to Dec. 12; Net profit, $178,583, equal to 40 cents a share, against $136,279, or 30 cents a share for similar period of previous year.

General expenses of the Central Hanover Bank Trust Co. are likely to rise during 1947 and unless total income can be increased, operating results of the bank this year may not be as good as in 1946, William S. Gray Jr. told the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday.

The Duke and Duchess of Windsor were mobbed by 100 wounded servicemen from six hospitals yesterday at a Purple Heart Party in the Hotel Delmonico. From the moment they appeared in the doorway with Mrs. Joan Baruch, who heads these parties; Mrs. Junius S. Morgan and Mrs. Nadine Bandler of the Citizen's Committee for the Army and Navy, "the panic was on," as one sailor put it.

City Councilman Edward Rager, chairman of the Lincoln Day dinner committee of the National Republican Club, declared yesterday he was not worried by prospects of a boycott of the dinner by Republicans resentful over the invitation to Harold E. Stassen, former Governor of Minnesota, to be one of the speakers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9--Senatorial investigation into the conduct of American forces and military governments abroad, which was blocked recently by Administration strategy and action, appeared again as a possibility today.
First returns from the city-wide home safety inspection made by school children and their parents indicated yesterday that fire hazards were the chief danger factors in New York homes.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 9--Microscopic ocean bacteria with a thirtyeight-letter name may be the means of vastly expanding the world's usable oil supply, according to a report issued today by the University of California at Los Angeles.

LONDON, Jan. 9--Burmese delegates arrived in London tonight for conferences, at the invitation of Prime Minister Attlee's Labor Cabinet, that are generally expected to result in hastening the exit of Burma from the British Empire.

The annual report of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service has just been submitted to Secretary of the Interior J.A. Krug by Albert M. Day, director of the Service, and the theme of the thesis seems to be "Peace can be harder on wildlife than war."

A convertible loan of $10,000,000 by the Hughes Tool Company was part of a financing proposal adopted last night by directors of Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., Jack Frye, president of TWA, and Howard Hughes, the company's largest stockholder, announced following a meeting of TWA directors at 80 East Forty-second Street.

PARIS, Jan. 9--Just as the deflation campaign was moving into high gear, with a tremendous psychological pressure put on the public through newspapers, a slowdown strike by rotary press personnel in Paris--which became a lockout early this morning--prevented the appearance of all newspapers in the French capital today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9-- The American Red Cross announced today a goal of $60,000,000 for its 1947 fund campaign to render service to the military forces at home and abroad and to veterans and to maintain its regular peacetime operations.

Bobbs-Merrill has scheduled for early publication a biography of Gen. George C. Marshall, entitled "Marshall: Citizen Soldier," by William Frye. Mr. Frye was a Washington correspondent of the Associated Press for many years. During the war he represented the Associated Press in London and followed the troops across the Rhine.

PEIPING, China, Jan. 9--The detailed report of Gen. George C. Marshall on the internal Chinese situation, with its virtual admission of the impossibility of success in further American mediation at this time in China's civil war, is regarded in informed quarters here as bringing very much into the foreground the question of the continuation of Executive Headquarters in Peiping.

Committed to a last-ditch fight against any fare rise on the cityowned transit lines, Mayor O'Dwyer was planning yesterday an allout campaign to obtain additional State funds to help balance the city's budget for 1947-48. The first definite step in this campaign will be taken tomorrow afternoon when the Mayor and his fiscal advisers confer at Gracie Mansion with the leaders of the city's Democratic delegation in the Legislature.

Two Russian composers who are alive, and two others who have passed from this world, made the program of the PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra, with Leopold Stokowski as guest conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall. The living men were Kabalevsky and Shostakovich, whose concerto for piano and strings was played by Eugene List.

The stock market was unable yesterday to emerge from its stalemate. Modest gains scored in the morning were reduced later in the day. Trading was leisurely and price changes were virtually meaningless, although the composite rate showed a minor improvement at the close.

The first President of the Fourth Republic, to be elected in France next week, has a big historical part to play, according to Maurice Schumann, a deputy of the Departement Nord and president of the MRP, Popular Republican Movement party.

YOKOHAMA, Japan, Jan. 9-- The six months of the Allied occupation of Japan ended Dec. 31 were accomplished without a single "major" act of violence by the Japanese against occupation troops or affiliated civilians. This was announced today by the high command of the Eighth Army.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9--Evidence mounted today that Senate Republican leaders were decidedly cool toward their House colleagues' proposal for a flat 20 per cent cut in taxes on personal income below $302,000 a year.

Florence Quartararo, one of the most promising additions to the Metropolitan last season, got a chance at a major role last night and made the most of it. Singing Desdemona in Verdi's "Otello" in place of Stella Roman, who was ill, Miss Quartararo gave a performance that would have been a credit to an outstanding veteran.

DETROIT, Jan. 9 (AP)--Blasting three goals within a fifty-six-second span in the opening period the cellar-dwelling Chicago Black Hawks beat the Detroit Red Wings, 6 to 4, tonight in a National Hockey League game before 10,493 fans at Olympia.

LONDON, Jan. 9 (U.P.)--Foreign exchange dealings under the recently promulgated new system of the Bank of England will be inaugurated Jan. 13 and in some quarters talk was heard of a possible revaluation of the pound sterling in terms of the United States dollar.
