Much of the war-developed trade between Latin America and the United States should be retained in the present post-war period, George Wythe, chief American republics division of the Office of International Trade said yesterday. Speaking at the Latin American Institute, he stated that since the end of the war, as most types of goods have become more plentiful, United States exports to Latin America have increased steadily.

Attorney General Walter D. Van Riper of New Jersey moved into the Alvin Paris football-fixing case yesterday. Twenty-four hours after Paris' conviction by a jury of having attempted to fix the championship game between the New York Giants and the Chicago Bears, the New Jersey official asked District Attorney Frank S. Hogan of New York County to send him a transcript of all portions of testimony and evidence relating to New Jersey.

One scholarship winner in a family is sufficient for most people, but for the family of Louis Swerdlove of 1920 Hone Avenue, the Bronx, the cup is running over. Mr. Swerdlove and two of his three children, Robert and Charles, have just won New York State war service scholarships in the competitive examinations held Dec. 3.

DETROIT, Jan. 9--The National Association of Manufacturers sought today to intervene in the Mount Clemens Pottery Company portal to portal suit when a petition was filed in Federal District Court here asking permission to enter the case.
Skiing conditions in the North Country continue to show an appreciable improvement this weekend, with the prospects for good running the best of the infant season.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 9 --The resignation of John B. Hutson, the only United States member of the United Nations high command, was accepted today by Trygve Lie, the Secretary General, on the eve of his departure for a tour of Central America.

NANKING, China, Jan. 9--In what is regarded as prompt reaction to Gen. George C. Marshall's report on last year's KuomintangCommunist negotiations, Peng Hsueh-pei, Minister of Information, in a formal statement tonight proclaimed the Government's willingness to discuss with the Communists concrete plans for the cessation of hostilities and Government reorganization.
The thirty-fifth annual appeal for the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund conducted by THE NEW YORK TIMES came yesterday within $197.07 of the record set a year ago.

Counseling short-term caution but long-run optimism for business, Murray Shields, economist and vice president of the Bank of the Manhattan Company, said yesterday that the nation is in the midst of a great technological revolution which gives promise that new investment in productive enterprise will again be a dynamic force for economic expansion.
Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt expressed the view last night that the United Nations would not prevent a new war unless it makes more progress than it has to date.

STUTTGART, Germany, Jan. 8 --Although United States policy in Germany is to delegate increasing authority to the Germans, neither German leaders nor United States officials are certain to what extent this authority may be assumed, Erich Rossmann, Secretary General of the new Council of States, declared today.

ALTHOUGH No. 10 Downing Street seems likely to remain a famous London address for a somewhat longer time, No. 10 Dulcimer Street is going to be famous for a while, too. That was where Mrs. Vizzard kept her boarding house. It was hardly a fashionable neighborhood, being unfortunately south of the river and more shabby than genteel, but Mrs. Vizzard couldn't help that.

The appointment of Gen. George C. Marshall as Secretary of State should facilitate the settlement of the problem of displaced Jews in Europe and the Palestine question, according to Bartley C. Crum, San Francisco attorney and an American member of the recent AngloAmerican Committee of Inquiry on Palestine.

Openings of blanket lines for the 1947 season indicate a price rise for all wool numbers and some wool, rayon mixtures, it was learned yesterday. An average increase of 5 per cent in the prices of North Star all wool blankets for delivery through June was announced by Harold J. Leydon, vice president of the North Star Woolen Company.

Asserting that the various moves to bring about a change in the leadership of Tammany had become a farce, Harold R. Moskovit, State chairman of the Affiliated Young Democrats, proposed yesterday that the reorganization of Tammany and the election of a new leader be postponed until after the primary elections next September.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9--On the eve of President Truman's Budget Message to Congress, a measure was prepared for introduction in the House tomorrow to pave the way for streamlining the Executive Branch of the Government and carry out a major Republican campaign pledge to cut Federal expenses to the bone.

Among coat and suit buyers in the market yesterday were many who were placing their first orders for spring merchandise, according to trade observers. Firmer positions taken by specialty shops in buying for the full season was an encouraging sign, it was stated.

Lending for commercial, industrial and agricultural purposes by the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System was comparatively steady in the week ended on Wednesday, rising $5,000,000 to a total of $3,781,000,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9--While Congress is pondering whether it can frame a statute acceptable to a Supreme Court majority that will retroactively demolish the ground on which most of the current portal-to-portal suits are based, lawyers think a judicial approach should first be made.

One of seven prisoners cleaning a ground-floor visitors' room in Bronx County Jail, at 653 River Avenue, escaped yesterday. He got out through an unlocked door leading into an areaway between the prison and a fifteen-foot picket fence surrounding the building.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9--For the first time in American history the planning of public works in full technical detail has been taking place on a country-wide scale during a period of prosperity and near-peak employment, the Federal Works Agency stated today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP)-- Forty-three former and 133 incumbent members of the House have applied for pensions under the Congressional reorganization act.

Action on the naming of replacements for vacancies in the Consistory of the Collegiate Reformed Church of New York City was postponed until next month at a meeting last night of twenty-two members of the Consistory at St. Nicholas Church, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 9--Communists were accused today by Wellington Koo, Chinese Ambassador to the United States, of standing athwart a dream of national unity in China.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The Republican leaders in the House have formed a stern line of authority along which all prospective labor legislation must pass the most critical examination and they probably will allow only a single emergency bill to reach the floor.

Montreal in Sight of Goal Completion by spring of the $200,000,000 bond-refunding program which Montreal set in motion last year now appears probable to bond underwriters. With yesterday's oversubscription of a $34,077,000 issue of refunding bonds, payable in Canadian funds, the Canadian city is near the halfway mark, having disposed of $56,000,000 of like debentures last summer.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP)-- Chairman Alexander Wiley of the Senate Judiciary Committee said today that he had told Attorney General Tom Clark that "I will do everything I can to reject any more New Deal appointments to the Federal judiciary."

For the first time since 1939, two overtime periods were required to decide a college basketball game at Madison Square Garden last night. Involved in the feverish struggle were New York University and Duke, and Howard Cann's well-conditioned Violet quintet prevailed, 64--61.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9 -- January wheat and corn advanced around 2 cents a bushel in the early trading today on the Board of Trade as the result of buying attributed to cash interests, commission houses and professional traders.

BOSTON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Diaries commenting on the "eligible daughters" of socially prominent Eastern families were being checked by police tonight after their writer, an ex-Harvard student, was held in $25,000 bail on charges of robbing Harvard mail boxes of veterans' checks.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 9--Joseph S.Fay, vice president of the International Union of Operating and Hoisting Engineers, AFL, and business agent of Local 825 of this city, went on trial today before a jury and Judge Thomas F. Meaney in Federal court on a three-count indictment charging he failed to pay $137,548 income taxes for the years 1940 to 1942, inclusive.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals here ruled yesterday that the acquisition of common stock through the conversion of preferred stock represents an "initial purchase," and that profits on stock so acquired are illegal when made within six months by persons owning more than 10 per cent of the stock.

We daily consume about five and a half pounds of food and water per person, but our consumption of air is about twenty-five pounds a day. It is not surprising then that impure air is inimical to health. Several pre-war but still valid studies of air pollution in New York City discuss this problem of smoke and its relation to health.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is hard to believe that you and your correspondent in the Jan. 5 issue of THE TIMES are serious in contention that universal military training would help to teach the "democratic ideal of tolerance" or be a "characterbuilding process."

A.F. Guckenberger, executive secretary of the New York State Food Merchants Association, called yesterday on the Government and all elements of the food trade for all-out joint support of an intensive sales promotion campaign next month for frozen foods.
CORAL, GABLES, Fla., Jan. 9 (AP)--Ted Atkinson, the nation's top rider last year with 233 victories, escaped injury in a spill in the seventh race at Tropical Park today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9--Justices of the Supreme Court showed a lively interest today in the argument of a case in which three Texas newspaper men appealed their conviction and jail sentences for contempt following their comments on a trial before a county judge.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 9 (AP)--Maj. Gen. George S. Gibbs, United States Army, retired, and vice president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, died tonight at Pratt General Hospital. His age was 71.

THE dictionary definitions of ideals and idealism are a trifle on the fuzzy side. So is most thinking along those same general lines. The National Collegiate Athletic Association, the parent body in sport for virtually every college in the land, has concluded its annual convention with the adoption of a "purity code" that will be written into its constitution for adoption next year.

LONDON, Jan. 9 -- The prospects for success of the Moscow meeting of the Big Four Foreign Ministers in March are believed by the British Government to be perceptibly brighter as a result of the recent improvement in AngloSoviet relations.

GANDER, Nfld., Jan. 7 (Delayed) --Night and day for the past three weeks, in good weather and bad, pilots of trans-Atlantic airliners in tests have been setting wheels down onto the icy, snowbanked runways of Gander Airport after using for the entire descent the war-developed radar landing system known as ground-controlled approach.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 9-- In his annual report to the university's 51,000 alumni today President Charles Seymour of Yale advocated an increase in the number of graduate fellowships with a greater financial attraction to overcome the shortage of faculty personnel among the country's colleges and universities.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 --The situation of the twenty domestic commercial airlines today, sixteen months after V-J Day, might be told in a short, short story thus: Net revenue from operations, 1946: $4,788,317. Net revenue from operations, 1945: $42,398,691.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 9--Almost unnoticed in the tumult of political events, Arthur Henderson, Under-Secretary of State for India, has arrived in New Delhi. He is to take up the question of terms under which the Indian Government services--including the famed Indian Civil Service--will be terminated.

Wholesalers reported yesterday that supplies of many perishable foods are smaller this week-end than last. Fortunately for the women who do their major marketing today and tomorrow, the commodities that have become less available have not risen in price in all instances.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The pamphlet recently issued by the Department of State as Publication No. 2630, under the title "United States Economic Policy Toward Germany," and announced in the newspapers as a review of the first year of occupation, is extremely disappointing.
WARSAW, Poland, Jan. 9--The Polish Government made no comment today on the United States note, the third from the State Department about the elections since last August.
LONDON, Jan. 9--Most sections of the stock markets were firm today. Some reinvestment demand was in evidence and business generally was slightly heavier.

LONDON, Jan. 9 (AP)--Authoritative sources said tonight that the British Cabinet had decided to give the problem of the German peace treaty priority over Palestine, amid rumors that the Palestine situation would be eased by a sixty-day suspension of violence there.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9--The new Congress will probably act at this session, it was indicated today, to restore to veterans the old-age and survivor benefits under the Social Security Act which many men forfeited by military service.

DETROIT, Jan. 9--Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, in a letter to Henry A. Wallace, editor of the New Republic, has accused that publication of inaccurate reporting in connection with the union's pay increase policy.
ROME, Jan. 9--The threat of a split in the Socialist party over a fusion with the Communists receded somewhat today as the twentyfifth Socialist Party Congress opened.

OSLO, Norway, Friday, Jan. 10 --The Russian request for military bases on Spitsbergen is not yet known to the Norwegian public. The newspapers learned about it late last night and tried desperately to get confirmation from the Foreign Office, where no one, however, wanted to make a statement.

Accessories and tricks to increase their versatility and fashion importance were presented yesterday in a fashion show at the Waldorf -Astoria. Featured were such ideas as eighteen-inch silk squares tied in pairs around the neck, or, singly, wound around the wrist with a simple, long-sleeved dress.

Rayon yarn and staple producers in the United States will have a production capacity of 1,120,000,000 pounds by the end of 1948, a 26 per cent increase over present operating capacity, it was predicted in a survey released yesterday by the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9--There is every indication that the advance of productive efficiency in manufacturing is being resumed and that the rise in productivity will be unusually rapid during the coming few years, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported in a special study published today.
Raging storms across the Atlantic were battering shipping and disrupting schedules yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9--The Agriculture Department, opening hearings today on the possibility of lowering milk prices in six northeastern metropolitan milk sheds for the rest of January, excluded from consideration the butter-based pricing formula which recently caused "price rigging" charges in New York.

PARIS, Jan. 9 (AP)--Dispatches from Hanoi said tonight that the three-weeks' siege of the capital of Indo-China by an estimated 10,000 Viet Nam Nationalists had been lifted by French military successes of the past few days.

A $3,000,000 corporation that will sponsor a wide variety of activities intended to improve agricultural production in Brazil and other countries has been established by Nelson A. Rockefeller and four other sons of John D. Rockefeller Jr.
Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, CIO, took the long-standing intra-union fight to the rank and file yesterday.

Harder Than It Looks Pictures of Mayor O'Dwyer in the newspapers are pleasant to look at. The Mayor is in the up-to-date phrase, photogenic, or what we of the older generation and vocabulary would call a fine figure of a man.

A tremendous gain in the cooperative movement in Sweden, which also is reflected in other European countries since the war, is causing serious concern to Swedish industrialists, Bjarne Asper, export manager, Johns-Manville International Corporation, said yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 9--Hundreds of thousands of European Jews must now recognize the fact that they must stay in the countries where they now are domiciled, Dr. Max Gottschalk, director of the Foreign Affairs Department of the American Jewish Committee, said at a press conference today.

ABOARD MOUNT OLYMPUS, in the Ross Sea Icepack, Jan. 9 (AP) --The Eastern Task Group, from which nine airmen have been missing since Dec. 30, still was having bad weather, said a report today from the seaplane tender Pine Island.

RARITAN, N.J., Jan. 9 (AP)--A memorial in the form of a heroic bronze statue will be erected by the John Basilone Post 280, American Legion, in honor of Sergeant Basilone, the Marine Corps winner of the Medal of Honor, who fell on Iwo.

The current shortage of 23,000 boxcars per day confronts rail shippers with the worst situation in more than twenty years, Warren C. Kendall, chairman, car service division, Association of American Railroads, declared here yesterday. During a conference at the twenty-third annual meeting of the Atlantic States Shippers Advisory Board at the Hotel Biltmore, Mr. Kendall said that greater availability of cars is expected later this month.

At 8 o'clock this evening the curtain will rise on the week's fourth opening, "Finian's Rainbow," at the Forty-sixth Street. A word to sagacious first nighters should be more than sufficient. On the basis of a rousing Philadelphia welcome, the show already is being advertised locally as a "completely captivating new musical."

Cinders of White Lawn, a black Persian male cat with copper eyes, as judged last night the best cat in the forty-fifth annual championship show of the Atlantic Cat Club. During the two-day show held at the Hotel Belvedere, 142 feline pets were exhibited and 2,500 fanciers attended.

Advertising in all New York newspapers for 1946 aggregated 126,966,808 lines, compared with 98,565,720 in 1945, or a gain of 28.81 per cent, according to a compilation of Media Records figures. All classifications showed gains, with automotive up 49.71 per cent; classified, 32.39 per cent; general, 30.79 per cent; retail, 27.27 per cent, and financial, 22.10 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9--General agreement has been reached by the preparatory commission of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization on the formation of a World Food Council with executive powers, it was learned today.

Spurred by the success of their comrades throughout eastern. Europe, the Communists in Hungary have apparently embarked on a desperate campaign to seize control of that country before the Russian occupation army evacuates it under the new peace treaty scheduled to be signed soon.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The United States in a note delivered today by Ambassador Arthur Bliss Lane in Warsaw warned Poland that "the continuation of the present policy of suppression, coercion, and intimidation as applied to political opposition in Poland constitutes a violation of the letter as well as the spirit of the Yalta and Potsdam agreements."

Airy delicacy and femininity characterized the spring collection of Walter Florell shown yesterday at 29 East Fifty-third Street. His themes were varied; however, the important news of the collection was his "Tilt," or forward, hats.

Postponement of some veterans' housing construction at colleges and universities in this area, pending further Congressional appropriation, was forecast here yesterday by John A. Kervick, regional director of the Federal Public Housing Authority.

The first major upset in the New York State squash racquets singles championship, now in progress at the New York Athletic Club, came yesterday in the second round when H.T. Waters of the Yale Club eliminated J.J. Smith of the Seventh Regiment, the No. 4 seeded player.

Harold A. Segur of Worcester, Mass., who has filed a claim that he is the son and heir of the late Mabel Seymour Greer, Park Avenue matron, and entitled to her $500,000 estate, will be required to submit proof of his relationship in answer to a motion to be heard this morning by Surrogate William T. Collins.

BOSTON, Jan. 9--Boston operagoers are sorry to hear that Lauritz Melchior, Metropolitan tenor, has decided not to sing in opera here again, but are comforted that he intends to keep an engagement to give a concert at Symphony Hall on Saturday night.

Because of the excessive load on the psychiatric service at Bellevue Hospital every effort will be made to open by Feb. 1 several foors of the seven-story psychiatric pavilion of Kings County Hospital in Brooklyn, Dr. Edward M. Bernecker, Commissioner of Hospitals, said yesterday.

Black market adoption practices will flourish as long as there is a lack of sufficient accredited social agencies to help unwed mothers place their children in the homes of suitable childless couples, Miss Dorothea P. Coe, director and executive secretary of the SpenceChapin Adoption Service, declared yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 9 -- The United Nations Security Council accepted tonight the General Assembly's mandate for world disarmament but ran into a stiff Russian-American dispute on just how it should be carried out.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Organized labor's counter-offensive against a tide of restrictive legislation was pressed today.

Authority to issue administrative directives of a kind that would have prevented the present suits for retroactive portal-toportal pay was asked of the Eightieth Congress yesterday by L. Metcalfe Walling, administrator of the Fair Labor Standards Act.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (U.P.)-- The United States in effect has rejected a French "protest" against a recent deal among four American oil companies in Saudi Arabia, a State Department spokesman disclosed tonight.

ALBANY, Jan. 9 -- Additional taxing powers being sought by upState cities and counties may give New York City power to impose a number of additional special levies such as a payroll tax, an automobile use tax and a billboard tax, it developed today.

Delinquents are not born that way, but if neglected as children, can soon grow into major community problems, Parole Commissioner Samuel J. Battle told the Harlem Y.M.C.A. board of directors and an audience last night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--President Truman's budget message proposed today a $3,000,000 appropriation to adminster his plan to minimize industrial strife and a $3,000,000 increase in the National Labor Relations Board allocation to enable it to keep abreast of its work.
President Truman recommended today the liquidation of five Goveminent corporations and return to the Treasury of $379,000,000 in funds of other corporations.

TOKYO, Jan. 10--Under the joint impacts of the Pauley reparations plan and the recently announced purges, Japan's administrative and business classes are falling out of love with the occupation. Marked changes have been noticeable in the past two months.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--Brig. Gen. William H. Draper Jr. expressed hope today that economic unity and the end of the present partition of Germany might be effected "before too long."

A campaign whose goal suggests by its size something of the magnitude of the human problems left in war's aftermath is now getting under way. The United Jewish Appeal seeks $170,000,000 in 1947, under the general chairmanship of Henry Morgenthau Jr., in what is described as the largest voluntary relief campaign in the nation's history.

The President's picture of the Government's financial prospects for the coming year is certain to create a genuine sense of disappointment which will by no means be confined to the superoptimists in and out of Congress.

The New York City Housing Authority awarded yesterday $8,011,000 of temporary loan notes dated Jan. 31 and due on Aug. 5 at an interest cost of 0.83 per cent to bidders as follows: To Chemical Bank and Trust Company, $7,011,000; to Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, $1,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--The National Association of Manufacturers announced today intervention as "a friend of the court" in the suit for retroactive pay for portal-to-portal time against the Mount Clemens Pottery Company.
PEIPING, Jan. 10 (AP)--China will open formal negotiations with Russia for the return of Dairen, Manchurian port, to Chinese authority "in the near future," Gen. Hsiung Shih-hui announced today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--The National Labor Relations Board announced today that it had ruled unanimously on the issue of foremen's organizing for the first time since James J. Reynolds Jr. became a member of the three-man board.

Buried under tons of debris when the third floor of a loft building collapsed during a fire early yesterday in the financial district, four firemen were rescued after being trapped for an hour. All were removed to Beekman Hospital, one in a serious condition.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Jan. 10 (AP) --The United State rapidly is becoming the "milkshed of the world," D. T. Carlson of Willmar, Minn., president at the American Dairy Association, observed today.

WARSAW, Poland, Jan. 10--The British Ambassador Victor F. W. Cavendish-Bentinck was named as the recipient from the Polish underground of unidentified "military and state secrets" in the elaborately staged opening today of the treason trial of Count Xavier Grocholski and three other Poles.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--Senator Joseph H. Ball, Republican, of Minnesota, proposed today a prohibition on industry-wide bargaining by cutting off the authority of international unions over their local unions. The effect, he said, would be the prevention of industry-wide strikes.

Dr. Harry S. Rogers, president of Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute, won yesterday the gold medal of the Downtown Brooklyn Association, which is awarded annually to the citizen who has rendered "the most distinguished service for Brooklyn."
A record was set yesterday by contributors answering the thirtyfifth annual appeal for the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund conducted by the THE NEW YORK TIMES.

PARIS, Jan. 10--Addressing himself to the country in a national broadcast, Premier Leon Blum tonight announced provisional salary increases for State employes, which he asked them to accept in the interest of national salvation.

The wholesale price of butter here dropped yesterday to the lowest point in five months and retail cuts of 2 or 3 cents a pound were promised for today. This decline indicated a decrease of at least 44 cents a hundred pounds in the return farmers will receive for their February milk.

Reactionary tendencies in the stock market, accompanied by a slump in the major commodities and an enlargement of selling, reduced prices yesterday on the Stock Exchange from fractions to approximately 2 points. Although the brunt of the pressure appeared in the forenoon, no serious rebound took place after the contents of President Truman's budget message appeared on the news ticker.
New Jersey's three tracks were allotted a total of 120 racing days in 1947 by the State Racing Commission today, with Atlantic City receiving the only split season.

NANKING, Jan. 10 (U.P.)--Even as Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's spokesman said the Government was willing to resume peace negotiations, Nationalist and Communist troops were locked in battles in Northern Kiangsu and Hopeh provinces, military sources said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--The National Labor Relations Board announced today that it had ruled unanimously on the issue of foremen's organizing for the first time since James J. Reynolds Jr. became a member of the three-man board.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--A demand that New York milk prices be brought down by the Department of Agriculture was made at the milk price hearings here today by Philadelphia distributors who claimed that they were adversely affected under the Federal pricing formula by recent New York "market rigging."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--Some key quotations from President Truman's Budget Message to Congress follow: SPENDING Expenditures under existing and proposed legislation are estimated at $37,500,000,000 and revenues under existing tax laws at $37,700,000,000, leaving a very slight margin of surplus.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 --Administrations of twenty-eight States set an example for the Federal Government today by showing a record-breaking financial reserve accumulated in the twelve months ended June 30, 1946.

Western Air Lines yesterday announced that it had amended its registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering 1,200,000 shares of capital stock with a disclosure of plans for extending its network of routes to link Minneapolis and St. Paul and Rochester.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Jan. 10 --Post-war innovations designed to make the lot of the nation's housewives more appealing and less strenuous continue at flood tide, according to a survey of home appliances displayed at the housewares show which closed a six-day exhibition at Convention Hall here today.

Olive MIddleton, English soprano, who has sung at Covent Garden under Sir Thomas Beecham principally in Mozart operas and has appeared with the Halle Orchestra in Manchester, gave a recital at Town Hall yesterday afternoon, singing numbers by Bach, Beethoven, Orczy, Faure, Chausson, Granados, Barbini, Barber and Bax.

Spokesmen for some stockholders of the Pere Marquette Railway Company urged the Interstate Commerce Commission today to reject the plan to merge that line with the Chesapeake Ohio through an exchange of securities. The plan has been approved by an examiner for the commission and final action is now up to that body.

Last night's opening of the first post-war National Motor Boat Show after a six-year lapse gave every indication that a nation hungry for peace had thousands of its people hungry also for the relaxation and pleasures of boats. Somewhere in the neighborhood of 25,000 jammed their way into Grand Central Palace and Show Manager Ira Hand was willing to surmise that it might be a record.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 10--Jamal el Husseini, acting chairman of the Arab Higher Executive, indicated today that the Palestinian Arabs would accept the new invitation from the British Government to name delegates for the conference on Palestine scheduled to be resumed in London on Jan. 21.

LONDON, Jan. 10--Plans for the meeting of the Foreign Ministers' Deputies in London next Tuesday are nearly complete. Ernest Bevin, British Foreign Secretary, will open the sessions with an address of welcome.

The most disappointing and disturbing element in the transit picture is the Mayor's timidity on the fare problem. We were already paying out of taxes a $57,000,000 annual deficit on the transit system for debt service on subway bonds. Now we have added to that something more than $18,500,000 in operating costs because of the receipt wage increases and changes in working conditions.

Cash payments of $180,000 were made to Joseph S. Fay, vice president of the International Operating Engineers Union and business agent. of Local 825, AFL, during 1940, 1941 and 1942 by contractors to take care of "labor relations," Government witnesses testified today.

After an absence of six years, during which she toured England, the Netherlands, Belgium, France and South America, Ruth Draper returns to the local scene tomorrow night at the Empire Theatre, where she will offer a program of characterizations and impressions.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--The Army and Navy stood by silently today as President Truman sent to Congress a budget calling for reductions of more than $3,400,000,000 in national defense expenditures.

BOSTON, Jan. 10 (AP)--The Boston Celtics broke a 59-59 tie in the last two minutes tonight to vanquish the New York Knickerbockers 66-62 in a Basketball Association of America game. Through the last five minutes most of the 3,250 fans stood and cheered the cellar occupants as they defeated the second place New Yorkers for the first time in three starts.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10 (AP)--The Association of Western Railway Executives announced today that new lower rate schedules for shipment of steel from Geneva, Utah, to the West Coast have been agreed upon by four rail carriers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--Frequency modulation has become associated in the minds of many time buyers in agencies with "long hair" music which gets low Hooper ratings, it was revealed here today by Hugh D. Lavery of McCannErickson, Inc.

A 16-year-old law-breaker with a record of three escapes from reformatories since the age of 12 staged a pre-dawn break yesterday from Youth House, delinquents' detention home at 331 East Twelfth Street. Last night he was still at large, the fourteenth inmate of New York institutions to have broken loose in eight days.

The $3,000,000 International Basic Economy Corporation established by five sons of John D. Rockefeller Jr. and their associates, to further agricultural development in Brazil' and other countries, is a practical implementation of the good neighbor policy.

Stockholders of three Southern cement companies have been notified of special meetings to be held next month to vote on a proposal to consolidate the companies in a new organization to be known as the General Portland Cement Company, it was announced yesterday.

The National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, 120 Broadway, was forced by last year's polio epidemic to use $1,500,000 of its research funds in the emergency, it was revealed yesterday by Basil O'Connor, president of the foundation.

The national council of the National Maritime Union, CIO, ended its week-long series of meetings yesterday without resolving several questions that have threatened the unity of the union governing body.

A crowded program for the entertainment of Prime Minister Alcide De Gasperi of Italy has been arranged for the two days of his official visit to this city, it was announced yesterday by Luigi Nardi, Italian Consul General here.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--President Truman formally submitted to Congress today his nomination of Warren R. Austin as United States representative on the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP)-- The report on Pacific island bases made public today by the House Military Affairs subcommittee of the Seventy-ninth Congress, contained but a single reference to the United Nations, saying merely that "many matters will be settled on an international plane" by that organization.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--James F. Byrnes said at the White House today that he would remain as Secretary of State until his successor, Gen. George C. Marshall, arrived and was prepared to take over, but that he would leave office "the minute my successor has qualified."

Sidney Foster gave a piano recital last night at Carnegie Hall that firmly established him as an artist of high rank. The youthful musician has made rapid strides forward in his work. His performances at this latest appearance disclosed a marked advance in all respects, and often reached pronounced heights, from the interpretive, as well as the purely virtuosic standpoint.

BALTIMORE, Md., Jan. 10-- Georges Pierre Lavalley, Mayor of the devastated Norman town of St. Lo, where the Twenty-ninth Dir vision won one of its greatest victories, arrived here this afternoon to participate in Baltimore's "Saint Lo's Day" festivities. These are part of a campaign to raise $100,000 for the construction of a hospital wing in Saint Lo.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--The federal Government will pour 3,510,000,000, or about one-tenth of its total expenditures in the fiscal year 1948, into its world-wide program of relief, aid and reconstruction, if the Congress approves in toto the recommendations made today by President Truman.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--The State Department made clear today its concern over the Soviet demands on Norway for military bases in Spitsbergen. It declared that the United States had a direct interest, obligations and rights as an original signatory of the treaty of 1920 through which the powers consented to Norwegian sovereignty over the archipelago.

Asserting that management in most companies has shown little more than talk about lowering distribution costs, Richard D. Crisp, sales analyst of S. C. Johnson Son, Racine, Wis., said yesterday marketing costs will have to be reduced if business "is to avoid the red ink that is nearer than we think."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--The Public Health Service stated today that infant mortality had dropped to the lowest point in American history and appeared to be declining further.

Two books on Russia, one a study of the Soviet system and the other a history of one of its states, have been scheduled by two concerns. Macmillan will publish on Tuesday "The Soviet Impact on the Western World," by Edward Hallett Carr, an analysis of how Russian methods in foreign trade, propaganda, and other fields have been reflected in Western nations.

RUTLAND, Vt., Jan. 10--The waxing hut of Pico Peak, one of North America's most diversified skilands, was a busy haven tonight as a galaxy of women stars, including nine of international experience, were polishing hickory runners for the opening of the revived United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association's combined downhill-slalom championships this week-end.
COLLEGE PARK, Md., Jan. 10 (AP)--Old T formation master Glark Shaughnessy resigned today as head football coach at the University of Maryland.
ATHENS, Jan. 10 (U.P.)--Turkey has closed the Greek frontier to prevent fleeing guerrillas from crossing her border, the Greek Foreign Ministry said tonight.

A man who withheld his identity telephoned the District Attorney's office yesterday and warned that if Alvin J. Paris, convicted wouldbe fixer of the recent Giants-Bears professional football championship game, "squealed" on anybody in the conspircay "he'll be taken care of in the Big House," obviously meaning Sing Sing.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 10-- A device by which electrons draw numbers on the surfaces of cathode-ray tubes was demonstrated before prominent mathematicians today by Harrison W. Fuller, 21-year-old research assistant at the Harvard Computation Laboratory.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Jan. 10 --Five administrative divisions of the United Nations will move Monday from Rockefeller Center to the Empire State Building to consolidate their downtown offices, officials announced today.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 10--The end of Gen. George C. Marshall's mission to China marks the beginning of an uncertain political year. The National Government, barring a miraculous end of the civil war, swift improvement in the military situation or further aid from abroad, will be fighting a war within a war to keep the economic machine functioning smoothly enough to avoid social unrest.
TRENTON, N. J., Jan. 10 (AP)-- Vice Chancellor Wilfred H. Jayne ruled today that a State court is without power to issue' a temporary injunction in a matter involving a national bank.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP)-- Henry A. Wallace expressed the opinion tonight that the United States or Great Britain "would use the atomic bomb against Russia in an aggressive way under certain conditions."

Immediately after the trial landing of a Lockheed Constellation plane at Floyd Bennett Field yesterday Pan American Airways announced at La Guardia Field that it would begin operations at the Brooklyn airport in February.
MOSCOW, Jan. 10 (AP)--Internationalization of the Panama and Suez Canals was advocated today by the New Times, weekly Soviet foreign affairs publication.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--A permanent American hold on the island areas of the Pacific wrested at arms from the Japanese, with provision for civil administration and for the spread of the English language among the natives, was recommended today to Congress.

Members of the American Walker Cup team that will go abroad to play the British in the first post-war renewal of the contest are to be named today when the United States Golf Association holds its annual meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Rumors at Police Headquarters that Michael A. Lyons and Cornelius O'Leary, third and fourth deputy police commissioners, respectively, had signified their intention to resign were unconfirmed last night.

President Truman made the following statement to a news seminar which he held Wednesday to discuss his budget message: The budget which I am transmitting to Congress is balanced. If the estimates are realised, the budget will be in balance for the first time since 1930--eighteen years.

(AP)--Despite an early threat of rain which later developed into intermittent showers, a crowd of 11,160 turned out to see Joseph J. Kelly's Chancegain capture the featured mile-and-a-furlong Glenloth Purse at Tropical Park today.

--With Australia abstaining, the United Nations Security Council voted, 10 to 0, today to assume responsibility for guaranteeing the integrity and independence of the Free Territory of Trieste. The Council agreed also to shoulder other duties placed on it under the permanent statute for Trieste.

STUTTGART, Germany, Jan. 10 --According to a source described as "reliable" the French Government has quietly been stripping large quantities of industrial machinery in its zone and transporting them to the Saar or Alsace in France. The machinery, which does not include items listed for reparations, is being removed in much the same manner as employed by the Russians in their zone, the reports said.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 10-- With industrial peace hinging on the outcome, management and labor must develop wage policies and negotiate agreements which are "compatible with the concepts of wage stabilization and industrial progress," Dr. George W. Taylor, former chairman of the National War Labor Board, declared here today.

ITHACA, N. Y., Jan. 10--Appointment of George K. (Lefty) James as head football coach was announced tonight by President Edmund Ezra Day of Cornell University. James succeeds Edward C. McKeever, who resigned last November. Selection of James was made after about sixty candidates for the job had been interviewed.

Fears of further Government curbs on speculation in cotton futures and buyers' resistance to high-price cotton goods brought in heavy selling yesterday in the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange, and final prices were 100 to 127 points net lower on active months.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--Railroad engineers hardly will be able to run their trains into open switches if there is general adoption of the track switch position indicator on which Patent 2,414,079 was issued this week to Theodore R. White of Brooklyn, N. Y., as one of the 404 granted by the United States Patent Office.

The American Assistant SecretaryGeneral of the United Natioas, Mr. John B. Hutson, has resigned after less than ten months' service. Mr. Hutson will leave with assurances from Secretary - General Lie that he has "performed a highly important service."

PARIS, Jan. 10--Prof. Johan J. Smertenko, vice president of the American League for a Free Palestine, which openly supports the Palestine underground movement, announced today he would leave for London on Wednesday in defiance of the British Government. It has informed him that he will be excluded from the country.

Storage stocks of frozen fruits are at an all-time high while industrial users who normally take a large part of the supply are producing at an all-time low, Joseph A. Raphael, president, New York Preservers Association, stated yesterday.

BOSTON, Jan. 10--Producers must lose no time in rebuilding producer-consumer good will, Dr. Glenn N. Merry, professor of marketing at New York University, told the opening session of the eighth annual New England salesmanagement conference today.

The training of pediatricians in psychiatry might succeed in preventing the development of neuroses in a large proportion of the adult population. Dr. Milton Senn, associate attending pediatrician of the New York Hospital, told members of the Women's City Club yesterday at the Hotel New Weston.

DETROIT, Jan. 10--Liquid fuel made from coal, natural gas and oil shale has proved its efficacy in the diesel engines of Navy war equipment, Capt. W. C. Latrobe of the Bureau of Ships, Navy Department, told the closing session of the meeting of the society of automotive engineers here today.

Taxpayers are facing another deadline next Wednesday. It is Jan. 15, the day when the fourth and final Installment on the 1946 estimated income tax is due. It is also the date when an amended estimate may be filed to correct past erroneous estimates, thereby avoiding a penalty for underestimating taxes.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 10--To facilitate the American Power Light Company's proposal to retire its preferred stocks, the Texas Electric Service Company and the Dallas Power and Light Company, subsidiaries of the Texas Utilities Company, applied today to the Securities and Exchange Commission for permission to amend their charters.
To his twelve victories in an unblemished 1946 ring campaign, Tony Janiro, promising Youngstown town (Ohio) welterweight, last night added his first of 1947, perhaps his greatest triumph.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP)-- The Department of Agriculture said today that mid-winter conditions affecting 1947 crops are fully as promising as those preceding any recent record crop years.

Dr. Robert R. Williams, internationally known chemist, took issue last night with some of the critics of vitamin uses by the public, in an address after the presentation to him of the Perkin Medal at a large gathering of chemists at the Hotel Commodore.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 10--The post-war Government of Italy through Premier Alcide de Gasperi, warned tonight that unless adequate aid were not tendered al once to that country, the "tragic heritage" of the war, there would become a "chronic and incurable disturbance."

Pearl Lusk, 19 years old, who on New, Year's Eve unwittingly snot Miss Olga Trapani on the BMT Forty-second Street subway station with a sawed-off shotgun that had been concealed by the former husband of the victim in a package, was freed yesterday by Judge James G. Wallace of General Sessions.

PARIS, Jan. 10--French troops, according to reports from Hanoi, have captured the large center of Son La, 130 miles west of Hanoi, in the upper region of the Black River after strong resistance by retreating Viet Nam forces.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10-- Through an agreement reached with Alcide de Gasperi, the Italian Prime Minister, during his conversations here this week the United States will make the transport vessels Hermitage and Monticello available for the Italian Government's use in the repatriation of prisoners of war from foreign areas. The ships will also be available for Italian emigration, and similar requirements of the Italian national interest, the State Department announced today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Jan. 10 --Commenting on the first anniversary of the United Nations inaugural meeting in London, Herschel V. Johnson, acting United States delegate to the Security Council, declared today that the United Nations' two most important goals in 1947 would be the development of a disarmament program and agreement on atomic energy control.

Nine Federal agencies and the International Bank were accused yesterday by the executive board of the United Public Workers, CIO, of refusing to hire Negroes released during the recent liquidation of a Government war agency.

CHEYENNE, Wyo., Jan. 10-- Gov. Lester C. Hunt of Wyoming stated today he will ask for an initial fund of $25,000 to be used in studying methods of improving production and distribution of wool as a means of protecting the American industry.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--President Truman in his budget message today called for increased outlays to support agricultural prices despite prospects of a strong demand for farm products in the next fiscal year.

NEWARK, N. J. Jan. 10--An alert policeman averted an almost certain tragedy today when Peter D. Krug lost consciousness while operating a cab and the vehicle careened across Broad Street, this city's principal thoroughfare, at the height of the homeward bound traffic at 5 P. M.

GERMANY, Jan. 10--Lieut. Gen. Lucius D. Clay, Deputy United States Military Governor, authorized military governments in each German State in the United States zone today to divert military coal and electric power resources for the use of the civilian population as a measure "to preserve life and to prevent disease," it was learned here today.

Gertrude B. Easley and 150 other tenants of the Murray Hill Hotel, Park Avenue and Fortieth Street, who have been threatened with eviction for the last year, will rest easier because of an order filed yesterday in the Appellate Division enjoining and restraining the lessee, the Grand Union Management Corporation, from discontinuing regular and necessary services so long as it continues in possession, pending appeals now before the court.

Washington Market produce wholesalers and farmers from a wide area made a joint effort yesterday to persuade the municipal administration or the Port of New York Authority to rebuild the congested market, the physical aspect of which has changed little in the last 100 years, or construct a new market on another site.

LAKEHURST, N. J., Jan. 10--A post-hunting season survey made from a Navy blimp today revealed fewer than 25,000 game ducks and waterfowl wintering in Long Island's myriad bays and icy marshes that were in times past their havens.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP)-- Two former Italian luxury liners will be returned by the United States to the Italian Government within the next few weeks, Government officials disclosed today.

The State Education Department answered today legislative charges of "improper instruction" in American history in New York's public schools by pointing to student scholastic records in the subject as "a tribute to efficiency of teaching."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--The Interstate Commerce Commission ruled today that reduced furlough fares on buses and trains for military personnel of the United States and its allies will go to the full civilian level on Jan. 31.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The series of weekly articles by Godfrey N. Nelson on Cooperatives and raxes which has been appearing in PHE times does a disservice to the true picture, as well as giving aid and comfort to an organization which Representative Wright Patman declared in Congress to be an "unscrupulous" enemy to "an honorable and extremely democratic segment of our economy."

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 10-- The Board of Education submitted its annual budget today for the consideration of the Board of Finance and included a $600 proposed pay increase for the city's school teachers.
ALBANY, Jan. 10--Establishment of comprehensive minimum fire safety standards in hotels throughout the State will be proposed by the Mitchell Committee on Housing and Multiple Dwellings.

--H. S. Suhrawardy, Premier of Bengal and member of the Moslem League, today assailed as "pretense" the action of the Congress party in accepting the British principle of compulsory grouping of provinces for writing a Constitution for Indian independence.

Fourteen persons have been killed and 127 wounded here to thirtysix hours to savage riots between Hindus and Moslems, it was announced tonight, and disturbances were reported in Calcutta, Karachi and the North-West Frontier Province.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--The text of the budget message of the President follows: To the Congress of the United States: I am transmitting the Budget for the fiscal year 1948. It includes recommendations for the entire Federal program.

Manhattan, a formidable dark-horse for the intracity basketball title, will oppose St. John's at Madison Square Garden tonight. This game, starting at 8 P. M., will be followed by a meeting between City College and St. Joseph's of Philadelphia.

--Free trade in vegetables with Canada was opposed by the Empire State potato club today, adopting a resolution to that effect at the closing session of its joint convention with the New York State Vegetable Growers Association. The resolution also "insists upon a tariff being maintained to protect potato growers."

Despite continuing difficulty in obtaining desirable counts of fine yarns, the American lace industry increased its volume of business in 1946, Gordon Buckman, vice president of the American Lace Manufacturers Association declared yesterday at the annual meeting in the Hotel Commodore.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 10-- Enterprise Productions is seeking an agreement with Zoltan Korda whereby Korda will come to the Enterprise studio to produce and direct the screen version of Aldous Huxley's short story, "The Gioconda Smile," it was learned today.

PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 10-- Princeton's basketball squad defeated Dartmouth, 40--36, in the opening game of the Eastern Intercollegiate League season in Baker Rink tonight, coming from behind in the opening minutes of the second period and maintaining its scant lead to the final whistle.
MADRID, Jan. 10 (AP)--A military court ordered prison terms ranging from two to six years today for ten prominent Spanish Leftists and acquitted two others on charges of "military rebellion."
PARIS, Jan. 10 (U.P.)--President Ho Chi Minh of Viet Nam republic said today that he had appealed to Premier Leon Blum and Marius Moutet, French Minister of Colonies, to end the rioting in IndoChina.
Stormy weather continued across most of the Atlantic yesterday and more steamship lines reported messages from vessels at sea saying that bad weather would delay them in reaching port

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Jan. 10 (AP)--Only a world-wide spiritual (revival will settle ideological controversies plaguing mankind, Dr. Hermann N. Morse told the Home Missions Council of North America upon retiring as its president today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--President Truman in his budget message today recommended greater expenditures for the promotion of the health welfare and social security of the people and said that "much remains to be done."

Jettisoning most of the buncombe of the traditional musical show, E. Y. Harburg and Fred Saidy have written an original and humorous fantasy, "Finian's Rainbow," which was put on at the Forty-sixth Street last evening. Do not be terrified by the news that it whirls around a leprechaun and a magic pot of gold.
(Canadian Press)--Medical experts seeking a cure for the common cold appealed today for additional human guinea pigs willing to risk induced colds In exchange for a fortnight's "easy living."

Puget Sound Power Light Directors of the Puget Sound Power Light Co. voted yesterday a 20-cent dividend on the common stock, payable on Feb. 15. The company paid 25 cents quarterly in 1946 and 30 cents quarterly in 1945.

Hortense Monath returned to the concert platform in this city last night in a piano recital at Town Hall after having spent the last two seasons as musical director of the New Friends of Music. She devoted her program to four composers, Brahms, Mozart, Debussy and Chopin.

LONDON, Jan. 10--The Government's terms for taking over the electric companies were made known today and led to disappointment and lower prices for those issues in the stock market. The take-over basis is to toe the issue of new Treasury stock to shareholders calculated on average market prices for the first week in November, last, or for the six months before the general election.

MOSCOW, Jan. 10--Turkey's position over the question of the Dardanelles does not pursue the country's own aims but those of Anglo-American reaction and atomic diplomacy, Dr. I. Miller declared in a lecture in the Polytechnical Museum last night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--Senate Republicans intend to grapple immediately with the problems raised by the "portal-to-portal" pay suits, its was indicated today. Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican, of Wisconsin, chairman of the Judiciary Committee, announced that hearings would start next Wednesday on the various restrictive measures which have been proposed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--The American representation on the International Bank has been strongly urged, it was learned here today, to work for amendment of the by-laws of the bank governing the powers of the executive directors, in order to facilitate the finding of a qualified man who will accept appointment as president of the bank.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--President Truman's $37,500,000,000 budget opened with a crash today the battle of appropriations versus taxes in the new Eightieth Congress.

New and severe anti-Semitic outbreaks are expected in Austria after the peace treaty is signed and occupation troops withdrawn, Ira A. Hirschmann declared yesterday. He returned last week after investigating conditions among displaced persons in Europe as a special inspector general of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration.

Jonce I. McGurk, an authority on early American art, lay helpless for four days in a bathtub full of water, after he had suffered a stroke while taking a bath. He was found, still conscious, last Monday.

Though breakfast may not be much of an occasion on weekdays, Sunday is a time for special dishes and even for entertaining a few friends. Often the occasion telescopes two meals into one, providing luncheon as well.

Fifteen courses for church school officers, teachers, parents, youth leaders, religious education directors and clergymen will be given during the thirty-fourth annual sessions of the Central Community School of Religion, starting Monday at 8 P. M. in the Biblical Seminary, 235 East Forty-ninth Street.
WASHINGTON,, Jan. 10 (AP)--A $71,591,865 program calling for construction or improvement of 800 airports was announced today by the Federal Government, which will put up $33,899,265 of the total.
ALBANY, Jan. 10--Establishment of comprehensive minimum fire safety standards in hotels throughout the State will be proposed by the Mitchell Committee on Housing and Multiple Dwellings.

Indoor track's rousing 1947 campaign, off to a flying start last Week, will gain additional momentum tonight with the post-war revival of the Columbus Council Knights of Columbus games, which go on at 8 P. M. at the Twenty-Third Regiment Armory in Brooklyn, providing the acceleration.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Jan. 10 --Great Britain filed with the United Nations Security Council today a formal complaint against Albania over the mining of the Corfu Channel, which resulted in the damage of two British destroyers and the loss of forty-four lives.

Tension Relieved The question of a refinancing program for Transcontinental Western Air, Inc., has been partly solved with Howard Hughes' agreement to pour an additional $10,000,000 into working capital and his apparent consent to the proposed increase of capital stock from 1,000,000 to 3,000,000 shares.

Assurance from Mayor O'Dwyer that he would recommend to the Board of Estimate an appropriation of $117,031 to finance an immediate campaign to abate the smoke nuisance throughout the city was received yesterday by Dr. Israel Weinstein, Commissioner of Health. The money will come from funds within the current budget.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 10 (AP)-- Twenty-one Army P-80 jet-propelled Shooting Stars stole the show today at the opening of Miami's fifteenth annual AllAmerican Air Maneuvers. A crowd estimated at better than 15,000 craned their necks while jets swished past the grandstands almost too swiftly to see.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 10 (AP)-- More people are drinking, and people are drinking more, according to Dr. E. M. Jellinek, director of the Tale School of Alcohol Studies.

All officers except one were reflected, awards were presented for 1946 season-long competition, some rules changes were announced and a start made toward a 1947 schedule at the annual meeting of the American Horse Shows Association at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday.
Modern medicine's version of the Scriptural "Take up thy bed, and walk" was movingly demonstrated yesterday in Bellevue Hospital.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES This note does not pretend to answer Mr. Tichenor's letter. The irony of his letter is that I have been accused by both sides to the controversy of unfairly stating their case.

Ferruccio Tagliavini, Italian lyric tenor, made his debut in "La Boheme" at the Metropolitan last night, and the old house had more excitement than it has known in weeks. Mr. Tagliavini got a big hand even before he opened his mouth.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--President Truman sent to the Congress today a budget for the next fiscal year, beginning July 1, calling for expenditure of $37,528,000,000 out of revenues he estimated at $37,730,000,000. He estimated military costs at $11,256,000,000.
ABOARD MOUNT OLYMPUS, Jan. 9 (Delayed) (AP)--The flagship flotilla of the Navy's Antarctic expedition, which set out for Little America, is moving in reverse.

One reason, perhaps, Their for so much that is being Limited said about the lower Gain's quality of the Hollywood product in. recent yearswith some notable exceptions, of course --is the way the income tax operates. The big-salaried stars can hardly be expected to put all their heart in their work when Uncle Sam leaves them only, a hundred thousand dollars out of every million dollars-taken in.

ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 10--A renaissance of the Moslem Orient, stretching from a future Pakistan [Moslem title for a separate state in India] to North Africa was advocated today at a press conference here by King Abdullah Ibn Ul-Hussein of Trans-Jordan.

LONDON, Jan. 10--The British Government decided today to use Army, Navy and Royal Air Force personnel to move food and other essential goods in the London area, where distribution has been brought to a standstill by a wildcat strike of truck drivers.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 10--A general business strike in the State of Oaxaca and a series of voteless municipal turnovers in the State of Chiapas today reflected the farreaching effect of the Tapachula shooting of Dec. 31, as a result of which the State Governor was ousted and a new Mayor was installed.

VIENNA, Jan. 10--Showing the same cooperative spirit they have exhibited for the last month, the Russians agreed with the Western occupation powers at today's Allied Council meeting to pool the zonal food resources of Austria to bridge the deficit left by the slow arrival of United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration shipments.

When the Board of Education meets next Wednesday William Jansen, Assistant Superintendent in the city's public school system, is expected to be elected to the $25,000-a-year position of Superintendent of Schools.

LONDON, Jan. 10--The British Government decided today to use Army, Navy and Royal Air Force personnel to move food and other essential goods in the London area, where distribution has been brought to a standstill by a wildcat strike of truck drivers.

Nine Federal agencies and the International Bank were accused yesterday by the executive board of the United Public Workers, CIO, of refusing to hire Negroes released during the recent liquidation of a Government war agency.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--Senate Republicans intend to grapple immediately with the problems raised by the "portal-to-portal" pay suits, its was indicated today. Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican, of Wisconsin, chairman of the Judiciary Committee, announced that hearings would start next Wednesday on the various restrictive measures which have been proposed.

The national council of the National Maritime Union, CIO, ended its week-long series of meetings yesterday without resolving several questions that have threatened the unity of the union governing body.

Several scattergun enthusiasts, whose doubles, autoloaders and pumps present them with nice patterns when they use shot sizes from 4 to 8, seem convinced that they must suffer from buck fever when they use the same guns on deer.

LONDON, Jan. 10--The Government's Electricity Nationalization Bill, published today, proposes to place the ownership of all Britain's electric power companies in the hands of an eleven-man Central Electricity Authority.

DEL MONTE, Calif., Jan. 10 (UP)--Sam Snead and his amateur partner, Roger Kelly, finished at dusk tonight to gain a tie with Dick Metz and Fred Dold in the first round of the $10,000 Bing Crosby pro-amateur golf tournament.

Moving with alacrity quite surprising for a ball club that had trouble getting off its own feet last summer, the Giants whipped across with two more contract signers yesterday when Secretary Eddie Brannick, who is "Old Man Optimism" himself these daya, announced that the two left-hand pitchers, Dave Koslo and Montia Kennedy, had accepted terms for the coming season.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--President Truman sent the budget message to Congress and met with the Cabinet; his visitors included Associate Supreme Court Justice Harold H. Burton with L. W. de Gast and Dr. Carson P. Frailey, Maj. Gen. Lowell Rooks, Representative Alfred L. Bulwinkle, Foreign Minister Jan Masaryk of Czechoslovakia and Ambassador James C. Dunn.

ALL the fabulous traditions of the Old South were inherited by Katharine Du Pre Lumpkin, whose forebears were plantation owners from, 'way back and whose father had fought gallantly through the Civil War and lived to tell the tale over and Over and over again.

MUNICH, Germany, Jan. 10-- One fantastic aspect of the attempt to denazify Germany is the fact that the Bavarian chairman of the strongest party, a self-announced liberal and known collaborator with the Allies during the war, is awaiting trial before a German denazification tribunal.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--The National Association of Manufacturers announced today intervention as "a friend of the court" in the suit for retroactive pay for portal-to-portal time against the Mount Clemens Pottery Company.

MOSCOW, Jan. 10--In what a guest described as ''the friendliest possible atmosphere," Generalissimo Stalin dined with Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery, chief of Britain's Imperial General Staff, in the Kremlin tonight. Others at the dinner included Foreign Minister Molotov, Marshal Alexander M. Vasilevsky, Soviet Chief of Staff, and Marshal Ivan S. Konev.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 10--The Colored Advisory Council, which is an official body, issued a statement today |after a two-day session here demanding full political right for nearly 1,000,000 colored South Africans.

35% Sales Gain in Week Retail trade here continued in large volume this week. Department store sales were estimated at about 35 per cent over the like period of last year. A prime factor was the return of more normal quantities of the goods usually promoted around this time, particularly cotton textile staples, together with clearances of women's coats and furs.

The Kings County grand jury that has been studying conditions at Brooklyn City Prison, since December, 1940, declared yesterday that responsibility for the recent jail break there "should be placed squarely on the shoulders of those city officials who, in the past, have repeatedly ignored the appeals of the people of Brooklyn to replace this obsolete structure."

IN "Journeys in Time" Blair Niles has woven together twenty-nine selections by twenty -six writers bearing on the humanity and literature of Latin America from 1519 to 1942. Mrs. Niles herself has contributed 50,000 words to the volume.

Not merely a few of the thousands who pour through the doors of the Motor Boat Show are sailloving seagoers whose hobby is breezing under canvas. Their ultimate dreams are not on view in fulfillment, being too lofty for the portals of the Palace, but there is the essence of them in blueprints and sketches, with full particulars to mull over at home.
BOSTON, Jan. 11 -- It appears, after twenty-five years of stout resistance, that Massachusetts jury rooms, like the barber shop, are about to yield to the onslaught of femininity.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 11 (AP) -- The right of freedom of the press as guaranteed by the Constitutions of the United States and of Maryland was raised today by the A.S. Abell Company, publishers of the Sunpapers, and its president, Paul Patterson, in connection with contempt of court proceedings filed against them.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 11 -- In his valedictory as Secretary of State, James F. Byrnes, a Southern Democrat, joined tonight with Arthur H. Vandenberg, a Northern Republican and self-described "junior partner" in the bipartisan foreign policy team of the United States, in extending to the world full assurances of this nation's intent to fulfill the responsibilities attendant to its military might.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- If not both sweetness and light, at least sweetness became this week one of the objectives of the Republican majority in the new Congress.

To the Drama Editor: WATCHING the climactic final scene of "Joan of Lorraine," I couldn't help thinking of "The Iceman Cometh." While O'Neill's overlong play offers us the defeatist alternatives of death or chronic inebriation, Anderson's drama is an affirmation of life.

THE orange crop this season is 20 per cent larger than that of last year and 53 per cent in excess of the average. The grapefruit harvest is also impressive, being 6 per cent greater than that of 1946 and 69 per cent more than the average.

In the spring of 1938, in what might be called the Japanese honeymoon in China, invading columns were pushing toward the junction of two important railways, at Suchow, south of the Yellow River. They never got far beyond Suchow, for the Chinese cut the dikes of the river and turned its whole flood southward across Honan, Anhwei and northern Kiangsu.

Money spent to acquire real esstate on Fifth Avenue and in the adjoining East Side areas, together with projected plans for new construction and renovation work, represents an aggregate investment of more than $200,000,000 which will result in further expansion for this Manhattan business and residential sector, according to a survey just completed by the Fifth Avenue Association.

JOSE LIMON'S performance at the Belasco Theatre last week was an occasion for general rejoicing, not alone for its immediate excellences but also for its broad implications. Tear after year a considerable body of enthusiasts, convinced of the essential powers of the dance as a unique medium for artistic communication, goes from theatre to recital hall, to studio performances, to choreographic workshops, looking always for a justification of its faith.
TORONTO, Jan. 11 (AP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs stretched their National Hockey League lead to seven points tonight by nosing out the Boston Bruins, 4 -- 3, before a crowd of 13,688.

The end of a strike threat by the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, AFL, against the New York State Gas and Electric Corporation, Consolidated Gas and Electric subsidiary, of Binghamton, N.Y., which would have affected forty-three up-State counties, was announced at 9:30 o'clock last night by United States Conciliator Fraak E. Walsh, after an eleven-and-a-half-hour conference with spokesmen for both sides.
Mayor O'Dwyer declared yesterday that democratic education "must be rooted in a well paid, secure teaching personnel."

THE central character in Glenn Allan's tall, gusty stories of the Little Sorrowful Swamp in South Carolina is a cheerful, peppery scatterbrain known as Mr. Chinhus. Once when Mr. Chinnus got in a fight, he swung a huge, old-fashioned watch by its heavy gold chain and knocked his opponent into unconsciousness.

THE Negro came to America almost as early as did the white man and he played a primary part in the settling of the continent. He came as a slave, in "one of the greatest population movements of all time," but he did not remain a slave.

TOKYO, Jan. 11 -- Our occupation costs will account for about 30 per cent of Japan's ordinary budget in the fiscal year beginning in April, but the Japanese public is not being informed of that fact. The civil censorship detachment has been eliminating from the press every reference to this subject.

ALBANY, Jan. 11 -- Establishment of a State Crime Institute to investigate the basic causes of criminal behavior will be proposed in a bill to be introduced in the Legislature Monday night by Senator Thomas C. Desmond, Republican, of Newburgh.

IT is Edith Halpert's hope that eventually some museum may organize a full-scale memorial exhibition honoring the late Arthur G. Dove who died in November last. Meanwhile, she, herself, has done extremely well with the Dove retrospective now current at her Downtown Gallery.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 11 -- Using its superior height to advantage, the Army basketball team defeated the Pitt Panthers by a score of 60 to 53 at the Academy Field House today.

IT is distressing news that the League of Composers will discontinue the publication of its magazine, Modern Music, which for twenty-three years has supported the most advanced movements in contemporary composition. This magazine was brilliantly edited by "Minna Lederman, for years almost single-handed in her task, and her later associates.

President Marine Trades Assn. I see a successful but not hectic career for the Marine Trades Association in 1947. We are over our hectic days, temporarily at least. No more outdoor floating motor boat shows for the time being and no more attempts to co-ordinate trade credit systems and discount practices, ever, I hope.

Last night was probably the happiest evening in three months for bedridden Anna Mayer. The 21-year-old victim of a hiccoughs attack, her second, received word that her appeal to President Truman asking him to grant a surgeon leave from duty with the Veterans Administration to operate on her had been transferred to appropriate authorities.

GOOD painters have seldom proved good writers. Mr. George Grosz, in his autobiography, is no exception. For once this defect is not of major importance, for however sloppily he may use words, for all his contradictions, ambiguities and obscurities, Mr. Grosz is anything but dull.

James Madison High's Brooklyn, Section 2, Public School Athletic League record remained unblemished yesterday as the Black and Gold quintet downed Lafayette High, 51 -- 38, before 8,000 spectators at Madison Square Garden. It was the fourth league triumph in as many outings for the Madison team, which broke a first-place tie with Abraham Lincoln to take the undisputed lead in Section 2.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Wheat spurted for gains extending to more than 2 cents a bushel at times on the Board of Trade today. Gains in oats ranged to around a cent, while corn was ahead fractionally. Wheat closed 5/8 to 2 1/4 cents a bushel higher.

"WHITE INDIANS" -- The Government makes no distinction between red-skinned and albino Indians in its census reports. Dr. D.B. Stout (Syracuse University) did, however, when he was working among the San Blas tribes of eastern Panama in 1940.

A REREADING of Hoffenstein is a reminiscent joy; and it is a voyage of discovery to a generation unable to read twenty years ago. It was many and many a year ago that I suggested, in writing, giving the Pulitzer Award for Poetry to Dorothy Parker for "Enough Rope," or to Samuel Hoffenstein for "Poems in Praise of Practically Nothing."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- It remains to be proved that a good soldier can, in a short time, become a good Secretary of State.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The Eightieth Congress is only nine days old. The new Democratic loyal opposition, or minority, has struggled long hours to pull itself into its unwanted role. It remains bewildered and baffled.

At a recent session of the national ski convention Mrs. Alice Damrosch Kiaer, chairman of the women's skiing committee, stated that the objectives of her committee are to foster and promote skiing for women in the United States and to recommend to the international competition committee women skiers to represent the association on United States teams in international competition.

A SMALL greenhouse that will extend the pleasures of gardening throughout the twelve months of the year is a dream which many enthusiasts hope will come true, before long. It can be started, however, long before ground is broken for the foundation.

More speech training is needed for prospective teachers, particularly elementary school teachers, it has been determined in a survey undertaken at New York University. The study, which is reported in The Quarterly Journal of Speech by Herold Lillywhite of the College of the Pacific, involved obtaining information by questionnaire from administrators and teachers in Minnesota elementary and high school systems and analyzing the recorded speech of 100 prospective teachers in three Minnesota teachers' colleges.

The sponsored program is a phenomenon of the radio industry for which no individual or set of individuals deserves credit or blame. Radio advertising just happened to develop in such a way that the sponsor's message customarily is related to and identified with a specific program content.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 11 (AP) -- La Salle College of Philadelphia, coming gamely from behind, struck for seven points in a second overtime period tonight to upset the sharpshooting North Carolina Tarheels, 65 to 62, in the opening game of a Convention Hall basketball double-header.

LONDON. THE topic, without any doubt, is the reopening of London's biggest and most historic theatre, the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane, just before Christmas with a new Noel Coward musical romance called "Pacific 1860."
OTTAWA, Jan. 11 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's shipbuilding industry, thriving as never before in peacetime, started off 1947 with a backlog of orders totaling around $110,000,000, a survey shows.

A YEAR ago the Trapp Family decided to save the profits from the sale of their souvenir concert programs to buy food packages for the needy in their native Austria. When, they were asked to pose presenting a check to Msgr. J.W. Wright to be turned over to CARE, they accepted.
LONDON, Jan. 11 (Reuters) -- Football results in the British Isles today follow: FOOTBALL ASSOCIATION CUP Third Round Blackburn 1, Hull City 1. Bolton 5, Stockport 1. Bournemouth 0, Derby 2.

WARSAW, Jan. 11 -- The public prosecutor today demanded the death penalty for three men in the treason trial of Count Xavier Grocholski. He declared that the British Ambassador, Victor F.W. Cavendish -Bentinck, had "transgressed against the elementary rules of relations between two friendly states" in seeking "state and military secrets" from the Polish underground.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- What does economic liberalism mean in the modern world of giant corporations, big unions, and expanding governmental power?
MOSCOW, Jan. 11 -- No international problem strikes deeper into the heart of the average Russian than the settlement of the German question.
