MONTREAL, Jan. 11 (AP) -- The tail-end Chicago Black Hawks scored twice in the second period tonight and went on to defeat the National Hockey League champion Montreal Canadiens, 2-1.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- President Truman's proposals for industrial peace, offered to Congress this week, are mild and non-punitive compared with, the chief measures offered in both houses.

BOSTON -- Winter was a long time coining to New England, but since the unofficial starting time of the wintersports season -- the Christmas-New Year's holidays -- this section has had snow, and skiers, on its broad slopes.

IN view of much recent conversation about the quality of certain British films -- about the vigor and freshness of their stories and the ingenuity with which they have been made -- it was quite an obliging coincidence that two of the holiday hits should have got onto psychical levels and that one should have been from Britain while the other was from Hollywood.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Jan. 11 -- Charles Atwater Sweet, vice president of Iselin-Jefferson Company and chairman of its finance committee, who was long prominent in the textile industry, died here today in his home at 10 Vine Street. His age was 60.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 11 (AP) -- David Ben-Gurion, chairman of the Jewish Agency Executive, said tonight that it was unlikely that Jews would participate in the London conference on Palestine and indicated that the Jews would welcome settlement of the Palestine problem by the United Nations.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 11 -- Slim little George Fazio Oflos Angeles, Canadien open golf champion, held a two-stroke lead over his closest professional rival today at the end of the second round of the fifty-four-hole $10,000 Bing Crosby pro-amateur tournament.

LONDON, Jan. 11 -- If the results of a poll of readers' opinions, taken by a London Sunday newspaper, can be considered representative the British public is sharply divided over the question of whether Princess Elizabeth ought to marry Prince Philip of Greece.

BATON ROUGE, La. -- American, tourists who have longed to see the inside of the old Southern plantations can now do so as paying guests. There aren't many plantations open to the public, and the total dining room and sleeping space is small compared to the number of applicants for the pleasure of living, if only for a day or two, in an authentic early American atmosphere.

TRAVEL aboard the snow buses now running out of midtown Manhattan to ski centers in the Catskills, the Berkshires, the Adirondacks and Vermont's peaks is even more informal, the merriment perhaps even more unconfined, than on the railroad's snow trains.

BEFORE the war when shipping lanes were open, all sorts of foods came into this country from abroad. Some of them, like tea and pepper, were the kind of thing that cannot be produced here, while others, like British sherry biscuits and French pate de foie gras, were quite frankly in the nature of luxuries.

A board appointed by the Navy last April to review the cases of all prisoners serving sentences of confinement imposed by general courts-martial has recommended modifications in 45 per cent of the 2,115 penalties reviewed, it was announced here yesterday.

To the Music Editor: RECENT Sunday editions of THE TIMES have contained mention of publication of the works of Soviet composers, particularly the choruses of Prokofieff's opera, "War and Peace," by a Russian-American music company of this city.

PUTTING proper emphasis upon the sharp price increases which have reduced real purchasing power, the economic report made to Congress during the week by President Truman suggested that the Government could point out dangers but that "the correctives must largely be applied by others."

Foreseeing increasing numbers of boatowners as motor-boats become available, the United States Coast Guard has requested the Coast Guard Auxiliary to offer a courtesy motor-boat, inspection to the public. This inspection program is expected to reduce substantially the annual number of marine accidents caused by violations of equipment regulations.

Quality control engineers from ten New York and New England metalworking and machinery manufacturing plants are cooperating in a new quality control training program planned for interindustry conferences at Federal Products Corporation, Providence, R.I., during the next six weeks.
Martin Boykan, 15-year-old New York pianist, gave his first recital here last night in Times Hall, playing numbers by Domenico Scarlatti, Mozart, Schubert, Chopin, Scriabine and Liszt.

A plan of action for establishing more effective machinery within the American Federation of Teachers for promoting education for democratic human relations was approved yesterday at a conference held in the Willkie Memorial Building, 40 West Fortieth Street.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11 -- The Illinois Legislature, after more than forty years of defiance of the State Constitution, is apparently in a mood to remap this Commonwealth's Congressional Districts and thus give the voters equal representation in the national House of Representatives.

THE Town Meeting of the Air, which recently has been heard on a sustaining basis, is scheduled to be sponsored on a cooperative basis over the network of the American Broadcasting Company. It is said to be the first time that a major public service offering and a program of an hour's duration has been presented under such auspices.

AFTER a year's absence from the fiction circuit, Howard Spring is back in top form for a popular repeat performance. His latest all-star-cast Victorian novel -- though it may seem to some readers to creak like an old rocking chair -- is full of the usual enticements.

IOWA -- Requirements New entrance requirements and a general revision of the entire course in the University of Iowa's College of Engineering will go into effect next June. Freshmen entering after June 1 must present credits in college algebra, trigonometry, English composition, speech and inorganic chemistry.

WASHINGTON. IN the old days when there was such intensive winding of oatmeal boxes with copper wire and setting the cat whisker on the crystal was such a delicate operation, Charles R. Denny was just a kid in short trousers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- John L. Lewis and the United Mine Workers asserted in a brief filed in the Supreme Court today that the Government surrendered to "political expediency" in the soft-coal strike last November and performed an amazing about-face on the question of injunctions in labor disputes involving the Government.

MOSCOW, Jan. 11 -- Germany must be unified politically and economically if the division of the country into spheres of influence is to be avoided, an international review in the New Times said today. The statement was regarded by foreign diplomats in Moscow as one of the most important opinions yet voiced on the German problem here.

WASHINGTON. ONE year ago we were involved in the huge task of military demobilization. Between October, 1945, and February, 1946, men and women left our armed services at a rate of more than a million a month. They returned to civilian life so rapidly that our nation was not fully prepared to receive them.
WARSAW, Jan, 11 -- The Polish Government says it is a lie that its Communist supporters are using terroristic tactics in the election campaign.

PARIS, Jan. 11 -- The Blum Government this past week has startled France with a tremendous effort to create "a psychological shock" that is intended to set up a trend toward lower prices and enable the country to escape the grip of inflation.

Editor New York Times Book Review: FREDERIC MARQUARDT'S review of my book, "Betrayal in the Philippines," which appeared in your Book Review section of Dec. 15, 1946, reveals precisely the type of thinking that, as I point out in my book, has been responsible for the confusion over the Philippine situation and in particular to the issue of collaboration.

Among the many deserved honors that have been bestowed recently upon Bernard M. Baruch was the Freedom House Award for 1946 "For Outstanding Service in the Cause of Peace." The long and influential public career of this wise and kindly statesman reached a fitting climax with the adoption by the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission of his recommendations for the control of atomic energy.

DONATION by John D. Rockefeller Jr. of that East Side site for the home of the United Nations has set optimistic folks to thinking the area might also be an inducement for the legitimate theatre's new home.

A GLANCE backward through philately in 1946 shows that portraits or figures or monuments or statues of 112 persons were introduced to the hobby's expanding gallery by fortyeight Governments. All but fifteen of these men and women are dead.

HERE is a selection of Mark Van Doren's "country" poems, just under a hundred of them, generously illustrated by John O'Hara Cosgrave II. The bulk of the poems is drawn from earlier Van Doren books, a generous sheaf from "Spring Thunder and Other Poems," virtually all the first two sections of "7 P.M. and Other Poems," and a scattering from "A Winter Diary and Other Poems" and "The Last Look and Other Poems."
BERLIN. EACH time Brig. Gen. Robert A. McClure gestures a caller to the sofa in his conference room at United States Military Government headquarters here, the visitor has a twofold reaction.

Dr. Karl von Frisch of Graz, Austria, is better known to authorities on the social insects than he is to the general public. If he is famous in a small European entomological circle it is because of the studies that he has made of what he calls the "language" of bees. Bees communicate by odors, according to von Frisch.

THE gardener's acquaintance with the firm that supplies his seeds seldom goes beyond the paper stage. A gay catalogue that arrives every January and a few stereotyped letters are the sum of a relationship that may extend over many years.
PARIS, Jan. 11 -- According to responsible diplomatic sources the Norwegian Government proposed to the Soviet Union on April 9, 1945 the joint defense of Spitsbergen.

Not unlike the feeling of many interested persons in the United States, who think that tax exemption of cooperatives affords these organizations a competitive advantage over ordinary business corporations, there developed, in Canada a few years ago a similar situation.

ANOTHER influenza epidemic is expected, possibly this winter, but it will not be like earlier ones. For the first time medical science has weapons with which to fight one of mankind's worst and most widespread scourges. Most authorities believe that flu killed more people immediately after the first World War than were killed by weapons during the war.

With more than three decades of educational service to the boating fraternity behind it, the United States Power Squadrons enters 1947 stronger than ever and With prospects for expansion of its activities never brighter.

Although they are operating under more liberal rules now with Frank R. Creedon as National Housing Expediter in place of Wilson W. Wyatt, home builders in the metropolitan district claim that they will find it impossble to attain peak production until further changes are made in the Government regulations.

LARAMIE, Wyo., Jan. 11 (AP) -- Wyoming University's board of trustees and President G.D. Humphreys today expressed confidence in basketball Coach Ev Shelton in the now famous "New York Incident" and suggested the ethics committee of the National Basketball Coaches Association determine whether City College Coach Nat Holman should be continued as a member of the organization.

IF you want to know why a Southerner, especially a Southerner of 50 or older, is that way, you can find the answer in Katharine Du Pre Lumpkin's quietly dramatic examination of her antecedents and her earlier years. You can also discover why only a small minority of Southerners even now break away, as did Miss Lumpkin, from their emotional? conditioning.

The text of the speech by Secretary Byrnes before the Cleveland Council of World Affairs last night, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES, was as follows: Mr. Chairman, and Ladies and Gentlemen: After the announcement on Tuesday night of my resignation as Secretary of State I advised Mr. Luce that I doubted whether under the circumstances the directors of the Cleveland Council would wish me to participate in this program.

NANKING, Jan. 11 (AP) -- A major Shakeup in the Chinese. Government, with liberal nonpartisans and minority party members getting at least half the ministries, will be completed within the next month, a well-informed .source said today.

The United States Lines trans ported nearly 150,000 passengers in 951 sailings in 1946, it was an nounced yesterday by company of ficials. The sailings were made by American-flag vessels owned or chartered by the company, or owned by the Government and operated by United States Lines as general agent for the Maritime Commission.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 11 -- Eternal Reward, the colt that sprang one of the biggest upsets of 1946 by winning the American Derby at Washington Park last summer, broke loose from an extended losing streak at Tropical Park today when he rallied from last place to earn a photo triumph in the $12,150 Tropical Handicap.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- John R. Steelman, assistant to President Truman, today barred any change in the Government's program for public purchase, and control of imports of natural rubber until Congress has acted upon recommendations for proposed extension of restrictions on domestic use of rubber.

He was America's top miler on the stopwatch in 1946 but slim, bespectacled Eddie Walsh of Manhattan was regarded as a rank outsider in the all-star six-man Eield for the Grand Knight 880yard run, feature event of the revived Columbus Council, Knights of Columbus, meet at the Twentythird Regiment Armory in Brooklyn last night.
Second of a series of ten articles on recent developments in contract bridge bidding methods.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Jan. 11 -- Richard W. Hill, retired secretary of the American Bankers Association and the American Institute of Banking, died last night in his home at 31 Myrtle Boulevard, Larchmont Gardens. His age was 68.

A part of historic Livingston Manor, where Robert Fulton landed his steamboat, the Clermont, after his celebrated trip up the Hudson River, has been purchased by the Carmelite Sisters for the Aged and Infirm, a Catholic order at 66 Van Cortlandt Park South in the Bronx, for its own use.

THE nature of a score of the newly opened exhibitions can only be indicated at this time. Sound and forceful landscapes by Lowell Bobleter are on view at the Joseph Luyber Gallery in the Hotel Brevoort. Adolph Gottlieb, at the Samuel Kootz Gallery, continues his exploration of primitive universals in man through pictographic and totemie symbol paintings.

Report on China When Gen. George C. Marshall stepped upon Nanking's dusty, windswept airfield one year ago last month and clasped hands with Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, China was engaged in a civil war that had been dragging on, intermittently, for nineteen years.

On Nov. 13,1946, Vincent J. Schaefer of the General Electric Research Laboratory created a meteorological sensation by "seeding" a cloud of water droplets with dry ice (solid carbon dioxide) and thus producing snow.

Many theatre parties have been arranged for the near future to raise funds for various philanthropies. The Home for Incurables will be the beneficiary of the performance of "The Big Two," with Claire Trevor and Philip Dorn in the leading roles, on Tuesday night at the Booth Theatre.

More hopeful than optimistic, the nation's steel industry will focus attention this week on the initial conferences in Pittsburgh between representatives of the United States Steel Corporation and the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, on the subject of a new wage contract.

Plans for a conference center on religion to serve all Protestant groups in the New York area were announced yesterday in connection with the purchase of a twelve-acre estate at Bridgehampton, L.I., by Presbyterian Associates, Inc. This is a non-profit organization that is starting a drive for funds to equip the property.

BY THIS time many people who dreamed through the war of building a fine new modern house have learned that there is more wisdom today in remodeling an old one. By "old" we mean any prewar house of traditional design that for one reason or another needs to have its face lifted.

Human Fellowship MAN'S ability to form associations has reached a certain point and then stopped. And at this point, as though to remind him of the difficult further step from which he shrinks, death and destruction on an unprecedented scale have intervened.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I should be most grateful if you would let me use the hospitality of your columns to correct the widespread misapprehension which has been caused by Frank Stuart's grossly inaccurate article, "Living in a Dead Man's Suit," which was published in The Saturday Evening Post on Dec. 28.

It is not easy or particularly pleasant to write of the new American opera, "The Warrior," music by Bernard Rogers and libretto by Norman Corwin, which, received its first performance, and simultaneously its first radio broadcast, yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House.

A rookie policeman's swift action saved the lives of a 5-year-old boy and his 3-year-old brother from the 100th Street pool in Central Park after they had scampered out across the thin ice to retrieve a rubber ball yesterday.

It would be hard to name anything overlooked in the way of marine engines at the show. There are more outboard motors there than ever before, with seven manufacturers all competing for the public's attention. There are gasoline engines of all sizes in profusion and plenty of Diesels, too.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Jan. 11 (AP) -- Young Linus Fobare of Saranac Lake, intermediate titleholder last winter, grabbed the halfway lead today in the Eastern States speed skating championships without winning a race.

To commemorate its bicentennial, Princeton University recently held a conference on genetics, paleontology and evolution. Distinguished biologists tried to predict the fate of man. Would he go the way of the dodo and the dinosaur? Or would he take his destiny in his own hands and make a better creature of himself?
LONDON, Jan. 11 -- The Palestinian problem was still fluid at the week-end despite hopes that Cabinet meetings this week would result in commitment to some form of solution.

DR. FOSDICK, who without doubt is the most widely esteemed Protestant preacher in America today, has followed up his popular "On Being a Real Person" and "A Great Time to Be Alive" with this even more attractive volume.

E.M. Forster, British novelist, author of "A Passage to India," is coming from England to speak at the Symposium on Music Criticism to be held May 1, 2 and 3 at Harvard University, it was revealed yesterday with the announcement of the tentative program for the event.

With the opening of the spring term a few weeks hence, high school graduates are once again discovering that it is extremely difficult to find a college or university with available space. Indications are that the record boom will continue during the coming year and probably until the end of this decade.

The Rev. Stephen Fielding Bayne Jr., chaplain of Columbia University since 1942, announced last night his decision to accept election as Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal diocese of Olympia, Wash. He will succeed the Right Rev. S. Arthur Huston, Bishop of Olympia since 1925.

The expected large influx of buyers to the wholesale markets featured business developments here last week. Arrivals this week are expected to be larger, marking the peak for the early part of the season. Reports indicated good orders were placed for medium price and better lines.

HERE is a pleasant presentation of intelligent gossip about some of the great and near great in Roman Catholic circles. The author has become widely known as a foreign correspondent who has covered the Vatican twenty-seven years for The Associated Press, the United Press and the International News Service.
It is a fair prediction that the popularity of recreational boating in the United States will triple within the next two years over that of any previous period in the sport's history.

A BOY in a blue shirt sat by himself, bent over a piece of woodwork. Two boys wrestled around the ping-pong table. Two more stood at a work bench -- one working, one watching and interfering now and then. One boy roved aimlessly around the room.

It's called the Motor Boat Show, but it's been a port of call for sailing men for many years, including this one. A lot of them prowl around the aisles with as much enthusiasm as the seeker for the latest mechanical gadgets.

As one of the most discussed literary items of recent months, "Thieves in the Night," Arthur Koestler's novel about Palestine and Zionism, has not been entirely ignored by alert but cautious Hollywood traders. However, recently, Irving Reis, who has directed films at RKO, and Mrs. Leo Spitz, acquired screen rights to the work and let it be known that they Would produce the film version independently.

President Truman's message to Congress on labor last week opened up a great public debate on the nation's No. 1 economic problem, which has wide ramifications also in the field of domestic political and social affairs and even in that of international relations and world peace.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 11 -- A single-engine plane, of which Thomas Michael Ryan, 21, great-grandson of the late New York capitalist Thomas Fortune Ryan, was pilot, crashed into San Francisco Bay in a heavy fog today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Harold E. Stassen, candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1948, assailed President Truman's Federal budget today as "padded, wasteful and extravagant" and said it could be cut $5,000,000,000 without impairment of Government services.

The fifty towboat companies that operate harbor craft here feel that in accepting the terms of settlement recently recommended by the Mayor's Emergency Labor Committee, they have assumed a heavy financial burden, it was pointed out yesterday by James P. McAllister, president of the McAllister Lighterage Line, Inc., and chairman of the Employers Wage Adjustment Committee.
In flight from their destitute territory, Puerto Ricans are swelling the city's population by 1,500 new arrivals a week, the Welfare Council of New York City said yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 11 (AP) -- A new policy on radio broadcasts of the world champion Cardinals' baseball games was announced today by Sam Breadon, club president, in a move likely to touch off a controversy with the Browns, the city's American League entry.
Winter strips the trees to their essentials. They stand now in bare bones, except the pines and spruces, and you can see what stands behind their graceful summer shapes.
Two deputy commissioners, with unblemished service records in the Police Department totaling nearly a century, yesterday mailed their resignations to Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander.

DETROIT -- After a harassing year, with production slowly bumping along over a series of obstacles ranging from strikes to unprecedented shortages of materials, the automotive manufacturers will in 1947 consolidate what few gains were made last year rather than attempt any radical departures, according to Alex Taub, Washington consulting engineer.

LONDON. "DULCIMER STREET" is a book about London which happens also to be written by a Londoner. This is unusual. But then it is unusual for anybody in London to be a native-born Londoner. Nearly everybody in Fleet Street, for example, seems to have come from Scotland" or Yorkshire or the West Country.

LONDON, Jan. 11 -- Preparations for drafting the peace treaty with Germany are under way already. In Berlin the Allied Control Council is preparing a report for consideration of the Foreign Ministers who are to meet in Moscow in March.

Ninety-two per cent of 1,000 veterans attending Columbia who responded to questionnaires distributed by the Columbia chapter of the American Veterans Committee feel that the Government should raise the veteran subsistence allowance.

PROFESSOR HANSEN is one of the leaders of modern economic thought in this country. An outstanding exponent of the "new economics" made famous by the late Lord Keynes, he is a strong advocate of flexibility in Government taxing' and spending policy as the safest and surest road to stable prosperity.

BOSTON, Jan. 11 -- A New York clergyman told the New England Sales Management Conference today that many American businessmen had succumbed to left-wing philosophy and had deserted the economic and social principles which had made the United States great.

In order to bring about lower rentals in new multiple housing projects and to stimulate the production of housing for veterans, the Federal Housing Administration has announced a reduction in monthly carrying charges on financing this type of housing.
LONDON, Jan. 11 (AP) -- John Hunter Harley, British author and journalist and one of the founders of the Labor party, died today at his home near London. His age was 81.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 11 -- Eva Tanguay, one-time queen of American vaudeville and musical comedy, suffered a stroke last night and died this morning in her Hollywood cottage. She was 58 years old.

Electrical equipment is plentiful at the Palace. On display are electric windlasses, ship-to-shore phones, electric sanders, any number of searchlights and, of considerable interest, the first civilian application of Loran.

RICHMOND, Jan. 11 -- Emphasis is being given in Virginia and North Carolina to the need for developing small, locally owned industries which would process agricultural products in their immediate areas, and help to balance agriculture with industry in these predominantly rural States.

Col. William Peter Cavanaugh, commander since 1944 of New York's old Sixty-ninth New York State Guard regiment, was promoted yesterday to brigadier general by Governor Dewey, it was announced here. New command of the 165th Infantry, as the Sixtyninth is now called, has been assigned to Col. Martin H. Meany.

HONOLULU, Jan. 11 -- Gen. George C. Marshall said today that he would rather be "a plain, private citizen" than Chief of Staff or Secretary of State but that he "considered it his duty" to accept President Truman's assignment to the Secretaryship.

The Harry Cowles invitation squash racquets tournament got under way at the Harvard Club yesterday. Play was held in two divisions, one for players now in active tournament competition and the other for those who once engaged nationally.

LONDON, Jan. 11 -- Britain's Labor Government will give the striking truckmen a chance to report for work Monday morning before using military personnel to truck foodstuffs to retail stores, it was announced today.

Arguments for and against the closed shop were delivered yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the National Republican Club, 54 West Fortieth Street, by Emil Schlesinger, attorney for the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, and William D. Rawlins, executive secretary of the Realty Advisory Board on Labor Relations.

IN his preface to "When the Going Was Good," Mr. Waugh says that it comprises "all that I wish to reprint of the four travel books I wrote between the years "1929 and 1935: 'Bachelor Abroad,' 'They Were Still Dancing,' 'Ninety -two Days', and (a title not of my own choosing) 'Waugh in Abyssinia.'

FOLLOWING the lapse of customary vigilance during the holiday activities, house plants need a careful scrutiny to detect the presence of insects which moved in while the gardener's back was turned. Prompt action will check their advances and prevent damage to plants.

The Republican-dominated Eightieth Congress has now finished its first week as an organized body. During this week it has been put through what is called in university circles an orientation course -- an exploration of the wide range of facts and ideas with which a subsequently followed curriculum will deal.

An astounding, utterly unprecedented record-breaking outpouring of folks with an ambitious hankering to have fun afloat demonstrated for twelve gay hours at Grand Central Palace yesterday that they are looking into this sport of pleasure boating to see what it's all about.

THE author of this excellent work is herself a foremost American practitioner and teacher of bookbinding. From a lifetime's experience in this difficult art she has given in these volumes, to those who are interested, both a historical record and, more important, an eminently practical guide, for which they will be immensely grateful.

BERLIN, Jan. 11 -- Mobs of as many as 700 Germans are looting coal trains and sometimes food trains at many points in the British zone as the mounting desperation of hunger and freezing breaks down the usual German submissiveness to law.

SET SVANHOLM, the Metropolitan's new Wagnerian tenor, was scheduled to go back to Sweden next month, but the Metropolitan has managed to arrange matters with the Royal Opera in Stockholm so that the Heldentenor can remain here to finish out the season.

COME this March the Literary Guild is celebrating its twentieth birthday. According to its bulletin, the guild is the world's largest book club, having at the moment some 1,250,000 members. In 1927, when the guild was launched, it distributed its first selection, "Anthony Comstock," to 5,732 club members.

Mayor O'Dwyer and key members of his official family held a long conference last night at Gracie Mansion with Senator Elmer Quinn and Assemblyman Irwin Steingut, leaders of the Democratic minority in the Legislature.

The stock market ended the week yesterday at the lowest levels of the new year, with railroad, liquor and amusement shares softest. Prices were off fractions to 5 points in the heaviest trading since Dec. 21, the turnover aggregating 620,000 shares, compared with 300,000 in the previous two-hour session.

ATHENS, Tenn., Jan. 11 -- McMinn County, scene of an August election day battle as veterans of World War II overthrew the controlling political machine, was without administration or legislative power today in sequel to the resignation of seven Democratic members of the County Court and four Democratic members of the County School Board.

With the capture yesterday in Brooklyn of Vito Panaro, who had broken away from a policeman while waiting for an elevator in the psychiatric building at Bellevue Hospital on Jan. 4, the police raised to five the number of recaptures among fourteen prisoners who had escaped in recent jail breaks.

Aside from the canal building hysteria of the early nineteenth century, New Jersey was the first state to recognize the potential value of navigable inland waterways as a means of travel, especially for recreation of the general public, and in 1908 the Inland Waterway Commission was created.

FROM all reports this looks like the biggest winter sports season in the history of American skiing. More people are taking up the sport and for their convenience more resorts are open, with more slopes, more tows, more of everything needed to make a successful winter season.

The Albanian Government has implied that the mines that tore holes in two British warships in the Corfu Channel and set off a bitter dispute between London and Tirana were laid down by Greek vessels, it was disclosed yesterday.

THE Polar regions are attaining an importance they have never had before. For centuries they were zones of mystery and much of them is yet unknown. make it difficult to reach. In the Arctic an ice-covered ocean is surrounded by land, from which adventurous souls have been able to push on by ship and air.

The first large-scale rental housing project in the New York area to be approved under the liberalized provisions of Section 608 of the National Housing Act was announced yesterday by Thomas G. Grace, New York State director of the Federal Housing Administration.

Activity in financial markets last week was overshadowed by President Truman's three messages to Congress. While more attention was given to the messages than to trading in securities, the financial community came to the conclusion that, as has been the case with Presidential messages, they represented a political point of view.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (U.P.) -- Albert W. Jacobson, former Chemical Warfare Service legal consultant and a key figure in the Garssons munitions inquiry, was found dead late today in his automobile.

The United States Government is in the boat and marine equipment business, too, through the United States Maritime Commission, the agency charged with the disposal of surplus wartime marine materials.

Maintenance and improvement of waterways by the Federal Government have been under the direction of the Corps of Engineers, United States Army, since about 1825. Prior to 1932 the primary basis for favorable Congressional action had been the benefit to commercial navigation.

HAMILTON, Bermuda -- Four months have passed since Bermuda's Motor Car Act, legalizing the general use of ten-horsepower cars and taxis, went into effect. In that time it has become apparent that the days of the horse-drawn vehicle are numbered here, although the bicycle is going as strong as ever.

WASHINGTON. I MAY be rushing in where angels fear to tread in offering advice to the party which won the Congressional elections in November. But I am not doing so on my own initiative, but at the request of the new YORK times; and I trust that the suggestions I shall offer will be accepted as sincere and not in any sense presumptuous.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The domestic shipping fleet, unable to make a profitable return to free enterprise, will probably continue under deficit Government operation indefinitely, it was indicated today in a report of the Interstate Commerce Commission.

MOSCOW, Jan. 11 -- The food situation in the two Soviet Republics of the Ukraine and of White Russia is extremely unfavorable, according to the heads of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration in those areas.

The National Sportsmen's Snow which will return to its old home in Grand Central Palace this year, is scheduled to run from Feb. 15 to 23, and according to its sponsors will offer the largest and most diversified program in the history of the exposition.
Ten years pass quickly and those who a decade ago thought that boats had reached the peak of development may well be wondering what boats and equipment will be ten years hence.

THE 1947 series of garden lectures will open at Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, on Jan. 29. This will be the first in a series of four programs, which will be held afternoon and evening of four consecutive Wednesdays.

Monthly installment payments by veterans on home loans made in the past two years by savings and loan associations and cooperative banks have reached a "near-perfect" record of 99.8 per cent, according to Walter W. McAllister of San Antonio, president of the United States Savings and Loan League.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 11 -- Governor Earl Warren's espousal of some form of State-wide health insurance, involving prepaid medical care, centered attention this week on what promises to be, as it was in 1945, the most controversial issue before the California Legislature.

ALBANY, Jan. 11 -- AttorneyGeneral Nathaniel L. Goldstein, in an opinion submitted to the Superintendent of Insurance today, paved the way for post-war construction by Insurance companies on leased properties.

Figures released at the local office of the Board of Election in the Borough Hall at St. George yesterday showed how rapidly Richmond County, for many years under the Democratic banner, was becoming a Republican county.

PROVIDED the amateur has at least some basic knowledge of photography, the camera-club talk or demonstration can be a fruitful source of information and guidance. One successful amateur, Mrs. Flora K. Howes, president of the London Terrace Camera Club, recently said that she had learned from camera-club lectures most of what she knows about photography today.

Maj. Gen. Harold N. Gilbert, whose administrative leadership of two of the largest military agencies in history earned him the appellations "Builder of the Armies" and "The Army's Master Salesman," has retired from active duty, the War Department announced yesterday.

VAUDEVILLE may be dead, but vaudevillians are not. They are writing books, like Sophie Tucker, Joey Adams, Benny Rubin, Willie Howard, Senator Ford, Harry Hershfield, Joe Laurie Jr. -- and now George Jessel. As you know if you listen to the radio, George is now a picture producer with Twentieth CenturyFox, but if his soul belongs to Darryl Zanuck his heart still belongs to vaudeville.

HOLLYWOOD. THE strike by the Conference of Studio Unions against film producers and the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes, now in its fourth month, has developed into a war of attrition and words.

LIKE a fife and drum corps, a circus calliope or a fire gong, the mournful wail of a locomotive whistle has magic power to quicken the pulse and turn sober, dignified citizens into eager schoolboys. Kip Farrington takes note of this trait with an excerpt from The Brattleboro (Vt.) Reformer that sets the pace for his latest book:

Under existing law, Congress has a major question of policy to decide before June 30. The question is whether money contributed to the Federal Government by the taxpayers of the country is to be loaned to or invested in private business and, if it is, for what purposes, on what terms and in what circumstances.

NEW DELHI, Jan. 11 -- British circles are still awaiting definite assurances from Mohammed Ali Jinnah, Moslem League president, that the League will enter the Constitutionmaking task in view of this week's Congress party resolution.

THE freak weather of last Sunday showed at least what can and what cannot be done about the weather. Snow, sleet, lightning and thunder built up suddenly and unpredictably in an area where flying should have been routine.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 11 -- The text of the speech delivered by Senator Vandenberg before the Cleveland Council of World Afairs: I congratulate the Cleveland forum upon the powerful program it has produced from all quarters of the globe in a striking exchange of international opinion.

TOKYO, Jan. 11 -- The resignation in mass of the Cabinet of Premier Shigeru Yoshida -- the fifth to hold office in Japan since the surrender -- today appeared as an increasing: possibility, according to well-informed political circles here. Such a resignation has apparently become a pre-requisite to any attempt to form a new national Government by the inclusion of Sociallist members of Parliament in the Ministry.

TO THE EDITOR: I read your article on "Chinatown -- Not East, Not West" I found it quite interesting and yet having lived in Chinatown ever since I can remember -- for fifteen years -- I would like to enclose my views on the subject.

ASHFORD, England, Jan. 11 (U.P.) -- A British Overseas Airways Corporation Dakota transport ran out of gasoline late today while trying to find a fog-free airport and crashed a few miles from the cliffs of Dover. At least five of the seventeen persons on board were killed.

A victory that did not seem possible when the opposition soared to an 11-point lead early in the second half went to the City College basketball team last night at Madison Square Garden. The speedy Beavers, rallying dramatically in the most thrilling and best-played court contest of the season, fashioned a 63-62 conquest over St. Joseph's of Philadelphia before 18,478 spectators who were limp from excitement at the end.
Lawrence Briggs of Massachusetts State College was elected president of the National Soccer Coaches Association of America at its annual meeting here yesterday, succeeding Robert Dunn of Swarthmore.

OUT of the bedded coals of medieval history Selma Stern has uncovered the flames of evil and destruction that swept the Jewish people to mass deaths and suicide in the fourteenth century. These were the dark days when the fate of the Jews in the towns and communities along the Rhine brings to mind recent grim events.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Senator Francis J. Myers, Democrat, of Pennsylvania, proposed in a letter today to Dean Acheson, UnderSecretary of State, that the United States submit the entire problem of Palestine immediately to the United Nations.

New Yorkers this year are going to have the rare opportunity of seeing the Gold Cup race run in the metropolitan area. They are doubly fortunate in that this promises to be the best of the forty contests for the ugly goldplated urn which has become motor boat racing's most highly prized trophy.

Acting Director, U.S. Coast and Geodetic Survey Dept. of Commerce The recent publication of a new nautical chart by the Coast and Geodetic Survey, Department of Commerce, covering Gravesend Bay and The Narrows at the entrance to New York Harbor directs attention to the important improvements in hydrographic charting of this area during the war period.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Congratulations on your excellent editorial on "Byrnes to Marshall." As a contemporary evaluation it has the soundness of long-timed interpretations by historians. The high editorial standards which you set, as our daily historian, can well form the pattern for American scholarship.

"FAMILY CIRCLE," by Eve Merriam, is an interesting group of poems. Archibald MacLeish writes, in the preface, that Miss Merriam's poems are not of the order etched on stone but are written to mean and be forgotten. Their temporary being, however, he believes to be their quality, not their defect.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 11 -- Making his fortieth annual speech from the throne at the reopening today of the Riksdag, King Gustaf, who is 88 years of age, echoed Sweden's desire to push atom research. He also stressed the nation's concern over threatening inflation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- There is mounting evidence in the files of the Washington fact-finders that prices generally have passed their peak, or certainly are approaching very close to the top level that may be expected.

The 1947 Elco fleet is made up of five models, all newly designed with their origins in the famous PT boats. They start with a 27foot Sport Cruiser and include the 35-foot Cruisette, 40-foot Express Cruiser, 47-foot DeLuxe Cruiser and the 62-foot Motor Yacht.

WACO, Tex., Jan. 11 (AP) -- Bob Woodruff, line coach at Georgia Tech, today was named head football coach at Baylor University. Woodruff signed a three-year contract at an undisclosed salary. He said he would bring three assistants with him, but did not name them or indicate from what colleges they would come.

Five hundred and twenty transactions involving approximately $7,503,300 were handled by the Bergen County branch office of J. I. Kislak, Inc., at 15 Main Street, in Hackensack, N.J., during its first year of operation, the company announced yesterday.

More than 50 per cent of the nation's business with comprehensive sales organizations are facing thorough "rehabilitation" of sales staffs from top executives down, James C. Olson, partner in the management consultant firm of Booz, Alien Hamilton, disclosed in an interview last week.

PARIS, Jan. 11 -- Dr. Walter H. C. Laves, who since 1943 has been a consultant on international affairs in the White House executive offices, has been appointed Deputy Director General of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

-- THE SENATE Impressively the United States Senate convenes -- "the world's most august deliberative body." At almost the same moment a professor of political science in Minnesota suggests that it should be organized on the basis of population, or perhaps abolished entirely.

SWEEPING changes in the distribution and exhibition of motion pictures -- changes which overlap the confines of trade boundaries, since they will most certainly affect public interest in this vast entertainment empire in many direct and indirect ways -- are ordered by the final cconsent decree determining the Government's nine-year-old antitrust action against the major film producing-distributing companies.

A GAY and spritely excursion into, fantasy has come up on the CBS wave length in the form of an importation from Canada: "Once Upon a Tune." Its authors, Morris Surdin and Ray Darby, both late of Toronto, have allowed their imaginations to frolic in the realm of pure fable and with delicacy and wit shown once more the sheer enchantment of true make-believe.

The proposal that a labor court would be "the fairest way" to deal with current problems facing management and labor was made yesterday at the Youth Forum conducted by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast over Station WQXR.
Since marine lubricants and gasoline play a part in the operation of many of the craft at the show, the oil companies naturally are represented.

AFTER the thundering accounts and analyses of China by foreign pundits, "Stories of China at War" conies with mocking voice to underscore an old truth: China can be known and felt best only in its native idiom.

LOS ANGELES: PARADOXICALLY, at a time when such hard-headed showmen as Billy Rose lament that producing even hit shows is uneconomic, there comes an aspirant solution for the theatre's perennially red-ink stained problem child, civic repertory.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 11 -- Through strengthened adherence to the ideals it holds in common with the United States the British Commonwealth of Nations has become more firmly united than ever, Lord Inverchapel, British Ambassador to this country, asserted here today.

Salary increases were advocated by Harry J. Carman, dean of Columbia College, in his annual report to Dr. Frank D. Fackenthal, acting president of Columbia University, which was made public yesterday.

Activity in all markets picked up considerably last week as the expected large number of buyers began to arrive in New York, according to a market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the McGreevey, Werring Howell Company.

ELIZABETH HAWES paints a striking picture of industrial America, from the underside. It Is a very competent picture. You seem to see with your own eyes what the author saw with her extremely keen vision. And she saw a lot.

The liner Monarch of Bermuda, well known to pre-war travelers from, this port, will re-enter the New York-Bermuda run late this summer or early in the fall, it was announced yesterday by Henry Smurthwaite, United States director for Furness, Withy & Co., owners of the vessel.

MEXICO CITY -- The winter season which got off to an excellent start in December is now in full swing with droves of visitors from the United States, who did not care to leave their own firesides until after Christmas, pouring across the border.

LAKE LENORE, Wash., Jan. 11 (AP) -- The rock walls of Grand Coulee echoed with the sounds of an artillery barrage Thursday as the War Assets Administration staged a "baby Bikini" to destroy ten tons of metallic sodium in the salty waters of Lake Lenore.

THE dynamic and dramatic qualities in paintings by B.J.O. Nordfeldt have never been more in evidence than in his current show at Georgette Passedoit's Gallery. With each exhibition there has been fearless experiment and daring innovation, but dramatic quality and drive have lent integrity and unity throughout his long career.
Before the war the smaller motor boats and even the larger power yachts up to those approximately 100 feet long were as a matter of course built of wood.

An immediate flood of orders from distributors and wholesalers swamped manufacturers of builders' hardware, plumbing and heating supplies and contractors' supplies last week, following the virtual ending of the CC priorities system by the Civilian Production Administraton of the Office of Temporary Controls.

IN case a theatregoer is interested in the world of today, his attention is respectfully directed to "Temper the Wind." A thoroughly engrossing drama, it puts into play form the intricate and endless problems of administering Nazi Germany after the war.

FRANCE is issuing a new series of postage dues with "Timbre Taxe" replacing the familiar 'Chiffre Taxe' along the base. The atter wording means literally 'Figure Tax"; the value of denomination appears as a large central figure or numeral.

IN 1819 the forests along the West Branch of the Susquehanna were filled with fine straight pines that were later to give shelter and a livelihood to the hardy settlers who came there. One of the first to stake his claim along the river is lanternjawed "Pa" Murphy, so called because, though only in his early twenties, his demeanor is overly sober and reserved.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 11 -- The latest pronouncement from Washington on the fate of the Japanese Empire has revived the misgivings over the position of the United States regarding the United Nations Trusteeship system.

Aluminum boats, not exactly new but coming into increasing vogue, are attracting attention at the boat show. Light weight, of course, is a primary consideration with the man who wants a small boat he can transport and carry readily, but other advantages are claimed.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 11 -- Three famous architects, Howard Robertson of Britain, Charles Le Corbusier of France and Oscar Niemeyer of Brazal, will probably be selected with seven other eminent designers to help draw up plans for the international skyscraper capital of the United Nations, it was learned today.

The price of butter dropped 3 cents yesterday in most of the city's retail stores, passing on to the housewives the decline in the wholesale price to the lowest point in five months that took place Friday.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Jan. 11 -- Communist Minister of the Interior Laszlo Rajk announced today the a prominent deputy of the majority Smallholders party, Kalman Salata, intimate friend and one of the political advisers of Prime Minister Ferenc Nagy, was a member of the committee of seven leading the alleged conspiracy to overthrow the Government.

Unification of all relief groups in the United States sending aid to the people of Germany was urged yesterday by Hans A. Specht, chairman of the American Committee for the Relief of German Needy. He spoke at the second annual convention of the committee in the New York Turn Verein Hall, Lexington Avenue and Eighty-fifth Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- A record of how the American National Red Cross rose to emergencies of the war years was revealed here today in a report covering the seven years from July, 1939, to July, 1946.

THE current literary season has, apparently, dedicated itself to rescuing the lost men of American history. Stewart Holbrook's recent and delightful exercise in historiography remains the comprehensive volume on the subject.
In its program of park and parkway expansion and other related improvements, the New York City Park Department has made a point of providing facilities for local pleasure boating enthusiasts.

WHEN I wrote "Years Ago," I forgot something. I forgot to write an epilogue. Perhaps it was inexperience or perhaps it just slipped my mind, but at any rate, people keep writing in to find out what happened.

GREAT wars affect the way women dress, and there are books and pictures to prove it. The results, however, are not always predictable. For the changes produced by the two world wars are as unlike as muskrat and mink. The elegant, glittering fashions recently shown in the plush salons of Paris, London and New York are nothing like those of the early Twenties -- when women gained the vote and lost their femininity.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics, in a summary of 1946 strikes, asserted today that if the industrial disputes pattern of 1919-20 constituted a parallel for the period following the second World War the country in 1947 might expect "somewhat fewer work stoppages and a substantial drop in the number of large-scale controversies such as occurred in late 1945 and in 1946."

Domestic and Foreign For Harry S. Truman, last week was one of the busiest since the early months of his Presidency. The President's activities made the headlines every day. These were the highlights of his week: On Monday he appeared before a joint session of Congress to read his State of the Union message.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Jan. 11 (AP) -- Purdue University's basketball team defeated Notre Dame, 60 to 56, tonight as a late Irish rally faded when freshman star Kevin O'Shea fouled out of the game. It was the Purdue Boilermakers' last test before starting their Western Conference schedule and their fifth victory in six starts.

WASHINGTON. THE cross that John Nicholas Brown, the new Assistant Secretary of the Navy for Air, has had to bear is that from boyhood through young manhood the Sunday supplements printed splashy features about him at least once a year, reminding their millions of readers that he was "the richest baby [later bachelor] in the United States."

MIAMI, Fla. -- The natives of Florida's East Coast, and many of their winter guests, too, are worried. What bothers them is not their current prosperity but the question of comparatives: Will this be a good season, a better season (better than most, that is), or will it be the best season ever?

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 11 -- Gov. Ellis Arnall today resigned "effective immediately after" the qualification of M. E. Thompson as Lieutenant Governor so that he may take over "the executive powers of government."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The problem of denazification has played a prominent role in the administration of the United States zone of Germany and in the meetings of the Control Council. The subject is on the agenda of the topics to be discussed in the next meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers at Moscow.

LONDON, Jan. 11 -- Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery, Chief of the Imperial General Staff, returned to Britain today from Moscow. He appeared highly appreciative of all he has seen in his five-day goodwill mission.
As progress continues on various new residential centers on Long Island, new homes are accounting for most of the realty trading.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Lynn Joseph Frazier, former Republican Senator from North Dakota, died tonight at the Leland Memorial Hospital in suburban Riverdale, Md. His age was 72.

THE avalanche of new compounds with striking insectkilling abilities that began with the appearance of DDT a few years back shows no signs of slowing down. New insecticides that in some respects are as good, or better than, DDT are being proclaimed by scientists.

NANKING, Jan. 11 -- One reaction to Gen. George C. Marshall's report on the Kuomintang-Communist peace negotiations of the last year is shared by virtually all Chinese. With their deep-rooted feeling for moral values they have acknowledged its straightforward honesty and sincerity.

A magnificent backhand drive by Al Parsells from the boards close to midring gave his Ramapo trio an 8-7 overtime decision over Red Bank in a tense and, at times, rough indoor polo match at Squadron. A Armory last night. The winning shot hit the goal just fourteen seconds after the throw-in for the sudden-death extra session.

American business men have clearly indicated their desire to see the British imperial preference agreements made the touchstone of the eighteen-nation reciprocal trade agreement negotiations which are planned for April this year in Geneva, trade circles pointed out last week.

Albany Message New York is the nation's most populous State and therefore it is a key factor in national politics. Its 1947-48 budget is $650,000,000 -- more than was spent in 1945 by Pennsylvania, Massachusetts and New Jersey combined.

RUTLAND, VL, Jan. 11 -- Running her characteristic forceful race, Miss Rhone Wurtele of Westmount, P. Q., was outstanding in a formidable Held of twenty-five today in the downhill phase of the first women's United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association's championships since 1941.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- A team of Government and industry experts will descend on La Guardia Field, New York, tomorrow on the first leg of a unique expedition to slash red tape which is snarling the great upsurge of post-war air commerce.

LAKELAND, Fla. -- The West Coast of this land of sunshine and citrus fruits is enjoying a boom season, no matter what is going on in the East Coast and other resort areas of the Southland. They highways are filled with cars wearing "foreign" license plates, and the problem of finding accommodations is indeed a problem if the tourist is particular about where he stays.

Problems of Security At Lake Success last week the United Nations Security Council considered two problems that had dominated the international gatherings in New York last month. The first problem concerned disarmament and the atomic bomb.

FOR THIS WEEK: Watch for a bud to appear from the amaryllis bulbs started a month or six weeks ago. Then move to a lighter and warmer place and increase watering.... Look over house drains and gutters to be sure they are not dripping on shrubs or perennials. If necessary, protect plants with a burlap or lath screen.

When it was announced, some weeks ago, that the 1947 International Gold Cup Regatta would be held in Rockaway Inlet on Aug. 10, subject to A.P.B.A. approval, many speedboating enthusiasts openly expressed their surprise.

Construction work is progressing steadily on the new apartment house of the luxury type at 3 East Seventy-first Street, and several suites already have been sold in advance in this "cooperative," Norman Tishman, vice president of the Tishman Realty Construction Company, reported yesterday.

ALMOST every soldier promised himself at some time during the war that he would not budge from his own back yard once the fighting was over. But today a sizable group of ex-service men has left home to attend schools in foreign lands on four continents.

ROME, Jan. 11 -- Italian socialism split today into a majority movement, which favors evercloser cooperation and ultimately fusion with the Communists, and a minority movement, which stands for freedom and autonomy of the Socialist party.

A second record was set yesterday in the thirty-fifth annual Christmas appeal conducted by THE NEW YORK TIMES as the number of donors to the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund reached 14,065. This is thirty-five more than the high mark of 14,030 set a year ago.

Dartmouth's losing streak at basketball was extended to eight games last night when Columbia beat the Green, 60-56, before a packed house at the Morningside Heights Gymnasium. This was the Lions' first Eastern Intercollegiate League game, but the Indians suffered their second circuit defeat in two nights.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Documents published by the State Department tonight on the Paris Peace Conference of 1919 revealed that in the course of the negotiations a significant warning of a second World War, with disastrous consequences to western Europe, was given by Gen. Tasker H. Bliss, a member of the United States delegation and former Army Chief of Staff.

To the Drama Editor: AFTER experiencing the last three theatrical seasons in Europe, aggravated by war and post-war conditions, I cannot agree with your critic's observation that the American theatre lacks sufficient contact with ideas from abroad.

Fredell Lack, young American violinist, gave her third New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. Her program included the first performance of three "Impressions From the Odyssey" by Frederick Jacobi, as well as the William Walton Violin Concerto and compositions by Vitali, Pergolesi, Schubert, Stravinsky, Kroll and Sarasate.

Editor New York Times Book Review: I'M afraid Mr. Abaya's letter doesn't lessen the confusion in American minds regarding the Philippine collaboration issue. Things get especially confusing when Mr. Abaya insists that he worked for the puppet Government to gather intelligence but denies the same privilege to President Roxas.
Once you've got that new boat you'll be interested in devices promoting your own safety as well as that of the craft. The Motor Boat Show has a number of items worth consideration.

ZACHARY TAYLOR, the twelfth President of the United States, was one of two professional soldiers to reach the White House. A much less able general than Ulysses S. Grant, he was, in his brief term, a much more respectable President.

ABOARD MOUNT OLYMPUS, in the Ross Sea Ice Pack, Jan. 11 -- Twelve days after they disappeared into foul weather over Antarctica six members of the crew of the Navy expedition's missing plane were sighted shortly after noon today, New York time.

ABOARD MOUNT OLYMPUS, Jan. 11 (AP) -- The search, plane from the tender Pine Island of the expedition's Eastern group found the survivors and the wreckage of the lost aircraft at 12:29 P. M., Eastern standard time. It then reported:

A group of men and women at Bellevue Hospital's Institute of Rehabilitation looked on with wonder Friday as patient after patient rose from wheel chair and bed to achieve victory over disabilities that long had denied them normal life.

The recent proposal by Assemblyman Edmund P. Radigan that Staten Island secede from New York City met with criticism yesterday on four fronts. The critics were Staten Island's State Senator, its Borough President, its Republican county leader and its sole member in the New York City Council.

The resignation of Secretary of State Byrnes and of Bernard M. Baruch and his associates, and the appointment of General of the Army George C. Marshall as Mr. Byrnes' successor, is a disturbing interruption in the continuity of our foreign policy.

The "Oh Niners," the volunteer civilian boat specialists who joined the United States Army Corps of Engineers, may remain unknown and unsung to the public at large, but deep in the annals of World War II there are recorded numerous exploits that bear evidence of a valuable contribution by these men to that new type of warfare commonly known as amphibious operations.

TOKYO, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Government workers, estimated by the Kyodo News Agency to total 40,000, rallied in the Palace Plaza tonight and threatened to strike to enforce demands for union contracts and minimum wages.

An unusually interesting program, featuring Richard Strauss' "Metamorphosen," which received its New York premiere, was presented by the Boston Symphony Orchestra, under Serge Koussevitzky, yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. Martinu's "Concerto Grosso for Chamber Orchestra," and Berlioz' "Harold in Italy" Symphony, with Jascha Veissi as the viola soloist, completed the offerings, all of which were superlatively performed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Senate Republican leaders today picked Senator Hickenlooper, Republican, of Iowa, to head the SenateHouse Committee on Atomic Energy. The move is regarded as insuring full GOP support of the Baruch "no-veto" plan for world development of the resource.

Department store sales by reserve districts, as reported by the Federal Reserve Board, are listed in the following table which gives percentage comparisons with a year ago: Weekly index, without seasonal adjustment, 1935-39 average equals 100:

OTTAWA, Jan. 11 -- Continuing their policy of orderly removal of emergency controls as production increases and the danger of shortages causing prices to soar is eliminated, Canadian price control authorities today announced the release from control of a long list of goods and services.

The elusive business of bringing Charlie Trippi into the Yankee organization both as a baseball, as well as football, player got under way late yesterday afternoon when the Georgia All-America backfield star arrived in town.

THIS is the eighth and the "Golden Jubilee" edition of "The Boston Cooking-School Cook Book." It is a work that ever since its authoress, "at the earnest solicitation of educators, pupils and friends," first put it forth in 1896 -- a small, mousetinted volume -- has justly earned the lady an undying regard.

NEWARK, N. J., Jan.11 -- The Federal Court trial of Joseph S. Fay, vice president of the International Union of Operating Engineers, AFL, for evasion of more than $100,000 in income taxes was thrown into a dramatic flurry this afternoon.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 11 -- One year ago the 800,000 members of the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, were prepared to begin the first industry-wide wage strike in the union's ten-year history.

LOS ANGELES -- California's celebrated missions, almost as familiar a symbol of the State as the Eiffel Tower is of Paris, are to be rebuilt and restored at the cost of half a million dollars in a project that will be meaningful to future travelers.

AN entirely new class of tourists will help swell the travel figures of the future, in the opinion of Lord Hacking, chairman of the Travel Association of Great Britain and Ireland, who is at present in this country conferring on British travel plans.

"MAN'S HOPE," the legendary Andre Malraux film which is scheduled to have its first public showing in this country on Friday at the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse and the Fifth Avenue Playhouse, was written, directed and produced by the author himself under extraordinary circumstances in Barcelona in 1938.

THE novels of Rex Warner, better known and more widely appreciated in his native England than they have so far been in this country, are in several respects as distinctive a genre as they are distinguished literature. Reading any page at random, one knows at once that this is writing of an elegance, music and compression rare enough at any tune, and particularly in our own.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 11 -- With the civil war continuing and United States policy uncertain, the Central Government is making, an inventory of its, assets here. It is going ahead with its policy of husbanding these resources and increasing the selfsufficiency of Shanghai as the economic heart o of Nationalist China.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- President Truman touched on housing in three messages to Congress this week. In all of them he told the dominant Republicans, gently and variously, but in so many words: "It's up to you, boys."

In calling attention to the exhibit of the Detroit Diesel Engine Division of General Motors, W.C. Gould, marine sales manager, points out that in 1946 preliminary surveys developed that 75 per cent of all Diesel horsepower installed was of the light weight, high speed type.

The library of first editions, illustrated books, a large number of Kate Greenaway items and other literary material formed by Mrs. George A. Martin of Cleveland will be auctioned tomorrow and Tuesday in four sessions at 2 P.M. and 8 P.M. at the Farke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.

HOLLYWOOD. IN the San Fernando Valley twenty miles north of here, where Hollywood peasants can see the setting sun simultaneously melt the mountains on their left and pink the peaks on their right, you follow a rutted dirt road to the home of a demonstrative Russian actor and drama theorist named Michael Chekhov.

Verdi's "Aida" was given last night at the Metropolitan with Ella Flesch in the title role for the first time here. Robert Merrill sang his initial Amonasro with the company at this event, and Kurt Baum appeared as Rhadames, a part he had not assumed previously this season.

A three-day meeting, under the auspices of the Canada Steamship Lines, opens tomorrow in Chicago, to plan travel promotion for this season in Eastern Canada and on the Great Lakes Traffic officials of the company from many parts of this country and Canada are expected to attend the sessions.

On the theory that a good forced landing is any one that the participants can walk away from, the Classon Avenue police station, Brooklyn, credited Stanley Miller, operator of a Putnam Avenue trolley car, with a good stop at Fulton Street and Lafayette Avenue yesterday although six automobiles were damaged.

A former convict was shot and killed by a patrolman in civilian clothes in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon under circumstances so peculiar as to precipitate investigations by ranking police officials in the borough. The fatal shooting topped a crime score sheet that showed entries of hold-ups, burglaries, a $5,000 safe robbery, and assault and robbery in the five boroughs.

Announcement of the team that will be invited to meet the British in this year's resumption of the Walker Cup matches at the St. Andrews Club, Scotland, May 16 and 17, was made yesterday at the fifty-third annual meeting of the United States Golf Association at the Waldorf Astoria.

FORTY-THREE years ago, on an October evening, a young Austrian scholar, Otto Weininger, Ph. D., killed himself in the same old Viennese house where Beethoven had died. A few months before that act of despair, 23-year-old Weininger had published an ambitious psychological treatise, "Geschlecht und Character" ("Sex and Character"), a 600-page affair.

HANOVER, N.H., Jan. 11 -- Dartmouth's hockey team, racked up its sixth victory of the season with a 7-to-4 triumph over the Yale sextet tonight. The outstanding play of the game came half way through the second period when Bruce Mather sank the rubber unassisted for Dartmouth with two of the Green players in the penalty box and the entire Yale team on the ice.

Visitor From Italy Alcide de Gasperi, 65, who has been Italy's Premier since June 12, 1946, governs an impoverished land. Many of Italy's 45,000,000 people exist on sub-subsistence diet; a black market flourishes. Two million of Italy's industrial workers are unemployed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) -- The Navy has announced receiving this afternoon a terse radio message from the Antarctic expedition reporting the sighting of the burned wreckage of the plane that set out Dec. 30 for a photo-scouting flight along the coast of Ellsworth Land and had since been missing.
TO THE EDITOR: Justice Jacob Panken's article, "The Real Delinquent -- the Parent," is sound and timely. But Justice Panken fails to tell, us why the parent is delinquent.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 11 (AP) -- Lets Dance, 5-year-old gelding from the Sunshine Stable, scored a surprise victory today in the $50,000-added mile and one-sixteenth San Pasqual Handicap at Santa Anita Park. Olhaverry was second, with Texas Sandman third.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The American Federation of Labor today protested against the decision reported from Paris a few days ago that officials of the World Federation of Trade Unions had decided to favor forced labor in the Ruhr coal mines.

Marshall Takes Over Gen. George Catlett Marshall has faced many great responsibilities in his life. In December, 1941, when war came to America he faced the task of winning a global conflict. Last week he took over the assignment of winning a global peace.

A former convict was shot and killed by a patrolman in civilian clothes in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon under circumstances so peculiar as to precipitate investigations by ranking police officials in the borough. The fatal shooting topped a crime score sheet that showed entries of hold-ups, burglaries, a $5,000 safe robbery, and assault and robbery in the five boroughs.

Announcement of the team that will be invited to meet the British in this year's resumption of the Walker Cup matches at the St. Andrews Club, Scotland, May 16 and 17, was made yesterday at the fifty-third annual meeting of the United States Golf Association at the Waldorf Astoria.

FORTY-THREE years ago, on an October evening, a young Austrian scholar, Otto Weininger, Ph. D., killed himself in the same old Viennese house where Beethoven had died. A few months before that act of despair, 23-year-old Weininger had published an ambitious psychological treatise, "Geschlecht und Character" ("Sex and Character"), a 600-page affair.

Revelations contained in the wire-tapping records at the bribery trial of Alvin J. paris, would-be fixer of the Giants-Bears football game, resulted yesterday in a political upheaval in Elizabeth, N.J.

TEXAS became a Republic in 1836 and for nearly ten years remained a Republic -- with Ministers abroad and the Lone Star flag at home. Texans never forget the fact of that Republic and seldom allow anyone else within reach of their voices to ignore it.

"Carmen" was presented last night at the Metropolitan Opera House with a new Don Jose and a new musical director. The new tenor was Mario Berini, who made his debut Nov. 28 in "Faust." The conductor was Max Rudolf, who joined the musical staff last season.
The Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo preached his last two sermons yesterday as minister of the Collegiate Church of St: Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.

Mr. and Mrs. Lindsay Bradford of 215 East Seventy-second Street and New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dorothy Walker, to Dr. John Blasdel Shapleigh 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Blasdel Shapleigh of St. Louis.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 12 -- Leaders of the opposition to Premier Ahmad Ghavam's new Democratic party apparently began exercising the ancient Persian custom of "royal refuge" today to protest against the Government's method of conducting the current national elections.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Jan. 12 (U.P) -- A fire started today in the Terra Haute House, a ten-story hotel, but quick action by fireconscious, guests and a young hotel employe, whose baby daughter died in a fire recently, prevented injuries, panic or serious damage.

SUFFERN, N.Y., Jan. 12 -- It was late yesterday afternoon when Mrs. Robert Gramweher began wondering about the silence. She looked out the window to where here children had been playing noisily, yelling, throwing snowballs and riding a sled.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Jan. 12 -- Reverberations of the Alvin Paris football bribe case in New York were still being heard here today as preparations were made to impanel the January term Grand Jury at the Court House on Tuesday.

An estimated half million workers, led by 6,917 chairmen, will participate in the 1947 March of Dimes drive, which begins Wednesday, it was announced yesterday by Basil O'Connor, president of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis. In a fifteen-day campaign they will seek a minimum of $24,000,000.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I noted with pride how the New York City police worked on the parking situation in midtown. A motorist myself, it is a relief to be able to cross Manhattan so rapidly. I think your paper is due a lot of credit for constantly reminding the public about the difficulty and danger of parking, etc.

The Young Men's Board of Trade of New York, 291 Broadway, acting as coordinator of the efforts of business and industry, lists the following free services to aid veterans in career-planning and employment: ADVERTISING -- Job Interviews conducted by Veterans Guidance in Advertising and Selling.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Jan. 12 -- The cornerstone of the Central Synagogue of Nassau County was dedicated here this afternoon, with Christian clergymen and village and county officials joining in welcoming the new religious institution to the county.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Looking over the prospects for 1947, international aviation, American and foreign, sees a 267 per cent rise in passengers over the great shakedown year of 1946, in which the post-war world routs pattern was crystallized and this country firmly settled its policy on the five freedoms of the air.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Income payments to individuals rose to a new high in November -- at an annual rate of $174,200,000,000 -- the Department of Commerce reported today.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 12 -- France's demand for a share in the exploitation of the American-controlled Arabian oil resources has attracted great attention in the press here. The outcome is being watched as a possible precedent for efforts by other powers, notably the Soviet Union, to break the virtual monopoly held by Britain and the United States in the Middle East's petroleum.

PARIS, Jan. 12 -- To insure against future aggressions on her eastern border, France desires to see the Ruhr, the Saar and the Rhineland detached from Germany and the creation of a decentralized German federation.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Enjoyed your editorial about moonlight skating in yesterday's paper. But where is there such a pond as you describe within range of New York City? I know there must be many such in Jersey or Westchester which can be reached by bus or train in half an hour or so.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 12 -- The Preparatory Commission of the International Refugee Organization will meet for the first time on Feb. 11 in Geneva, it was announced today. This was considered an important step toward an international program of assistance for the 1,000,000 refugees in Europe.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Jan. 12 (AP) -- Al Casale of Bloomfield, N. J., won the senior men's title in the Eastern speed skating championships today when young Linus Fobare withdrew a protest upon which Casale had been disqualified in the 220 yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- A Senate subcommittee of the seventy-ninth Congress called today for "a complete overhauling" of the War Assets Administration "with respect to top personnel, internal organization and policies."
C.H. Stephens has been named sales manager by the Philadelphia and Reading Coal Iron Co.

LONDON, Jan. 12 -- British industrial problems are becoming increasingly difficult every day. Many industries now are suffering from insufficient coal and the electricity industry constantly is having to restrict power. Added to this, there are obvious signs of labor discontent in persistent disputes.

Larger Rug Promotions Although the 1947 advertising schedules of all rug manufacturers have not yet been completed, it was indicated in the trade last week that this will be a year of expanded promotions, compared with 1946. Two major manufacturers have all but completed increased schedules calling for larger space allotments in newspapers and magazines, in addition to regular trade-paper schedules.

Camilla Williams, soprano, gave her first New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall before a large and responsive audience. The program presented econtained the aria, "Dove sono" from Mozart's "The Marriage of Figaro," and that composer's "Allelujah;" German Lieder by Schubert, Brahms and Strauss; French lyrics by Faure and Bizet; English songs by Barber, Diamond, Dunhill and Giannini, and a final group of Negro spirituals.

BERLIN, Jan. 12 -- Germans of all political persuasions saw some hope of unification of Germany this week-end as Ambassador Murphy departed for London. They had reason to believe that unification was now in the interest of the principal protagonists involved -- the United States and Britain on the one hand and the Soviet Union on the other.

The program of assistance for the survival of the Jews in Europe should stress reconstruction rather than relief, Herbert H. Lehman, former director general of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, declared yesterday.

Gov. Ellis Arnall's announcement that he will resign tomorrow when (or if) Lieut. Gov.-elect M.E. Thompson is sworn into office brings to immediate issue the distracting question of constitutional government in Georgia.
