This would seem the normal procedure for carrying out the will of the people, or at least the will of the only effective minority of Georgia's citizenship, as expressed in the last State election.
Dr. Alcide de Gasperi, Premier of Italy's infant democracy, arrived in New York yesterday for a two-day visit.

ATLANTA, Monday, Jan. 13 (U.P.) -- S.A. Kemp, assistant regional administrator of the CAA, said today that the failure of the WinstonSalem radio beam could not have contributed to the airliner crash near Galax, Va.
ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- Republican leaders are pressing for speedy action by the Legislature on the appropriation of $25,000,000 to provide a State-financed pay increase for all public school teachers.

At Sterling Oval in the Bronx yesterday, the New York Americans gained the verdict over the Brooklyn Wanderers, 3 to 2, in their American Soccer League match. The home team was leading by 2-0 at the change of ends.

BERLIN, Jan. 12 -- For the past two and a half months, George M. Mardikian, owner of Omar Khayyam's Restaurant of San Francisco, has been traveling from one Army mess to another in occupied Germany. He has been trying to figure out ways to make Army food taste better.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 12 (AP) -- George Fazio of Los Angeles, and lanky Ed Furgol of Detroit posted fifty-four-hole totals of 213 today to finish in a tie for first money in the $10,000 pro-amateur golf tournament sponsored by Bing Crosby.

AMSTERDAM, Jan. 12 -- The Netherlands stepped up its industrial production considerably in the twelve months ended in October. This is shown by the Statistical Bureau's new combined production index which, on the basis of 1938 equaling 100, rose from 53 in October, 1945, to 79 in September, 1946, and to 89 in October.

Emanuelina Pizzuto, young pianist, well known to radio listeners, made her first personal appearance in recital in this city last night at Times Hall in a program consisting of four works for piano and orchestra, one by Bach, the Concerto in F minor, and three by Mozart.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Jan. 12 -- Embitterment in Great Britain at the failure of Switzerland to do her expected share in the "job of world reconstruction" owing to a "rigidity of outlook of powerful Swiss banking groups," as reported from London in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Dec. 23, has aroused fear in Switzerland that unless the real facts are disclosed now, international business relations would be vitiated without justifiable reason.

LONDON, Jan. 12 -- Ambassador Robert D. Murphy and Gen. Mark W. Clark arrived in London today for the meeting of the Big Four Foreign Ministers' deputies, which begins here Tuesday. Mr. Murphy will represent the United States on the German question and General Clark on Austria.

It was New York over Boston, on both counts in the matinee hockey double-header at Madison Square Garden yesterday. In the feature game on the program the Rovers handily subdued the Boston Olympics, 6 to 1, and in the preliminary clash a team of all-stars from the Metropolitan Amateur League set down the Boston Olympic Juniors, 2 to 1.

CHICAGO, Jan. 12 -- The supply of feed grains in this country is more than ample to cover domestic and foreign needs, the Department of Agriculture reported last week. However, the possibility of a shortage of wheat later in the season is mentioned by brokers as a result of the department's estimate that farm holdings of 366,000,000 bushels on Jan. 1 were only 5,000,000 in excess of last year.

LONDON, Jan. 12 -- Stock market activity here remains on a substantial scale but the signs are that more attention is being paid to unfavorable economic factors. Boom conditions noticeable at the opening of the new year have been modified, though the importance of these factors on industry has not yet been fully recognized.

An outstanding wonder of the present age is man's growing mastery over the facts and forces of life, but his control over the world is absolutely dependent on his self-control, the Rev. Dr. William Pierson Merrill declared in a sermon yesterday at the Brick Presbyterian Church, 1140 Park Avenue.

Ingrid Robertson, soprano from Philadelphia, where she studied at the Curtis Institute, gave her first New York recital yesterday afternoon at Times Hall before an enthusiastic audience. The performance justified the enthusiasm, for Miss Robertson displayed an unusually fine voice with real art, musical feeling and intelligence.

RUTLAND, Vt., Jan. 12 -- Canada's spectacular skiing twin sisters, Rhoda and Rhona Wurtele of Westmount, Que., dominated the renewed women's United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association's combined downhill-slalom championships that finished a two-day run this evening at Pico Peak.

DETROIT, Jan. 12 (AP). -- Registering four goals in an impressive shooting display in the final period, the Detroit Red Wings treated 13,633 fans to a 5-to-1 National Hockey League victory over the Boston Bruins tonight.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Further cuts in tariffs on imported goods and commodities that compete with American products were vigorously opposed today by spokesmen for wage-earners and farmers.

The Fathers of the New YorK Apostolate Mission Band celebrated yesterday their golden jubilee of religious service. A solemn Mass of thanksgiving was held in St. Stephen's Roman Catholic Church, 149 East Twenty-eighth Street, from which parish the organization has worked for forty years.

Politicians who say that taxes can be slashed while the peace is being won are "guilty of deception," United States Senator Wayne Morse, Republican, declared here yesterday. He criticized "those pressure groups" inside and outside of Congress that are calling for a cut in Federal taxes, terming them "isolationists in disguise."

Arguments supporting continuation of present tariffs on various rubber products have been filed with the State Department by the rubber mechanical goods, rubber footwear and the rubber drug sundries divisions of the industry, it was announced over the week-end by the Rubber Manufacturers Association.

Repeating his victory of last year, Champion Monarque of DahLyn, owned and handled by John B. Royce of Brookline, Mass., was named best of breed at the fiftyninth specialty show of the Pekingese Club of America at the Hotel McAlpin yesterday.

Alas, poor Horatio! On the 115th birthday yesterday of the man whose name symbolized an era in American history, a poll taken among boys and girls from the ages of 8 to 14 revealed that Horatio Alger Jr. was almost an unknown to them.

Philip Freund, author of "Edward Zoltan," part of a trilogy on New York City, will have two books published by Beechhurst Press this spring. "How to Become a Literary Critic," which will be issued on Feb. 21, is a collection of essays on writers and critics.

One hunderd and fifty national leaders of the United Office and Professional, Workers, CIO, voted yesterday to seek a 30 per cent wage increase for all white-collar workers as a means of restoring their living standards to 1939 levels.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Jan. 12 (AP) -- Syracuse University's Archbold Gymnasium, a campus landmark for forty years, was destroyed early today by a three-alarm fire of undetermined origin.

A trip into deepest Africa to bring, back to this country Tare birds never before seen in captivity will be taken by D.L. Mobley, superintendent of the world-famous Santa Catalina Island Bird Park, it was learned yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 12 (AP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks, finally showing signs of life after a prolonged term in the National Hockey League cellar, fashioned their third straight victory tonight by downing the Montreal Canadiens, 3 to 1, in a rough-and-tumble match before a sell-out Chicago Stadium crowd of 18,537.
Republican moves to treat unions as "monopolies" drew fire from all sections of the labor movement yesterday.

The New York City Airport Authority submitted to Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday a proposal for development and operation of the city's airports by supplementing the municipal investment of about $91,000,000 with $80,000,000 of Authority financing by means of forty-year bonds bearing interest of approximately 2 1/2 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- L. Metcalfe Walling, Administrator of the Wages and Hours Law, minimized today the ultimate liability in the staggering portal-toportal pay suits, but asked Congress for authority to make binding interpretations under the act to enable him to protect honest employers from civil and criminal liability.

LONDON, Jan. 12 -- Troops were moving into the London area today, preparing to take over tomorrow morning the distribution of food and other essential supplies, which has been brought almost to a standstill by the week-old truck strike.

A majority of the nation's top economists who attended the latest economic forum sponsored by the National Industrial Conference Board see a recession for 1947, the board announced over the weekend. They generally agree, however, that the effect will approximate the setback of the Nineteen Twenties rather than that of 1929.

Christians are, in a sense, "committed to compromise" in working out the problem of applying the ultimate truths of their religion to specific modern needs, the Rev. Dr. C. Ivar Hellstrom, associate minister of the Riverside Church, declared yesterday in his sermon.

Over two hundred diseases that afflict animals and plants have been traced to viruses. Poliomyelitis is one of these. News came from California last Friday that Drs. Hubert S. Loring and C.E. Schwerdt of Stanford University had obtained a concentration of polio virus which was at least 80 per cent pure.

Secretary of Commerce W. Averell Harriman's recent order directing immediate transfer of the New York Customs statistic section to Suitland, Md., for consolidation with the headquarters unit there has been deferred for two months.

Unless productive efficiency of American labor is Increased, another general wage increase now only will mean still higher prices, according to Dr. Jules Backman, Associate Professor of Economics at New York University, in a study entitled "Wages and Prices" released for publication today by The Foundation for Economic Education, Inc., Irvington-on-Hudson, New York.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 12 -- Spurred by a wave of automobile casualties startling even to a city of superlatives, Los Angeles authorities are coming to grips with a traffic problem which is almost literally inconceivable in New York terms.

Holding in reserve the possibility of a resort to new or heavier special taxes as a means of balancing the city's budget for 194748, Mayor O'Dwyer, Controller Lazarus Joseph and the leaders of the Democratic minority in the Legislature have agreed unanimously to intensify and accelerate their campaign for a substantial increase in State aid.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 12 -- The steel industry was able to raise its operating rate to 90 per cent of rated capacity last week, up 3 points from the week before. Barring serious labor disturbances or a complete drying up of the scrap flow, observers here believe that the rate will fluctuate around 90 per cent for several months.
SHANGHAI, Jan. 12 -- Across the street from Ward Road Jail, reported to be the largest municipal "pokey" in the world, is a small shabby-fronted restaurant called "The White Horse."

For the eighth successive year, earnings of the Irving Trust Company increased in 1946, operating profit amounting to $6,764,109, compared with $6,608,012 in 1945, according to the bank's report to its stockholders, just issued in advance of the annual meeting on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations, fighting a battle on two fronts -- one against the restrictive legislation promised by the Eightieth Congress and the other for wage increases this year -- renewed its attack today.

NANKING, Jan. 12 -- President Chiang Kai-shek praised Gen. George C. Marshall's report on his China mission and placed the blame upon the Communists for the continuance of civil war in China in an interview here today with this correspondent and two other American newsmen.

California gathered the third largest crop of figs in its history last fall. In addition, figs have been arriving in the United States recently in sizable quantities from Turkey for the first time since Pearl Harbor. Total supplies, as a matter of fact, give the illusion of being even greater than they are, because the armed forces have ceased to take the large proportion of the domestic harvest that they did during the war.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan. 12 -- War Veteran Vincent Kasky of Greenfield, Mass., wearing the colors of the Edelweiss Ski Club, soared high and handsome to capture the Franklin D. Roosevelt Ski Jumping Trophy today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 12. -- J.M. Noriega, Mexican production manager for RKO, disclosed today that his company had completed Spanish remakes of three RKO films under its new Mexican production program and that a fourth remake is scheduled for the cameras in February.

DEL MONTE, Calif., Jan. 12 (U.P.) -- Fred Corcoran, tournament manager of the Professional Golfers Association, tonight threatened to sue Dick Metz as a result of their Friday night fist fight, which appeared today to have brought to a dead long-standing friction in the ranks of the pro linksmen.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Gen. George C. Marshall will find complete blueprints of the current United States diplomatic policy toward every major foreign country when he sits down at his State Department desk this week.

Charley Rayner did not shut out the Toronto Maple Leafs in the National HocKey League game at Madison Square Garden last night, but the goalie for the New York Rangers did the next best thing. After yielding two goals to the league-leading Leafs in the first period, Rayner played perfectly through the second and third.

ROME, Jan. 12 -- Two rival Socialist party congresses were in full swing in Rome today. The larger one was that of the old Socialist party, which is now definitely committed to merging with the Communists in the more or less distant future.

PARIS, Jan. 12 -- This week starts an intensive period of politics in France. Members of Parliament will reassemble tomorrow and take their political positions on the organization of both Houses Tuesday.

Contrary to rumors of impending dissolution of the Committee for Economic Development, it will hold a series of meetings in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel this week at which Paul G. Hoffman, the chairman, will ask the trustees to name new executives in a reorganization program.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 12 -- As the strike of 580 employes of The Philadelphia Record entered its tenth week, the homes of an executive of the newspaper and an official of the American Newspaper Guild, CIO, were defaced when jars of paint were thrown through windows and doors.

Ordinarily the report of a concert in the daily press consists in a review of performances. But there is more than that to chronicle about the program given by the League of Composers last night in the Museum of Modern Art, in honor of Sergei Koussevitzky.

After a Sabbath, interlude, the amazingly popular National Motor Boat Show, which crowded its gunwales to overflowing Friday night and all day Saturday, will resume this morning at 11 o'clock for six full twelve-hour days at Grand Central Palace.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 12 -- Attachments, which froze the bank accounts of two Connecticut companies being sued for portalto-portal pay, have been released by the unions, their attorneys announced today.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Jan. 12 -- In a clear northerly atmosphere and a fine gentle breeze, ten races were held today by the Dinghy fleet at the Larchmont Yacht Club. Thirty craft competed, the top number of the winter season here so far.

WEEK ENDED JAN. 11, 1947 It was another week of light business and minor price changes in the foreign exchange market. Interest centered almost entirely in the routine day-to-day requirements which were negotiated at no striking variation over those of the preceding week.

A sane view of life demands self-forgiveness, the Rev. Dr. F. Eppling Reinartz, pastor of the Evangelical Lutheran Church of The Holy Trinity, Central Park West at Sixty-fifth Street, declared yesterday.

WESTFIELD, N.J., Jan. 12 -- Announcement has been made here by Judge Shackleford Miller Jr. of Louisville, Ky., of the engagement of his daughter, Frances Effinger, to Robert A. Hultgren, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur C. Hultgren of this place.
The Thirty-fourth Street Midtown Association announced yesterday that it was conducting a smoke abatement campaign in the area between Thirtieth and Thirty-eighth Streets, East River to North River.

ABOARD MOUNT OLYMPUS, Jan. 12 -- The six survivors of the Dec. 30 crash of the Navy Antarctic expedition plane were picked up early today from the ice fringe of the Ellsworth Land Coast and flown to warm bunks aboard their base ship, the seaplane tender Pine Island.
MOSCOW, Jan. 12 -- The United States was sharply reminded today by Izvestia, Government newspaper, that the Kurile Islands were now Russian territory and would remain so.
LONDON, Jan. 12 -- Partial resumption of trading for private account in foreign exchange begins in London tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (U.P.) -- America's merchant fleet is dropping steadily toward its pre-war size, which caused a transportation crisis when the nation went to war, the industry disclosed tonight.

Gunnar Johansen, Danish pianist and composer proved his right to a place among the leading keyboard artists of the present time, at his first New York recital given last night at Town Hall. His playing exhibited a rare combination of intellectual keenness, emotional warmth and sensitivity.
F.S. von Stade, who heads the Saratoga Racing Association, has been re-elected president of the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association, it was announced yesterday.

Retail sales last week were maintained at a fairly high level with the result that buyers in the wholesale markets were again placing orders with more confidence for spring business, according to the reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.
To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The radio industry's firing of liberal commentators is alarming and is reminiscent of the elimination of the opposition in countries where fascism won power.

When a series of airplane crashes, major and minor, come close together, as they have in the extremely bad weather prevailing in many parts of the world in recent weeks, the effect on public confidence is likely to be out of proportion to the statistical facts. A number of the recent accidents have occurred to unlicensed carriers and to lines operating under special circumstances, such as those in China.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 12 -- Mexican authorities are investigating the case of four to seven United States fishing vessels rounded up by the gunboat Guanajuato for netting shrimp in waters of the Bay of Campeche, it was learned today.

The bipartisan unity and high level of statesmanship that have distinguished American foreign policy during the past year attained a new and fitting expression in the speeches by Secretary of State Byrnes and Senator Vandenberg before the Council of World Affairs in Cleveland.

ATHENS, Jan. 12 -- Albanian implications that Greeks might have laid the mines that struck British ships in the Corfu Channel were authoritatively said today to be baseless. The suggestions were held to be part of a systematic and intense application of the "smear" technique allegedly used not only by Albania but also by the rest of the Slavic bloc before the arrival here of the United Nations investigating committee.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your publication of Jan. 5 you print a letter of Professor Graham of Princeton University, purporting to point out fallacies in present discussions about wage increases.

A preview of typical post-war financing requirements of local Governments and a market test likely to influence the price levels of tax-erempt securities for weeks to come are seen by investment men here in a succession of major municipal utility bond issues aggregating $95,461,000 now on their way to market from Western communities.
CHICAGO, Jan. 12 (AP). -- Robert R. Young was revealed today to be planning to establish the nation's first coast-to-coast railroad system, a project which Federal agencies have long opposed.

Big Jobs for Two Men Our neighbors to the left on this page have noted the great opportunity to make architectural history which has been presented to Wallace Harrison as Director of Planning for the group of buildings destined to take care of the central activities of the United Nations.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Henry Ford 2d today declared that the price level in the United States is "too high."

The Board of Education announced yesterday the largest budget estimate in the history of New York City's public school system. The school officials propose to spend $175,075,182 during the year 1947-48. This is $17,243,000 more than the current budget.
Widespread need of day care services for GI student families was reported yesterday by the Child Welfare League of America's committee on day care.
TOKYO, Jan. 12 -- Within the past fortnight there have been two developments in the problem of the cost of our occupation.

Textile distributors have expressed their willingness to cooperate with dress manufacturers in advancing seasonal opening dates, it was announced over the weekend by the Textile Distributors Institute. Rayon converters said that they will be ready to show fall goods next month and spring and resort fabrics in October, thus advancing their openings by about forty-five days.
A reading of the budget message submitted to Congress by President Truman on Friday suggests an almost infinite number of editorial possibilities. This essay will confine itself to two.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (U.P.) -- Nearly 200 House members, all veterans of World War I or II, will meet tomorrow to map strategy on legislation aimed at showing exsoldiers, sailors and marines, sponsors of the gathering say, that they are not "the forgotten men and women" of 1947.

GALAX, Va., Jan. 12 -- An Eastern Airlines passenger plane from Detroit to Miami crashed and burned during a rainstorm in the high country ten miles west of here early today, killing fifteen passengers and the crew of three.

High food costs may cause an increase in the number of tuberculosis cases and deaths in America, Dr. Edgar Mayer, chairman of the National Medical Advisory Board of the National Jewish Hospital at Denver, said yesterday.

A system that would permit unions to regulate their own labor practices, rather than the imposition of rigid governmental controls, was proposed for Congressional consideration yesterday by George W. Morgan, president of the Association of American Ship Owners.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Under a Washington dateline of Jan. 2 you printed an Associated Press dispatch stating that Secretary of State Byrnes has instructed our embasssy in Warsaw to expedite action of visa applications of Poles desiring to enter the United States.

SAARBRUECKEN, Germany, Jan. 11 (Delayed) -- With the food situation grave, French officials here expect most of the gains made in coal production and in the direction of winning support for an economic union with France will be seriously jeopardized if the local population is not fed better within three months.

Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander, in orders issued for to day, cited 211 policemen for meritorious conduct in line of duty. Honorable mention, the nigh citation signifying conspicuous bravery, went to six men, one posthumously.

Dark since the hasty departure on Jan. 4 of "Love Goes to Press," the Biltmore is to be relit Wednesday evening, Feb. 5, with "Apartment 17-B." George Abbott, director and co-producer with Richard Aldrich of the Virginia FaulknerDana Suesse comedy, has been susceptible to Wednesday night premieres for a long time.

MANILA, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Mount Mayon, the Philippines' most spectacular volcano, covered 50,000 square miles of sky with sulphurous smoke today and gave out sharp reports like cannon fire which hastened the steps of villagers fleeing from its oozing streams of lava.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- The Commerce Department said tonight that enough meat may be produced this year to provide every person in the United States with 150 pounds, more than at any time in the last thirty-five years.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On Tuesday, Jan. 14, Dr. Albert Schweitzer will celebrate his seventysecond birthday in the forests of the Ogowe, in Gabon, French Equatorial Africa. Few Americans have an adequate estimate of the power and significance of Dr. Schweitzer's life.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The first floor fight of the Eightieth Congress will open in the Senate tomorrow over the question of continuance of the Senate War Investigating Committee -- the former Truman Committee later headed by James M. Mead.
TEL AVIV, Palestine, Jan. 12 -- Terrorists blew up the northern district police station in Haifa tonight.

Between 75 and 80 per cent of member firms outside of New York, which supply a large part of the business of the New York Stock Exchange, oppose the permissive incorporation amendments, the Committee in Opposition to Passage of Permissive Incorporation Amendments reports in a second folder to the member firms today.

NEW DELHI, Indian, Jan. 12 -- M. Asaf Ali, India's first Ambassador to Washington, will turn over his Government portfolio of Transport tomorrow and expects to leave about Feb. 5 for the United States.
PARIS, Jan. 12 -- Premier Leon Blum got first-hand reports on Indo-China today from the two principal French emissaries that had been sent to that troubled area.

WARSAW, Jan. 12 -- The Polish election campaign draws to its bloody and violent end this week. Only the post-election attitude of the United States and Great Britain remains as a question still unanswered.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (U.P.) -- House records disclosed today that seventeen of the thirty-three Townsend National Recovery Plan workers registered with Congress as lobbyists get a share of membership dues from the nation-wide string of Townsend clubs instead of salaries.

Among the art events opening this week will be an exhibition on Wednesday at the Brooklyn Museum by the Brooklyn Society of Artists honoring the organization's thirty-first annual exhibition. The Wildenstein Galleries have selected from their extensive collections paintings by famous Italian artists of other centuries.

BOSTON, Jan. 12 -- A questionnaire sent out by the Association of American Colleges indicated a majority of the member institutions favored Federal aid, but Dr. Guy E. Snavely, the association's director, declared today he was "dead opposed" to such financial help.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (U.P.) -- Representative Stephen Pace, Democrat, of Georgia, said today that the new Congress must go to work immediately on a long-range program to support farm prices if it is to avert "an agricultural debacle worse even than in 1920."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (U.P.) -- Representative Stephen Pace, Democrat, of Georgia, said today that the new Congress must go to work immediately on a long-range program to support farm prices if it is to avert "an agricultural debacle worse even than in 1920."
After holding fairly steady within a narrow trading range during most of last week, cotton prices in the domestic market turned sharply lower as the period drew to a close.

Coincident with the announcement of the most comprehensive ratings the National Boxing Association has undertaken since prewar days, President Abe J. Greene yesterday issued a statement recommending involuntary retirement for Fritzie Zivic, Pittsburgh ring veteran, who formerly held the world welterweight title.

Small business, purchasing through Reconstruction Finance Corporation, can exercise priority at a $20,000,000 original inventory sale of construction and farming machinery, automotive parts, hardware, plumbing and electrical equipment at the United States Army sub-depot, Voorheesville, N.Y., beginning today, Frank L. Seymour, regional director, War Assets Administration, announced over the week-end.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I would like to join officials of the U.N. in praising the splendid service rendered by THE NEW YORK TIMES in covering the recent General Assembly. As usual, your news reporting was factual, complete and timely. The Sunday Review Section was especially helpful in giving background material and interpretation.

LONDON, Jan. 13 (AP)--The dispute began a week ago when the truck drivers walked out. They demanded a forty-four-hour week, overtime pay after eight hours daily and other concessions. Their present pay is approximately $20 a week.

Net operating earnings of the Brooklyn Trust Company in 1946 amounted to $1,122,990, compared with $993,876 in 1945, George V. McLaughlin, the president, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday.

The National Council of Jewish Women appealed yesterday to national leaders of the Congress of Industrial Organizations to help make permanent the ouster of an employe accused of using her connection with the council to promote the Communist party line.

PARIS, Jan. 13--On the eve of the resignation of his Cabinet and at the start of France's crucial political week, Premier Leon Blum went to London today in a lastminute attempt to obtain a decisive improvement in French-British relations.

Cheered by word that the physician who operated on her successfully three years ago was flying to her bedside from Louisiana, Miss Anna Mayer, 23-year-old victim of a six-week attack of hiccoughs, was resting "a little easier" last night at her home, 122-67 South Ozone Park, Queens.

PARIS, Jan. 13--The report of Marius Moutet, Overseas Minister, on his trip to Indo-China, which may come up for Cabinet consideration tomorrow, is expected to characterize the present Viet Nam Government as extremist-controlled and to call its attack on the French last Dec. 19 as premeditated as the Japanese bombardment on Pearl Harbor.

A soldier of high achievement and a modest gentleman, if ever there was one, has been chosen to head the trade association of aircraft manufacturers in the United States. Selection of Maj. Gen. Oliver P. Echols as president of the Aircraft Industries Association affords an occasion to describe the vast and daily critical job he performed during the war.

ONE of the most interesting new arrivals upon the literary scene last year was a young English veteran named George Millar. In two companion volumes, "Waiting in the Night" and "Horned Pigeon," he wrote the best account of personal war experience I have read so far. The first was about Captain Millar's incredibly daring and hazardous adventures as a leader and organizer of an underground French resistance group.
ALBANY, Jan. 13--The Legislature was asked tonight to consider legislation cutting the total take on pari-mutuel racing from the present level of 15 per cent to 10 per cent.

Record Budget for 'Sanforized' The "Sanforized" label will be promoted by a record advertising budget of more than $1,000,000 this year, the tenth of general consumer advertising for the mark, Robert M. Dowling, advertising director of the "Sanforized" division of Cluett, Peabody and Co., Inc., stated yesterday.

Sweeping ahead with two laps remaining, Ray Blum of the Paterson Skating Club captured the two-mile Race of Champions that featured the twenty-third annual Silver Skates program sponsored by the News Welfare Association at Madison Square Garden last night.

LAKEWOOD, N. J., Jan. 13-- James Fullen, 24 years old, of Toms River, a Navy veteran, was held without bail in the Ocean County jail today on a homicide charge while police agencies continued an investigation into the mysterious death of his 22-yearold wife Jean here early this morning.

CHICAGO, Jan. 13--J.O. McClintock, vice president of the Continental Grain Company, today was elected president of the Chicago Board of Trade, defeating Harry C. Schaack, who has been president for the last two and one-half years.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 13 --The Westchester Board of Supervisors opened a new inquiry today into rising commercial rents and received from County Executive Herbert C. Gerlach a 7,000-word annual message on the state of the county.

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 13-- Continued rationing and price control of sugar, but under the control of the Department of Agriculture was urged today by the National Food Brokers Association at their forty-second annual convention at Haddon Hall Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The Metal Trades Department of the American Federation of Labor recommended today that its 1,500,000 members should not "dishonor" existing agreements by filing suits for portal-to-portal pay when such a demand was not taken up at the time the contracts were made.

Emmett R. Gauhn, chairman of the State Youth Commission, went on a tour of child care centers yesterday, to see for himself New York's need for such services. Accompanied by Welfare Commisioner Edward E. Rhatigan and Second Deputy Commissioner Crystal M. Potter, Mr. Gauhn visited three representative centers.

BERLIN, Jan. 13--The virtually unmanageable United States occupation organization is one of the principal factors in the slowness of weeding out key pro-Nazis and in the failure to make a better impression on the Germans we are trying to govern.

OXFORD, Miss., Jan. 13 (AP)-- Harold (Red) Drew today announced that he would resign after one season as head football coach at Mississippi to take over Alabama's gridiron machine from the ailing Frank Thomas.

Thirty years ago, when Mrs. Shapiro was a pigtail girl at grammar school, the "big guys" on the corner would sometimes sing: "And you wouldn't dare insult me, sir, if Jack were only here." Yesterday Mrs. Shapiro had a couple of uninvited guests--with pistols-- and Jack, her husband, was not around.
Early yesterday morning Delia Edwards clumped down the dark circular staircase in the old brownstone house at 247 Baltic Street, near Brooklyn's Borough Hall.

NANKING, Jan. 13--In his report on his China mission Gen. George C. Marshall said that one of the most important factors in the recent breakdown of KuomintangCommunist negotiations was the "dominant group of reactionaries" in the Kuomintang, who opposed almost every effort he made to influence the formation of a coalition Government.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13--The Braden - Messersmith controversy over United States policy toward Argentina has, for the time being, ended in a stalemate. As a result, one of Secretary of State Byrnes' recommendations to Secretarydesignate Gen. George C. Marshall is likely to be that he let the problem drift for a while.

LONDON, Jan. 13--The Burmese delegation and heads of the British Government held their first meeting here today. This evening at an official reception it was clear that both sides felt they had got off to a good start.

Net profit of the International Shoe Company for the fiscal year ended last November was $5,448,781, including a reserve credit of $1,000,000 and $2,211,001 estimated tax carry-back credit, the annual report showed yesterday.

ABOARD MOUNT OLYMPUS, Jan. 13 (AP)--Calm self-discipline and the leadership of Capt. Henry H. Caldwell were credited today with saving the lives of the six Navy men who were brought back by air yesterday to the Eastern group's seaplane tender Pine Island.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The Supreme Court today upheld, five to two, the lower court decision that the receiver of the National Bank of Kentucky in Louisville could not revive stock assessment suits against the executors of seven shareholders of the Banco Kentucky Company, a holding concern.

The Maritime Commission has approved the applications of two steamship companies for Government financial aid to enable them to meet lower-cost foreign competition between United States Atlantic and Gulf of Mexico ports and the West Coast of Africa, it was announced yesterday.

ABOARD MOUNT OLYMPUS, Jan. 13--The story of how six men of the Navy's Antarctic expedition--stranded on the ice plateau of the Ellsworth Land coast after their plane exploded-- kept alive for twelve days of frigid wind and blizzard, unfolded today as the six recuperated aboard their base ship, the tender Pine Island.
When the Water Level Limited arrived at Grand Central Terminal yesterday, attention was focused on its tiniest passenger, 4-year-old Nancy Drury, "polio poster girl" for the 1947 March of Dimes.

The proposal of the New York City Airport Authority to take over and develop Idlewild, La Guardia and Floyd Bennett Fields by supplementing the municipal investment of about $91,000,000 with $80,000,000 of Authority financing drew criticism yesterday from some airline officials.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13--By the narrow division of five to four the Supreme Court ruled today that Louisiana may lawfully order another execution for Willie Francis, the 17-year-old slayer who escaped death when the electric chair failed to operate.

A two-day study of the difficulties met by international air travelers when they pass through La Guardia Field's customs, immigration and public health offices started yesterday. Nine Government and airline officials landed at the Municipal Airport at 10:40 A.M. aboard a plane of the Civil Aeronautics Administration from Washington and immediately started inspections and discussions.

Expenditures for national defense constitute by far the largest single item in the President's budget. They alone, in fact, account for 30 cents in every dollar that the Government proposes to pay out. Moreover, the next two largest items--veterans' benefits and interest on the national debt--are for all practical purposes fixed items, incapable of reduction.

CHICAGO, Jan. 13--Removal of hedges against sales of wheat and flour for export and commissionhouse buying lifted wheat prices nearly 2 cents a bushel in the early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade.

LONDON, Jan. 13--Britain's industry will bear the brunt of the coal cuts necessary to spread the nation's limited fuel supplies to the greatest advantage during the next critical six weeks, Sir Stafford Cripps, President of the Board of Trade, announced today.
Stressing the need for a trade body that will specifically deal with boys' apparel, thirty-two manufacturers in that field organized yesterday a new association for the industry.

Benjamin H. Namm, president of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, last night called on the nation's retailers to undertake an aggressive campaign for the preservation of a free economy and to counteract the spread of "economic color-blindness which is the gravest danger we face today."
Omelio Agramonte, Cuban heavyweight, last night received the verdict over Teddy Randolph of Washington Heights in a disappointing ten-round bout at the St. Nicholas Arena. The decision was unanimous.
Despite the poor hunting conditions which prevailed throughout most of the deer season in New York, licensed shooters took 50 per cent more deer than in 1945.

Selective selling in the 1947 buyers' market was keynoted by executives of Kirby, Block Co. at a "Spring Accessory Clinic" for clients of the company held at the Hotel McAlpin yesterday. Bernard W. Smith, division merchandising manager, stated: "Manufacturers as a whole realize they are in a buyers' market.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 13--As a prelude to the opening of negotiations this week for a new wage contract with the basic steel industry, the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, expects to file thirty-day strike notices in Washington either tomorrow or Wednesday against an estimated fifty companies.

Although reconversion proved more difficult in many respects than were the adjustments to wartime needs, the Piper Aircraft Corporation, in a statement covering the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30 last, said yesterday that it was able to increase plane production "to a point considerably in excess of any rate previously attained by the company."

ALBANY, Jan. 13--Governor Dewey welcomed back to his Cabinet tonight Alger B. Chapman, who resigned as president of the State Tax Commission last summer to manage Mr. Dewey's campaign for re-election.

The London transport strike brings the British Government face to face with a critical problem of the same kind as those which confronted our own Government in last year's succession of paralyzing walk-outs in vital services. This problem is the paramount necessity of protecting the public.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The Navy Department has come forward with a proposed new method of budgeting its funds which would revolutionize its traditional fiscal practices, study of the pending Federal budget reveals.
The Ribbon of the King's Medal, a British award for citizens of foreign countries, was presented yesterday to 198 residents of the metropolitan area at a reception in the Plaza Hotel.

OTTAWA, Jan. 13--Defining Canadian policy in world affairs, Louis St. Laurent, Minister for External Affairs, in a speech, prepared for delivery in Toronto tonight laid down as the first general principle that it should not destroy Canadian national unity.

N.Y.U. and L.I.U., the local color-bearers in tonight's college basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden, will be tested by strong opposition when the Violets clash with North Carolina and the Brooklyn Blackbirds engage St. Louis. The latter contest will be the curtain-raiser, starting promptly at 8 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13--Dissension within the ranks of the National Woman's Party came into the open today with the revelation that a rebel group had attempted to take over party headquarters, the Alva A. Belmont House, on Capitol Hill, in the name of Mrs. John L. Whitehurst of Baltimore.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Jan. 13 --The Smallholders party today Began to evince the first faint stirrings of an intention to defy the attempt being made by the Hungarian Communists--with the backing of the Soviet Army--to rush the party out of the majority position to which the Hungarian voters elevated it in the last general election.

Store Sales Up 33% in Week Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores were up 33 per cent last week in comparison with the like week of last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

SAARBRUECKEN, Germany, Jan. 13--At the request of French Military Government officials, the twelfth anniversary of the Saar plebiscite was unmarked yesterday by any activity by the political parties in this province. However, 10,000 posters which with great secrecy were posted last night throughout this industrial area, reminded the 800,000-odd inhabitants that the French remembered the date well.
New steps were taken yesterday to offset the difficulties of two Protestant churches in Manhattan.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Jan. 13-- Free capitalism has been outlawed throughout half the world and in other areas free enterprise is being slowly strangled, William K. Jackson of Boston, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, said in an address here tonight.
LONDON, Jan. 13--Premier Blum of France arrived in London today on a surprise visit as a guest of the British Government "to discuss questions of common interest to the two countries."

The appointment yesterday of Whitelaw Reid as editor to succeed his father, Ogden Reid, who died on Jan. 3, was announced by The New York Herald Tribune. The appointment was made at a meeting of the board of directors of New York Tribune, Inc., which publishes The Herald Tribune.
MOSCOW, Jan. 13--The plan for production of tractors by the Ministry of Agricultural Machinery was not fulfilled in 1946, Pravda, official organ of the Communist party, revealed today.

Bernard Segall, Brazilian pianist, honored his former teacher and marked the tenth anniversary of his local debut by opening his program, at Carnegie Hall last night with ten of the preludes from Alexander Siloti's edition of Bach's "The Well-Tempered Clavier."

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 13--The Seattle Gas Company's amended plan of recapitalization, filed after the recent refinancing of the company's mortgage indebtedness, was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

A drop of 7 cents in the retail price of butter today will bring it to 70 cents a pound in most of the chain stores in the metropolitan area. Independent grocers, whose prices are in many cases a few cents higher, announced comparable reductions following yesterday's break of 6 and 6 1/2 cents in wholesale prices.
Robert K. Christenberry, president of the Hotel Astor, was reelected president of the Broadway Association yesterday at its thirtysixth annual meeting at the Hotel Astor.

An Army or Navy cook--or so one gathers from returned veterans--is a man who is grossly overpaid for turning good food into bad, or bad food into worse. Some men liked cooks less than buglers. But the Army thinks, and George M. Mardikian, a San Francisco restaurant keeper, thinks, that cooks are not so much malicious as misled.

ALBANY, Jan. 13--The State Senate by a unanimous vote tonight approved a $25,000,000 appropriation to complete the State's emergency housing program for veterans which is in danger of being stalled for lack of funds.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Jan. 13 (AP) --Notre Dame's Fighting Irish "make no apologies for wanting winners," the Rev. John J. Cavanaugh, C.S.C. university president, declared tonight in a challenge of "so-called reformers" of collegiate football.

When Science Droops On the one hand science, with the aid of the electronic microscope, has managed to get a glimpse of the virus of polio, of which 40,000 specimens can be aligned on the head of a pin.
Cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange moved yesterday in a fairly wide range, and closed irregular, 5 points lower to 15 points higher on the day.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- On the eve of the argument in the Supreme Court on the contempt conviction of John L. Lewis and the United Mine Workers of America, the Congress of Industrial Organizations filed today a brief with the Supreme Court challenging the Government's contentions.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A recent editorial from THE NEW YORK TIMES titled "Collective Bargaining" was reprinted in The Racine Journal Times by the J.I. Case Company. The editorial is based upon erroneous facts and it is for that reason that I am authorized to address this letter to you.

While estimating that the city's 1947-48 tax levy budget would not exceed $800,000,000, Controller Lazarus Joseph told the City Council finance committee at City Hall yesterday that he favored a three-point program to obtain additional financial aid from the State.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 13--In an unusual statement, Dr. Juan Atilio Bramuglia, Argentine Foreign Minister, tonight attacked United States Secretary of State Byrnes and called on George Messersmith, Ambassador to Argentina, now in the United States, to bear witness for him against Mr. Byrnes.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 13 --Activities at the United Nations headquarters here, which have slowed down since the close of the General Assembly last month, will be speeded up next week when full commissions of the Economic and Social Council begin daily meetings.

LONDON, Jan. 13--The French have abandoned their demand for political separation of the Ruhr and the Rhineland from the rest of Germany. This is perhaps the most important new factor in the situation faced by the Foreign Ministers' deputies as they prepare to start formal meetings on Germany and Austria here tomorrow.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 13 (U.P.) --A showdown between the battling touring professional golfers and their executives appeared in the making today as the players committee scheduled a special meeting to be held at Richmond, Calif., on Wednesday, just prior to the opening of the $10,000 Richmond Open tournament.

Baseball's 1947 spring training campaign, which already is set to establish some sort of mileage record, received promise of an additional international flavor yesterday when Branch Rickey announced that his Dodgers would engage the Yankees in six games on foreign soil next March.

LONDON, Jan. 13--The Judicial Committee of the Privy Council, the highest tribunal of the British Empire, delivered a judgement today that signed away its right to hear appeals from any Canadian court.

Back in Stride It has taken approximately one month following the strike's end for the nation's steel mills to return to the level of operations prevalent prior to the beginning of the soft coal strike last November.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 13-- California is consistently killing more persons on "congested, obsolete highways" than thrice-aspopulous New York and Pennsylvania combined, Gov. Earl Warren told the Legislature today. He appealed for a higher gasoline tax and other increased revenues for elimination of bottlenecks and construction of thousands of miles of divided roads.

RUTLAND, Vt., Jan. 13--The good-will developed in recent years between the United States and Canada on the ski hills will receive another impetus this week-end when rival women's teams from the Eastern sector of the respective countries come together at Mont Gabriel, Que., in the opening of the home-and-home competition.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Lyman P. Hammond, in a letter to THE TIMES published Jan. 4, advances a concept of national wealth which to my mind is singularly misleading. Rejecting national income as a criterion of the national credit position, he offers some vague and unsupported figures on "the assessed value of all taxable property" as proof that the national debt of $250 billions is "eating heavily into our capital."

WARSAW, Jan. 13--This is frankly an attempt to put down the Polish Government's point of view about the events in this troubled land--a point of view that Government officials say bitterly is not being presented honestly in the press of the United States and Great Britain.
ABOARD PINE ISLAND, Off the Antarctic Coast, Jan. 13--Diaries of the days passed on the ice were kept by Captain Caldwell and by Photo Mate Owen McCarty.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 13-- Comet Productions, the Mary PickfordBuddy Rogers-Ralph Cohn company, today signed Jackie Cooper for the leading role in "Stork Bites Man," a screen comedy which will go before the cameras Wednesday, with Cyril Endfield directing.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13--Like all other lesions in men and materials, Washington "leaks" come from all parts of the structure--top, side and bottom. But the leaks of the capital are unusual in that their source very seldom is the top. They usually appear lower down.
Henry Morgenthau Jr., general chairman of the campaign of the United Jewish Appeal for $170,000,000, called last night on all Americans to take an active part in its program.

"Sixty minutes to the hour," is the way veteran police reporters describe "Mike" Lyons and "Con" O'Leary in gabfests across the street from Police Headquarters. That is their way of saying that Third Deputy Commissioner Michael A. Lyons and Fourth Deputy Commissioner Cornelius O'Leary are officers who resisted the manifold temptations of the Tammany era and worked their way up from beat-pounding through merit alone.
The Board of Education's proposed budget for 1947-48--largest in the school system's history-- drew only qualified support yesterday from the United Parents Associations and the Teachers Guild.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13--The conviction of James M. Curley, Mayor of Boston, on mail fraud charges was affirmed today by a 2-to-1 decision of the United States Court of Appeals.
LONDON, Jan. 13--The truck strike had little effect in the stock markets here today and prices in most sections were firm.

Among the many problems that will confront General Marshall when he assumes office as Secretary of State will be to determine just what kind of relations we shall maintain with the new Communist-dominated regimes in the Balkans and in Poland. The problem arises because these regimes are creatures of outside forces seeking to perpetuate themselves in power by terror and fraudulent elections.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13--A Federal subsidy to go straight into teachers' pay checks would be provided under a bill just introduced by Senators Theodore Francis Green and J. Howard McGrath, both of Rhode Island.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Jan. 13-- Four hundred welders and burners, who walked off their jobs last Wednesday at the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company at Kearny, refused today to return until the alleged use of skilled workers at unskilled pay rates was remedied.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP)-- Sale of 20,000,000 Texas grapefruit for distribution throughout the British Isles was announced here today by Austin Anson of Harlingen, Tex.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 13--Part of Haifa was cordoned by 2,000 British soldiers and policemen in the search for terrorists who last night blew up the district police headquarters there, killing four and injuring sixty-six.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 13--Joseph S. Fay, fourth vice president of the International Union of Opperating Engineers, AFL, took the witness stand in his own defense today in Federal Court to deny that he willfully and unlawfully withheld income - tax payments from the Government on $186,000 of unreported income in 1940, 1941 and 1942.

Prices of oil burners for household and commercial use will probably be firm during the entire year and lower priced units are definitely in the planning stage for later production. The foregoing forecast was made yesterday by W.A. Matheson, executive vice president of Eureka Williams Corporation and president of the Oil Heat Institute of America, following the regular quarterly meeting of the directors of the Institute at the Hotel Commodore.

Recommendations that no reductions be made in duties on cotton textiles in the forthcoming reciprocal trade agreement negotiations are contained in a brief filed yesterday by the Cotton-Textile Institute with the Tariff Commission.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 13--Coincidental with the transfer of additional troops to Palestine, Lieut. Gen. Sir Evelyn Barker, British commander of Jerusalem, conferred here today with Gen. Sir Miles C. Dempsey, commander in chief of the Middle East, but a great secret is being made of his movements and the purpose of his visit.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- A clamor grew today in Congress for an investigation of airplane crashes and other phases of the giant aviation industry which is in the throes of operational reconversion and readjustment to business with the peacetime public.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your editorial entitled "A Test of Standards" in THE TIMES of Jan. 4 you very properly deplore the confusion attendant upon the attempts to bar Senator-elect Theodore G. Bilbo of Mississippi from taking his seat in the United States Senate.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Words are strange things. All of us are familiar with words that have changed their meanings from the original, until they now mean exactly the opposite of the first definition. I would like to know, quite seriously, if "unloosed" is one of these.

Reconversion of the Canadian Pacific Railway's "Princess" fleet to peacetime service is virtually complete, it was announced yesterday. Twelve passenger ships with accommodations for 10,000 persons are in operation between Pacific Coast points, Vancouver Island and Alaska.

The National Maritime Union, CIO, has asked Secretary of Labor Lewis B. Schwellenbach to appoint an arbitrator to settle the union's demands for a wage increase of 25 per cent from thirty-nine Atlantic and Gulf Coast shipping companies, it was announced yesterday.

There seems no limit to the boating excitement for 1947 caused by the revived annual show this week at Grand Central Palace. After letting the easy-going-vacationing cruiser skippers and outboard fishermen hold the limelight for the first couple of show days, the fraternity of daredevils who drive inboard and outboard pancakes at incredible speeds in regattas assembled yesterday from California, Florida, Canada and way stations.

WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 13 (AP) --Stockholders of Transcontinental Western Air, Inc., meeting after a long series of postponements, adopted today a resolution increasing the company's common stock from 1,000,000 to 3,000,000 shares.

For the second time since his conviction for bribery in his abortive attempt to fix the GiantsBears professional football championship, Alvin J. Paris was taken from the Tombs yesterday for a long talk with his mother, Mrs. Charlotte Ginsberg.
BOSTON, Jan. 13--Two prominent churchmen pleaded tonight before more than 600 leading educators for greater integration of religion and all education to promote unity and peace in the world.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13--The new Senate Republican majority ran into an intramural quarrel today, which threatened to cause it defeat in its first voting test.

In his Economic Report, President Truman pointed out three types of conditions under which he considers wage increases to be desirable: where productivity has increased, where wages have lagged "substantially" behind the increase in living costs in the past few years, and where wages are "substandard."

Dr. Alcide de Gasperi, Premier of Italy, whirled yesterday through the grand tour of the city that New York reserves for its distinguished visitors. In a motorcade, accompanied by piercing sirens of the motorcycle escort, he sped to a garment factory in downtown Broadway, returned to the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel to receive labor committees, then hurried to garment factories in the midtown area.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13--Remaining controls over the production and distribution of textiles were relaxed and consolidated into one master order today by the Civilian Production Administration Division of the Office of Temporary Controls.

After a voyage in which she was beset by mountainous waves and winds of hurricane force for all but a few hours of her time at sea, the America, of the United States Lines, arrived at Pier 61, North River, at 10:45 o'clock last night, bringing 1,005 passengers from Cherbourg, Southampton and Cobh.

Alarmed by the shortage of cooks and other restaurant personnel, the Society of Restaurateurs announced yesterday its intention of establishing a training school modeled after the Restaurant and Hotel School of Paris, France.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13--The Small Business Advisory Committee of the Department of Commerce advocates as a primary principle in labor-management relations that "the public interest must be paramount," W. Averell Harriman, Secretary of Commerce, reported today.

ATHENS, Jan. 13 (AP)--Sophocles Venizelos, a leader of the opposition to the Greek Government, demanded the resignation of Premier Constantin Tsaldaris today. In a statement issued after a conference with the Premier, he said he had told the Premier "there must be a change" to effect a coalition Government.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP)-- The Federal Power Commission announced today that the PennYork Natural Gas Corporation of Buffalo, N.Y., had asked authority to construct and operate a pipeline to transport natural gas for resale in Canada.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13--Col. Axel H. Oxholm, Norwegian-born forester, who took charge of fuel wood cutting for the Allied Armies during the 1944 invasion of Normandy and drive into Germany, was decorated today with the French Medal of Honor, Merit Agricole, in the office of Lyle F. Watts, chief of the United States Forest Service.

Katja Andy, German-born and German-trained pianist, gave her first New York recital in Times Hall, playing a Bach-Mozart program she had recently presented in Chicago. The Bach numbers were Toccata in D major, Partita in E minor, Prelude and Fugue in A minor, and the Italian Concerto.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 13-- President Eurico Dutra today condemned the Brazilian Communist party. He said that to vote for Communist candidates in Sunday's State elections would be tantamount to voting for a foreign power and for totalitarianism.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 13 (U.P.)--Sam Garfield's Shiny Penny, who was nosed out of the Dade County Handicap by Tarpan on New Year's Day, had little trouble winning the Maypole Purse at Tropical Park today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- War veterans in the House organized into an informal association today and named as chairman Representative Francis E. Walters, Democrat, of Pennsylvania.

MANILA, Jan. 13 (AP)--Mount Mayon volcano in southern Luzon, famed for its perfect cone, swelled and burst with an earth-shaking roar today, at 10:16 A.M., sending fiery lava and house-sized boulders two miles above its top.

LONDON, Jan. 13--The first indications of an early settlement of the illegal strike of London's truck drivers, which has paralyzed meat deliveries for almost a week, came tonight following a day in which troops had replaced the striker and delivered meat to retail stores.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13--In the last act of essential preparation for legislative work House Republicans accepted today a leadership slate of committee assignments which at every vital point had been picked with firmness and meticulous care.
New homemaking courses that will teach modern ways of shopping and decorating, among other topics, will be offered in evening sessions beginning this month in colleges, schools and libraries.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 13 --The social division of the United Nations revealed today that primarily as a result of the war, there now was a world shortage of more than 100,000,000 houses.

The stock market sustained yesterday its most serious reversal since early last December under a concentrated wave of selling. Prices were set back 1 to 4 points in a long list of key issues although peak losses were lightened when pressure lifted in the late trading.

YONKERS, N.Y., Jan. 13-- Panicky as smoke and flame in the eight-family house at 92 Vark Street cut off escape from her apartment on the fifth floor, Mrs. Josephine Morris, 24 years old, dropped her two children from a window, then leaped after them today. All three died within an hour in local hospitals.

ROME, Jan. 13--The twentyfifth Socialist party congress ended late tonight with a definite setback for communism. The principal aim of the organizers of the congress was to sanction evercloser cooperation, and eventually fusion, of the Socialist and Communist parties.

Although no contracts have been signed, Jed Harris has agreed to direct "Three Indelicate Ladies," the Hugh Evans comedy about three teen-age girls who run a detective agency, it was learned yesterday. Hunt Stromberg Jr., who is sponsoring the project in association with Irving Cooper and Jack Cassidy, would neither confirm nor deny the report last night.
ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 13 (U.P.)-- Movie Executive Louis B. Mayer tonight was reported negotiating the sale of his vast thoroughbred racing interests to an Eastern syndicate.
A former Soviet trade official who quit his post in Mexico to seek sanctuary here, came out of hiding yesterday to deny Russian charges that he was an embezzler.

SPORTS books of various descriptions have been piling up on this desk for the past few months. One of the best of them has been "The Detroit Tigers," written by the veteran baseball chronicler, Fred Lieb, and published by Putnam's. This is the tale of one of the fightingest ball clubs the game ever has produced, a team that always has teemed with color and class.

The United States will continue to insist upon the basic principles of the Baruch plan for international atomic control, including the abolition of the veto on punishment, it was announced last night after a conference between Bernard M. Baruch and Warren R. Austin, the new American representative on the United Nations Security Council.

ATLANTA, Jan. 13--The Talmadge and Arnall-Thompson forces each claimed a show of strength today in Georgia's unprecedented fight for the Governorship. Talmadge adherents were elected speaker and clerk of the State House of Representatives and Arnall-Thompson supporters were named president and secretary of the Senate.

Twenty-six persons contributed $156 yesterday to the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund conducted by THE NEW YORK TIMES. The amount collected since the thirtyfifth annual appeal started now stands at $388,653.13 and 'the number of contributors at 14,118.

Wintry weather, which calls for food that's warming as well as nourishing, is just the time for serving soups hearty enough to be almost a meal in themselves. Whether the stock is made from a bone left over from the Sunday roast or from fish or dried beans purchased especially for the dish, many soups provide a thrifty change from more expensive and elaborate menus.

An issue of $2,250,000 of School District 16 bonds of Escambia County, Fla., was awarded yesterday to a banking group consisting of the Chase National Bank, Harris Trust and Savings Bank, Whiting Weeks Stubbs and Emerson, Cook Co. at a bid of 102.19 for 2 5/8 s maturing from 1949 to 1968. The second-best bid was 102.109.
A former Soviet trade official who quit his post in Mexico to seek sanctuary here, came out of hiding yesterday to deny Russian charges that he was an embezzler.

SPORTS books of various descriptions have been piling up on this desk for the past few months. One of the best of them has been "The Detroit Tigers," written by the veteran baseball chronicler, Fred Lieb, and published by Putnam's. This is the tale of one of the fightingest ball clubs the game ever has produced, a team that always has teemed with color and class.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Jan. 14 -- A dividend of 50 cents a share on the common stock, the first in fifteen years, has been declared by the board of directors of the Elizabethport Banking Company here, it was announced today by Clarence R. Sanford, president, at the annual meeting of stockholders.

Third place in the National Hockey League standing beckons the Rangers tonight, and when the call comes it may find Frankie Boucher's squad handicapped by the absence of a vital unit. More important is the fact that the Blue Shirts need a victory or tie over the Detroit Red Wings at Madison Square Garden to maintain their hold on fourth place.
LONDON, Jan. 14 -- Military personnel continued to deliver London's strike-bound food supplies today as prospects brightened for early settlement of the truckmen's ten-day-old walkout.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Henceforth the vaunted Black Knights of the Hudson are going to take their football a little less grimly and play most of their games in their own backyard.

Charles E. Saltzman, vice president of the New York Stock Exchange and chairman of the New York City Committee for a nationwide $2,000,000 drive of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America, announced yesterday that a quota of $500,000 had been set for this city.

Award was made yesterday of bond issues aggregating $35,500,000 by the East Bay Municipal Utility District, California, to a banking syndicate headed jointly by Bank of America National Trust Savings Association and the National City Bank of New York.

The congregation of the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, organized as the Society of Christian Work of St. Nicholas Church, held its final meeting last night. Dissolving, the congregation disposed of its assets, $40,000 in cash and securities and property including church house chairs, dishes and silverware and books.

Devin-Adair will publish next Monday "Pearl Harbor: The Story of the Secret War," by George Morgenstern, an account of the back-of-the-scenes developments in Washington and Tokyo in 1941. It is based on public records and testimony taken in official investigations.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 14 -- The United Nations committee on the progressive development and codification of international law will hold its first meeting here in mid-March, Dr. Yuen-li Liang, director of the United Nations Division on International Law, revealed today.

Congress will be asked to make La Guardia Field a custom-free port of entry for transient goods and passengers, it was announced last night at the municipal airport after a day-long meeting of Federal officials surveying "red tape" that hampers international air travel.

ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- Internal strife in the Democratic minority was aired in the Assembly today when Leonard Farbstein was defeated, 9 to 133, in an attempt to obtain redress for a slight he claims to have received from Irwin Steingut, minority leader.

NANKING, Jan. 14 -- The first official Communist reaction to Gen. George C. Marshall's report on his China mission reached here tonight in the form of a Yenan broadcast of a speech by Gen. Chou En-lai.

While the Board of Health postponed a decision on compulsory vaccination of all 600,000 dogs in New York against rabies, it did enact measures yesterday to induce dog owners to protect their pets against the fatal disease.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 14. -- In a surprise move, the United States Steel Corporation stated late today that "by agreement" the opening of collective bargaining negotiations Thursday had been postponed until early next week. Spokesmen for both the corporation and union declined further comment.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In a letter published in THE TIMES on Jan. 2, the Rev. Karl Chworowsky writes, "We shall all want to see our great ship of state piloted safely to port, avoiding both Scylla and Charybdis, as did that little vessel which good old Ulysses brought successfully home."

BADEN, Germany, Jan. 14 -- French occupation officials said today that they saw no reasons to join the French zone with the United States and British zones in the near future for economic unity. Participation in the venture would cost France money to help subsidize British-United States occupation costs, it was said.

We believe Governor Dewey's committee on education has done some straight thinking in its report on teachers' salaries. It does not pretend to have found a permanent solution of the problem. Its most notable achievement is to have devised a formula that will provide greatest relief to distress cases, such as those in one school district where the minimum pay for a teacher was still $1,200.

Inflationary price rises must follow any further substantial upswing in wages, Albert Bradley, executive vice president of the General Motors Corporation, said yesterday at the eighth annual meeting of the National Council of Private Motor Truck Owners in the Hotel New Yorker.

Pvt. Daniel O. Pinchera of the 346th Ground Service Engineering Regiment came to New York last night and went to the theatre. He had been to New York before but had never gone to a Broadway show. It was a great event for Private Pinchera and for forty of his friends who were with him.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- A Congressional "big six" to replace the "big four" that conferred regularly with the President when Democrats held the majorities was projected today at the White House.

Nine Americans received decorations yesterday from the French Government for meritorious service performed during the war. At a ceremony at the French consulate, 610 Fifth Avenue, The Legion of Honor with the rank of Chevalier was conferred upon the following:

WARSAW, Poland, Jan. 14 -- President Boleslaw Bierut today rejected United States and British charges of political oppression by the Polish Government and told a news conference that he did not exclude the possibility" that the Government, after the election on Sunday, might order an amnesty or political prisoners.

The formation of a coalition Government, representing all political parties and strong enough to disarm conflicting factions, is the only solution of Greece's problems in the opinion of John Sofianopoulos, former Greek Foreign Minister, for whom a general press interview was arranged yesterday in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

DAVENPORT, Iowa, Jan. 14 -- The educational committee of the Board of Education today ordered distribution of copies of the New Testament in Davenport public schools halted after Rabbi Abram Vossen Goodman protested that the practice would "open the door to fantastic operations in the name of religion."

Salomon Brothers Hutzler will place on the market today $50,000,000 of serial and term debentures of Swift Co., meat packers. The offering consists of $35,000,000 of twenty-five-year 2 5/8 per cent debentures priced at 100 1/2 and $15,000,000 of serial debentures maturing from 1948 to 1957, inclusive, and bearing interest of 1.10 per cent for the first maturity to 1.90 per cent for that of 1957.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The Export-Import Bank earmarked $100,000,000 today as a conditional credit to be drawn upon by Italy in financing her imports from the United States.

BRUCETON, Tenn., Jan. 14 (AP) -- A Congress of Industrial Organizations' union drive to organize a shirt factory in this West Tennessee town today was interrupted by a band of men who were determined "to see that our women-folk could go to work without trouble."

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- The Netherland Government submitted to the Foreign Ministers' deputies today a comprehensive memorandum urging the creation of a confederation of German states with centralized economic administrations.

They are trying it again! Almost every four years someone decides there should be a law requiring the Federal registration of firearms, and on each of these occasions the sponsors have been able to prove that such a law would accomplish but one thing:

An oversupply of poultry, which has forced wholesale rates downward much faster than retail prices, gave promise to housewives yesterday of lower prices to come. Broilers and fryers, between 45 and 55 cents a pound at retail a few weeks ago, were 43 cents yesterday in chain stores and a few cents higher in most independent markets.

The thirty-first annual exhibit of the Brooklyn Society of Artists opened yesterday afternoon with a preview at the Brooklyn Museum, where, beginning today, it may be visited by the public through Feb. 9. Oils, water-colors, prints, drawings and sculpture are included, the material installed in the special exhibition gallery and in the main entrance hall.

PARIS, Jan. 14 -- Vincent Auriol, a Socialist, was re-elected today as President of the National Assembly and Auguste Champetier de Ribes of the Popular Republican party was re-elected as President of the advisory upper house, the Council of the Republic.

Almost every operation of the National City Bank of New York "whether in currency, checks, loans, foreign credits or bond transactions made new records" in 1946, according to the report to shareholders yesterday at the 135th annual meeting.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The letter from my old friend, Andre Michalopoulos, published in your issue of Dec. 18, was a strange and contradictory document. He began by agreeing with the friends of Greek democracy about Prime Minister Tsaldaris' recent mission to the United States.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The new Senate Republican leadership squared off tonight for its first test of strength under controversy, apparently confident that it had the votes to win despite almost solid Democratic opposition and still unmeasured disaffections within the Republican ranks.

Minesweeping -- one of the most hazardous occupations of wartime -- still is continuing along the coasts of a large part of the world, and it will be another year before the seas are "reasonably safe" for all traffic.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 14 -- James H. Dawes Sr., retired engineer who was widely known throughout tie Eastern seaboard for construction work on water systems, electric plants, railroads and other engineering projects, died today in his home here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Installed in a brilliant ecclesiastical ceremony as the twentieth Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopai Church, the Right Rev. Henry Knox Sherrill today called on Christians everywhere to combat the forces of evil.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As a graduate student of physics at Harvard University, I write as a young scientist who was formerly at a war research and development laboratory and now looks forward to practicing his profession in an atmosphere of freedom and in the interest of peace.

ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- Governor Dewey's committee on a State educational program recommended today an emergency appropriation of $32,000,000 to finance a $300-ayear pay increase for New York's 77,000 regular public school teachers for the next fifteen months and to establish a State-wide minimum teacher pay scale of $2,000 a year.

ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- Following is the text of the report on teachers' salaries presented today by Governor Dewey's Committee on the State Educational Program: The Committee on the State Educational Program is confronted with a three-fold problem, namely:

Airline Financing Within the last week three large domestic airlines announced plans for imminent equity financing -- the first such financing since the middle of last year. United Airlines has plans for floating a $10,000,000 preferred stock issue, Western Airlines is preparing a new common stock issue and Transcontinental Western Air, Inc., received approval of its stockholders for an additional 2,000,000 shares of its capital stock for marketing at the appropriate time.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 14 -- The Central Penn National Bank reported today that net operating income in 1946 was $854,448, an increase of $27,684 over 1945. The board of directors was increased from 13 to 15, and Albert A. Garthwaite, president of the Lee Tire and Rubber Corporation, and William B. Griscom Jr., secretary of Abbott Dairies Inc., were elected to the new posts at the annual meeting.

The off-the-face, backward silhouette was featured in a showing of spring and summer fashions last night in the Astor Hotel by the Millinery Stabilization Commission, Inc. Interpreted in many shapes -- bumper brims, pillboxes and bonnets -- back interest was maintained by choux of veiling, drapes of flowers and low-flaring back brims.

Hilda Degerlund, widowed in the bombing of Helsinki in 1944, stepped from the Swedish American liner Gripsholm yesterday to a new life -- a life that she said she owed to the American press and traditional American compassion for the unfortunate.

SOMETIMES it takes a long time for an English novel to cross the Atlantic. Rex Warner's "The Aerodrome"* was published in England five years ago and is only now available here. Since it is a peculiar, poetic book by a peculiar poet, the delay will hardly seem important to many. Mr. Warner has never found a wide public and probably never will.

ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- A Senate resolution offered today by Harold I. Panken of Manhattan, a member of the Democratic minority, asked that a "thorough and complete investigation of the activities and conduct of the State Liquor Authority, as well as the activities of all alcoholic beverage control boards," be undertaken.

BERLIN, Jan. 14 -- A notable absence of understanding of the task for which the Military Government was created and frequent shortsightedness in high places as to the fundamental philosophy are among the great obstacles in the path of German denazification.
