LONDON, Jan. 14 -- The Paris treaty of 1920 that gave Norway sovereignty over Spitsbergen islands "cannot remain valid" because among the signatories there "were states which fought against the Allied powers," Tass, the Soviet news agency, said tonight.
Open warfare on the existing Tammany organization was declared yesterday.

While bad flying weather delayed the arrival from Louisiana of the surgeon who three years ago cured Miss Anna Mayer of an attack of hiccoughs, her family told yesterday of the hundreds of suggested remedies that have reached her home at 122-67 South Ozone Park, Queens, during her current seizure.

Prospects of increased trade for United States exporters to Australia are dim for the immediate future, particularly in durable goods, Fred A. Weisenbach, special representative for the York Corporation, told a luncheon meeting of the Export Managers Club at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 14 -- The United States has decided to postpone Its demand for a showdown vote in the United Nations Security Council on the international control plan approved by the Atomic Energy Commission.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Republican members of the House Ways and Means Committee agreed today to continue all excise taxes at their present levels for an indefinite period.

An expanded research program to reduce heating costs, conducted jointly by oil burner manufacturers and oil refiners, was authorized yesterday by the Oil-Heat Institute of America, Inc., at a meeting at Hotel Commodore. Frank H. Faust, chairman of the engineering committee, also disclosed that the industry has developed the first "prototype burner," which will be used as the basic reference test unit for improving oil burner performance.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Speaker Joseph W. Martin. Jr. told members of the House of Representatives today that a preliminary audit of their Capitol Hill bank "indicates a shortage of $121,000 in the accounts."

In spite of the advantages of new automatic laundering equipment, it will take continual education to make women break with traditions of having washday once a week or religiously soaking clothes overnight, members of the Electrical Women's Round Table were told last night.

At a time when crimes and delinquency are focusing the city's attention on the need for ways and means of solving its social problems, the drive for $100,000 of the eight settlement houses in Brooklyn belonging to United Neighborhood Houses of New York, Inc., deserves sympathetic consideration.

Mayor O'Dwyer's announced purpose of seeking increased State funds and exploring all other sources of revenue before considering an increased fare on the cityowned transit lines was characterized as political maneuvering but also defended in a forum discussion over WQXR yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 14 -- An amendment to the voluntary plan for the merger of American Gas and Power Company and its principal operating subsidiary, Minneapolis Gas Light Company, and for the dissolution of American's parent. Community Gas and Power Company, was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Columns of space are being devoted by THE TIMES daily to depict the plight of the teachers and the municipal employes of this metropolis. The reader is confronted with a multitude of news items and editorials, all intended to prove that present salaries are inadequate.

Helping a child learn better ways of behaving is the true purpose of discipline, and getting a child "to stop" is not all there is to it, Dr. Mary Fisher Langmuir said yesterday. There are times when enough is enough, and there is no need to be squeamish about penalties, but "discipline" is not something applied in emergencies, it is "day-to-day living," she said.

A second-half letdown proved costly to the N.Y.U. basketball team, the Violets dropping a 50-48 decision to the Tarheels of North Carolina last night at Madison Square Garden. The opener also resulted in a 2-point margin as L.I.U., staving off a closing spurt by the visitors, outlasted St. Louis, 46-44.

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- Although the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Hugh Dalton, has not yet received the United States Treasury's latest letter questioning certain clauses in the Anglo-Argentine financial agreement, a Treasury spokesman said today that any offending clauses would definitely be left out of future agreements with the sterling creditors of Britain.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Secretary of Labor Lewis B. Schwellenbach said today that he was ready to cooperate with the Republicans dominated Congressional committees in writing labor measures, but that he was strongly opposed to setting up a mediation board, inside or outside the Labor Department, to handle disputes.

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- A recommendation that the Associated British Picture Corporation and Associated British Cinemas, Ltd., should be freed from American financial interest is contained in a lengthy memorandum from the British Film Producers Association to the Board of Trade.
"Little A," which opens tonight at Henry Miller's, will introduce two newcomers to the Great White Way -- Hugh White, author, and Sam Nasser, producer. An 8:20 curtain is announced.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The Army Air Forces during 1947 will add about 11,000 to its present roster of 7,000 regular officers to advance it further toward its ultimate goal of 27,500 regular officers, Maj. Gen. Fred L. Anderson, assistant chief of air staff for personnel, disclosed today.

Sixty-five Hanscom bake shops in the metropolitan area were closed yesterday as an outgrowth of a work stoppage by 300 employes at the company's central bakery, 35-25 Thirty-fifth Street, Long Island City.

Elisabeth Schumann sang at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon, and she showed what a true artist could do with the most limited of means. For the soprano's voice is small and narrow in range. Listening to it is like looking through the wrong end of a telescope.

The Canadian freighter Tecumseh Park was reported "breaking up" last night in the storm-swept North Atlantic while an Army transport, crowded with homebound GI's, stood by the battered vessel ready to provide help.

The action of the Department of Justice in ordering the deportation of Dr. Karl von Kleczkowski, former German military intellgence officer, and his wife, Stella, was characterized as "arbitrary, capricious and an abuse of discretion" in a supplementary petition filed yesterday in Federal Court.

IT'S a most laudable ambition but virtually unattainable. Chuck Rayner has a violent yen to score a goal. Most hockey players are fired with that same lofty desire but not when they are goalies. Chuck Rayner is a goalie. In fact there are many who rate him as the best cage guardian in the National Hockey League.

BOSTON, Jan. 14 -- The Veterans Administration will attempt to work out a plan to pay in advance 75 per cent of the cost of schooling veterans in non-profit higher educational institutions, Gen. Omar N. Bradley, Veterans Administrator, told the Association of American Colleges today.

Full-scale war will be declared on organized waterfront thieves on the first of next month by the Bureau for the Suppression off Theft and Pilferage, Inc., James B. Young, president of the bureau, announced yesterday.

PARIS, Jan. 14 -- The Viet Nam radio said today that the French had launched an operation to lift the siege of Hue, capital of Annam, which has been surrounded and cut off from Hanoi, in Tongking, since the fighting began on Dec. 19.

Fifty-six contributions totaling $1,287.63 were received yesterday by the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund conducted by THE NEW YORK TIMES. Since the thirty-fifth annual appeal started, $389,940.76 has been sent in by 14,174 contributors.

Outright termination of the mortgage moratorium, full support of all-year Saturday closing, an increase in the savings bank life insurance limit from $3,000 to $5,000 and the right to invest in Canadian bonds are features in the program of the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York for 1947 as a result of action taken yesterday at the State Association's annual all-day mid-winter conference in the Hotel Biltmore.

Agreement among members of the Board of Estimate on the New York City Airport Authority's plan for an $80,000,000 development of three major city airports is expected at City Hall today, it was learned yesterday from official sources.

Communists have moved in on the American Veterans Committee and changed it from "a flowering, inspiring group of young Americans interested in the nation's welfare" to an organization that is "tattered and torn and factionalized," Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., national housing chairman of the AVC, charged yesterday.

Leslie MacMitchell has joined the New York Athletic Club. Manhattan College will start construction today on a new outdoor board training track. A record-breaking total of 645 entries has been received for the Metropolitan A.A.U. indoor championships, which will be held at the Twenty-third Regiment Armory in Brooklyn Saturday night.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 14 -- Enterprise Productions has acquired screen rights to Stephen Vincent Benet's 1937 short story, "Johnny Pye, the Fool Killer," as a vehicle for William Conrad, it was learned today. The story is a New England allegory.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 14 -- Dinners, prizefights and midnight suppers, with the bill for a festive night running well over $1,000, were commonplace for the guests of Joseph S. Fay, fourth vice-president of the International Union of Operating Engineers, AFL. defense witnesses testified today in Fay's Federal Court trial for evasion of income taxes.

Baroness Isabella Carvallo de la Bouillerie, who is making her home in the Hotel Stanhope, started a damage suit for $100,000 in Supreme Court yesterday against her brothers and sisters and several relatives by marriage, alleging that because of false charges made to the German occupation authorities, and later to the French Provisional Government, she was kept in prison in France for a year.

MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 14 -- Absolute control and management of Investors Syndicate and its group of investment companies was restored today to the stockholders with the termination of a threeyear voting trust agreement and the election of three new directors to replace those elected to the board under that agreement.

Paul D. Kirkpatrick, formerly supervisor of the Ohio-Michigan area of the A.E. Staley Manufacrturing Company, processors of corn and soy beans, has been appointed assistant sales manager in charge of Eastern division package operations.

MOSCOW, Jan. 14 -- A blistering attack on the "kiss and tell journalism" of John Fischer, former reporting officer of The United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration's mission to the Ukraine, was launched today by Paul White, present head of the mission.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The three Supreme Court opinions by which Governor Jimmie Davis of Louisiana was authorized to enforce a new execution warrant against Willie Francis, 17-year-old Negro, are human interest documents of a kind that issue rarely from tribunals.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The Federal Reserve Board is studying a proposal to revise its restrictions on installment credit "from time to time" in order to adjust Regulation W to changing conditions of supply and demand.

The "undisclosed reserves" of the First National Bank of the City of New York now total about $6,000,000, Alexander C. Nagle, president, said in presenting his report to the annual meeting of the bank's stockholders yesterday. Although these reserves are not now needed, the bank's directors, he said, are of the belief that they should be maintained while the immediate future continues to be uncertain.

ABOARD MOUNT OLYMPUS, Jan. 14 -- After two weeks of battling with the Antarctic ice pact the ships of the Navy's expedition to Little America finally broke clear into the open water of the Ross Sea this morning.

National Bronx Bank The National Bronx Bank of New York reported as of Dec. 31, 1946, total deposits of $42,079,037 and total assets of $44,797,972, compared, respectively, with $42,172,161 and $44,374,763 on Dec. 31, 1945.

ROME, Jan. 14 -- When Premier Alcide de Gasperi returns to Rome on Friday or Saturday -- depending on whether he decides to visit Premier Leon Blum in Paris -- he will have to cope with the chaotic Cabinet situation brought about by the Socialist party split.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 14 -- A Joint application - declaration in which General Public Utilities Corporation and one of its principal subsidiary public utility companies, New York State Electric and Gas Corporation, requested permission to undertake several transactions was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Closer working arrangements between retailers and manufacturers to meet quality and price requirements of the "customer's market," which is now here, were urged yesterday by speakers at the annual convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Eighteen hundred children have been kept out of foster homes and institutions through the efforts of professional homemakers since the beginning of the Department of Welfare's homemaking center, in September, 1943, Welfare Commissioner Edward E. Rhatigan said yesterday.

New York City's public school teachers may strike unless "their reasonable requirements are met," a spokesman for the Teachers Salary Conference and the Joint Committee of Teachers Organizations said yesterday. He voiced the indirect threat of a strike as teachers throughout the school system were intensifying their campaign to obtain pay increases of $1,050 a year.

The New York State Commission Against Discrimination has received only 653 complaints concerning alleged employment discrimination by business organizations in the sixteen months since the State law against discrimination became effective on July 1, 1945, James Lovatelli, president of the industrial and management consultant firm tearing his name, disclosed yesterday.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Two Youngstown high school students faced charges of first degree murder tonight in the slaying of William S. Spieth, 52-year-old Ashtabula salesman found shot and beaten to death in his automobile near here yesterday.

TOKYO, Jan. 14 -- Labor as well as capital will come under the newest purge directive of the Japanese Government ousting from positions of political and industrial importance those men who are deemed to have advanced the cause of the militarists and imperialists before and during the war, it was decided by the Cabinet of Premier Shigeru Yoshida tonight.

BOSTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- On the impetus of four quick field goals and two foul shots by George Lawry, Princeton's basketball team jumped into a quick lead tonight and downed Harvard, 45 -- 35, in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game at the garden.

Supplies of household appliances will not equal the demand for at least six months, despite the fact that production on some large units has been moving ahead at a rate in excess of the pre-war output. For example, in October, 1946, 63,000 more gas ranges were manufactured than in an average month before Pearl Harbor, and 30,000 more electric ranges.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 14 -- Guarantees of "jobs for all" cannot be carried out by governments without trespassing on individual freedom, according to a resolution on maximum employment handed on to the United Nations today by the International Chamber of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended Jan. 8: Decreases of $282,000,000 in loans, $227,000,000 in holdings of United States Government obligations, $137,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted, and $379,000,000 in United States Government deposits.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14 -- Labor union leaders are seeking private employers to provide wage and other concessions which union organizations do not grant to their own paid workers, Charles Luckman, president of Lever Brothers Company, said today.

"A wonderful opportunity'' for American business exists today in Latin America, but this chance "will slip away from us unless we fight off European competition" in that area, Albert V. Moore, president of Moore-McCormack Lines, declared yesterday.
LONDON, Jan. 14 -- Closer economic cooperation between Britain and France was agreed upon today in talks that Premier Leon Blum had with Prime Minister Attlee and Foreign Secretary Bevin.

The front office organization of the Yankees underwent another alteration yesterday when Larry MacPhail announced that he and Del Webb, who along with Dan Topping form the baseball triumvirate, had bought equal shares in the football enterprise.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The Interstate Commerce Committees of Congress, spurred by recent airline accidents, moved today to Inquire into the whole field of civil aviation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The Supreme Court dug sharply today into the arguments offered by the Government and defense counsel in the appeal from the conviction of John L. Lewis and the United Mine Workers for contempt of court in refusing to obey the restraining order to call off the soft coal strike on Nov. 20.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 14 -- Authoritive quarters confirmed today that Britain was sending a military mission to Saudi Arabia to organize legions of that country. American interests have their richest foreign oil concession in Saudi Arabia.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Clifford R. Hope, chairman of thE House Agriculture Committee today named a seven-member food investigating subcommittee, with Representative August Andresen, Minnesota Republican, as chairman.

Because of a crime wave that has threatened their lives, tenants of the six-story apartment house at 50 Manhattan Avenue have hired armed guards to patrol the building twenty-four hours a day and are petitioning the Office of Price Administration to reduce rents to compensate for this expenditure.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 14 (AP) -- A crowd of 10,380 turned out to see a program of nine races at Tropical Park today, the extra event being the Damon Runyon Memorial Purse. The mile and a sixteenth contest was marred by a disqualification, D.F. Harrington's Weathercock being placed first after Sam Garfield's F.B. Eye, first past the wire by a head, was set back out of the money.

A formal plan which will permit Motty Eitingon, Inc., to resume operations and to pay off its creditors has been worked out to the satisfaction of most of those concerned, George J. Beldock of Beldock Meadow, spokesman for the dealer-manufacturer committee, stated at a creditors' meeting at the United States Court House yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Jan. 14 -- Norman P. Mason of North Chelmsford, Mass., president of the National Retail Lumber Dealers Association, said today that the building industry dare not risk "another year of failure." Addressing 1,000 members at the opening session of the fifty-fifth annual convention of the Middle Atlantic Lumbermen's Association at the Claridge Hotel, Mr. Mason said "the responsibility is no longer that of a paternal Government -- it is ours."

Mayor O'Dwyer paid his tribute yesterday to a potential Hollywood glamour girl in the person of 4year-old Nancy Drury of Louisville, Ky., who was received at City Hall as the "Polio Poster Girl" in the $24,000,000 campaign of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis.

Advice by President Truman not to "pay too much attention to what you read in the newspapers" was relayed last night to 100 delegates from civic, trade union and welfare groups at a meeting of the New York City Consumer Council.

A day of two ago we had occasion to write here in praise of the bipartisan character of American political policy in the international field, and of the high quality of statesmanship which it reflected.

DETROIT, Jan. 14 -- The United Automobile Workers, Congress of Industrial Organizations, which has been holding its fire because of a possible technicality, will open its fight tomorrow for a wage rise of more than 30 cents an hour.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The powerful new amalgamated House Committee on the Armed Services will act on no fundamental military policy until it obtains from the State Department information as to this country's precise diplomatic position and commitments in the world. Disclosures of unprecedented scope would be expected.

TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Jan. 14 (AP) -- Harold (Red) Drew, Mississippi football coach in the 1946 season and former assistant here, was named head coach at Alabama today to replace the ailing Frank Thomas, producer of six post-season bowl elevens in sixteen seasons.

Selective improvement invaded the stock market yesterday after the sharp reaction of Monday as fractional gains dominated the list, although the heavy industrials failed to maintain peak additions. Trading on the Stock Exchange fell to only 850,000 shares, against 1,590,000 shares the day before.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Now that the President has proclaimed the cessation of hostilities, I find that I have more time to devote to thoughts on the possibility and the probability of obtaining in any of the four quarters of 1947 one type 47 tube, for lack of which my radio is suffering acutely, but not silently.

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- After some early hesitation in the stock markets here today, caused by the cut in allocations of coal to industry, the more reasurring news of an early ending to the truck drivers' strike had one or two sections closing firm.

Endorsement of United States cooperation with the International Refugee Organization was given yesterday by the Women's Action Committee for Lasting Peace. The group's stand on this and other current issues was made known in a statement of policy released at its headquarters, 1 East Fiftyseventh Street.

ATLANTA, Wednesday, Jan. 15 (AP) -- After the General Assembly had elected Herman Talmadge Governor for four years early today, Governor Arnall issued this statement: The office of Governor belongs to the people.

Nineteen-year-old Rose Marie Nazar, French and pretty, is on her way today to join her husbandto-be in Washington Courthouse, Ohio, after an introduction to the United States she won't forget for a long time.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 14 -- The New Jersey Legislature convened its 1947 session today and heard Gov. Walter E. Edge, in his final legislative message, call for a strengthened State utility antistrike law to assure continued service for consumers.

Endorsements of local, State and national leaders were given to the fund-raising drive of the American Women's Voluntary Services at a luncheon yesterday at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel. Messages of commendation from President Truman and Governor Dewey were read and guests added their approval.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Mark Thistlethwaite, Washington correspondent since 1921 of The Indianapolis News, The Fort Wayne Journal-Gazette and The Terre Haute Tribune, died this afternoon in his home at 200 Holly Avenue, Takoma Park, Md., near here.

Buyers' Total Higher Visiting buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday totaled 3,565 compared with 2,147 in the previous week and 3,412 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Efrem Zimbalist is not a showy violinist. Indeed, he is conspicuously lacking in many of the attributes that make for popular appeal. Yet year after year he attracts large audiences, and last night he drew another full house to his annual Carnegie Hall recital.

Pillsbury to Use 171 Papers Pillsbury Mills will expand its advertising campaign for Pillsbury's Best Flour, using both color and black-and-white ads in 171 newspapers from coast to coast, R.J. Keith, director of advertising, announced yesterday.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York cleared $23,665,000 in 1946, compared with $25,337,000 in 1945, Allan Sproul, president of the bank, announced yesterday. Assets stood at $11,704,486,000 on Dec. 31, 1946, compared with $11,666,274,000 a year earlier, he said.

ATLANTA, Wednesday, Jan. 15 -- Herman Talmadge, 33-year-old son of the late Governor-Elect Eugene Talmadge, was elected Governor by the General Assembly early today by a vote of 161 to 87. The Assembly had been in session since yesterday morning.

Retail sales in 1947, unless badly hit by labor disturbances, crop failure or other catastrophes, should go well beyond the $100,000,000,000 mark, according to Paul H. Nystrom, president of the Limited Price Variety Stores Association and professor of marketing, Columbia University School of Business, yesterday.

Net operating earnings of the Corn Exchange Bank Trust Company during 1946 amounted to $4,129,728, or $5.43 per share, compared with $4,070,726, or $5.51 a share at the end of 1945, according to Dunham B. Sherer, chairman, at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14 -- Buying by shorts and cash interests resulted in active grain markets on the Board of Trade today. January wheat sold at $2.19 1/2 a bushel, up 2 1/2 cents, to a new twenty-sixyear high, While March wheat at $2.11 1/2 was in new seasonal ground.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange developed irregularity yesterday, and closed 18 points higher to 9 points lower than on Monday. Near months were relatively stronger than distant.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- After a series of showdown conferences, domestic operators have refused to take control of their pre-war domestic shipping fleet, leaving it under deficit Government operation, it was learned today.

In opening the London Conference of the Deputies of the Big Four Foreign Ministers, charged with preparing the ground for a German peace treaty, Foreign Secretary Bevin noted that this conference is also supposed to prepare a peace treaty with Austria. That unhappy land, once the center of a large empire, was Hitler's first victim.

Dates, Rates, Weights Meat for Americans will be produced in 1947 to the amount of 150 pounds for every person. That is the forecast from the Department of Commerce. It will be the largest per capita supply in a generation.

An outburst of legislative indignation against the efforts of professional gamblers to fix sporting events developed yesterday in numerous State Capitols throughout the country. In Albany a resolution was introduced into the Legislature calling for a full-dress investigation into gambling, gamefixing and other corrupt practices in amateur and professional sports.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Jan. 14 -- The Foreign Missions Conference of North America received today, at the opening of its annual meeting, a report recommending development of a program of "group evangelism," designed to speed the work of Christian missions abroad and make evangelism more "relevant, vital and fruitful."

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 14 (AP) -- Tom Smith, veteran trainer restored to good standing following a suspension for alleged stimulation of a horse in New York, today received a license from the California Horse Racing Board. Smith's application for a California License had been held up temporarily while the board exchanged formal views with the New York State Racing Commission.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 14 (AP) -- Tom Smith, veteran trainer restored to good standing following a suspension for alleged stimulation of a horse in New York, today received a license from the California Horse Racing Board. Smith's application for a California License had been held up temporarily while the board exchanged formal views with the New York State Racing Commission.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Organization of the Eightieth Congress was completed today, except for one remaining formality, when the Democratic caucus of the lower chamber approved selections of minority members of committees.

More effective sales promotior to speed the flow of merchandise to consumers, including expanding research, intensive cooperation between stores and newspapers, new display techniques and stronger public relations, was emphasized yesterday at the annual convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

An increase of 1,665,000 barrels last week in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the end of the week they amounted to 96,547,000 barrels, compared with 94,882,000 a week earlier and 99,882,000 on Jan. 12, 1946.

In the important field of fiscal policy Republican leadership in the new Congress has made an auspicious start. Majority members of the Ways and Means Committee, paralleling, if not following, the recommendations of President Truman in his budget message, agreed to continue all excise taxes at present levels for an indefinite period.

Ad Contest Winners Announced Winners in the nation-wide annual newspaper advertising contest sponsored by the National Retail Dry Goods Association were announced yesterday at the annual convention of the association here.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 15 -- The United States, which until now has been uncompromising in its demand for maximum speed in disposing, of the question of international atomic control, today asked the United Nations Security Council to postpone until Feb. 4 all discussions of this and other provisions, of the General Assembly's disarmament resolution.

WARSAW, Poland, Jan. 15 -- The Peasant party's leader, Stanislaw Mikolajczyk, tried tonight to ask the Polish people to unseat the present regime in Sunday's elections, but a sharp censor's pencil deleted from his major preelection radio address the call to change the "present state of affairs."

Preliminary action toward ousting 2,769 families from public lowrent apartments was announced yesterday by Edmond Borgia Butler, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority. As the flats are emptied, they will be turned over to veterans with low incomes.

Two attacks on the plans of the City Airport Authority for the future of Idlewild, La Guardia and Floyd Bennett Fields were placed before Mayor O'Dwyer during an executive session of the Board of Estimate yesterday.
The Marine Midland Trust Company cleared $1,716,771 in 1946, compared with $1,472,379 in the previous year, James G. Blaine, president, reported yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders.

ATLANTA, Jan. 15 -- Gov. Ellis Arnall, challenging the constitutionality of Herman Talmadge's election to the Governorship early today at a tumultuous session of the General Assembly, took his tattle into court this afternoon.

LONDON, Jan. 15 -- An out-ofcourt settlement under which Winston Churchill is to receive "substantial" damages from Harper Bros., publisher, for libelous statements in the book "Dinner at the "White House," by Louis Adamic, was announced in a London court today.
LONDON, Jan. 15 -- Britain and France have agreed to conclude a military alliance "at the earliest possible moment."

The $3,200,000 raised by Beekman -Downtown Hospital for a new building at William, Beekman and Spruce Streets may not be adequate in view of the probability that the hospital will not qualify for a grant of Federal funds, Howard S. Cullman, president, reported yesterday at the annual meeting.
The general community hospital will be the base of future modern medical service, Dr. Willard C. Rappleye, Dean of'the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University, predicted yesterday.

PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., Jan. 15 -- After developing a sumptuous estate here into a business headquarters, the General Precision Laboratory Corporation felt today that life in the country was wonderful from every industrial, economic, social and labor relations viewpoint.

HANOI, Indo-Chlna, Jan. 15 (Reuters) -- Several thousand ragged, half-starved Annamese, Chinese and Indians who had been trapped in the native quarter of Hanoi today trekked out through barbed wire and street barricades under a truce arranged between the French and Viet Nam forces.

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 15 -- Because of the housing shortage and the lack of skilled labor in the building industry, thousands of Americans may soon emulate their ancestors of pioneer days and tackle the problem of building their homes themselves.
Rescue craft were fighting their way through pounding North Atlantic surf last night to aid two battered, wallowing vessels.

Unless labor declares a one-year moratorium on wage demands, rising prices virtually will; end buying, Earl O. Shreve, vice president of the General Electric Company and a vice president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, asserted yesterday. He said prosperity and lower prices would result from stabilized wages.

The action of the congregation of the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, in dissolving and distributing its assets of more than $40,000 was a "surprise" to the consistory, governing body of the five Collegiate Reformed churches in the city, consistory officers said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The resignation of Donald S. Russell of South Carolina as an Assistant Secretary of State was expected to follow that of his chief and law partner, Mr. Byrnes, and it did. Mr. Russell, like Benjamin V. Cohen, the Counselor, was a personal appointee of Mr. Byrnes from outside the trained staff of the Department.

Although Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander declined yesterday to detail a patrolman to guard the apartment building at 50 Manhattan Avenue, in which tenants have hired "guards" to protect them against crime, a precinct captain assigned last night a policeman and a radio car to patrol the immediate area.
MOSCOW, Jan. 15 -- British Foreign Secretary Bevin was accused of renouncing the Anglo-Soviet treaty of 1942 in an article today in Pravda, newspaper of the central committee of the Communist party.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The State Department declared today that the United States would have to be consulted in case Norway and the Soviet Union reached an agreement for modification of the 1920 treaty according Norway sovereignty over Spitsbergen.

ALBANY, Jan. 15 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey signed today the bill of Senator MacNeil Mitchell, Republican, of Manhattan, to appropriate $25,000,000 to continue the emergency housing program for veterans, making it the first new law of the 1947 session of the Legislature.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan." 15 -- Yale lost its tenth game of the season in eleven starts at the Payne Whitney Gym tonight when the Columbia quintet conquered the Elis, 50-39. It-was, the fifth triumph for the Lions against a pair of reversals and their second consecutive Eastern Intercollegiate victory.

By a secret vote of four to three, the Board of Education yesterday elected Dr. William Jansen, assistant superintendent in the New York City public school system, to the $25,000-a-year post of Superintendent of Schools. This action ended a ten-month search throughout the country to find the best man available for the position.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Text of the statement issued today by Italian Premier de Gasperi shortly before leaving by plane for Rome: American friends: I am addressing you once again at the end of my ten days' stay in your wonderful country where I had the pleasure of meeting American statesmen, officials, technicians, men and women of your noble people -- industrialists and workers.

Three organizations of teachers -- the Teachers Union of the CIO, the Teachers Guild of the AFL and the Teachers Salary Conference -- drew up yesterday plans for a mass demonstration at a public hearing tomorrow on the Board of Education's annual budget.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 15 -- Warren Robinson Austin -- a Vermonter, a former United States Senator, a lawyer and ono-time Mayor -- took over today as United States representative on the United Nations Security Council and a few hours later delivered a scholarly little lecture that tied up some very ancient Latin with some very modern atomic affairs.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Georgia's dispute over its Governorship threatened to overflow into the national capital today, but nearly all concerned managed to steer clear of it. The Georgia delegation in Congress, with one exception, avoided taking sides and the War Department decided that it has no reason yet to intervene in Atlanta.

BOSTON, Jan. 15 -- The Association of American Colleges referred to committee today proposals for Federal aid at the primary and secondary levels of public education and scholarships for able students but sidestepped the major issue of over-all, Federal aid for higher education.
General liquidation controlled the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, and prices at the finish were, virtually at the lows of the day and 63 to 84 points net lower.

PARIS, Jan. 15 -- Vincent Auriol, just re-elected President of the French National Assembly, was the leading candidate tonight for election as President of the Fourth Republic by the congress of the two Houses of Parliament tomorrow in Versailles.

FranK C. Bals, close personal friend of Mayor O'Dwyer sines the days when the Mayor was a rookie patrolman and frequently lauded by the Mayor as one of the best criminal investigators in the country, has submitted his resignation as Seventh Deputy Police Commissioner, it was announced yesterday.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 15 -- In answer to a charge by Harold Cutright, a director, E. B. Greene. president of the Cliffs Corporation, said that the corporation had never received an offer of $10,000,000 or any other amount for its holdings of the common stock of the ClevelandCliffs Iron Company.
Former Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins said yesterday she would like to see the Federal Government keep out of worker-employer disputes.

BERLIN, Jan. 15 -- It is the firm conviction among the more thoughtful Military Government personnel and anti-fascist Germans that there is only one way to lead Germany out of her warlike attitude. That way is to eliminate the Nazis and Nazi-minded from high places and, having done so, control the education of the rising generation so that it will think along saner lines than in the past.

LONDON, Jan. 15 -- Six hours of discussion between the warring factions of the Transport and General Workers Union failed tonight to bring an end to London's outlaw strike of truckmen and their thousands of sympathizers in related unions.
The State Athletic Commission supervised a business that grossed close to $8,000,000 last year, and almost doubled the 1945 tax yield to State coffers.

NANKING, Jan. 15 -- Continuing their efforts in the face of Gen. Chou En-lai's uncompromising broadcast from Yenan, the Government framers of a new set of peace proposals to the Communists today submitted their plans to President Chiang Kai-shek.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 15 -- For the first time since the end of the war a railway train is reported to have left Peiping en route to Suiyuan Province through captured Kalgan. Traffic also has been opened tentatively over the Tsinan-Tsingtao line through the narrow Nationalist corridor in Shantung.

An increase of about one-third in the rates of the Associated Hospital Service, effective May 1, was announced yesterday by Louis H. Pink, president. Coincidentally, greater benefits will be allowed members. The increase in rates is due to a rise in hospital costs of approximately 40 per cent.

WARSAW, Poland, Jan. 15 -- Formally rejecting American notes urging free elections here, the Polish Government has told the United States that its fears about the elections are based on misrepresentations and "groundless charges raised by anti-democratic elements in Poland."

Although investment commitments for residential construction in the thirty-seven States east of the Rocky Mountains reached an all-time peak of $3,142,102,000 in 1946, according to a survey by the F.W. Dodge Corporation, a study of the figures indicates that higher building costs accounted for about 24 per cent of the increase.

CHICAGO, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Frank La. Forge of New York, voice teacher, pianist and composer, was in "good shape" today, physicians at Presbyterian Hospital reported. Mr. La Forge collapsed on Sunday in his hotel room. He had accompanied Lily Ppns Saturday night in an Orchestra Hall recital.

A pair of goals by Phil Watson gave the New York Rangers a hand-earned victory over the De troit Red Wings in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. The Blue Shirts, fighting to keep their hold on fourth place in the league race, had to flash an inspired rally in the third period to tally twice and skate off with the decision 4 to 3.
This business of signing Charle Trippi, Georgia's gridiron star, to a dual football and baseball contrac is not developing into so simple a task as some folks had been led to believe.

Sugar may be short, but heavy cream again is available, to add sumptuousness to desserts. Its cost is fairly high, ranging widely in retail groceries and hovering in the ricinity of 43 cents a pint for the home-delivered product. But even so, used as a luxury should be -- that is, on occasion and not often -- the tariff is not too budgetbreaking. Besides, a little of such richness goes far.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- President Truman appealed today-to every State and community to "work unceasingly throughout 1947 to promote highway safety."

Fifty members of the women's Lighthouse committee of the New York Association for the Blind, 111 East Fifty-ninth Street, attended a rally at their headquarters yesterday to open the association's 1947 campaign for $250,000.

Syracuse and Temple will be the visitors in tonight's college' basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden. The Orange quintet will meet Manhattan in the first game at 8 P. M., with the Owls opposing St. John's In the nightcap.

The State of Louisiana announced yesterday that it would offer on Feb. 20 three highway bond issues totaling $19,000,000. One issue will be designated Series 1-A, and will consist of $15,000,000 of bonds dated Jan. 1, 1947, and due Jan. 1 from 1951 to 1965, with bonds maturing after Jan. 1, 1953, callable on Jan. 1, 1952.

NEWARK, N. J., Jan. 15 -- Joseph S. Fay, 54-year-old fourth vice president of the International, Union of Operating Engineers, AFL, was acquitted by a jury in Federal Court here tonight on all three counts of an indictment charging income tax evasion of $118,000 for the years 1940, 1941 and 1942.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Secretary James F. Byrnes announced today an agreement between this country and Canada for sale of the surplus crude oil facilities of the expensive and controversial Canol project.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Baseball's bonus regulation moved a step nearer enactment today as Commissioner Albert B. Chandler's advisory council reached agreement on the measure and sent it to the minor leagues for approval.

Attacks on two women in neighboring office buildings within an hour and the capture of their alleged assailant after a police search of Doth structures late yesterday caused considerable excitement among homeward-bound workers in the lower Fifth Avenue business district.

The diversion of 845,000 yards of scarce textiles worth $500,000 into the black market was disclosed yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation after the arrest of eight men on charges of participating in the sale of fraudulent War Production Board priorities.

Manufacturers Trust Company has been appointed paying agent for City of Lakeland, Fla., 3 per cent sewer sinking fund bonds, issue No. 124, dated July 1, 1946, and 4 1/2 per cent -- 2 3/4 per cent refunding bonds, dated July 1, 1946.

In selecting William Jansen as Super intendent of Schools the Board of Education has made a good choice. Dr. Jansen has had. an intimate contact with every department of the school system. He knows and understands the problems that lie ahead. During the last thirty-eight years he has 'served with, distinction as teacher, supervisor, principal and assistant superintendent.

Mona Paulee, Canadian-born mezzo soprano, who joined the Metropolitan Opera five years ago, gave her second local recital last night at Town Hall. She confined the foreign-language part of her program, to three composers, Jean Canteloube, Hugo Wolf and Francis Poulenc.

OSLO, Norway, Jan. 15 -- The Soviet statement referring to "the necessity of joint defense" of Spitsbergen is seen in diplomatic circles here today as a reduction of the original "stiff demands" made to Norway in 1944. It is believed that when the Russians first broached the matter, they had in mind an outright lease of Spitsbergen.

LONDON, Jan. 15 -- Prof. Johan J. Smertenko, vice president of the American League for a Free Palestine, was lodged in a suburban police station tonight awaiting his forced departure tomorrow in the same chartered plane that brought him from Paris to Croydon Airfield today.
VILLANOVA, Pa., Jan. 15 -- Fordham University's basketball team staved off a last-half Villanova rally to defeat the Wildcats, 41 to 39, in a thrilling game before 2,700 fans tonight.

TORONTO, Jan. 15 -- The principal task facing credit managers in 1947 is-that of increasing retail credit sales on a sound basis, J. Gordon Dakins, manager, credit management division, National Retail Dry Goods Association, said here today.

Spring is closer than you think. The first green shoot is "Little A," which was put on at Henry Miller's last evening. For Hugh White's portentous drama of domestic hatred in the big gray house on the hill looks suspiciously like the sort of thing that goes on in the theatre at the tag end of winter when everyone starts losing his mind.

BOSTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Sparked by four new players, the Boston Bruins strengthened their shaky hold on the National Hockey League's third rung by storming from behind for a 6-3 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks tonight before 13,900 at the Boston Garden.

Too many boat-minded folks guessed that a rainy Wednesday would produce an ebb to the tidal wave of visitors to the National Motor Boat Show. So thousands of them gravitated toward the Grand Central Palace yesterday, bundled in storm coats, carrying umbrellas and wearing galoshes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- A number of important measures looking to assisting Italy's economic recovery were agreed upon during the eleven-day mission here of Prime Minister Alcide de Gasperi, the State Department announced today.

The thirty-five-acre estate of the late Sidney Borg on Sunnyside Lane, Tarrytown, Westchester County, has been purchased by interests represented by Clement Merowit, builder, who contemplate development of the property.

Bank of Yorktown Net operating earnings of the Bank of Yorktown last year amounted to $376,078, compared with $288,877 in 1945, George M. Adrian, chairman and president, reported yesterday. After deductions for taxes, and reserves and after payment of dividends, there remained a balance of $179,337 which was added to undivided profits.

There is no factor in the economic picture which makes prob1947, Leo B. Cherne, executive secretary of the Research Institute of America, asserted yesterday. But if business persuades itself that a recession is imminent, it can easily bring one about by buying and selling accordingly, he said.
"Roundabout America," an entertainment program for children 8 to 14 years old, will tie presented at the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, on Saturday at 10:30 A.M..

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The first committee of the new Republican Congress to hold hearings went to work today to fashion a measure to meet the problem raised by a great mass of claims for portal-to-portal back pay.

The fourth" annual Tobe Award for distinguished service to American retailing was presented last night to Walter H. Rich, president of Rich's, Atlanta, Ga., at a dinner in the Hotel Ritz-Carlton. The award was made in recognition of Mr. Rich's contribution to labor and consumer relations.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 15 (AP) -- William Woodward's Hyflare, a 3-year-old gelding that had never won a race, captured the mile and a sixteenth fourth contest at Tropical Park today and paid $197 for $2, biggest straight return of the meeting.

Two hundred thousand workers in three major divisions of the textile industry will receive wage increases amounting to nearly $55,000,000 a year as a result of contracts negotiated in the last month by the Textile Workers Union, Emil Rieve, president of the CIO affiliate, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- President Truman, condemning "a tendency in this country" toward revival of bigotry and intolerance, called today for legislation to implement the Bill of Rights and protect the civil rights of citizens in those local areas from which Federal enforcement agencies have been excluded.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 15 -- "He Ran All the Way," a forthgoming novel by Sam Ross, has been purchased by Liberty Films for $75,000, the company ' announced today.' George Stevens, one of the three producing partners in Liberty, will produce and direct the screen adaptation of the novel, which deals with a young man who kills a policeman.

A record budget of $15,393,938 for New York's four city colleges for the 1947-48 fiscal year has been recommended by the Committee on Finance and Facilities of the Board of Higher Education, Dr. Ordway Tead, chairman of the board, announced yesterday afternoon at a public hearing of the committee at Hunter College, 695 Park Avenue.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 15 -- David O. Selznick's much-publicized new $5,000,000 Western film, "Duel in the Sun," which has stirred considerable comment at local showings because of its torrid romantic scenes, today was denounced by Catholic authorities and a Protestant group.

PARIS, Jam. 15 -- Vice Admiral Georges Thierry d'Argenlieu, French High Commissioner to Indo-China, announced today that the French Government had appealed to the International Red Cross for intervention with Viet Nam officials. The French concern is for the safety of French civilians and some Chinese prisoners who, it is stated, are being held by the Viet Namese as hostages.

THERE always is a shuffle of coaching portfolios at the end of each football season as the members of the fraternity engage on their own version of a game not unlike musical chairs. But the better operatives in the lodge never are "it" at the end. They always are seated comfortably when the music resumes. However, the constant scrambling always produces a vast amount of interest among-gridiron fans.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- A "gradual but not precipitious" decline in the prices of many food and clothing items over the next six months was forecast today by officials of the Department of Commerce.

PASSAIC, N.J., Jan. 15 -- Carl R. Griffen, vice president and cashier of the Passaic National Bank and Trust Company, was added to the board of directors by stockholders at their annual meeting yesterday. A native of Clinton Corner, N.Y., he has been with the bank twenty-four years.

As a concrete example of the kind of economic policy we will have to pursue abroad to save the fruits of victory, the American Government, through the Export-Import Bank, has extended a credit of 5100,000,000 to Italy for imports from this country. Simultaneously it has diverted in mid-ocean six wheat-laden ships from Germany to Italian ports.
LONDON, Jan. 15 -- The British Foreign Office spokesman indignantly denied today a statement in the Soviet newspaper Pravda that Mr. Bevin "disavows the AngloSoviet treaty of mutual assistance."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- President Truman was taken to task by the Republican party today on the eve of his first meeting with its Congressional leaders for what was described as "intentional failure" to send Congress a definite and comprehensive legislative program.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 15 -- The staff of the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it would recommend approval of a proposal to transfer the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation's interests in its southern operating subsidiaries and in the Savannah River Electric Company to the newly organized Southern Company of Commonwealth, provided the program is amended to conform with its views.

Guy R. Brewer, Tammany leader of the Twelfth Assembly District, North, declared yesterday that, although he was the first leader to challenge the domination of Tammany by Clarence H. Neal Jr., he had been excluded from the socalled Irish group of insurgents headed by Frank J. Sampson.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.
ALBANY, Jan. 15 -- The State Board of Regents was urged today to undertake a comprehensive study of the nursing needs of New York State.

BUCK HTTVT. FALLS, Pa., Jan. 15 -- A reorganization of the Christian foreign mission enterprise, providing a realistic approach, to man's economic and physical problems as well as his spiritual needs, must be consummated if Christianity is to continue as a force in the world, the Rev. Leland S. Albright, assistant secretary of the International Missionary Council of New York, declared today.

At the annual meeting of stockholders of the Irving Trust Company yesterday, Harry E. Ward, chairman, was confronted with a briefly discussed labor problem. In one of the shortest meetings in the history of the bank, according to one of the officers, two of the three stockholders who took the floor quoted from a press releasetuned for the meeting by the Financial Employes Guild, Congress of Industrial Organization, which represents security and maintenance employes.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Jan. 15 -- The mystery of the alleged conspiracy to overthrow the Hungarian Republic took a new form today, when Premier Ferenc Nagy told a meeting of Parliamentary Deputies belonging to his Smallholders party that other parties in the coalition, as well as the Smallholders, were involved in the affair.

PARIS, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The announcement that Britain and France had agreed to conclude a treaty of alliance was seen in Paris tonight as a major diplomatic achievement for Premier Blum, increasing greatly his chances of receiving an offer of the Premiership in France's first permanent Government of the Fourth Republic.

A program to facilitate world travel by getting rid of the red tape and irritating delays involved in crossing international borders was introduced last night at a dinner in honor of Vice Admiral Emory S. Land, USN (retired), at the University Club.

TOKYO, Jan. 15 -- Attempts to form a national Government for Japan through the inclusion of the Socialists in the Cabinet on an equal basis with the majority Progressive and Liberal parties apparently had broken down tonight.

Horatio Weaves Legend A welcome note was struck in the Herald Tribune's editorial comment the other day on Horatio Alger, concerning whom it had been disclosed on his latest birthday that very few children today have heard of him and practically nobody reads him.

Net earnings from current operations of the Chase National Bank last year were $2.59 a share, or 10 per cent greater than in 1945, when the net was $2.36 a share. But a relatively sharp decrease in profits on securities more than offset the gain, Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the board, said yesterday in the bank's annual report.

The Office of the Cultural Attache to the French Embassy announces an exhibition of work by the French artist, Jean Crotti, which will open tomorrow afternoon at the Centre d'Etudes Superieures Franco-American, 934 Fifth Avenue. The work to be shown is a new medium of art expression, "Les Gemmaux," the use of bits of colored glass skillfully applied.

After study of the alternative plans for completion, and operation of New York City's airports we believe the city's interest will be best served by putting the Port Authority in charge, and for these reasons: 1. The $80,000,000 investment offered by the City Airport Authority is entirely inadequate to provide for the city's expanding air future.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Public hearings on the impending opening of negotiations for broadened reciprocal trade treaties, ended here today by the Committee for Reciprocity Information, have built up a voluminous record demonstrating in the main that war experience did little to close the gap in opposing views on reciprocity.

During 1946 the volume of business of the Title Guaranty and Trust Company exceeded that of any year since 1932 and net operating profit was $1,004,394, Harold W. Hoyt, president, reported yesterday at the annual stockholders' meeting. In addition, he said, $124,071 was realized from the sale of securities.

The Washington Capitols increased their lead over the New York Knickerbockers in the race for the Eastern Division title of the Basketball Association of America by defeating the local professional quintet, 65 to 63, in a thrill-packed contest at the Sixtyninth Reghnent Armory last night.
LONDON, Jan. 15 -- Deputies of the Council of Foreign Ministers spent a fruitless and discouraging day arguing on procedure for the German peace treaty and they ended just about where they began.

At a negotiations meeting held yesterday at the American Merchant Marine Institute, 11 Broadway, it was proposed that Atlantic and Gulf Coast steamship operators accept the results achieved by wage arbitration on the Pacific Coast, as a national pattern for radio officers.

Satisfactory customer service essential now that stores agair face the need for intensive selling may best be achieved by building of a top-flight personnel. J.N. McFee, store manager of Hutzler Brothers Company, Baltimore, declared yesterday.

BERLIN, Jan. 15 -- The commander of the Russian military administration in Germany, Marshal Vassily D. Sokolovsky, has promised leaders of the Socialist Unity party (S.E.D.) that the dismantling of industrial plants in the Russian zone will cease and that reparations from current production will be considerably limited, it was reliably learned tonight.

In what undoubtedly constitutes an unprecedented action in the theatre, Jose Ferrer star and producer of "Cyrano de Bergerac," will turn over his production of the Rostand play this afternoon to a staff of understudies. The standby artists will assume all the leading roles while the featured players will portray the bit parts.

Bearing the label of Sophie, a collection of ready-to-wear millinery with a fine individualized feeling: was introduced by Saks Fifth Avenue yesterday in a showing at the Sophie Studio, 27 West Fiftysixth Street. These hats will be available at Saks stores throughout the country and at specialty shops in other cities.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Secretary of State Byrnes will sign the peace treaties with the former Axis satellites in the State Department Monday, the State Department announced today.

In a move to place operations on a profitable basis, Taca Airways, S.A., holding company of the Taca Airways System, announced yesterday a sweeping reorganization of administrative personnel and a new financing program in which Waterman Airlines, Inc., will play a prominent part.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The emergency fund of the late President Roosevelt, into which Congress put $648,900,000 and required no detailed accounting during the war, emerged today as a prospective principal target of the Senate War Investigating Committee.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company reported yesterday that net income for the December quarter amounted to $53,234,000. This was equal to $2.59 a share and compared with $45,704,293, or $2.27 a share, in the final quarter of 1945.
Counsel for Charles Edwards, found dead on Monday in his fiveroom cold-water flat at 247 Baltic Street in Brooklyn said yesterday that he had left a will that in due time will be filed for probate.

Isthmian Steamship Lines takes over today the east side of the Port of New York Authority's grain terminal pier at Columbia, Street, Brooklyn, on a "preferential, but not exclusive" lease, if was announced last night. The west side berth has been awarded to the Fern Line, as of May 1, 1947.

Isthmian Steamship Lines takes over today the east side of the Port of New York Authority's grain terminal pier at Columbia, Street, Brooklyn, on a "preferential, but not exclusive" lease, if was announced last night. The west side berth has been awarded to the Fern Line, as of May 1, 1947.

Georgia's political tangle now presents the unedifying spectacle of two Governors trying: to rule the State, each claiming constitutional authority and each with his own military establishment to back it up. Such a troublebrewing situation cannot last. Obviously only one holds office legally. Either "Governor" Arnall or "Governor" Talmadge must yield.

Gounod's "Romeo and Juliet" received its first performance of the season last night at the Metropolitan, with Jussi Bjoerling in the role of Romeo for the first time with the company. Bidu Sayao was the Juliet of the competent cast. The presentation moved smoothly, and with dramatic forcefulness.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 15 -- Making unions equally responsible with management and revision of the Wagner Act were urged here tonight by C.M. White, president of Republic Steel Corporation, in an address before the National Materials Handling Association.

The versatile talents of Edith Head, Hollywood designer associated with Paramount Pictures, were expressed yesterday noon in a large collection of her designs, seen at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in the Sert Room. The interest in this designer's work was evidenced by the fact that the restaurant was packed.
Assisted by 4-year-old Nancy Drury of Louisville, Ky., Mayor O'Dwyer officially opened the March of Dimes campaign in Rockefeller Plaza yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The United States and Poland stood deadlocked today over the election in that country with the receipt by the State Department of the note from the Provisional Government in Warsaw rejecting the American protests.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Louis V. Dionne, an employe of the War Assets Administration, and George A. Gormley, a former convict, have been arrested for an alleged fraud, J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, stated today.

TO THE EDITOR OF NEW YORK TIMES: It would be a pity if recent discussions of the excesses that have been attending college athletic contests were allowed to lapse into an attitude of complacency on our part or should not be productive of constructive action to remove the evils pointed out here.

A 10 per cent cut in the city's child health services went into effect yesterday as the Health Department began withdrawing: nursing service from public and parochial schools and closing child health stations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The Republican leadership of the Senate hopes to have labor legislation ready for floor action about March 1, it was announced today by Senator Robert A. Taft, chairman of the Republican Policy Committee.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 15 -- Establishment of an inter-governmental shipping organization is expected to be pressed by the maritime powers in the United Nations. It would be patterned after agencies such as the World Health Organization and take its place beside the transportation agencies for aviation, postal services and telecommunications.

LONDON, Jan. 15 (U.P.) -- Following is the text of a note from Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov to Lieut. Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, United States Ambassador to Russia, in reply to a note from the latter on the Polish national election to be held Sunday:

The share market on the New York Stock Exchange was unable yesterday to retain the slight advantage scored on Tuesday due to a final-hour attack which eliminated or reduced mid-session gains. The late pressure was not concentrated on any particular group but ranged through a list of individual issues recently the target of liquidation, so that 433 out of the 905 issues dealt in closed lower while 257 showed gains.

MOSCOW, Jan. 15 -- The Soviet Government sees no necessity of interfering in the conduct of the forthcoming Polish elections or the internal affairs of Poland, according to a note signed by Foreign Minister Molotov that answered a United States note presented by Ambassador Walter Bedell Smith on Jan. 5.
LONDON, Jan. 15 -- Britain, in a third note to Warsaw published here tonight, accuses the Polish Government of violating its pledge to hold free elections.

Nail Shortage Returns The critical shortage of nails marking price control has returned in an equally, severe form, industrial buyers reported here yesterday. Steel and bronze nails for roofing purposes are particularly short, they said. Price increases have resulted in expansion of some production, they said, with some improvement expected before the end of the second quarter.

This country, on the eve of the Moscow conference, still lacks a definite peace policy toward Germany, Mrs. William Dick Sporborg, member of the United States national commission for the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, declared yesterday.

Three members of a Brooklyn family, said by the Federal Bureau of Investigation to be members of an "underground movement" to assist escaped Italian prisoners of war, were charged yesterday in Federal Court, Brooklyn, with harboring two fugitives.
LONDON, Jan. 15 -- With professional buyers in evidence activity increased in the stock markets today. Steady buying sent industrial shares soaring in practically every group.

An account of Russia and of the average Russian citizen has been written by Richard E. Lauterbach, the first American correspondent to visit Vladivostok and the Soviet Far Eastern areas since the war. 'Through Russia's Back Door" tells also how he escaped with his uncensored notebooks and 200 photographs.

CHICAGO, Jan. 15 -- There was a lack of the aggressive buying of grain futures on the Board of Trade today such as featured yesterday's session. Cash and commission houses were on the selling side and although short covering caused some recovery wheat futures closed at losses of 3/8 to 7/8 cent a bushel.
TORONTO, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs stretched their National Hockey League lead to nine points tonight by clipping the runner-up Montreal Canadians, 2 -- 1.

Steel Negotiations Industrial and steel circles have been speculating on the "real reason" for the eleventh-hour postponement of wage negotiations between officials of the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, and the United States Steel Corporation, which were scheduled to commence this morning in Pittsburgh.

HARRISON, N. Y., Jan. 15 -- Tattered maps were examined, town archives were brought from storage and shovels were swung today in a frantic search by Harrison officials and property 'owners for 752 feet of missing sewer line. The sewer has been listed on town maps since 1913, when it was supposed to have been installed, and the abutting property owners have been taxed for it ever since.

Random, notes. East Coast sportsmen who are aware of the importance of eelgrass and its definite relation to the abundance of waterfowl and coastal fishes will be relieved to know that a co-operative project to restore this plant along the Atlantic coast has been initiated by several State and wildlife conservation agencies.

MOSCOW, Jan. 15 -- The Soviet Government sees no necessity of interfering in the conduct of the forthcoming Polish elections or the internal affairs of Poland, according to a note signed by Foreign Minister Molotov that answered a United States note presented by Ambassador Walter Bedell Smith on Jan. 5.
LONDON, Jan. 15 -- Britain, in a third note to Warsaw published here tonight, accuses the Polish Government of violating its pledge to hold free elections.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16--The use of fog dispersal equipment, airborne radar and other new devices and mechanisms would immeasurably promote aviation safety, James M. Landis, chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, told the Senate Commerce Committee today.
Made up entirely of paintings owned by the firm, a big and remarkable exhibitions of Italian art has been opened to the public at Wildenstein's 19 East Sixty-fourth Street.

Retailers of the nation were called upon "to discourage price advances, insist on improved merchandise quality and work for stabilized levels which will encourage consumption and maintain production and employment," in a resolution adopted unanimously yesterday at the conclusion of the annual convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

If you happen to be fishing along the Florida Keys this winter and come across a man on one of the tidal flats whose face shows an expression of mingled anticipation, rapture and fear, you can be certain it will be Dick Warner or another angler who has just found out about bonefishing.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP)-- Officials of the War and Justice Departments conferred today on the Georgia Governorship fight and its relation to that State's National Guard.

The need to "glamorize" house-hold employment to attract more workers was emphasized yesterday by Julius A. Thomas, director of industrial relations of the National Urban League. He spoke at a panel discussion on "The Vanishing Domestic Worker," yesterday in the clubrooms of the New York City branch of the American Association of University Women at the Midston House.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16--With bi-partisan support, Representative Robert A. Grant, Republican, of Indiana, introduced a bill in the House today to freeze for an indefinite period excise taxes on liquor, furs, jewelry and many other luxury items at their present wartime rates.

LINCOLN, Neb., Jan. 16--Prosecution of the Government's anti-trust case against the Association of American Railroads, the Western Association of American Railroads, the Western Association of| Railway Executives and others will open in Federal court here on April 23.

A consistent decrease in the nation's water supply that may result in its strict control and rationing was reported yesterday at the ninety-fourth annual meeting of the American Society of Civil Engineers at the Commodore Hotel.

Unless the tenants of 50 Manhattan Avenue, near 102d Street, assume full responsibility for the "guards" they hired to protect them against crime in the sixstory modern apartment house, the owner will remove the men from the premises, he said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16--President Truman's announcement of the proposal to unify the armed forces won quick approval from some members of Congress tonight, but others asserted that they wanted to "see the details."

CORAL, GABLES, Fla., Jan. 16 (AP)--The flashy Westminster took all of Tropical Park's $30,000 Double Event as he sped home in record-breaking style with three lengths ahead of the small five-horse field today to capture the second division on the track's closing program.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP)-- The State Department said today in a report on international atomic energy control policy that it must be accepted "for the foreseeable future there can be no adequate military defense against atomic weapons."

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 16--The appalling loss of more than two hundred lives in the three recent hotel fires could have been averted by the "application of a few simple, well-known principles in the fields of fire prevention and protection," Curtis W. Pierce of New York, president of the National Fire Protection Association, asserted here today.

CAIRO. Egypt, Jan. 16--With the time approaching for the FourPower commission to visit Libya, political activity is increasing among the Arabs of the former Italian colonial territory who aspire to future self-government.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Jan. 16--Protestant missionary leaders urged the Foreign Missions Conference of North America today to formulate a Christian program of sufficient magnitude to counteract the "steadily increasing adherence to the materialistic faith of Marxian philosophy, fostered by the expanding influence of Soviet Russia."

A new type of non-run nylon stockings will be released to the public in a "very short time," it was announced yesterday. The stockings are finished with a wartime developed chemical demonstrated last night by Dr. Donald H. Powers, director of textile chemical research for the Monsanto Chemical Company.

Big Harry Boykoff netted 24 points, matching the season's high rat Madison Square Garden last night, and it was well for St. John's that he did. For the Brooklyn Redmen otherwise would have been in straits against a spirited Temple University quintet that Swaged a tremendous uphill struggle before succumbing, 64-50.
LONDON, Jan. 16--The formation of a British committee, under the chairmanship of Winston Churchill, to further the cause of a United Europe was announced today.

William (Little Gangy) Davidson, 41 years old, reputed aspirant to the leadership of Brownsville's underworld, was sentenced yesterday by Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz in Kings County Court to twenty to forty years in Sing Sing on six counts of assault.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 16--A public opinion poll on national politics is now being conducted by the independent Ta Kung Pao, China's most influential newspaper. Ta Kung Pao's readers tend to be on the intellectual side and the first week's response of sixty-two letters is by no means conclusive.

BOSTON, Jan. 16--Because public service is not held in high esteem, the country is constantly in danger of entrusting highly complex responsibilities to second-rate men, Arthur S. Flemming, United States Civil Service Commissioner, warned today.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 16 (AP)--The Pittston Company is not opposed to dissolution of Cliffs Corporation but will "fight and insist" that the common stock of the Cleveland Cliffs Iron Company, a Cliffs Corporation subsidiary, be sold in one block at competitive bidding, J. P. Routh, Pittston president and board chairman, declared today in a telegram to E. B. Greene, Cliffs Corporation president.

Every move made by the New York Yankees to land Charley Trippi for their gridiron and diamond forces was so much waste of time and effort. That became certain early yesterday when the Georgia tailback strode into the Yankees offices and informed the powers-that-be that he would not accept their offer, said to be $105,000 for five years of football and two years of baseball.

Treasury Redemption The Treasury's announcement yesterday that it would redeem in cash $1,000,000,000 of a $4,953,989,000 issue of one-year 7/8 of 1 per cent debt certificates maturing on Feb. 1 was scarcely unexpected in view of earlier portents.

MOSCOW, Jan. 16--Concern over the possible Americanization of the Ruhr as a result of the economic union of the United States and British zones in Germany was expressed today in another article outlining the Soviet viewpoint on Germany.

LONDON, Jan. 16 -- Britain's outlaw strike of truckmen, food handlers and dock and river workers was settled today, and 50,000 workers in the London area alone will return to their jobs Saturday. Outside London also, where several thousand sympathy strikers have tied up food deliveries in industrial and seaport areas, the announcement of the London settlement started a return-to-work movement, and all areas were expected to be in normal operation by Saturday.

In its report for 1946 the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation is able to note that for the second year in succession there was not a single failure among the insured banks of the nation. In only one instance was it found necessary to forestall such a possibility by arranging for the merger with a stronger institution of a bank which found itself in a "shaky" condition.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16--Final 1947 farm production goals, announced today by Secretary of Agriculture Clinton P. Anderson, are higher than last year's actual plantings and higher than the prewar averages.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16--During the week ended Jan. 15 the Federal Reserve Board announced today, member bank reserve balances decreased $26,000,000.

ABOARD MOUNT OLYMPUS, Off the Bay of Whales, Jan. 16-- Completing a 10,000-mile voyage southward from Norfolk, Va., the main body of the Navy's Antarctic expedition arrived at Little America yesterday morning.

Reynolds to Spend $2,000,000 A national advertising program to spend up to $2,000,000 in newspapers and magazines on the 1947 line of Reynolds "Rocket" ball pens, with 90 per cent to be expended in newspapers, was announced yesterday by Milton Reynolds, board chairman, in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

PARIS, Jan. 16--Vincent Auriol, "old guard" Socialist from the south of France and chairman of the newly created National Assembly, was elected the first President of the Fourth French Republic today by a joint session of Parliament sitting in the Palace of Versailles.

Curtailment of some nursing services in public and parochial schools and closing of child health stations in some sections of the city are "only temporary measures" and the services will be reestablished as soon as possible, Health Commissioner Israel Weinstein said yesterday.

Wholesalers of apparel items can bring about a closer tie between themselves and manufacturers by concentrating on a program of brand-name promotions, it was pointed out last night by Bernard Sands, executive secretary of the National Wholesale Garment Association.

Although the understudies of Jose Ferrer's "Cyrano de Bergerac" are inferior to the principal performers, let's face it. They are very good indeed. "Cyrano" may not be rattling good theatre at their hands, but it still swashbuckles in the proper places.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16--The texts of exchanged letters and a proposed executive order on armed forces unification issued by the White House tonight are as follows: The President's Letter Letter from President Truman to Secretaries Patterson and Forrestal:

ROME, Jan. 16--The Vatican City newspaper Osservatore Romano said today the Italian clergy would exert all influence in its power to combat legislation harmful to the interests of the Catholic Church.

PARIS, Jan. 16--The longawaited report of Overseas Minister Marius Moutet on his trip to Indo-China, which was to have been presented on Tuesday, was heard today at the last meeting of Leon Blum's Socialist Cabinet before it resigned. M. Moutet also talked to United States Ambassador Jefferson Caffery.

MINDEN, Germany, Jan. 16-- In a surprising demonstration of strong central party leadership, the Socialist Democratic party took over the economic leadership of the Anglo-American zones today. The first act of the new Economic Executive Council, most powerful German economic group in both zones, was to force the resignation of Dr. Rudolph Mueller, chairman of the body, and his deputy, Dr. Harold Rasch, neither of whom has any party affiliation.

Shipping in New York Harbor began to move again yesterday and some plane operations were reported at La Guardia Field, as light showers caused a break in the fog that has blanketed the area for two days.
