BERLIN, Jan. 15 (AP)--Lieut. Gen. Lucius D. Clay, chief of United States Military Government, asked the Russians for an explanation today of their announced plan to increase the level of production in German industry by 200 to 300 per cent in their zone.
ALBANY, Jan. 16--The Legislature was asked today to set the State up as a patron of resident artists.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16--A twoyear-old wage dispute which led to last fall's strike of Trails World Airline pilots was laid in the hands of a three-man arbitration board here today as attorneys for the company and the Air Line Pilots' Association, AFL, made their concluding remarks.

Representatives of the seventeen airlines with leases at Idlewild Airport are scheduled to meet here today to seek means of speeding the settlement of the controversy over the completion of that facility and the improvement of La Guardia Field.

"China's Destiny," by Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, has caused so much interest that two concerns Will publish it within one week of each other, and under the same title. The book originally was published in China in 1943, and was Issued in 1944 in a revised edition.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16--Grain markets were under pressure early, with wheat off 1 3/4 to 4 1/8 cents a bushel and corn and oats more than 1 cent off at one time on general selling which disclosed a lack of support. Some stop-loss orders were uncovered in July wheat, which lead the decline.
CHICAGO, Jan. 16 (AP)--The Chicago Cubs kept mum today on their plans for All-America football star Charley Trippi, when and if the Georgia University athlete comes to baseball terms with them.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16--The first official move in the new Congress to block extension of the reciprocal trade treaty program of the Administration occurred today with introduction of a House resolution by Thomas A. Jenkins, Republican, of Ohio.

The Board of Estimate authorized yesterday the use of $50,000 of capital funds to enable City Construction Coordinator Robert Moses to employ engineers and architects to assist him in the job of rounding out street approaches in the vicinity of the permanent home of the United Nations. The work will be done near Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive, between East Forty-second and Forty-eighth Streets.

ATLANTA, Jan. 16 -- Herman Talmadge, supported by a few uniformed military men, took possession of the Gubernatorial chambers in the State Capitol and the Executive Mansion today in his battle with Ellis Arnall, rival claimant to the Georgia Governorship.

The Maritime Commission has approved the sale of an additional 101 war-built merchant ships, it was announced h yesterday. This raises to 818 the number of such vessels disposed of under the terms of the Ship Sales Act of 1946.

NANKING, Jan. 16--The Chinese Government launched, a new move for peace with the Communists today. It announced that Gen. Chang Chih-chung, Governor of Sinkiang Province had been named to visit Yenan in an attempt to renew peace negotiations with the Communists.

EXPLORERS, says Vilhjalmur Stefansson, are cocky folk. Although their courage, heroism, endurance and skill are often magnificent, most explorers are inexcusable braggarts, always claiming that they have "discovered" new islands and new lands. Whereas the fact is that everywhere an explorer has gone, except to Antarctica, he has been met on the spot by the original settlers of the place.

MONTREAL, Jan. 16 (AP)--R. A. A. Holt, British universities champion, entered the third round of the Canadian amateur racquets championships today by defeating R. R. McLearnon of Montreal with the loss of only 9 points.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 16--The Birmingham Electric Company's proposal to sell 45,478 shares of its preferred stock to the First Boston Corporation, representing an underwriting syndicate, was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Another pair of the younger crop of welterweights will headline the boxing program at Madison Square Garden tonight. Billy Graham, East Side warrior, will oppose Ruby Kessler, willing performer from Coney Island, in a ten-round clash, and in so doing will make it two in a row for the 147-pounders at the Bight Avenue Arena.

PARIS, Jan. 17 (AP)--Prof. Johan Smertenko, vice president of the American League for a Free Palestine, returned today from London where he spent a night in a police station and said he had asked the United States State Department to protest his exclusion from Britain.

The proposed amendment to the constitution of the New York Stock Exchange permitting member firms to incorporate failed yesterday to win the approval of a majority of twenty-two governors present at a regular meeting held in the Exchange board room.

As a result of its growth in membership and world-wide activity the religious sect known as Jehovah's Witnesses will begin construction soon of a ten-story addition to Bethel Home, its national headquarters at 122-124 Columbia Heights in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16--Lewis B. Schwellenbach, Secretary of Labor, today approved health and welfare fund clauses in collective bargaining contracts as "an effective and flexible means of providing greater social security through collective bargaining."

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 16--A revolt against the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen welled up today among the 2,700 members who work for the Pacific Electric Company, a Southern Pacific Railroad subsidiary which operates intercity trains and buses in the Los Angeles area.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 16-- Paramount today announced plans for a film treatment of the reign of Ludwig II of Bavaria and his patronage of Richard Wagner, under the title "Midnight King." Aeneas MacKenzie is writing the scenario for Robert Fellows, producer, and production is scheduled for late 1947.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Jan. 16 --The "United Nations commission of inquiry to the Balkans left for France en route to Athens today aboard the liner America, taking seven tons of cooking stoves, typewriters, sleeping bags and other equipment.

The report of the Pennsylvania-Central Airlines Corporation, issued yesterday, for the nine months ended with last September showed a net loss of $1,029,841 after a $581.000 tax carry-back credit. For the corresponding period of 1945, the airline had a net Income of $796,618, or $1.67 a share.

Twenty-six men and women were honored yesterday for service to the Belgians during the war with awards from Charles, Prince Regent of Belgium, in a presentation ceremony at the Hotel St. Regis. Baron Robert Silvercruys, Belgian Ambassador to the United States, conferred the decorations, assisted by Count Yvan du Monceau, millitary attache, and Carlos van Bellinhen, first secretary of the embassy.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Jan. 16-- Budapest has been wrapped for most of today in a fog worthy of London at its worst. It formed an ideal background for Hungary's present political situation, crowded as it was by accusations and counter-accusations of plots and counter-plots.

RICHMOND, Calif., Jan. 16 (AP) --United States Open Champion Lloyd Mangrum, the man with the stylish swing, carded a 64 today to equal the course record and move into the lead in the first round of the 72-hole $10,000 Richmond open golf tournament.

BERLIN, Jan. 16--The aims of the United States Military Government for the future control of the German radio were set forth today to counteract reports that the United States desired state ownership of the broadcasting facilities.

Four groups of well designed hats were presented yesterday by Emme in a spring and summer collection at 21 East Fifty-sixth Street. In the first group, small, close-fitting hats were featured in snug, helmet-like little caps, softened by folds and deftly manipulated brims.
Settlement of difficulties in the operation of a school for sixty children of Russian representatives here was forecast yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: For the technical information in Father La Faroe's letter on the status of Myron Taylor and the Apostolic Delegate, I am grateful. It, however, does not change the fact that most Protestants will welcome the withdrawal of Mr. Taylor.

A BANK clerk almost ruined one of the most important and vital trades he ever maneuvered, Larry MacPhail confided the other night. What is more, he confided it to Branch Rickey, the man he was trying to foil on that particular occasion.

Stock prices followed a shifting course again yesterday and closed firmer after new lows for the year had been set. While final quotations were at the best of the day, the list still leaned heavily to the lower side. But some optimism developed when the rails pushed forward sufficiently to offset a loss in the industrial section and leave a slight advantage for the composite rate.

American dollars--millions of them--are this week feeing spent at the moat amazing, fantastic, record-shattering National Motor Boat Show in history. Yesterday was another day of superlatives at the Grand Central Palace, with another large crowd.

Distorted, faded and otherwise damaged clothing and draperies were displayed yesterday at 101 West Thirty-first Street by the National Institute of Cleaning and Dyeing to show faults in textiles that often prevent further use after cleaning.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16--Average primary market prices advanced 0.6 per cent during the week ended on Jan. 11, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, United States Department of Labor.

The clouds of uncertainty that have been hanging over France and all western Europe have lifted measurably as a result of two promising developments The first is the election by the two Houses of Parliament of Vincent Auriol, a Socialist and the most success ful peacemaker in French politics, as the first regularly chosen President of the Fourth French Republic.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (U.P.)-- The Veterans Administration has officially closed its pension list based on service in the War of 1812. Its report for 1946 revealed that the final beneficiary died last March, more than 130 years after the war ended in 1815.

Richard Steere, cigar connoisseur, who was an employe of Park Tilford's for fifty-three years until his retirement eight years ago, died on Wednesday in his home at 420 Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn. His age was 82. Mr. Steere was born in Sherbrooke, Canada, came to this country in 1886, and joined the company the same year in its store at Sixth Avenue and Ninth Street.

Skiing conditions, as usual this winter, continue to be uncertain and a bit deplorable as the reports yesterday from the North Country showed a variety of weather that is record-breaking in itself this season.

TOKYO, Jan. 16--The next session of the Japanese Parliament was postponed today from Jan. 21 to Feb. 1 to permit the political situation to be clarified before any new legislative program is introduced. This action was taken by the Parliamentary party leaders of the Lower House who met this afternoon and approved the Government's request for a delay.

The weekly statement of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System issued yesterday is marked by the absence of any significant changes over the previous week. The report, released by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, covers the week ended on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16--Those who privately discussed labor-management problems with Miss Frances Perkins while she was Secretary of Labor were not surprised to note that, in a Town Hall lecture in New York City yesterday, she put her finger accurately on the basic fault in the most recent portal-to-portal decision of the Supreme Court.

Issues Spring Hosiery Colors Five new tones, three of which were created specifically for nylon and two for silk and rayon, are shown in the confidential advance hosiery card for spring, issued yesterday by the Textile Color Card Association.

The Bethlehem Steel Company became yesterday the first basic steel company to receive the contract demands of the United Steel Workers, CIO. A union committee, headed by Joseph P. Molony of Buffalo, district director, presented the demands to company officials at a two and one-half hour session in the Bethlehem offices at 25 Broadway.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16--Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended Jan. 11, 1947, totaled 830,945 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 143,517 cars, or 20.9 per cent more than for the preceding week, 58,057 cars, or 7.5 per cent more than for the corresponding week of last year, and 47,885 cars, or 6.1 per cent more than for the corresponding week of two years ago.

A new form of an old art will be seen today at the Centre d' Etudes Superieures, 934 Fifth Avenue, where will be opened the first American exhibition of paintings constructed of glass by the French artist, Jean Crotti.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: THE NEW YORK TIMES editorial on the President's message is very much to the point, especially in its criticism of Mr. Truman's labor program. There is little doubt that these recommendations, as a whole, fail to furnish a comprehensive answer to the industrial relations issue, so important an aspect of our confused national scene.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16--Richard S. Whaley, Chief Justice of the Court of Claims of the United States since 1939 and a member of that bench since 1930, has sent his resignation to President Truman. The Chief Justice was 72 years old in July.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16--Robert E. Hannegan, Democratic National Chairman, today called upon Republicans favoring cooperation between Congress and the Chief Executive to "choose between their honest convictions and the instructions they are getting from Republican headquarters."

There Are Tickets It is not unusual of late to meet people who tell you with every sign of happy anticipation that they have in their pockets a couple ef tickets for "Oklahoma" purchased at the box office and not, as you would imagine, for a year and a half ahead, but only for a fortnight away or possibly even sooner.

ROME, Jan. 16--The announcement that France and Great Britain intend to conclude a military alliance was regarded in Italy today as a great victory for the French anti-fusionist Socialists headed by Premier Leon Blum.

MONTREAL, Jan. 16 (AP)--The Canadiens ended a four-game losing streak tonight by battling the National Hockey League's front-running Maple Leafs to a 1-1 tie. Bud Poile blasted a shot past Goalie Bill Durnan of the Canadiens at 2:30 of the first period, during which Referee King Clancy called ten of twenty penalties imposed during the game.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16 (AP)--The Federal Government today charged a patent-holding company, nine screw manufacturers and eight screwdriver and bit manufacturers with violating the Anti-Trust law through price-fixing, patent-pooling and other restraints of trade.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16--President Truman announced tonight that the War and Navy Departments had officially resolved their long and bitter row by agreeing to unification of the armed forces.

TOKYO, Jan. 16--Tanzan Ishibashi, Japan's Finance Minister, recited for the foreign press tonight a number of developments and Cabinet decisions that he felt would improve the economic situation and revealed his optimism.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16--The veto power of the five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council cannot be used legally to protect an aggressor from the consequence of his crime, Warren R. Austin, United States representative to the United Nations and its Security Council, told the eighth general assembly of the Council of State Governments here today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16--Department store sales in the week ended Jan. 11 were 24 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of last year:

OSLO, Norway, Jan. 16 (U.P.)-- Norway is willing to consider the possibility of a Russian-Norwegian agreement for military bases on Spitsbergen provided that the United States, Britain and other interested powers agree, a Foreign Office communique said tonight.

RYE, N. Y., Jan. 16--A drive to collect $2,000,000 for construction of Stepinac High School for Boys in White Plains was started tonight at a rally of 1,500 Roman Catholic priests and laymen in the Westchester Country Club here.

Frederick Lewis Allen, editor of Harper's, warned the nation's magazine publishers yesterday that "a trend toward journalism of the closed mind" is limiting the area for free discussion in periodicals and hastening the hardening of this country's "intellectual arteries."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16--Educators, scientists and military officials have presented their separate views on universal military training before the fifth session of the President's Advisory Commission on Universal Training, the White House announced today.

Four of the hardy perennials of the Stokowski programs, in the shape of as many of his most popular and familiar transcriptions of Bach and Wagner, plus the second "Brandenburg" concerto and Beethoven's Eighth Symphony, made the program that the conductor arranged for his fourth and final Thursday appearance as guest leader this season, of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall.

The Greek-owned steamship Katoomba, visiting the port of New York on her first service from the Mediterranean, was the object of a $300,000 suit filed in Federal court in Newark yesterday by fifty-seven dissatisfied passengers.

A court-inspired promise to repeal information on the recent Brooklyn City Prison jail break won yesterday for James Donnelly, 28 years old, a delay and possible leniency in his sentence on a charge of robbery.

Scruggs - Vandervoort - Barney, Inc., of St. Louis, registered an unspecified number of shares of $4.50 cumulative preferred stock, Series A without par value but with a stated value of $100 a share. An underwriting group headed by Union Securities Corporation, Boettcher Co. and G. H. Walker Co., will offer the securities to the public at a price to be filed by amendment.

Anna Mayer stopped hiccoughing yesterday. Relief came to the 23-year-old victim of a sixty-day attack after the surgeon for whom she had appealed to President Truman had operated on her for the third time. The operation, in which an inch and a half of the phrenic nerve that controls the diaphragm was removed, was pronounced a success, but Miss Mayer's condition was still listed as serious.

The major decline in butter prices since the end of the year has featured a general decline in food prices. When the President announced the elimination of price controls for foods, and later for other products, there were many predictions that "runaway prices" would inevitably develop.

LONDON, Jan. 16--With brokers reporting a considerable increase in buying orders the stock markets here opened in good style today. A small setback around midday, due to profit-taking, was regained and markets closed firm.
CHICAGO, Jan. 16--John Holmes, president of Swift Co., told stockholders today that prospects for large meat production in 1947 give promise of a "favorable year" for the meat industry.

At the third performance this season of Rossini's "The Barber of Seville," given last night at the Metropolitan, Ferruccio Tagliavini made his second appearance with the company. The Italian tenor, who had scored heavily at his recent debut as Rudolfo in Puccini's "Boheme," this tune was entrusted with the role of the Count of Almaviva, a part entirely different in its vocal and histrionic demands.

ALBANY, Jan. 16--Up-State mayors, at a meeting here today agreed unanimously on a five-point program for broadening municipal taxing powers that they will ask the Legislature to approve. New York City was not represented at the meeting but sent word that it did not believe additional taxing powers for cities is the proper solution for their financial difficulties.

One of the curious truths about the smoke nuisance in cities is that the offender who creates this smoke, which costs the innocent millions of dollars in a place like New York, would save himself much money if he burned his coal efficiently with a minimum of smoke.
MOSCOW, Jan. 15 (Delayed)-- The "agitation point" of the Thirtyfifth Ward of the Kirov election district of Moscow is a pretty busy place now that elections for the Supreme Soviet are approaching.

Although abundant supplies of most foods have resulted in lower prices on the wholesale market, retail stores have not made many drastic reductions. In fact, quite the contrary has taken place, and housewives doing their shopping this week-end will notice increases in a number of cases.
ALBANY, Jan. 16--The Court of Appeals granted a new trial today to Benjamin Feldman, Brooklyn pharmacist, convicted last year of murdering his wife by strychnine poisoning.

LONDON, Jan. 16--Britain must try to adjust the balance between earnings of American films in Britain and those of British films in the United States, Sir Stafford Cripps, President of the Board of Trade, said tonight.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 16-- Business men, individuals and firms, who operate in rented quarters, are rolling up their sleeves to do battle with landlords on what spokesmen assert will be a country-wide, united front. The first step was taken today in San Mateo County, adjoining this city, with the filing of incorporation papers of the National Business Tenants' Association with the County Clerk at Redwood City.

MILL NECK, L. I., Jan. 16-- Despite warnings by policemen and school teachers to stay away from Beaver Pond here, a dozen small boys came from nearby Locust Valley after school this afternoon for a romp on ice that proved too thin.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16--William L. Clayton and Dean Acheson were accused today by Representative Paul W. Shafer of Michigan of using their high State Department offices for personal gain. In a speech to the House he demanded that Gen., George C. Marshall fire the two Undersecretaries and "others who have been posing as pious, public-spirited servants of the people while making exorbitant profits by reason of their high places."

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 16 (AP)--Hialeah Park officials went forward tonight with plans to open a fortyday race meeting before 25,000 spectators in the face of a strike by exercise boys and grooms at Florida's picture book race track.

LONDON, Jan. 16--The underlying economic objective of Franco-British rapprochement, signalized by yesterday's joint expression of intention to draw up a treaty of alliance, is the establishment of a common plan for the development of basic industries.

Two visiting French opera singers reported yesterday to the police of the West Fifty-fourth Street station that their room in the Hotel Chesterfield, 130 West Forty-ninth Street, had been robbed of furs and jewelry valued at $5,500.

All the 400,000 Jews left in Rumania are dependent on the Jews of America for the basic essentials of life, Chief Rabbi Alexander Shafran of Rumania reported yesterday to the administrative committee of the $170,000,000 campaign of the United Jewish Appeal, 342 Madison Avenue.

SHEFFIELD, Ala., Jan. 16 (U.P.) --Police disclosed tonight that a crowd of 300 American Federation of Labor members raided the Committee of Industrial Organization portal-to-portal suit headquarters here, beat up a dozen members of the rival labor organization and ordered them to "get out of town."

LONDON, Jan. 16--Deputies of Council of Foreign Ministers, by a judicious mixture of compromise and postponement, swept aside today many of their procedural dissensions and got down to real business on the German and Austrian treaties.

TRENTON, N. J., Jan. 16--The New Jersey Supreme Court declined today to approve a new trial for John R. Longo, political foe of Mayor Frank Hague in Jersey City, convicted of falsifying his own voting records. A further appeal of the Court of Errors and Appeals is planned.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 16--Predictions of a routine recession in 1947 were discounted here tonight by Merryle Stanley Rukeyser, of New York writer of an economic column for the Hearst newspapers, speaking at the fifty-sixth annual convention of the American Warehousemen's Association in connection with the materials handling exposition.
E. W. Metzger and Frank Walton have been appointed manager of domestic branches and manager of sales training, respectively, of Sharp Dohme, Inc., Philadelphia, pharmaceuticals and biologicals.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) --Retailers may legally refund a purchaser "an amount equivalent to" part or all of the 20 per cent Federal excise tax on furs, jewelry (including silverware) and cosmetics, the Internal Revenue Bureau said today.

American Can Company presented its plan for allocation of tin plate in 1947 to representatives of trade associations of nine of the major industries served by the company, during a meeting here yesterday, company officials announced.

Three juvenile "ambassadors" of good-will from China, the Vlachos-Wei musical prodigies, had their first glimpse of Manhattan yesterday from the Hotel Wentworth. The Chinese mother is Mrs. Frances Han Vlachos-Wei and the children are Sophie, Madeleine and George, 12, 10 and 8 years old, respectively.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 16-- Charles S. Reid, former Chief Justice of the Georgia Supreme Court, expressed as his private opinion today that any realistic view" must lead to the conclusion that Herman Talmadge was illegally elected by the General Assembly as Governor of Georgia.

Henry Soderberg, Swedish, secretary of the International Young Men's Association, returned to New York yesterday after a fourmonth nation-wide tour on which he renewed friendships with several thousand former American prisoners of war he first met in German prison camps from 1942 to the end of the war.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP)-- The Agriculture Department indicated tonight that it would support producer prices of eggs at a national average of 35 to 36 cents a dozen between Feb. 1 and April 30. Under a support program for any commodity, the department offers to buy at its support price any surplus the regular markets cannot take

Sweeping changes in marketing practices to be used immediately by the War Assets Administration in the sale of surplus machine tools were announced to members of the machine tool advisory committee in Washington on Tuesday, members who returned from the meeting disclosed here yesterday.

Twenty-five years ago a young war veteran was running for county judge in Jackson County, Mo. An incident of that campaign that stuck in his memory was "an organization that met on hills and burned crosses and worked behind sheets." The things this organization was doing were such that its members were either afraid or ashamed to show their faces--no doubt a little of both.
An enlarged schedule of racing for next summer, in fact the largest in its one-hundred-year history, was announced last night for the New York Yacht Club by Commodore de Coursey Fales.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16--Powerful industrial voices were raised today in appeals to the new Republican Congress not only for an end to portal-to-portal back pay suits but for "a general overhauling" of the Wage and Hour Law in its entirety.

Student veterans living at Army Hall, a City College dormitory building, are "growing increasingly restive" under the "unjust imposition" of maintaining college classrooms in the building through their dormitory rents, Dr. Harry N. Wright, president of the college, has informed the Board of Higher Education in a message accompanying his budget request for the 1947-48 fiscal year, it was learned yesterday.

WARSAW, Jan. 16--Rising tension throughout Poland, touching off an increasing number of clashes between the underground and the Government security forces, was reported today. In about seventytwo hours the country will go to the polls in the first election since 1935.

The Board of Estimate voted yesterday an appropriation of $3,866,000 to cover the cost of completing 1,000 temporary apartments for veterans that otherwise would have been dropped from the Federal program.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16--The Senate Rules Committee voted today to provide $35,000 for an investigating subcommittee to inquire into contested Senatorial elections in Maryland and West Virginia.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16--Secretary of State Byrnes will leave the first Cabinet post with few regrets. He has helped to contain the Soviet surge. He is about to sign the first five peace treaties of World War II. He is relaxing and letting his mind turn back again to his two loves:

Two weeks ago our State Department urged Moscow to join with us in demanding that the Provisional Government of Poland stop terrorizing its opponents and take steps to assure that "free and unfettered election" which was solemnly promised by the Yalta and Potsdam Declarations--to both of which Russia and the United States were parties.

Our faithful Canadian scouts stumbled over an item yesterday and thought it of sufficient importance to apprise us immediately. The gist of their findings went like this: "Donald Wolf it and his troupe of classical actors due at New York's Century Tuesday night, Feb. 18. Roger!"
SAIGON, French Indo-China, Jan. 15 (Delayed)--It is entirely possible that this undeclared war in Indo-China may develop a second front.

A program to increase consumer demand for broilers will begin immediately, it was announced yesterday following a special meeting of the Northeastern Poultry Producers Council in the Pennsylvania Hotel.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Darby Deirdre, a mare owned by L. O. Handley, won the featured Six-furlong Pere Antonine Purse at Fair Grounds today.

The New York City Airport Authority, which submitted to the city last Monday an offer to develop and operate the municipal airports by issuing $80,000,000 of Authority bonds to supplement a city investment of $91,000,000, notified Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday that earlier, assurances of financial backing were repeated on Thursday by representative investment bankers.

Paul G. Hoffman, chairman of the Committee for Economic Development and president of the Studebaker Corporation, called yesterday for retirement of several billion dollars of the public debt even at the sacrifice of needed tax reduction. Debt reduction, he declared, is sound fiscal policy in this period of high prosperity.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Spruille Braden, Assistant Secretary of State, today disclosed plans for a series of conferences with President Truman on the failure of Argentina to comply fully with United States demands for the elimination of Nazi agents and influences.

Billy Graham, East Side welterweight, ruined whatever chance Ruby Kessler had of fighting for the world welterweight title in the immediate future last night in Madison Square Garden. But he couldn't erase the fact that the Coney Island youngster is one of the most courageous fighters in the welterweight class today and a lad who is dangerous even when stag gering around the ring groggily under fire.

LONDON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Two important alterations are embodied in a rare revision of the rules by the Marylebone Cricket Club, ruling body of the sport. The complete revision, first in sixty-three years and only the fourth in cricket history, will go into effect in 1948 following perfunctory approval at a general meeting of the club May 7.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The Federal Reserve System unexpectedly announced tonight the end on Feb. 1 of its anti-inflationary 100 per cent margin requirement for buying securities, and the restoration of the moderately restrictive 75 per cent margin which was in effect for about six months after the end of the war.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- President Truman, in an abrupt move for economy, recommended to Congress today the repeal of appropriations to several Federal departments and agencies totaling $563,888,579.

PEIPING, Jan. 17 -- Nationalist military officials in Changchun, Manchuria, have ordered the Communists in the branch of truce Executive Headquarters there to shut off their radio and remain in their residences at night.
LONDON, Jan. 17 -- Deputies of the Big Four Foreign Ministers made some progress today in clarifying their objectives.

Twelve hours remain -- from 11 o'clock this morning until 11 tonight -- for New Yorkers and visiting cousins to see the spectacle, for the first time since 1941, known as the National Motor Boat Show. Whether they are using inflation dollars or not, the fact remains that visitors to the Grand Central Palace have been buying an unprecedented number of cruisers, runabouts, outboards, motors and gadgets that probably will total $5,000,000 for the week.

Former Governor Herbert H. Lehman received yesterday from the Czechoslovakian Government the Order of the White Lion for his services as Director General of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration. Presentation of the order was made at Mr. Lehman's home, 820 Park Avenue, by Foreign Minister Jan Masaryk of Czechoslovakia.

Michel Nazzi, oboist; Christine Nazzi, flutist; Shephard Coleman, 'cellist, and Bernice Horowitz, harpist, gave a concert of seventeenth and eighteenth century chamber music last night at the Carnegie Chamber Music Hall, which should have been heard by a larger audience, because of its real worth.

A new version of wedding etiquette has resulted from the increased divorce rate, Mrs. Marjorie Woods, wedding counselor for Bride's Magazine, declared yesterday at its ninth annual bridal business clinic at the Hotel WaldorfAstoria.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 17 -- Lieut. Col. Ludwig Ehrhardt, chief of the Nazi intelligence service in the Orient, was sentenced today to life imprisonment by the United States Army Military Commission. He was convicted of conducting espionage for the Japanese after Germany's surrender.

MINDEN, Jan. 17 -- In the first tri-zonal trade conference since the United States and Britain economically fused their zones of occupation, German officials, representing the Soviet-occupied area, predicted today that trade between the combined western area and the eastern zone would be quadrupled this year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The Ways and Means Committee gave speedy and unanimous approval today to a bill to peg excise taxes on furs, liquor, jewelry and many other goods and services at present wartime rates.

ALBANY, Jan. 17 -- The Bankers Trust Company, 16 Wall Street, New York, was authorized by the State Banking Department today to open a branch office temporarily at 61 Broadway for the limited purpose of conducting certain operations of the corporate trust department.

Every child, given the opportunity can create; every child has in him somewhere, some genius, according to Lillian Olinsey, director of the Greenwich House Children's Art Workshop. She has no favorites among the eighteen young artists who, under her supervision, have turned out about forty paintings to be exhibited for two weeks beginning tomorrow in the Village Art Center, 224 Waverly Place.

PARIS, Jan. 17 -- President Vincent Auriol, eager to reach a rapid solution of the French governmental crisis, today designated Paul Ramadier, another old-guard Socialist and colleague, to make the first effort to form a new French Cabinet.

One of the season's worst Atlantic storms was moderating yesterday but several ocean vessels were still running far behind schedule and ships coming in reported details of high winds and rough seas during the crossing.

The World Jewish Congress disclosed yesterday that it would urge the Big Four to include in the German peace treaty control of Germany for at least another generation and some acknowledgment by that nation of the Nazi conspiracy to annihilate the Jews in Europe.

MOUNT HOPE, N.Y., Jan. 17 -- The twelfth annual competition for the Douglas Medal, a three-day bonspiel with an international flavor, opened at the three-rink indoor curling arena of St. Andrews Golf Club today with the field cut in half from its original entry of eighteen rinks.

Opposition to Mayor O'Dwyer's plan to reorganize Tammany by electing Frank J. Sampson leader to succeed Edward V. Laughlin was indicated yesterday when less than a majority of Tammany executive committee members attended a meeting at the Hotel Commodore.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 17--The United Steelworkers of America, CIO, presented today its fourteen contract proposals, topped by a demand for "a substantial wage increase," to the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation, the country's fourth largest basic steel manufacturer.

Responding to protests by the United Parents Association and other civic organizations against closing six of the city's sixty-two child health stations for lack of nurses, Health Commissioner Israel Weinstein announced yesterday he had found a way to keep them open.
Formation of a National Association of Consumers with a membership goal of 10,000,000 was announced here yesterday. The aim will be to "raise and protect" the the American standard of living.

DETROIT, Jan. 17 -- A longbrewing battle between the Chrysler Corporation and the United Automobile Workers, CIO, the outcome, of which may set a new pattern for wages and other contractural agreements in the automotive industry, was brought into the open today with the release of their respective demands.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 17 (UP)-- Maintenance of our post-war Navy at-its current strength and support of a large naval reserve was recommended tonight by Fleet Admiral William F. Halsey Jr., "to guarantee a sound, fair and lasting' peace."
Revised racing rules were presented last night to delegates of the North American Yacht Racing Union assembled in the New York Yacht Club. While it was not so stated, they may be adopted universally.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 17 (AP) -- The American motion picture made British cinemas possible, Samuel Goldwyn, producer, declared today in reply to an English critic of Hollywood films.

BERLIN, Jan. 17 -- A high British Military Government official announced today a plan to turn over the responsibility of coal production in the Ruhr to the Germans. Until now, although allocations of coal had been placed in German hands effective Jan. 1, the actual production job has been retained by the British Control Council for Germany.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 17 -- Gov.elect Alfred E. Driscoll disclosed today his intention to make few changes in key positions in his administration. Most of the executives who have served with Gov. Walter E. Edge were expected to remain.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- A Democratic surprise threw the Senate into a new turmoil today over the Republican proposed continuation of the special War Investigating Committee and appeared to put the result much in doubt.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 17 -- The United Nations will be forced to postpone a study of the industrial uses of atomic energy, proposed by the United States, because of the scarcity of concrete technical information, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The Department of Agriculture announced today the pegging of the New York fluid milk price to producers in February at $5.02 per hundredweight, a 44-cent reduction from the present price of $5.46.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Jan. 17-- Kalman Salata, one of the two Small Holders Deputies expelled by the party two days ago together with a request to the Speaker to suspend their Parliamentary immunity, was missing from his home in Budapest today.

The Metropolitan Opera is running into good luck these days. Its latest newcomer, Mihaly Szekely, who made his debut as Hunding in "Die Walkuere" last night, turned out to be a singer of quality. Exactly how good Mr. Szekely, a basso from Hungary, can be remains to be seen, for Hunding is a short, ungrateful role, but there is no question that he is good enough to be welcome.

'Test for Advertising,' Ryan Says Advocating "hard-hitting, believable" copy as a basic principle for future economic prosperity, Frederick B. Ryan, chairman of the board of Ruthrauff Ryan. Inc., warned last night that the advertising profession is entering a period in which it faces the most serious test in its history.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17--surprise, gratification and relief marked today's discussions on Capitol Hill of President Truman's announcement that the War and Navy Departments had agreed on a formula for unification of the armed forces.

RICHMOND, Calif., Jan. 17 (AP) -- Staving off all challenges with another blistering sub-par performance, U. S. Open champion Lloyd Mangrum had a total of 131 today to hold his lead at the halfway mark of the 72-hole $10,000 Richmond open golf tournament.
WATERTOWN, N.Y., Jan. 17 (AP)--A fire attributed to a lighted cigarette today swept the upper floor of the Graystone Hotel, burning three persons to death and injuring two other guests.

BOSTON, Jan. 17 -- Church-related colleges must carry "out on their campuses a constructive program for Christian living and education to meet the needs of students, the annual meeting of the Council of Church Boards of Education was told today.

ALBANY, Jan. 17 -- Announcing "great concern" about the teacher shortage, the State Board of Regents urged the Legislature today to revise the formula for State aid to education in order to "make permanent an adequate pay schedule for teachers throughout the State."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: THE NEW YORK TIMES should be highly applauded by the citizens of New York for its well-informed and aggressive approach to the problem of smoke abatement. The Park Association of New York City has followed all that has been published on this subject with great interest and approval.

Attempts have been made over and over again to transmit human poliomyelitis directly to some cheap experimental animal. Success was achieved with the monkey, an animal much too expensive for a poorly endowed laboratory. Last November there appeared in the New York State Journal of Medicine an article in which Dr. Claus W. Jungeblut of the College of Physicians and Surgeons described his success in directly infecting albino mice with human polio virus.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Automobile drivers will be able to keep the sun out of their eyes without any trouble if the advantages claimed for a new anti-glare shield by Louis Spraragen of Bridegport, Conn., its inventor, stand up and it is generally adopted.

An exchange of cancer research specialists between Russia and the United States probably will take place in the near future, Prof. Vassily Parin, Secretary General of the Academy of Medical Sciences, U.S.S.R., said yesterday. Professor Parin sailed aboard the Swedish American liner Gripsholm for Goeteborg from pier 97, North River, with 430 other passengers.

The Federal Trade Commission has denied that it categorically supports advertising allowances in the apparel trades on the basis of current practices, it was asserted yesterday by Erwin Feldman, director-counsel of the National Association of House Dress Manufacturers.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 17 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission and the financial field began today a comprehensive study aimed at overhauling the Securities acts.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- As a result of the intensive investigation of Federal workers suspected of subversive affiliations, Carl Aldo Marzani, 35 years old, former State Department employe, has been indicted on charges of concealing his membership in the Communist party, Tom C. Clark, Attorney General, stated today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 17 -- The United Nations Security Council devoted its entire session today to eulogizing Dr. Pedro Leao Velloso, Brazilian representative, who died of a heart attack yesterday in New York.

WARSAW, Jan. 17 -- The Polish authorities' campaign for "manifest and open" voting in Sunday's election -- one of the Government's major weapons to force a majority for itself -- was cloaked today in the legality of a strange interpretation of Poland's Constitutional guarantees for a secret ballot.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 17 -- Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association, declared today that the British threat to impose quotas on the exhibition of American films in Britain would if carried out touch off an international battle of quotas detrimental to the motion-picture industry as a whole.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Judging from the letters published in a recent issue of THE TIMES, there are many people interested in smoke elimination.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17--A chapter closed on two long and bitter fights last night when the President announced that the War and Navy Departments had agreed on a plan for reorganization of the armed-forces.

CHICAGO,. Jan. 17--Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson declared today that despite the great promise of peace embodied in the existence and progress of the United Nations and in our strong adherence to it, we must, pending a general disarmament, remain strong militarily or forfeit our "ability to promote the cause of peace" and expose ourselves to "the greatest peril."

ROME, Jan. 17 -- Plans for the evacuation of 29,000 Italians from Pola, a town in Istria that is to be handed over to Yugoslavia after ratification of the Italian peace treaty, were said today to have been virtually completed.

ALBANY, Jan. 17 -- The State Board of Regents called upon the Legislature today to give the State Education Department authority to revoke the licenses of motion pictures advertised in a suggestive fashion.

The stock market repaired yesterday the damage done earlier in the week to prices as a technical rebound which centered in the industrials produced a recovery of 1 to 2 points. The rally was labeled technical by analysts since the gap made in THE NEW YORK TIMES index on Monday was closed, an operation which market followers insisted must develop before any set course could be charted.

Investment of 2 per cent of the American national income annually for the next twenty years in the economic development of the less fortunate countries of the world was urged last night by Chester Bowles, former Director of Economic Stabilization.

Emerging from a fall season which showed losses for many departments selling women's and misses' apparel, store buyers are determined to prevent a recurrence this spring, according to resident buyers yesterday. Mark-downs will be avoided, they said, by the expedient of moving goods out as fast as they are received with no attempts to build up stocks as was the case last fall.

John M. Hancock, who was associated with Bernard M. Baruch on the United States delegation to the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission until their resignation two weeks ago, predicted yesterday that the United States and Soviet Russia will get what they want eventually in the way of international control of atomic energy.

"DARK DOMINION,"* by Marianne Hauser, is a Gothic tale of contemporary Manhattan. It is a psychoanalytical novel, full of strange undertones and overtones in which dreams count more than realities until the macabre end. The style is as mannered as, say, the different styles of Jenny Ballou or Isaak Dinesen.

BERLIN, Jan. 17 -- This city's 480,000 union members organized under the catchall Free German Trade Union may find themselves without elected leadership if the Allies fail in protracted efforts to settle the problem of voting procedure.

Two new works, by composers who were present, and 'cello playing of a superlative sort, distinguished the recital given by Raya Garbousova, assisted by Erich Itor Kahn, pianist, last night in Town Hall. The composers were Boleslav Martinu and Nicolai Lopatnikoff, the former represented by his First Sonata for 'cello and piano, the latter by his Variation and Epilogue, op. 31, for the same instruments.

MOSCOW, Jan. 17 -- There is mounting dissatisfaction over the manner in which the United States is claiming bases in the Pacific and Arctic while at the same time criticizing Soviet claims that are considered relatively modest.
MONTREAL, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Two British and two United States players advanced to the semi-finals of the Canadian amateur racquets championships today.

The Federal Reserve Board's decision to restore 75 per cent margins on stock dealings was viewed last night in important Wall Street quarters as a timely effort to provide a needed measure of liquidity in securities trading.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- A third of the major air accidents in 1946 would have been prevented by the use of modern communication and landing devices, T.P. Wright, Civil Aeronautics Administrator, declared today.

Seatrain Lines, Inc., of 39 Broadway, has no intention of resuming its services between New York and Havana, and New York and New Orleans while Cuban Presidential Decree No. 5 remains in force, Graham M. Brush, president of the company, declared yesterday.

Navy's improved young basketball team outsped, outdrove and outshot Columbia to register a 60-to-50 triumph before a full house of 2,000 spectators at the Light Blue gymnasium last night. In recording their fifth triumph in six starts, the midshipmen gave as fine an exhibition as has been seen on a local court this season.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 (AP) -- AllAmerica Charley Trippi of Georgia today signed an unprecedented $100,000, four-year contract with the Chicago Cardinals, climaxing the greatest professional football player build-up since Illinois' famed Red Grange joined the Chicago Bears two decades ago.

Grave concern over the possible future effects of the policy under which the Allies are permitting German film production to be revived as a potential national industry was expressed yesterday by Irving Mass, vice president and general manager of the Motion Picture Export Association.

TROY, N.Y., Jan 17 -- An increase in the tempo of political science at American colleges to include instruction in the mechanics of practical politics was recommended by educators at a session at Russell Sage College here today. The topic was "College Responsibility for Education in Citizenship."

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 17--The Aluminum Company of America and two subsidiaries, today petitioned the Federal District Court here to dismiss claims toy employes not specifically named in a $64,000,000 portal-to-portal pay suit filed recently by the United Steel Workers of America, CIO.

Failure to end violence in Palestine will endanger the continued support and good will of Americans who have contributed to its upbuilding, the New York Chapter of the American Council for Judaism, Inc., warned yesterday.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 17 (UP) -- British authorities tightened their censorship of Palestine newspapers today, apparently in the opening move in a new campaign to suppress Jewish underground violence, as the High Commissioner, Gen. Sir Alan G. Cunningham returned from London.

Dr. Robert L. Dickinson of the Planned Parenthood Federation announced yesterday that Dr. Alan F. Guttmacher of Baltimore and Dr. Abraham Stone of New York City had been named for the third annual Lasker Awards. The awards consist of a medallion and a $500 cash prize for each winner, and were given this year for distinguished leadership in marriage counseling.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 17 (AP) -- The A. S. Abell Company, publishers of the Baltimore Sun papers; Paul Patterson, its president, and Detective Capt. Henry J. Kriss were acquitted of contempt of court today jy Judge Emroy H. Nilea in Criminal Court.
It will be a case of join the Yankees and see the world this spring when the Bombers set out on one of the most extensive exhibition tours ever undertaken by that organization.

While the Board of Education was holding an open hearing yesterday to consider the biggest school budget estimate in its history, thousands of teachers outside the school headquarters building made it plain by a mass demonstration that they were dissatisfied with the budget and also with the State's recent offer of a $300 pay increase.

ATLANTA, Jan. 17 -- Ellis Arnall was barred from his makeshift office in the rotunda of the State Capitol today and established new "Governor's quarters" in his down-town law office. In a radio address he appealed to the people of Georgia not to "give up for one moment the fight for decency, democracy, law and order."

Anthony C. Trabasso, 18-year-old Poughkeepsie commercial art student at Pratt Institute, was found unconscious on the sidewalk early yesterday morning a few doors from the rooming house where he lived at 269 Ryerson Street, Brooklyn.

BAKERSFIELD, Calif., Jan. 17 -- Seven passengers were killed and about seventy were injured early today when a Southern Pacific Railroad train struck a defective rail at Lerdo, twelve miles north of here, and twelve of its fifteen coaches left the track.

MOSCOW, Jan. 17 -- The Soviet Army closed an old account recently by hanging Ataman Peter Nikolaevich Krasnov, leader of the White Russian forces who ravaged the Ukraine during the Russians' civil war, four other White Army leaders and German SS Maj. Gen. Helmuth von Panvitz.

ROME, Jan. 17 -- Only a few hours after the return of Premier Alcide de Gasperi by air this morning from the United States, a Cabinet crisis was precipitated by the resignation of Pietro Nennl, Deputy Premier and Foreign Minister.

WITH NAVY EXPEDITION, at the Bay of Whales, Jan. 16 (Delayed) -- The writer dropped through a skylight today into the sub-zero buildings and tunnels of the last site of Little America, buried under twenty feet of snow where everything was perfectly preserved and untouched since the camp was abandoned six years ago.

MOUNT GABRIEL, Que., Jan. 17 -- The annual international rivalry on the ski hills between Eastern United States and Canadian women's teams will be resumed tomorrow when the downhill takes place on lightning-fast Tamarack Hill of the Mount Gabriel Club.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The Administration made known its intention to go forward with the reciprocal trade agreements program through, a letter given out by the State Department today from William L. Clayton, UnderSecretary of State for Economic Affairs, to Senator Hugh Butler, Republican of Nebraska, who has called for a halt to it.

Barry Fleming, author of "Colonel Effingham's Raid," has delivered the manuscript of a new novel to Lippincott. Entitled "The Lightwood Tree," it has been scheduled for midyear publication. Mr. Fleming describes it as a contemporary story with a Georgia setting, dealing with grass-roots politics.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Between 1898, when Guam was ceded to the United States by Spain, and 1941, when it was seized from us by Japanese forces, few Americans had any concept as to what and where Guam was, and what manner of people were its inhabitants who had become wards of the United States.

Stressing exterior and interior improvements, the 1947 Pontiac lines were announced yesterday by Harry J. Klingler, general manager of Pontiac Motor Division of the General Motors Corporation, at a luncheon for New York zone dealers at the Essex House.

Heavy Brazilian demand for machinery, tools and manufactured products highlighted BrazilianAmerican trade in 1946, Garrido Torres, recently elected director of the Brazilian Government Trade Bureau, stated yesterday. A survey of trade trends during the past year indicates, he said, that Brazilian demand for United States goods was principally for replacing worn-out manufacturing equipment and increasing the industrialization program.

Lawrence Langner, co-administrative director of the Theatre Guild, arrived from London yesterday on the Queen Elizabeth and brought with him, among other things, the news that the Guild will receive shortly the draft of a new play which Bernard Shaw is finishing. The script, as yet untitled, will be presented this summer at the Malvern Festival in Worcestershire, according to Mr. Langer, and the chances are that it will be done here next season.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Dean Acheson, Under-Secretary of State, and William L. Clayton, Undersecretary of State for Economic Affairs, denied emphatically in separate statements today accusations made against them yesterday in the House by Representative Paul W. Shafer, Republican, of Michigan, that they had used their offices for personal gain.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The Army-Navy merger compromise plan, explained in detail today by official spokesmen, was revealed to be the beginning of an evolutionary -- rather than a revolutionary -- step toward unification.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 17 -- Robert McLean, president of The Asiociated Press, denounced today proposals that the Government merge all communications beyond its shores and establish short-wave radio broadcasts "to express our thoughts to other peoples."

The Rev. Dr. Martin Niemoeller, militant Lutheran pastor from Germany, who was imprisoned on an order from Hitler and spent eight years in concentration camps, will be heard at several meetings in the metropolitan area next week, starting tomorrow night.

Seriously concerned over widely distributed misinformation about increases in prices of builders' hardware, the National Contract Hardware Association made a national survey to determine actual extent of increases since October, 1941, John R. Schoemer, managing director, revealed here yesterday.

A German settlement that would open the way toward the economic unification of Europe by the peoples of Europe was advocated last night by John Foster Dulles, Republican adviser on international affairs, for the agenda of the forth-coming Moscow conference.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Jan. 17 -- A budget of $456,000 for 1947 and a resolution advocating the construction and endowment of a Christian university in Japan at a cost of not more than $15,000,000 were approved today by the Foreign Missions Conference at the final session of its annual meeting.

PARIS, Jan. 17 -- The Viet Nam radio was quoted by the French news agency tonight as saying that the Vietnamese "were feverishly making preparation for a long war; hostilities are entering a phase that will certainly be bloody."

Dr. Grantly Dick Read of London, who has developed a technique for eliminating pain during childbirth through "natural" methods, explained his theories yesterday at a press conference at the Maternity Center Association, 654 Madison Avenue.

LONDON, Jan. 17 -- Industrial shares, stimulated by a batch of good dividend announcements plus continuation of yesterday's rush to buy any equity showing a reasonable return, had prices climbing again today in the stock markets here.

Federal Judge Simon H. Rifkind authorized yesterday a trial on Feb. 10 on the issues of fact and law leading to the order for the deportation of Dr. Karl von Kleczkowski, former member of the Abwehr, German military intelligence organization, and his wife, Stelia.

Appleton Company A dividend of $1.50 a share was declared by the Appleton Company for payment Feb. 1. Last year the company distributed 75 cents each in February and May, $1.25 in August and $3.50 in October.
Motorcycle Patrolman Harry Schiffries, 39 years old, of Squad 1, died at 5:05 P. M. yesterday at New York Hospital, the victim of a cold-blooded gunman.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It has been several weeks since, in your editorial column, you suggested the formation of an independent citizens' group to foster air pollution control activity in New York City. Since then many New Yorkers interested in this matter have been waiting for some organization or individual to take the initiative in starting a group of this nature.

If porterhouse steak, lamb chops or a slice of ham are the main feature of your plans for Sunday dinner, you may present them in an appetizing manner, which has the added advantage of being timesaving, by broiling other foods along with the meat.

The giant Cunarder, Queen Elizabeth, one of the foremost transatlantic speed queens, entered another race yesterday as her 1,273-man crew strove mightily to prepare the 83,673-ton vessel for the fastest peacetime turn-around the line has ever attempted.
LONDON, Jan. 17 -- Britain has a nine-day breathing spell in which to find a solution of the truckmen's demands for a new contract or face another strike, it was learned today.

Week's Sales Seen 20% Higher Retail trade this week was fairly active, with bad weather conditions serving to hold down expansion of volume. Department store sales were estimated at better than 20 per cent over the like week last year. Clearances continued to be stressed in preparation for inventory -taking.

An 800-ton yacht, the subject of international "representations" and of considerable speculation on the New York waterfront as a "mystery" craft, is headed eastward from Marseille presumably to engage in running the British blockade carrying Jewish refugees into Palestine, it was disclosed yesterday.

Random notes. Before putting your shotgun (or guns) away for the spring and summer it might be a good idea to go over it carefully and decide whether it is going to need the attention of a gunsmith before you take it into the field next fall.

The progress toward reconversion recorded in New York State should be sufficient to ward off a recession this year, Dr. Martin P. Catherwood, Commissioner of Commerce, declared yesterday at the New York State Commercial Secretaries' Conference in the Hotel Martinique.

If women fail to interest themselves in relieving the human misery, suffering and ignorance they see around them they will fail to obtain peace, Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce, author and former member of Congress, declared yesterday.

ABOARD THE NORTH WIND, in the Bay of Whales, Jan. 16 (Delayed) -- The first Antarctic camp built by Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd in 1928 and christened Little America, with its clustered buildings and three sixty-foot radio towers, has been crushed out of existence.

Benjamin Franklin was described as an outstanding defender of freedom of the press and a staunch believer in international understanding at ceremonies held yesterday at City Hall to commemorate the 241st anniversary of his birth.

United States support for a plebiscite for 550,000 Pomak of Greek origin residing in Bulgaria was urged yesterday by two representatives of the minority group inhabiting the Rhodope Mountain range in the region of the GreekBulgarian border.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 17 -- Yugoslavia "is not inclined" to sign the peace treaty with Italy, Maj. Gen. Vladimir Velebit, Deputy Foreign Minister, said today. He added, however, "Politics depends on actualities."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Congress was put on notice today of formidable labor opposition to pending Senate proposals to amend the Wage and Hour Law, specifically directed against portal-to-portal back pay suits.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The Big Four Foreign Ministers Council released today the official texts of the peace treaties with Italy, Bulgaria, Hungary, Rumania and Finland.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 17 (AP) -- Hialeah Park opened its horse-racing season today in perfect weather, with Hilton Dabson's Nance's Ace, a $28.90 for $2 shot, winning the $12,275 Inaugural Handicap, under Mike Gonzalez before a crowd of 19,691 that bet $1,024,953 on the eight-race program.

Small plants have been hit particularly by three hardships which are making it necessary for them to look to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for more consideration in granting loans for working capital purposes, Alexander Berger, president, Associated Foundries and Manufacturers, Inc., disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Americans for Democratic Action stated today that the new group planned to organize the liberal forces of the country on a regional and local level and disclaimed "third party" objectives.

BERLIN, Jan. 17 -- A demand that Germany be represented on the peace treaty discussions in Moscow in March was made today by Jacob Kaiser, chairman of the Christian Democratic Union in Berlin and the Soviet zone.

Quality unprecedented in the fifty-six-year history of the meet marks the record entry of 645 athletes for the Metropolitan A.A.U. senior indoor track and field championships, which will be staged tonight in the Twenty-third Regiment Armory, Brooklyn, under the auspices of Brooklyn Council, Veterans of Foreign Wars.

A proposed plan by the Diamond Match Company to purchase the assets of the B-F-D Company, manufacturer of paper, pulp and woodenware, which has been affiliated with Diamond Match several years, was recommended yesterday by Abraham J. Halprin, referee, for approval in a report filed in the New York State Supreme Court.

A number of readers have raised questions, some quite indignantly, about our recent editorial commenting on the report of the Governor's committee suggesting $32,000,000 additional State aid for raising teachers' salaries. We commended this report for what it was, an emergency treatment of the problem.

BERLIN, Jan. 17 -- The problem of finding enough politically unobjectionable teachers and textbooks is a large obstacle in the way of leading German youngsters away from the tenets of, nazism. Relatively few "pure" books exist in Germany and reliable teachers are almost equally scarce.

A stronger spot basis in the South and lack of offerings carried cotton futures yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange to closing levels 20 points higher to 2 points lower than the day before after an early sharp dip.

Madison, Wis. Madison, Wis., announced yesterday that it would offer on next Wednesday an issue of $400,000 of park revenue bonds dated Feb. 1, 1947, and due on Feb. 1, 1948 to 1962. Interest must not exceed 3 per cent.

A New Jersey-bound bus, approaching the entrance to the Lincoln Tunnel late yesterday afternoon, was disabled when part of its transmission assembly burst through the flooring. Three passengers in the crowded vehicle were taken to St. Vincent's Hospital with injuries not regarded as serious.

Plans for standard bedroom, bathroom and workroom units, for paralyzed veterans are ready for a "field test," it was announced yesterday "by the New York Chapter, American Institute of Architects. Arrangements are being made to have "dummy" units set up at Halloran General Hospital on Staten Island.
LONDON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Russian fishermen recently picked up a buoy containing a dramatic note from members of a long-forgotten American North Polar expedition, the Moscow radio said tonight.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 17 -- Almost on the eve of the first full meeting of the Economic and Employment Commission, which is to open discussions of the world's employment ills here Monday, United Nations officials discovered today that they had some vexing labor problems of their own to solve.
General Into Secretary General Marshall, resting in Honolulu before proceeding to Washington to take up his duties as Secretary of State, consumes books at the rate of four a day or more.

This newspaper publishes today the Allied peace treaties with Italy, Hungary, Bulgaria, Rumania and Finland, which will be signed in Paris on Feb. 10. In book form these texts would make a hefty volume. Since most of us, journalists included, have faulty memories, we have believed it well worth while to present this mass of easily forgotten details in the consecutive pages of a single issue.

TOKYO, Jan. 17 -- The last death directly traceable to the atom bombing of Hiroshima and Nagasaki in August, 1945, occurred in October, 1945, and everyone seriously wounded had recovered by last April, it was announced here today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower tonight warned Americans that "we cannot permit complacency or an 'atomic bomb mentality' -- a possible modern counterpart of the 'Maginot Line mentality' -- to lull us into another post-war apathy."
The Manufacturers Trust Company has been appointed New York registrar for the common stock issue of the Virginia Electric and Power Company.

New Capital Market New issues of stock reappeared in the capital market here this week in a succession of four small flotations aggregating $1,186,677. Bond issues, mostly municipal, continue, however, to occupy most of the attention of underwriters.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 -- Grain markets developed a decidedly heavy undertone on the Board of Trade today as the result of announcement by the Kansas City office of the Commodity Credit Corporation that it would not guarantee to pay the prevailing price for cash wheat after 12 o'clock noon tomorrow.
BOSTON, Jan. 17 -- The Rev. Dr. Frederick M. Meek was installed tonight as the eighteenth minister of Old South Church since its establishment in 1669.

BERLIN, Jan. 17 -- An official United States Military Government spokesman asserted tonight that Communists were still in control of the Berlin City Government despite the resounding defeat of the Communist-controlled Socialist Unity party in the October elections.

While leather will not be overplentiful during the current year there probably will be sufficient to produce about 425,000,000 pairs of shoes, according to a report made this week to the board of directors of the National Shoe Manufacturers Association. This will approximate the 1946 production, market sources estimated.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The jubilant Republican Congressman who passed out crisp, new brooms to his colleagues on the opening day of Congress might have made a more propitious and a more truly symbolic gesture if he had passed out oil cans instead.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18 -- The Chicago Bears today signed Bob Fenimore, fleet Oklahoma A. M. halfback, completing a local onetwo punch in talent grabbing which the National Football League hopes may knock the rival All-America Conference out of Chicago and perhaps right out of business.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18--Harvey D. Gibson, president of the Manufacturers Trust Company of New York, was appointed today to serve as national chairman of the 1947 Red Cross Fund during March. He served in the same capacity during the drive for funds last year.

HERBERT KLINE, the documentary film producer, who is currently editing a feature picture about refugees in Palestine which he produced and directed there, is preparing to embark on a film based on the biblical story of Ruth.

TO THE EDITOR: * * * The article, "Our Incredible City," by John Joslin, to my knowledge contains one incredible statement; viz., "New York consumes three and a half million quarts of milk a day, the gift of some 117,000 uncomplaining cows."

THOSE persons heading for the Bahamas who prefer sea trips will be glad to hear that a New York-Nassau service will get under way in February, exact date to be announced later, according to the Eastern Steamship Lines.

LONDON. THE gradual return to normalcy of English life and manners has produced two recognizable types of current quips and anecdotes. On the one hand, there are jokes about services and commodities that were nonexistent during the war.

MONT GABRIEL, Que., Jan. 18 -- In one of the most exciting "straight down" races witnessed in this part of the world a select array of Eastern Canadian women skiers turned back an American team today in the downhill phase of their annual international rivalry at this picturesque FrenchCanadian hamlet.
WITH Actors Equity now officially on the barricades in the battle against racial discrimination in Washington's National Theatre and elsewhere, the principal question along the Rialto last week was:

FEW people who saw Nijinsky dance have forgotten him. If their memory is photographic they carry an ineffaceable image of the slave in "Scheherazade," the puppet in "Petrouchka," "Spectre de la Rose," the faun in "L'Apres-midi d' un Faune."

A delegation, of twenty-three United Service to China, Inc., chairmen from New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and other eastern States left yesterday in a special car over the Pennsylvania Railroad for Junction City Kan. They will join a hundred other leaders from thirty-four States in a three-day conference to plan a national campaign for China relief.

WASHINGTON. WASHINGTON'S social season is in full swing. White House dinners follow one another in ordered succession: Congress -- a new Congress with new faces -- is in session, and the insatiable Washington lust for entertaining is being fed by countless parties.

WASHINGTON. POLITICAL observers are asking a pertinent question as the Eightieth Congress gets into its stride: Did the Republicans, who now control both Houses, receive a mandate from the voters last November? Undoubtedly many Republicans believe they have a mandate, and their course as legislators will be influenced by their convictions.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18--Republican chairmen from twelve Midwestern States today said that "the welfare of this nation can well be entrusted to a Republican President who is symbolic of the ideals and heritage of the Middle West."

DURING the North African campaign George Millar, a former London war correspondent serving with the British Army, was captured by Rommel. After twenty months in prison camps on the Continent he escaped, made his way back to England, suffered an embittering personal tragedy and returned to the French underground to become a leader in the Maquis.

IT does not matter, of course, whether a writer is 21 years old. or 41, or 61; what matters is, that the writing be good. Yet it is interesting to note, as a sort of sidelight on "The Varmints," that its author was born as recently as 1925.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs. 1,000 head (estimated); total not given. Compared with week ago: Hogs under 240 pounds and sows 75 cents to SI higher; weights over 240 pounds around 50 to 75 cents higher.

'Unification' The evidence * * * reveals the complete inadequacy of command by mutual cooperation where decisive action is of the essence. said they could pare it sufficiently to permit a 20 per cent reduction in income tax levies, which would amount to $3.5 billion -- or almost 10 per cent of the budget.

Reduced prices of automobiles are no index to future price trends of industrial durable goods, supply and equipment manufacturers pointed out yesterday, in calling attention to the different relationships between demand, production costs, gross volume and profit ratios which exist in industrial equipment, for example, compared with passenger automobiles.

The Western Union Telegraph Company has asked the Public Service Commission for permission to increase its intrastate telegraph rates by 20 percent, its commercial news department charges by 15 percent, and its money order premium charges by about 4 3/10 percent, it was learned yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 18 -- Rudolph P. Miller, former Superintendent of Buildings of the Borough, of Manhattan, and a past president of the General Society of Mechanics and Tradesmen of the City of New York, died here today at his home, 24 Midland Avenue, after a long illness. His age was 80.
FOR THIS WEEK: Take inventory of fertilizers, insecticides, pots, seeds and other materials for advance and outdoor planting, so that needed supplies can be ordered promptly.

THIS slim bit of soap flake holds few of the satisfactions one would expect from so practiced a hand as this author's. True, the plot is handled dextrously, and life is made to seem quite simple after all. Miss Sims' prose, too, glides along smoothly.
A 14-year-old boy was fatally shot yesterday afternoon when he accidentally discharged the loaded shotgun of his playmate while they were shooting at Idlewild, Queens.

American historical autographs from the Mercantile Library Association of New York and books belonging to John W. Castles Jr. and the late Mrs. Andrew Carnegie will be auctioned in three sessions tomorrow afternoon and evening and Tuesday afternoon at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.

SEEDSMEN and nurserymen have introduced enough new flowers this year to provide almost constant bloom from spring through winter. The list of novelties announced by leading concerns prior to catalogue mailings is short compared with prewar years, but it includes an exceptionally good assortment of garden flowers.

WATERLOO, Iowa. WANT a Job in this curious industry called radio ? Better stop knocking on doors at the CBS Building, Radio City and 1440 Broadway. Instead, take a course or two in veterinary medicine, meteorology and agricultural practices.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 18 -- In an era of soaring prices in most lines, California highway users continue to quote a cheap price on life. In some respects the extent of today's automobile killings was carrying older residents back to an earlier day when they or their rugged, gun-toting fathers in the Old West gave little heed to the value of another man's life.

MINDEN, Germany, Jan. 18 -- Germans representing the Soviet zone concluded today the first two trade agreements with the fused United States and British zones. One covered the exchange of materials and goods amounting to 210,000,000 marks for this year and the other covered the establishment of common statistical and other trade procedures.

A LARGE exhibition that gives to the series of fifth-floor rooms distinctly the aspect of a museum opened last week at Wildenstein's. Impressively displayed, these forty-four paintings are by Italian masters and all are owned by the Wildenstein firm, which has played so active a role in the forming of collections, both museum and private, in this country.

SOME San Franciscans are viewing the Metropolitan Opera's plans for West Coast visits with alarm. They see them as a threat to their own opera company, which has, been operating for twenty-four seasons under Gaetano Merola.

THE Andromeda is an American tramp steamer. The last p to leave Singapore before its fall, she is homeward bound across a Pacific dominated by enemy aircraft and submarines. Besides her crew, she carries one male and one female passenger and a load of symbolism that hampers her considerably.

A dramatic and undignified stage in the Georgia gubernatorial dispute ended yesterday when Lieut. Gov. M.E. Thompson was sworn in and former Gov. Ellis Arnall announced his "resignation." Mr. Arnall had been successively locked out of the executive chambers, excluded from the Capitol and barred from the Executive Mansion.

To the Screen Editor: SO much of the criticism being written about the movies today is so vague, so personal, or so trumped up, that specific issues are often lost. I often wonder why the output of Hollywood is not cried down for its simplest faults, which are hack work and incompetence.

ATLANTA, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Every Southern State except Mississippi is now providing graduate education for Negroes under a costly system of "differential scholarships" that grew largely out of a Supreme Court decision of nine years ago.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Jan. 18 -- The United States delegation to the United Nations Security Council is expected to drop its fight for final approval of international atomic control before other aspects of disarmament are taken up.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18 -- Residents of Chicago and the rest of Cook County are digesting with deep interest and some concern a series of United States Public Health Service reports which disclose the existence of serious threats to the public welfare in this area.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Many times wise observers have spoken of the role of government as an impartial umpire settling disputes between conflicting interests, negotiating compromises and cooperative solutions.
