Though the modern state must still discharge the law-and-order functions and the cooperative service functions, and is now venturing more consciously into the economic and social control functions, still the umpire functions continue to be of central importance.
The cotton market on the New York Cotton Exchange resumed its downward course in yesterday's short session, and closed 43 to 58 points net lower, at or near the day's lows.

MOUTH - WATERING pictures in the catalogues tempt the gardener to think about having vegetables again this spring. This might be the year to plant a real gourmet garden. At least five vegetables can be savored to perfection only when rushed from the ground to the table.

If the McCarran bill, calling for consolidation of all international air-transport systems of the United States into a single community company, is reported favorably out of the Senate Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce, to which it was referred last week following its introduction on the floor, the measure will be challenged by vigorous and almost unanimous opposition from the country's airlines, especially the overseas carriers, at the subsequent organizational hearings prescribed by the legislation.

British Admiralty officials, restating Britain's charges that mines laid by Albania had damaged two British warships and killed forty-four crew members declared yesterday that a small unarmed boat transporting supplies for the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration had been machine-gunned from the Albanian shore

The recent increase in juvenile delinquency, making it the "No. 1 youth problem in America," should bring about the creation of more boys' clubs and the training of more leaders in the field, David W. Armstrong, executive director of the Boys Clubs of America, declared yesterday.

Editor New York Times Book Review: CHARLES UNIVERSITY of Prague, Czechoslovakia, has recently founded a chair in American Literature and the History of American Civilization. As far as I know, there are only two other universities on the European Continent, the Sorbonne of Paris and Upsala, Sweden, that have similar departments.

With activity stimulated in coat and suit departments, general store-wide activity was excellent last week, according to a survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Also busy were dress, fur and linen departments and South shops.

MISS RUBISSOW'S book is an album of Russian paintings, with an introduction setting out the main facts about the different schools and the most prominent artists. So little is Known about Russian painting outside of Russia that the book is highly welcome.

Convinced that, the cold-blooded killers of Motorcycle Patrolman Harry Schiffries are "hot," Acting Deputy Chief Inspector Conrad Rothengast put 300 men on the case yesterday with orders to carry out the search with "guns drawn."

PEIPING, Jan. 18 -- The naval general court-martial of Marine Corp. William Gaither Pierson, charged with raping a 19-year-old Chinese girl student, reached the climax today when the girl, Shen Chung, identified Pierson as the man who attacked her four times in three hours on the Peiping Polo Field on the night of Dec. 24.

The country is about to experience an era of unprecedented construction activity in which the best efforts of everyone connected with housing will be challenged, according to Joel W. Schenker, president of the Roth-Schenker Construction Corporation, which is now completing construction of large-scale temporary housing for veterans in Castle Hill, the Bronx, and Ulmer Park, in Brooklyn.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 18 -- The Yale basketball team, which had lost ten of its first eleven games, four of them in league competition, turned in a surprising upset here tonight, defeating Cornell, 39 -- 36.

To the Screen Editor: The article by Bosley Crowther last Sunday comparing certain aspects of Frank Capra's "It's a Wonderful Life" with the Michael Powell-Emeric Pressburger "Stairway to Heaven" evoked recollections of other Capra films.

SAIGON, French Indo-China, Jan. 18 -- The French in Indo-China are fighting a type of elusive guerrilla opposition that the Annamese can prolong indefinitely against all reinforcements now visualized.

MOSCOW, Jan. 18 -- The possibility that the question of Poland's western frontiers might be discussed at the Council of Foreign Ministers' meeting here in March was quashed today by a categorical statement in an editorial in The New Times, leading Soviet review of international affairs.

MOSCOW, Jan. 18 -- An attack on the Vatican and what was termed its policy of defending military criminals and providing refuge for "prominent Fascists" was launched today in the New Times, the Soviet Union's leading review of international affairs.

PARIS, Jan. 18 -- Charges of having had relations with the enemy were dropped today against Camilla Chautemps, former Premier, and Vice President of the Council at the time of France's downfall, at a session of the Investigation Committee of the High Court of Justice.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 18--The texts of the letter of resignation as Governor from Ellis Arnall to William Dean, president of the State Senate, and Mr. Arnall's radio address, in part, delivered today after his resignation, follow: LETTER OF RESIGNATION Dear Mr. President and Members of the Senate:

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Jan. 18 -- The Hungarian Smallholders party is commiting suicide by means of a party purge because of direct Soviet pressure, according to a report from a reliable Government source today. This report explained what was otherwise inexplicable -- the reason why the conservative element in Hungary, despite its substantial electoral majority, had not resisted the Communist-directed campaign of arrests based on allegations of conspiracy against the Republic.

The ship repair business in this port is enjoying a "boom" of such proportions as to recall the feverish World War II days even to the point of shipyard labor shortages, it was learned yesterday. Practically all local shipyards report heavy demands for their facilities, and all disclose the need for additional skilled workers.

HAVANA, Jan. 15 -- Although Cuba is now grinding the largest sugar crop since the Twenties, which means increased prosperity for the island, dissatisfaction with the Grau San Martin Government is growing rapidly.

The "melting pot" may make Americans out of immigrants in the political, economic and cultural sense, but it has not yet produced a distinctive American physical type. This is the conclusion reached by Dr. Alice M. Brues in the American Journal of Physical Anthropology.

Twenty members of a gang accused of stealing $500,000 worth of scarce merchandise from New York City business concerns in the past year were rounded up by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in the metropolitan area early yesterday. Another man was seized in Miami Beach, Fla., while four others are in custody of the police on other criminal charges.

TEN years after, its first publication, Dos Passes' "U.S.A." has reappeared in a handsome three-volume edition, with hundreds of pen drawings by Reginald Marsh that catch the spirit of the text. One feels on rereading it that the novel'has earned tills treatment reserved for the recognized classics.

NANKING (By Wireless.) NO harder school of preparation and training for the duties of an American Secretary of State could have been found than the one in which Gen. George C. Marshall has just passed thirteen feverish, exacting months. During his service in China as President Truman's special envoy the Secretary has revealed the methods and attitudes which he may be expected to follow in the many duties of his new post.
A New York Athletic Club trio headed by Billy Nicholls rallied in the fourth period to beat Squadron A, 13-12, in the star clash of the indoor polo double-header at Squadron A Armory last night.

The decontrol of all rents "at the earliest possible date" and a study by a bi-partisan legislative committee of the need for future public housing in the State were recommended yesterday by Walter S. Dayton, president of the New York State Association of Real Estate Boards, at the thirty-sixth annual dinner of the Long Island Real Estate Board in the Biltmore Hotel.

DETROIT, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Owner Walter O. Briggs of the Detroit Tigers hinted today that the sale of slugger Hank Greenberg to the Pittsburgh Pirates might have been influenced by national publicity of a week ago suggesting that Greenberg might like to finish his major league career in his native New York City with the Yankees.

"EDWARD EGGLESTON," by William Peirce Randel, recreates the life of one of our most curious frontier writers. Most readers are familiar at least with the title of his most famous work, "The Hoosier Schoolmaster," a classic of the Indiana wilderness.

THIS is an important book by a man who has few peers in agriculture and possesses a profound knowledge of the soil which is the foundation of our existence. It is to some extent a controversial book and as such an important sign of the renewed, living and growing interest in agriculture.

THE Postoffice Department has made available a description of the 3-cent purple which will be issued on Feb. 11 to commemorate the centenary of the birth of Thomas Alva Edison. In size, format and design it conforms to the five-stamp group which as part of the "Famous Americans" series of 1940 bears portraits of inventors: Whitney, Morse, McCormick, Howe, Bell.
TORONTO, Jan. 18 (AP) --Toronto's high-flying Maple Leafs stretched their National Hockey League lead to 11 points tonight by conquering Detroit's Red Wings, 7-4, before 13,592 fans.

Interest in today's state elections in Brazil will not be confined to that troubled country. They should reveal the direction of the political wind in most of Latin America. Communism has been making gains in many South American republics. In Brazil it is expected to show its peak strength.

HERE is a book that will hold a special charm for those who, at one time or another, have wanted to chuck the horrible monotony of office routine, time clocks, or housework, and go off adventuring into the "back of beyond." And that includes just about all of us.

COMMERCIAL, airlines have known since the early days of scheduled passenger flying that the crash of any air transport for whatever reason was reflected, more or less briefly, in the records of their reservations departments.

THE writings of Robert Schumann, nineteenth - century German composer and critic, may be enjoyed for their contemporary quality, their liberalism and high-mindedness, their humor and their fine epigrammatic style. These criticisms and these aphorisms, taken largely from the magazine that Schumann founded.

MANHATTAN'S East River front is in the midst of a renaissance that has already seen slums converted into fine residential sections and great hospitals raised on land that was considered beyond redemption. And now, in the most dramatic of all projects in this area, the United Nations is going to build its world headquarters.
The investigation of the death of Anthony C. Trabasso, 18-year-old commercial art student at Pratt Institute, was closed yesterday as, "definitely suicide."

NANKING, Jan. 18 -- All prospects of resuming peace negotiations with the Communists in the near future are believed in Government quarters to have been eliminated this morning when the Communists in Yenan rejected Nanking's plans for new parleys.

BRATISLAVA, Czechoslovakia, Jan. 18 -- The expulsion of the Magyars from south Slovakia and their removal to Bohemia and Moravia under the compulsory labor decree is being carried on under the direction of the Office for Slovak Colonization in Magyar populated regions.

NORMAN, Okla., Jan. 18 (AP) -- President George Cross of the University of Oklahoma announced today that Charles (Bud) Wilkinson, assistant football coach, had been elevated to the head coaching position to succeed Jim Tatum, who resigned to become head coach and athletic director at the University of Maryland. Tatum regretted leaving Oklahoma but believed the move would afford his family more security and himself a greater opportunity.
TO THE EDITOR: Recently the Magazine printed an article -- "Wardens No More," by Herbert Mitgang -- on the air raid and other voluntary services of New York since the war.

ANY fisherman who found this excellent collection in his Christmas stocking is going to be a happy man indeed. It's not the first compilation of fishing stories ever made, nor will it be the last; but it is now, and is likely to remain, the best.

During the war years salaries of America's schoolteachers lagged far behind the rise in the cost of living. For example, the average New York City teacher's salary has risen 16 per cent since 1939. The Consumer Price Index has risen 52 per cent in the same period.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations proclaimed today its implacable opposition to any Congressional action to quash the vast claims to portal-to-portal back pay now pending.

The past few days have resulted in "special meetings" being called by most of the sportsmen's groups in this area and the reason for this activity is due to the recent proposal by the Attorney General to require the Federal registration of firearms.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Two fundamentally conflicting military theories were temporarily compromised this week as a Presidential announcement wrote the end of a chapter of recriminations and bitterness unprecedented in the history of the armed forces.
ATLANTA, Jan. 18 (AP)--Herman Talmadge said tonight that if Georgia courts held that he was not entitled to the Governorship he would abide by the decision.

IN the second great war of this century, some thousands of gray-haired civilians who also had served in the first World War were affectionately called "retreads." Max Miller, a retread by his own admission, in this, his eighteenth book since his famous "I Cover the Waterfront," writes a novelized biography of the period between his discharge from the Navy as a lieutenant commander and his return to his peacetime occupation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- In 1919 Premier Ignace Jan Paderewski of Poland was convinced, as A dolf Hitler was twenty-two years later, that an army could march against Russia and to Moscow. He urged the Allied and Associated Powers to approve such an operation by a Polish army of 500,000 men, but this project was disapproved in the Peace Conference after long discussion.

While weather conditions retarded retail trade here last week, volume gains over last year were reported. Department store sales were probably 20 per cent or more ahead of the like week last year. Clearances in anticipation of inventory at the end of this month were general.

Although a depression is not likely to affect the nation's economy in the current year, because of the production of durable goods, economists urged yesterday that some form of long-range planning be instituted to offset the threat of inflation in the years ahead.

COLLECTED into five short stories, "The Gypsy's Baby" is a good deal more of Rosamond Lehmann, herself, than we have been allowed to meet before. This author's work, so detached, remote and impersonally dedicated to beauty, has kept itself at arm's length from the flavor of autobiography.

TO THE EDITOR: I'd like to challenge the statement made by Justice Jacob Panken in his article, "The Real Delinquent -- the Parent," that "nowhere in the junior and senior high schools in this country are courses given to fit our young for responsibilities of marriage and parenthood. * * *"

AMERICAN painting is another fabulous invalid whose death in our time has been exaggerated. It is true in some cases that the rustic, floral and quaint fishing-smack realism is difficult to distinguish from rigor mortis. On the whole, however, painting in this country has the virtues and drawbacks of any young, vigorous, provincial form of expression that is coming into adolescence the hard way -- that is to say, without adequate support and appreciation.

Spurred by the announcement after the close of trading on Friday that the Federal Reserve System had relaxed margin trading to 75 per cent, effective Feb. 1, trading on the New York Stock Exchange in the two hours to noon yesterday was the heaviest for a Saturday session since Dec. 7, the turnover being 790,000 shares, compared with 620,000 a week earlier.

ATHENS, Jan. 18 (U.P.) -- A sevenman United States economic mission, headed by Paul Porter, former chief of the Office of Price Administration, arrived today to determine Greece's reconstruction needs in terms of American dollars.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18 -- The teamwork of several generations of scientists and statesmen will be required to translate international control of atomic energy into an actual fact, Rear Admiral William S. Parsons, Navy Director of Atomic Defense, declared today at the traditional Founder's Day exercises of the University of Pennsylvania.
An exposition of American folk art, in which they participated, delighted a capacity audience of 500 school children in the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, yesterday.

OTTAWA, Jan. 18 -- The agitation by the seaboard cities of Canada for the establishment of free ports such as that in New York and the one more recently established in New Orleans, has been rejected by a special inter-departmental committee of Canadian Government officials.

Ted Schroeder, the Glendale, Calif., netman who helped Jack Kramer bring the Davis Cup back to the United States with his brilliant showing in Australia last month, was rewarded with the No. 2 berth in the national rankings. This was announced as the United States Lawn Tennis Association held its sixty-sixth annual meeting at the Vanderbilt Hotel yesterday.

Scientifically it is the junco, and the name probably came from the Latin word for seed. Maybe there is reason behind that name, but there's not much beauty in it. The common name is snowbird, and it persists. It belongs to the finch family, along with the sparrows, the grosbeaks, the buntings and the redpolls.

Eight months of reconversion work on the Grace liner Santa Rosa are just about over and the popular pre-war Caribbean cruise vessel will come back to this port next week as a "civilian" for the first time since Pearl Harbor.

WHAT do we mean when we call a writer a genius? This is one of the tricky words, one of those words of big implications which are used too readily, as all words of that kind are; and like the others, it is surrounded by a mist.

EATERS-IN -- Data on life in the United States. 1946: Americans spent a total of $46 billions, or $330 per capita, for food and beverages last year and "ate more meals at home" (Office of Business Economics).

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The Bankers Farm Mortgage Company of Fond du Lac, Wis., Is considering whether to request a rehearing by the United States Court of Claims of the suit by the company against the Government for $7,886,047.

MILTON BERLE will be featured performer on a new comedy-variety show scheduled to replace the Rudy Vallee Show on NBC Tuesdays at 8 P.M. Mr. Berle will start his comedy routines on March 11 aided by Dick Farney, singer, and an orchestra under the direction of Ray Bloch.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18--Keen Johnson, Under Secretary of Labor, discussing the possibilities of a "boom and bust" in our economy, declared today that "the question of purchasing power is perhaps the most important in the economy," and forecast "both lower prices and higher incomes."

OSLO, Norway, Jan. 18 -- The Soviet Union's renewal of its 194445 demand for a Spitsbergen base has come as something of a surprise to Scandinavians. This is especially so in view of the recent apparent shift in Russian policy to a more conciliatory course and since the United States has moved out of its Iceland bases and is expected here to evacuate Greenland.

TORONTO, Jan. 18 (Canadian Press) -- Dr. Tilson L. Harrison, whose thirst for adventure in the world's trouble spots for half a century led him into wars and uprising's on five continents, died Jan. 10 on a mercy mission to one of China's Communist-held sections, according to word received today from Shanghai.

Last Sunday night at the Museum of Modern Art the League of Composers presented a program of modern music in honor of Serge Koussevitzky, conductor of the Boston Symphony Orchestra and founder of the Koussevitzky Music Foundation which, in memory of the conductor's wife, has commissioned many new works by American composers.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The trustees and an alumni committee of Washington and Lee University met here today and approved a resolution to raise a $3,000,000 bicentennial fund.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 18 -- If the United States ever needs combat, landing and supply vessels in a hurry again, it won't have to waste time building them, thanks to the creation of the moth ball fleet. This group of 113 ships is undergoing preservation treatment at the Terminal Island naval operating base.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Gen. George C. Marshall, who has been vacationing briefly in Hawaii en route home from his special mission in China, will fly. here and be sworn in as Secretary of State in President Truman's office at 11 o'clock Monday morning, the White House announced today.

The writer of the following letter, formerly Professor of History at the University of Warsaw, is on the Fordham University faculty and is director of the Polish Institute of Arts and Sciences in America: TO THE EDITOR OF NEW YORK TIMES: Everybody knows that the elections to be held in Poland on Jan. 19 will be neither free nor unfettered.

RICHMOND, Calif., Jan. 18 -- Almost unknown to the professional golfing tourists and as lean as his pocketbook, George Schoux of San Bruno, Calif., paced the field today with a sixteen-under-par 197 for the first three rounds of the 72-hole $10,000 Richmond open tournament.

HOLLYWOOD. CLARK GABLE'S first appearance before the cameras in eighteen months has produced decided gratification among Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer attaches, whose proprietary interest in the company's box-office stars never flags.

Vassar College is losing faculty members to other colleges that are offering them more money, Miss Sarah Gibson Blanding, new president of Vassar, said yesterday in her first public address in New York since her inauguration in October.

ALONG with the sturdy pioneers who pushed our frontier westward must have gone, too, many a drifter, many a balmy eccentric. Although the frontier has disappeared into the Pacific, the westward movement still continues, from Iowa, Kansas and points east.

THE general verdict upon the opera "The Warrior," given its premiere at the Metropolitan Opera House a week ago yesterday, was adverse. It was so adverse that many people, the writer among them, raised the question, reiterated by several of our correspondents, as to why this work, so conspicuously ineffective and invertebrate in its nature, should have been given a prize, or should have been performed by the Metropolitan.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 18 -- The British armed forces in Palestine are capable of handling a largescale "frontal" rebellion by either the Jewish or the Arab section of the population. But they are unable to cope as effectively with the sporadic guerrilla warfare that is being carried out by small underground groups who take advantage of the element of surprise in plotting their coups.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 18 -- Public Safety Director John B. Keenan clashed today with the Civil Aeronautics Administration over, its method of installing experimental lighting at Newark airport. He said the installation contemplated by the Authority is a "grave menace to the safety of planes and workmen," and warned that he would not accept responsibility as public safety head unless the specifications are changed.
LONDON, Jan. 18 -- Final results of the British newspaper poll on the question whether Princess Elizabeth should marry Prince Philip of Greece showed that readers were nearly two to one in favor.

SUN VALLEY, Idaho -- The Roundhouse, 8,000 feet up the steep slopes of snow-powdered Mount Baldy, overlooks the jagged expanse of the Sawtooth Range. Three nights and two days by train from New York, this log and stone structure, with its huge fireplace, thick glass windows, and piping hot food, is the goal of most of the nation's skiers.
LONDON, Jan. 18 -- The Russians have again grabbed the initiative in the struggle over Germany's economic future.

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Elizabeth, which arrived Friday, one day behind schedule because of North Atlantic storms, sailed yesterday for Southampton after a brief thirty-two-hour layover. The ship departed at 3:15 P.M. from Pier 90, North River, with 2,188 passengers.

The Government's poll on what business men think of its reciprocal trade agreements program, as evidenced in public hearings before the Committee for Reciprocity In formation last week, was definitely on the negative side, foreign trade circles pointed out yesterday.

In selecting Dr. William Jansen as the city's Superintendent of Schools, the Board of Education last week brought to dose a year's intensive search for a capable educator to head the world's largest school system.

THE presence of bubbles In lenses is the least of the lensmaker's troubles, but because bubbles are easily seen they assume exaggerated importance in the eyes of the layman, writes Dr. K. Pestrecov of Bausch Lomb's Scientific Bureau, in the current issue of the National Photographic Dealer.

HERE are two books of interest for both the experienced yachtsman and the wouldbe boat owner. A great many volumes have been written on the care and handling of motorboats. Mr. Moore's ranks among the best.

BUFFALO, Jan. 18 -- Shipping, industrial and civic groups of the Niagara frontier which for years have asked for improvements in the Black Rock Canal lying on the east side of the Niagara River will attend a hearing Feb. 6, conducted by Col. Herbert D. Vogel, United States District Engineer.

IT is a trifle early for summer to be intruding on the scene, but there are two warmweather events of sufficient stature to cast their shadows this far before them. One is a new setup at the "university of the dance," founded by Ted Shawn at Jacob's Pillow, near Lee, Mass., and the other is a second international choreographic competition sponsored by the Archives Internationales de la Danse in Europe.
Of World Peace II Twenty months after World War II ended, Chapter I of World Peace II was spread on the record yesterday; the treaties for the five German satellites in Europe were published.

MR. MENCKEN has re-shot his bolt against religion, "Treatise on the Gods," which was launched in 1930 with great accuracy and no visible damage. The modernized missile contains improved materials and is armed with a proximity fuse in the form of a preface.

ALCOHOLISM -- In an effort to discover the causes of chronic alcoholism the Research Council on Problems of Alcohol has presented to Cornell University Medical College the first of five annual $30,000 checks to finance a five-year, $150,000 research project at the New York Hospital -Cornell Medical Center.

France has now become the Fourth Republic. The election of Vincent Auriol, Socialist leader, as President last week put into effect the new Constitution and he immediately set out to form a new Cabinet to replace that of Leon Blum, who declined, on account of bad health, to form another Government. Paul Ramadier, also Socialist, was given the task of Premier.

Optimism outweighed pessimism as retailers surveyed their prolems last week at the annual covention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association. The optimism was held in check by the fear of an anticipated business setback, but on balance it appeared the cosensus that this year would be profitable one despite price resistance, higher percentage operating costs and inevitable readjustments in merchandising practices to me a market in which the "consumer is boss."

THERE are twenty-three million pleading voices in America. They are the tragic voices of the physically disabled-voices of children who have had infantile paralysis and cerebral palsy, of men and women maimed or broken in accidents, of those who have arthritis or tuberculosis or who have suffered a stroke.

The discovery of a new antibiotic substance that, like penicillin or the newer streptomycin was found to retard tuberculosis in experimental animals was disclosed yesterday by Dr. Alfred Marshak of the United States Public Health Service.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 18 -- Henry (Hank) Greenberg, the major lague's home-run king, today was Purchased by the Pittsburgh Pirates from the Detroit Tigers for an undisclosed but "sizable" sum of cash.

Metal stamping methods for mass production have become an accepted subject for technical education, in fifty-four out of seventythree engineering colleges and universities, a national survey by Lockhart International, Inc., disclosed here yesterday.

OUT of a sensitive, discerning mind has come a quietly searching novel that seeks to find the answer to a question that now embroils the world: How to get on with one another While Elizabeth Yates thinks in the broadest terms of man's responsibility to man despite differences of race, creed and Ideals, she narrows her sights to one particular spot--the small New England village of Nearby.

MR. STONE does a quiet and simple reporting job in this story of the weird migration of the Jews from Europe to Palestine. It was a dangerous assignment. In it were all the elements that might tempt a reporter to flood his pages with hysteria in type.
THE distinction of writing the first complete volume on cooking under pressure goes to Leone Rutledge Carroll, whose book, "Pressure Cookery," was published last week by M. Barrows Co., Inc.

Since "Lakme" was revived for her in 1932, Lily Pens has been the reigning incumbents in the title role at the Metropolitan Opera, but last night a new singer was heard in the part. She was Patricia Munsel, 21-year-old soprano, who joined the company four seasons ago.

Influenza and the common cold are frequently confused. In cases of the common cold the upper respiratory tract is chiefly affected. Hence runing noses, sore throats and coughs. Influenza is accompanied by chills, irritation of the throat, generalized aches and fever.

Support of the United Nations and the creation of the Atomic Energy Commission are important examples of the contribution of this nation to world peace and unity, participating pupils said yesterday in the Youth Forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast over Station WQXR.

Rehabilitation is a word of broad and divergent meaning. It may describe the social or economic rehabilitation of a war-torn country. It may mean the human reclamation program that operates in a military disciplinary barracks. But to America's millions of disabled it means hope that comes from the opportunity to retrain themselves for useful living.

A jealous husband, reported to have said that he planned to murder his wife and her escort, was captured early yesterday after an exchange of shots with Detective Edward Fitzgerald. In Felony Court the prisoner, Walter lema, 30 years old, of 186 Tenth Street, Brooklyn, was held by Magistrate Thomas Cullen without bail for a hearing on Friday.

To the Drama Editor: I HAVE read with a great deal of interest the pro and con by Messrs. Richard Rohman and Alan S. Downer of Princeton University bewailing the revivals of the present season and the latter's defense of the same.
PARIS, Jan. 18 -- Consultations over the formation of a new French Cabinet were prolonged throughout today, with only a slight prospect of conclusion before Sunday night or Monday.

THE United States is proceeding headlong toward the worst economic crisis of all time. That is the unqualified prediction of Fritz Sternberg, who, unfortunately, is a prophet with a remarkable record for accuracy. The introductory portion of this book amounts to a sort of revision, in the light of late history, of the works of Karl Marx and Frederick Engela.

From Entebbe, East Africa, comes a letter to the International Health Division of the Rockefeller Foundation from Dr. K.C. Smithburn of the Yellow Fever Institute about a monkey laid low with a new disease similar to poliomyelitis.

THERE was a story on these pages a week ago that Honus Wagner had signed his contract as a Pirate coach and would report to the Miami Beach training base. The startling part of that announcement was the revelation that the greatest shortstop baseball ever has had would be making his first trip to Florida. That's almost as incredible as the tall tales he delights to tell.

MR. GORDON'S short, ultraclinical novel is one of those tours de force designed to appeal to the head rather than to the heart. Concerned with a vitally important theme (the moral breakdown of the homunculus under the strain of wartime living) it makes its points with precision and economy.
Baseball under the incandescent will get an earlier start at the Yankee Stadium next season, but the maximum he followed last year will be observed in the 1947 campaign by President Larry MacPhail.

JUDGES of the Manhattan Camera Club's annual competition last week had to make a difficult decision. They wanted to give their votes for the club's Print-of-the-Year to a print with merely pictorial appeal, but the force of human qualities of David Teich's outdoor portrait of an old man compelled them to give the award to the portrait.
A COMBAT team of 11,000 men, which can be reinforced to the strength of two military divisions, is required to do battle against New York's greatest menace from the air -- snow.

Split and Conquer For its first President the so-called Fourth French Republic has elected a Socialist and close associate of the veteran Leon Blum, thereby giving a new twist to the proverb about Divide and Conquer.

PARIS, Jan. 18 -- With a new President, Vincent Auriol, installed for a seven-year term in Elysee Palace, France has now but to find a Premier who can form a Government supported toy a firm majority. Then the French may enter into that stability fondly desired since their liberation and mostly found lacking in their provisional regimes.

The revival of margin trading on Stock Exchanges on a 75 per cent basis, aside from its immediate effect on stock transactions, was evaluated over the week-end by leaders in the securities industry as a significant gain in the effort to release the market from controls which they have protested were too severe.
SHANGHAI, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Possibly 400 Chinese drowned today when a small Yangtze River steamer collided with a lighter and sank off Woosung.

When Henry Ford 2d announced the first post-war reduction in the price of automobiles last week, he dramatized a great economic issue which confronts the American people in the imminent renewal of labor contracts for the mass production industries.

REGARDLESS of the weather outside, gay succulents bring an atmosphere of warmth and color into the home which no other plants can quite achieve. In sunny windows, their silhouettes are interesting, their bloom and foliage varied.

A resurgence of Russian activity and propaganda in the Middle East was reported here yesterday by John S. Badeau, president of the American University at Cairo. Mr. Badeau, just backs from Egypt, spoke at a luncheon meeting of the Foreign Policy Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel attended by 600 persons.

SAN SALVADOR, El Salvador, Jan. 18 -- A statement by Trygvye Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, to the effect that the United Nations could not live without the freedom of the press, made today in response to a question by a local reporter, was considered significant in view of the strict censorship recently imposed here.

Late in 1943 small groups of military men sat huddled in feverish conferences in all parts of the nation planning the strategy, tactics, supplies and other problems for the invasion of Hitler's European, fortress. They discussed radar, amphibious craft, rocKets arid other scientific developments that were generally unknown to the public.
MEXICO CITY, Jan. 18 -- Municipal disturbances of one sort or another have now been reported from at least fifty communities in six Mexican States. Fifteen persons have been killed.

ATLANTA, Jan. 18 --Ellis Arnall resigned today as Governor of Georgia in favor of Lieutenant Governor M. E. Thompson, who immediately took up the Governorship fight with Herman Talmadge by proclaiming himself acting Governor "until such time as the people themselves may elect."

For the first time in several years, fabric buyers in the markets here last week shopped thoroughly before placing commitments, according to a market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block and Company.

BERLIN, Jan. 18 -- A ten-day tour of consumer industries in the United States zone discloses remarkable strength in the war-torn manufacturing establishments. It also reveals a startling optimism among plant managers who hope to reassert themselves on the world export market.

Humiliated in the last quarter by the tail-end Boston Celtics, the New York Knickerbockers dropped a 58-45 decision to the Hub entrant in a Basketball Association of America encounter at the Sixtyninth Regiment Armory last night. Three fouls were all the secondplace Knicks were able to count throughout the last twelve minutes.
HOLLYWOOD. THE furor which arose last week over the Los Angeles showing of "Duel in the Sun," as a result of protests by religious and lay groups, has put David O. Selznick in a difficult position.
Celebrating her tenth anniversary as the star in the Hollywood Ice Revue, Sonja Henie will begin her annual personal appearance run at Madison Square Garden next Thursday night.

Coming through even better than expected in the flat races and upsetting the form chart in the hurdles and relays, Manhattan scored a surprise victory over New York University and the New York Athletic Club in the fifty-sixth annual Metropolitan A.A.U. senior indoor track and field championships last night.

THE six previous items in the Makers of Modern Literature series have been intelligently selected and executed. It was well conceived that an all-purpose book on the poet Robinson should be a seventh item, and poet and critic Yvor Winters its author.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Territorial Governor Ingram M. Stainback says Hawaii's white population has increased, the ratio of Japanese has decreased and the happy-go-lucky native Hawaiian population is growing fast.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The formation of an independent, democratic Jewish state, consisting of all of Palestine, but not Trans-Jordan, was proposed today by Joseph Clark Baldwin, former Representative from New York City, in a 12,000 -word report to President Truman.

The text of a note, dated Dec. 9, from the Government of the United Kingdom to the Albanian Government, whose reply was published last week, follows: I. His Majesty's Government in the United Kingdom have been reviewing the recent incidents in the Corfu Channel ending with j the serious incident of 22 October in which two of His Majesty's vessels were heavily damaged by mines with a grievous loss of life.

EDWIN SEAVER, editor of the distinguished "Cross Section" series of new American writing, reports that this past year his selections were laboriously drawn from no less than 7,000 manuscripts, a vast array produced in the main by beginners.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Jan. 18 (AP) -- Charles Brinton of Philadelphia, national champion, moved into the semi-finals of the Atlantic Coast squash racquets tournament today, easily defeating Paudia Ralli of New York and Roger Bakey of Boston.

ALBANY, Jan. 18 -- Consumption of alcoholic beverages and smoking of cigarettes in New York State during 1946 exceeded all previous records, the State Tax Department announced today. New records also were established in the amount of State tax revenue from sales of alcoholic beverages and cigarettes.

RADCLIFFE -- Management Courses To make room for the steadily growing number of applicants and to meet a widening range of interests, the series of evening lectures offered annually at Radcliffe College by the Management Training Program will be expanded this year into four short courses.

Plans for a fourteen-story commercial building at the northwest corner of Maiden Lane, Water and Fletcher Streets, were announced yesterday by Riker Co., Inc., representing a syndicate of investors which has acquired the property.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Incometax evasion is probably at an all-time peak in the United States, costing the Federal Government an estimated $3,000,000,000 a year.

BOSTON, Jan. 18 -- The projected modernization, of New England's textile industry to meet post-war competition, higher wages and lower worker productivity is viewed as being a big step in helping to boost the industry to a new peak.

THE author of these stories is curator of an animal museum on the outskirts of Chicago, one of several Trailside Museums established in our National Parks to give boys and girls an opportunity to make friends with wild animals.

THE Federated Garden Clubs of New York State will hold its fifteenth annual judges course at the Waldorf-Astoria, Tuesday through Friday. Planned for members and nonmembers who wish to become flower show judges, it also offers instruction in flower arranging.

The chance discovery that two bars in the cell of one of the nine men who escaped Jan. 2 from the Brooklyn City Prison had been sawed through has resulted in the 500 inmates being placed in solitary confinement, it was revealed yesterday.

SPACE has been found today for another short installment in our piecemeal roundup of art books. The present assortment consists of a few recent books dealing with individual foreign artists or artists of European origin.

A HOCKEY fan once approached Harvey Jackson, one of the foremost left-wingers when he played for the Toronto Maple Leafs, and asked: "Will you help me get a goalie's stick for my son? If he doesn't get one he'll have a headache."
Third of a series of ten articles on recent developments in contract bridge bidding methods.

Miss Kathryn Ehlers of The Skating Club of New York won the Middle Atlantic figure-skating championship on the Iceland Rink last night. In second place was Miss Andra Carol McLaughlin, her clubmate, with Miss Donna Jean Pospisil placing third.
The Council suggests that good radio planning means installing a radio outlet in the living room, den, recreation room and any other spot where a bigger-than-portable set might be used permanently.

OF all the books that have recently been written on Brazil this one occupies a place apart. The author went to Brazil thirty years ago when she was young and Brazil, in some ways, was still young, too. She had a friend who had been lady-in-waiting to the last Empress (whose husband abdicated in 1889) and a brother who was engaged in work outside of Rio de Janeiro.

The extent to which new construction in New York City is easing the housing shortage is indicated by figures announced yesterday by the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the United States Department of Labor.

TODAY, after months of dreams and delays, of hagglings and compromises that have turned Broadway into a minor league Flushing Meadow, those of us who have fought the battle in behalf of an outlet for young playwrights and directors, actors, composers and designers see the fruition of our labors about to be realized within the next few weeks.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., Jan. 18 -- Henry T. Smith, who was a member of the art staff of The Evening World in New York throughout its existence as a separate newspaper and was head of its art department from 1901 until the paper was sold to the ScrippsHoward chain in 1931, died here today in his home at 56 Oakwood Avenue.
ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 18 -- Georgia's gubernatorial fight involving Ellis Arnall, Herman Talmadge, and M. E. Thompson has sharply divided public opinion in the State.

Wage increases and improved standards of living will follow increased production of goods, Chester Bowles, member of the American delegation to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization said yesterday at a conference in the Hotel Pennsylvania sponsored by the National Consumers League and its New York and New Jersey branches.

GANDER, Nfld. -- Aviation is currently divided by the controversy over which of two instrument-landing systems is better. The Civil Aeronautics Administration favors ILS -- instrument landing system -- which employs a localizer, a beamed glide path and radio marker beacons.

A PLEASANT dipping-and browsing sort of book this, made up of the writing of many English anglers through the centuries, plus a few American fishing narratives -- stories of big fish and of odd stream side incidents -- are the bulk of its contents.

ATHENS, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Premier Constantin Tsaldaris met a challenge of six Cabinet resignations and opposition attacks tonight with a declaration that he would battle his opponents to a showdown when Parliament reopens Monday.

WHILE the rest of Hollywood searches with a frenzy born of desperation for best-seller novels and hit plays, Producer Jerry Wald goes right along turning out box-office "smasheroos," as they say in the trade, which do not stem from either of the customary sources.

THIS department was going along minding its own business when across its desk, elbowing each other as they came. arrived two titles. Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's "China's Destiny." published by Macmillan, and Generalissimo Chiang Kaishek's "China's Destiny," published by Roy.

PROFESSOR CANTOR is hopping mad about American education. He thinks we have been using a false psychology of teaching and learning. Moreover, he believes he has the answer. His answer isn't very startling. Comenius said it in the seventeenth century: "Let the main object of this, our didactic, be as follows: To seek and find a method of instruction, by which teachers may teach less, but learners learn more."

PORTLAND, Ore. FOLKS out this way quarrel and bicker about a lot of things, but you can bet your warmest suit of winter woolens that they all want that 20 per cent reduction in personal income taxes. You can't start any rumpus on that. It's as popular as a nice rich elk stew around the campfire.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 18 -- Horsemen, jockeys and the rumor factory continued to work overtime at Hialeah Park today as Leo Gerngross' Michael B. took the $13,025 Hibiscus Stakes on the second program of a meeting still plagued by the strike of grooms and exercise boys.

Concerned over apparent lack of interest in Japanese silk by textile manufacturers, the United States Commercial Company will intensify its efforts to gain a wider acceptance of the fiber, it was learned last week. If it follows recommendations of a committee appointed to make a survey of the market for silk, USCC will embark on an extensive publicity campaign to promote "silk consciousness," according to trade sources.

GRAND CAYMAN, B. W. I. -- This remote British West Indian island, once a hideout of buccaneers and more recently a rendezvous for antisubmarine patrols, is slowly working its way into the ranks of the more popular out-of-the-way vacation spots.

ROME, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The text of Pope Pilus' address: You have come to Europe, we are told, desirous of getting firsthand knowledge of post-war conditions. An important mission for men of your profession, and one that may be productive of farreaching good.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., Jan. 18 (U.P.) -- Jim Tatum today was named head football coach of the University of Maryland after resigning as head coach of the University of Oklahoma. Tatum, who accepted by telephone from Norman, Okla., also will be in general charge of athletics.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 18 -- A proposal for establishment of a world trade center in San Francisco, not only for the benefit of the West but as a device to aid success of the United Nations, now is before the California Legislature.
HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Jan. 18 -- Fordham snapped Hofstra's victory streak at ten games tonight, and boosted its own skein of successive victories to four as it downed the Flying Dutchmen, 59 to 45.

The comprehensive executive development program instituted two years ago by the Standard Oil Co. (N.J.) is being expanded to cover personnel in all fifty of the organization's major affiliates throughout the world, Ralph Mason, employe relations director, disclosed in an interview last week.

MONTREAL, Jan. 18 -- Montreal's Canadiens snapped a midseason slump with a bang at the Forum tonight, hammering the New York Rangers, 6 -- 2, as Center Bill Reay collected three goals in a National Hockey League game before a crowd of 11,314.
CHICAGO, Jan. 18--Chicago's Mayoral campaign was described tonight by Carroll Reece, Republican national chairman, as a major preliminary to the 1948 battle to elect a Republican President.

PARIS, Jan. 18 -- All Viet Nam resistance in the area between the southern edge of Hanoi and the circular route about three miles from the center of the city has ceased after a rapid advance of French troops cleared the last centers of resistance, Indo-China dispatches reported tonight.

The 6,000-ton American freighter Flying Cloud was loading all last week in the East River at Maiden Lane, where, nearly 100 years ago, a Flying Cloud of another era loaded for her notable 89-day, 23hour run to the Pacific Coast.

AKRON, Ohio, Jan. 18 (AP)--The founder and director of the National Association of Personnel Directors told his organization today that he was once a convict, and then won a standing vote of confidence after offering to step aside if the majority desired.

BROWNSVILL.E, the Brooklyn district that has produced some of our best-known killers, is the locale of Mr. Dortort's novel--and, though the story wanders afield at times in the interests of murders, the thumbprint of that environment is on every page.

Over the Governorship Eugene Talmadge, native of Forsyth, Ga., once said he never cared about winning an election in a county that had street cars (most of Georgia's 159 counties don't). The remark typified his political technique. He was born in 1884 on a farm in middle Georgia, used his grass-roots origin to build a rural political machine that gained him three terms as Governor.

For tax purposes, in the interest of good accounting, income must toe reported on the basis of the annual accounting period employed in keeping the taxpayer's records An individual taxpayer who does not keep books must make his income tax return on the calendar year basis.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18--Unemployment insurance claims dropped from a post-war peak of 2,000,000 a week last March to about 1,000,000 at the end of 1946, the Federal Security Administration reported today.
The Emir Saud, eldest of the forty sons of King Ibn Saud and heir apparent to the throne of Saudi Arabia, arrived yesterday in New York form Washington by train for a four-day visit.
BAY OF WHALES, Antarctica, Jan. 18 -- The cargo ship Yancey began unloading trucks, jeeps, tractors and other supplies today for the Navy expedition's base in Antarctica on a new Little America site.

DETROIT, Jan. 18 -- The Ford Motor Company, old independent of the automotive industry, came up this week with another first -- the initial post-war price slash among the highly competitive car builders.

The recent action by the Office of Temporary Controls in raising the volume of non-housing construction from $35,000,000 to $50,000,000 a week is most encouraging to the architectural profession and to the construction industry as a whole, James R. Edmunds, president of the American Institute of Architects, declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The House leadership moved today to postpone consideration of a bipartisan "bill to peg excise taxes at their wartime rates.

HAWTHORNE, N.J., Jan. 18 -- Using a double-barreled shotgun, Walter Birchenough, 33 years old, killed his estranged wife, Mrs. Lulu Birchenough, 33, and then fired the second charge into his abdomen and critically wounded himself this afternoon, according to Police Chief Ryan Vandervalk.

FLINT, Mich., Jan. 18 -- Buick 1947 cars in three series and nine body types were announced today by Harlow H. Curtice, general manager of the Buick division and a vice president of the General Motors Corporation.

MOUNT HOPE, N.Y., Jail. 18 -- Semi-final brackets in the twelfth annual bonspiel for the Archibald Douglas Medal were filled at the St. Andrews Golf Club today, with the Ardsley Curling Club placing in each half of the draw.

SEATED at a table in Detroit's Book-Cadillac Hotel, Charles F. ("Boss") Kettering, a vice president of General Motors Corporation and one of the pioneers of the automotive industry, emphasized that actual experience produces results that cannot be gleaned from rule-of-thumb theories.

LONDON, Jan. 18 -- Britain escaped the menace of a general transport strike this week when peace moves initiated by the Labor Government ended a two weeks' "wildcat" strike that originated with the truck drivers and eventually involved the dock workers, warehousemen and lightermen of London.

JACKSON, Miss., Jan. 18 -- That Senator Theodore G. Bilbo, who underwent a surgical operation in New Orleans this week has gained political strength throughout Mississippi because of the effort to unseat him in Washington is conceded even by his bitterest enemies. They frankly say that if his case should today be submitted to the voters he would triumph by a large majority.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Labor's Monthly Survey, economic publication of the American Federation of Labor, asserted today that while wage increases without price increases were vitally necessary, "it is not true that industry can afford a 25 per cent general wage increase in 1947."

The Federal Reserve System has just announced that, effective Feb. 1, "trading on margin" on the nation's securities exchanges will be permissible again for the first time since Jan. 21 of last year. The margin required from now on will be 75 per cent.

(Drama Critic, The Baltimore Sun) IN BALTIMORE, a city with, a population around the million ark, there are now not more than 20,000 habitual playgoers. e existence of the professional eatre depends on this tiny mority.

WARSAW, Jan. 18 -- A large proportion of the Polish electorate of 12,000,000 will go to the polls tomorrow to confirm in power -- whether they like it or not -- the Communist-dominated Administration that has marked the Government of this country since its liberation nearly two years ago.

THE posthumous publication of Henry Adams' writings has made him one of the significant historians of the tumultuous, confusing years between the Civil War and World War I, during which industrial capitalism engulfed and transformed agrarian America.

Vanda Oiticica, Brazilian soprano, gave her first New York recital late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. Ably assisted at the piano by Robert Payson Hill, Miss Oiticica presented a program comprising early classics by Scarlatti and Bach; French lyrics by Hahn, Moret and Debussy; the Air de Lia from Debussy's "L'Enfant Prodigue"; and a final group composed of Brazilian songs by Villa-Lobes, Guarnieri, Ovalle, Brandao, Ernani Braga, and Mignone.

"DEATH Comes to Manhattan by Atomic Attack," which, recently opened the new WMCA series on nuclear energy (9:30 P.M. Fridays), was one of those radio offerings which unhappily tried the listener's hospitality.

PARIS, Jan. 18 -- Destined like Trieste, Danzig and many other tiny districts to be eternally in dispute, the small Saar territory bordering France, Luxembourg and Germany is again an international issue.

OF the several highly graphic organizations which the late war presented to Hollywood, such as Commandos, the airborne divisions and the counterespionage unit of the FBI, it is doubtful if any has been more welcome -- or will be more frequently reported in future films -- than the Office of Strategic Services, or the OSS to you.

LONDON, Jan. 18 -- Premier Leor Blum came to London on the eve of the meeting of the Deputy Foreign Ministers to prepare" peace terms for Germany and Austria. While outwardly there was no direct connection between the two events, it is in relation to one another that they should be viewed.

Poland Chooses Poland has been a bone of international contention since July, 1944. Then a Polish Committee of National Liberation, composed of Poles in general sympathy with the Soviet Union, was formed at Lublin. The committee later became the "Provisional Government of Poland."

ANN WATKTNS "Taken at the Flood" is a new hind of anthology, a sort of literary smorgasbord laden with excerpts from some of the better books produced by American authors during the past quarter-century. In preparing her feast of thirtynine tempting morsels. Miss Watkins, an eminently successful literary agent, enjoys an excellent position. Several of her clients are indeed represented, and by selections which stand as a fitting tribute to her taste and perspicuity.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 18 -- Senator James O. Eastland of Mississippi has plenty of backing in his contention that the Deep South, including agricultural leaders and workers, favors continuation of reciprocal trade agreements.

Coming long after the security markets had closed on Friday, the announcement by Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, that all-cash trading in registered stocks would end on Feb. 1 came as a welcome relief to the financial community.

MINDEN, Germany, Jan. 18 -- The formation of a new political party in the United States occupation zone of Germany to buck the strong leadership of Dr. Kurt Schumacher of the Social Democratic party was predicted today by Dr. Rudolph Mueller, former chairman of the Executive Committee for Economics.

BOSTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- With Woody Dumart scoring twice, the Boston Bruins strengthened their hold on the National Hockey League's third berth by topping the Chicago Black Hawks, 3-1, tonight before 13,900 fans at the Boston Garden. It was the Bruins' second triumph in four nights over the last-place Hawks on Boston ice.

LITTLE. ROCK, Ark., Jan. 18 -- Bill Dickey, who served a short term at the helm of the New York Yankees last year, signed a oneyear contract today as playermanager of the Little Rock Travelers of the Southern Association, with whom he began his baseball career twenty-two years ago.

Education for women has fallen to "alarming depths" in fifteen countries of Europe, the Orient and Latin America, according to a report by the American YWCA, which is conducting a campaign this month and next to raise $2,100,000 for rehabilitation purposes.

RESEMBLING a piece of hand luggage, a redesigned battery portable Electroflash unit is announced by Wabash. All controls have been placed at one end of the new unit, which now features built-in electronic triggering to assure freedom from flash failure.

ONE of the paradoxes or modern times is that with the increase of scientific knowledge there has developed a growing skepticism of science as a mode of knowledge. The more power scientific knowledge commands, the more profound in many quarters is the distrust of the possible uses of scientific method in social affairs.

THIS volume is an arrangement of classic passages from the Holy Scriptures of Judaism -- the Law, the Prophets, the Writings -- which best exemplify the literary and ethical values of that religion. Since these scriptures are also part of the Christian Old Testament and of the teachings of Mohammedanism, it is obvious that they are among the most important and universal of all religious writings.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 18 (AP)--The general executive board of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters today informed Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican leader, that it "bitterly opposed" any legislation to provide for setting up a Government tribunal or commission having the power of settlement of jurisdictional disputes within the labor family.

A legislative program calling for $90,000,000 additional State aid to help balance the city's expense budget, retention of the five-cent fare and amendment of the State rent control law freezing "maximum rentals at the Jan. 1, 1947, level upon termination of Federal controls was made public yesterday by the New York City chapter of the National Lawyers Guild.

JANUARY is stock-taking month in the homefurnishings world. Designers, makers, buyers and sellers all troop to the wholesale markets in Chicago, Grand Rapids and New York to inspect the new creations and swap words of wisdom on prospects for the next six months.

In ordinary times (if it is still possible to imagine what ordinary times are like) one might see only minor significance in such a resolution as that introduced in the House by Representative Thomas A. Jenkins of Ohio to suspend further reciprocal trade agreements until a "scientific study" has been made.

The first steps toward framing a world code to guarantee fair labor practices and standards on all projects carried out through the use of international funds will be taken soon at the United Nations headquarters at Lake Success, N.Y., it was disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Successful prosecution of Robert H. Best and Douglas Chandler, now awaiting trial in Boston on treason charges, will require the Justice Department to meet unusually severe tests of proof.

Detroit, Jan. 18--The sweeping wage and social-security demands of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, were defended today as just and reasonable by Walter P. Reuther, union president, at a national wage-policy conference.

IN sharp contrast to the amiable atmosphere of give and take in which the New York Film Critics recently made their awards for the movie "bests" of 1946 was the meeting at which eighteen Parisian film critics voted to award the Louis Delluc Prize for the year's outstanding French picture.

BECAUSE most attention centers on prices, the most dramatic business development of the week was the Ford announcement of reductions ranging from $15 to $30. Retal merchants from all over the country who were meeting here in convention echoed this action of the automobile firm by calling for an end to price advances and a lifting of merchandise qualities.

Doing what was expected of them, all eight seeded players won their opening matches as the fourth annual Bulldog handicap tournament of the National Squash Tennis Association started on the Yale Club courts yesterday. Twenty-one matches were played; another went by default.
TRENTON, N. J., Jan. 18--Alfred E. Driscoll, 44-year-old lawyer of Haddonfield, becomes Governor of New Jersey at noon Tuesday.

Miss Yvonne Sherman and Robert Swenning, representing the Skating Club of New York, won the mixed pairs title, as the Middle Atlantic figure skating championships on the Iceland Rink came to a close yesterday.

The tug-of-war between landlords and tenants over evictions, rent increases and reductions, and such questions as who must pay for a paint job and when, has become so widespread that the Office of Price Administration has found it necessary to restate the rules in question-and-answer form.

The Rev. Dr. F. Eppling Reinartz, secretary of the United Lutheran Church in America, announced yesterday that nineteen delegates had been named to a Lutheran world assembly in Lund, Sweden. The world group will meet from June 30 to July 6 to complete organization of a Lutheran World Federation.

RICHMOND, Calif., Jan. 19 (U.P.) --George Schoux, newest Cinderella man of the golfing professionals, today won the $10,000 Richmond open tournament with a record-breaking 16-under-par score of 268 for 72 holes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP)-- Rep. Gerald W. Landis, Republican, of Indiana, of the House Labor Committee outlined today a proposal to prevent serious industry-wide strikes by restoring, with novel changes, the Government's wartime power to seize plants.

LONDON, Jan. 19--London headquarters of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration has received reports from field representatives in Germany and Austria that agents of the Intergovernmental Committee on Refugees are interfering seriously with efforts to persuade displaced persons to accept repatriation, the UNRRA office stated today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 19-- "Lady in Ermine," a European play by Rudolph Schnazer and Ernest Welisch, which Twentieth Century-Fox bought in 1942 from Warner Brothers, will be made this year, with Ernest Lubitsch as producer-director.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 19 (AP)--John Madala, chief of fire and police protection at Hialeah race track, said tonight that 35 per cent of the striking grooms were back at work and predicted the plush racing plant would be "back to normal in two or three days."

DETROIT, Jan. 19 (U.P)--The Detroit Red Wings came from behind with less than two minutes to play tonight to tie the Montreal Canadiens, 2 to 2, in a National Hockey League game before 14,181 fans at Olympia Stadium.

Work clothing manufacturers are not looking for any easing in the standard fabric supply situation this year, market sources said yesterday. With some second-quarter offerings already being made, it was declared, it can be seen that available fabrics for staple garments will not go ahead of the firstquarter level, and in some instances will fall slightly behind.

RED BANK, N.J., Jan. 19-- Amateur boatmen along the Shrewsbury River were cheered today by a War Department announcement of a report by district engineers of the North Atlantic Division, recommending a detailed survey to consider a "turning basin" in the north branch of the river at feed Bank.

WEEK ENDED JAN. 18, 1947 Business In the Canadian free dollar dominated trading in the foreign exchanges last week. After a dragging market in early week which culminated in a new low for the movement of 94.62 cents, on Wednesday, volume buying quickly checked the decline and returned it to 95.25 cents, on successive trading days.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP)-- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation has announced that it will discontinue on Wednesday the "blanket participation agreement" program under which it guaranteed up to 75 per cent bank loans to industry without examining the loan applications.

LONDON, Jan. 19--The British Government has taken the unusually emphatic course of communicating direct to Generalissimo Stalin a strongly worded protest against a "misleading" Pravda article alleging that the Anglo-Soviet alliance had been disavowed by Foreign Secretary Bevin, the Foreign Office announced tonight.

Telephone subscribers in the Pennsylvania 6, Lackawanna 4 and Longacre 3 exchanges were unable to get incoming calls for an eleven-minute period, from 7:20 to 7:31 o'clock last night, because of a breakdown in the "ringing" machine in the New York Telephone Company's central office.
Formation of a new organization to work for democracy, as opposed to fascism and communism, was announced yesterday. It is to be known as Common Cause.

The high rate of dissolution of war-time marriages is a threat to American hopes for a better world, the Rev. Thomas F. Maher of the staff of St. Patrick's Cathedral declared yesterday in a sermon in the Cathedral.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 19 (U.P.)--The waters of two big Southern river systems, the Tennessee and the Alabama, brimmed over the tops of their banks today and forecasts of more rain raised the prospects of major floods.
From a spokesman for the National Association of Manufacturers organized labor received unqualified support yesterday for its last-ditch fight against compulsory arbitration.
Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, expressed yesterday opposition, to several labor bills introduced in Congress by Senator Joseph H. Ball, Republican, of Minnesota.

Yarn spinners, knitters aid weavers are watching the developments in the so-called fur-blend yarns which will reach their peak introduction to the public this year under new processes brought to perfection during the war years. At the recent show of the Men's Fashion Guild of New York there were several garments shown in which the fur-blend yarns were used, ranging from hosiery, knitted scarfs and sweaters to woven sports garments.
RAFINA, Greece, Jan. 19 (U.P.)-- Greek naval authorities and British Army medical corps men said that 196 survivors had been taken ashore here and in small villages along the coast.
A mother who knew only that her son had been killed last July in an accident in Korea learned the details yesterday from Miss Louis Yim, a member of the Korean delegation to the United Nations.

ORANGEBURG, N. Y., Jan. 19 --Housing relief for veterans in Rockland County was assured as forty-five local veterans signed leases yesterday and today for Federal Public Housing Authority apartments at Shanks Village. John J. Harrison, county director of veterans' affairs, predicted at least forty veterans would sign daily until the allotted 260 apartments were filled.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (U.P.)-- Senator Arthur Capper's bill for a uniform marriage and divorce law, a bitter pill for State's rights advocates, won a strong adherent today in Chairman Alexander Wiley of the Senate Judiciary Committee.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19--Of $4 953,989,000 in 7/8 per cent Treasury certificates of indebtednes coming due on Feb. 1. about $1000,000,000 will be retired for cast the Treasury Department announced today.
Greece will buy 100 Liberty ships from the United States, it was announced here yesterday by Nicolas Avraam, Greek Minister of Merchant Marine.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 19-- Nine seagoing unions have indicated, either formally or indirectly, their intention of being represented at a meeting in Washington to achieve a united front on maritime issues coming before Congress, it was announced today by Vincent J. Malone, president of the Independent Marine Firemen, Oilers and Watertenders, who issued the invitations late in December.
PEIPING, China, Jan. 19 (AP)-- In a tit-for-tat operation, the Communists today cut off the electric power and water for Changchun, Chinese Government-occupied capital of Manchuria.
BURBANK, Calif., Jan. 19-- Gen. George C. Marshall took off from Lockheed Airport at 6:58 o'clock tonight en route to Washington, where he will take the oath of office of Secretary of State tomorrow.

LONDON, Jan. 19 (AP)--The text of a British statement to Russia follows: His Majesty's Ambassador in Moscow has been instructed to communicate to Generalissimo Stalin the following statement of the views of His Majesty's Government regarding an article which was published in Pravda on Jan. 15:

MT. HOPE, N. Y., Jan. 19--W. Barton Eddison, skipping the Ardsley No. 2 rink, regained the Archibald Douglas medal for his club after a two-year lapse on the lanes of the St. Andrews Golf Club indoor curling rink today. Eddison had piloted the only previous Ardsley C. C. victor in the twelve-year history of the event here in 1944.

The number of out-of-town buyers in the New York wholesale markets last week was high and was reflected in the brisk activity n most fields, according to the reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Caution and selectivity were the keynote in purchasing operations, which, in some cases, had shifted from better to medium and popular priced merchandise, the reports continued.
AMSTERDAM, Jan. 19--Preparations for a Dutch-Belgian customs agreement, with an eventual full economic union, are making slow headway. The difficulties are considerable.

In line with Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander's expressed desire to infuse the department with younger blood, the retirement applications of fifty-two members will come before the board of trustees of the Police Pension Fund at 10 A. M. today in Police Headquarters.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (U.P.)-- Industry is facing the prospect that it may be ordered to negotiate with unions on retirement and pension plans.

YONKERS, N. Y., Jan. 19--Police of this city joined today with other Westchester authorities in a hunt for thieves who looted the homes of Theodore Kiendl in Yonkers and Harry B. Harvey in the adjoining village of Hastings-on-Hudson.

Viana Bey, 14-year-old pianist from California, where she is a pupil of Ethel Leginska, made her New York recital debut at Times Hall yesterday afternoon. The program included numbers by Bach, Beethoven, Chopin and Cadman and the Wagner-Liszt March from "Tannhaeuser."

Two thousand persons lined up outside the Park West Memorial Chapel, 1284 Central Avenue, Far Rockaway, Queens, yesterday to pay tribute to Motorcycle Patrolman Harry Schiffries, slain Friday by two men whose automobile he had halted for passing a red light on Park Avenue at Sixty-seventh Street.

A complete set of modern oak furniture, the first pieces to be received here of a line to be sold exclusively for veterans, has just been delivered to a student veteran and his wife living at Riverside Campus, the North Brother Island housing project, as a gift from the manufacturer, it was announced yesterday.

PARIS, Jan. 19--Paul Ramadier, old guard Socialist Minister of Justice, was invested late tonight with formal authority to present himself and his program--regardless of the new Cabinet's ultimate complexion--before the National Assembly Tuesday.
GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 19--This fashionable town on the shores of Long Island Sound has a sizable housing problem on its hands.

WARSAW, Jan. 19--Without waiting for the polls to close, Stanislaw Mikolajczyk, Peasant party leader, tonight announced his intention to appeal today's elections and to ask the Polish Supreme Court to nullify the results because of alleged violations in every district.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Jan. 19 (AP)--Bill Linney of Lyon Mountain and his veteran team of Republic Miners, defending champions in the James Hopkins Memorial Trophy race, repeated their 1946 victory today in the opening of the Mount Van Hoevenberg Olympic bobsled trail.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP)-- Small business which survived ared better financially than big companies during the war. A Federal Reserve Board report indicated oday. By the end of 1945 small and medium-sized concerns were 'probably in a more liquid position than they had ever been in the history of the country," it was pointed out.

ATLANTA, Jan. 19--Carrying on the fight against Herman Talmadge for the Governorship of Georgia, M. E. Thompson, in the role he has assumed as Acting Governor, instructed the State's Attorney General today "to take proper legal steps and bring suits to protect the funds and property of the State and each and every agency and department of the State Government."

In its annual review of the silver market, released for publication today, Handy Harman, silver dealers of New York, estimated that the United States last year produced 21,200,000 ounces of silver and that the nation's arts and industries consumed 105,000,000 ounces of the metal during the year.

ALBANY, Jan. 19--Senator Benjamin F. Feinberg's bill appropriating $32,000,000 to finance temporary pay increases of at least $300 for public school teachers appeared tonight to be certain of passage in both branches of the Legislature before the end of the week.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Since V-J Day there has been much talk about a housing program for the returning GI. Thus far this much needed project has not emerged from the talking and "blueprint stage. The business man takes the position that housing program is the Government responsibility.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Senora Esther N. de Calvo, one of two women members of the National Assembly of Panama, is conferring here with women members of Congress and with health and welfare authorities to obtain ideas to help her in framing laws which will put into effect the new Panama Constitution which she helped draft.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Jan. 19--Pending the outcome of the Moscow conference of Foreign Ministers, the further development of the half-constructed democratic organisms in the United States and British zones is now suspended in a welter of unresolved questions of constitutional law.

The New York Rovers got a onegoal jump on the Baltimore Clippers in the first period and maintained that edge throughout to score a 4-5 triumph in the Eastern Hockey League game that featured the double-header at Madison Square Garden yesterday. In the preliminary game the Manhattan Arrows had an easy time subduing their Metropolitan League rivals, the Brooklyn Torpedoes, 7 to 3.

Fluctuating over a wide trading range, cotton prices in the domestic market last week moved downward. At the close on Saturday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net losses for the period of 104 to 126 points. In the previous week declines of 137 to 179 points were registered.

BRATISLAVA, Czechoslovakia, Jan. 19--The Office for Slovak Colonization in Bratislava, which keeps the records of Magyars expelled and sent under the forced labor decree to Bohemia and Moravia, has stated that as of mid-January 16,500 Magyars had been deported from southern Slovakia.

A three-goal lead in the first period fortified the New York Rangers in their National Hockey League game with the Chicago Black Hawks at Madison Square Garden last night. The Hawks went about the task of whittling this advantage in the subsequent sessions, and at one time in the third frame were only a goal behind.

How the enormously expanded war-time Red Cross, now seeking a peace-time level of operation, has found itself shouldering heavy responsibilities derived from the war is described in the annual report of the New York Chapter, made public yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19--Congress must end the Senate filibuster and strengthen majority and minority policy control before its job of modernizing is complete, the National Planning Association declared today.
MOSCOW, Jan. 19-The projected Anglo-French alliance is viewed

BELTON, Mont., Jan. 19 (U.P.)--A relief expedition led by a snowplow set out today for the little mountain town of Babb, which was running out of food and was nearly without light after being isolated by snowstorms for a month.

LONDON, Jan. 18--The stock markets here continue to display in amazing indifference to the labor strikes, coal shortage, manpower difficulties and numerous smaller economic clouds that are darkening Britain's business horison. After having simmered down somewhat, the markets broke out this week into renewed activity and boom-like movements in security prices.

ATHENS, Jan. 19 (AP)--One survivor of the sinking, a 44-year-old school teacher, estimated today that almost 200 of those drowned were women and children. He said: "I am afraid every child aboard was lost, and 95 per cent of the women."

The destiny of man in the atomic age can be mastered by the spirit of man, the Rev. Robert Killam, minister of the Church of the Unity, Springfield, Mass., declared yesterday at the morning service of the Unitarian Church of All Souls, Lexington Avenue at Eightieth Street.
Only five members of the former congregation were among the 160 worshipers yesterday morning at the Collegiate Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.
