CHICAGO, Jan. 19--The United States Junior Chamber of Commerce announced today its selection of the country's ten outstanding young men of the year. Only those 21 to 36 years old are eligible for the honor.
Activation of the first air wing of the New York National Guard was announced yesterday by Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum, commanding general of the State force.

POPULAR BLUFF, Mo., Jan. 19 (AP)--W. Frank Steelman, 42, brother of John R. Steelman, Reconversion Director, was killed instantly today by the accidental discharge of a shotgun while hunting rabbits on the Black River in southeastern Missouri.

MINDEN, Germany, Jan. 19 -- United States and British Military Government officials are making special provisions in proposals for raising the level-of-industry plan, should the Soviet dismantling prove larger than authorized. They fear that economic unity with the Soviet zone under such condition would prove "a serious economic liability on Western Germany."

With the filing in the United States Supreme Court last week of a brief by the Department of Justice seeking Federal title to the three-mile limit off the California coast, the controversy going on for fears as to whether title to these lands was vested in the United States Government or in the State of California moves one step nearer to final adjudication.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP)-- T. P. Wright, civil aeronautics administrator, said today that all pilot certificates issued prior to July 1, 1945, would expire on July 1, 1947, but before then could be exchanged with CAA inspectors for new certificates "without red tape or written application."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19--The Navy Department announced today that a second fighter of the Ryan Fireball series, equipped with a gas turbine for its propeller and a jet tail boost, had successfully completed flight tests. Test data during a month of successful flying indicated that the new plane, the XF2R-1, would probably be in the 500-mile-an-hour class, it was said.

Admission of twenty young children for examination and treatment of personality difficulties was revealed yesterday by the Council Child Development Center, 227 West Fifty-ninth Street, first project of its kind in New York City.

MONT GABRIEL, Que., Jan. 19--With the spectacular Wurtele twins monopolizing the action again, an Eastern Canadian women's ski team routed an American unit in their annual international series concluded today. The meet ended with the holding of the slalom.

DALLAS, Jan. 19 (AP)--The Southwest Conference today rejected the principle proposed by the National Collegiate Athletic Association under which off-thecampus recruiting would be barred but suggested a joint meeting with neighboring conferences in an effort to reach a compromise acceptable to the N.C.A.A.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 19--When President Miguel Aleman took office just seven weeks ago it was generally agreed that one of the most pressing problems with which he would have to deal was the transportation system.

Lotte Lehmann presented the irst of a series of three recitals, yesterday afternoon, at Town Hall. For the first half of the program he eminent soprano had chosen our Beethoven songs and the "An e ferne Geliebte" cycle of that omposer, while the rest of the chedule was devoted to Lieder by Schubert.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19--Although unprecedented uncertainties prevailed throughout most of 1946 in the meat processing operations of Wilson Co., wide diversification of other business contributed to one of the most profitable years in the company's history, Edward F. Wilson, president, said in his annual report to shareholders today.

Thirteen months ago President Truman made a moving appeal for this admission of at least a few of Europe's displaced persons to this country and issued orders to the executive agencies concerned to do what they could within existing laws. The quota admissions, which had fallen during the war to between 5 and 10 per cent of the legal maximum, would have opened the doors to about 39,000 immigrants.

The March of Dimes poster girl in the current campaign of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis was received yesterday morning by Cardinal Spellman after she attended the 10 A. M. mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

In a letter sent yesterday to Lazarus Joseph, City Controller, the seventeen airlines with leases at Idlewild Airport again questioned the ability of the City Airport Authority to finance the project. They were joined in their attack by former Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia, who said in his noon radio talk that Controller Joseph should "protect" the city.
Reports from conquered Germany have been so uniformly pessimistic that the first feeble whispers of economic optimism may sound louder than they should. But at least they are now being heard.

Sight damaged by hemorrhage has been improved by a simple operation in which fluid from the patient's own spine is injected into the eye, the Eye-Bank for Sight Restoration, Inc., announced yesterday.

George Santayana, who is living in Rome, has completed the final section of his autobiography, "Persons and Places," but will not permit its publication until after his death. The first two volumes, "Background of My Life" and "The Middle Span," already have been released by Scribners.
ROME, Jan. 19 (U.P.)--The 1947 edition of Annuario Pontificio, the official Vatican listing of the hierarchy, appeared today with six changes in the list of Popes.

As part of its program for utilizing television as an educational medium, New York University will present a half-hour program on atomic energy tonight at 8:30 o'clock from Station WABD. Laboratory demonstrations and motion pictures will be used to explain atomic energy in terms understandable to a layman.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19--Reports that Government purchases on Jan. 16 bids for lard were 20,000,000 pounds stimulated buying of lard futures on the Board of Trade late last week. Prices advanced sharply, but the outside figures were not held owing to profit-taking, and a belief that the make of lard would increase in the near future.

A plea for the ending of national hatreds and denominational animosities under "the totalitarian rule of our Lord, Jesus Christ" was advanced last night by the Rev. Dr. Martin Niemoeller. He made his first public appearance here before nearly 6,000 persons in the St. Nicholas Arena, 53 West Sixty-sixth Street.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Jan. 19 --The Security Council and three Economic and Social sessions will convene here tomorrow in a sharp step-up in United Nations activities following the thirty-six-day lull since the close of the General Assembly on Dec. 15.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19--Representative Henry M. Jackson, Democrat, of Washington, will introduce in Congress tomorrow a joint resolution which would empower President Truman to establish a civilian administration for Guam, American Samoa and the former Japanese-mandated islands.

Interesting fabrics, new rugs aid a collection of recently imported European antiques are the highlights of a group of interiors that will be opened today at W. J. Sloane. This suite, called "House in Town," redesigned for the first time since the war, emphasizes elegance for those who never need bother to look at a price tag.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 19-- With a number of constitutional realities yet to be faced, the Indian Constitution-making Assembly will resume its sessions tomorrow.

New York City's housing achievements during 1946 are presented in some chilly figures made public yesterday by the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Two cheerful details are that nine times as much money was spent on buildings started during 1946 as was similarly spent during 1945, and that nearly 84 per cent of it was spent on homes.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (U.P.)-- General Marshall will be sworn in as Secretary of State tomorrow. Immediately afterward he will confer with President Truman.

The Young's Men's Board of Trade of New York, 291 Broadway, acting as coordinator of the efforts of business and industry, lists the following free services to aid veterans in career-planning and employment:

Industrial metals, textiles, apparel, drugs, cosmetics, medical and paper products head War Assets Administration surplus disposal efforts in this region this week, officials disclosed over the weekend. Twelve location sales will be held in New York and New Jersey with $54,000,000 original price inventories to be sold.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19--Grain markets turned downward late last week after an early upturn had carried January wheat to $2.19 1/2 a bushel, a twenty-six-year high, and March oats to 77 1/2 cents, which equaled the high since midOctober.

There are more reasons than the esthetic one for carving correctly and neatly. Meat actually tastes better if the man who cuts it knows what he's about. And there is also the economy angle--a skilfully carved roast yields more servings than one that is hacked haphazardly.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 19--Steel ingot production last week again reached its post-war peak of 91.5 per cent of rated capacity, up 1 1/2 points from the week before.

PARIS, Jan. 19 (U.P.)--The two-year territorial dispute between France and Siam ended officially today with the transfer of southern Laos Province west of the Mekong River to Sisavang Vong, King of the French Indo-Chinese protectorate of Laos, the French Press Agency reported today.

Ruth Kisch-Arndt, contralto, who has been giving unusual concerts since she arrived here eight years ago, last night presented "An Evening of Early Music" at Times Hall. Her selections ranged from two songs of the fifteenth century to Mozart's "La Batulia Liberata."

For five and a half cold hours, members of the Polish-American Congress picketed yesterday before the Polish Consulate, 151 East Sixty-seventh Street, to protest the "phony" election in Poland. They carried signs and gave out handbills charging Russian manipulation of both the election and the Polish Government.

R. T. Stafford has been named assistant to W. C. Johnson, vice president in charge of the general machinery division of the Pittsburgh works of the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company. He will operate out of New York. J. W. McMullen has been made general manager of the Pittsburgh works.

That the Yankees, with a first-case problem on their hands, allowed Hank Greenberg to be waived out of the American league and wind up with the Pirates, has caused more lifting of ebrows than any major-league amond transaction since Hank orowy landed with the Cubs.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19--A wire recorder combined with a home radio-phonograph--the first of its kind in actual production--was shown for the first time at the American Furniture Mart yesterday amid the predictions of radio experts that it will revolutionize the recording and broadcast industries.

An auspicious bow is made by a new journal devoted to better conditions on the highways and streets, appearing under the name Traffic Quarterly, from the Eno Foundation for Highway Traffic Control. The quarterly is planned as a medium of expression for expert opinion on all phases of the traffic problem, and deals with such subjects as the President's Highway Safety Conference, zoning as applied to parking, pedestrian traffic and driver attitudes.

Jewelers to Expand Ads There will be an expansion of consumer advertising by jewelers during the current year, it was pointed out yesterday by Albert E. Hasse, executive director of the Jewelry Industry Council, at a meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria. He based his statement on replies received on 1947 advertising plans from a cross-section of the industry consisting of 1,064 retailers and 79 manufacturers who used consumer advertising last year.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Jan. 19--Denmark, three times attacked by Germany in the last 100 years, is especially concerned to see that her neighbor shall be completely disarmed and denazified, Gustav Rasmussen, Danish Foreign Minister, said today.

Marie Arakian, Armenian-American soprano, at her recital last night in Town Hall presented a program containing arias by Bach, Handel, Mozart and Tchaikovsky, lyrics by Rubinstein and AlabieffGlinka, and in addition a number of offerings sung for the first time anywhere. These comprised seven songs by Pietro Cimara, the Metropolitan conductor; the Saint-SaensAslanoff "Reverie Algerienne," the Mussorgsky-Aslanoff "Orientalia" and a group of arrangements of Armenian folk songs.

Mayor O'Dwyer's annual message to the City Council, already twice postponed, may not be submitted until after Feb. 1, it was indicated yesterday. The message will outline in detail the city's current fiscal position, its revenue needs for the 1947-48 budget year and the possible methods of balancing the budget.

MOSCOW, Jan. 19--The United States foreign policy was subjected to a barrage of criticism in the most recent edition of The Agitators Notebook. The publication claimed that "reaction" in the United States was appealing for use of force seeking to destroy the foundations of the United Nations and construct an Anglo-American bloc directed against the interests of the other nations.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Jan. 19-- Sending his boat Agony out in front of the fleet in five out of eight races, Arthur Knapp won the dinghy series today at the Larchmont Yacht Club. There were twenty-nine of the new Interclub craft out.

ATHENS, Jan. 19 (AP)--Leaders of seven Opposition parties commanding a majority in Parliament demanded today that King George summon the Crown Council with the view of forming a new Government. They signed a protocol agreeing to participate in a new Government under any Premier the King might designate except the present Premier, Constantin Tsaldaris, Populist leader.

Legislation restoring to veterans the Social Security credits put in jeopardy by military service should be enacted by this Congress with the least possible delay. It is a reproach to the last Congress that it failed to pass a bill to restore to veterans the Social Security status they would have had if war had not interrupted their employment in incurable industry.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19--Labor legislation, housing, veterans' problems and national defense will be discussed by the United States Conference of Mayors in its three-day annual meeting beginning here tomorrow.

This week in the art world includes an unusual number of outstanding events in museums and other institutions. On Friday the Metropolitan will open a loan exhibition of masterpieces of English painting by Turner, Constable and Hogarth, pictures lent by King George and by British public and private collections.

Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said in a radio broadcast yesterday afternoon from Washington that there would be no change in America's foreign policy with the Republicans in control of Congress, but the Republicans were likely to "ask more questions" in matters dealing with world trade.

What kind of Italy will come out of the treaty to be signed today by Mr. Byrnes as his last act as Secretary of State? For the past few weeks the writer has been discussing this question in Italy with leaders of the various political parties and scores of Italians of all shades of opinion and every walk of life.

ATHENS, Jan. 19--About 300 persons were feared lost today when the 1,500-ton steamship Himara struck a mine just before dawn near the entrance to the Gulf of Petalia and sank, in high seas, in half an hour. The gulf is about twenty miles from Athens.

LONDON, Jan. 19--Britain's Labor Government played tonight its final card--a procedure for Parliamentary decision--in its attempt to bring employers and truck drivers here together on a new work contract.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19--The Navy is planning to tow some of the atomic bomb target fleet without crews to Hawaii and the West Coast for thorough radiological and mechanical examination.

A newcomer to the local boxing scene will be presented at Madison Square Garden tonight when Al (Red) Priest opposes Cowboy Ruben Shank in the ten-round feature bout. Priest, a Boston product, has developed into one of the greatest attractions in the Hub since the days of Jimmy Maloney and Jack Sharkey. Incidentally, he is under the management of Johnny Buckley, who guided Sharkey to the heavyweight championship of the world.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 19--Publication of the final program for King George VI's visit to South Africa has intensified the various symptoms here of "royal fever."

PARIS, Jan. 19--The French Government announced tonight that land and sea operations had begun yesterday morning to free the city of Hue, in Indo-China. This is the capital of the east central state of Annam, where a battalion of French troops has been holding off a besieging force of Viet Namese since last Dec. 19.

A piece of wood, an inch long and 3/4 inch in diameter, embedded in the brain of a 60-year-old man who was beaten by unidentified assailants, was removed at 2 A. M. yesterday at Bellevue Hospital. The patient's condition was reported as critical. Hospital surgeons expressed belief the piece of wood might have been part of a chair-rung with which the man's skull was fractured.

MOSCOW, Jan. 19--A nationwide campaign to register Russia's orphans, place them in children's homes and check upon the home conditions of the children whose mothers work is under way as a result of a series of decisions passed yesterday by the All Union Central Committee of Trade Unions.

BOSTON, Jan. 19 (UP)--The Boston Bruins rallied in the final period to score twice and defeat the league-leading Toronto Maple Leafs, 3 to 2, in a National Hockey League game before 13,900 at Boston Garden tonight.

LITTLE AMERICA, Jan. 18 (Delayed) (AP)--Admiral Cruzen said tonight the submarine Sennet will abandon her attempt to penetrate the Ross Sea ice pack and will start back to the United States about Feb. 1.
With pledges amounting to $268,000 received at the dinner, the American Federation for Polish Jews opened last night its 1947 campaign for $3,000,000 for the relief of Polish Jews.

Like other city dwellers, most New Yorkers believe that smoke goes straight up, barring wind. They do not know that under certain conditions smoke particles fall straight down. Consequently, there were thousands of puzzled expressions in Times Square last night as what appeared to be a gentle dust storm smudged the faces and clothing of pedestrians, and even left a coating in which tire tracks were visible on the streets.

LONDON, Jan. 19--Two members of the committee formed by Winston Churchill to promote the cause of a united Europe wrote letters to the Times of London today saying the committee did not plan a United States of Europe. They were Sir Walter Layton and Dr. Gilbert Murray.
A Tale of Two Cities It seems that the acute stage of the traffic problem which has given New York its worst headache for so many years has caught up with Los Angeles.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Will there never be an end to the marvels connected with, or produced by, the war? The latest startling revelation, guardedly disclosed, is of a typewriter that takes dictation by itself. The details of this machine, developed in Germany during the war, are in the possession of the Army Signal Corps, and are being treated strictly as a war secret.

NEWBURGH, N. Y., Jan. 19 (AP) --A former United States Navy Air Corps radio technician, Ray Blum of the Paterson Skating Club, and Miss Marion Hanley of the Grossinger (N. Y.) Skating Club, swept the senior divisions of the twenty-sixth annual Middle Atlantic outdoor speed skating championships held at the Delano-Hitch Memorial Rink today.

PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 20-- Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince, the Emir Saud, inspected the Robert Garrett collection of Arabic manuscripts at Princeton University's library this afternoon as the guest of Dr. Harold W. Dobbs, president of tne university. The Crown Prince was accompanied by Sheikh Fuad Hamza, ambassador to this country, and a party of fifteen, including State Department officials and secret service men.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP)-- Two Federal agencies have pooled facilities with White House help to arrange for the most complete business condition reporting system the Government has yet devised. Roger E. Barnes, chief economist for the Federal Trade Commission, told a reporter today that the Budget Bureau aided his agency and the Securities and Exchange Commission in working out the cooperative statistical plan.

Wilson Oelkers has been appointed purchasing agent of the radio division and William Chaffee purchasing agent of the refrigerator division of Philco Corporation. George Hulse has been named assistant to the general purchasing agent and Louis H. Niemann, assistant purchasing agent of the radio division.

EAST ORANGE, N. J., Jan. 20Seventy-one-year-old Irving Van Gilfler Perine, retired industrial executive, a church and civic leader here, was killed and his wife, 'Mrs. Adelia Marten Perine, suffered a broken collarbone in a motor accident a.t Charleston, S. C., on Thursday, according to word received here today. The Perines, who had been driving to Florida, I lived at 179 Harrison Street here.

NEWARK, N. J., Jan. 20 -- As hundreds of persons streamed by unaware, a retail liquor dealer was stabbed to death at noon today in a hold-up in his store at 949 Broad Street, near City Hall and Police Headquarters. The bandit, cornered after a four-block chase, was wounded critically by two radio car policemen when he attempted to draw a six-inch combat blade.

OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 20--A four-engined hospital plane of the Naval Air Transport Service, on the way from Moffett Field to Washington with fourteen passengers and a crew of seven, crashed and burned at the Oakland Airport this afternoon in an attempted radar landing in thick fog.
Prof. Johan J, Smertenko, vice chairman of the American League for a Free Palestine, charged yesterday that the British Government had attempted to stifle free discussion of its policy in Palestine.

LONDON, Jan. 20--A gloomy Diagnosis of Britain's economic health and a delcaration of the views of Government, industry and labor leaders on what this country must do to recover are set out in a White Paper issued by the Government today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20-Hearings on labor legislation before the Senate Labor Committee, scheduled to start Thursday, will be completed about March 1, it was announced today by Senator Taft, committee chairman. Witnesses would be asked to submit written statements before their appearance, he said.

ROME, Jan, 20--Only three days after his return from the United States, Premier Alcide de Gasperi this evening handed in his resignation and that of his Cabinet to the Provisional President of the Italian Republic, Enrico de Nicola. The resignation was accepted, but Signer de Gasperi, who also was Minister of the Interior, was asked to remain at the head of Italian affairs until a new Government could be formed.

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 20-- Wholesale grocers should not take excited or precipitate action in making decisions on taking inventory losses in a period of falling markets, Francis L. Whitmarsh, president, National-American Wholesale Grocers Association, warned today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The Supreme Court rejected today three appeals protesting a $15,000,000 litigation settlement between the Pennsylvania Railroad and the Pennroad Corporation of Delaware. The payment was to be made by the Pennsylvania Company to Pennroad under term of an agreement in 1945.

A team of expert organizers was sent Into New York yesterday to induce 7,000 Western Union Telegraph Company employes to transfer their allegiance from the Congress of Industrial Organizations to the American Federation of Labor.

The men who write for the editorial pages of our newspapers bear a heavy responsibility to their public if they do their work in good conscience. They have an obligation to be well informed to a degree that could consume every waking hour and still be unsatisfied. They are writers of opinion, but they must at the same time be fair.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20 (AP)-- In an application for modification of an order of the Securities and Exchange Commission, the United Corporation of New York gave today its plans for operation as an investment company.

Describing the Federal excise tax as "No. 1 problem of credit jewelels," the National Association of Credit Jewelers went on record yesterday in opposition to the tax, characterizing it as "punitive" and calling for its elimination or reduction, at the annual meeting of its board of directors at the Hotel Commodore.
The effectiveness of the Police Department's chief palliative for traffic congestion was demonstrated again yesterday.

ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- By unanimous vote the Senate approved tonight the Feinberg bill to appropriate $32,000,000 to finance $300 pay increases for public school teachers. It first voted down, 38 to 15, a series of Democratic amendments.

"All the King's Men," by Robert Penn Warren, has won the Southern Authors' Award as the most distinguished book of 1946 by a Southern author on a Southern subject. Books that won places on the honorable mention list were Eudora Welty's "Delta Wedding"; "Experiment in Rebellion," by Clifford Dowdey; "The Shore Dimly Seen," by Ellis Arnall, and "Those Other People," by Mary King O'Donnell.

In a prepared statement which he issued yesterday, Hank Greenberg, who was waived out of the American League and now is the property of the Pirates in the senior circuit, gave no intimation of his plans for the future. He expressed disappointment over the deal, first word of which he heard on a radio broadcast last Saturday, as well as regret that he must part from his Tiger team-mates.

Bach's "Christmas Oratorio," rarely heard even in separate performances of its six cantatas, was heard in its entirety last night at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and Ninetieth Street. The performance was given by the Cantata Singers, Arthur Mendel, conductor, with soloists, chorus of forty voices, organ, harpsichord and chamber orchestra of the size used by Bach himself.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20--Through no fault of the State Department its new Secretary will find it waiting for him tomorrow in a state of suspension, and on his desk will be the resignations of all its high appointive officers. If the basic system by which the Department is manned and governed had the element of continuity which, for instance, the British Foreign Office has, neither of these conditions would be confronting General Marshall.

The stock market indicated yesterday that it would require something more than just a relaxation of the all-cash basis for trading to produce a more definite trend of prices. The slight bulge which developed on Saturday was erased easily during the morning, after which quotations sagged further to bring inroads of 1 to 3 points in the industrial issues.

LEXINGTON, Va., Jan. 20--Dr. Francis Pendleton Gaines, eighth president of Washington and Lee University today called for a new allegiance to the fundamental concepts of American history. Dr. Gaines spoke at Founder's Day exercises held here before the largest assembly in the university's twocentury history.

When infantile paralysis last summer hit the nation the hard- est blow in thirty years the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis was able to send 2,000 nurses, 300 physical therapists and scores of physicians into stricken areas -- thanks to funds given to the March of Dimes.

Construction contracts to provide housing relief for 65,615 families in metropolitan New York and northern New Jersey were awarded during 1946, the F. W. Dodge Corporation reported yesterday. The dollar value of the contracts amounted to $471,351,000, compared with $272,559,000 in 1939, which was the previous high mark during the past sixteen years.
TRENTON, N. J,, Jan. 20-Arrangements were completed here tonight for the inauguration tomorrow noon of Alfred E. Driscoll as New Jersey's next Governor.

Mayor O'Dwyer was asked yesterday by the Park Association of New York City, Inc., to turn over city-owned lands valued at $1,800,000 to the Park Department for beach park improvements without requiring the department to pay the city for the lands.

A large loan exhibition of sculpture and drawings by the late Gaston Lachaise, distinguished sculptor, opened with a preview yesterday afternoon at Knoedler's, 14 East Fifty-seventh Street. It opens to the public today and will continue through Feb. 15.
Random Notes. Some days we just can't get away with a paragraph.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20--Dr. Lee De Forest, "father of the radio," says he harbors not the slightest tinge of bitterness because he failed to reap financial rewards commensurate with the tremendous benefits his invention of forty years ago brought to mankind.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20-- The Government was back in the market as a buyer of, cash wheat today. However, its bid was lowered 2 cents, being $2.05 a bushel for ordinary No. 1 hard winter in storage at Kansas City. This was for delivery on or before Feb. 20, with 1 cent discount for delivery Feb. 21 to 28 and 2 cents for delivery March 1 to 10.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Fifteen tenants ordered evicted from the nineteen - story apartment house at No. 55 Central Park West won at least a temporary victory when the Supreme Court, by six to three ruled today that they were entitled to have their protests considered by the Temporary Controls Administrator and the Emergency Court of Appeals.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20- The Supreme Court ruled today that the Federal District Court in New Jersey has authority to decide the $15,000,000 tax claim of that State against the Central Railroad of New Jersey.

Premiums of from three to nine cents a pound are being asked by brokers and speculators in sheet Steel who have raised prices of small available stocks outside the regular channels of trade to new high levels. Small plants are being asked to pay from twelve to fourteen cents a pound for cold rolled steel sheets in weights from 18 to 22 gauge, while mill prices remain at a low level.

A moderate increase in shortterm interest rates on Government securities was hinted at yesterday by Allan Sproul, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, speaking at the mid-winter meeting of the New York State Bankers Association. The meeting in the auditorium of the Federal Reserve Bank's Building was attended by 1,000 banking executives.

Teachers College of Columbia University began an action yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Bernard Botein for discontinuance of experimental Horace Mann-Lincoln School after June 30, 1948. Opposing the closing are the Parent-Teacher Association of the school, headed by its president, Mrs. Elinor S. Gimbel, a group of students, and a contributor to the school improvement fund.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio, indicated his belief today before the United States Conference of Mayors that rent control should be extended in some form beyond the present June 30 deadline.

NANKING. Tuesday, Jan. 21-- The Government announced at 2 A. M. today its readiness to resume peace negotiations with the Communists. Minister of Information Peng Hsueh-pei had spent most of the night drafting the statement.

A block of 140,900 shares of $5 par value common stock of Old Town Ribbon and Carbon Co., Inc., family-owned manufacturer since 1917 of carbon papers, inked ribbons and like products, will be placed on the market today by an investment banking group headed by The First Boston Corporation.

As was freely predicted by all neutral observers, the Communist-dominated regime in Poland proclaims a sweeping victory for itself in the first parliamentary election held in that country since it emerged from its fourth partition between Russia and Germany.

International Bank Bond men at the Municipal Forum luncheon yesterday found no new disclosures of fact in the talk on International Bank securities given by J. Burke Knapp, Federal Reserve System researcher, but they were impressed by his stated belief that the new lending institution, despite its reported difficulty in finding a new president, will place its debentures on the market by mid-year.
Poultry growers from the Northeastern States met yesterday to talk about breeding a chicken that would have more housewife appeal.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 20 -- The United Nations Security Council today approved by a 9-to-2 vote a United States request that consideration of international atomic control and other phases of disarmament be postponed until Feb. 4.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- President Truman indicated today that he did not want the Seriate to continue beyond Jan. 31 the special War Investigating Committee, which he started and first headed as a Senator.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20--Suppression by the late President Roosevelt of an industrial mobilization report prepared in 1939 by the short-lived War Resources Board was largely responsible for a delay of eighteen months in gearing industry to war time production after the attack on Pearl Harbor, it was charged today by Robert E. Wood, chairman of Sears Roebuck Co.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Our German policy is in danger of turning from negation to patchwork and ending in futility. Positive measures taken, or announced, to date have little bearing on the basic economic situation.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Jan. 20This city's tax rate, Which will be announced tomorrow when the annual budget is presented to the City Commission, will be the highest in Jersey City's history, city officials admitted today. It probably will exceed $70 in $1,000 of assessed valuation.

Broccoli as crisp and green at if picked fresh from the garden on a summer day is arriving from Texas, California and Arizona to provide one of the most economical and plentiful sources of valuable nutrients available in the market now.

ATHENS, Jan. 20--The Greek Parliament convened tonight, and although it had been expected that Premier Constantin Tsaldaris would call for a vote of confidence, the Speaker, at the instance of party chiefs, postponed the sitting until Thursday.

A committee representing day care centers and other groups concerned with child welfare will go to Albany this week to discuss a permanent State program of aid to child-care services, it was announced yesterday. After a meeting at Forest Neighborhood House, 1122 Forest Avenue, the Bronx, George Gregory Jr., chairman of the city-wide legislative committee of child-care centers, said a drive would be made to emphasize the importance of the program.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 20 (UP) -- Newspapers estimated today that a third of Brazil's 7,500,000 registered voters had stayed away from the polls in yesterday's State elections in spite of appeals by the Catholic Church and democratic leaders for a large turnout to counter the Communist vote.

A subsidiary company of the General Realty Utilities Corporation obtained a new first mortgage loan of $2,750,000 at 3 1/4 per cent interest for twenty years from an insurance company oh the forty-story office building at 444 Madison Avenue.

HANOVER, N. H., Jan. 20--In an Eastern Intercollegiate League contest that saw the lead change hands seven times, Cornell's quintet triumphed over Dartmouth by 38-35 tonight. Big Ed Peterson connected for 17 markers to lead the Ithacans to their third loop triumph in four starts.

The Office of Scientific Research and Development is no more. It died officially yesterday when the President received Dr. Vannevar Bush and eleven of his top associates and thanked them for the work that they did during the war in organizing research in technology and the natural sciences, including medicine, to meet the exigencies of the war.

Delegates to the United Nations, members of the diplomatic corps and other friends attended yesterday a solemn high mass of requiem in St. Patrick's Cathedral for Dr. Pedro Leao Velloso, Foreign Minister of Brazil and chief of his country's delegation to the U. N. Security Council and General Assembly, who died here on Thursday of a heart attack at the age of 60.

PARIS, Jan. 20--Arrangements for a revolving credit of u12,500,000 lave been concluded through Lazard Brothers, Ltd., London, to finance French purchases of wool within the British Empire in the next twelve months, according to reliable advices received here.

A Navy Department certificate of appreciation to Cardinal Spellman for meritorious service and achievement as Vicar of the Armed Forces during the war was presented yesterday at a brief ceremony in the Military Ordinariate headquarters, 462 Madison Avenue.

Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander decided yesterday to create three new divisions in a sweeping reorganization and physical realignment of his forces that will involve the shifting of hundreds of detectives and uniformed policemen.

Families who take pride in their homes sometimes want to immortalize favorite rooms in paintings, just as others sometimes commission an artist to portray a favorite horse or dog. A collection of thirty-six such paintings of rooms in gouache by David Payne was put on exhibition yesterday in Manor House, 383 Madison Avenue, where it will remain until Feb. 15.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 (AP)--J. O. McClintock, new president of the Chicago Board of Trade, today termed the Government's present program of loans on farm commodities "a mischievous method of wealth transposition."

Net income of the Emerson Radio, and Phonograph Corporation and its wholly owned subsidiaries was $1,340,356, equal to $3.35 a share on 400,000 capital shares, the annual report for the fiscal year ended on Oct 31, last, disclosed yesterday.

Removal of the excise tax on women's handbags to "correct a long-standing error by which, handbags have been improperly classified as 'luggage' for excise tax purposes," was urged yesterday by the Popular Price Shoe Retailers Association.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 20-West Coast designers are telling .their summer story in pleats, rippling circular skirts and wide bell-bottom flares. Straight line fullness with every known pleating and some new inventions, vies with swing hemlines for easy action clothes for hot days.

Store Sales Here Up 20% Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores last week were 20 per cent above those for the like week of 1946, according to the "flash report" issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Last of the college basketball double-headers at Madison Square Garden until Feb. 18. tonight's twin bill at the Eighth Avenue Arena will send N. Y. U. against Colgate and St. John's against Western Kentucky. Howard Cann, Violet coach, and Joe Lapchick, St. John's mentor, look for stubborn opposition from the visiting quintets.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 20-- Justin Miller, president of the National Association of Broadcasters, said today that the Federal Communications Commission had gone beyond bounds indicated by the United States Supreme Court in its regulations of radio broadcasting.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The term "Secretary of National Defense" in the Army-Navy unification plan typifies a deplorable drift away from basic United States principle. I refer to its use of national to describe our federal union. If this drift is not checked the President will soon be sending messages on "the state of the Nation" instead of the Union.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) The Senate confirmed today Archibald L. M. Wiggins of South Carolina as Under-Secretary of the Treasury, succeeding O. Max Gardner, Ambassador to Great Britain. Also confirmed were John Nicholas Brown of Rhode Island as Assistant Secretary of the Navy for Air and William A. Rowan of Illinois as Controller of Customs with headquarters at Chicago.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 20-- Enterprise Productions announced today that Ginger Rogers has acquired screen rights to "Great Answer," a 1944 novel about a newspaper woman by Margaret Runbeck. According to the studio, Miss Rogers will produce and star in the film adaptation on a profitsharing basis after she completes "Maggi July" and "Wild Calendar" for the company.
A small mongrel dog ran under a north-bound Amsterdam Avenue trolley car during yesterday morning's rainstorm.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 20 -- Representatives of Palestine Jews solemnly warned terrorists today that they must cease truculent operations against British forces or take the consequences of action by their own people.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20 -- A registration statement covering 405,000 shares of $1 par value capital stock to be offered as a speculation at $1 a share was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by Verde Explorations, Ltd., New York.
The Rev. Dr. Martin Niemoeller a symbol of resistance against nazism to many, but regarded as an exponent of German nationalism by others, replied here yesterday to accusations made against him.

DETROIT, Mich., Jan. 20--In an effort to compile proof of the authenticity and scope of the opposition to the Nazis by the Evangelical Church in Germany during the war, the American section of the Lutheran World Federation appropriated funds today to finance the necessary research.

Price quotations for spot deliveries of staple textiles are too high to encourage volume purchases and represent too great a hazard under current conditions, visiting wholesale dry goods merchants asserted yesterday.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 20 -- Sir Sarvapalli Radhakrishnan, Indian educator, asserted in the reconvened Constitution-making Assembly today that India must sever her ties with the British Commonwealth.
Mayor O'Dwyer swore in Maurice Rosenfeld, president of the Equitable Paper Bag Company of Long Island City, at City Hall yesterday, as an honorary Deputy Police Commissioner.

LONDON, Jan. 20-The Baruch plan for control of atomic energy is open to the objection that it would allow the United States Congress to withhold ratification at any of its stages, Britain's Atomic Scientists Association stated today.

ATHENS, Jan. 20 (AP)--The possibility that a time bomb had sunk the Greek steamer Himara, sending 392 panic-stricken persons to their deaths yesterday in the frigid waters of the Gulf of Petalia, was being investigated tonight by officials of the Ministry of Merchant Marine.

The Musicians' Guild, Inc., a new organization of fine musicians who seem to care greatly about good music, presented its first program at Times Hall last night, and it turned out to be music-making of rare distinction. The works played were all worth hearing, and the performances were of the highest quality.

The middleweight bout between Al (Red) Priest,Boston youngster, and Cowboy Ruben Shank, rugged Donverite, brought out the musical talents of a gathering of 9,146 fans who paid $29,605 in receipts last night at Madison Square Garden.

Continuation of play in the fourth annual Bulldog handicap squash tennis tournament in the Yale Club yesterday sparkled when an entry from the home club, playing the third game of his career, eliminated Don F. Haggerty, a clubmate who was third seeded.

Herbert Sorkin, 26-year-old New York violinist, gave his first local recital last night at Town Hall. The three major works of his program were Hindemith's Sonata in E, Bach's D minor Partita for violin alone and Prokofieff's Concerto No. 1.
LONDON, Jan. 20--The British Government has agreed to proposals for a new Constitution giving Malta a greater degree of self government, it was announced today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20--Congress, with economies in mind, began today the task of scrustinizing in detail the $37,528,000,000 budget for the 1948 fiscal year recommended by President Truman.

TOKYO, Jan. 20--The Cabinet of Premier Shigeru Yoshida will hold its first general meeting today since last week's failure to form a National Government with the Socialist party. According to political circles a large-scale shakeup will probably be decided upon, to take effect by the week-end.

LONDON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Heads of two Of Britain's biggest banking chains, taking stock of their swollen deposits, questioned today the effect of such large reserves on the nation's economic health. Both complained that the British Government's cheap money campaign encouraged "prodigality" and inflated stock prices.

Czechoslovakia between two world wars was an island of liberal democracy in Central Europe. The Second World War really began when Hitler's troops occupied the country in March, 1939--or perhaps even when the great democratic Powers refused to come to her aid in the fall of 1938.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 20James E. Folsom was sworn, in today as the forty-sixth Governor of Alabama. The ceremony was marked by pageantry in which the old South and its modern aspirations were closely Interwoven.

INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 20 (AP)-- More money for tiie drivers and more speed to thrill the spectators attending the thirty-first annual 500-mile race at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway next May 30 were forecast today by Wilbur Shaw, the general manager.

The "hired man," surviving representative of an era in which Americans generally were neither workers nor employers as an industrial age defines them, is going to be allowed to continue in his own unclassified and individualistic way.

The State of New Mexico announced yesterday that it would accept bids until Feb. 5 on an issue of $1,000,000 of highway bonds bearing interest of not more than 3 per cent, dated Feb. 1, 1947, and due on each Feb. and Aug. 1 of 1957 and 1958.

Gaston Maurice Friedmann, 3year-old Jewish refugee war orphan has been made mascot of the Comtte 'Centrale 'Israelite boarding school at 50 Rue Gallait, Brussels, Belgium, because his American foster-father is Mayor O'Dwyer.

W. A. Patterson, president of United Airlines, announced yesterday that the company had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering plans for a new $49,500,000 financing program.

The Maritime Commission announced yesterday that it would redesign its standard C-3 type cargo ships for increased speed, carrying capacity and economical operation. The step is part of a plan to improve the competitive position of the American merchant marine in post-war international trade.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20--The Senate Armed Services Committee declined today to interfere with the proposed sale of the Big Inch and Little Big Inch pipelines. By a vote of 6 to 1, it decided to table the O'Mahoney-Revercomb resolution which would have postponed final decision for ninety days.
LITTLE AMERICA, Jan. 20-- The Navy Antarctic expedition's new Little America camp, High jump Base, is Beginning to take shape today in the outline of a tent city atop the Ross ice barrier.
As part of a program designed to cut expenses in all departments, the New York Central Railroad announced yesterday that it had laid off 7,000 maintenance-of-way employes.

A total of $564.35 was received yesterday from thirty-six contributors for the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund, increasing the total of the thirty-fifth annual appeal sponsored by the NEW YORK TIMES to $396,203.86. The number of donors now stands at 14,271.
LONDON, Jan. 20--News of the coal cuts to the steel industry, coupled with week-end ministerial speeches on production shortages, had the stock markets dull and unsettled today.
Cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange continued their downward course yesterday and closed 13 to 52 points net lower on the day, with the near months showing the greatest weakness.

Local citizens who were Their moved by sentiment or the New spirit of adventure to make Life the last trip on the last trolley car of the Fifty-ninth Street crosstown line or the Broadway and Forty-second Street line would have considerably prolonged their journey if they had remained in their seats for some time to come.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Jan. 20 -- Prof. Ragnar Frisch, Norwegian economist, was elected today chairman of the Economic and Employment Commission at its first session as a fully constituted organ of the Economic and Social Council.

The temperature rose higher here yesterday than it had on any Jan. 20 in the history of the local Weather Bureau. At 2 P. M. the thermometer reading already had equalled the record high of 56.8 degrees established in 1890, but the mercury continued to rise, setting a new record of 61.3 degrees at 3:45 P. M.

MOSCOW, Jan. 20-A. Sharov, chief of the City and Town Department of the Soviet Union's State Planning Commission, scathingly criticized in the newspaper Pravda today the work of various Ministries and emphasized the "close connection" between the worker's output and his living conditions. In the Soviet Union housing is divided among numerous Ministries, each dealing with a single industry.

LONDON, Jan. 20 -- Russian tactics have caused a change in the United States plans for discussions of the Austrian peace treaty, it was learned today. Instead of offering a complete treaty draft; as originally planned, the Americans will present their proposals section by section.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 20--Dr. Carson Chang, head of the Social Democratic party, has been expelled from the left wing Democratic League. The expulsion came as the result of a new league policy to reorganize on a basis of individual membership.

A two-year study of 313 textbooks used in elementary and secondary schools, and in introductory college courses throughout the country, and of courses of study in sixty schools, disclosed few instances of intentional bias toward any population group, Dr. Howard E. Wilson reported to a group of educators and publishers last night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- The Maritime Commission said today that Russia had bought two of the Navy's surplus ocean-tug auxiliaries for $265,000 each. The tugs were described at the Navy as noncombatant ships.

A dental "backlog" of aching teeth with 500,000,000 cavities makes national dental health insurance "impossible," dentists of New York State were told yesterday at the opening of a three-day "workshop" in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20--The American public is regarding the nation's foreign relations in a spirit of "greater realism" and not if isolation, Senator Hugh Butler, Republican, of Nebraska, said today. He criticized views expressed by Under Secretary of State William L. Clayton favoring extension of the reciprocal trade agreement proposal.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- "There isn't enough money in that bush league town of New York to buy Mickey Vernon."

Prospects are favorable that a new standard order form and uniform terms of purchase may be in use for the fall buying season, it was reported here yesterday. Questionnaires covering a tentative order form will be sent to member stores on Thursday by the National Retail Dry Goods Association, with replies requested by Feb. 8.

Concrete evidence that a buyers market In furniture has begun was manifested yesterday by the nature of buyer registration at the opening of the fifty-sixth annual New York winter market. Not only was the final figure for the day of 4,412 nearly 1,000 less than the record 5,200 last January but Jack Melniker, vice president of the New York Furniture Exchange, reported that the "overwhelming bulk" of retail representatives were from out-of-town.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 (AP)--Circuit Judge Harry M. Fisher today took under advisement arguments in a suit by George Mikan, former De Paul University star, to break his $60,000, five-year contract with the American Gears of the National Basketball League.

The Board of Higher Education approved last night the $15,393,938 budget for the fiscal year 1947-48 recommended by its finance and facilities committee, but added a provision whereby the salaries of teachers in the four city colleges might be increased.

Isidore Rappaport, 55 years old, one of the four defendants in the Mergenthaler Linotype Company swindle case, was freed last night in bail totaling $90,000. Of the sum, $5,000 was posted in Federal Court, Brooklyn, to bring about his release, pending trial, on a Federal indictment.

MONTREAL, Jan. 20--A case of a ski coach possessing more good material than he can use is being faced here at McGill University. Harold Pangman appears to have another intercollegiate championship array in the making.
LONDON, Jan. 20-The British Parliament reopens tomorrow with a heavy program of legislation that will keep it busy for the next six months.

MINDEN, Germany, Jan. 20--To compensate for the loss of the Saar steel output if that territory is attached economically to France, the British and United States occupation officials are expected to propose a 1,000,000-ton annual increase in the permitted capacity of industry in their zones.

Two rookie patrolmen, acting on a tip they had picked up in the neighborhood, walked into a Brooklyn dwelling at 11 o'clock last night and seized Anthony Abbandola, one of the nine convicts who escaped from the Brooklyn City Prison on Jan. 2. He was the third fugitive captured.

Children took the initiative yesterday in two events for the March of Dimes drive for S24,000,000 conducted by the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis. Nancy Drury, 4-year-old "polio poster girl" for the drive, met young fellow-victims of the disease at Knickerbocker Hospital, 70 Convent Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 President Truman nominated Maj. Gen. Ira T. Wyche to be Inspector General of the Army and Marvin. Jones to be Chief Justice of the United States Court of Claims his visitors included Herbert Rivers, 'Donald M. Nelson, delegates from the United States Conference of Mayors, Roy Howard and Dr.Vannftvar Bush with a group of eleven scientists.

Roland L. Redmond, a lawyer, was elected yesterday as president of the Metropolitan Museum of Art at the institution's seventyseventh annual meeting. He will take office on March 1, succeeding William Church Osborn, who has held the post in j 1941.

With a gibe at journalistic "trained seals" who write syndicated columns of opinion, Sevellon Brown, editor and publisher of The Providence Journal-Bulletin, called yesterday on the nation's press to build up individual editorial pages for the guidance of readers through the maze of the news.
ALBANY, Jan. 20-New York City asked- tonight to be given broader regulatory power over employment agencies.

NEWS of the transfer of Hank Greenberg from the Detroit Tigers to the Pittsburgh Pirates by means of the waiver route is just about as stunning and unexpected as stepping into an open manhole in the dark. It becomes all the more surprising in view of the fact that the seven other clubs in the American League could have used Hank's big bat.

LONDON, Jan. 20 -- Foreign Secretary Bevin will sign the peace treaties with Italy, Hungary, Bulgaria, Rumania and Finland at the British Foreign Office within the next few days, it was announced today. This means that he, like Secretary Byrnes, does not intend to go to Paris for the formal ceremonies on Feb. 10.

WARSAW, Tuesday, Jan. 21 -- The Polish Government announced early today that the Government bloc's candidates had won 327 of the 372 seats at stake in Sunday's elections. The victory far surpasses anything forecast before the voting.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 20 (AP)-- Grooms and exercise boys remained on strike at the Hialeah race course today, but the track enjoyed its biggest day of the 1947 meeting when 17,992 fans wagered $1,200,311--nearly $200,000 more than opening day Friday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Jan. 20 -- More than 1,000 staff employes of the United Nations met in closed session today and established a union in everything but name. The circumspect staff members of this diplomatic realm delicately entitled their new labor group the Association of the Staff of the United Nations.

ATLANTA, Jan. 20-Public sentiment, including that of church and educational forces, mounted heavily today on the side of_ the Thompson-Amall faction in opposition to Herman Talmadge as the rival claimants to Georgia's Governorship agreed to let the courts decide the constitutional question and to abide by that decision.

There are still skeptics who doubt that the United Nations will work. The immediate answer is that, in the sense in which the word is used by men the world around as they go to shops, offices and farmlands, U. N. is already working. The great controversies are on the surface of the news,, as they must and should be.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 -- When Gen. George C. Marshall takes the oath as Secretary of State in Washington at 11 A.M. tomorrow he will be taking it reluctantly, he intimated today. The general seemed sorry he was not going instead into private life.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Jan. 20 Hungary's frontiers have been sealed since Saturday to prevent the escape of members of an alleged conspiracy against the republic who are being arrested in ever-increasing1 numbers. Even couriers of the Hungarian Foreign Office are not being allowed to pass, Russian occupation authorities having suspended the issuance of clearances. Only foreigners are exempt.

Paula Stone and her husband, Michael Sloane, will present Bobby Clark in Victor Herbert's musical, "Sweethearts," tonight at the Shubert Theatre. The operetta, first produced here in 1913, is the week's only opening and is said to give free rein to Clark's antic personality.

HANOI, Indo-China, Jan. 19 (Delayed)--Today, one month after the Viet Nam Republic opened a full-scale rebellion with a surprise attack by night throughout Hanoi, calm has returned to this ravaged city. Contact between the opposing forces is confined to patrol brushes.

The Board of Education adopted yesterday the largest budget estimate in its history at a tense meeting that was marked by one memer's unprecedented criticism of the Superintendent of Schools and of the board itself.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 20 (AP)--The possibility of either a split in the National Collegiate Athletic Association or establishment of a "police bureau" to enforce the proposed new amateur code was foreseen today by Fritz Crisler, director of athletics and head football coach at the University of Michigan.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Chief of Staff, asserted today that in war, democracy, as it related to the individual, was not a consideration that would worry him in taking a tough objective.
MEXICO CITY, Jan. 20--Nearly 50,000 bullfight fans staged a riot of such unprecedented proportions in the world's greatest bull ring yesterday that it was described as the "battle of the century."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20--An old charge, once endorsed by President Truman, that the Roosevelt Administration delayed the nation's mobilization for war by a year to eighteen months by scrapping recommendations of the War Resources Board will be thoroughly aired by the Senate War Investigating Committee if the committee is continued by the scheduled vote Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 --The White House issued rain checks today to the swearing-in of the new Secretary of State. The retiring foreign policy spokesman, James F. Byrnes, postponed his departure for Spartanburg, S.C., for twenty-four hours.

Plans for a new bank building at 243-47 First Avenue, for the Union Square Savings Bank of 20 Union Square were filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings by Voorhees, Walker, Foley Smith, architects. The estimated cost is $175,000.

PARIS, Jan. 20-Having com pleted his consultations, Socialist Paul Ramadier decided tonight tc gp before the National Assembly tomorrow as. French. Premier-designate ignate and present the program of the Government he intends to form. His program Will be defined as the completion of the economic experiment initiated by Leon Blum, but the composition of the'Cabinet M. Ramadier Will form, if endorsed by the Assembly, depends on lastminute action by the Popular Republican party [MRP].

Color combinations to harmonize with the shades of next summer's dresses highlight a new group of wrought iron and aluminum furniture shown yesterday by Molla, Inc., at the Hotel McAlpin. Bright chartreuse upholstery with dusty pink metal frames and tawny orange fabric with white are used for traditional wrought-iron tables, chairs and chaises and on heavier, more ornate pieces of cast aluminum.

The trial of Serge M. Rubinstein, 37-year-old former president of the Panhandle Producing and Refining Company, hit an unexpected snag yesterday just when it seemed that the Government finally was to have an opportunity to prove its draft-evasion charges against him.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Jan. 20 -- Diplomats who attended the first meeting of the Economic and Employment Commission here today startled United Nations visitors by displaying portable radios suspended from their necks and using wireless in the established G.I. style of walkie-talkie -- without the talkie.

HARTFORD, Jan. 20--Sounnd cultural and commercial relationsnips between the United States and the nations of Latin America must replace the "wartime brotherhood of nations" if the cause of the community of American nations is to advance, Arnold Tschudy, exeeutive vice president of the Council for Inter-American Cooperation, Inc.. told the annual meeting here tonight of the Connecticut Development Commission.
ATLANTA, Jan. 20 (AP)--Swollen by nearly three weeks of almost steady rain, streams throughout the South surged from their banks today, flooding lowlands and driving many families from their homes.

LONDON, Jan. 20--Word that the Palestinian Arabs, coming here to attend the resumed conference on Palestine, would not reach London before Thursday prompted Foreign and Colonial Office officials to postpone the opening until next Monday, it was learned today.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 20--W. Averell Harriman, Secretary of Commerce, tonight called for the breaking down of barriers to international trade on the part of our Government as well as other countries, and declared that the promotion of imports to this country was necessary to the success of any foreign economic program.
TOKYO, Jan. 21--If Japan hopes to implement her new educational policies she will have to recruit and train more than 150,000 school teachers.

DETROIT, Wednesday, Jan. 22-- The likelihood existed here early today that the 269-day-old strike at the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company would be settled this morning at a meeting of the toppolicy committee of the United Automobile Workers, Congress of Industrial Organizations, which has been called by Walter P. Reuther, international president.

The Canadian freighter Tecumseh Park, reportedly in danger of sinking last week in a North Atlantic storm, showed no signs of breaking up when the Army transport Gen. M.L. Hersey reached her last Wednesday, William Bevens Jr., third mate of the transport, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21--President Truman has invited Herbert Hoover to make a study of food and related economic problems in the American and British zones of occupied Germany. He will discuss the proposal with the former Republican President at a White House conference tomorrow.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: We have been much interested in recent letters appearing in your paper concerning the crime radio serials written for children. In moving about the country with my husband, a major in the Army, I have heard everywhere great resentment expressed against these programs, not only by the conservative but also by the young and socalled "modern" parents.

The Public National Bank and Trust Company of New York operated at peak levels during 1946, E. Chester Gersten, president, reported yesterday at the bank's annual stockholders' meeting. Deposits, loans and foreign department transactions, he said, all reached record figures, and the facilities of the bank were used to a greater extent than in any previous annual period of its thirtynine years of existence.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP)-- The Office of International Trade today removed all controls over export of new motor trucks, buses and bus-chassis and eased the restrictions on automobiles. Officials told a reporter that manufacturers have shown no disposition to press for export sales at the expense of the American market.

Reflecting continued growth of cotton consumption and mill pricefixing and a stronger technical situation, the futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned upward yesterday and closed 28 to 51 points net higher.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: My attention has just been called to a letter in your issue of Jan. 15 from William J. Cheyney, executive director of the Retail Credit Institute of America, attacking my views on control of consumer credit and quoting what are "said to be" my exact words.

LONDON, Jan. 21--United States Zionists are ready to pour "millions" of dollars into the financing of "illegal" immigration of Jews to Palestine, Dr. Emanuel Neumann, vice president of the Zionist Organization of America, said here today.

BERLIN, Jan. 21--According to secret reports by American members of the four-power inspection teams, the French are laggard in destroying German war plants in their zone, it was learned today. The British are said to be slow, the Americans on schedule and the Russians doing "a first-class job."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21--The State Department has refused the request of the Soviet Embassy to deliver Kirill Alekseev, formerly an employe of the Soviet trade representative in Mexico, to Russian authorities as a criminal, the department announced today.

Final details of the bare-boat charter of two V4-M-A1 tugs from the Maritime Commission to haul two big dredges to the Netherlands Indies are now being worked out, officials of the Moran Towing and Transportation Company, Inc., 17 Battery Place, reported yesterday.

The Republican enrollment in New York City climbed almost to Presidential year totals last fall, the Board of Elections revealed yesterday in giving out the figures on how voters declared their party intentions during the 1946 registration period.

BERLIN, Jan. 21--Abolition of the Trading With the Enemy Act so far as Germany is concerned was advocated publicly today by Gen. Joseph T. McNarney, retiring United States Military Governor, who said he had so recommended to Washington.

Because of "myths and resistances" in health education, people often do their best to undermine their health and allow themselves to be ruled by cults, fads and phobias, Dr. Lawrence S. Kubie, psychiatrist, declared yesterday.

HANOI, Indo-China, Jan. 21-- Negotiations with the rebel Viet Namese Government can be taken up only "when the military solution has been advanced," an official who ranks high in the French Commissariat here, but whose name cannot be used, said today.

Butter prices dropped another 2 cents a pound in the local wholesale market yesterday, with the result that today's price in most chain stores and some independent shops will be 65 cents a pound. A further decline was indicated, and much butter remained unsold at the close of the day's trading at the New York Mercantile Exchange.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Jan. 21-- Belgium's claims against Germany in form of raw materials and her conception of a future federated Germany were made public today by Foreign Minister Paul - Henri Spaak. He took occasion to express strong disapproval of the methods apparently to be adopted in London and later at Moscow where small nations are concerned.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21--Senator Kenneth D. McKellar of Tennessee intimated before the Senate Public Works Committee today that three high officials of the Tennessee Valley Authority were Communists. He named J.C. Swidler, general counsel; Arthur Jandrey, assistant general manager, and E.B. Schuttz, director of labor relations, as well as James T. Ramey, a former member of its legal staff.

CHICAGO, Jan. 21--Announcement that the Commodity Credit Corporation had withdrawn all bids for cash wheat but would refer any offerings to Washington for acceptance or rejection led today to general selling of wheat futures on the Board of Trade.

Besides "Temper the Wind," another Broadway closing looms at the end of this week. The latest ality is "The Big Two," which will bid farewell to the Booth after the twenty-first performance. In ssing, let it be noted both plays such upon our foreign relations-- Temper the Wind" with the American-occupied zone in Germany; "The Big Two" with the S.S.R.

CHICAGO, Jan. 21--The list of approved hospitals in the United States and Canada was made public today by the American College of Surgeons. Following are the approved hospitals in New York City, Long Island and Westchester County, an asterisk denoting provisional approval.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- A United States "take all" policy for an estimated 1,500,000 ton increase in 1946 Cuban sugar was indicated at hearings today by the new food investigation subcommittee of the House Committee on Agriculture. The State Department has urged a sharing of the increase with other countries.

LITTLE AMERICA, Jan. 21--A young sailor from the attack cargo ship Yancey became the first American to die in Little America today when he apparently was thrown into the spinning track of one of the vehicles on the ice. He probably was killed instantly by a blow on the head.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21--The impending first voting test of the new Senate Republican leadership under fire, scheduled for 2 P.M. tomorrow, had both sides working hard while keeping fingers crossed tonight. From Republicans and Democrats alike the prediction was that "it might well go either way."

CHICAGO, Jan. 21 (AP)--The National Football League will get a full report from Commissioner Bert Bell on the attempted fix of its 1946 championship game when the ten-member circuit tackles next season's schedule-making tomorrow through Saturday.

Stand on a rocky promontory that juts into the sea--where the jagged, tumbled granite boulders reach to the waterline at low tide. Whether bright day or gray, the mood of the ocean in winter is predominantly the same. That mood tells man of the unfathomable power of the ocean.

According to a letter just received from Bill Sharpe, publicist and noted collector of "Tar-Heelana," the bears are causing more trouble in North Carolina than anything that has happened since Zebulon Vance found a Republican in the State House.

The causes of prejudice and intolerance were traced to the home and to educational institutions yesterday by adults and youths who participated in a joint program sponsored by the Bureau for Intercultural Education at Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street.

Hearings on plans for the development of Idlewild Airport and the improvement of La Guardia Field will open next Wednesday morning in City Hall before the special committee of city offiicals, under the chairmanship of Robert Moses, construction coordinator, appointed by Mayor O'Dwyer to recommend a settlement of the controversy.

The Committee for Economic Development has adopted a new statement of principles reaffirming its adherence to the free enterprise system as a "flag" of its Americanism, it was learned yesterday, because of recent attacks from ultra-conservative business sources against its moderate viewpoint on labor, fiscal and other economic issues.

All textile items sold by pu veyors who supply the laundries hotel and transportation trades an in relatively free supply with the exception of sheets and pille cases, table-cloths and napkin Maurice S. Hymans, president the Institutional and Service Textile Distributors Association, said yesterday.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 21 -- Chang Ah-ni, a sharp-featured rickshaw boy who goes after trade in front of the Cathay Hotel, ordinarily calls it a day after midnight. Tonight he picked up his shafts and trotted off light-heartedly several hours ahead of schedule.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 21--A new approach to the problem of how to enforce the proposed system of international atomic control is under consideration by the United States. The plan, it is understood, has the approval in principle of Bernard M. Baruch, who resigned early in January as United States member of the Atomic Energy Commission, as well as of John Foster Dulles and other Republican experts on foreign policy.

The six-story twenty-four-family apartment house at 232 East Fortieth Street has been sold by David S. Meister, after a short ownership, to an investing client of S.S. Goldsmith, attorney. The property, assessed at $110,000, occupies a plot 40 by 98.3 feet in the block between Second and Third Avenues.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 21--The Convention of the Mississippi Valley Association today went on record unanimously urging Congress to "proceed at once with appropriations" for various flood control, navigation, irrigation, soil conservation and related projects for the twenty - three - State Mississippi basin, as approved by the Army Corps of Engineers and the Interior Department Bureau of Reclamation, and which are "economically justified."

The Board of Education of Union Free School District No. 7 of the Town of North Hempstead has purchased from Louise U. Eldridge approximately seven acres of vacant land on Hawthorne Lane and Bayview Avenue in the village of Saddle Rock, North Hempstead, L.I. Alfred T. Davidson, attorney, represented the seller and Bleakley, Pratt Walker acted for the purchaser.

David Drechsler, general counsel to the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the United States for the last twenty-three years, was honored last night by 1,200 members of the industry at a testimonial dinner in the Hotel Commodore.

Post-war problems of veterans and their families have created a new need for planned parenthood information, Dr. Abraham Stone, a vice president of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America, declared yesterday. He spoke at the opening of the federation's two-day twenty-sixth annual meeting in the Hotel Roosevelt.

LONDON, Jan. 21--A record profit for 1946 of L9,148,357 (about $36,593,428) was announced here today by F.W. Woolworth Co. This figure shows an increase of nearly L1,900,000 on the 1945 profit and tops the previous record of L8,471,291 established in 1940.

D. Parry Forst, president of the Robertson Manufacturing Company, Trenton, N.J., has been elected chairman of the Tile Council of America. A.R. McMannis, sales manager of the United States Quarry Tile Company, Canton, has been named to the newly created post of vice chairman.

ATLANTA, Jan. 21--Herman Talmadge, speaking as "Governor" before a joint session of the Georgia General Assembly, challenged today M.E. Thompson, rival claimant to the Governorship, to resign with him and "let the white people of Georgia determine their choice" in a Democratic white primary.

The persistent fight by Alfred Reeves, advisory vice president of the Automobile Manufacturers Association and manager of the annual automobile show, for improved parcel-checking facilities in Grand Central Terminal bore results yesterday.

WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 21-- Transcontinental Western Air, Inc., will ask the Civil Aeronautics Administration to permit its pilots to make precision instrument landing approaches at its terminals. They would use war-developed landing aids.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 21 (AP)-- Blazin' Bob Feller signed a oneyear contract with the Indians today, stipulating the fireball strikeout king would receive $? ?,000 for his 1947 mound chores.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 21 --Acting on a motion presented by the United States, the United Nations Economic and Employment Commission set aside today its plans for a study of the industrial uses of atomic energy.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (U.P.)-- Secretary of the Navy Forrestal gave a complete inventory tonight of the ships, planes and men on active duty in the Navy on Dec. 31, 1946.

MERIDEN, Conn., Jan. 21-- With production schedules of 1847 Rogers Bros. silverware this year more than double those of 1941, the best pre-war year, the International Silver Company will utilize in 1947 the "largest advertising appropriation in silverware history," it was announced today by Craig Munson, vice president of the company.

All plans for national passenger car and commercial vehicle shows in England this year have been cancelled by the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders, the British organization that sponsors these exhibitions, it was learned yesterday.

DETROIT, Jan. 21--Price increases on luxury models in four lines and an across-the-board increase in the Pontiac eight-cylinder class have been ordered by several divisions of the General Motors Corporation.

The American Committee for Protection of the Foreign Born announced yesterday that it had singled out a test case to fight Government deportation proceedings against more than 100 aliens for past or present membership in the Communist party.

Viking Press will publish next month Lillian Hellman's current Broadway hit, "Another Part of the Forest." A thought cherished by that concern is "that some day we can talk her into putting her Hubbard family into a novel for us."
LONDON, Jan. 21 -- The warning contained in the Government's White Paper on Britain's serious economic position brought about a sharp reaction in the stock markets today.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 21--Alfred E. Driscoll became New Jersey's forty-sixth Governor today. In his inaugural message he called for prompt revision of the State's century-old Constitution and new principles of collective bargaining to encourage labor-management peace.

Reduction of the national debt and balancing the Federal budget should be undertaken now when national income at the rate of $170,000,000,000 annually provides the means, Alben W. Barkley, Senate minority leader, declared yesterday.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 21 (AP) -- Blacksmiths "went fishing" today while a crowd of 16,077 at Hialeah Park braved a threat of rain to see Mrs. E.D. Jacob's Stan Tracy win the mile and a sixteenth Grade D $4,000 Featherbeds purse, first turf course feature of the young meeting.

BOSTON, Jan. 21 (U.P.)--The Holy Cross Crusaders, taking advantage of their opponents' poor markmanship from the foul line, defeated Manhattan College, 58 to 49, tonight before about 10,000 fans in the first game of a basketball double-header at Boston Garden.

The Lincoln Management Corporation sold the four-story building accommodating sixteen families at 171 Van Buren Street, in Brooklyn, to Jacob Abramsky through the Dansker Realty and Securities Corporation, broker. The property is assessed at $47,000.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial on "Georgia's Two Governors" was distressingly confusing. To one who is very concerned about democracy in the South your call for Governor Arnall to withdraw from the struggle seems to be even worse than a counsel of defeatism.
A comprehensive program for the maintenance of industrial peace in Brooklyn, will be opened Feb. 1 by the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce, Milton Dammann, president, announced yesterday.

The need for additional recreational and social facilities for students at City College was emphasized yesterday by Mrs. Herman L. Weisman, chairman of the Women's Division of the City College Centennial Fund. In the campaign to raise $1,500,000, the women's goal will be $250,000 to build a war memorial student center.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (U.P.)-- The Government tightened safety rules for non-scheduled air carriers today as a result of a study of recent air accidents.
