By keeping 500,000 German prisoners of war in "slave labor camps" and forcing most of them to work in the mines, the French Government is "breeding, the next war," Clarence E. Pickett, exeeutive secretary of the American Friends Service Committee, declared here yesterday.

Col. Larry MacPhail held his "final" press conference at the New York Yankees' Fifth Avenue offices yesterday and, in addition to revealing that thirty-three players now are under contract, announced a new executive set-up.

DETROIT, Jan. 21--Christianity, fighting for preservation, is locked in crucial battle with communism in central Europe, it was asserted today by the Rev. Dr. Rees Edgar Tulloss, president of the National Lutheran Council, in the opening session of the twentyninth annual meeting.

Buyers' Arrivals Continue Heavy Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 2,174, against 3,565 in the previous week and 2,162 in the corresponding week of 1946, according to the listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES.
Two issues of school district bonds of Los Angeles County, Calif., aggregating $1,278,000, were awarded yesterday to bidding syndicates and were immediately reoffered.

The New York Zoological Society announced a gift of $2,500,000, the largest in its history, at the fifty-first annual meeting of the membership in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel last night. Fairfield Osborn, president, also announced that the society had received other cash gifts and pledges in 1946 totaling $282,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Gen. George C. Marshall said today, before he was sworn in as Secretary of State, that he "never could be drafted" for political office. He added that he could never "be considered as a candidate" for the same type of office.

A retrospective and comprehensive exhibition of ballet and costume designs by Eugene Berman opens at the Museum of Modern Art today and will continue through March 9. More than a hundred gouaches and drawings have been assembled, together with several stage models.

A strong France is the best insurance that "American boys will no longer be sent across the Atlantic," Mayor Georges Pierre Lavalley of St. Lo, France, told 100 guests of American Aid to France at a reception in his honor yesterday at the Hotel St. Regis, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street.

Fleet Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Chief of Naval Operations, expressed the belief last night that wars are not inevitable because the United Nations "offers us the greatest chance we have ever had to avert them."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The Soviet Government will permit foreign correspondents at the peace conference beginning March 10 in Moscow "to write with complete freedom on conference matters," but does not yet know how many correspondents will be permitted in Moscow, the State Department said today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21--President Truman called upon Congress today to extend from March 1 to July 1 the date by which Government operation of merchant ships must be ended.

TOKYO, Jan. 21--With the sole exception of raw silk, the demand for Japanese goods gives promise of outrunning any supply available during the current year, according to occupation experts concerned with this problem. Industrial depressions limited staple goods exports.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 21-- RKO today announced the abandonment of plans to produce "Tycoon" in Mexico City and disclosed that the picture will go before the cameras in Hollywood Thursday with Richard Wallace directing and John Wayne and Laraine Day heading the cast.

The Appellate Division unanimously reversed yesterday a decision of Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy that reduced from $250,000 to $40,000 each the bail for Joey Rao and Michael (Trigger Mike) Coppola. They are being held as material witnesses in the investigation of the fatal beating of Joseph Scottoriggio, Republican district captain in the Eighteenth Congressional District, last election day.

The compelling pressure of economic events has forced the British Government to place major emphasis upon increasing output. According to a dispatch yesterday from London, increasing productivity has replaced full employment as the "Number One objective" of British economic policy.

Acting Detective Lieutenant William J. Grafenecker, who was one of Thomas E. Dewey's principal aides in his rackets investigation, caused a stir in the Police Department yesterday by applying to Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander for retirement, only to withdraw the application a few hours later on the urging of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan.

Reflecting record sales in 1946, net earnings of the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company last year increased to $27,972,599 after taxes and all charges from $19,229,310 earned in 1945, the annual report of J.W. Glenn, president, disclosed yesterday.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 21 (AP) --Communist party candidates, some of whom had taken an early lead on the basis of first scattered returns from Sunday's State and local elections, began to drop behind tonight as additional figures trickled into the capital from the interior.

President Truman, Mayor O'Dwyer and many other civil and military leaders will be invited to join in a program to promote public interest in national security, it was announced yesterday by a special committee of the Reserve Officers Association of the United States.

Precision Bidding The Omaha civic leaders who campaigned through the war years for municipal adoption of the Nebraska Power Company saw the project successfully through the permanent financing stage yesterday in the sale of $42,000,000 of serial and term bonds running to 1977 at an interest cost of 1.98 per cent.

The stock market backed down further yesterday with fractional losses the rule as interest dwindled to the smallest in five months. The restraint in trading was general throughout the session and only in a few cases did the turnover in individual issues reach major proportions.

The French in Indo-China have launched a drive by land, sea and air to wrest the important city of Hue from the Viet Nam insurrectionists. If it is successful, General Leclerc's forces would control both Hanoi, capital of Tongking, and Hue, capital of Annam, the two districts constitute the Viet Nam Republic.

Eugene Ormandy returned with the Philadelphia Orchestra last night to Carnegie Hall. The shimmering orchestra, with its splendid virtuosity, and the program, one of uncommon interest, testified to his skill in rehearsal and arrangement.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21--It is customary in Washington to treat most potential Presidential candidates with polite, and sometimes impolite, skepticism. When they protest their lack of ambition for the nomination, reporters look for the "positively."

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 21 -- A registration statement relating to voting trust certificates for 4,750,000 shares of $1 par value common stock of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation of Willow Run, Mich., was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The Appellate Division annulled yesterday the State Liquor Authority order canceling the license of the Longchamps restaurant chain for violations of the Alcoholic Beverage Control Law. By a vote of 3 to 2 the court remitted the case to the SLA for further testimony on the restaurant's contention that it was "a common practice" to serve liquor on credit as part of a meal.
Three educators testified here yesterday in the Supreme Court that private schools had outlived their usefulness as places for experiments in new educational ideas.

Bond issues totaling $55,000,000 of two public utility enterprises-- one publicly owned, the other privately owned--were awarded at competitive sale yesterday to investment banking syndicates headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.
Authorities investigating the Jan. 2 escape of nine prisoners from Brooklyn's City Prison last night were sifting a report that $1,000 was distributed inside the jail to insure the delivery.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 21 (AP)-- Laraine Day, screen actress, and Leo Durocher, manager of the Brooklyn Dodgers, returned here by airplane late today after she had obtained a divorce in Juarez Mexico, and later were married in El Paso, Texas.

LONDON, Jan. 21--Statistics issued today show that British exports in 1946 nearly doubled in value those of the basic pre-war year of 1938. However, the volume of exports was almost exactly the same as in 1938 and even more serious is the fact that the trend of exports rose little if at all after the middle of the year.

The Gnilbe Corporation, part of the Ebling estate, sold for all cash the gasoline service station and diner on a plot about 100 by 112 feet at the southwest corner of Bruckner Boulevard and East Tremont Avenue, the Bronx, to an investing client of the James H. Burns Company, broker.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21--A final audit showing a shortage of $125,563.73 in the House Sergeantat-arms office was turned over to the Attorney General for action today by Speaker Martin.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- By different philosophical approaches, Charles E. Wilson, president of General Motors Corporation, and William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, arrived at the conclusion today that the labor situation could lead to state socialism.

WARSAW, Jan. 21--Only a few hours after the sweeping election victory was announced to the nation, leaders of Poland's Left-Wing Bloc began consultations today on the formation of a new government. Unquestionably it will again be led by Boleslaw Bierut as President.

Nineteen points behind at one stage, the St. John's University basketball team scrapped all plans for fast-breaks, switched to a deliberate, painstaking attack and before long had the Hilltoppers of Western Kentucky reeling, ripe for a knockout at Madison Square Garden last night.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 21 (AP)-- The Los Angeles Rams of the National Professional Football League and General Manager Charles F. (Chile) Walsh came to a parting of the ways today.

DALLAS, Tex., Jan. 21--A 100 per cent Dallas showing took place last night in the ballroom of the Adolphus Hotel with the presentation of the March of Dimes fashion show, held under the auspices of the Dallas fashion group.

Tony Zale, world middleweight champion, will be honored tonight as the outstanding boxer of 1946. Promoter Mike Jacobs of the Twentieth Century S.C., will be rewarded for long and meritorious service to boxing. Ray Robinson, world welterweight titleholder, will receive a belt emblematic of the championship he acquired when he conquered Tommy Bell, Columbus, Ohio, challenger.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 21--Subject to modification in certain minor particulars, the Securities and Exchange Commission approved today the amended recapitalization plan of the Interstate Power Company of Dubuque, Iowa, a subsidiary of the Ogden Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP)-- Opposition developed in the railroad industry today to pending legislation to exempt rail and other carriers from anti-trust prosecution for making agreements on rates and fares. It came from Robert R. Young, chairman of the board of the Chesapeake Ohio and capped strong-spoken criticism of the measure by officials of the Department of Justice.

MOSCOW, Jan. 21--Agriculture will be the most important part of Soviet economy in 1947. For the nation, now striding ahead in the field of industrial rehabilitation and expansion, suffered in 1946 from the worst drought in fifty years and a good harvest this year is essential to further progress in the general economy.

CHICAGO, Jan. 21--For the first time since 1918, when the American College of Surgeons began listing hospitals which meet its requirements as a move toward hospital standardization, there is a decline in the number of hospitals on its approved list, compared with the preceding year, Dr. Irvin Abell of Louisville, president and chairman of the board of regents of the organization, said today.

Mayor O'Dwyer complimented Dr. William Jansen as a diplomatic city official yesterday as he swore the Assistant Superintendent of Schools into his new post as Superintendent of Schools to succeed John E. Wade.

Negotiations preliminary to a proposed merger of Froedtert Grain Malting Company of Milwaukee and Rockwood Co. of Brooklyn, chocolate manufacturers, were disclosed yesterday by Kurtis R. Froedtert, president and chairman of the board of the Froedtert Company, and H. Russell Burbank, Rockwood's president.

DHAHRAN, Saudi Arabia, Jan. 21--While his eldest son is touring the United States, King Ibn Saud came here today to take a look at a bit of America within the borders of his kingdom, the booming oil towns along Saudi Arabia's east coast.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Jan. 21-- Thirty-three persons were injured tonight after a section of the spectator stands of the Jersey City Gardens, Franklin and Ogden Avenues, collapsed at the end of a boxing program. At least 200 persons fell to the floor of the arena.

Chief among Victor Herbert's "Sweethearts," put on at the Shubert last evening, is Bobby Clark, who has been a sweetheart for quite a long time. Since Herbert's sweethearts are pretty languid for a cold night in 1947, it is a fortunate thing that Mr. Clark, the illustrious clown, has decided to pay as little attention as possible to the music, the plot and the scenery.

Children today have lost their fear of dentists, Dr. C. Clyde Stevens, supervising dentist for the Children's Aid Society, declared yesterday at its James Center, 154 Hester Street. On the eve of celebrating the society's anniversary today of the establishment of the first free school dental clinic forty years ago in its now defunct West Fifty-third Street Industrial School, Dr. Stevens filled the 300,000th tooth for the society.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21--A national policy of fostering civil air transportation as an essential for the country's defense was urged tonight by C.R. Smith, chairman of the Board of the American Airlines.

MARTIN SHERIDAN was not quite as impressed as he should have been. The huge field-event performer from the Irish-American A.C. was standing in the bow of the S.S. Barbarossa, which was taking the American Olympic team to Athens for the big international show of 1906. The boat was not far from Naples and the athletes were watching the wild waves stirring restlessly on the turbulent ocean.

A survey, of Italy under the pruning knife naturally leads to Trieste, pivotal point not merely of the Italian treaty but of the reorientation of southeastern Europe. Trieste today is a city of high winds and low whispers, a city shivering as it waits to become the subject of the first experiment in United Nations administration.

An auction Of five parcels of real estate held in reserve by the Longchamps organization was held yesterday at the Commodore Hotel by Stephen A. McDonald, vice president of Joseph P. Day, Inc. None of the properties offered is occupied by any of the Longchamps restaurants.

Detroit Edison Directors of the Detroit Edison Company announced yesterday that applications would be made to the Michigan Public Service Commission and the Securities and Exchange Commission for permission to pay a 10 per cent stock dividend.

ROME, Jan. 21--The Provisional President of the Italian Republic, Enrico de Nicola, today began consultations with principal political figures with a view to solving the present Cabinet crisis. This was precipitated yesterday by the resignation of Premier Alcide de Gasperi.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 21-- In an attempt to ease the housing shortage here, the Greenwich Representative Town Meeting, legislative body of this place, approved unanimously tonight appropriations totaling $340,000 to purchase thirty-three acres and construct forty homes as temporary shelter for veterans.

The National Association for American Composers and Conductors presented one first performmance and two New York firsts at its concert last night at Times hall. The world premiere was of Joseph Wood's Sonata for violin and piano, played by Harold Kohon and Leon Kushner, respectively.

Voluntary health insurance along with legislation to provide better food, housing and clothing for the underprivileged is the "American way" of answering the proponents of compulsory health insurance, Dr. Abraham Koplowitz declared last night in an inaugural address as president for 1947 of the Medical Society of the County of Kings.

PARIS, Jan. 21--French efforts to clear an area about Hanoi and end the Viet Namese military threat to the Tongkingese capital gained at several points today. Several prongs of a drive into the western area reached as far as ten miles from the city while other troops were said to have grained control over the entire circular road surrounding Hanoi at a radius of about three miles from its center, official and semi-official dispatches reported.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The appointment of General Marshall as Secretary of State has caused considerable comment on the danger inherent in having a military man guiding a democratic nation in its foreign affairs, particularly in a post-war period when the immediate objective is the establishment of permanent world peace.

Saudi Arabia has spiritual values to offer Americans which far transcend the importance of her oil, Dr. Ralph C. Hutchison declared yesterday. The president of Lafayette College was the princiipal speaker at a luncheon given by Thomas L. Watson, president of International Business Machines Corporation, at the Union Club, Sixty-ninth Street and Park Avenue, to honor the Emir Saud, heirapparent to the Arabian throne.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21--American foreign policy requires that this country adopt "a broadly conceived economic policy, both domestic and foreign," the Committee on International Policy of the National Planning Association stated here today in a report on "Goals of Bipartisan Foreign Policy."
LONDON, Jan. 21--The war of attrition over the control of "German" assets in Austria is not expected to be settled during the current meeting of the Foreign Ministers" deputies.

The Very Rev. Dr. Claude W. Sprouse, dean of Grace and Holy Trinity Cathedral, Kansas City, Mo., will be nominated to succeed the Right Rev., William T. Manning, now retired, as Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of New York next Tuesday at a special conven tion in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

The New York Knickerbockers hope to end a losing streak of three straight games tonight at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory when they meet the Chicago Stags, and perhaps have the law of averages with them, as the Stags have defeated them in two of three meetings.

A special gifts committee to assist in obtaining $3,000,000 for a new Law Center at New York University was organized last night at a dinner meeting of lawyers, bankers and industrialists at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel. Former Governor Herbert H. Lehman was named chairman.

ALBANY, Jan. 21--The emergency teachers pay bill received the unanimous approval of the Assembly today after liberalizing, Democratic amendments were defeated by a vote of 99 to 45. Passed by the Senate last night, the measure goes to Governor Dewey for his signature.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21--The Army and Navy are continuing their pre-war practice of engaging in heavy buying each June, the final month of the Federal fiscal year, so as to obligate themselves for appropriated funds that otherwise would revert to the Federal treasury, investigation revealed today.

Aided by notables of stage, screen and radio, the New York Dress Institute opened its third annual March of Dimes fashion showing yesterday at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel for the benefit of the Greater New York Chapter of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 21--Four participants in a radio forum agreed here today that in consumer goods industries voluntary programs of stabilized employment would benefit labor, industry and the nation as a whole.

LONDON, Jan. 21--Whether there must be a German Government to sign a peace treaty was a main topic discussed today by the deputies of the Big Four Foreign Ministers. Robert D. Murphy of the United States gave a long exposition of his informal ideas on the subject, putting forward the possibility of drafting an international statute rather than a peace treaty.

MOSCOW, Jan. 21--An underground Nazi movement is growing in strength throughout western Germany and even has entered Berlin, aided by the negligence of the United States and British occupation authorities, who are charged with protecting Nazis in industry and utilities.

Mainly About Housing Most often when people bring up the price paid for Manhattan Island it is to imply that the Dutch purchasers rather took advantage of the original owners. To be sure, there are times when New York's littered streets or the record of New York district politics will bring forth the opposite opinion that Peter Minuit was stung when he gave $24 for Manhattan.

MOSCOW, Jan. 21--An underground Nazi movement is growing in strength throughout western Germany and even has entered Berlin, aided by the negligence of the United States and British occupation authorities, who are charged with protecting Nazis in industry and utilities.

Kirsten Flagstad, Norwegian soprano, who has been in Norway since April, 1941, will return to this country next month for a concert tour in the west, George Engles, president of Consolidated Concerts Corporation, announced yesterday.
LODI, Calif., Jan. 21--Alice Dean Devine, 16, a Lodi high school senior, was returned home unharmed tonight, more than twenty-four hours after she was reputedly kidnapped and held for $10,000 ransom.
CHICAGO, Jan. 21 (U.P.)--Buddy Young, Illinois star halfback, announced today he was quitting school, but he denied any immediate plans to join a professional football organization.

By unanimous vote, the City Council approved a resolution introduced by the Democratic majority yesterday asking the Legislature to approve a $450 annual salary increase for teachers instead of the $300 passed by both houses of the Legislature.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21--A delegation of the American Jewish Labor Council, recently returned from a European trip, asserted today that the people of Poland enjoy all the freedoms of democracy regardless of the political opinions they hold.

SHORTLY after the completion of Gordon Ray's monumental edition of Thackeray's letters in its four majestic volumes, the first of three projected Thackeray biographies, including one by Mr. Ray, is published. It is "The Showman of Vanity Fair"* by Lionel Stevenson, a Professor of English at the University of Southern California. A lively, able, readable biography it is, too, but scarcely an inspired one.

PARIS, Wednesday, Jan. 22-- Paul Ramadier as Premier-designate received an overwhelming vote of confidence in a session of the National Assembly yesterday that was characterized by the urgent appeals of leaders for unity in supporting a Government dedicated to national, as opposed to party, interests.

LONDON, Jan. 21--The collision between the liner Queen Mary and her British Navy escort, the cruiser Curacoa, in October, 1942, was caused solely by the negligence of the cruiser, the Admiralty Division of the High Court of Justice found today.

ALBANY, Jan. 21--Recurrent criticism of the functioning of the state Division of Veterans' Affairs me to a head today with introduction of a Democratic bill seeking an investigation of the agency, eady the subject of one inquiry dered by Governor Dewey.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21--Congress was told today that its own action in withholding firm rulemaking power from the Wage-Hour Administration had opened the way for the vast portal-to-portal back pay claims now piling up against industry and the Government alike.

TOKYO, Jan. 21--Faced with a threatened general walkout of more than 800,000 Government employes on Feb. 1, the Cabinet of Premier Shigeru Yoshida today made two moves. The first was designed to adjust some of labor's demands.

If there is a youth in your family who plays on the high school basketball team or a young girl who devotes her after-school hours to clerking in a store, their diet needs as close attention as that of much younger children. Although we are apt to group teenagers with their elders when planning meals for the family, these youngsters actually need a larger amount of body-building and energygiving foods than adults do.

There will be no pussyfooting in the big mile races this winter. Gil Dodds has thrown his hat back into the ring. This leaves the footracing "cuties" who gamble on their finishing kicks in jog-trotting scrambles for position out in left field.
The Old Flash, The Meal Ticket, Black Mike and Ol' Mose finally made the Baseball Hall of Fame.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art will be seventy-five years old next month, and for more than half of its lifetime William Church Osborn has taken an active part in its affairs. Mr. Osborn is now retiring as president of the museum after nearly six years in office.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The State Department emphasized today the concern of the United States Government over "the activities of dissident Korean Groups." It said that these actions cannot but militate against the efforts of those Koreans who are earnestly desirous of attaining a united and independent government for their country."

There are no way stops on the schedule for Rune Gustafsson and Haakan Lidman. In their first tests this week-end, the Swedish track athletes run smack into America's best. Both are booked to compete in The Philadelphia Inquirer Games at Convention Hall tomorrow night and the revived Massachusetts Knights of Columbus meet at the Boston Garden Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Clinton P. Anderson acted tonight to place the nation's commodity futures markets under close governmental surveillance because of a growing volume of trading. He announced that the Commodity Exchange Authority, which is charged with policing these markets, will be freed of its other regulatory tasks so that it can give full time to the work.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The United States Conference of Mayors adopted resolutions today urging continuance of rent controls, passage of the long-term Wagner-Ellender-Taft housing bill and completion of the Federal emergency housing program.

A provocative group exhibition opened this week at the Betty Parsons Gallery, 15 East Fifty-seventh Street, where it will remain through Feb. 8. It is called "The Ideographic Picture" and is made up of work by Hans Hofmann, Pietro Lazzari, Boris Margo, B.B. Newman, Ad Reinhardt, Mark Rothko, Theodore Stamos and Clifford Still, each artist represented by two canvases.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 22 -- Despite previous East-West disagreement over future United Nations' economic policy in Europe, the United States and Poland today agreed generally that immediate practical needs should be the first consideration in Europe's reconstruction.

A further increase last week of 1,466,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, they were 98,013,000 barrels, compared with 96,547,000 a week earlier and 101,109,000 on Jan. 19, 1946.

Two sizzling drives in the first half provided the momentum as the New York Knickerbockers rolled to a 74-to-64 triumph over the Chicago Stags before 2,518 spectators at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory last night.

The Teachers Guild, AFL, will propose today that the Teachers Salary Conference prepare to take a strike referendum whenever leaders of teachers agree that the time is appropriate. The conference will meet this afternoon.

Gabardines in the softest pastels were featured yesterday by Russeks in a showing of spring suits at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Used alone or in jackets for contrast against darker skirts, the pale shades were effective in tones of cream, delicate blue and pink.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- George Marshall, Secretary of State, has asked Dean Acheson to remain at the State Department as Undersecretary and the latter has agreed to do so for several months at least, it was learned today.

LONDON, Jan. 22 -- Though the Palestine conference opens here on Monday, the British Government is still without a solution to offer if the discussions with the Arabs should break down, it was learned authoritatively today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The House Rules Committee today gave clearance for floor consideration of the bipartisan bill to peg excise taxes on liquor, furs, jewelry and a number of other "luxuries" at current wartime rates.

ALTOGETHER there must be somewhere in the neighborhood of 5,000 golf clubs in the United States. Of that number, fewer than one-seventh -- only 698 in fact -- are members of the United States Golf Association, the game's governing body in this country. At least, that was the number given at the annual meeting of the organization here recently.

The American Repertory Theatre, threatened these last few weeks by a financial crisis due to high operating costs, has come up with a plan designed to insure its theatrical existence, it was announced yesterday. Beginning late next month, the repertory company will switch to a policy of offering single plays on a four to six-week basis.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22 -- The threeman arbitration board appointed to settle the pay-and-rules dispute between Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., and the Air Line Pilots Association, AFL, today unanimously awarded pay gains to pilots and co-pilots of TWA's four-engined DC-4 Skymaster and Constellation Aircraft.
LONDON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Britain has agreed conditionally to the incorporation of the frontier areas of Burma within the independent Burma state now being created, a Government source said today.
DETROIT, Mich., Jan. 22 -- Rebellion against the leadership of Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, flared today when the other three international officers...
An amazing record of sports promotion was revealed last night at the annual beefsteak of the Boxing Writers Association of New York in the Ruppert Brewery.

The Greek-owned passenger ship Katoomba, whose return trip to Genoa has been delayed pending deposit of a bond to cover a $300,000 damage suit brought by fiftyseven passengers who arrived in the ship Jan. 10, is scheduled to sail from Hoboken on Saturday, the Greek Line announced yesterday.

Johnny Roukema of Paterson, N.J., national five-mile speedskating champion, charged in an interview yesterday that he was being unfairly excluded from the final American Olympic trials to be held at St. Paul, Minn., Feb. 4-9, to select a team to compete at St. Moritz in 1948, The Associated Press reported.

Seventy prominent Americans, a majority of them of the liberal stamp, have cabled a statement to British Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin declaring that American foreign policy is not of the "Henry Wallace variety" and deploring efforts here and in England to break up British-American collaboration.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The report that four Republicans with isolationist tendencies have been appointed to the House Foreign Relations Committee to rank just below the chairman, Representative Eaton, is most disturbing.

TOKYO, Jan. 22 -- The Cabinet of Premier Shigeru Yoshida offered sweeping concessions tonight to Government employes who threatened to strike on Feb. 1, causing virtual paralysis of all Japanese industry.

The Expert Cloth Sponging Company has purchased for occupancy the eight-story loft building, on a plot 50 by 92 feet, at 35-37 East Twentieth Street from the 35 East Twentieth Street Corporation in a deal negotiated by Williams Co.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Senator Kenneth D. McKellar, Democrat, of Tennessee, will oppose the confirmation of David K. Lilienthal as chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, he said today. He expects to appear in opposition during next week's hearings on the confirmation.

Underwriting managers here will place on the market today refunding bonds of a public utility company and stocks of industrial companies, as follows: New York State Electric and Gas Corporation -- $13,000,000 of first mortgage 2 3/4 per cent bonds due in 1977 at 102 7/8 by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc; bid cleared by Securities and Exchange Commission.

In 1876 an organization was founded in New York City whose like was not known in this country. It was the Legal Aid Society, and the purpose as stated in its constitution was "to render legal aid gratuitously, if necessary, to all who may appear worthy thereof, and who are unable to procure assistance elsewhere, and to promote measures for their protection."

The youthful Herman C. Schwab, member of the Yale and Piping Rock clubs, continued to be the sensation of the Bulldog Handicap squash tennis tournament at the Yale Club as play moved into the quarter-finals last night.
Sonja Henie and her Hollywood Ice Revue tonight will open a seventeennight run in Madison Square Garden, scene of some of the skating star's greatest triumphs.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 22 -- Dr. Oswaldo Aranha, former Foreign Minister of Brazil, has been asked by his Government to succeed the late Dr. Pedro Leao Velloso as representative to the United Nations Security Council, and has accepted the invitation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- An ambitious program of investigations covering Communistic activities in many enterprises, including labor unions, education and motion pictures was projected today by the House Committee on un-American Activities.

Words Become Strange In the field of international relations there is a process at work that might be described as anti-semantic. Semantics is the science of the meaning of words. Semanticists frequently and plausibly insist that they have an important contribution to make to the cause of international peace and One World.

Stanley Clarke, president of the Hugo Stinnes Corporation, Inc., took issue yesterday with a recent article of the Moscow Bolshevik, which asserted that United States' capitalists were "reaching out their hands toward" industry in the German Ruhr, particularly the Stinnes coal mines.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 22-- Germany is afflicted with an economic paralysis which will affect Europe and the United States unless "full and consistent support" is given to a plan to make Germany self-sufficient through industrial activity, William L. Batt, president of SKF Industries, warned here today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The Export-Import Bank today approved a broad line of credits to Finland, including a long-term credit of $20,000,000 and shorterm credits of $12,000,000. To these were added a potential further credit of $5,000,000 for probable participation with, exporters in financing the sale of "selected industrial commodities" to Finland.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 22 -- Maurice E. Bathurst, legal adviser to the British delegation to the United Nations, is preparing to fly to London for approval of a new atomic control plan that would give an Atomic Development Authority full power to order war against violators -- with or without the approval of the Security Council.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Kenneth C. Royall, Under-Secretary of War, declared today that he has set up procedures for carefully surveying Army expenditures in order to prevent any unnecessary buying at the end of the fiscal year to "beat" the deadline for expiration of appropriations.
LONDON, Jan. 22 -- Speculative selling which followed the Government's White Paper warning on production deficiencies dried up in the stock markets today and a better tendency was seen.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Anderson asked Congress today for immediate legislation to allow sale of Government-owned wool at less than parity prices.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 22 -- India's Constitution-making Assembly, dominated by the Congress party and with the Moslem League still absent, adopted unanimously today Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru's resolution defining its objective as an independent sovereign republic.

Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson indicated yesterday that the city's expanse budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1 may be $100,000,000 over the present budget. Previously, estimates by other city officials showed that not more than an additional $90,000,000 would be needed to run the city during the 1947-48 fiscal year.

Fordham's basketball team notched its fifth straight victory last night at the Rose Hill Gymnasium by defeating St. Peter's College of Jersey City, 55 -- 33, before a crowd of 1,500. After a slow first half that ended with Fordham leading, 15 -- 13, the Rams were never threatened.
LONDON, Jan. 22 -- Great Britain is in a "really grave situation" with "a very tough economic struggle ahead" for "two or three years at least."

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 22 (AP) -- The Pennsylvania Railroad, declaring it is "keeping fully abreast of every modern development in all forms of motive power," announced today a $30,400,000 program to replace its through-service fleet of coal-burning steam-powered engines with Diesel electric locomotives.

The General Electric Company outwitted Germany in the acquisition of patents for the manufacture of hard metal compositions, Walter Gordon Merritt, counsel for the company, declared in Federal Court yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Gambleproof legislation designed to keep professional football clean will be urged by Commissioner Bert Bell of Philadelphia at the opening of the National Football League's three-day meeting here tomorrow.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22 -- Heavy short covering developed in wheat futures on the Board of Trade today. This followed announcement by Secretary of Agriculture Clinton P. Anderson that the Government would seek to export 350,000,000 bushels of wheat and wheat flour during the current crop year, compared with an original allocation of 267,000,000.

ATLANTA, Jan. 22 -- The Georgia Senate, which a week ago joined the House in electing and inaugurating Herman Talmadge as Governor, today confirmed its journal of proceedings showing that, in an open session Monday, M.E. Thompson, rival claimant to the Governorship, took the official oaths both as Lieutenant Governor and Acting Governor.

An issue of $1,750,000 of school district bonds of York, Pa., maturing on Feb. 1, 1949 to 1970, was placed on the market yesterday by a banking group composed of the Harris Trust and Savings Bank, Stroud Co., Inc., Schmidt, Poole Co., Phillips, Schmertz Robinson and Singer, Deane Scribner.

Sharp breaks in fat and oil prices are unlikely "before results of the 1947-48 crops are reason ably definite," Charles E. Lund, chief of the foodstuffs division of the Office of International Trade, Department of Commerce, stated yesterday at the annual meeting of the Association of American Soap and Glycerine Producers in the Waldorf-Astoria.
Cessation of liquidation and a revival of export demand carried cotton prices higher yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange, with closing quotations 30 to 41 points above Tuesday's levels.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The meager attention given to that part of the Patterson-Forrestal agreement to coordinate the armed services which provides for a Council of National Defense is probably to be explained by two circumstances. One is that the concept of the Council is so important and well worked out that no objection can be found to it, even as to detail.

A record output of over $100,000,000 annual gross volume is expected to be attained in the foreseeable future by manufacturers of mineral wool. Wharton Clay, secretary, the National Mineral Wool Association, said here yesterday. The announcement was made in connection with an expanded research program, authorized at a meeting of its research committee here this week.

Keeping Syndicate Secrets Competitive sale pricing practices were put aside this week to meet the unprecedented situation presented by the simultaneous bidding today at noon on four separate issues of railroad equipment trust certificates.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Members of the House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee censured Government aeronautical agencies today for what was termed their failure to recommend to Congress measures necessary to promote safety in the air.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- A resolution intended to help the country's railroads effect financial reorganizations without going through bankruptcy proceedings was introduced today by Senator Clyde M. Reed, Republican, of Kansas, and Senator Francis J. Myers, Democrat, of Pennsylvania.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Jan. 22 (AP) -- The death of an aged Negro in a shabby flat has this Mississippi River town's famed Beale Street dreaming over the past, when fabulous Mac Harris was the "king of the gamblers."

CHICAGO, Jan. 22 -- The insurance all-industry committee and representatives of the National Association of Insurance Commissioners met here today to define fair-trade practices in the insurance business. The purpose of the meeting, which will continue through Saturday, is to draft a model law for State control of the industry's trade practices to avoid first-hand regulation by the Federal Trade Commission.

HANOI, Indo-China, Jan. 21 (Delayed) -- One of highest ranking officials in the French Commissariat for Tongking charged in an interview today that the rebel Government of the Viet Nam Republic was Communist and totalitarian.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I would appreciate it if you would permit me to offer a comment on the editorial in the Jan. 20 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES entitled "Injustice to Veterans."

PARIS, Jan. 22 -- After another day of laborious conferences with party leaders, Paul Ramadier, the new Socialist Premier, presented to President Vincent Auriol the coalition Cabinet that he has formed to continue Leon Blum's experiment for reconstruction.

The Tri-Continental Corporation had net assets of $47,890,209 on Dec. 31, 1946, compared to net assets of $53,253,928 on Dec. 31, 1945, according to the annual report, released yesterday by Francis F. Randolph, chairman of the board. The asset figures were equivalent to $10.86 a common share at the year-end, against $13.07 a share a year earlier.

There is no early prospect of a rise in either the level of interest rates charged on mortgages or the dividend rate being paid by savings and loan associations, according to the executives of those organizations attending a "management conference" of the Council of Insured Savings Associations, at the Hotel Commodore, yesterday.

More than a year after 7,000 Western Union telegraph workers in this city walked out on a fiveweek strike, an arbitrator decided yesterday that the company was right and the union was wrong in the dispute that led to the communications tie-up.

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 22-- The free ride which the food industry has been enjoying has come to an abrupt stop, Clarence Francis, chairman of the board of General Foods Corporation, told a luncheon meeting of the National-American Wholesale Grocers' Association here yesterday.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 22 -- An old salt's tale that would have stirred the envy of Conrad or Melville today earned John C. Caves of Baltimore a temporary haven in the Salvation Army and the dismissal in Police Judge P.J. Pellechia's court of a charge of creating a disturbance.

A 14-year-old boy, known as a neighborhood gypsy, was believed last night by the police to be the wild-shooting hoodlum who had wounded three persons slightly within twenty-four hours with a 22-caliber rifle in the vicinity of Fiftieth Street between Ninth and Tenth Avenues.

The City Planning Commission announced yesterday at a public hearing at City Hall its intention to move speedily to impose new zoning restrictions upon the area in the vicinity of the site of the permanent home of the United Nations on the east side of midManhattan.

Charitable and religious institutions share virtually all the estate of Mrs. Estelle A. Manning, widow of Joseph Day Manning, New York Stock Exchange broker. Mrs. Manning died on Nov. 12, 1943, leaving a gross estate of $4,707,433 and a net estate of $4,513,642, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday.

If Daniel Boone were to return Sunday and drop in at the smallbore matches at the Fourteenth Regiment Armory, he would take one look at the targets turned in by some of the shooters, trample his coonskin cap and leave his long rifle in the ash can as he left.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- A revitalized mediation and arbitration program of the United States Conciliation Service, with particular attention given to public utilities disputes, was credited today with helping to keep the country's strike totals at new low levels.

There are current reports that some American quarters are considering a new plan for international control of the atomic bomb, in order to meet Russian objections to the official American plan already adopted in principle by the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- To "relieve some of the burden on American taxpayers," Herbert Hoover accepted today an invitation from President Truman to undertake an economic mission to study food and collateral problems in Central Europe and to make recommendations for their solution.
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 22 (AP) -- Sanford Stud Farm's Round View, hero of last year's Flamingo Stakes, today won the $10,000 added Royal Palm Handicap by a head at Hialeah Park.

PARIS, Jan. 22 -- Andre FrancisPoncet, who was Under Secretary for Foreign Affairs in re-war Cabinets and the last French Ambassador to Germany, an article in the newspaper igaro today takes issue with a abled version of an editorial in THE NEW YORK TIMES concerning French policy in Indo-China.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 22 -- Leslie D. Farnath, media director of N.W. Ayer Son, Inc., has been awarded the first annual Media Buyer and Digest award "for his outstanding contribution to the profession of media buying during 1946," it was announced here today.

BERLIN, Jan. 22 -- Completely eliminating from positions of power or influence not only members of Nazi organizations but also nonparty members who were part and parcel of the Nazi machine is a top-priority aim of the American military government, Lieut. Gen. Lucius D. Clay, deputy military governor, said today.

The Right Rev. Charles K. Gilbert is commended by twenty-four prominent clergymen and laymen for successor to the Right Rev. William T. Manning as Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of New York in a letter that will be mailed out today.

The West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company earned $5,103,607 net in its fiscal year ended with last October, compared with $2,142,072 in the previous year, representing a return of 8.6 per cent and 3.9 per cent, respectively on the capital employed, the annual report disclosed yesterday.

Hope for peaceful settlement of the crucial wage negotiations between the United States Steel Corporation and the United Steel Workers, CIO, rose yesterday with reports of behind-the-scenes talks between top management and union representatives.
The police were convinced yesterday they had recovered the stolen car used by the gunmen who shot and killed Motorcycle Patrolman Harry Schiffries last Friday at Sixty-seventh Street and Park Avenue.

Gifts totaling $4,303,505 have been received for the projected New York University-Bellevue Medical Center, it was announced yesterday at a luncheon in the Commodore Hotel. A goal of $1,000,000 a month during the rest of this year was set by fund leaders.

ROME, Jan. 22 -- Four former Fascists went on trial today for the murder of Giacomo Matteotti, Socialist Deputy, on June 10, 1924. They were Amerigo Dumini, believed to have been the killer; Francesco Giunta, Cesare Rossi and Amleto Poveromo.

WARSAW, Jan. 22 -- The victorious Government Bloc split up the election melon today to "hosannas" chanted in the streets by almost 100,000 of its followers marshaled by the leadership of the Communist and Socialist parties for a "manifestation of joy" about the results.
BRUSSELS, Jan. 22 -- A move is under way to recover from Austria, under the peace treaty, the ancient regalia of the Order of the Golden Fleece, valued at some $25,000,000.

ABOARD MOUNT OLYMPUS, at Little America, Jan. 21 (Delayed) (AP) -- Two PBM Mariners of the Antarctic expedition's Western Task Group made successful photographic flights today over the unknown continent, with one apparently flying 250 to 300 miles inland over Adelieland, which is French-claimed territory.

New York City's American Red Cross quota for 1947 will total $6,153,600, or about $4,000,000 under that for last year, James M. Cecil, general chairman, announced yesterday at the campaign's initial meeting in the chapter's headquarters, 315 Lexington Avenue.
MOSCOW, Jan. 22 -- Although it is believed that the Government will be subjected to sharp attacks from, the Right, there is considerable satisfaction here over recent events in France.

NAIROBI, Kenya Colony, Jan. 22 -- Prof. W. Le Gros Clark, Oxford Professor of Anatomy, has ranged himself alongside the South African prehistorians, Prof. Raymond Dart and Dr. Robert Broom, in the belief that fossil material discovered at Sterkfontein and Kromdraai represents a link in the evolution of man.

ROME, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Alcide de Gasperi, who brought on Italy's current political crisis two days ago by resigning as Premier, was asked tonight by President Enrico de Nicola to organize a new Government.

ALBANY, Jan. 22 -- With the full support of Mayor O'Dwyer and the city administration, a bill was introduced today to empower the city to sell advertising space on subway gratings to raise additional revenue.

LODI, Calif., Jan. 22 (AP) -- Millard L. Fore, chief of police, said tonight that Earl Shelton, 40, who was questioned in San Francisco in connection with the case of Alice Dean Devine, would be brought to Lodi to be viewed by the girl tomorrow morning.

William Z. Foster, chairman of the Communist party of the United States, termed the "strong labor movement the greatest of all chievements of the working class" under the regime of the late President Roosevelt in an address last night at Madison Square Garden.

ALBANY, Jan. 22 -- In a speech before the State Agricultural Society, Governor Dewey declared today that means must be found to prevent farm living standards from tobogganing with the decline in food prices now getting under way.

ALBANY, Jan. 22 -- Governor Dewey announced today a $3,200,000 program of new emergency housing for veterans. Conversion of six unused school buildings in New York City to living purposes is included.

The new machinery for consideration of the national budget, provided by an Act of Congress adopted at the last session, has now begun to function. The first move has been to create something hitherto unprecedented in Washington: a Joint Committee on the Budget, representative of both Houses.

WARSAW, Poland, Jan. 22 -- Vice Foreign Minister Zygmunt Modzelewski, who has just returned to Poland from Moscow where he talked about Germany with Soviet leaders, said today the Allies should draw up a reconstruction plan for Germany "calculated both for the development of German industry and the payment of reparations."

During the past year individuals have been saving a smaller proportion of their income. More than one-quarter of their income after taxes was saved by individuals in the years 1942 to 1945. This was an abnormally high ratio of savings. It reflected the effect of wartime shortages of civilian goods, price control and wartime deficit financing.

A five-room model apartment, furnished and decorated for $650, will go on display today under the auspices of the Hudson Guild in the building at Tenth Avenue and Twenty-seventh Street. This is the first completed unit of the John Lovejoy Elliott housing project which was opened a few weeks ago by the New York City Housing Authority.

Although the Navy, in a letter to the National Association of Wholesalers, has stated that its policy of central procurement does not necessarily exclude wholesalers, discrimination still exists, Joseph Kolodny, president of the association, asserted yesterday.
DUESSELDORF, Germany, Jan. 22 -- British plans for the voluntary socialization of German industry were set back today by the Germans themselves.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22 (AP) -- The New York Rangers tallied twice in the final period for a 4-to-2 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks tonight in a National Hockey League game before 16,102 persons in Chicago Stadium.

Social investigations employed by probation officers might be used to advantage in the administration of justice in matrimonial actions, authorities in this field declared yesterday at the thirtyeighth annual State Conference of Probation Officers, held in the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn.

A policy of appeasement toward Soviet Russia win be more disastrous than was appeasement of Hitler Germany, Louis F. Budenz, former managing editor of The Daily Worker, declared yesterday at a luncheon meeting in the Columbia University Club, 4 West Forty-third Street.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 22 -- A proposal to exchange up to 800,000 shares of common stock of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation, together with $400,000 for 200,000 shares of its outstanding $3 cumulative preference stock was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the United Corporation.

Nick Etten, who only a few days ago was seriously concerned about his status with the Yankees, had some of his doubts dissipated yesterday when he went into a brief huddle with President Larry MacPhail and Manager Bucky Harris and then signed his contract for 1947.

Many students of rural sociology and agricultural economics have insisted that the traditional family farmstead was the strongest and most desirable type of farming in our democratic society. This point of view has received powerful support in the recent report from the Senate Small Business Committee.

Unwanted parenthood constitutes a threat to world peace, Dr. O. Spurgeon English, Professor of Psychiatry at Temple University, declared yesterday at the twentysixth annual meeting of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America at the Hotel Roosevelt.

Three of the five members of the Federal Trade Commission live with "other folks" to help share household expenses, while the wife of one member helps out financially by taking in day pupils for piano lessons, it was disclosed yesterday.
VILLANOVA, Pa., Jan. 22 -- A hard-fighting Villanova quintet gave unbeaten Seton Hall a firsthalf scare before losing by 55 to 46 before 4,000 in the Main Line hall tonight.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 22 -- Dimitry D. (Jimmy) Viner, veteran pilot who has logged more hours in rotary-winged aircraft than any other airman, was honored here tonight by officials of Sikorsky Aircraft for his contribution to the development of the helicopter.

LONDON, Jan. 22 -- The War Office denied today in the House of Commons that Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery had conducted any military discussions on the basis of the Anglo-Russian alliance during his recent visit to Moscow.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The Senate Republican leadership, with Robert A. Taft of Ohio at the command post, won its first test under fire today.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Jan. 22 -- Veteran American troops who fought World War n in Africa, Italy and through Europe from Normandy to Berlin are grimly busy here in the first Arctic maneuvers ever held toy the United States Army.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 22 -- Zoltan Korda has concluded arrangements with William Goetz, Universal-International production chief, for filming "Mortal Coils," a Photoplay by Aldous Huxley, at Universal, it was learned today Contracts being drawn up for signature by the principals call for Korda to direct the picture for U-I, he disclosed.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown, tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Delays up to ten years are faced by Europeans and Asiatics seeking to come to this country as immigrants. That much time may elapse for some before they can hope to obtain passport visas from overworked American consulate staffs.

Jascha Heifetz was handicapped by an unhappily devised program at his recital last night in Carnegie Hall. Even so eminent a violinist could not appear to the best advantage in a series of offerings, not one of which was of first-rate importance.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Jan. 22 (AP) -- Delegates to the National Canners Association's convention here approved today a resolution calling for the legislation upon which "the continued economic welfare of the nation is dependent." The resolution said "unnecessary labor disturbances have greatly impeded the orderly transition from a wartime to a peacetime economy."
The Institute of the Aeronautics Sciences announced last night it awards for achievement in aviation during 1946 and its officer for the coming year.

Lea Karina, Finnish mezzo-soprano, who made her debut here six years ago and has been heard in joint recital with her husband, Isidor Achron, composer-pianist, gave her second Town Hall recital last night.

Proposing a federated Germany as the best post-war reorganization plan for that country, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president emeritus of Columbia University, revealed yesterday the part that he played in the creation of the British Commonwealth of Nations.

SIR SAMUEL HOARE (Viscount Templewood) likes to call himself a liberal among conservatives, a conservative among liberals. It is a nice conceit and one, possibly, that tends to mean less and less the more you look at it -- like Masefield's "The days that make us happy make us wise." (Try: "The days that make us unhappy make us ignorant." )

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The Treasury Department ruled today that if employers against whom portal pay suits have been filed must pay such claims they can adjust their income taxes to charge the payments against the income for years on which the suits are based.
LONDON, Jan. 22 -- Poland and Yugoslavia struck hard at Germany and Austria today through the deputies of the Council of Foreign Ministers, meeting here to prepare the peace treaties.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Secretary of Agriculture Clinton P. Anderson today pleaded for high 1947 farm goals because he expects high export demands. He testified today at the House Agriculture Committee inquiry into the two-year Steagall price support problem.

CALCUTTA, India, Jan. 22 (Reuters) -- Police opened fire in renewed Calcutta disturbances today, injuring one man, as armed mobile police squads patrolled the city's tense trouble spots. Three persons were injured in stone throwing and police were reported to have fired blanks to scare away a crowd attempting to set fire to a private car.

For the welfare of the world the peace treaty to be made with Germany should create a loose federation of German states and a special regime of international supervision for Ruhr and Rhineland industries capable of increasing Germany's war-potential, Dr. Eelco N. van Kleffens, Netherlands delegate to the United Nations Security Council, declared last night.

Some progress was scored yesterday by the stock market as a result of a limited amount of buying in the afternoon, but turnover again proved so light that the gains held little significance. Meager bidding in the steels and motors accounted for the first upturn of the week and left the number of issues to advance well above those declining.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The Department of Commerce declared to Congress today that it shared with business a "deep concern" that the national economy might suffer "great damage" from the claims for portal-to-portal back pay piling up over the country.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 22 -- Stronger ties between Brazil and the United States are likely to result from the appointment of Dr. Oswaldo Aranha as Brazil's representative to the United Nations Security Council. Dr. Aranha is expected to confer with Secretary of State Marshall on many issues.

Stevedoring companies are facing considerable difficulty in getting back to normal commercial operation as the result of many "practices" that originated during the war -- practices that will require several years to correct, Howard J. Cole, president of the National Association of Stevedores, said last night.

A gang of thieves who evidently knew what they wanted -- the establishment of an underworld arsenal -- broke into the Morton Jewelry Curio Shop, 40 Fulton Street, over the week-end and got away with forty-one pistols of various makes, the police revealed yesterday.

Eighty-five colts and a nearrecord total of ten fillies have been named for this year's seventy-ninth running of the $100,000 added Belmont Stakes, it was announced yesterday by the Westchester Racing Association.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: May I please call your attention to a serious misstatement in your editorial of Jan. 12 entitled "Sponsored News."

The coldest day this winter congealed New York and its environs yesterday. In sharp contrast to the mild weather with which the week started -- the mercury touched a high mark of 61.3 degrees Monday -- a low of 11.2 degrees was recorded at 8:15 A. M.

By adopting unanimously Pandit Nehru's resolution to proclaim India as an independent, sovereign republic, the Constituent Assembly at New Delhi has taken a step away from the British Commonwealth of Nations. The ultimate effect of this action depends on how far the voice of the Assembly is the real voice of the Indian peoples.
TRENTON, N. J., Jan. 22 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll moved quickly today to get his proposals before the New Jersey Legislature.

New plastic-coated decorative fabrics that are safe from hazards of ink stains or fingerprints without offering a hard and shiny surface in the bargain were shown yesterday by the Fisher Plastics Corporation at the Hotel Pierre.

Construction of twelve new plants in the New York metropolitan area will substantially increase fiber can and tube production here, Paul S. Hanway, managing director, National Fibre Can Tube Association, disclosed here yesterday. While shipments of fiber cans and other products are now twelve weeks behind customer requirements, a new industry-wide program of efficiency will improve output, he said, although at present levels production is 80 per cent above maximum pre-war records.

In the first expression from the Army Air Forces since President Truman's budget figures were submitted to Congress, Lieut. Gen. Ira C. Eaker, deputy commander of the Army Air Forces and Chief of Air Staff, told a luncheon of the Wings Club in the Biltmore Hotel yesterday that the country was in "imminent danger."

BOSTON, Jan. 22 -- Dr. Charles Henry Hare, who retired several years ago while one of New England's leading gynecologists and was a Brown University benefactor, died yesterday at the Harvard Club, where he lived. His age was 84.

Five art editors protested, in a letter disclosed last night, against the obliteration of the mural in the chancel of the Rutgers Presbyterian Church, Seventy-third Street and Broadway. They declared that a work of art in a semi-public institution was part of the artistic patrimony and heritage of a community.

Another of the nine men who escaped from Brooklyn City Prison last Jan. 2, the fourth to be recaptured, was seized by New York and Hoboken policemen as he sipped a highball in a Hoboken tavern last night, about twenty-five minutes before he had planned to take a train for Cleveland.

NANKING, Jan. 22 -- The Government is expected formally to hand over its latest four-point peace proposal to the Communists tomorrow. The four points are: cessation of hostilities with troops retaining their present positions, army reorganization, reopening of communications and a "just and equitable" solution of the problem of regional administrations.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 22 (AP) -- The American Distilling Company lost an appeal to the State Supreme Court today in its effort to attach a fancy label to bottles containing whisky less than a month old.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Dismayed when a Federal District Court held invalid the "historical use" base for rationing sugar to industrial consumers, the Government hurriedly announced today that the decision would be appealed and a stay requested.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (U.P.) -- The FBI struck twice tonight -- in Columbia, S. C., and New York City -- and arrested seven men on charges of trying to bribe a War Assets Administration official to help them purchase fraudulently nearly $1,000,000 in Governmentowned surplus property.

ALBANY, Jan. 22 -- The Legislature will be asked tomorrow to consider amending the Walker Law, successfully employed by the State in breaking up the Ku Klux Klan, to permit its use against the Communist party.

Opens 1947 Blanket Line Chatham Manufacturing Company will include in its 1947 line, four standard numbers and four deluxe numbers in addition to its baby blanket line, it was announced yesterday at the formal presentation of the line in the Hotel Pierre.

With final details of the plan under which Motty Eitingon, Inc., mouton furs, will be furnished $1,000,000 in new capital expected to be completed within a week, the creditors' hearing yesterday at the United States Court was adjourned until Jan. 29.

Brides who have had to set up housekeeping in cramped quarters lacking adequate cooking facilities may be encouraged to know that cakes as finely textured and delicate in flavor as those baked in a regular oven may be produced on top of the range or on a hot plate.

Economic and Social Council -- The Social Commission opened discussions on transfer of social welfare advisory activities of UNRRA and also transfer of former League of Nations' functions in traffic of women and children, child welfare and crime prevention to the United Nations.
PARIS, Jan. 23--Leon Blum formally transmited the powers of government today to his successor, Premier Paul Ramadier, whose Ministers also assumed their duties.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Jan. 23--Carroll Reece, chairman of the Republican National Committee, in a letter to Mrs. Ana Maria Iriarte, Republican Committeewoman for Puerto Rico, published in this morning's El Mundo, gives the statehood movement for Puerto Rico the strongest encouragement of recent years.

The ninety-third anniversary of the incorporation of the New York Infirmary, 321 East Fifteenth Street, was marked yesterday at the annual meeting of the hospital's board of trustees, at 597 Madison Avenue.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 23 --A meeting of the United Nations Security Council has been called by its chairman, Ambassador Norman J.O. Makin of Australia, for 11 A.M. Tuesday, to take up the question of Britain's charges against Albania.

"Experimentation in education is necessary both today and in time to come," Dr. John M. Ramseyer, director of the University School of Columbus, Ohio, declared yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Bernard Botein, who is hearing a suit brought by Teachers College of Columbia University to discontinue the Horace Mann-Lincoln School.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--A resolution to require the immediate return of 229 American merchant ships still operating under the British flag under a wartime agreement was introduced in the House today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 23 --Supreme Court Justice Frederick G. Schmidt signed a decision here this afternoon sustaining the findings of a jury that the State Liquor Authority had been "arbitrary, capricious and unreasonable" in refusing to grant a package store liquor license in a twelve-mile arid belt of northern Westchester and southern Putnam counties.

One of the more popular myths concerning the American war effort is that the only concerns to show substantial profits were a handful of the nation's industrial giants. Contributing no little to the maintenance of this belief have been some of the fanciful statistics produced by the economists of the Smaller War Plants Corporation and the even more fanciful deductions drawn therefrom.

WITH U. S. ARMY TASK FORCE FRIGID NEAR FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Jan. 23--The thermometer read a little more than 30 degrees below zero tonight as this group of 1,500 officers and men under Col. Paul V. Kane bivouacked for the night.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Jan. 23-- Atomic nuclei, made to whirl at dizzying speeds by induction of a radio-frequency current in experiments at Stanford University are being turned into submicroscopic radio transmitters which give off visible signals identifying the atoms of materials used.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23--Grain markets showed an easy undertone the greater part of the day after a small advance in the early trading on the Board of Trade today. Uncertainty as to the action of January wheat and corn, trading in which ceased at the close, tended to discourage general interest in the market.

The increased interest in hunting has been accompanied by an equal, if not greater, increase in the popularity of the shooting dog, and almost every mail brings at least one inquiry from a prospective dog owner, who wants to know the best all-around dog and where one can be bought cheaply.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 23--Conditions in Argentina for educators who refuse to follow the Peron line have become so unfavorable physically as well as mentally that at least five university professors are desperately seeking haven in Mexico. So many others are in jeopardy of one kind or another that interested persons here hope to provide refuge for as many as 100 in all, it was learned today.

DETROIT, Jan. 23--The top strategists of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, rejected today a company proposal for settlement of the 271-day-old strike against the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company in West Allis, Wis.

Fifteen-year-old Alfred Sand, one of four youngsters involved in the theft of between $17,000 and $18,000 in a burglary in Manhattan last Dec. 5 and all four of whom lived in Florida on the proceeds, was found guilty of juvenile delinquency in Children's Court yesterday by Justice Matthew Diserio.

Labor shortages, brought about by the British policy of restricting Jewish immigration into Palestine, are seriously hindering the economic development of that country Itshaq Ben-Aharon, a member of the political department of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, declared yesterday.

ALBANY, Jan. 23--Gov. Thomas E. Dewey signed today the $32,000,000 Emergency Teachers Pay Bill, using the occasion to reply to charges that his administration has been niggardly in providing State funds for education.

Money spent to improve subway and bus service will do more to relieve New York City's traffic congestion than the investment of large sums in the construction of express highways, Leslie Williams, city planning and traffic engineer of the American Transit Association, declared yesterday.

The Treasury has ruled that employers who must pay claims arising out of portal-to-portal pay suits can revise their tax returns for the years in which the liability was incurred. Since a large part of this liability will apply to the war years 1942-45, the net result will be to transfer most of these payments to the taxpayer.

SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 23 (AP) --Playing in burning heat, Tom Brown Jr. of San Francisco and Gardnar Mulloy of Miami battled their way to the semi-finals of the Australian singles tennis championships today with hardearned victories over Adrian Quist and Lionel Brodie, respectively.

NANKING, China, Jan. 23--"Reactionary imperialist capitalism" in the United States faces inevitable defeat at the hands of the peoples of the capitalist, colonial and semicolonial countries within the next few years, according to an analysis of the world political situation by Lu Ting-yi, head of the department of information of the Chinese Communist party.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 23-- Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard, proposed today a terminal two-year college education to be provided locally with the aid of Federal funds to meet the increasing demand for education beyond high school.

LONDON, Jan. 23--The British Cabinet is actively considering the importation of substantial numbers of displaced persons from European refugee camps to relieve Britain's acute labor shortage, it was learned from an authoritative source today.

PARIS, Jan. 23 -- Robert Murphy's proposal in London that there be no German signatories to the treaty with Germany and that the procedure be replaced by an "international statute" will receive consideration here, political quarters indicated today.

A terminal contribution of $10,000,000 by the Rockefeller Foundation to the China Medical Board, Inc., for the support of Peiping Union Medical College, was announced yesterday. This brings to $44,652,490 the sums the Foundation has appropriated to this field since 1915, making it the largest grant to a single project in the history of the Foundation.

DETROIT, Jan. 23--The Committee of 100, composed of prominent lay members and clergy of the Presbyterian Church, today completed its program designed to fit the needs of the Church to world conditions created by the war.

Rune Gustafsson will have his first fling at board-track racing tonight. Sweden's 4:04.6 miler and Haakan Lidman, his hurdling compatriot, launch their American invasion in The Philadelphia Inquirer games at Convention Hall. This meet, first major event of the 1947 indoor track season, opens a big week-end for the spiked shoe brigade, which also will rendezvous tomorrow at Boston and West Point.

WARSAW, Jan. 23--The future of Stanislaw Mikolajczyk's Polish Peasant party (PSL) rested tonight on the decision of the party's executive commitee on a proposal made by M. Mikolajczyk to resign immediately from the Provisional Government as a protest against Sunday's elections.

ESSEN, Germany, Jan. 23.-- Lieut. Gen. Lucius D. Clay, Deputy United States Military Governor, pledged today a recruitment drive in the American zone for 50,000 men to work in the British zone in an effort to raise the Ruhr coal output to 400,000 tons a day.
LONDON, Jan. 23--The cooperative international effort to distribute Europe's scanty coal supplies fairly through the European Coal Organization will continue for another year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--Senators of opposite political faiths today offered widely different methods for solving the current labor-management crisis. Those who spoke out were in agreement, however, against granting the Government compulsory power in labor disputes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--Andrew J. May, former Democratic Representative from Kentucky who was chairman of the powerful House Committee on Military Affairs, was indicted today with Henry M. Garsson, Murray Garsson and Joseph Freeman, officers of a wartime munitions combination, on charges of conspiracy to defraud the Federal Government.

Recognition of "the constructive possibilities" of neighborhood gangs was suggested yesterday as an aid in the solution of juvenile problems by Dr. G. Howland Shaw, president of the Welfare Council of the City of New York. He spoke at the annual State Conference of Probation Officers in the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn.
MOSCOW, Jan. 23--Not content with vodka and other noted temperature raisers, the Russians are introducing Canadian hockey here this winter.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Jan. 23 -- Miss Polly Hodder, captain of the Middlebury College women's ski team and queen of the Middlebury College carnival, flashed down the fast, icy Worth Mountain trail at Bread Loaf Mountain today to capture first place in the downhill event and lead her team as Middlebury College nosed out McGill by a fraction of a point for first place.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--President Truman stated flatly today that he favored continuation of country-wide rent controls but he indicated at the same time that the responsibility rested now with Congress and not the Chief Executive.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--Despite his Democratic colleague's defeat in the Senate yesterday on the question of special investigative committees Representative John W. McCormack of Massachusetts, minority whip, took the issue to the House floor today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP)-- An action seeking to invalidate the election of Representative Vito Marcantonio of New York was filed today with the House by a self-described "citizen and voter" of Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--Senator K.D. McKellar, Democrat of Tennessee, continued his campaign today to convince the Senate Public Works Committee that the Tennessee Valley Authority suffers from Communist influence in its higher command.
LONDON, Jan. 23--The British Government will give "all possible moral support" to American mediation efforts in China, Viscount Jowitt, the Lord Chancellor, said in the House of Lords today.

Stores to Boost Linage An expenditure of $735,000,000 by the retail dry goods field for newspaper advertising linage this year was predicted yesterday by Milton Stern, president of Controlled Promotions, Inc., following a survey among 400 department stores.
Harold Bernhardt left Bellevue Hospital yesterday the perfect example of the near-miracles being achieved by the New York University -Bellevue Hospital Institute of Rehabilitation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--The capacity of the Big Inch and Little Big Inch pipelines has reached approximately 110,000,000 cubic feet of natural gas a day and their operation is relieving gas shortages as far north as Detroit and Buffalo.

The instant that Charles Muench raised his baton as guest conductor of the Philharmonic - Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall it was evident that we had with us a superb musician and orchestra leader to boot. The beat, the gesture, sometimes very economical, sometimes high, wide, and handsome, brought immediate results.

The belief that Governor Dewey is misleading the people of New York regarding the amount of State funds available for permanent housing was expressed last night by the Human Relations Commission of the Protestant Council of the City of New York.
LONDON, Jan. 23--New emphasis today by Sir Stafford Cripps on the seriousness of Britain's economic position helped bring about further losses in the stock markets.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 (AP)--Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs. 9,000 head, total 16,000: market slow; 15 to 25 cents lower early, with most of decline on weights over 250 pounds: these weights closed 25 to 50 cents lower; top $24

LODI, Calif., Jan. 23 (AP)-- Police acknowledged they were back where they started today after their "No. 1 suspect" was exonerated last night of the abduction of 17-year-old Alice Dean Devine, daughter of a wealthy grape grower.

Of outstanding importance is the "Masterpieces of English Painting" exhibition, which opened with a preview last evening at the Metropolitan Museum. The British Ambassador, the Right Honorable Lord Inverchapel, took part in the brief official ceremony, and Sir Alexander and Lady Cadogan were also guests of honor.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: THE NEW YORK TIMES of Jan. 14 reports that William K. Jackson, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, regards "the Philip Murrays and the Reuthers" as threats to capitalism and the profits of employers.
