Mr. Jackson, the report states, urges an educational campaign to "restore faith in the American way of life."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--Department stores in the week ended Jan. 18 were 17 per cent above sales in the like week last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from corresponding periods of 1946:

Familiar Roll-Call Georgia is in the big headlines on a grave issue of popular government. California, for the moment, is in the big display advertisements for a less compelling reason; it is the name of a new film musical.

LONDON, Jan. 23--The British Government is eager to enter into negotiations for a treaty of alliance with France as soon as the new French Government is ready, Prime Minister Attlee said in the House of Commons today.

A message from President Truman, commending the American Jewish Committee for its "long and honorable campaign against bigotry and prejudice," was made public yesterday by Joseph M. Proskauer, president of the committee, which will open its fortieth annual meeting tomorrow in the Commodore Hotel.

Textile manufacturers must cut their profits along with retailers until it can be determined how far the public will go in decreasing its soft goods purchases, Adam Gimbel, president of Saks-Fifth Avenue, declared yesterday. Consumers can be educated to pay more for goods, he said, but in doing so, they will expect more for their money.

The Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad reported yesterday for 1946 a net income of $36,216 after charges and taxes but including a tax carry-back credit of $915,558. For 1945, it reported a net deficit of $3,292,145 after New Jersey back taxes and interest of $3,376,000 and amortization charges of $3,234,000 in excess of normal.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Jan. 23 --Deputy Premier Matyas Rakosi, leader of the Communist party, demanded the death sentence yesterday for those convicted of conspiracy against the Hungarian republic.

The New York City Housing Authority yesterday awarded bond issues maturing in five years at an interest cost of 1.1698 per cent for $3,316,000 maturing June 1 from 1948 to 1952 and at an interest cost of 1.787 per cent for $550,000 maturing on April 1 of the same years.

Total assets of the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York, as of last Dec. 31, amounted to 553,480,699, compared with $42,406,294 on the December date in 1945, Nugent Fallon, president, reported yesterday at the annual stockholders' meeting.
MOSCOW, Jan. 23--A violent attack on the "nauseating and corrupt nonsense" of the philosophical school of existentialism led by Jean-Paul Sartre was launched today by David Zaslavsky in Pravda.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Because of the urgent need of the American Women's Voluntary Services Motor Transport Service for additional volunteers, a friend of the organization placed an advertisement in the Public Notices of THE NEW YORK TIMES on Jan. 7.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP)-- The Commerce Department estimated today that the United States last year provided foreign contries with $8,200,000,000 more in goods and services than it got from them.

Founded a quarter of a century ago, the United Parents Associations has won a valuable place for itself in the community. As it celebrates its twentyfifth anniversary the organization, consisting of parents whose children are attending our schools, is looking ahead toward greater effort.

Marginal Note Of interest in the light of the Federal Reserve Board's decision to restore 75 per cent margin trading in stocks on Feb. 1 is the result of a poll of member firms of the New York Stock Exchange on the number of accounts that they were handling.
Allowing Mady Christians, one of our favorite actresses, to remain idle is tantamount to a heinous oversight. Don't fret, she won't be.

BERLIN, Jan. 23--The Russians have extended the olive branch to the Social Democratic party, which they eliminated in their zone last April, it was reliably learned today. Dr. Kurt Schumacher, head of the Social Democrats in the British zone, has been asked to discuss the re-establishment of the party in the Soviet zone with leaders of the Socialist Unity party.

MOSCOW, Jan. 23--The claim first made on Jan. 15 that Foreign Secretary Bevin of Britain renounced the Anglo-Soviet treaty of alliance in his speech on Dec. 22 was defended today by Pravda, official organ of the Communist party.

James A. Moffett, oil company executive and former Federal official, filed suit in Federal Court here yesterday for $6,000,000 against the Arabian American Oil Company for services which he claims saved the company at least $30,000,000.

LONDON, Jan. 23--History repeated itself today when Australian and Soviet representatives clashed over small-power participation in peace-treaty talks. The squabble, which duplicated previous quarrels in Paris and New York, concerned the German peace-treaty preparations of the deputies of the Council of Foreign Ministers, who are meeting here.

DETROIT, Jan. 23 (AP)--Pete Horeck poured in four goals against his former Chicago teammates tonight as the Red Wings crushed the Black Hawks, 8 to 2, in a National Hockey League game before 11,705 fans.

Commercial, industrial, and agricultural loans of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $54,000,000 last week to reach a new high level of $3,848,000,000, it was disclosed yesterday. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York, in issuing the statement of the banks for the week ended on Wednesday, explained that a varied list of borrowings accounted for the increase.

LONDON, Ont., Jan. 23--John Gielgud opened his first North American tour in more than ten years at the Grand Theatre here tonight in a scintillating performance of the Oscar Wilde classic, "The Importance of Being Earnest."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 23-- The story of Mrs. Tillie Majczek, who scrubbed floors for ten years in Chicago to save $5,000 and then offered it as a reward for information which would clear her son. Joe, of the murder of Policeman William D. Lundy, for which Joe had been sentenced to ninety-nine years in prison, will be brought to the screen by Twentieth CenturyFox, the studio announced today.

Electric Boat Company, New York manufacturer of submarines, PT boats and pleasure water craft, will enter the aircraft industry this week by taking over complete production of four-motored "North Star" transport planes at Montreal, it was announced yesterday.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Jan. 23-- A major research program for minor planets has been set up by the American section or the International Astronomical Union in charge of Dr. Paul Herget, University of Cincinnati astronomer. The research is expected to discover minor planets still unknown and to study those discovered in recent years.

The glamour inherent in a motionpicture personality, abetted by real skill and a world reputation in figure skating, lured 12,000 into Madison Square Garden last night for Sonja Henie's Hollywood Ice Revue. It was the opener of a seventeennight stand that will last through Jan. 30, then will be interrupted to reopen Feb. 3 and run through Feb. 11.

John Leonard (Pepper) Martin returned to the major leageues yesterday, brought back by the man under whose aegis the Wild Horse of the Osage won his greatest fame --Branch Rickey, president of the Dodgers. Rickey hired the former Cardinal third baseman and outfielder as a member of the farflung Brooklyn farm organization.

Some strange intelligence spread around the secluded reaches of northwestern Westchester County in the last few days. It seems that the New York Central printed a new suburban timetable which introduced, by way of innovation for Sunday morning travel, Train No. 136, leaving Peekskill at 6:20 A.M. and arriving at Grand Central Station at 7:30 A.M.

LONDON, Jan. 23--Arab and Zionist quarters said today they were convinced that opposition by Foreign Secretary Bevin to the partitioning of Palestine into Arab and Jewish states had blocked Britain's attempts to devise a solution of her own.

Although cold weather has slowed up wholesale vegetable transactions with the result that the housewife will find prices for fresh produce a little higher in the stores this week-end, she will be pleased to note that the abundant supplies of all kinds of meat that continue to flood the market have brought about a drop in the cost of most cuts.

LONDON, Jan. 23--Pravda's rejection today of the official British explanation that Foreign Secretary Bevin's broadcast of Dec. 22 did not imply disavowal of the AngloSoviet alliance has deepened the already serious concern felt in London at Moscow's attitude.

With the aid of wholesalers, the country's 200,000 independent retailers can materially speed up merchandise distribution by concentrating once more on major promotional seasons of selling, William E. Long, chairman of the committee of distribution, the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute, pointed out yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 23 --United Nations plans to prevent clashes among national economies were carried a step farther today when the Economic and Employment Commission tentatively approved the setting up of coordinating commissions for Europe and for Asia and the Far East.

Skiing continues to be on the gloomy aide, generally speaking, for this week-end with an encouraging note in the prediction of much-needed snow for the hardpacked hills in New England. The best reports yesterday were from the Adirondacks of New York State where Snow Ridge in Turin and Saranac Lake wired "excellent," an adjective that has been missing too long in the weekly observations from the north.
MEXICO CITY, Jan. 23 --The full extent of President Miguel Aleman's victory over the oil workers' union is becoming plainer every day.

LIVERPOOL, Jan. 23 (Reuters) --A dispute within the giant film organization headed by J. Arthur Rank over the policy of placing "prestige pictures" above all other considerations tonight led to a new resignation of an executive from the firm.

Admitting that it had received some complaints from residents of the upper East Side of the taste of chlorine in their drinking water, the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity announced yesterday that it was doing its utmost to alleviate the condition.

DHAHRAN, Saudi Arabia, Jan. 22 (Delayed)--King Ibn Saud and his entourage drove today through the quiet sunlit streets of this American village transplanted to Arabia. He inspected modern industrial installations that yield him a daily income of more than $40,000 from oil royalties.

Consumers today are expecting lower prices and improved quality of merchandise, according to the results of a survey on the trend of public thinking on prices and qualities announced here yesterday by the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

The steels and motors sparked again yesterday a late rally in the stock market. With spirited bidding in the final hour when more than a third of the day's business took place, the composite price index was lifted about a point and many key industrials rose even more.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 23--The delayed formal wage negotiations between the United States Steel Corporation and the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, will begin here at 9:30 A.M. tomorrow.
ALBANY, Jan. 23--The controversial proposal for an upstate sales tax was resubmitted to the Legislature today in a bill containing several features designed to curtail opposition.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 (AP)--The National Football League today gave Commissioner Bert Bell dictatorial power designed to crush attempted fixing of its games, including life banishment of implicated players.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 --Secretary of Agriculture Clinton P. Anderson cleared the potato market today of its huge price-depressing surplus by a departmental order to dump all low-grade or deteriorating potatoes stored under the pricesupport program.

The American occupation forces in Germany and Japan have been reduced to such a level that "we have reached the point of danger," Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Army Chief of Staff, declared last night at the annual dinner of the Bond Club of New York at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Murray W. Garsson issued the following statement tonight in behalf of himself and his brother, Henry M. Garsson, in connection with today's indictment on charges that they conspired to defraud the Government:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--President Truman made it plain today that George C. Marshall, new Secretary of State, will run his department as he sees fit.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended Jan. 18, 1947, totaled 828,060 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Jan. 23 --Three of the top-flight English racquet stars survived the first round of the Tuxedo Gold Racquets tournament, which opened today. Chief among them was John Pawle, British universities champion, who defeated J.R. Pearson of Philadelphia, 15--2, 15--5, 15--7.
Four versions of lighting a living room were offered by four authorities last night at a meeting of the Residence Lighting Forum, in the General Electric Auditorium, 570 Lexington Avenue.

Net assets of Chemical Fund, Inc., an investment company, rose from $14,760,804 to $20,883,536 in the course of last year, F. Eberstadt, president, disclosed yesterday in his annual report to stockholders.

A startling new way of mounting pictures on three-dimensional backgrounds to bring them directly into a room is shown in a series of modern reproductions now at Macy's. Instead of being framed in the conventional way the prints are attached directly to backgrounds in curved rectangular and cube shapes.

Action for a strike poll of New York City's 35,000 public school teachers was postponed yesterday after the Teachers Salary Conference voted to give a "reasonable time" for the State Legislature to enact a permanent salary increase of $450 instead of the $300 temporary rise approved by Governor Dewey.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--The Republican majority leaders in the Senate may be wrong, but they believe they are likely to have less trouble from now on in maintaining their party line on issues before that body. Their narrow but sufficient margin in defeating the Democratic effort yesterday to disband the special War Investigating Committee has persuaded them of this.

The General Electric Company did not smother the production of carbide hard metal compositions, as charged by the Government in an anti-trust suit now on trial in Federal Court, but instead "made this country ready for war."
LONDON, Jan. 23--Clive Duncan, a young British designer, presented his spring models to fashion buyers in London today.

A second book about the top Nazis who were imprisoned in Nuremberg has been written by a psychiatrist. Farrar, Straus will publish on March 26 "Nuremberg Diary," by Capt. G.M. Gilbert, who was a prison psychologist during the entire course of the trials.

Eleven leaders of the wartime armed forces will be honored by Columbia University at a special university convocation at 4 P.M. on Feb. 21, in Low Memorial Library, Dr. Frank D. Fackenthal, acting president of Columbia, announced last night.
The war-wracked remnants of a once proud fleet will help to shape the course of future history in the Mediterranean.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--With higher prices in all groups except foods, average primary market prices rose 0.6 per cent to a new post-war high during the week ended Jan. 18, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

BERLIN, Jan. 12--The French official attitude on Germany at present is that momentary and economic considerations must net be permitted to obscure the main objective in the settlement--security from future German aggression.
FIELDSBORO, N.J., Jan. 23-- With this borough of 550 persons minus all important officials except two Councilmen who do not constitute a quorum, municipal affairs are at a standstill today.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23 -- Through amendments, the American Water Works and Electric Company, Inc., of New York, today brought its recapitalization plan into line with views expressed by the Securities and Exchange Commission in an opinion handed down last month.

A list of twenty-one recommendations to correct fire hazards in the nation's hotels was adopted by the International Association of Fire Chiefs yesterday at the close of its three-day meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Banking syndicates headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., received yesterday the award of four issues of railroad aerial equipment trust certificates aggregating $20,490,000. Competition for the awards brought out twenty-one bids from syndicates headed by ten different managers.

There has been little change in the public attitude toward unmarried mothers since the days when Nathaniel Hawthorne wrote about Hester Prynne in "The Scarlet Letter," Florence Turkington, a lieutenant colonel in the Salvation Army, declared yesterday.

When the additional January Kings County grand jury begins its inquiry on Monday into the escape Nov. 2 of nine men from the Brooklyn City Prison it will study allegations of gambling activities within the institution, District Attorney Miles F. McDonald announced yesterday.

Some immigration statistics made public this week by the State Department, together with others previously announced, make startling reading. Perhaps the most astounding is the report, in an Associated Press summary, that "if the bars were let down 14,000,000 Italians would seek to emigrate to this country."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--Back from a two-week field inspection during which he said he was shocked by the sight of 20,000 Army vehicles slowly rusting away at a single field, Maj. Gen. Everett S. Hughes, Army chief of ordnance, declared today he would urge a revision of plans for proper storage facilities, or junking of much materiel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--President Truman refused today to classify the Senate's action in continuing the War Investigating Committee over his opposition as a rebuff for his Congressional cooperation program. Denying any connection between the two, Mr. Truman said he thought the cooperating program was doing very well.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: We hope that you will find it possible to publish in your paper the following appeal, which has been received by us from Europe.

Two editors of sixteen pulp magazines published in this city have been using stationery in the course of their work with the printed legend "crime does not pay." It was doubtful last night, however, whether they had ever read the motto carefully.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 23--A proposal to establish a Christian Service Committee that would serve as a "trouble shooter" in meeting emergency needs in all parts of the world was approved by the Missions Council of the Congregational Christian Churches today.

In spite of fairly heavy Southern liquidation, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday 7 to 33 points net higher, with the far months relatively stronger than near months. The market started with gains of 12 to 17 points and then sold off on liquidation and some hedge selling.

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 23--Opposition to the decontrol of sugar at this time, careful attention to the problems of installment selling and distribution of frozen foods were highlighted in resolutions passed by the National-American Wholesale Grocers Association in the final session of the 1947 convention today.
Josef Winiewicz, newly appointed Polish Ambassador to the United States, described yesterday the recent elections in his country as "fair and unfettered."

ABOARD MOUNT OLYMPUS, at Little America, Jan. 23 (AP) -- A three-man, helicopter crashed into the ocean and was lost yesterday on a take-off from the carrier Philippine Sea off Scott Island some 700 miles north of here, but its occupants were rescued unharmed.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Jan. 23 --Leading economists of the country were told tonight that it would be advisable for the United States to take measures to reduce the vulnerability of its most concentrated and important atomic bomb targets.

LONDON, Jan. 23--A century of full productive activity lies before the world if it will apply Great Britain's theory of full employment to the problems of international trade, H.A. Marquand, Secretary for Overseas Trade, said today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP)-- Forty high school seniors from sixteen States and the District of Columbia were named today as finalists in the sixth annual Science Talent Search.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 23 (AP)--Tony Skoronski rode four winners at Hialeah Park today, including Bill Ross, who captured the first division of the Spanish Moss Purse in the fifth event, as striking stable help returned to work. Skoronski, a Chicagoan, scored the first jockey's "home run" of the Hialeah season when he piloted Burgoo Maid to victory in the eighth race.
LONDON, Jan. 23--James L. Garvin, one of the greatest independent British editors, died today at his home in Beaconsfield, Buckinghamshire, at the age of 79.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 23-- Despite protests of T.K. Chang, Chinese Consul General here, the daughters of two of China's prominent men were detained aboard ship in San Francisco harbor for two days this week to await posting of bond, it was disclosed tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--The Government asked today that the master portal-to-portal back pay suit be rejected unless the workers could make a stronger case than yet made that their claims to past overtime pay were really substantial and not against the public interest.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 23 -- A petition urging the State Teachers Association House of Delegates to break a 102-year-old precedent by calling an emergency session to fight for higher teachers' salaries was sent to the association today by 300 presidents and legislative chairmen of teachers associations of the southeastern part of the State.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--President Truman is preparing for transmission to Congress next week a message on priority and allocation powers recommended for retention beyond March 31, the expiration date of the Second War Powers Act.

LONDON, Jan. 23 (AP)--Germany and Japan definitely were banned from participation in the 1948 Olympics today when the organizing committee revealed the two Axis nations would not be invited to compete.

ATLANTA, Jan. 23--Funds for the operation of the Georgia Revenue and Highway Departments were ordered held up today by State Treasurer George B. Hamilton as legal complications mounted in the Governorship battle between Herman Talmadge and M.E. Thompson.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--President Truman has asked former President Herbert Hoover to undertake a fact-finding survey of the German economy not because he needs more facts but because he needs facts that will impress the Republicans in Congress.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--The shortage of school teachers will become more aggravated during the year as a result of economic distress caused by the upward trend in prices, Willard E. Givens, executive secretary of the National Education Association, warned today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- A Budget Bureau slash of nearly 20 per cent in the 1947-48 Federal funds for promoting safe civilian flying was uncovered by the House Commerce Committee today in its inquiry into airplane crashes.

Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander said yesterday he would ask the Board of Estimate on Monday for appropriations to create a new post, Chief of Detectives, and appoint four additional inspectors, four deputy inspectors and seven captains.

The many "pre-inventory sale" advertisements appearing in the daily papers these days, provide this recorder with an idea--not a new one--that while business is taking inventory of its goods and chattels this is also a good time to take inventory of the human element in business.

After cutting a wide swath in the Bulldog handicap squash tennis tournament at the Yale Club, Herman C. Schwab, hard-hitting Yale Club newcomer in the game, was brought to the end of his road yesterday by Vincent Furno, veteran Class A star of the Columbia University Club.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The Army-Navy merger program, compromised between the armed services after a long deadlock, was headed tonight toward a bitter jurisdictional dispute in Congress.

DETROIT, Jan. 23--Results of its efforts to coordinate health and welfare activities of the 461 Lutheran agencies which operate in the United States were reported today to the annual meeting of the National Lutheran Council, in session here, by its division of welfare.

Another attempt to overcome the difficulties raised by Russia's continued objection to the American plan for control of the atomic bomb--a plan already accepted in principle by the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission--has been brought forward in certain British quarters.

The Rev. Dr. Harold Hitchcock Kelley, director of the Seamen's Church Institute, 25 South Street, has been chosen as the candidate of both the Anglo-Catholic group and the "low" church group in the Episcopal Diocese of New York to be the permanent chairman of the special convention of the diocese next Tuesday to elect a successor to Bishop William T. Manning.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation, the giant lending agency of the Government, acknowledged today that there were "deficiencies" in its accounting practices.

ROME, Jan. 23--Another step toward re-establishing normal diplomatic relations between Italy and her wartime enemies was made today when Yugoslavia volunteered to appoint a "political representative" to the Italian Government.

RACQUETS is a game to knock your eye out. Played with bats and hard, leather-covered balls in huge, four-walled cement courts, it's faster than any other played afoot, and there actually have been instances of a man losing an optic or consciousness when struck by the ricocheting pellet.

Establishment at Beth Israel Hospital of a new foundation for medical research that will undertake promptly a major effort in the relatively neglected field of hypertension, the greatest killer of all, was announced yesterday by Dr. Maxwell S. Frank, medical director of the hospital.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, opening "motion-picture collection week" of the annual "March of Dimes" drive for the Infantile Paralysis Fund originated by President Roosevelt, appealed to contributors today to give "two dimes instead of one" to assure a victorious campaign.
The first demonstration of a new type of music therapy for the physically handicapped was presented yesterday at the Brooklyn Music School Settlement, 126 Felix Street, Brooklyn.

The Maritime Commission announced yesterday afternoon the names, new owners and registry of 204 more war-built merchant ships on which title passed either to American private owners or foreign nations, under terms of the Merchant Ship Sales Act of 1946, in the final two months of last year.

The Fourth Republic begins to function in France with the transition from provisional government to the first administration formed and installed under the terms of the new Constitution. The transition was difficult in the extreme. France has been in a state of acute political crisis for nearly two years.

Sharply critical of the newspaper publicity given to the Queens victim of a hiccoughing attack, the Queens County Medical Society asserted yesterday that there was "no justification" for the intervention of President Truman in a purely local matter that could have been settled as such.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 24 -- First Air Force Headquarters of the Army Air Forces Defense Command announced today that its combat and service personnel consists of 4,000 reserve officers and National Guardsmen out of 25,000 needed.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 24 -- The Argentine Foreign Office announced today that a decree of President Juan D. Peron had empowered the Government to buy all assets of business concerns in Argentina that formerly belonged to nationals of Axis countries.

New York City's "most bored people" are young girls who came here from out of town to work as clerks and never learned properly how to use their leisure time. Dr. Milton Gabrielsen of the New York University School of Education asserted yesterday.

Stanley Grayson of 173 Riverside Drive, veteran securities promoter who allegedly profited by $100,000 through misrepresentations in the sale of oil royalties, was found guilty yesterday of mail fraud and violations of the Securities and Exchange Act after an eight-week trial before Federal Judge Edward A. Conger.

Christopher (Spud) Elsis, the fourth felon recaptured of the nine men who escaped Jan. 2 from Brooklyn City Prison, was held without bail yesterday in Felony Court on a charge of being an escaped prisoner.

Metalworking plant executives reported here yesterday that prices are in the most confused state in years because of fantastic trends of three categories. These are: (1) Scrap prices; (2) inadequate price information on steel extras; (3) profiteering on sheets and strip steel by speculators.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 24 -- The United States is not in any immediate danger of a business recession, but the country will run into possible economic storms in four or five years unless wages rise, Chester Bowles, former price administrator, said today.

Prices on the stock market managed yesterday to remain on the higher side, although the advan was less pronounced than previously this week. Dealings turne more selective, a few special si uations showed major gains, b the main bulk of the list mov ahead only about 1/2 point.

DETROIT, Jan. 24 -- The AllisChalmers Manufacturing Company it West Allis, Wis., has demanded a housecleaning of the leadership of Local 242 of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, as a condition of settlement of the 272-dayold strike, it was learned today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 24 -- United Nations officials are disappointed with New York's plans for improving the area surrounding the projected world capital site on the East River and have asked for a better "beautifying" program, it was learned today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24 (AP) -- The National Football League, despite a franchise bid by the San Francisco Clippers of the Pacific Coast League, will retain its present 10-club membership for "three or four years," Commissioner Bert Bell said today.

A Southerner born and bred, Thomas Sancton, leads off the Survey Graphic's current symposium on racial segregation. Mr. Sancton's home, like Senator -elect Bilbo's, is in Mississippi. From this vantage point he goes a little further than do many Northern friends of the Negro in advocating federal legislation as a means of forcing a democratic conception of civil rights upon the South.

DHAHRAN, Saudi Arabia, Jan. 24 -- A fat roasted hump of young camel was set before King Ibn Saud of Saudi Arabia last night at an Arabian Night's feast that was the climax of the most colorful spectacle ever witnessed here by the Americans who are pumping oil out of Saudi Arabia's soil.

MONTREAL, Jan. 24 --The Provisional International Civil Aviation Organization will become a fully functioning body on May 6, when its permanent assembly, representing at least forty-seven and possibly fifty-one countries, meets here.

WITH TASK FORCE FRIGID, near Fairbanks, Alaska, Jan. 24 -- Operating in temperatures ranging from thirty-seven to fifty-one below zero over the frozen muskeg of Alaska's Tanana Valley where the sound of an engine had never been heard before nor the weight of a wheel felt, Task Force Frigid concluded today the final phase of a tactical problem by halting a theoretical enemy bent on capturing high ground commanding Fairbanks and the surrounding territory.

LAHORE, Punjab, India, Jan. 24 (AP) -- The Punjab Provincial Government today outlawed the Moslem League's National Guard, a semi-military volunteer body, and arrested eight high ranking League members.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Secretary of State George C. Marshall will attend the conference of the Council of Foreign Ministers in Moscow, March 10, for drafting the German and Austrian peace treaties, the State Department announced today.

WAKE FOREST, N.C., Jan. 24 -- Larks are larks, sparrows are sparrows and buzzards are buzzards, but down here quail are "birds," and according to one old counterpart of Uncle Remus who directed us to a place where a covey was "usin," they'll be here "when dere ain't a drop a balm lef in Gilead."

LONDON, Jan. 24 -- It can be stated on excellent authority today that the British are not going to yield to the Egyptians on the question of the Sudan. Therefore, if reports from Cairo are correct, the controversy will go to the United Nations, and it can also be said that the British feel sure they will win.

Muriel Kerr, who gave a piano recital at Carnegie Hall last night, has been before the public for a good many seasons and seems to have developed a sizable following, judging by the size and disposition of her audience. There is sound reason, for she has a style of her own, which is neat, fastidious and poetic, but not fussy.

DETROIT, Jan. 24 -- The National Lutheran Council concluded its annual meeting today with the creation of a Division of American Missions, designed specifically for the purpose of presenting the true Christian approach to the Jewish people.
ALBANY, Jan. 24 -- The State Banking Department announced today its approval of several increases of capital and one decrease in State banks.

A set of six principles, formulated by the Executive Committee of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women as a guide to Government officials and legislators in understanding the federation's point of view, was made public yesterday following a closed meeting at the Barclay Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The International Bank, organized as the $8,000,000,000 fountain of reconstruction loans for war - torn countries, faced today an uncertain and critical problem in organization, following the death last night of its vice president and acting president, Harold D. Smith.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Senator Joseph A. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, proposed safeguards for the closed shop today without an outright prohibition.

The exact timing is not clear; but apparently at about the very moment that the editor of Pravda was preparing to return enthusiastically to the attack on Mr. Bevin -- on the ground that he had "renounced" the Anglo-Soviet treaty -- Mr. Stalin was assuring the British Foreign Secretary that they "share the same viewpoint" about that agreement.

Low-rent housing and slum clearance will be held back by at least a year if the Legislature follows Governor Dewey's recommendation, made in his annual message, that "no further [housing] bond issue should be contemplated." The facts are clearly set forth by former State Housing Commissioner Edward Weinfeld in a letter published today in another column on this page.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Jan. 24 -- The new $10,000,000 Mill Creek barrier dam was dedicated today, the tenth anniversary of "Black Sunday," the grimmest day in the Ohio River flood of 1937. Senator Robert A. Taft, speaking to several hundred business men at a chamber of commerce luncheon, paid tribute to the Army engineers for the barrier-dam job, and said:

CHICAGO, Jan. 24 -- Nearly 1,600 delegates to the national mobilzation conference of the Zionist Organization of America were registered today and assigned to discussion panels for Sunday's sessions. Sabbath services will be held tomorrow morning for visitors.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 24 -- Partly because Britain has not yet joined the project, the outlook for establishment of a new international agency to take over from the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration the care of refugees and displaced persons is becoming doubtful, it was learned today.

Republican Representative Katharine St. George of the Twentyninth Congressional District said yesterday that she and Republican leaders in the House had been told by a high naval official that the Army and Navy Department budget figures could be slashed by 20 per cent without danger.
An acrobatic thief with an armed confederate spent sixty seconds in the business office of The Brooklyn Eagle yesterday and walked out with a $20,000 payroll.

NANKING, Jan. 24 (AP) -- ProGovernment dispatches from Manchuria said today that Chinese troops had formally taken over the hydroelectric installations the Russians had been garrisoning on the Yalu River northeast of Antung.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Jan. 24 -- Franz von Papen went on trial as a "major" offender under the German, denazification law today before a German denazification tribunal. His trial is being held in a schoolhouse a mile from the Nuremberg Palace of Justice where he was acquitted by the International Military Tribunal on war crimes charges last October.

ATHENS, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Cabinet posts filled by Premier Maximos in his announcement to Parliament tonight, with the parties represented in the coalition, are: Vice Premier and Foreign Minister -- Constantin Tsaldaris, Populist. Vice Premier and War Minister -- Sophocles Venizelos, Venizelist Liberal.

The New York Stock Exchange outlined yesterday to its members how they will be required to conduct their transactions under the amended supplement to Regulation T of the Federal Reserve Board. The amendment will restore 75 per cent margin trading in sercurities on Feb. 1.

Pointing out that disposal of surplus textile products is a contributory factor to lessened volume of some boys' and men's wear manufacturers, Jules Goldstein, secretary and counsel of the National Heavy Outerwear Association, has called upon eight other trade associations to protest present methods of Government surplus sales.

TOKYO, Jan. 24 -- Six months after the conversations started, a wool deal between the Occupation and Australia is reported to be about to be concluded. It will involve between 250,000 and 300,000 bales of low-grade wool at a price of about $100 a bale.
The American Jewish Committee will open its fortieth annual meeting today at the Commodore Hotel. Five hundred Jewish leaders from all parts of the country are expected to attend.

The United Nations should exert moral persuasion on Russia to liberate Lithuania and "other oppressed small nations," the Most Rev. John Mark Gannon, treasurer of the Administrative Board of Bishops of the National Catholic Welfare Conference, declared here yesterday.
Four more signed contracts dropped into the Horace Stoneham hopper yesterday and a bit more optimism dripped from Garry Schumacher, the Giants' publicity man, as he made the announcement.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Jan. 24 -- Flashing surprising strength in the opening three events, Dartmouth's skiers tonight held a slim margin over New Hampshire's Wildcats as the sixteenth annual Middlebury College carnival got under way.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 24 -- In protest against the membership of Franco Spain in the century-old International Penal and Penitentiary Commission, the Social Commission of the Economic and Social Council voted here today to withdraw an invitation for a representative of the penal group to take part in United Nations deliberations on crime prevention.
PARIS, Jan. 24 -- The French Foreign Ministry proposed today the establishment of a German Federation of States in which federal control would be limited to economic and financial matters.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24 -- Armour Co., meat packers, declared today a dividend of $10 a share to apply on the arrearage on the company's $6 prior preferred stock. It is payable Feb. 14 to stockholders of record of Feb. 3. The payment will amount to $5,329,960.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24 -- Until it is proved otherwise, Leslie MacMitchell still is the king of the indoor milers. The Bronx express made a runaway of his first 1947 start at the eight-furlong route tonight. His withering twolap blast at the finish left Rune Gustafsson far behind in the American debut of the 4:04.6 outdoor miler from Sweden.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 24 -- By unanimous vote the Indian Constituent Assembly adopted a resolution today calling for the appointment of fifty persons to a committee dealing with the "fundamental rights" of minorities and tribal areas.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Here is the vote by which the Senate today approved an eight months' study of small business problems by a special committee:

Arriving on the United States liner Marine Marlin for his first visit to this country, Dr. Kazys V. Grinius, 80-year-old ex-President of Lithuania, said yesterday that it was his firm belief his country would once again become an independent republic, free of Russian dominance.
TOKYO, Jan. 24 -- The trial of former Premier Hideki Tojo and twenty-five others was adjourned today to Monday, when American and Japanese defense counsel will ask dismissals of the indictments.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 24 -- The United States Steel Corporation and the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, agreed today to extend the existing wage contract covering some 150,000 employes to April 30. The pact normally would have expired Feb. 15.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- New research studies into tuberculosis therapy and mental health problems were announced today by the United States Public Health Service.

If Joseph Forman, Ulster County Democratic leader and former corporation counsel of Kingston, wants a jury of farmers when he goes on trial in Federal Court on Feb. 4 it can be obtained in Manhattan, Bronx and Westchester Counties, United States Attorney John F.X. McGohey asserted yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24 -- Production of paper boxes during 1946 exceeded the 2,000,000-ton mark for the first time in the industry's history, A.E. Murphy, executive director of the Folding Paper Box Association, said today in announcing the final estimate of output.

The Negro problem "is not insolvable if the American people enter upon and support a constructive program in education," Mrs. George A. Wyeth, former president of the Women's National Republican Club, declared yesterday.

Langston Moffett, whose first novel, "Devil by the Tail," will be published by Lippincott on Monday, will have a first one-man showing of his paintings at the Joseph Luyber Galleries, at the Hotel Brevoort, on Tuesday. The exhibition will run until Feb. 15.

ALBANY, Jan. 24 -- New grounds to question the wisdom of the blanket civil service preference, extended to war veterans by constitutional amendment in 1945, was seen today in the announcement made of results of State police promotion examinations.

MOSCOW, Jan. 24 -- The United States plan for the control of atomic energy was assailed today as part of an alleged policy of procrastination whose aim was to postpone international control of the atomic bomb while the United States continued bomb production.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The Senate Republican leadership won its second voting test of strength today as the new Majority rejected an appeal from one of its own members, Charles W. Tobey of New Hampshire, to revolt against "those who are using the party for their own advancement."

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Saturday, Jan. 25 -- The House of Assembly voted, 82 to 46, to approve Prime Minister Jan Christiaan Smuts' presentation of the Southwest African and Indian issues before the United Nations General Assembly.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24 (AP) -- An order of Federal Judge John P. Barnes, discharging two reorganization managers whom he previously had appointed for the Alton Railroad Company, was reversed today by the United States Circuit Court of Appeals.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Three Alaskan steamship companies which have threatened to discontinue service unless they have higher rates when the Government returns the lines March 1 are expected to present an interim plan to Congressmen here Tuesday.

MOSCOW, Jan. 24 -- Francis Cardinal Spellman and Cardinals in England, Poland, Hungary, Germany and the Netherlands are leading the Vatican's "struggle against democracy," disguised as an anti-Soviet, anti-Communist drive, according to an article in New Times today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The House Committee on Expenditures in the Executive Departments voted today to join its Senate counterpart in an investigation of surplus war property disposal.

Ground-breaking ceremonies fo the 300-bed James Ewing Memorial Hospital, at First Avenue from Sixty-seventh to Sixty eighth Streets, took place yesterday afternoon in the presence of distinguished gathering of city officials, physicians, public health authorities, industrialists and leaders in many other walks of life.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Jan. 24 -- Maj. A. Ronald Taylor, British Army - Navy champion, stunned a gallery of racquets fans here today by easily defeating his fellowcountryman, John Pawle, British universities titleholder, in the second round of the Tuxedo Gold Racquets tournament.

LONDON, Jan. 24 -- The reaction of the gold-share section in the stock markets today when the terms of the leases granted to the African European Investment Company became known was one of disappointment to speculators. Higher prices were quoted at the start, but it was not easy to sell shares in any quantity and a sharp decline was recorded in ate trading.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 24 (U.P.) -- British Ambassador Sir Ronald Ian Campbell called on Egyptian Premier Mahmoud Fahmy Nokrashy Pasha tonight and submitted a message from the British Government that was believed a final conciliatory effort to keep AngloEgyptian talks alive.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 24 -- Not man but God won the victory over Hitler, the Rev. Dr. Martin Niemoeller declared tonight before a capacity congregation of 2,000 persons at the First Presbyterian Church. His topic was "The Gospel Empowered Through Persecution."

Better Business Bureau Active Indicating a considerable increase in interest in the Better Business Bureau of New York City, 24,596 inquiries and complaints were received by the bureau last year, it was announced yesterday by H. J. Kenner, general manager.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 24 -- Charles Laughton was signed today by Paramount to appear with Ray Milland in "The Big Clock," which Jonathan Latimer has written from a mystery novel by Kenneth Searing, purchased by the studio last June for a reported $45,000.

United States Attorney Don Miller, a member of Notre Dame's Four Horsemen of yesteryear, who now heads the Department of Justice's drive through sports against juvenile delinquency, told a diversified group at the New York A.C. yesterday that his executive committee had started a campaign to enlist sports notables in the movement.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- President Truman praised the Women's Patriotic Conference as "performing a most useful public service," as women representing twenty-nine organizations assembled today.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 24 -- The British Government in Palestine has reached the saturation point so far as terrorism is concerned and is prepared to clamp down with the severest measures at the next outbreak. The defense against terrorism is placed squarely on local Zionists.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 --Plan for the utilization of vibrations, including those in the supersonic range, to dissipate fog and of infrared radiation for the de-icing of windshields, thus reducing to a minimum these major hazards of land, sea and air transport, are among the 356 inventions for which patents were issued this week by the United States Patent Office.

We have had many disappointments in our well-meant efforts to help China solve her political perplexities. But none can doubt our motive or the humane usefulness of trying to provide more and better medical care for the stricken Chinese people, millions of whom are remote from hospital or doctor.

MOSCOW, Jan. 24 -- The peoples of Europe and "first of all the Soviet people" demand fulfillment of the plan for German reparations and the end of sabotage and distortion of that plan by the Americans and British, it was declared here today in the longest and bitterest protest yet to appear on the problem.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Former Representative Andrew J. May of Kentucky and the other three men who were accused yesterday by a Federal grand jury of conspiring to defraud the United States Government, pleaded not guilty today. They were held under a $2,000 bond each for trial on March 19.

A 33-year-old divorced mother was believed yesterday to be the first parent to be taken into custody by the city for neglecting an offspring when an old but revised section of the Penal Law was invoked for the first time. She was charged with contributing to the delinquency of her 14-year-old son, who had been arrested Wednesday for wounding three persons with a rifle.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- John R. Steelman, Presidential assistant, tonight hailed the extension of contracts between the CIO steel workers and the U.S. Steel Corporation as "a very fine move on the part of all concerned."

Marine air conditioning has been developed in the past decade to the point where satisfactory shipboard performance has become commonplace, H.E. Parker, engineer of the shipbuilding division of Bethlehem Steel Company, said last night.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24 -- Important untapped sources of uranium oxide, vital to the manufacture of the atomic bomb or development of atomic power, are virtually under the nose of Russia in near-by Sweden, one of the country's noted scientists, Dr. Gustav Egloff, told 800 chemists today at a conference at Northwestern University's Technological Institute.

HALIFAX, N.S., Jan. 24 (AP) -- Two crew members were seriously injured and four passengers, including a service woman, suffered minor injuries tonight when a United States Navy Air Transport Service Dakota plane overshot the airport near here and caught fire.

LONDON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Following are the texts, as made public by the British Foreign Office, of the messages exchanged between foreign Secretary Bevin and Premier Stalin about the twenty-year treaty of alliance between Britain and the Soviet Union:

Plans for a twenty-story store and office building at 101-07 East Fifty-ninth Street and 503-09 Park Avenue were filed yesterday by Park Avenue Properties, Inc., of 2 Lafayette Street, the owner. Emory Roth, architect, estimated the cost at $l,20O,000.

Raising the salaries of staff nurses of the city's Health Department was declared an essential step in preventing further curtailment of public health nursing service at a meeting yesterday of the board of directors of the National Organization for Public Health Nursing at 268 Madison Avenue.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 24 -- For the first year, the International Children's Emergency Fund will need $450,000,000 to finance its relief program for 20,000,000 Youngsters in war-devastated areas.

The two top-seeded players, F. Barry Ryan Jr. of the host club, No. 1, and J.B. Rose of the Princeton Club, No. 2, lived up to their ratings yesterday as they advanced into the final round of the Bulldog handicap squash tennis tournament, annual Yale Club fixture.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 24 (AP) -- Showing a fondness for running on grass, Gustave Ring's Argentinebred filly Grillette scored her first success in this country today when she captured the Orange Blossom purse with ease by two lengths at Hialeah Park.

Pierre Luboshutz and Genia Nemenoff, duo-pianists, provided their large audience with a series of superlative performances at their recital last night at Town Hall. In a highly varied program that ranged from Mozart to the moderns, the two artists invested their work with a grasp of style, imaginative insight, and taste, not easily rivaled by other teams of the kind.

Charging that Governor Dewey had grossly deceived the public in his statement on teachers' temporary salary increases, leaders of teacher organizations demanded yesterday that the Governor make public all the facts.

Radio manufacturers will produce at least 2,000,000 frequency modulation sets this year, virtually a tenfold increase over those turned out in 1946, it was announced yesterday by R.C. Cosgrove, president of the Radio Manufacturers Association and vice president of the Crosley Corporation.

Important changes in the cast of "Nozze di Figaro" last night in the Metropolitan Opera House were those of Martial Singher, who made his first appearance there this season as Figaro, and Claramae Turner's first Marcellina. The performance was smooth in its stage business and sure and lively in the ensembles.

Despite the fact he fought the last half of the battle with a cut and swollen left eye, Herbie Kronowitz, Coney Island middleweight, last night won a ten-round decision over Billy Walker of Saybrook, Conn., in the St. Nicholas Arena before a crowd of 3,304.

BERLIN, Jan. 24 -- Anti-semitism in Germany is as strong as ever and if the Rev. Martin Niemoller denies it exists, he has lost contact with the people, according to Rabbi Barnett R. Brickner of New York, now touring Europe for the United Palestine Appeal.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24 -- Brokers placed a moderately bullish construction on a report of the Department of Agriculture issued today showing 39,000,000 fewer bushels of wheat in all positions in this country on Jan. 1 as compared with a year before.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Jan. 24 (AP) -- The General Electric Company called today for "corrective labor legislation" to restore what it termed the "balance of industrial relationships" but warned that "excess is no solution." In a report to its 248,424 stockholders, the company said:

BOSTON, Jan. 24 -- The twentyfifth anniversary of the nursery school movement in the United States and the Nursery Training School of Boston was celebrated tonight by alumnae at a reception honoring Dr. Abigal Adams Eliot, founder and director of the Boston school.

WARSAW, Jan. 24 -- The American and British Ambassadors here, Arthur Bliss Lane and Victor F. W. Cavendish-Bentinck, are preparing reports on the elections that confirm nearly all the charges on which Stanislaw Mikolajczyk, Peasant party leader has said he would ask the Polish Supreme Court to annul the elections.

New Capital Market The new market for capital was occupied mostly this week with municipal bonds and railroad equipment -trust certificates. Of twelve bond issues totaling $85,013,000 that were offered, seven amounting to $51,523,000 were municipal; four, $20,490,000, were railroad issues, and one, $13,000,000, was a public utility.

A suspended detective and his former partner, a recently retired member of the force, were arraigned yesterday in Kings County Court on an indictment charging conspiracy, attempted bribery and unlawfully accepting fees.

DETROIT, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Tami Mauriello, the Bronx Bulldozer, floored John Thomas, New York heavyweight, four times in the first round tonight, then won on a technical knockout with three more knockdowns in the second. Mauriello weighed 201 pounds, Thomas 192.

ATHENS, Jan. 24 -- A new Greek Government under the Premiership of Demetrios Maximos, 74year-old former Governor of the Bank of Greece and a member of the royalist Populist party, was sworn in tonight by King George II.

LANSING, Mich., Jan. 24 -- The 1947 Oldsmobile in twelve body styles was presented today by the Oldsmobile division of General Motors Corporation. Sturdiness of construction and economy of operation were emphasized in the company announcement of three series.

LONDON, Saturday, Jan. 25 (U.P.) -- Premier Stalin has turned down a suggestion by Britain that he consider exchanging officers of the British and Soviet Armies, holding that such measures "might be interpreted as preparation for war," Tass, Soviet news agency, said today.

Robert H. Jackson, Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court, declared in an address here yesterday that from the trial of the major Nazi leaders in Nuremberg may develop a system of international law that will establish the doctrine that wars of aggression are illegal and criminal.

"THE NEON WILDERNESS,"* by Nelson Algren, isn't exactly what you would call a cheerful book, though there is some humor in it. The humor itself is apt to be briskly grim. For in the main this is a collection of stark tales from the murky depths, a chapbook of the hopeless and the twisted and the damned.
A new method of judging Pulitzer Prizes in journalism was announced yesterday by Carl W. Ackerman, Dean of Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism.

Good to fair results in the clearance of seasonal ready-to-wear stocks in many sections of the country was reported here yesterday. The business being done, of course is of the forced draft variety with mark-downs providing promotional stimulus. In some areas, however, consumer demand has been such that some retailers are trying to replace stocks.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Twenty -five European opera singers were stranded here today, awaiting either an angel or money to get back home. The financial angel -- with, at least $60,000 in his jeans -- was needed to enable Impresario Ottavio Scotto's United States Opera Company to open in Chicago's civic opera house next Monday with a performance of Pucccini's "Turandot."

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 24 -- John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, told the Bankers Club of Pittsburgh tonight that more than $2,000,000,000 had been recovered in the Treasury's income tax evasion drive.

A discussion of housing problems, and the way private and public forces may cooperate toward their solution, took place yesterday. Meeting in the office of Herman T. Stichman, leaders of several real estate groups conferred with the State Housing Commissioner and Robert F. Wagner Jr., City Commissioner of Housing and Buildings.

Twelve instead of only nine concerts will be given next Summer by the Boston Symphony Orchestra at its Berkshire Festival Concerts, it has been announced by Serge Koussevitzky, music director of the orchestra, from Symphony Hall, Boston.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Jan. 24 -- The historic Gardiner Manor House, situated on Gardiner's Island several miles northeast of this township and in possession of the Gardiner family for 300 years, was destroyed by flames early this morning.

LONDON, Jan. 24 -- Premier Stalin has fully accepted the British Government's view that Foreign Secretary Bevin's recent remarks on British foreign policy did not repudiate the British-Soviet treaty of alliance, but has suggested that the pact must be changed in some respects before it can be extended.
An unprecedented peacetime tide of rubber is flowing into New York and other Atlantic Coast ports, shipping companies disclosed yesterday.

M. Lee Marshall, chairman of the board of Continental Baking Corporation, accepted yesterday the New York City campaign chairmanship of the Greek War Relief Association's drive in the metropolitan area for $2,500,000 toward its national goal of $12,-000,000.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The Associated Austrian Relief ask the courtesy of some space in order to question some statements on the Austrian situation which Ira A. Hirschmann gave to the press on his return from a special mission in Europe for UNRRA, as reported under the caption "Austrian Attacks on Jews Forecast."

The annual dinner-dance in aid of the Blue Ridge School of Virginia will be given Friday in the grand ballroom of the Pierre under the auspices of the New York auxiliary of the beneficiary. Mrs. Richard K. Hines heads the benefit committee.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The Preparatory Commission of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization proposed today a world food program explicitly placing the responsibility for future international action upon voluntary cooperation by individual nations.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In his recent message to the Legislature Governor Dewey refused to recommend additional loan funds for low-rent housing and slum clearance, stating that "of the 300 million dollars set as the goal and authorized by the people, there remains 272 million dollars of authorized bonds still to be issued.

As the basis of a strong campaign to restore discounts to their normal figure, a study will be made to determine those lines in which discounts have been reduced or eliminated, it was announced yesterday by Lew Hahn, president of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

Albert Merlis and Siegfried Hermann and two companies that they owned were found guilty by a Federal court jury yesterday of having defrauded the Government by using forged and counterfeit meat ration checks for 12,000,000 points and having obtained illegally $263,000 in meat subsidies.

Earl Bunting, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, urged yesterday the immediate end of all the Government's remaining war controls and emergency powers over business and industry that cannot be proved essential to a sound foreign policy or national security.

The scientific acumen of two detectives of the mobile unit of the Police Scientific Laboratory early yesterday morning brought about the quick arrest of a 17-year-old boy in the fatal beating of an unidentified man in the hallway at 101 West 112th Street and the detention of his older brother as a material witness.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- House Republican policy makers arranged today to meet early next week to decide on the type of labor-control bill they would support.

The proposed Army-Navy merger compromise was endorsed yesterday by the Air Force Association as "a definite step in the right direction." The association is composed of officers and men who served in the Army Air Forces during the recent war.

Stepping momentarily outside the realm of American art, in which, from the beginning of its career, it has played a role of distinguished leadership, the Whitney Museum, 10 West Eighth Street, acts as host to a large group of modern French painters
WASHINGTON. Jan. 24 -- Efforts by New York State and New York City Democratic party officials to replace the present leadership of Tammany Hall were brought to the White House today.
LONDON, Jan. 24 -- The British started putting into use today the new international identity documents that are to serve displaced persons in place of passports.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Congress will keep a close watch on the activities of the United States Atomic Energy Commission, Senator Bourke B. Hickenlooper, Republican, of Iowa, promised today as he was elected chairman of the Congressional Joint Committee on Atomic Energy.

In his annual report to the Board of Overseers, President Conant of Harvard offers an interesting proposal. He suggests that the local communities, with the aid of Federal funds where necessary, establish two-year terminal colleges for their students. Under this plan thousands of men and women, now unable to get into the traditional fouryear college, could receive a higher education.

PARIS, Jan. 24 -- While official silence continued on the operation begun Sunday to reach besieged Hue, capital of Annam in IndoChina, it was learned today that the drive had slowed considerably after its initial success.
Stores Hold Trade Gain Retail trade here held its rate of gain this week about in line with the preceding week. Department -store volume was estimated at about 20 per cent above last year.

Lieut. Gen. Ira Eaker, Deputy Chief of Air Forces, earnestly and eloquently described in an address this week the hazardous situation in which the country finds itself at this moment, and the still more hazardous situation it would face as a result of neglect of adequate air defense.

Frank Mangiapane, captain at N.Y.U. last season, and Bob Fitzgerald, ex-Seton Hall star, will make their debuts with the Knickerbockers tonight when the New Yorkers tackle the Boston Celtics in a Basketball Association of America test at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory.
LONDON, Jan. 24 -- The Colonial Office confirmed tonight that Foreign Secretary Bevin would head the Government's delegation to the Palestine conference, resuming here on Monday.

Losing early moderate gains, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday 5 to 21 points net lower than the day before. Starting unchanged to 7 points up, it worked up to gains of 4 to 27 points on short covering, some small trade buying orders and talk of increased export business.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Senate kers of amendments to the ges and Hours Law made plain ay that they would maintain s issue at the head of their "urt" list, despite the strong intertion by the Government itself inst portal-to-portal back-pay ms.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24 -- The amended reorganization plan of the Interstate Power Company, a subsidiary of the Ogden Corporation, was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Senator Kenneth D. McKellar of Tennessee is making a fight against the confirmation of David E. Lilienthal as chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission and of Gordon R. Clapp to succeed Mr. Lilienthal as chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority. Senator McKellar is no longer the presiding officer of the upper House, with the prerogatives of a Vice President.
Dan Topping's football Yankees scored a clean hit yesterday when it was announced that his club has just signed Ben Raimondi, University of Indiana backfield star, to a three-year contract.

Six hours after it left a quickfreeze plant in Cuba, the first sizable shipment of frog legs and lobster tails to come from that country arrived at La Guardia Field yesterday, the cargo of a Pan American Airlines DC-4.

ABOARD MOUNT OLYMPUS, in the Ross Sea, Jan. 24 -- During the past week, according to plan, three ships of the Navy's Antarctic expedition sailed into the Bay of Whales and tied up. No other visitors were expected, but last night one arrived vast and unpredictable.

Without making any reference to the recent prison outbreaks, Albert Williams, Commissioner of Correction, asked Thomas J. Patterson, Budget Director, yesterday for an increase of $1,751,491 to operate his department for the fiscal year beginning July 1.

BERLIN, Jan. 24 -- United States Military Government officials complained today that an unpublicized pact between Berlin trade union officials and the former city government was interfering with their efforts to run the United States sector of Berlin.

ATLANTA, Jan. 24 -- Herman Talmadge, defending his right to the Governorship of Georgia over his rival claimant, M.E. Thompson, declared in a radio address to the people of the State tonight that "the present revolt against your mandate at the ballot box is a crusade of radicals, and its ugly roots are fixed in soil outside Georgia, its purpose determined to destroy the dominance of the white race in the South."

The Erie Railroad yesterday reported for 1946 a net income of $2,994,724 after charges and taxes, equal, after preferred dividend payments, to 40 cents a common share. This compares with $5,797,185, or $1.54 a common share, in 1945.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Republicans and Democrats moved toward common ground today on the issue of reducing personal income taxes.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Jan. 24 -- Financial and public economists agreed today at the annual forecasting session of the American Economic Association that the United States was in the midst of a very large and important inflation boom. They agreed also that the boom would reach its peak this year, with many holding that the crest would be reached by midyear or early in the fall.

Unable to obtain a theatre for his production of "Lovely Me," which must vacate the Coronet tonight to make room for the incoming "All My Sons," David Lowe has decided to close down the Jacqueline Susann-Beatrice Cole comedy.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 24 (AP) -- E.J. (Dutch) Harrison of York, Pa., posting a 6-under-par 65, set a sizzling pace today to lead a star-studded field in the first round of the 72-hole $10,000 Phoenix open golf tournament.

VIENNA, Jan. 23 (Delayed) -- The Austrian Chancellory is on edge waiting for a Russian offer for settlement of Soviet claims under the Potsdam agreement for the transfer of German holdings to Russia on the reparations account.

Discontent With Winter The sixty days following the winter solstice have a bad name in folklore. That bad name, like so many other things, began with the Greeks. Hesiod, who was writing poetry in Boeotia in central Greece in the eighth century B.C., was the first European we know of to voice complaints about the winter weather.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- A moderate easing of rent controls through the liberalization of provisions applying to landlords suffering an economic hardship was disclosed today by Maj. Gen. Philip B. Fleming, Director of the Office of Temporary Controls.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 24 (AP) -- Forbidden C, an 18-1 shot, ran down the favored Shim Malone in the stretch today to capture a $10,000 allowance race for 3-year-olds at Santa Anita. The race was regarded as a conditioner for the $100,000 Santa Anita Derby March 8.

The first book printed in the Colonies, the extremely rare Bay Psalm Book, will be auctioned at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street at 8 P.M. Tuesday. The auction is by order of the Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney Trust, and the proceeds will go to the North Country Community Hospital of Glen Cove, N.Y.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 25 (AP)-- A high-scoring Canisius quintet routed Long Island University's cagers, 72--48, tonight in Memorial Auditorium as near riots broke out twice in the closing minutes. Georgetown nipped Niagara, 66--64, in overtime in the first game before 9,748 fans.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP)-- James J. Laughlin, Washington attorney, said that an informer's suit was filed in the Federal Court at Knoxville today accusing the State of Tennessee and some oil companies of illegally collecting taxes on gasoline and oil shipped into the state for use of the armed forces.

WE had long entertained the suspicion that American opera, in the vital contemporaneous sense of that word, would be more likely to come from our popular theatre than from our august temples of the operatic art.

On the assumption that "portalto-portal" back pay, as well as amounts awarded as liquidated damages, can be claimed by way of refund or credit by employers, and that both classes of payments will be taxable to employe-recipients, this column estimated that the Treasury would have to stand approximately 40 per cent of such amounts required to be paid by employers.

IF Mr. Cain's fame were not so well established, the title of his present work might be misleading. He is not writing for garden lovers, nor quite in the spirit of Maeterlinck's "The Blue Bird." The only insects in his story are the human order.

TALK is around town of the rising prices tagged on books and just how much they will have to rise to keep publishing activities wholesome. The unlegislated ceiling for the novel has been $3. Well, it's possible that publishers, in some cases, will have to go through that ceiling.

Howard J. Rose of the Princeton Club yesterday took the measure of F. Barry Ryan Jr. of the host club, in the final-round match of the fourth annual Bulldog handicap squash tennis tournament at the Yale Club, 15--11, 8--15, 17-- 14.

WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 25 -- Westchester County has immediate minimum need of 3,600 new singlefamily houses and 9,680 additional apartment units, a survey conducted by the Westchester County Realty Board indicated yesterday.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, and Charles E. Wilson, president of General Motors Corporation, speaking at Washington before the United States Conference of Mayors, both had occasion to touch on the possibility that the present labor situation could lead to State Socialism.

The Nation Takes Stock The nation last week was taking stock of its economy. At the same time the Republicans, who won control of Congress last November on issues of domestic policy, was getting down to the real work of hammering out a domestic program.
Fiorello H. La Guardia predicted yesterday that the State Legislature would ignore again the need to reduce the "archaic, cruel and unconscionable" interest rates on small loans.
To the Music Editor: A letter containing some extraordinary statements involving "a Russian-American music company of this city" appeared in the Jan. 12 Music Page of THE TIMES.

The threat of a power shortage, due to the inability of turbinegenerator manufacturers to cope with the record demand for such equipment, looms as the only major cloud on an otherwise bright horizon for the electric light and power companies during 1947.

One of the largest benefit entertainments of the winter season will take place on the night of Feb. 4 in the Grand Ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria, where the Outdoor Cleanliness Association will present The Winter Ball as the first in a series of annual fetes.
During the past six months there has been considerable discussion, argument and speculation regarding the waterfowl situation and the factors responsible for the decline in the waterfowl population.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 25-- Written invitations to all seafaring and waterfront unions of the Pacific, Atlantic and Gulf Coasts to send delegates to a maritime conference in New York on March 15 were in the mail today from Louis Goldblatt, secretary pro tem of the Committee for Maritime Unity.

With amortization and satisfaction of mortgages in recent years proceeding at a rapid pace, savings banks in this State have turned more toward housing developments in the last few years as a source of investment for the employment of their mounting deposits, the annual report of the Savings Banks Trust Company indicated.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 25--Job reclassifications entailing $32,000,000 in back pay and wage increases of about $17,000,000 annually were disclosed today in simultaneous announcements by the United States Steel Corporation and the CIO United Steelworkers of America.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 25-- New York University, Manhattan College and Army bagged the major share of the honors in the fourth annual West Point relays before a crowd of 4,000 in the cavernous Field House today.

IF a social agency had decided to replace a routine case worker with a sensitive novelist and had given the latter unlimited time to study the lives of a low-income group, the result might have been similar to "Families in Trouble."

The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association will open its 1947 season with inter-club team matches the last Tuesday in April. This year the association is inaugurating inter-club matches to be known as a "Cup Series," patterned after the system that has been so successful in the Philadelphia district.

HOLLYWOOD. CHARLES CHAPLIN is a taciturn and unapproachable man while his pictures are in production, but last week he relaxed and invited this reporter to visit him at the laboratory where he was recording the musical score for his new photoplay, "Monsieur Verdoux, a Comedy of Murders."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Prof. Sumner Slichter of Harvard University has pointed out that the Nathan report on "A National Wage Policy for 1947" is useful because of the issues it raises. The issues cannot be clearly drawn until the evidence relating to wage-rate increases has been carefully evaluated.

In 1938 Dr. Robert Broom of the Transvaal Museum, Pretoria, South Africa, found in South Africa the petrified bones of two "man apes." One of these he christened Plesianthropus or "Near Man," the other Paranthropus or "Beside Man." Broom came to the conclusions that they were important links in the evolution of man.

LONDON, Jan. 25 -- The Nazi party has recovered from the first shock of Germany's defeat and is quietly reorganizing for return to power through capturing control of democratic institutions set up by the Allies.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Jan. 25--A fighting New Hampshire unit made a gallant comeback in the classic ski events, jumping and cross-country and the combined, to overtake the Big Green squad from Hanover today and win the sixteenth Middlebury College carnival, one of the finest in its varied history.

PUBLIC faith in the efficacy of collective bargaining tends to rise and fall with each shift in strike totals. In the period since V-J Day the recurrence of crippling walkouts has brought a general feeling that there is something basically wrong with our whole approach to managementlabor relations.

LONDON, Jan. 25--The deadlock between Canada and the Soviet Union over the Canadian demand to be heard on procedural matters of the German peace treaty continued unbroken today and prevented any meeting of the Big Four Foreign Ministers' deputies for Germany.

Business volume shows a marked tendency to stabilize, with high production and sales seen for several months, if not interrupted by work stoppages, members of the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents revealed in a report released for publication today.

IN the saga of medical discovery no story is more thrilling, no search for a weapon in man's fight against disease more productive in lives saved than the discovery of insulin in 1921 by Dr. Frederick Banting and Dr. Charles H. Best, and its use in a human patient early in 1922.

IN days when the pressure on Franco Spain is mounting, the verse of Pablo Neruda acquires a timeliness quite apart from its essential merit. The distinguished Chilean diplomat-poet was in Madrid during the Civil War--and his feeling for the Loyalist cause burns intensely through most of these rhymeless lines.

THE attempt to reconcile science and religion--and explain evil in the world--does not date from the advent of the atom bomb, but Fannie Hurst must have had Hiroshima on her mind when she set out to grapple with the problem in her latest novel.

Nations participating in the proposed international atomic control system have the obligation to take collective action against violators "whether or not the Security Council acts," Warren R. Austin, American representative on the Council and on the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission, declared last night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25--Senator Kenneth McKellar, Democrat, of Tennessee, named twenty-two former and present employes of the Tennessee Valley Authority today as "well-known Communists." Continuing his campaign to prevent Senate confirmation of Gordon R. Clapp's appointment as TVA board chairman, Mr. McKellar made the accusation as chief questioner of Mr. Clapp before the Senate Public Works Committee.

TORONTO -- American tourists no longer have to change their drinking habits when they come visiting in Ontario. Beginning the first of this year it became possible for the first time since pre-prohibition days to buy liquor by the glass in hotel dining lounges and cocktail bars.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 25 -- Spearheaded by substitute Don Casey of Bogota, N.J., an aggressive University of Pennsylvania quintet swept from behind in the last 15 minutes to hand Cornell a 44-38 setback in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game before 4,500 in the Palestra tonight.

ERIC HATCH, the creator of "My Man Godfrey" and sundry other well-done versions, has picked on the war for the subject of his latest foible. No one need fear that the war has greatly modified the characters, of Mr. Hatch's creation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25--The fight of rival claimants to the Governor's chair in Georgia has renewed interest in the question of the Presidential succession. Georgia's troubles appear, however, to have broadened, rather than to have hastened, the search for the right solution.
