With "sale" merchandise drawing customers to coat and suit departments, general activity in department stores was good last week, according to a survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

ANDREW J. VOLSTEAD, on Jan. 20, at Granite Falls, Minn. Age 87. Member House of Representatives 1902-22; chairman of Judiciary Committee which drew the enabling law (Volstead Act) for enforcement of Prohibition Amendment. Favorite butt of anti-prohibition cartoonists and wits in Twenties.

BOSTON, Jan. 25--The special scholarship program set up by the United Prison Association of Massachusetts to enable selected inmates of two State prisons to pursue courses at recognized schools is being viewed in some quarters as a revolutionary step in the postinstitution care of prisoners.

A NATIVE of Georgia, now teaching school in Seattle, this author does not make the usual mistakes of the first novelist, who is traditionally given to fine flights of prose, soaring purpose and broody introspection. For "Ceylun" she has chosen the sure-fire subject of pursuit in wedlock and has expounded it gustily in a narrative that is as economical as it is extrovert.
The United Nations will begin its task tomorrow of writing an International Bill of Rights.

TORONTO, Jan. 25--Claude (Chuck) Rayner took over as Mr. Zero of the National Hockey League tonight when the New York Rangers moved into third place in the league race by defeating the Toronto Maple Leafs, 1--0.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25 (AP)--Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 500 head (estimated): total not given. Compared with week ago: all weights, barrows and gilts, 50 higher: sows steady: top at close, $24.25.

Robert Turner, pianist, who gave his initial New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall, was first heard here as a member of a trio eight years ago. In the meantime he has been a soldier, serving with the military intelligence in Germany, and has become a professor.

Continuing his struggle to win the restoration or removal of the mural effaced in September by the Rutgers Presbyterian Church, Seventythird Street and Broadway, Albert D. Crimi, the artist, announced yesterday that he was preparing to bring suit against the church authorities.

UNDER the title of "School Teacher--1947," WJZ and the American Broadcasting Company will undertake an examination of public education in America in a series of three halfhour broadcasts on two successive nights beginning Sunday, Feb. 16, it was announced last week by Robert Saudek, director of public affairs for the network.

FRANK CAPRA was disturbed and no little angered as the interview got under way. He had just read the allegations of Sir Stafford Cripps, President of the British Board of Trade, that England's pictures were not getting a fair break in American theatres, and, the night previous, he had listened to some challenging opinions anent the quality of films made in Hollywood at a session of the P.E.N. Club.

ABOARD MOUNT OLYMPUS, Little America, Jan. 25 -- The Navy's Antarctic Developments Project is progressing. The declared purpose of the project is twofold. It seeks to enlarge geographical knowledge of four million square miles of unsighted territory.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25--Four Republican Senators will propose early next week a bill providing for an immediate substantial increase in rent ceilings and the removal of all controls by the end of this year or April 30, 1948.
Since the first of the year the United Nations Security Council, guardian of "international peace and security," has had on its agenda two documents which may hold the key to peace and security.

THE hero of this almost endless bender has an infinite capacity for both self-pity and the sauce. Gargantuan in build, he is but a shrinking child within-- and, as his merciless creator points out, he drinks to drown this inadequacy.

NASHVILLE. WHILE Some GI's were busy at a politically stormy session at Athens, Tenn., last summer, others were plotting a musical revolt in the proverbial Athens of the South. The music boys wanted a symphony orchestra and, with widespread public support, produced one, in effect reviving the former Nashville Symphony which flourished eight years until the depression silenced it.

The Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra was led by Charles Muench last night at Carnegie Hall in a program featuring Poulenc's Concerto in G minor for organ, string orchestra and kettledrums, which had not been performed previously at these concerts.

WITHOUT a law to that effect, the principle of a "cooling off period" has apparently taken hold in important quarters. Congress is not going ahead full tilt to repeal the Wagner Act, slash taxes and otherwise carry out some of the ambitious schemes which filled the air last fall.
Rabbis in sermons here yesterday urged steps to speed immigration of displaced persons to the United States.

Great Britain, which for more than a century was one of the world's greatest creditor nations, became a debtor nation when World War II drained its resources. Today the economic situation in Britain recalls Carlyle's words that economics is "the dismal science."

TO judge by the wrath and indignation which is boiling in film circles these days at the tentative threats of the British to slap heavier import restrictions upon American films, you might think a war was in the making between Great Britain and the United States instead of the normal operation of economic laws.

United Nations officials, as George Barrett reported in a Lake Success dispatch to this newspaper yesterday, are tactfully but firmly disappointed with the zoning arrangements so far made or promised to protect the neighborhood of the proposed world capital. We can scarcely dismiss these comments as the effort of a group of foreigners to tell us what to do with our own city.

The stock market closed on about dead center yesterday in the second dullest and narrowest session of the year. The trend throughout the two-hour trading period on the Stock Exchange was vague, and only a few thin market issues managed to exhibit changes of more than fractions.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Maurice Scharf, in a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES of Jan. 10, proposes "a realistic Revision of the Potsdam program on the basis of either the abandonment or the elimination of German war potential or the reduction of the German population to a level where it can be self-supporting without developing an industrial base for military power."

THE sixth annual short course in news photography at Kent State University, Kent, Ohio, will be given March 19 to 22, with Edward J. Steichen heading a list of thirty speakers. This year the course will stress shooting techniques, color in newspapers and freelancing, according to the announcement by Alfred A. Crowell, executive secretary.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 25--Little Ben Hogan, National Professional Golfers Association titleholder and defending champion here, tossed a stunning challenge to a star-loaded field in the Phoenix seventy-twohole open golf tournament today when he racked up a 64 and a halfway total of 131 to take full command.

PARIS, Jan. 25--The decision to restrict Premier Paul Ramadier's Cabinet to its present membership and not to appoint any Under-Secretaries of State was taken at the first Cabinet Council of the new Government today.

IT'S easy to see why C.W. Anderson's books have such a greedy audience. In the first place there are his lithographs, realistic enough to suit the most knowing young horseman, and the eager colts and fillies, the very new foals in "Tomorrow's Champion" are among his most sensitive and spirited pictures.

Offhand, the layman cannot guess at the rights and wrongs of the proceedings of the Anti-Trust Division of the Department of Justice against the United Shoe Machinery Corporation. But the decision handed down Friday in Boston by Federal Judge George C. Sweeney throws an astounding light on the complexity of American business.

LONDON, Jan. 25 (Reuters)-- Football Association fourth-round cup games were played under wintry conditions throughout the country today, but the greatest chill was provided by Sheffield Wednesday, an English League second division club battling to avoid relegation to the third division.

American professors who have protested against the employment of German scientists and their permanent settlement in this country will not be cheered to learn that Professor Frank G. Hall (Duke University School of Medicine), after spending two and onehalf months in Germany at the request of the Army Air Forces, has made arrangements to bring over selected medicos for research in aviation medicine at military posts.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 25-- Something is being done about the weather at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 25 (AP)-- Second Army headquarters today announced plans for assembling star soldier-athletes in its sevenState area into baseball, football, boxing and basketball teams that would represent the command against other service units and civilian teams.

LOS ANGELES. THE visit a few days ago of George A. Sloan, the Metropolitan Opera's board chairman, to the City of Angels adduced some interesting and unexpected West Coast reactions in the realm of operatic music.

DOWN at Twenty-third Street and Eighth Avenue there is a theatre: a movie house now, but in its heydey the last word in dramatic elegance. It must be older than three-quarters of a century, but it is still a close second in size to the venerable Metropolitan Opera House.

NOW that pickings are slim in the garden and the birds have stripped many of the berry-bearing shrubs, they would certainly enjoy a special winter feast. One might select an evergreen tree outside the living room window, and twine about its branches garlands of popcorn, doughnuts, grapes, cranberries, dried apples and pieces of toast.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP)--A decision of the World War I Allies to try to erect a "barbed wire fence" around Bolshevism was detailed tonight in the new State Department volume.

COSMETICS-- Cosmetics are now tested on rabbits, rats and guinea pigs to determine their physiological effects before they are placed on the market, Harry Hilfer said before the Chicago section of the American Chemical Society. Apart from the suits brought by women who were peculiarly sensitive to some dyes and skin preparations which made animal tests necessary, there was a demand for chemical research.

Scientific studies to analyze and treat religious prejudice as an "emotional illness" have been undertaken at several universities under the sponsorship of the American Jewish Committee, Dr. John Slawson, executive vice chairman, reported last night.

A SPELLBINDING concoction of history, romance, suspense, "Close Pursuit" is aptly named, for that is precisely what it will exact from intrigued customers. Katharine Newlin Burt is a master story-teller who grasps her reader firmly by the hand and does not let him go until all the lovers have been mated or parted and every murky identity has been disclosed.

THE public education system of this country is one of the great social experiments of history. Public support for education from the kindergarten through the university has never been tried elsewhere on the scale developed here since Horace Mann left his law office and went forth to battle for a system of free public schools.
College students are consuming more alcoholic drinks today than formerly and creating a new problem for education, Mildred McAfee Horton, president of Wellesley College, reported yesterday.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 25-- The Congress party - dominated Constituent Assembly adjourned today until April, by which time the Moslem League may have decided whether it will enter into the constitution-making labors.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Last January the British Government, in response to renewed diplomatic pressure from Guatemala, offered to settle the long-standing dispute between them over British Honduras by submitting the matter to the International Court of Justice--the new World Court.

A VINE is a plant that has a stem so slender as to require support. They've been dubbed the plants that cover architects' mistakes, but for every one that does this there's one so luxuriant in growth that it is spoiling the proportions of a house.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 25--Three years ago, Canada was forty-first on the list of nations buying from Mexico and twentieth on the list of those selling to this country. Today, Canada is fifth in the former category and fourth in the latter.

Seven armed bandits entered the office of Silver's Baths, 3060 West Twenty - third Street, Brooklyn, early yesterday and escaped with 150 metal strongboxes containing the jewelry and cash of 200 men and women customers sleeping one floor above.

ONE of the most heartening things about America in 1947 is the spring freshet of enthusiasm for native balladry and folklore that is running through the country from coast to coast. Big, dulcet-voiced Burl Ives from Indiana, Josh White with his South Carolina blues, Woody Guthrie with his Okie songs, Susan Reed with her winsome Southern lyric songs have become nationally known.
MADRID, Spain, Jan. 25--The Spanish Cabinet is on the verge of a serious overhauling according to political circles here, although all preliminary moves are being carried out in great secrecy.

A warning that large-scale training programs of the armed forces in colleges were threatening the nation's supply of potential scientists was delivered here yesterday by Dr. M.H. Trytten, director of the Office of Scientific Personnel.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 25 (AP) --All the talk about high-pressure athletics isn't registering at the United States Naval Academy. The new skipper is emphatic: middle football teams will not become enmeshed in the "big time."

THAT discrimination problem at the National, Washington's only legitimate theatre, continued to make news last week. It was learned that three more dramatists, Donald Ogden Stewart, Thornton Wilder and S.N. Behrman, had added their names to those of the thirty-three who perviously announced they would not permit their plays to be shown there until Negroes were permitted to attend.

National Committee for Mental Hygiene THE increasing consciousness since the war of the frailty of human adjustment has served at least one important purpose: to a large extent it has broken down the obstacle that prevented men from going to psychoanalysts, whom they regarded as doctors for the insane.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Jan. 25-- A total of 7,786 permits for new construction of various types representing a value of $27,481,000, was issued by fifty-four of Bergen County's seventy municipalities during the first eleven months of 1946.

ON the evidence now before us, this may be described as the season that broke the Broadway formula for the commercial musical show. Eliminate Kurt Weill's version of "Street Scene" from the discussion for the moment.

MR. WILLIAMS is a noted biochemist in charge of a research institute at the University of Texas. He is also author of two widely accepted chemistry texts, and recently he and his brother were jointly awarded the Chandler Medal for discoveries in the field of vitamins.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Asserting that private industry will have practically a free hand in producing moderate-priced homes, the two top Federal housing officials predicted today the transfer of many homes from the sales market to the rental market in 1947.

JAMES FEIBLEMAN, whose "An Introduction to Peirce's Philosophy" (Harper) and "Theory of Human Culture" (Duell, Sloan Pearce) have appeared recently, is--perhaps not unnaturally --a gentleman with a certain philosophic perspective.

MORTALITY-- Provisional figures of the United States Public Health Service indicate that the infant mortality rate in the United States last year was the lowest ever recorded-- slightly more than 35 per 1,000 live births.

IN "Black Anger" Greek meets Greek -- white psychoanalyst meets African witch doctor in the slums of the golden city of Johannesburg. The techniques of both are exposed in juxtaposition --the witch doctor's bones thrown on the ground beside the bookcase that holds the analyst's volumes of Freud, Jung and Adler.

IF we're to judge by the comments of readers that reach this department, cheese cake will some day rival apple pie and ice cream as a leading American dessert. A favorite question addressed to the TIMES' test kitchen is, "Is cheese cake hard to make? Will you please send me a recipe?"

MONTREAL. PERHAPS the most significant thing about the visit to North America of Donald Wolfit and his Shakespearean repertory group is the almost unbelievable revival of interest in the Bard's works.

United States international proposals that lack Republican support will fall short of any "very serious" consideration by foreign governments, John Foster Dulles, Republican adviser on world affairs, declared yesterday. Apart from recognizing the power of a Republican Congress, he said, foreign diplomats "suspect what we know--that in two years a Republican will be in the White House."

MOSCOW, Jan. 25 -- The military appropriations in the United States budget will strengthen the rising power of American militarists, an article in Pravda, newspaper of the Communist party, said today.

Department store sales by reserve districts, as reported by the Federal Reserve Board, are listed in the following table which gives percentage comparisons with a year ago: Federal 4 Weeks Year Reserve 1 Week Ended Ended to

MONTREAL, Jan. 25--One of the achievements of which the American delegation to the Provisional International Civil Aviation Orgranization is most proud is the completion for the first time of a standard map of the world.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The big story just under the surface in Washington today is the attempt of the Republicans to bring their economic foreign policy into line with their political foreign policy and to reconcile their desire for world security with their traditional support of restrictive tariffs.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (Science Service)--Low-cost atomic power will not be available before 1960, two War Department atomic experts said today.

FOR fifteen years and more, bridge writers have been defining and redefining the responses to an opening bid of one no trump. The last two or three years have been no exception. At least three new interpretations of no-trump responses have been proposed.

MONTREAL, Jan. 25 (AP)-- Paced by Toe Blake's two goals, the Montreal Canadiens defeated the Boston Bruins, 4--1, tonight in a National Hockey League game. The second-place Canadiens piled up a 4-0 lead in a bruising game witnessed by 11,488 fans at the Forum before Joe Carveth netted the Bruins' counter in the last two minutes.

TWO group shows are being held simultaneously at the A.C.A. Gallery -- one of paintings by the seven members of the gallery who have won awards in the various Pepsi-Cola competitions and the other a general exhibition bringing together recent paintings by some forty other artists associated with the gallery.

Commercial bankers, eager and ready to invade the field of consumer credit in full force as soon as consumer durable goods become available in ample quantities, are becoming increasingly aware of the pitfalls in their path, according to informed financial observers.

BOSTON, Jan. 25--It's the same old devastating Gil Dodds. Picking up where he left off in 1944, the pace-setting parson from the Boston A.A. ran away and hid from the rest of the milers tonight in his first major test since he pushed the world indoor record down to 4:06.4 three years ago.

The Municipal Civil Service Commission announced yesterday that it would begin soon a check on employes of the IRT and BMT transit systems who were aliens in 1940 when those lines were acquired by the city.

HOLLYWOOD. WHILE local receipts from David O. Selznick's "Duel in the Sun" increased by 30 per cent last week following denouncement of the picture by Arshbishop John J. Cantwell of Los Angeles, representatives of thirteen women's organizations met and deplored the picture at a regular round-table discussion sponsored by the Association of Motion Picture Producers.

ADELAIDE, Jan. 25 (Reuters) --Walter Hammond, with 188, and James Langridge, with 100, added 243 for the sixth wicket and helped the Marylebone C.C. to carry the first innings' total to 562 for nine in the second day's play against South Australia.

The city Health Department reported yesterday in a summary of vital statistics that between 1898 and 1945, while the marirage rate per 1,000 population varied slightly from 8.8 to 9.4, the live birth rate fell from 36.4 to 16.7 and the death rate declined from 20.3 to 10.3.

IN such books as "Rome Haul," "Chad Hanna" and "Drums Along the Mohawk," Walter D. Edmonds has been pleasantly and successfully engaged in portraying aspects of the New York State of yesterday. His novels have been notable for combining good entertainment with historical exactitude.

The Boston Celtics, near the bottom of the league standings for most of the season and at present the tenants of last place in the Eastern Division, rapidly are gaining the reputation of being the giant killers of the Basketball Association of America.

MEN who have spent long years working on staffs of libraries at scholarly tasks are apt to have a becoming humility. The New York Public library has been fortunate because of the number of such distinguished men who have served it and about whom the public seldom hears.

One of the baffling problems of agriculture is close to solution. According to Dr. Robert M. Salter, chief of the Bureau of Plant Industry, "new soil fumigants bid fair to become one of the greatest boons to agriculture since the development of fertilizer." Chemical warfare is invading the farm, and the results will mean bigger and better crops from good soil that has fallen off in production.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 25 (AP)-- A Communist plurality in the fiftymember City Council in Rio de Janeiro appears likely as returns from Sunday's election continued to put them far ahead of all opposition.

A youthful star and an elder statesman of baseball will receive two of the most coveted awards in the game, the plaques annually bestowed by the New York Chapter of the Baseball Writers' Association of America.

THE board of directors of the New York PhilharmonicSymphony Society is set to meet next week. One of the major items of business should be the selection of the conductor for next season. Artur Rodzinski, whose contract expires this year, is said to be in line for a new threeyear contract.

Prices of residential properties are the same or slightly lower than last summer, according to a nationwide sampling of local real estate boards and real estate brokers just completed by the research department of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane.

The Navy Department has asked Congress to enact a new law that will keep intact the right of the armed services to enter negotiated contracts, the bulletin of the National Association of Purchasing Agents disclosed last week. Army officials also favor the plan, the report said.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25--Senator W. Lee O'Daniel, Democrat, of Texas, described portal-to-portal pay suits filed by Congress of Industrial Organizations unions as "a crime against commerce" as he testified today in support of legislation he has proposed to discourage such suits and to limit employers' liability.
ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 25-- Louis B. Mayer's $5,000,000 racing stables, built up since 1938 as the greatest in the West, will be sold at public auction on Feb. 27, it was announced today.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 25 (AP)-- Earshot, fleet filly owned by William Helis, broke well and drew away from her field to capture the six - furlong $5,000 Natchitoches Handicap at the Fair Grounds today.

THIS bevy of bright red chess books would have scandalized their comparatively funereal ancestors and their own earlier editions. The gay raiment reflects the greatly increased popular interest in the game and the new attitude that chess is not all silence and solemnity, but rather excitement and intellectual stimulation.
Two more persons were arrested yesterday in connection with the investigation of the mass jail break from Brooklyn City Prison on Jan. 2.

BOSTON, Jan. 25--Warning that many young students were imbued with a philosophy of utter negation, Dr. Sarah Gibson Blanding, president of Vassar College, called today for educators and adults to hold fast their convictions that a solution of the world's ills can fee found.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25--Shipments of relief and rehabilitation supplies reached the 20,000,000-ton mark this week with the loading of the Liberty ship Hoosier State with a cargo for Austria, Greece, Hungary, Italy and Yugoslavia, the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration announced today.

No better example of a "safe ship" from the standpoint of fireproofing may be found than the Grace Line's Santa Rosa, which is due to make her first post-war appearance here as a "civilian ship" tomorrow morning, company officials said yesterday.

Mark-down clearances and special promotions in recent week have moved large quantities of women's apparel, staple goods and sub ard merchandise, but indications are that fiscal year inventories at the end of this month will show heavy gains in retail stocks over a year ago.

OMAHA, Jan. 25 -- Nebraska's unique unicameral Legislature, a monument to the late Senator George W. Norris, observes its tenth birthday this month. The anniversary is passing quietly-- in sober routine legislative work.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25--The woman in the home must save this country from totalitarianism, speakers today told the Twentyfirst Women's Patriotic Conference on National Defense.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25--The investigative urge is strong in the new Congressional Republican majorities. A race is on for the most favorable position. From present indications, attention will be sharply on Democrats and what they have done or failed to do during their long national tenure.

WITH the continuing and in some ways increasing importance of Japan to American interests of every kind and in the formation of American policy, there is now an unprecedented demand for short, simple books that will make Japan easy for the American to understand.

New sources of uranium have been opened through the development of a large shale oil industry in Sweden to offset coal and petroleum shortages, Dr. Gustav Egloff, director of research of the Universal Oil Products Company and chairman of the Petroleum Division of the American Chemical Society, reported at a technical conference sponsored by the Chicago section of the society at the Northwestern University Technological Institute.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25--President Truman has pledged the aid of the United States Government in the reconstruction of "a peaceful, prosperous and democratic Italy," it was disclosed today.

MUNRO Leaf's engaging comic imps are at work again. The skillfully drawn little pixies who made manners, grammar, safety and health into such lively books are bent on instructing your child in the elements of behavior.

SINCE "Unconqjuered" is well on its way toward completion, Cecil Blount De Mille is somewhat passive about pre-Revolationary Pennsylvania, an aide of the producer-director was saying the other day. Not that he has lost any of his passion for that vehicle, mind you, but only because he is now busily engaged on his forthcoming production, "Samson and Delilah."

DETROIT, Jan. 25 (AP)--Ray Blum, Navy veteran from Nutley, N.J., took a narrow lead over Bobby Fitzgerald of Minneapolis, defending champion, today in the senior men's division of the North American speed skating championships.

PARIS, Jan. 25--The chief responsibility for France's return in the past week to a party coalition form of government rests with the Communist party. It was their insurmountable opposition that prevented the reconstitution of the all-Socialist Cabinet, which had given the country a taste of aggressive and coordinated action and which a large part of the population would have liked to see continued.

FROM the age of 3 months until soon after his graduation from Knox College, Earnest Elmo Calkins lived in Galesburg, Ill. Like many another American community of the Eighteen Sixties, Galesburg progressed within the strict limits of fundamentalist religion, and the Calkins home was regimented in the complete orthodoxy of its time and place.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Jan. 25 (Aneta)--A new memorandum stating that the Netherlands' territorial claims against Germany might, for technical reasons, be expanded slightly eastward and asserting that the Netherlands economic hinterland in Europe included the Danubian countries was submitted today by the Netherlands Government to the Deputies.

HOLLYWOOD. IN circles where his name and art are known, Walter Hoffman is fond of saying that in his time he has blown up half the world. Mr. Hoffman is no anarchist and has felt no throb of ideological fervor, having never dynamited a bridge for Hemingway or the O.S.S.

WHAT is going on in the German mind today, twenty months after the end of the war? What are the German people thinking, fearing, hoping, hating? Is there any indication of psychological change? The answer to these questions is a key to the future of Germany and of world peace.

JULIUS HENRY COHEN has been a distinguished New York attorney for almost fifty years and served as general counsel to the Port of New York Authority and its predecessors for twenty-five years before he returned to private practice in 1942.

THE first authoritative analysis of the Army's wartime motion-picture program as a guide for post-war educational film making has just been presented with the publication of "Movies That Teach," by Charles F. Hoban Jr. Dr. Hoban, who, as a major in the Signal Corps, served as chief of the film distribution and utilization branch of the Army Pictorial Service, currently is special assistant in the division of visual education of the Philadelphia public school system.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 25 (U.P.)--The all-Jewish City of Tel Aviv was placed out of bounds to British offduty troops today as part of precautions to meet expected new outbreaks on behalf of Dov Gruner, Irgun Zvai Leumi member sentenced to be hanged for complicity in an attack on a police station last April.

ROME, Jan. 25--Italy is in the throes of her sixth Cabinet crisis since the middle of 1944. These recurrent crises, which follow one another with almost chronometric regularity every six months, may be regarded optimistically as part and parcel of the unsettled conditions that are bound to exist in a country that has only recently emerged from a disastrous war.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Jan. 25 (AP) --Al Capone, ex-Chicago gangster and prohibition era crime leader, died in his home here tonight.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 25--The Shaker, flying the same black and yellow silks which used to be sported by such equine celebrities as Man o' War, War Admiral and other famous stakes winners, flashed to a half-length triumph in the $11,500 Palm Beach Handicap at Hialeah Park before a capacity crowd of 18,398 today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (U.P.)-- Veterans enjoying benefits under the G.I. Bill of Rights will not be affected by President Truman's Dec. 31 proclamation ending hostilities, the Veterans Administration said tonight.

PORTRAITS in sculpture make up a group exhibition at the Clay Club and the major part of Arline Wingate's current show at the Midtown Gallery. In the former event a number of wellknown artists are represented as well as newcomers and there are examples in plaster, terra cotta, bronze and wood.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25--The eyes of the country were turned to Capitol Hill this week when the Senate Labor Committee opened a new chapter in the all-engrossing discussion of labor problems.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25--The Paris Peace Conference of 1919 gave tacit recognition to Russia's vital interest in Poland's eastern borders by refusing to go far toward solving that question in Russia's absence, according to a volume on foreign relations issued by the State Department tonight.
LONDON, Jan. 25--The great problem before Britain today is how to maintain a decent standard of living in her home islands and still fulfill her role as a world power.

Miss Marie Corridon of the Women's Swimming Association kept the women's Metropolitan A.A.U. senior 100-yard free-style championship and Herman Winckler of the New York A.C. became the men's senior 220-yard breaststroke titleholder in a swimming meet at the N.Y.A.C. last night.

Schools should emphasize training for citizenship and for "the well-being of the child in late life," according to pupils who participated yesterday in the Youth Forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast by Station WQXR.

COMPARISON of New York State's proposed highway program for 1946 with the work actually accomplished last year leads J.R. Crossley, vice president of the Automobile Club of New York, to conclude that construction lagged so far behind schedule as to jeopardize the State's five-year highway building program.
Declaring themselves ready to meet the challenge of changing market conditions, wholesalers last week outlined essential steps for strengthening their position in the distribution picture.

Bottlenecks which increase costs and reduce production are targets for cost-cutting work-simplification programs in many plants, C. Stuart Brown, director work-simplification, American Viscose Corporation, disclosed here last week. Members of the Purchasing Agents Association of New York, who heard Mr. Brown describe recommended methods at their monthly meeting, said here last week that cutting costs and increasing output are the two best weapons industry can use against inflationary trends.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25--The National Atomic Energy Commission named Frank J. Wilson, retired chief of the United States Secret Service, today to be consultant in formulating a security system to safeguard this country's supremacy in atomic energy secrets.

ANY book Bernard De Voto writes makes exciting reading. History, criticism, biography, novel are all included in his lengthening line of volumes, and whatever judgment reviewers have passed on this or that performance, not the most captious of them has called him dull.

ANTARCTIC Expedition: Station Nave aboard the U.S.S. Mount Olympus, now in the Antarctic, schedules RCA and Press Wireless at New York twice daily, at 7:30 A.M. and 6:30 P.M. NAVE calls on 17,820 mcs. and sometimes shifts to 19.090 mcs.

IT is rather superfluous to say that basketball is now embarked on the greatest season in its history. We'll just take that for granted as an original premise and skip along blithely from there. Baseball had its most successful campaign and so did football. Why not basketball?

BERLIN, Jan. 25--The reorganization of the Communist-controlled Socialist Unity party, which is recognized only in the Soviet zone and Berlin, apparently will result in a complete overhauling, it was indicated today.

A series of six-day cruises between New York and Nassau in the Bahamas for the Eastern Steamship Lines' Yarmouth, commencing with a departure from here on Feb. 28, was announced here yesterday by Alton B. Sharp, president, who said the cruises were the first of the kind announced by an American-flag company since the end of the war.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25--Secretary of State George C. Marshall is expected to clarify our policy with regard to Argentina in clear and unmistakable terms as one of the first official acts of his administration of the State Department.
Col. Larry MacPhail of the Yankees came up with another first baseman yesterday--but he didn't pay out the $150,000 he said he was willing to disburse for one. This fellow cost nothing.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 25--The Essex Troop polo team of Newark, triumphant in twelve straight games, went down to its first defeat of the indoor season tonight, dropping a 14-to-8 decision to the Squadron A Falcons of New York at the Essex Troop Armory.

OF the many envoys, official and unofficial, who have been sent by the United States to Russia in recent years it is doubtful that any have been more effective than "Russ" Deane--a man whose name is hardly known to the American public.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 25--On the heels of an immigration case involving the daughters of two prominent Chinese, the Chinese Consul General charged today that other passengers, including a scientist en route to Yale University as a research fellow under a United States Navy contract with the university, had been detained by immigration authorities for several days on shipboard and at San Francisco's shoreside "Ellis Island."

Giving up three goals by handicap, Al Parsells' Ramapo Polo Club trio handed the Squadron A side a 14-to-10 setback in the featured game of the indoor double-header at the Squadron A Armory last night.

The decision of the United Nations Organization to make its permanent nome in Manhattan and the removal of most restrictive price ceilings and priorities by the Government are hailed as good omens by Fred Berger, president of the Fred Berger Company. Inc., who sees the metropolitan realty market "standing on the threshold of perhaps the greatest activity in all its long and varied history."

BERLIN, Jan. 25--A demand that the Minister-President and Minister of Culture of WuerttembergBaden be classed as "offenders" and tried by a denazification tribunal has been made by the Stuttgart public prosecutor. The request was formally made to the denazification tribunal in Stuttgart, which has the power of decision.

Described by its sponsor as the "first complete manual" on the control of radiant panel heating, a booklet entitled "Automatic Control of Radiant Panel Heating" has just been published by the MinneapolisHoneywell Regulator Company.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Jan. 25 --National productivity--the overall industrial output for each manhour of labor--was 18 per cent higher in 1946 than it was in 1940, Benjamin Graham, financial economist of New York, reported today before the annual meeting of the American Economic Association here.

THIS is a disappointing book, although the central theme is sound enough. Briefly, it is contended that society is at the present time profoundly disorganized, that the disorganization expresses itself in the large number of neurotic personalities among both men and women, but that the state of women is crucial because women as mothers transmit the psychological disorientation to the next generation.

RECENT paintings by Joseph Floch make up an impressive exhibition at the galleries of the Associated American Artists. When the Vienneseborn painter has not been looking out upon New York receptively and with observant eyes from a skyscraper studio, he has been busy with aspects of the New England coast or capturing personalities in small, quite psychological, portraits.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 25--Grand jury and legislative investigations were demanded today into reported efforts to bribe legislators when General Assembly action was pending on the controversial issue of Georgia's Governorship.

A FEW billion years ago by solar clock a reckless amoeba, stirred by wanderlust, moved sluggishly in the steaming primordial slime. He told an amoeba brother, "I'm getting out, Bub. These mud flats are overcrowded." He was the first pedestrian.

A number of particularly extravagant and destructive speeches on "unification" by officers of the Army Air Forces in December and January strengthened the opposition of a group of naval aviators to the reorganization that was finally announced ten days ago.

Life insurance companies, whose assets have pyramided to nearly $50,000,000,000, are struggling to solve the dilemma of lowered returns from traditional investment fields and legal restrictions on other outlets for the profitable employment of their huge resources.

ABOARD MOUNT OLYMPUS, at Little America, Jan. 24 (Delayed) (AP)--The crews of the two planes from the Navy Antarctic expedition's Eastern Group that flew over uncharted territory Thursday, reported sighting two new high mountain ranges and seeing dirt at the coastline, which is a rarity in the Antarctic.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25--Speakers on a State Department broadcast said tonight that the leftist press and propaganda services in eastern Europe had long been campaigning "to misrepresent us" through distortion of news, suppression of facts and misstatement.

HANOI, Indo - China, Jan. 23 (Delayed)--Civil and military dignitaries of the rebel Viet Namese Government entertained consular representatives of the United States, Great Britain and China at a sumptuous thirteen-course dinner last night in celebration of the Chinese and Annamese New Year festivals which this year happen to fall on the same day.

Joseph Weingarten, Hungarian pianist, gave his first New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. The exacting program contained the Bach - Liszt "Fantasia and Fugue" in G minor; Beethoven's Sonata in E flat. Op. 31, No. 3; the four "Ballades" of Chopin; Kodaly's "Dances of Marosszek," two Preludes by Rachmaninoff and the "Dante" Sonata of Liszt.

Acceptance by the Brooklyn Real Estate Board of an offer by the Inter-County Title Guaranty and Mortgage Company of a $1,000 prize to be awarded to the broker or salesman member of the board who negotiates "the most ingenious real estate transaction in Brooklyn in 1947," was announced last night by George H. Gray, president of the board, at the forty-second anniversary banquet of the organization at the Hotel Commodore.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25--Whatever else may be said of President Truman's offer of mutual cooperation with the Republican majority in Congress, it became abundantly clear this week that both sides have no intention of letting it interfere with their 1948 Presidential plans.

ONE of the most remarkable events of the postwar period in Europe is the emergence of large Catholic mass parties who stand for democracy and social reform. One of their best known spiritual ancestors and founding fathers is Luigi Sturzo who has been a Catholic priest for more than fifty years and who, during that period, has helped Italy in various ways:

THE serious writer of today-- the writer who aims at something more than killing time for his reader--is too often a bewildered man. Everything about him is in such a state of flux-- the conditions of his craft, the world in which he lives--that a firm stance is hard to find.
CHICAGO, Jan. 25 (AP)--A slightly lower trend developed in grains on the Board of Trade today, although the March wheat contract displayed independent strength.

Retail trade for the week ended Jan. 25 maintained about the same percentage of gain as in the preceding week. Department store sales, it was estimated, were about 20 per cent above those of a year ago.

The markets continued active last week although fewer buyers were in town than in the previous week, according to a market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company. Domestics buyers concentrated on obtaining items formerly dificult to secure.

MOSCOW, Jan. 25--To the studious reader of the Moscow newspapers, to the working man or woman who listens to the radio or to the speakers at the local "agitation point," it is clear that international reaction is in full assault on those areas ideologically left of center and inhabited by "progressive democrats" and Communists.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 25--Despite disparaging remarks occasionally directed at Californians for this failing, they continue to talk of "unusual weather" when it too wet or too dry or too hot or too cold. An "unusually long" cold spell--cold in the utopian West Coast sense--and "denser-thanusual" fogs are giving the weather a high priority in coastal thoughts.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25--Five educators have been appointed as consultants to special subcommittees of the President's Commission on Higher Education, George F. Zook, chairman, said today.

As part of their program for demonstrating the latest achievements in their field, the home builders of the country will hold an appliance show when they convene in Chicago next month for the annual meeting of the National Association of Home Builders.

TO THE EDITOR: In the Magazine article, "Senator Ball Outlines a Labor Policy," Senator Ball says: "All disputes between employers and employes should be settled in so far as is possible through free collective bargaining, with the right of the employes to strike, and the right of the employer to try to beat the strike preserved."

CHICAGO, Jan. 25--A pledge of $1,000,000 for an expanded Zionist public relations and education program was made tonight at the first plenary session of the National Mobilization Conference of the American Zionist Organization.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Jan. 25 --Dr. E.A. Goldenweiser of the Institute for Advanced Study, Princeton, N.J., former research director of the Federal Reserve Board, urged tonight in his presidential address before the American Economic Association that the country's economists act as advisers to the public on economic questions.

One reason people frequently dislike modern chamber music is that it is often, barbarously performed. But such was not the case in Hunter College Playhouse last night at the first concert of the season to be presented by the United States section of the International Society for Contemporary Music.

London. A TIRED British official, toward the end of the Paris conference, remarked to a friend that there are two sorts of people in the world: those who have tried to negotiate with Molotov and know that it is impossible, and those who have not, but believe that it can be done.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25--Dr. J.E.M. Thomson of Lincoln, Neb., president of the American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons, told the academy's annual dinner tonight that members of an American medical mission were unable to find "the iron curtain" during a tour of medical centers in Czechoslovakia last summer.

MADDY VEGTEL, an accomplished writer of the short fiction piece, is adept at capturing the atmosphere of smug uppermiddle-class society wherever she meets it. When it is in her native Holland, where her first novel is laid, she knows exactly out of what kind of cloth her countrymen are cut.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25--Republican charges of corruption and graft in the City Hall administration, of a "terrifying" crime wave and political protection of lawbreakers have already enlivened Chicago's Mayoralty campaign, which will come to its climax with the municipal election on April 1.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 25--A personal feud that had already involved one attempted murder resulted in the death of an apparently unintended victim today in the strange outgrowth of a romance between the widow of Manuel Avila Camacho's brother and Jorge Velez, a Mexican movie star.
WARSAW, Jan. 25 -- A new chapter in modern Polish political history, filled with a mixture of grave possibilities and bright hopes, opened this week when the nation held its long-awaited election.
SHANGHAI, Jan. 25 -- Increasing unrest in Szechwan and Sikang, western provinces, is expected to become associated with the civil war if it continues to spread.

An imaginary ten-minute trip by rocket ship one hundred miles above the earth was outlined last night by Dr. James A. Van Allen of the Applied Physics Laboratory of Johns Hopkins University, at a dinner of the Explorers Club at the Hotel Plaza.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25--The State Department, in an unexpected statement that was widely believed to point toward a reconciliation of differences with Argentina, welcomed today as an "important step" the promulgation of the decree by President Juan D. Peron for the taking over by his Government of sixty Nazi business concerns in the country.
In an article written for The Associated Press, Attorney General Tom C. Clark declared yesterday that the future of America and of the world was in the hands of youth.

MOSCOW, Jan. 25--Revision of the British-Soviet treaty to provide conditions for extending the alliance as suggested by Premier Stalin to Foreign Secretary Bevin would center on more specific clauses concerning economic and cultural relations and a bilateral pact of defense against any German military renaissance, in the opinion of British and American diplomats here.

At the Institutum Divi Thomae, Cincinnati, Ohio, an extract of brain tissue has been found to be superior to penicillin in combating infections caused by Staphylococcus aureus. It is this "coccus" that causes boils on the neck. The discovery was made by Dr. Leo G. Nutini and Sister Eva Maria Lynd.

LONDON, Jan. 25 (U.P.)--A controversy of international proportions loomed tonight over the rivalry between the United States Amateur Athletic Union and the Amateur Hockey Association of America to place teams in the world hockey championship at Prague next month.

I DO not know a single writer, French, English or American, who is a better authority on modern France than Denis Brogan. He has intimate knowledge and profound sympathy: he is, I believe, the only British professor who has a son named Vercingetorix, and he is Honorary Citizen of La Roche Blanche, in Puy-deDome.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 24 (Delayed) --John J. Schulter, special representative of the American Congress of Industrial Organizations, left today for Chungking to make a personal investigation of charges by the Kuomintang General Labor Union against Chu Hsueh-fan, former leader of the Chinese Association of Labor.

Cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange ended yesterday 13 to 18 points net lower than the day before. They started with a moderate volume of overnight price-fixing orders, 1 to 14 points up, but the slight advance met Southern and New Orleans selling which was persistent enough to give the market a barely steady tone most of the short session.

CROSS - LIGHTING -- light striking the subject from the side--is the key to good architectural photography. This fact is especially apparent in the exhibition of architectural photographs at the Architectural League of New York, 115 East Fortieth Street.

BRATISLAVA, Czechoslovakia, Jan. 25--More than 100 political secret police and regular police invaded the principal hotel in Bratislava about 2 o'clock this morning. Guards were placed around the hotel and on all floors.

WITHIN two weeks after the publication of my novel, "Miss Dilly Says No," seven play producers wanted to acquire the dramatic rights. I informed them that I would sign with the first to come up with a top-notch dramatist.

SYDNEY, Jan. 25--Gardnar Mulloy of Miami, Fla., was beaten in the semi-finals of the Australian title tennis tournament today by John Bromwich, but not before the American had argued with a linesman and invited a spectator to come down out of the stands.

IN the past an almanac was known as a "book or table containing a calendar of days, weeks and months of the year, a register of ecclesiastical festivals and Saints days, and a record of astronomical phenomena." But John Kieran, citing this encyclopedic definition in his foreword, sponsors more pace and range in this 952-page volume of fact and comment, the first volume in a new series.

THE first newly built train to go into service in the East since 1941 began operating last week over the Baltimore Ohio, offering luxurious comfort for daylight coach travel between Baltimore, Washington and Cincinnati.

The most photographed girl in America this week is Nancy Drury, 4-year-old poster girl of this year's March of Dimes. There is a dramatic appeal in the story of this little Louisville girl's recovery from poliomyelitis that will make Americans for these two weeks more thoughtfully conscious of the problems of infantile paralysis.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 25--The Temple Medal, top prize in the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts 142d Annual Exhibition, was awarded to "The Majestic Tenement," a large painting in the abstract manner by Arthur Osver of Long Island City, N.Y.

New Jersey property owners desiring to participate in the State's new plan to ease the housing shortage for veterans by conversion of privately owned singlefamily dwellings to multiple occupancy have been asked to communicate with the New Jersey Public Housing and Development Authority of the Department of Economic Development at Trenton.

IN "La Science et l'Hypothese" Henri Poincare amusingly illustrates the difference between the historical and the scientific points of view. "Carlyle," he writes, "has written somewhere something like this: 'Nothing but facts are of importance.

PARIS, Jan. 25--In her second appearance outside of Norway since the war, Kirsten Flagstad, noted Wagnerian soprano, gave the first of two concerts here today, d was well received by a moderate-sized audience that included a large number of Americans.

SELECTING the plant of one of the country's best known makers of small, personal type aircraft, the author, who has previously dealt with trains, ships and automobiles, again says, "Let's you and I go see how they do it."
IT has been one of those weeks. The congestion of important events, each meriting extended notice, creates a problem that can be resolved only in terms of compromise.

DURHAM, N.C., Jan. 25--Five Evangeline League players were placed on baseball's ineligible list today by Judge W.G. Bramham following an investigation of alleged irregularities in the league's post-season series between Houma, La., and Abbeville, La.

SHOPPING for home furnishings today is a bewildering experience. It is hardly necessary to mention that you will pay top prices for anything you buy, since recent increases of 5, 10 or 20 per cent on various types of furniture, rugs and fabrics have been widely reported.

HAD Franklin Delano Roosevelt lived he would have been 65 years old next Thursday. But death overtook him just two months and thirteen days beyond his sixty-third birthday, and so he has been gone from the scene for nearly two years. This anniversary occasion, it seems to me, is an appropriate time to examine the literature about him that has accumulated during those distressful months since the sudden ending of his gallant life.

IN "La Science et l'Hypothese" Henri Poincare amusingly illustrates the difference between the historical and the scientific points of view. "Carlyle," he writes, "has written somewhere something like this: 'Nothing but facts are of importance.

PARIS, Jan. 25--In her second appearance outside of Norway since the war, Kirsten Flagstad, noted Wagnerian soprano, gave the first of two concerts here today, d was well received by a moderate-sized audience that included a large number of Americans.

SELECTING the plant of one of the country's best known makers of small, personal type aircraft, the author, who has previously dealt with trains, ships and automobiles, again says, "Let's you and I go see how they do it."
IT has been one of those weeks. The congestion of important events, each meriting extended notice, creates a problem that can be resolved only in terms of compromise.

DURHAM, N.C., Jan. 25--Five Evangeline League players were placed on baseball's ineligible list today by Judge W.G. Bramham following an investigation of alleged irregularities in the league's post-season series between Houma, La., and Abbeville, La.

SHOPPING for home furnishings today is a bewildering experience. It is hardly necessary to mention that you will pay top prices for anything you buy, since recent increases of 5, 10 or 20 per cent on various types of furniture, rugs and fabrics have been widely reported.

The national squash racquets doubles champions, Donald Strachan and Charles Brinton of the Philadelphia Country Club, had no great amount of trouble yesterday advancing into the semi-final round of the University Club's invitation tourney for the Arthur H. Lockett trophy, one of the most prized awards in the sport.

THIS department has received the following letter from the Columbia Broadcasting System on the subject of sponsored news and comment: TO the Radio Editor: Perhaps you will permit me to make brief comment on your column, "Commercial Comment," in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Sunday, Jan. 5, and THE TIMES editorial titled "Sponsored News" of Sunday, Jan. 12.

LAHORE, Punjab, India, Jan. 25 (AP)--Local police sprayed tear gas into a procession of 200 shouting Moslem women and swung batons on other Moslem League members today in efforts to check continuing violent demonstrations against the Punjab Provincial Government's action declaring the Moslem "National Guard" illegal.

PARENTS should have something to say about how teen-age allowances are spent. Boys should meet the girls' parents when calling for a date. Parents should set the hour for coming home from a party and expect an accounting for being late.

THE person who broke into a warehouse in Nyack, N.Y., and made off with that village's Christmas street lights, may or may not qualify as the "meanest thief of 1946," but he was a fitting member of the unusual crop of that ilk that turned up during the year.

ROME, Jan. 25--The explosion in Rome of five bombs, which in exploding scattered propaganda leaflets around, announced the birth of another neo-Fascist oragnization under the name of "Fasces of Revolutionary Action."
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 25 (AP)--Immediate lifting of all wartime controls on consumer installment credit was urged today by C.W. Bailey of Clarksville. Tenn., president of the American Bankers Association.

United States Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney, Democrat, of Wyoming, called last night for decentralization, of Federal Government. He declared that otherwise the system of free enterprise in this country would be threatened.

MINNESOTA--Radio Lessons An innovation in correspondence courses is offered for the first time by the general extension division of the University of Minnesota in its course in American Philosophy, the lesson material of which is broadcast to the students over the university radio station KUOM three afternoons a week.

OF only one actor starring on Broadway these days can it be deemed a compliment to say that his literary taste runs to comic books. He plays a role of Hamlet-like proportions, probably the juiciest part ever written for a child and certainly one that many a grown-up member of Equity would gladly go back to knee pants to play.

ALL'S right with the world again. Max Beerbohm--Sir Max--has a new book out. It is a thin, a delicate book. Its elegant exiguity would scarcely take up the paper of a tabloid daily, yet it is crammed with news of the moment and of all time.
An in-service course for teachers on "Evaluating the News," sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and the Board of Education, will open on Feb. 18 at The New York Times Hall.

The motives of the New York City Housing Authority's recently announced drive to clear 2,770 middle-income families from its low-rent housing projects were clarified yesterday in a statement by Edmond Borgia Butler, chairman.

BRANCHES of some flowering shrubs and trees, brought indoors in Winter, will slowly open their flowers and leaves and provide a glimpse of spring while the landscape is still bleak outdoors. This will not happen if the forcing is attempted in any hit-or-miss fashion, and some understanding is needed of the way dormancy works.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 25 (AP)-- See-Tee-See, a 4-year-old bay gelding owned by C.T. Clifford, captured the $50,000 added Santa Catalina Handicap today over nine other California-bred candidates at Santa Anita Park.

The most celebrated of early employe investment plans will bow out of the American industrial scene on Friday when the Ford Motor Company completes financial settlements on the workers' saving program inaugurated almost twenty-seven years ago.

LONDON, Jan. 25 -- Second thoughts in Britain about Premier Stalin's recent letter to Foreign Secretary Bevin have brought some anxiety about the possibility that Moscow's aim may be to extend the British-Soviet treaty to make it a much broader instrument, operative against not only Germany but also any "aggressor."

Joseph C. Quirk of Greenwich, Conn., heads the judging slate announced yesterday for the Morris and Essex Kennel Club show, this country's foremost outdoor dog fixture. It will take place Saturday, May 24, on the estate of Mrs. M. Hartley Dodge, the show's sponsor, at Madison, N.J.

WHEN Nick was adopted and his sister Penny was left behind in the Florida orphanage they ran away and hid all night in an empty sailboat. Thus they met Ben, a very good guy who was having his own troubles trying to keep his uncle from selling the boat.

THE petunia is making horticultural news. Long a popular annual, it has been so improved of recent years by foremost hybridists that the newest varieties would be almost unrecognizable to an old-time gardener, so much more glamorous are they than the simple petunia of yesteryear.

Although financial markets continued to act cautiously last week, there were many signs of an improvement in sentiment as the week drew to a close. Outstanding was the better relations between the steel industry and labor on the current wage negotiations, and a possible solution to the porportalto-portal pay controversy.

Thomas Jefferson, the nation's first Secretary of State, took office on March 21, 1790. He headed a department staff of five clerks, a diplomatic corps of three ministers and sixteen consular representatives. Only four foreign countries--France, Denmark, Spain and Great Britain--took the new republic seriously enough to honor it with legations.

American textbooks used in school and colleges are on the whole free from any intentional bias toward any population group. However, a number of books, wholly without malice, perpetuate errors and myths about the different cultural or national groups in this country.

Predictions that food prices would lead a general decline in prices during 1947 were substantiated by food industry leaders meeting in Atlantic City last week. They seemed to agree that the cost of food items to the consumer would decline about 25 per cent from present levels during the next twelve months.

THE usual post-holiday travel lull does not appear to have materialized this year, according to local travel agents, who report continued heavy bookings for Florida, points South and the West Coast. Particularly in demand are train reservations for San Diego and Los Angeles.

BERLIN, Jan. 25--Jews in displaced persons camps are so acutely aware of anti-semitism that if occupation troops were withdrawn tomorrow they would leave the camps and scatter, Rabbi Barnett R. Brickner of New York said today.

THE bird-of-paradise flower, Strelitzia regina, has become familiar of late because it is suitable for flower arrangements in the modern manner. It is seen in flower shops more often than in homes, but it can be grown, none the less, as a house plant.

TOKYO, Jan. 25--Purges have taken or are taking toll of most of Japan's experienced big business men and public servants of today but those of the past will be spared, according to a Home Ministry announcement. Monuments to national heroes, erected before the Manchurian incident of 1931, will be allowed to remain.

THE philatelist who "knows" his stamps in association with history is studying the peace treaties now concluded with Italy, Hungary, Bulgaria, Rumania and Finland. Some major transitions in geography are included under the terms of the pacts drawn up by the Allied and Associated Powers and there is ample precedent, particularly developments during the era immediately after the first World War, to suggest that current changes affecting terrain will result in new postal paper.

LONDON, Jan. 25--Before the horrified gaze of relatives and friends who had been waving farewell, twelve of the twenty-three passengers and crew of a Dakota plane were burned to death today at Croydon Airport.

IN publishing the first American edition of GranvilleBarker's "Prefaces to Shakespeare" the Princeton University Press has performed an inestimable service to all students and lovers of Shakespeare. The director and producer, professional or collegiate, will be most in his debt, the potential actor almost equally so; for GranvilleBarker was first, and in his heart's core, a man of the theatre; but he was also a scholar, a playwright and a man of letters.

AMSTERDAM -- The Netherlands is devoting much thought and debate to its coming touring season and the possibility of developing an all-time record harvest of tourists to yield, an estimated $10,000,000 to bolster the nation's foreignexchange position.

MUSSOLINI'S "new order" has yet to receive the fictional treatment of the late Adolf Hitler's; somehow the Italians have escaped being typed as melodramatic villains, and, except for Hersey's sympathetic portrayal, their collective experience in the war is only now beginning to be explored--outside of Italy.

DETROIT, Mich., Jan. 25--Judge Frank A. Picard, author of the muti-billion-dollar portal-to-portal pay opinion, retired to his home in Saginaw today to review evidence on which he will reconsider his decision.

The case against Hideki Tojo, Japan's wartime Premier, and twenty-five other Japanese war lords is now complete. The prosecution has rested and the remainder of the trial before the tennation international tribunal in Tokyo will be devoted to the defense. The proceedings have already lasted eight months and may take six months more.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25--Senate Republican leaders appeared today to be seeking a compromise with the State Department to permit the Administration to extend its reciprocal trade program, but with limited authority to reduce tariffs.

NANKING, Jan. 25--In further elaboration of the Communist antiGovernment and anti-American propaganda campaign, the Yenan Government has proclaimed Nov. 4 "National Humiliation Day." The Sino-American commercial treaty was signed at Nanking on Nov. 4, 1946.

BERNE, Switzerland. Jan. 26-- Reports received here from Spain indicate that the economic crisis there is increasingly serious. Moreover, quiet negotiations are still proceeding between Monarchist and Republican political representatives in an effort to find agreement on grounds to oust the Franco regime without another civil war.

SAIGON, French Indo-China, Jan. 26--It is difficult to see how France can achieve a military victory in Indo-China in a reasonable length of time, even with the promised reinforcements and with superior arms.

Rocky Graziano, leading contender for the middleweight boxing title, was questioned Saturday night and until 5 A. M. yesterday by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan and two aides in the racket bureau exploring the peculiar circumstances of the cancellation of Graziano's scheduled bout with Ruben (Cowboy) Shank.

Governor Dewey gave the opinion yesterday that the Polish election of Jan. 19 "constituted a contemptuous indifference to the principles of free government" and that the results cannot be accepted "as giving the present Polish Government a mandate."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The National Labor Relations Board told Congress today that the Wagner act, which the board administers, had "served the public well by reducing strife" resulting from disputes over the organization and recognition of unions.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Jan. 26-- Twenty-eight jaunty little sailing dinghies were sent through their paces today in the cold-season regatta at the Larchmont Yacht Club and again that front-running Wall Street skipper Arthur Knapp, who spends his week days in the steam heat and hot air of the Stock Exchange, came out the victor.

Seventeen members of local school boards in Manhattan, whose appointment was announced yesterday by Borough President Hugo E. Rogers, will be sworn in tomorrow at 3 P. M. in Mr. Rogers' office in the Municipal Building.

Attorney General Tom C. Clark gave full credit yesterday to Clinton P. Anderson, Secretary of Agriculture, for having started the investigation that led to the filing of criminal informations against the Dairymen's League Cooperative Association and four of its officials for alleged violation of the Commodities Exchange Act by rigging wholesale butter prices here in December.

Donald Strachan and Charles Brinton of the Philadelphia Country Club gained the Arthur H. Lockett Trophy yesterday by emerging in first place in the invitation squash racquets doubles tournament at the University Club. Strachan and Brinton, who hold the national championship were forced to go through some intense competition to capture the award, one of the highly prized trophies in the realm of squash racquets.

High heels wero outlawed and excessive use of the "loafer shoe" and the sneaker condemned yesterday at the annual "day of science" of the Podiatry Society of the State of New York, held at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Jan. 26 -- Grace Moore, 45-year-old American opera and film star, Prince Gustaf Adolf, eldest son of the Crown Prince of Sweden, and twenty other persons were killed today when a Dakota plane of the KLM Dutch Airline nosedived to the Kastrup airport, near here, two minutes after its take-off.

LITTLE AMERICA, Jan. 25 (Delayed)--Little America I., the camp of Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd's 1928-29 Antarctic expedition and base for the only flight over the South Pole, was revisited today for the first time in six years.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Jan. 26--"If My Verses Had Wings," to the music of Reynaldo Hahn, was the greatest hit in Grace Moore's program last night. Her singing again conquered the Danish audience hi Copenhagen's largest hall, which had been converted for her final concert.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 26 (AP) -- Ben Hogan, the little Mr. Big of golf, shattered par and the hopes of his rivals today as he won the $10,000 Phoenix open tournament with a 72-hole score of 270, keeping the title he won a year ago. United States Open Champion Lloyd Mangrum of Chicago and Ed (Porky) Oliver of Wilmington, Del., tied for second place with scores of 277.

Mayor O'Dwyer will break ground for additions to Public Schools 102 and 106 in the Park-Chester area of the Bronx tomorrow afternoon, it was announced yesterday. The school construction is the first to be initiated in the Bronx in five years. The halt was occasioned by the war.

The Young Men's Board of Trade of New York, 291 Broadway, acting as coordinator of the efforts of business and industry, lists the following free services to aid veterans in career-planning and employment.

The world's food problem is to be attacked by the voluntary action of separate nations, voluntary cooperation among nations and an advisory World Food Council. This decision, backed by American pressure, was reached last week by the Preparatory Commission of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization after nearly three months of discussions by representatives of seventeen nations meeting in Washington.

The famous Poughkeepsie Regatta, missing from the rowing calendar since 1941, is to be revived this year, according to an announcement yesterday by Asa Bushnell, commissioner of the Eastern College Athletic Conference.
ORLANDO, Fla., Jan. 26 (AP)-- Two upsets marked the finals of the twentieth annual Florida State tennis tournament today as topranked performers in both the men's and women's division were defeated.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP)-- President Truman said today that the country faced "fateful" security problems, and urged all citizens to join in observing "National Security Week" Feb. 12-22.

In conformity with the plans worked out by his predecessor, Secretary of State Marshall has decided to attend the next meeting of the Big Four Foreign Ministers, scheduled to begin in Moscow March 10 for the drafting of peace settlements with Germany and Austria.

HOUMA, La., Jan. 26 (AP)--Two questions popped up in the Evangeline League today following the declaration by Judge W. G. Bramham that five players in the baseball circuit are ineligible for further participation in the game because of charges that they conspired to "throw" a contest in a post-season series between Houma and Abbeville, La.
MOSCOW, Jan. 26--Economic unity for Germany is assuming increasing importance here.

From the amusement world's cornucopia of talent came entertainers galore prepared to aid the sick and distressed of their profession at last night's sixty-fifth annual benefit of the Actors Fund of America, held at the Majestic Theatre.

During 1946 production of radio sets broke all previous records for the industry, it was announced over the week-end by the Radio Manufacturers Association. FMAM and television receiver production reached their peak in December, it was stated, indicating a steadily rising growth for 1947.

A midwinter thaw is a brief interlude of relaxation. Cold weather loosens its grip momentarily and rivulets of pewter-gray water trickle around the ends of barns and across farmyards. Usually there is a day or more of rain that clears the snow from roofs and changes smooth white fields to gray granular-grained stretches.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 26 --News of the death of Prince Gustaf Adolf today was broken to Sweden by a radio flash that interrupted a program.

CINCINNATI, Jan., 26 (AP)-- Union printers at Cincinnati's three daily newspapers voted tonight to strike in protest over contract differences but delayed setting a date for the walkout pending further negotiations.

The Grace Line's Santa Rosa, due to dock here this morning, conies back to her peacetime role of Caribbean cruise liner after eight and one-half months of reconversion work. The port will extend its traditional welcome, with fireboats, airplanes, tugs and launches participating.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 26--The United States Steel Corporation is expected to make its counter proposals to the fourteen demands of the United Steel Workers, CIO, on (resumption of contract negotiations here at 10:15 A. M. tomorrow.
The Rev. Dr. Robert James McCracken, pastor of Riverside Church, preached his first sermon of the new year yesterday after an extended vacation.

BRATISLAVA, Czechoslovakia, Jan. 26-Deputy Foreign Minister Vladimir Clementis said tonight, after week-end conversations here with Foreign Minister Janos Gyongyosi of Hungary, that he saw no evidence of an early change-in the stalemate over Czechoslovakia's desire to transfer some 300,000 Magyars from Slovakia to Hungary.

Rejecting threats of a teachers' strike as undignified and unprofessional, the United Teachers of the City of New York announced yesterday its incorporation with 3,000 members and a program for the permanent improvement of teaching conditions.

MOSCOW, Jan. 26--The Anglo-American pipeline agreement in the Near East is viewed here as another aspect of the organization by the United States of a world-wide system of military and economic bases alongside existing British naval and air bases.

LONDON, Jan. 26--The stock markets here, which up to now have shown an amazing disregard of the steadily gathering clouds on Britin's economic horizon, have displayed in the last few days an awareness of what is threatening.

TUXEDO PARK, N. Y., Jan. 26 --Robert Grant 3d, national amateur titleholder, reached top form for his American professional racquets match next Wednesday by defeating Frederic F. de Rham of Tuxedo here today in the Tuxedo gold racquet tournament final, 15-9, 15-7, 15-7.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26--Factory workers averaged $46.83 a week during last December, just 70 cents below their peak wartime earnings of January, 1945, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 26--A National Institute of Fine Arts and Literature, dedicated to the best possible presentation to the world of "the personality of Mexico," has been established by decree of President Miguel Aleman. It will be headed by Carlos Chavez, conductor and composer, with the cooperation of the nation's leading artists, painters, actors, sculptors and writers.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26--A broader demand for loose lard is reported, including talk that soap manufacturers took a moderate amount last week and continue to bid 23 1/2 cents a pound while packers are asking 24 cents.

Automotive vehicles which originally cost over $3,300,000, including 107 amphibian "ducks" from the armed forces, are among current offerings of approximately $256,000,000 surplus goods by the War Assets Administration, Carl P. Malmstrom, regional director, disclosed over the week-end. Seven new location sales for veterans, small business and commercial buyers are scheduled, he said.
STOCKHOLM, Jan. 26 (AP)-- Prince Gustaf Adolf started chooling himself for royal duties early and at 18 presided for the first time over a Cabinet Council meeting.

The Pro Arte Quartet returned to the New Friends of Music late yesterday afternoon for that organization's eleventh concert of the season at Town Hall. The group played Bartok's Fifth String Quartet, Stravinsky's Concertino for String Quartet and Dvorak's Quartet in G major, Op. 106.

Marion Kerby, who in the late Twenties established a form of entertainment known as "Negro exaltations," and thus was a pioneer in the singing of spirituals, gave a performance of these "exaltations" yesterday afternoon at Times Hall.

An expanding economy in the United States, with a higher standard of living, will prove effective against racial bigotry and intolerance, according to Thurman Arnold, former Assistant United States Attorney General. He spoke to the American Jewish Committee last night at the closing session of its fortieth annual meeting in the Hotel Commodore.

ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- Governor Dewey's Executive Budget, which will be submitted to the Legislature this week, will recommend an increase of $60,000,000, or almost 20 per cent, in State aid to local governmental units, it was reported reliably tonight.

After initial weakness, cotton prices in the domestic market last week turned firmer and closed the period generally higher. At the close on Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net changes for the week of 1 point up to 54 points down. The only net decline was registered in. the spot month.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 26 -- A 48year-old British business man and former Army major, H.A.I. Collins, was kidnapped tonight from a house in the center of Jerusalem by four men and a girl armed with revolvers and a tommy-gun. All five are said to be members of the Irgun Zvai Leumi, a terrorist organization.

DHAHRAN, Saudi Arabia, Jan. 26--With the new wells being drilled this year American concessionaires in Saudi Arabia will have more than enough oil to meet their commitments and fill the 1,200mile pipeline it is proposed to build from here to the Mediterranean coast.

In the old Roman days it was truthfully said that the crowd on the Appian Way never grew old. The same cannot be said in modern times of the crowds on Broadway and Fifth Avenue. The City Health Department, reporting on this matter Saturday, sketches the change in the situation since 1898.
