Wanda Landowska gave her first recital of the season last night at Town Hall before an ardently enthusiastic capacity audience. The eminent harpsichordist again proved her right to a unique and enviable niche of her own among keyboard artists of the present time.

SAIGON, Jan. 25 (Delayed)-- (AP)--Vice Adm. Georges Thierry d'Argenlieu, French High Commissioner to Indo-China, said today that the Viet-Namese Government of President Ho Chi Minh was Communist-inspired and that the conflict in Indo-China was another battleground between the western democracies and Marxism.

Al Capone was the symbol of a shameful era, the monstrous symptom of a disease which was eating into the conscience of America. Looking back to it now, this period of Prohibition in full, ugly flower seems fantastically incredible. Capone himself was incredible, the creation of an evil dream.

In a move to streamline the operation of the city subway lines, the Board of Transportation has awarded to the Budd Company of Philadelphia a $1,158,800 contract for manufacture and delivery of ten stainless steel cars, to be operated as an experimental train on the BMT and IND divisions of the city system.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I hope you will find space for some comments on the recent letter from Hyman H. Bookbinder, assistant director of research, Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America. He takes the position that the proposed uniform 20 per cent reduction in income tax rates would unfairly benefit the higher income groups at the expense of the lower income groups and offers the following table purporting to demonstrate it:

LITTLE AMERICA, Jan. 26 (AP) --Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd and his six big transport planes were poised for a take-off from the small flight deck of the carrier Philippine Sea today--while the ship wallowed through the only bad weather in the Antarctic areas the Navy expedition is exploring.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26--The right of the Arab states to discuss the future of Palestine through participation in the Anglo-Arab Conference on Palestine to convene in London tomorrow was challenged here tonight by Dr. Abba Hillel Silver, president of the Zionist Organization of America.

Business in the wholesale markets last week was active as reorders began to arrive already, pointing to a good spring season, and indicating that buyers may have underestimated needs in their first purchases, according to the reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. In the textile trades, the allotment plan was being abandoned, it was reported.

Rifled of an estimated $21,600 in cash and jewelry, the 150 steel safe deposit boxes stolen early Saturday from a Coney Island bathhouse were found yesterday scattered about a vacant lot in the New Lots district in Brooklyn.

THERE was universal satisfaction in sports circles last week when Messrs. Carl Hubbell, Frank Frisch, Mickey Cochrane and Lefty Grove were ushered up the celestial stairway to baseball immortality in the Hall of Fame. The baseball writers did the voting, as usual, and they finally elected someone to Cooperstown after five years of failing to elect anyone.

The visit of Frank J. Sampson and Democratic State Chairman Paul E. Fitzpatrick to the White House last Friday is to be followed up with an immediate "offensive" in the drive to reorganize Tam-many Hall, it was disclosed yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: With regard to your editorial of Jan. 21 entitled "Czechoslovakia's Minorities," which was evidently inspired by two dispatches of your correspondent, Albion Ross, from Bratislava which were published on Jan. 19 and 20, I wish to make a few comments.
WASHINGTON. Jan. 26 (U.P.)-- The Post Office Department soon will put out a new "air letter," similar to V mail, that can be sent anywhere outside the United States for 10 cents.

The United States must "turn to the East" and maintain its power and prestige "always at the highest level" among the one billion members of the Oriental races to prevent the spread of communism in that area, Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, Philippine delegate to the United Nations, said yesterday.

Twenty British graduate students are now studying in this country under Commonwealth Fund Fellowships, the twentyeighth annual report of the fund disclosed yesterday. This constitutes a renewal, after a lapse of five years during the war, of a program originated in 1925 by the late Edward S. Harkness, then president of the fund.

TOKYO, Monday, Jan. 27 (AP)-- Sir William Webb, Australian president of the International War Crimes Court, refused today to hear defense motions challenging Gen. Douglas MacArthur's authority to set up the tribunal hearing the case against former Premier Hideki Tojo and twenty-six others.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26--Wheat prices averaged higher and feed grains lower on the Board of Trade last week, with March wheat selling close to the seasonal high. July corn came within a small fraction of a cent of the seasonal low and July and September oats went to a new low.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (U.P.)-- A high official of the Congress of Industrial Organizations tonight called the American Federation of Labor's position on the national wage increase question "diabolical" as signs increased that the two organizations were squaring away for an Intensified battle for leadership of the labor movement.

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 26 -- In one of the closest elections in collective bargaining history, the United Automobile Workers' Local 248 appeared tonight on the basis of complete returns to have retained its collective bargaining rights in the plant of the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company in West Allis, where a strike has been going on for 273 days.
CHICAGO, Jan. 26 (U.P.)--The Chicago Black Hawks rallied tonight to gain a 6-6 tie with the league-leading Toronto Maple Leafs in a National Hockey League game before 17,673 fans.

New York officials of KLM were in touch with the airline's headquarters in Amsterdam last nigh seeking a full explanation of the crash of the Dutch airliner at Copenhagen. They expected to receive a full report after a committee of experts had viewed the wreckage.

The recent news that some of the nation's leading rail systems have laid off employes as part of a program to reduce expenses came as a surprise to many people largely because they were acquainted only casually with the difficult and uncertain position into which the railroads have been forced by economic and political developments.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Jan. 26 --Toward his official economists and the profession they represent President Truman is "from Missouri," the economists and statisticians of the country learned as the joint annual meeting's of their organizations closed in the Haddon Hall Hotel today.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $58,369,158,693. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of in-debtedness, bills and notes as follows:

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 26--What will be the biggest high-pressure pipeline in the world is being fabricated by a steel plant here at the rate of nine miles a week to link Southern California's growing market for gas with the naturalgas fields of New Mexico and west Texas.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 26--Although the Government has staved off an immediate Chinese New Year crash by credit subsidies to hardpressed business, Wang Hsia-lai, chairman of the National Chamber of Commerce, predicted here today that an economic bacle would be forthcoming this spring unless the civil war were ended.

PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 26-- The appointment of Dr. Donald B. Aldrich, former Bishop Coadjutor of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Michigan and for twenty years rector of the Church of the Ascension, New York City, to succeed Dean Robert Russell Wicks as dean of the Frinceton University Chapel was announced today by Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of the university.

ATLANTA, Jan. 26 -- George B. Hamilton, State Treasurer, warned the rival Governorship claimants tonight to submit at once to consent to litigation in the State courts to settle their dispute if a serious crisis in the financing of State services was to be averted.

ALBANY, Jan. 26--Six bills designed to reduce fire hazards in hotels, tenements, lodging houses and apartments in New York City will toe introduced tomorrow on behalf of Senator MacNeil Mitchell's joint legislative committee on housing and multiple dwellings, it was announced tonight.
CHICAGO, Jan. 26 (U.P)--Club owners still haggled over the National Football League's 1947 schedule tonight, twenty-four hours after their three-day meet was supposed to end.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26--The National Education Association was assailed as a "company union" today and blamed by the American Federation of Labor for the critical shortage of teachers.

Extension for two and one-half months of the wage agreement between the United States Steel Corporation and the United Steel Workers, CIO, was interpreted in labor circles yesterday as evidence of Philip Murray's determination to avoid big CIO strikes this year.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Jan. 26-- How the ski report can become a fundamental part of college life is vividly demonstrated here at historic-steeped Middlebury, where virtually all of the 1,200 student body spends most of its leisure time learning to handle a pair of hickory boards.

BERLIN, Jan. 26 -- United States and British officials, announcing the first major agreement with a foreign government to facilitate international trade for the Germans, disclosed tonight that they had signed a provision permitting Netherlands businessmen to deal directly with the Germans.

After three years of comparative sanity, delirium has been restored in the mile run. Gilbert Dodds, the man of God who gallops at a devilish pace, is responsible. The pounding parson, back on the board-track merry-go-round after a three-year absence, created the nightmare with his smashing 4:09.1 solo in Boston.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Robert P. Patterson, Secretary of War, told the twenty-first Women's Patriotic Conference on National Defense today that universal military training "is a must."

Brand Name Show Oct. 27 There are about 1,500 items in the wearing apparel, accessory and furnishings field that can be called for by name, it was said over the week-end by Arthur Tarshis, president of Exhibitions of Fashions, Inc.
Add to the horse-racing records of 1946 the all-time high of $852,025 in steeplechase purse distribution.

MADRID, Jan. 26--All Spain is still suffering today from a cold wave that began yesterday with heavy snow all over northern Spain. With discomfort increased by biting wind, the present fuel shortage makes suffering acute among the poorer classes.

Changes and modernization of the American Locomotive Company's executive organization nave been made in order to meet changing conditions in the railroad equipment field, it was announced over the week-end by Robert B. McColl, president.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26--Immediate adoption of universal military training to supplant the Selective Service system was urged today by the American Legion's National Defense Committee.

WASHINGTON. Jan. 26 (AP)-- President Truman may give Congress this week his recommendations on dropping some war powers and continuing others, an official disclosed today, with decontrol of molasses under consideration.

America is fast becoming one of the most pagan nations in the world, the Rev. Dr. Gordon H. Baker declared yesterday in a sermon at the Lenox Road Baptist Church, Lenox Road and Nostrand Avenue, Brooklyn.

The present week in the art world is unique in that all of the approximately thirty new events are one-man shows. Today's openings include the first post-war show of recent paintings by Picasso at the Samuel Kootz Gallery. Two author-artists are also represented in the galleries--little pictures by the dramatist Clifford Odets at the New Art Circle and paintings by Langston Moffett in a show opening tomorrow at the Luyber Gallery in the Hotel Brevoort.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 26-- Metro - Goldwyn - Mayer has announced that Frank Sinatra's next picture for the company will be "The Kissing Bandit," a Joseph Pasternak production, in which the singer will appear with Kathryn Grayson.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Jan. 26 --The resettlement of 20,000 displaced persons as coal miners in Belgium under an agreement about to be signed in Brussels will mark the beginning of a series of positive steps to resettle those of the 500,000 displaced persons in the American zone who will never go home, Elliott M. Shirk, zonal chief for the Inter-Governmental Committee on Refugees, said today.

MINEOLA, L. I., Jan. 26--Led by District Attorney James N. Gehrig and Chief Inspector William K. Allen, a squad of thirty detectives and uniformed police of Nassau County staged an early morning raid on a dice game in Glen Head today that netted ninety-nine players, twelve alleged operators and $10,600 in cash.

In an interesting report on the present mood of Germany published yesterday in the NEW YORK TIMES Magazine, Shepard Stone quotes a Heidelberg student as saying, first, that most of the students are still nationalistic, and, second, that 90 per cent of them would leave Germany if they had a chance to emigrate.

David H. Gordon Jr., 28-year-old Army veteran and a former student at Harvard University, plunged to his death, from the eighty-sixth floor observation tower of the Empire State Building yesterday morning, and his body struck a woman pedestrian, who was critically injured. The police listed his death as a suicide.
DHAHRAN, Saudi Arabia, Jan. 25 (Delayed)--A revolution in Arabian society was accomplished today by the American community of Dhahran.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26--The War Assets Administration threw open the door today for the export sale of surplus goods. Revising policy, the WAA placed nonpriority exporters and nonpriority domestic buyers on an equal basis as to price, apportionment of quantities and other conditions of sale.

The Right Rev. Charles Kendall Gilbert, for the last sixteen years suffragan Bishop or assistant Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, will be nominated for Bishop tomorrow by the Rev. Dr. Louis W. Pitt, rector of Grace Church, Broadway and Tenth Street.
ALBANY, Jan. 26 (AP)--The appointment of minimum wage boards for the beauty service, confectionery and cleaning and dyeing industries was announced today by Edward Corsi, Industrial Commissioner.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Jan. 26 --The United Nations Security Council is scheduled to take up the British-Albanian mine dispute at its next meeting on Tuesday but up to tonight no formal word had been received at United Nations headquarters here from Tirana concerning the controversy.

A continued but not crippling reduction in the size of the armed forces during the fiscal year 1948 was indicated last week as the House Appropriations Committee started hearings on the $11,256,000,000 budget for the Army and Navy.

Grace Moore, the soprano who was killed yesterday in the crash of an airliner in Copenhagen, had sung her way from the choir of the First Baptist Church of Jellico, Tenn., to the stage of the Metropolitan Opera House.

MOSCOW, Jan. 26 -- The program for United States foreign policy laid down by Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg in his Cleveland speech was assailed in Pravda today as a consistent and frank program of imperialist expansion. Pravda also declared that the proposal of John Foster Dulles for the organization of a Western bloc, including Germany, France, the Netherlands and Belgium would be indignantly rejected here.

LONDON, Monday, Jan. 27-- Every newspaper in London this morning devoted editorial comment to crashes of Dakota planes over the week-end and they all demanded an investigation into reasons. Experts generally say the cause was overloading.

The Metropolitan Opera House was filled to capacity last night for the annual benefit concert of the Knights of Columbus. The program was opened by the Metropolitan's orchestra, Max Rudolf conducting, in the Overture to Rossini's "Il Barbiere di Siviglia," after which Thelma Altman sang numbers by Verdi and Rachmaninoff, and Henrietta Schumann played the last movement of Rachmaninoff's Second Piano Concerto, in C minor.

DETROIT, Jan. 26 (AP)--Mario Trafeli, 18-year-old Wayne University football player from Detroit, captured the senior men's crown in the North American speed skating championships here today by coming from behind to a thrilling victory in the final fivemile race.

This is the second in a series of articles on the preparation and carving of large cuts of meat. The third will appear next Monday. Though a carver may be skilled in the technique of cutting a roast so that it will yield the greatest possible number of delicately tender slices, it is essential that he have good tools with which to work if he is to do his best.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 26 (AP)--Preliminary steps toward formation of the Class A Atlantic Coast Baseball League were taken today and brought from Claude B. Davidson, who presided, a prediction that an eight-club circuit will be organized by next fall and in operation by 1948.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 26--Despite the fact that most steel companies have refused to make firm commitments on delivery promises beyond the end of the second quarter of this year, steel demand last week was said to be continuing at a high level.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 26 (U.P.) --The Punjab Government tonight released the eight Moslem leaders whose arrest Friday precipitated two days of rioting throughout the Province and brought a scathing denunciation of the act from Mohammed Ali Jinnah, Moslem League president.

BERLIN, Jan. 26 (AP)--Lieut. Gen. Lucius D. Clay challenged as a "prematurely drawn conclusion" today an assertion by the International Committee for the Study of European Questions that the great majority of Germans were not accepting a conversion to democracy.

BOSTON, Jan. 26 (U.P.)--The Boston Bruins, sparked by Joe Carveth, regained third place in the National Hockey League tonight with a 4-to-3 victory over the Detroit Red Wings before a capacity throng of 13,900 at Boston Garden.

Rare gems and crystals in the collection of the American Museum of Natural History, which, were stored in a New York bank vault during the war years, are again on display at the museum, Central Park West and Seventy-ninth Street, Dr. Frederick H. Pough, curator of mineralogy, announced yesterday.

Tribute to Trinity In all our memory, Trinity Church has stood a dark brown pile at the top of Wall Street, and Wall Street has been a narrow canyon between skyscrapers. The skyscrapers have risen higher and the canyon gone darker and deeper until from down in it the church is seen through a mere slit.

WEEK ENDED, JAN. 25, 1947 An incident which came at the week-end and fell upon a market ordinarily limited by the half-session, that of an order by the Canadian Foreign Exchange Control Board governing the sale of short-term Canadian, securities in this market by Canadian nationals, passed over without effect because of the short trading period left to its workings.

PHILADELPHIA. Jan. 26--New issues of corporate securities offered for cash sale in October aggregated $323,000,000, compared with a monthly average of $510,000,000 for the first nine months of 1946, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today in its December Stastical Bulletin.
JERUSALEM, Jan. 26 (U.P.) -- Mr. Collins was kidnapped as he was having afternoon tea in his apartment with a Jewish girl. She said three underground men and the

The National Association of Manufacturers in a statement over the week-end urged industrialists to use extreme caution in basing production and marketing plans on current statistical interpretations of the nation's industrial inventories.

Investment banking men here generally believe that a Federal lending agency like the Reconstruction Finance Corporation can serve a useful purpose in the nation's post-war life if the agency is held within strict limits by Congressional definition and if it is set up to complement, not to compete with, private finance.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26 (U.P.) --Cotton fabrics now can be protected from mildew by making them fire-resistant, scientists at the Philadelphia Quartermaster Depot have announced.
The twentieth century must choose between leadership by religion or by dictators, the Rev. Dr. George Fielden MacLeod, leader of Scotland's Iona movement to rejuvenate Christianity, said yesterday.

Published reports that his office is exercising or threatening to exercise undue censorship over current or future theatrical productions on Broadway were described yesterday by License Commissioner Benjamin Fielding as "unwarranted agitation."

ZURICH, Switzerland, Jan. 26-- If the Swiss-Argentine trade agreement signed last Monday after months of negotiation works smoothly in practice, the economic advantage to both countries will be substantial. Each has just what the other wants.

Unable to make a go of it, "Little A," with a cast headed by Otto Kruger, Jessie Royce Landis and Wallis Clark, drops out of contention Saturday night at Henry Miller's. The total run at that house will consist of twenty-one performances.

The Citizens Union, in a letter to Mayor O'Dwyer. went on record yesterday as opposing the plan of the City Airport Authority for the development of Idlewild and La Guardia Fields and favoring the plan of the Port of New York Authority.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 26--A spokesman for the Foreign Office charged today that the Greek Government was obstructing the work of the Balkan inquiry commission appointed by the "United Nations by the tactic of delaying the issuance of visas to the Yugoslav delegation.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 26 (U.P.)-- Egypt has broken off negotiations with Britain for revision of the 1936 treaty and will submit all "outstanding problems" to the United Nations Security Council, Premier Mahmoud Fahmy Nokrashy Pasha announced today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26 (AP)--The International Harvester Company announced today that although its sales in 1946 were the highest for any peacetime year, net income was less than in 1945. Its net income last year was $22,326,000, equal to $3.91 a share of common stock, compared with $24,477,000, or $4.42 a share, in the previous year.

The accumulated liability of employers under the decision of the United States Supreme Court on portal-to-portal pay is so great that it could cause bankruptcies, prevent reduction of the personal income tax and affect the Federal treasury, the national debt and the public interest, Raymond S. Smethurst, counsel for the National Association of Manufacturers, declared in a debate broadcast last night.
The Iron Horse is changing his diet from coal to oil.

A bill transferring to the Commissioner of Housing and Buildings virtually all the exclusive powers of the five borough superintendents has been introduced in the City Council with Mayor O'Dwyer's approval, it was learned yesterday. The measure, sponsored by Councilman Joseph T. Sharkey of Brooklyn, Democratic majority leader, is in the hands of the building committee.

LONDON, Jan. 26--The five Yemenite delegates to the Palestine conference arrived here today and the stage is now set for another apparently hopeless effort to solve the Palestine problem However, this time, it is universally expected that, when the inevitable impasse is reached, the British Government will at last plunge for a definite plan for Palestine.

Eighteen years ago Britain enacted the legislation which from that day to the present has been the basis of her system of regulation of corporate practices--the Companies Act of 1929. With the passage of time that Act, like most codes of the kind, revealed increasingly serious defects in its practical application; defects which produced mounting public criticism and a public demand for modernization of the law.

Stricter control of dogs rather than compulsory vaccination against rabies was urged yesterday on the city Board of Health. Two dozen speakers, who gave their views on a proposal to require annual vaccination of all dogs in New York City, appeared at a public hearing called by the board in Washington Irving High School auditorium, East Sixteenth Street and Irving Place.

Sharply increasing traffic on the city's transit system, run down by years of receivership and war, soon will create subway jams that only the fittest of New York's millions of daily riders will survive, Charles P. Gross, chairman of the Board of Transportation, warned yesterday.

Representatives of several leading American Art galleries met recently to make final arrangements for an organization of dealers in American art. The institutions represented included the A.C.A., Babcock. Downtown, Ferargil, Grand Central, Kraushaar, Macbeth, Midtown, Milch and Rehn galleries.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 27 -- The United States Steel Corporation proposed today an open shop for its five subsidiary companies as it opposed a union-shop demand made by the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, as part of the union's fourteen demands for a 1947 wage contract.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 -- Demand for quality merchandise at reasonable prices marked the opening of the spring market week here as trade spokesmen today declared that a "normal" market was under way in contrast to the frenzied buying of the last few years.

The preliminary report of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad disclosed yesterday a net operating income for 1946 of $958,326 in contrast to $10,552,809 for the previous year. The gross income was $149,259,513 compared with $173,196,985.

Reports that textile mills were finding difficulties in buying the qualities of cotton needed stimulated yesterday a trade covering movement in the cotton futures market. On the New York Cotton Exchange prices rose 26 to 32 points on the day.

In its annual report, just published, the National Labor Relations Board argues that it is unfair to blame the Wagner Act for the wave of strikes that cost the country more than a hundred million "man-days" of work last year -- by far the greatest loss on record.

PARIS, Jan. 27 -- The French liner Pasteur docked today at Marseilles with 1,500 civilian and military evacuees from Indo-China, including 350 ill or wounded soldiers. According to a dispatch by Maurice Ferro, correspondent of the Monde, who accompanied them from Saigon, disease is almost as effective an enemy as the Viet Namese.

Reporting on operations of Universal Pictures Company, Inc., for the fiscal year ended on Nov. 2, last, J. Cheever Cowdin, board chairman, and N.J. Blumberg, president, informed stockholders in the annual report issued yesterday that the company broke all records in income from operations, net profits and working capital.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 27 -- Confident of support from the Soviet Union, the Egyptian Government formally announced tonight that it would appeal to the United Nations Security Council in an effort to terminate the 65-year-old British occupation of Egypt and to obtain recognition of Egyptian sovereignty over the Sudan.

An exhibition of embroideries and needlework techniques called "Stitches in Time," was opened yesterday afternoon at Cooper Union" Museum with a private view for members of the museum's advisory council and representatives of the Pleaters, Stitchers and Embroiderers Association and the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, Local 66, which supplied the modern examples.

PARIS, Jan. 27 -- The United States outdistanced all foreign purveyors to France during 1946, according to official customs figures obtained here today. Goods purchased from the United States were 35.5 per cent of the total imports, compared with 15.5 per cent in 1938.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 27 -- Arthur J. Altmeyer, the American representative, proposed to the Social Commission of the Economic and Social Council today that it adopt seven guiding principles for the operation of the International Children's Emergency Fund.

ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- Governor Dewey called tonight for the immediate appropriation of $2,500,000 to insure that the hot-lunch program in the schools, jeopardized because all Federal aid would be used up within a month, could be continued without interruption.
Following are the texts of memorandums written by Mr. Stimson after talks with Presidents Roosevelt and Truman.

New York harbor extended its traditional loud and colorful welcome yesterday to the refurbished Grace liner Santa Rosa. She arrived here from Newport News, Va., where she underwent reconditioning after serving as a transport.

The belief that disease is a natural consequence of old age was called "a false concept" yesterday by Miss Marion Rickert of the New York State Department of Social Welfare. The same diseases afflict young persons, but the consequences are more grave among the aged, she said.
PARIS, Jan. 27 -- Dr. Jose Giral resigned today as Premier of the Spanish Government in exile and asked Diego Martinez Barrio, as exiled President, to form another Cabinet.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Government, labor and industry officials scanned the industrial horizon today and saw signs that betokened the possibility that the nation may be moving into "an era of good feeling" in labor relations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Reversal of a Federal District Court ruling holding the Lea Act, which was aimed at the "stand-by" rules established by the American Federation of Musicians, to be unconstitutional, was asked of the Supreme Court by the Justice Department today.

ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- To assure that housing on properties condemned for city projects be salvaged wherever possible, the O'Dwyer administration asked authority tonight to relocate for purposes of resale any dwellings thus acquired.

Carl H.T. Sloss has been appointed national sales manager for the Cohama men's wear fabrics department, it was announced yesterday by Edwin Loewy, vice president in charge of the Cohama Fabrics division of the Cohn-HallMarx Company.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Jan. 26 (Delayed) -- While the peace treaties with Hungary, Rumania and Bulgaria are about to be signed and ratified and the pact with Austria is being discussed, their real future is being written not on paper in the capitals of the great powers but in actuality on the spot.

Important executive changes in the Corning Glass organization, announced yesterday by William C. Decker, president, include the election of Eugene W. Ritter as president of Corning Glass Works of South America. Formerly vice president and manager of the company's consumer products division, Mr. Ritter succeeds William H. Curtiss, who will continue as vice president and secretary of Corning Glass Works.

An effort to help worthy projects in the theatre got under way yesterday as top-ranking Broadway players and representatives of theatrical unions and stage crafts met in the offices of Robert Breen, executive director of the American National Theatre and Academy, to discuss ways and means of assisting the American Repertory Theatre.

The Long Island Rail Road, in a final brief filed yesterday with the Public Service Commission, held that while there might not be enough seats to accommodate all standees during the "one hour" morning and evening rush, this fact did not constitute proof that service during these hours was unreasonable.

Replying to many misgivings and some open criticism aroused by this country's use of the atomic bomb against Japan, both President Truman and former Secretary Stimson, the two men who flashed the signal for the opening of the atomic age, have now published statements of the reasons which prompted them to introduce this dread weapon to modern warfare.

Having recently acquired Frank Mangiapane and Bob Fitzgerald, the New York Knickerbockers further indicated yesterday that their effort to bolster the squad is an earnest one. Following a workput in which the entire team participated it was announced that Paul Walker, Yale's great football, baseball and basketball star of two years ago, has been signed to finish the campaign with the Knicks.

Judge Learned Hand of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals, who attained a hale seventy-fifth anniversary yesterday, belongs among the first jurists of his generation -- not excepting those who have sat or now sit on the nation's Supreme Bench. His opinions, in the judgment of lawyers, will rank with the soundest current contributions to the growing law.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 27 -- Tu Yuehsen, stoop-shoulder, asthmatic, aging leader of the powerful secret societies that once dominated Shanghai's underworld, is scheduled to sail for Hong Kong Saturday for what might be a "prolonged" stay, it was reported tonight.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 27 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, United States delegate, was elected chairman of the United Nations Human Rights Commission by acclamation today. She declared the key problem before the commission was how to "enforce" the international bill of rights that the commission will write.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 27 -- The Republican party should give full said hearty, not grudging support to expansion and continuation of the reciprocal trade agreements, Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association, declared here tonight before the Chamber of Commerce.
Former Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson presents today, in an article in Harper's Magazine, the first official version of the historic decision to use the atomic bomb on Japan.

LITTLE AMERICA. Jan. 27 -- In a spurt of exploration, seaplanes of the Navy Antarctic expedition filled in yesterday thousands of square miles previously blank on the maps of the South Polar continent.

Store Sales Up 17% Here Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase last week of 17 per cent over the like period last year, according to the "flash report" issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

BERLIN, Jan. 27 -- Marshal Vassily Sokolovsky, Russian military governor, must have been somewhat surprised today when he read his statement attacking the Western powers in the papers. Released from Moscow, it put him in the position of violently attacking the Western powers for allegedly blocking a four-power report on demilitarization and denazification, and it caused considerable stir here.

Room 1703 of the Federal court house on Foley Square, where ordinarily the judges of the Court of Appeals sit in robed dignity, was turned into a virtual television laboratory yesterday as the Federal Communications Commission resumed its hearings on color video.

Plans for a twelve-story building at 4-8 West Fifty-eighth Street, with a store on the ground floor and showrooms and offices on the upper floors, were filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings. The 7545 Realty Corporation, of 565 Fifth Avenue, is the owner, and Max Siegel is the engineer.

The worst scandal in the history of American boxing was unfolded yesterday when the District Attorney's office announced that Rocky Graziano, most colorful middleweight since Mickey Walker, had received an offer of $100,000 to "throw" a fight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, confirmed today that he had requested his predecessor, Henry Morgenthau Jr., to return to the Treasury Department the voluminous, so-called Diary which Mr. Morgenthau took with him when he left office.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- An attack on the reciprocal trade agreements program as "a gigantic hoax on the American people," with tariff reductions being made by a "packed jury," blew the lid off a smoldering Senate fight today.

Clint Hartung, Texas baseball rookie who was bought by the Giants last spring for $35,000 and four players and then went back into the Army because he didn't want to be sent to a minor league team, accepted terms yesterday. The announcement came from President Horace Stoneham by telephone from Minneapolis, where the Giants' boss has been looking over the Minneapolis Millers, a New York farm club.
Dr. Kazys V. Grinius, 80-year-old former President of Lithuania, announced here yesterday that he intended to make his home in the United States and become an American citizen.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- Pointedly avoiding any reference to the Egyptian Government's decision to appeal to the United Nations, Foreign Secretary Bevin announced to the House of Commons today the breakdown of Anglo-Egyptian negotiations in measured terms, evidently intending to hold the door open for a possible resumption of talks.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- French proposals for a loose federation of German States contrary to the concept of a centralized government for the future Germany were presented to the State Department today by Henri Bonnet, the French Ambassador.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Jan. 27 (AP) -- Bill Dudley, scourge of the National Football League last season as the No. 1 back of the Pittsburgh Steelers, gave up the playfor-pay business today to become backfield coach at the University of Virginia, where he gained AllAmerica fame lugging the leather in 1941.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 -- Bearish sentiment predominated in the grain markets early today with wheat and corn futures off around 1 cent a bushel on the Board of Trade. An oversold condition developed and the markets rallied rapidly, with the close about the top.

Fatal air crashes around the world, repeated in recent weeks with mournful monotony, have convinced people here and everywhere that we must somehow find the still-hidden path to safer flying. Such disasters are necessarily accepted as normal hazards in wartime.

A special convention of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, comprising the ten southern counties of the State, will meet this morning to elect a successor to Bishop William T. Manning. Bishop Manning retired on Dec. 31 at the age of 80 after twenty-five years as Bishop here.

One hundred and two major American industrial organizations that gave on-the-job training to Chinese technicians here during World War II received the thanks of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek at a dinner given by the China Institute in America at the University Club, 1 West Fifty-fourth Street, last night.
LONDON, Jan. 27 -- The Rand mineworkers' strike, coupled with the effects of the increasing fuel shortage in industry generally, caused the stock markets to be dull today.

Announcement that the New York University School of Law intends to establish a citizenship clearing house, to induce intelligent young men and women to take a greater interest in politics and public affairs, is interesting news. Speaking recently at the annual meeting of the American Political Science Association in Cleveland, Dean Arthur T. Vanderbilt of the Law School outlined some of the details of this proposed bureau.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Two Senators introduced legislation today to reduce industrial strife by banning jurisdictional strikes and effecting other important revisions in the Wagner Labor Relations Act. Senator Joseph H. Ball, Republican, of Minnesota, and Senator Alien J. Ellender, Democrat, of Louisiana, said that their separate proposals also sought to give to employers "more equal" standing with labor than under the Wagner Act as it stands.

Mrs. Genevieve Rivera, 33 years old, who was reported to have been the first parent arrested in Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander's campaign to hold parents responsible for their children's delinquencies, was adjudged guilty yesterday of contributing to juvenile delinquency.

Newspaper advertising in fiftytwo cities last year totaled 1,729,713,225 lines, an increase of 338,083,795 lines, or 24.3 per cent over 1945, according to Media Records. All classifications showed gains as follows: Classified, 32.3 per cent; retail (including department stores), 26.4 per cent; department stores, 24 per cent; total display 21.9 per cent; automotive, 21.5 per cent; financial, 19.4 per cent, and general, 8.2 per cent.
MOSCOW, Jan. 27 -- The most important job facing the Soviet Union and its people today is this year's harvest.

The city yesterday awarded the hermit Collyer brothers $7,500 for 39,794 square feet of the 308,000 square feet of land they own at Merrick Road and 109th Street in Laurelton, Queens. The city condemned the smaller tract for new streets.

All the Fruits Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, had an extremcly well-written letter on this page a few days ago. Its effect, however, was reduced for at least one reader by a familiar biblical metaphor in the very last line.
Without conceding the invincibility of Gil Dodds, Leslie MacMitchell yesterday gently eased off the spot he put himself on by asserting "Dodds won't beat me again."

A number of new materials developed during the war but used since then only for experimental pieces appeared in profusion among the new designs at Macy's midwinter furniture show, which opened yesterday. As in other current home furnishings shows, however, the emphasis was on the luxury-priced semi-custom designs, with new offerings for the mediumsize pocketbook still few and far between.

ATHENS, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Premier Demetrios Maximos announced to Parliament tonight that "to end the civil war," his new coalition Government would apply "all possible measures of appeasement and pacification," including a general amnesty to all guerrilla bands that surrendered within a fixed tune.

Heat and waterproof insulation and portable testing devices attracted most attention from electrical engineers at the opening of the Electrical Engineering Exposition at the 71st Regiment Armory here yesterday. Public utility engineers also showed interest in a transmission line construction truck built to carry tools, supplies and equipment for power line construction.

Her flags at half-mast because of the death of Prince Gustaf Adolf, eldest son of the Crown Prince of Sweden, the SwedishAmerican liner Drottningholm docked at Pier 97, North River, yesterday with 686 passengers from virtually every country in Europe.

ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- A complete revision of wage and salary schedules of State employes to incorporate emergency compensation into the permanent pay base, eliminate inequities and simplify the wage structure was recommended to the legislature tonight by the Salary Standardization Board.

W. Averell Harriman, Secretary of Commerce, told the Honors Night Dinner of the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences at the Astor Hotel last night that certain aviation writing and advertising, particularly in popular magazines, had oversold the public on the utility of flight in its post-war development.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Jan. 27 -- Civil aviation authorities issued an order today prohibiting the use of Danish airports by Dakota transport planes with a take-off weight exceeding 25,200 pounds and a landing weight exceeding 24,420 pounds as a result of the crash of a Dutch-operated airliner yesterday with the loss of twentytwo lives. [Similar action was taken by Swedish authorities at the same time.]

LADD FIELD, Alaska, Jan. 27 -- Task Force Frigid, which moved late Saturday from bivouac areas in the frozen tundra to the warm buildings of Ladd Field because of a shortage of gasoline to operate vehicles and generators, started today to return to the field for the final phase of the cold weather tests.

The January Grand Jury returned indictments late yesterday afternoon against three of the socalled higher-ups in the bookmaking syndicate on whose behalf Alvin J. Paris tried to "fix" the Giants-Bears professional football championship game on Dec. 15.

A new issue of $25,000,000 of twenty-five year debentures of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, intended to finance retirement of 4 1/2 per cent preferred stock, will be placed on the market today by an underwriting syndicate headed by Harriman, Ripley Co., Inc. and Otis Co.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- Asserting as a basic principle that "safety considerations must prevail, whether economic consequences may be involved," Lord Nathan, Minister of Civil Aviation promised today a speedy and complete inquiry into safety measures for commercial air traffic.

Carmine (Moody) Emmino, 22 years old, the fifth of the nine fugitives in the Brooklyn City Prison break to be returned to custody, shared yesterday the responsibility for having obtained the hacksaw blades that were used to cut the bars of the prison window through which the felons escaped.

Mrs. Huttleston Rogers, executivechairman of the Medical and Surgical Relief Committee, 420 Lexington Avenue, presented yesterday to Georges Pierre Lavalley, Mayor of St. Lo, France, the first shipment of medicines and instruments for a medical center in the village of Isigny, in western France.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- The deputies of the Council of Foreign Ministers struggled manfully but vainly again today at their meeting here in an effort to solve the two big peace-making issues that thus far have effectively stymied them.

Dan Ferris, secretary-treasurer of the National A.A.U., told The United Press yesterday that an amateur team selected by the A.A.U., "and no other," would represent the United States in the world ice hockey championships at Prague next month.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- A Senate Judiciary Subcommittee reached the decisive phase today in its consideration of legislation against portal-to-portal back pay suits and the House prepared to deal urgently with similar bills.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The Department of Agriculture was beginning today to get the protests on potato dumping which Secretary Clinton P. Anderson predicted months ago.
CHICAGO, Jan. 27 (AP) -- One hundred pounds of live hog brought as much as the same weight of cattle in the Union stock Yards today -- $25 was the top price for both types of meat animals.
In one of a series of optimistic labor developments here yesterday, the contract covering 70,000 employes of the Bethlehem Steel Company was extended from Feb. 15 to April 30.
LONDON, Jan. 27 -- The Government put forward a new step in its organization of industry today. It is a bill that provides for the establishment of "development councils."

A late rally in the heavy industrials on the stock market replaced losses incurred during the morning yesterday and, accompanied by increased interest in the final hour, raised prices as much as 2 points in some key units with a gain of about 1/2 point in the composite rate.

With a price cut close to 30 per cent announced by the United States Commercial Company, prospects for increased consumption of Japanese silk now appear brighter than at any time since the Government agency took over the sale of the fiber, it was pointed out in trade circles yesterday.

When a food drops in price as sharply as butter has, from a range of 89 to 98 cents a pound just a little over a month ago to the present 63 to 75 cents, then there's good reason for asking: "How have consumers responded to this drastic reduction? Are they buying more butter than they did?"

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 27 -- Walls painted purple and chairs upholstered in shocking pink enrich room settings that went on display today at Bamberger's. Equally dramatic use is made of bright decorative fabrics, including felt used for sequined accessories in glowing colors.

Passengers gazing from the windows of elevated trains that rumbled along Jerome Avenue, the Bronx, saw an unusual sight yesterday at Mount Hope Place and 177th Street. Seated glumly on the sidewalk in the midst of housefurnishings was a very sad family.

MANILA, Jan. 27 -- President Manuel Roxas, reviewing the state of this newly independent nation as the second session of the first National Congress convened today, found it successfully past the stage of despair and confusion prevailing eight months ago and "well into the period of progress."

Sandy Saddler, East Side featherweight, gave a ten-pound weight advantage to Humberto Zavala of Mexico last night at the St. Nicholas Arena and knocked out the game little lightweight in the seventh round of their scheduled ten-round feature bout.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 (AP) -- The National Football League today agreed to a maximum twelve-game schedule for each club in the tenteam circuit -- one more per team than last year -- and marked time in a bid for its first fugitive from the rival All-America Conference, Big Bill Daley, former Minnesota and Michigan fullback.

To the Editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES : It was to be expected that Prof. F.W. Foerster would not agree with the declaration of the ten former members of the German Reichstag which you were good enough to publish in your issue of Dec. 29. Nevertheless, even he concedes that a conquered nation has the right to be represented at the peace table and that the territorial claims of the Poles are exaggerated.

The presidents of the American Medical Association and the New York State Medical Society, urged last night that members of the Medical Society of the County of New York give full support to voluntary health insurance plans.

Foreign Borrowing Foreign bonds again are figuring in the conversations of new issue distributors. Most imminent are refunding operations for the Commonwealth of Australia and the City of Montreal. For the Commonwealth, a borrowing tentatively set for next month will mark Australia's third tap on this market since the eve of last Labor Day.

ATLANTA, Jan. 27 -- Attorneys for Herman Talmadge sued today to force George B. Hamilton, State Treasurer, to accept revenue collections from the Talmadgeappointed Commissioner of Revenue, Charles D. Redwine.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- An informal canvass of Congressional committees dealing with rent control indicated today predominant sentiment for continued control but with upward adjustments.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Since the retirement of B.M. Baruch as the United States representative on the Atomic Energy Commission of the U.N. various efforts have been made to excise the "heart" of his plan. This is the section which would preclude any nation possessing veto powers in the Security Council from preventing by veto the punishment of another which violates the projected agreement to control the uses of atomic energy.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- Following is the text of the Soviet delegation's proposal on procedure for preparation of the German peace treaty submitted to the deputies of the Council of Foreign Ministers: Members of the Council representing those parties that were signatories to the German Act of Military Capitulation at Berlin will participate in the drawing up by the Council of Foreign Ministers of the peace treaty with Germany.

EASTMAN, Ga., Jan. 27 -- Although Californians are notoriously proud of their State, their pride is an insignificant thing in comparison with the regard Joe Puett has for Eastman and the surrounding countryside, which, he insists, has more fish per cubic yard of water and more quail per acre of land than any similar area on the hemisphere, to say nothing of doves.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Prompt Congressional action on legislation to set an eight-year limit on the Presidential tenure was assured today by agreement of House Republican leaders.
LONDON, Jan. 27 -- The Palestinian Arabs made it clear to the British Government today that they would fight partition "with all the means at their disposal."

ONCE upon a time there was a simple rule for appraising the value of a mile clocking on the Boston Garden boards. It supposedly was four seconds slower than a corresponding effort in Madison Square Garden. But don't jump to the conclusion that Gil Dodds' blazing 4:09.1 at the Hub on Saturday is the equivalent of a 4:05 achievement here. The old rule has had to be discarded.

Help by private agencies must be extended to save the children of Europe, former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman declared yesterday at a conference sponsored by the Jewish Child Care Association of New York in the Hotel Commodore.
The success of the first general conference of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization is a "fact of extraordinary importance," Archibald MacLeish asserted yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 27 (U.P.) -- Officials of the Browns tonight announced the appointment of Jerome Herman "Dizzy" Dean to broadcast all 1947 games for the American League club. The Cardinal's former star pitcher will team with his regular mate, John O'Hara, at the microphone.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 27 -- The abduction of another Briton by terrorists today was followed by a stern warning from the High Commissioner, Lieut. Gen. Sir Alan Cunningham, of virtual martial law over certain areas of Palestine.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Jan. 27 -- The first nation-wide employeremploye contract adopted in the American rubber industry was announced here today. About 30,000 workers of the United States Rubber Company in its sixteen factories from Rhode Island to California are affected.

Four officers of the Dairymen's League Cooperative Association, who earlier had pleaded not guilty to a five-count criminal information accusing them of rigging the price of January milk, changed their pleas yesterday to guilty and were fined $1,000 each by Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe.

ROME, Jan. 27 -- Although Italy now is a republic, titles of nobility are not to be abolished. That, atleast, is the recommendation made by the so-called Committee of Seventyfive charged with drafting the new Constitution. What is even more remarkable is that even the Communists are of two minds about forbidding the use of titles that were conferred on the nobility under the monarchy.

BOSTON, Jan. 27 -- President Truman in a letter to Dr. Karl T. Compton, president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said that the final decision on the use of the atomic bomb against Japan "had to be made by the President, and was made after a complete survey-of the whole situation had been made."
In existence since 1891, the New York branch of The Needlework Guild of America, Inc., will close its doors at 119 West Fifty-seventh Street on Friday.

Fellow opera and motion picture artists and a legion of other friends will pay final tribute to the memory of Grace Moore at 3:30 P.M. Thursday at a service in the Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive. Miss Moore was killed Sunday when a Royal Dutch Airlines transport exploded and crashed in Copenhagen.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The United States is now entering a vital third step of development, that of mass distribution to consumers, Brig. Gen. Donald Armstrong, assistant to the chairman of the executive committee of the American Standards Association, told the National Conference of Business Paper Editors yesterday.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 27 -- The New Jersey Legislature received today the first of the program bills of Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll. Among them was one to establish special counsel to the executive department in place of the Attorney General.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 27 -- Gas, oil and coal were pitted against each other in exhibits competing for attention of thousands of architects, engineers and contractors attending the international heating and ventilating exposition today.

MADRID, Jan. 27 -- The new Argentine Ambassador's presentation of credentials to Generalissimo Francisco Franco today was made the occasion for a political demonstration to emphasize SpanishArgentine friendship in the face of foreign criticism.

Retail lumber dealers who accept shipments at exorbitant prices will face serious losses as a result of falling inventory values because of resistance of home purchasers to high selling prices, Ralph E. Jordan, president of the Northeastern Retail Lumbermen's Association, warned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- H.C. Howard and F.E. Grutznik, Interstate Commerce Commission examiners, today recommended that the ICC authorize an extension of the maturity of $1,733,000 first mortgage forty-year 5 per cent gold bonds of the Macon, Dublin and Savannah Railroad Company, from Jan. 1, 1947, to Jan. 1, 1972, to bear interest in the extended period at 4 per cent.

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 27 -- A new vote will be sought by the Independent Workers of Allis-Chalmers, newly organized unaffiliated union at the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company's plant in West Allis as a result of the close election held yesterday, in which the new group lost to Local 248 of the United Automobile Workers by about 100 votes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Early resumption of Good-Neighbor relations between the United States and Argentina was forecast in diplomatic circles today after the departure of Ambassador George S. Messersmith on his return to Buenos Aires.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 27 -- India's princes will begin this week to view their constitutional position a little more closely and attempt to ascertain their probable position in India's evolution to independence.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- In a review today of the more than 1,100 applications for new forms of service pending before the Civil Aeronautics Board, the main trends in post-war commercial aviation development were clearly defined.

TOKYO, Jan. 27 -- The harassed Tokyo citizen, who has experienced almost every known kind of vicissitude during the last year now has met a new one, police reports revealed today: Bands of clothing thieves, who roan the isolated districts at night and strip unfortunate passers-by of their wearing apparel.

The controversy over the publication of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's book, "China's Destiny," by two New York concerns continued yesterday with the issuance of three statements designed to clarify the situation.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 27 -- David O. Selznick announced today that "Sands of Time," a photoplay by Vicki Baum, will be produced by his company in the spring, with Cary Grant and Dorothy McGuire in the leading roles. Miss Baum's story deals with an American sailor who is mistaken for an English nobleman drowned at sea and who assumes the peer's identity and falls in love with the peer's fiancee.

A successor for Jim Crowley as commissioner will be the main business confronting the owners of the eight clubs as the AllAmerica Football Conference begins its annual meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Appointment of a president for the International Bank appeared close today as officials here intensified the search for a man qualified and willing to accept the leadership of the organization.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 27 -- The Georgia Power Commission intervened in proceedings before the Securities and Exchange Commission today to protest the plan of integration of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, which proposed retention of its subsidiary, the Georgia Power Company, in a new holding system to be known as the Southern Company.
Dr. Will W. Alexander, vice president of the Julius Rosenwald Fund, warned yesterday that segregation was spreading and was hampering the improvement of housing.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 -- A belief that record production of building materials this year not only will insure large gains in home buildings, but also will enable the Government to remove its restrictions over commercial and industrial construction, was expressed today by Frank R. Creedon, national housing expediter.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 27 -- The Albanian Government notified the United Nations today that it has named Hysni Kapo, its representative in Belgrade, to answer charges in the Security Council that it was responsible for damage to two British warships, which apparently struck a mine in the Corfu channel last October.

Vladimir Drozdoff, Russian pianist, who has given frequent recitals in this city in the last few years, was heard last night in Times Hall in a big and exacting program, beginning with Beethoven and Schumann, who were followed by a Russian group, and continuing with Liszt, Chopin and the VerdiLiszt "Rigoletto" transcription, the Wagner-Brassen Fire Music and Wotan's Farewell from "Die Walkuere" and the Strauss-SchultzEveler "Blue Danube" waltz.

A $1,500,000 penthouse apartment building sixteen stories high, the first of many new projects being planned for the vicinity of the world capital, will be erected on Forty-eighth Street directly north of the United Nations headquarters tract, it was learned yesterday.

Moritz Hilder of 399 Park Avenue, a retired importer and manufacturer, who at one time was executive vice president of the Goldwyn Pictures Corporation, died Saturday in the Lenox Hill Hospital after an operation. He was 81 years old.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 27 -- As Sweden planned a state funeral for Prince Gustaf Adolf, second in succession to the throne, the Civil Aviation Board announced today a reduction to 25,000 pounds in the permitted take-off weight on Swedish airports for Dakotas.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- The talks with the Burmese leaders ended today. Burma will have her elections for a Constituent Assembly in April, as the Burmese leaders demanded; there will be an interim Government with powers virtually as great as the Indian Government now holds and Burma will have pledges of economic help and of independence within the near future, although not within a year, as originally demanded.
NUREMBERG, Germany, Jan. 27 -- A high point in the series of American zone trials of German leaders was reached here today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Gen Dwight D. Eisenhower, Chief of Staff, today pronounced the occupation of ex-hostile territory this country's most pressing present problem.
Dr. Harry S. Rogers, president of the Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute, received yesterday from the Downtown Brooklyn Association its gold medal for distinguished service to the borough during 1946.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 27 (U.P.) -- Judge Windham's kidnapping caused the British Army to give up its search for Mr. Collins in Jerusalem and to concentrate on Tel Aviv. It was believed that all the city's 16,000 buildings would be searched and all 200,000 inhabitants would be questioned.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Samuel H. Mayes, who was the youngest first 'cellist of any major orchestra when he was appointed to the chair here three years ago, has resigned from the Philadelphia Orchestra to become a concert 'cellist.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- A proposal to put the new Congress on record for an international agreement, to remove compulsory military service "from the policies and practices of all nations" was made today by Representative Gerald W. Landis, Republican, of Indiana.

Leon Fleisher, San Francisco pianist, who gave a recital last night at Carnegie Hall, is only 18. Yet it was his second recital at the hall and already he has played twenty-six engagements with major symphony orchestras, including the New York Philharmonic Symphony with which he was heard at his local debut in November, 1944.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Republican leaders in the Senate indicated today that they would press for closer military participation in the new United States Atomic Energy Commission than the Administration had envisaged. The divergence of views came into the open during the hearing of the Senate members of the Joint Congressional Atomic Energy Committee on the nomination of David E. Lilienthal as chairman of the commission.
To the editor of the new york times : I read with much interest your editorial, "Georgia Crossroads," in THE TIMES of Jan. 13.

Described as a new type of department store operation catering to the needs of middle and lower income groups and to meet competition of medium-price chains, the merchandising philosophy behind Marshall Field Co.'s new budget floor was outlined yesterday to 400 representatives of merchandise resources at a luncheon at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

EVER since it was first published in March, 1943, there has been a lot of curiosity in this country about "China's Destiny,"* by Chiang Kai-shek. The fact that our State Department had a translation it wouldn't even let members of Congress see, sensational rumors and a race between competing publishers to get different versions of the book into the book shops first have all added to the excitement.

Talk on the American prospects for the 1948 Olympic games to beheld in St. Moritz, Switzerland next February, is running high. In 1936 during the ski competition a Garmisch-Partenkirchen, the American color-bearers fared better than expected, with such talented exponents as Dick Durrance, Warren Chivers, Birger Torrissen et al performing in a way that bespoke well for American chances in the future.

Three or four men in a stolen auto engaged in a brief pistol battle with two radio patrolmen in East Eighty-first Street between First and Second Avenues last night but escaped after the patrolmen had chased the car for several blocks.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 27 -- Westchester County completed today its arrangements for general collection of tolls on parkways. This will make possible by June, officials said, the collection of the first general tolls after a decade of survey, negotiation, legislation and litigation.

MIAMI, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Mrs. Babe Zaharias led qualifiers in the fifteenth annual Doherty golf tournament today by firing an eight-under-women's-par 68 to break the women's tournament record for the Miami Country Club course.

BATON ROUGE, La., Jan. 27 (AP) -- Charles Phelps Manship, editor and publisher of The Baton Rouge State-Times and The Morning Advocate, died at his home here today after a long illness. His age was 65.

SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Dinny Pails, apparently taking a lesson from the tactics of America's victorious Davis Cup squad, snatched the Australian tennis singles title from John Bromwich today after a fighting fifth set in which he once was only one point from defeat.

Mayor O'Dwyer and the Board of Estimate hold open hearings tomorrow to decide what agency shall complete and operate the city's airports. They will then be making, within a few days, what is probably the most important decision that has faced them since the present Administration came into office.

DHAHRAN, Saudi Arabia, Jan. 26 (Delayed) -- A survey party of experts has returned to the United States to write a report on proposed public works projects for Saudi Arabia, whose monarch, Ibn Saud, will have $100,000,000 from oil royalties to spend in the next five years.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 27 (AP) -- Mrs. George Smith's veteran Gorget, a belated third in his previous attempt here, had speed right from the gate today and surprised with a half-length victory in the Zephyr Purse, six-furlong Grade D headliner at Hialeah Park.

Members of the general executive board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, AFL, reported yesterday that production for the spring season in all sections of the women's clothing industry was equal to the high levels of last year.

LONDON, Jan. 28--The settlement with the Burmese leaders, granting Burma the right to elect a Constituent, Assembly and have an interim government with great powers on the way to speedy independence, was announced to Parliament today.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 28--The legislative forces of Herman Talmadge and Melvin E. Thompson, Georgia's rival Governors, came to grips again today when the Talmadge faction sought to repeal all State primary laws and establish party-controlled elections, while Thompson followers proposed to keep the laws and tighten educational qualifications of voters.
The Regional Plan Association announced yesterday that it would support the Port of New York Authority proposal for operating the city's airports at the Board of Estimate hearing today.

Reflecting a record sales volume of $101,000,000 for the nine months ended with last December, the net income of Remington Rand, Inc., of $10,009,300 reached the highest for any comparable period in history, J. H. Rand, president, reported yesterday.
The Right Rev. Charles Kendall Gilbert was elected eleventh Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York yesterday on the first ballot at the special convention of the diocese.

Dr. Karl von Kleczkowski, former German espionage agent, and his wife, Stella, were interned here as dangerous enemy aliens after they had failed to convince "authorities" of the value of their services.

IN western Kansas some forty years ago the American country town was at its peak. No movies, radios or hard roads with thundering herds of automobiles he yet corrupted the pure provincialism of the country town with their false fronts of city slickness. The pioneering struggles of the frontier were over, but not for so long that they were not a living memory.

The National Republican Club started last night a dispossess move, subject to approval of the Office of Price Administration, against the New York Republican County Committee, which occupies the fourth floor of the club's building at 54 West Fortieth Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28--Former Representative Joe Starnes of Guntersville, Ala., told the Senate Public Works Committee today that President Truman "couldn't have made a happier appointment" than the nomination of Gordon H. Clapp to be a director of the Tennessee Valley Authority.

LONDON, Jan. 28--The admission of a half million displaced persons to relieve Britain's manpower shortage has been agreed upon by the Ministry of Labor and the Trades Union Congress, it was learned today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP)-- The text of a State Department statement on the recent elections in Poland:

WEST ORANGE, N. J., Jan. 28 --The mystery that for fifteen years has surrounded Thomas A. Edison's roll-top desk in his laboratory and library here will be unfolded Feb. 8, three days before the centennial of the late inventor's birth.

DETROIT, Jan. 28--Walter P. Reuther, president, and R. J. Thomas, vice president, squared away today for a battle to the finish for control of the top leadership of the United Automobile Workers, CIO.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28--Present security methods must give way to a better system if the United States is to guard its atomic secrets, David E. Lilienthal told the Senate members of the Congressional Joint Atomic Energy Committee. His nomination as Chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission is before the committee.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Jan. 28 --There is little chance for the establishment of the International Refugee Organization if Great Britain has decided not to join until after Congress has actually voted the United States contribution, responsible authorities said tonight.

LONDON, Jan. 28--Yugoslavia accused the United States before the deputies of the Council of Foreign Ministers this afternoon of "a flagrant violation of the terms of the Paris agreement" on German reparations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28--The United States charged today that the Provisional Government of Poland had "failed to carry out its solemn pledges" to conduct free and un trammeled elections as called for in the Yalta and Potsdam Agreements.

Dr. Le De Forest, inventor of the electron tube in 1906 and frequently called "the father of American radio," received the Edison Medal at the annual winter meeting yesterday of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers. The meeting is being held in the Engineering Societies Building, 33 West Thirty-ninth Street.

Representatives of the Association of Buying Offices conferred yesterday with the sub-committee on discounts of the vendors' relations committee of the National Retail Dry Goods Association and it was found that in most cases, large concerns were the ones which "have arbitrarily reduced established discounts."

MOSCOW, Jan. 28--Britain's relations with the United States have assumed the character of a military alliance while her policy toward the Soviet Union no longer corresponds to the principles of the treaty of alliance with Russia, the Tass news agency charged today.

Although Arthur Miller's first Broadway play, "The Man Who Had An the Luck" (1944), vanished after its fourth performance, his adherents advised all and sundry to be careful and not to sell short a potential champion. Tonight his second attempt, "All My Sons," will pass in review (the curtain will rise at 8:20) at the Coronet, where "Luck" was so fickle to the young playwright.

ALBANY, Jan. 28--A constitutional amendment to bar the closed shop, first piece of restrictive labor legislation to go before the Legislature this year, was introduced today by Senator Frederic H. Bontecou, Dutchess County Republican.

The deputies gathered in London to prepare the ground for the Foreign Ministers' Conference in Moscow seem to be mostly sitting. Russian insistence that the procedure in negotiating the German and Austrian treaties must follow the pattern adopted for the five treaties already drafted evidently applies to pace as well as formula.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28--Warren R. Austin, representative of the United States in the United Nations Security Council, today described universal military training for American youth as the "basis of our domestic peace program."

SECURITY COUNCIL Postponed full, debate on Great Britain's charges that illegal minelaying by Albania cost lives of forty-four British sailors until arrival of representative from Tirana; Yugoslavia protested that Greece would not admit Belgrade's representative on Balkan Inquiry Commission.

Eight charitable, religious and educational institutions were named legatees in the will of Mrs. Georgie Bruce Cook de Heredia, who died at Lenox, Mass., on Dec. 13, it was learned yesterday when her will was filed in Surrogate's Court. She was the widow of Carlos M. de Heredia, the founder of Reconstruction Hospital in World War I.

Almost no news of Pablo Picasso came to us during the war years Now we know that all that time he was right in occupied Paris, furiously working, refusing to let anything interfere with his creative activity. The Nazis, of course could have raided his studio and put a stop to this.

Consolidated net earnings of the United States Lines, Company and its subsidiaries for the year 1946 are estimated by John M. Franklin, president, at $6,507,000 after provision for taxes and all charges he said yesterday. The consolidated net profit for 1945 was $2,079,377.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 28-- Twentieth Century-Fox today named Jennifer Jones to play the leading role in the screen adaptation of Christine Weston's novel, "The Dark Wood," which Otto Preminger will produce and direct after he completes "Forever Amber."

As the deputies of the Big Four Foreign Ministers, charged with preparing the peace treaties for Germany and Austria, start on their third week of discussion, it is evident that history is repeating itself and that the writing of these treaties promises to be every bit as difficult as the writing of the peripheral European agreements.

CHICAGO, Jan. 28--Grain markets moved upward on the Board of Trade today under the leadership of wheat. The March delivery was up 2 3/8 cents a bushel at one time, selling at $2.11 1/4, the seasonal high, but the market was under pressure from profit-taking sales later and March closed cent higher while the distant months were unchanged to 5/8 cent higher.

An official of District 4 of Mr. Lewis' United Mine Workers announces that the miners are planning to petition the State Legislature to prevent the Pennsylvania Railroad from buying and putting into service twenty-five new Diesel-electric engines. "Every time a steam engine is replaced with a Diesel," declares this official, "two miners are out of a job."

The latest incidents of violence in Palestine brought yesterday from the American Jewish Committee the statement that such actions jeopardized major Jewish objectives in the Holy Land and were "contrary to the spirit of the Jewish religion and tradition."

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 28 (AP)--Kin garvie, winner of the Kings Plate and Canadian Championship Stakes last season, in addition to scoring several times at Detroit, won his first Florida race at Hialeah Park today when he led all the way in the featured Biscayne Purse.

DALLAS, Tex., Jan. 28 (AP)--J. Walter Morris, the man who pushed an investigation which resulted in five Evangeline League players being blacklisted from baseball because of an alleged conspiracy to throw a game, now is pushing the gamblers.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28-- Electric Bond and Share Company's proposal to conduct market stabilization operations in the common stocks of American Gas and Electric Company and Pennsylvania Power and Light Company from Jan. 27 to Feb. 17 was sanctioned today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Employers in the $800,000,000a-year men's clothing industry want to keep industry-wide bargaining and the closed shop, both of which would be outlawed under labor bills introduced by Senator Joseph H. Ball, Republican, of Minnesota.

LONDON, Jan. 28--An Anglo-American film venture, involving Warner Brothers, Hollywood producers, and the Associated British Picture Corporation, was announced here today. Warners plan to produce a minimum of six British pictures here annually with the aid of American stars, directors and other personnel.

LONDON, Jan. 28--The British Government is not likely to make a firm commitment to join the proposed International Refugee Organization until the United States adherence has been approved by Congress, according to exceptionally well-informed sources in London today.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 28--Negotiators for the United States Steel Corporation and the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, began today the first give-and-take phase of collective bargaining for a new 1947 wage contract.

LONDON. Jan. 28 (AP)--Foreign Secretary Bevin will delay signing the peace treaties with Italy, Rumania, Hungary, Finland and Bulgaria until after a foreign affairs debate in the House of Commons, due next week, a Foreign Office spokesman said today. As a result, the treaties will go to Moscow and Paris first. The Foreign Office spokesman explained that Mr. Bevin's decision was merely "an act of courtesy toward the House of Commons.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28--The new Congressional reorganization act put the Committee on House Administration upon the horns of a dilemma today.

PARIS, Jan. 28--The United Nations Educational. Scientific and Cultural Organization has launched its campaign for $100,000,000 in goods and money for the relief and rehabilitation, of schools, libraries, laboratories and museums devastated by the war, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28--Lewis B. Schwellenbach, Secretary of Labor, today found a new atmosphere in labor relations and looked forward to fewer strikes in 1947 but was chary of making absolute predictions. He testified before the Senate Labor and Welfare Committee.

The Right Rev. Charles Kendall Gilbert, who was elected Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of New York yesterday, has had the rather unusual experience of serving all the forty-two years of his ministry in this diocese and of living all his sixty-eight years in this State.

Commercial enterprises all over the country--and probably in other nations as well--are adopting the name of the United Nations in increasing numbers, and United Nations officials are pressing for protective legislation.

BERLIN, Jan. 28--Dr. Kurt Schumacher, Germany's most prominent political leader, called tonight on the forthcoming Foreign Ministers' conference in Moscow to consider Germany not as an isolated problem but as part of the greater problem of all Europe.
