KANSAS CITY, Jan. 28 (AP)--A group of striking contract carriers of The Kansas City Star were ordered today by Circuit Judge Paul A. Buzard to cease picketing the newspaper, but tonight composing room employes failed to return to work.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28--The Joint Legislative Committee on the Budget set out today to trim President Truman's $37,500,000,000 spending program for fiscal 1948 to fit the Republican economy pattern.

TOKYO, Jan. 28--Despite the Government announcement Jan. 18 that attempts to form a national administration by the inclusion of the Socialists in the Cabinet of Premier Shigeru Yoshida had been abandoned, new offers now have been made and are under consideration by Social Democratic leaders, it was learned on good authority today.

BERLIN, Jan. 28--The British and United States Military Governments have agreed in principle on a more effective screening of Germans nominated for important positions on bizonal agencies, it is learned from a British source.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 28--Premier Mahmoud Fahmy Nokrashy Pasha expressed astonishment today that British Foreign Secretary Bevin, in announcing the rupture of the Anglo-Egyptian treaty negotiations, had described the present Egyptian Cabinet as a "minority Government."

The national president of the Girl Scouts, Mrs. C. Vaughan Ferguson, who visited Europe last fall, declared yesterday that she returned home "much more in sympathy with the United Nations and what that great body of people with different ideologies and backgrounds faces."

LITTLE AMERICA. IV, Jan. 28 (U.P.)--Lieut. Richard E. Byrd Jr., the explorer's son, has volunteered to stay behind in the Antarctic to help rescue any airmen who may be stranded here when the Navy's expedition heads home.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28--The Chamber of Commerce of the United States said today that preliminary reports on a referendum of its member organizations showed overwhelming support for changes in the Fair Labor Standards Act.

WARSAW, Jan. 28--Stanislaw Mikolajczyk twice rejected the Communists' offer of the Premiership of the Polish Provisional Goverment during the Moscow negotiations that preceded its formation. The offer was withdrawn at the third Moscow conference, in June, 1945, when M. Mikolajczyk was willing to accept.

Sees Less Restaurant Linage Although moat Hotels and restaurants ate maintaining their advertising appropriations for this year at about the same level as during 1946, it is expected that total linage will fall off somewhat, hotel men said yesterday.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., Jan. 28 (AP)--The fishing industry in this old port--a $12,000,000 business in 1946--was paralyzed today as buyers and seamen remained dead-locked on methods of weighing out catches.

Manufacturers now finding it necessary to increase their promotional efforts should steer clear of cooperative advertising allowances to retailers, Joseph Lorin, vice president of the Grey Advertising Agency, declared, yesterday.

Because of the actually lower fatality rate on the scheduled airlines of the United States, despite the accumulation of spectacular crashes at the year-end, the Institute of Life Insurance announced here yesterday that 98 per cent of life insurance companies now issue policies at standard rates to airline passengers.

THE gambling industry, which probably does a bigger annual business than United States Steel, is very mysterious to the average person. It's also very mysterious to the average sportswriter, even though he's supposed to know a bit more about what is going on than most folks.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As a member of the American delegation which drafted the basis of the United Nations Charter at Dumbarton Oaks, I would like to make some observations on the speech of my good friend Senator Warren Austin on the subject of international atomic control at the dinner of the New York State Bar Association on Jan. 25.
The usually routine sessions of the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences came close to developing an International incident yester day.

Coming Tax-Exempts Municipal bond men are on the lookout for the year's first big chunks of the $800,000,000 of veterans' benefit bonds approved at November referendums. Syndicates are forming for the $270,000,000 Michigan issue, which may reach the market within a month.

COPENHAGEN, Jan. 28 (AP)--A Royal Dutch Airline DC-3 plane, its elevator flap locked by a steel wedge, may make an experimental take-off from Kastrup Airport soon to determine if such a condition could have caused Sunday's crash, an airline official said tonight.

That right-handed hitting outfielder, so sorely needed by the Giants, is on the verge of acquisition, according to Manager Mel Ott, who checked into New York yesterday and held court in the West Forty-second Street offices. Naturally, Mel could not give any details nor even suggest the identity of the player, but he admitted the deal was well on its way and felt reasonably certain it would go through soon.

WASHINGTON. Jan. 28--Responsibility for administrative supervision of the Office of Naval Research is being shifted to the office of the new Assistant Secretary of Navy for Air, John Nicholas Brown. A directive now being drawn up in the office of Secretary James Forrestal will formally transfer responsibility for this important agency.

Temporary barter agreements between United States foreign traders and business men and government officials in the Netherlands were suggested yesterday by L. Smilde, director of promotion, The Netherlands Chamber of Commerce in New York, Inc. Speaking at a luncheon session of the Export Managers' Club at the Hotel Pennsylvania, he urged American exporters and importers to visit the Netherlands as a group or Semi-official body to discuss details of trade.

ALBANY, Jan. 28--Machinery should be set up at the current session of the Legislature for payment of the proposed $400,000,000 State bonus to World War II veterans, Governor Dewey declared tonight. If this were done, he said, veterans could begin collecting the bonus next January instead of waiting until August, 1948, for the first payment.

ATHENS, Jan. 28--The Soviet delegation to the United Nations Inquiry commission, comprising seventeen members, or more than twice the number expected by the Greek authorities, arrived here last evening. While the delegation appears to be headed by A. A. Lavrlehchev, it is not ascertained Whether Mr. Radianov, who accompanied it, is in Athens as Ambassador or a member.

East Meets West King Ibn Saud sat on a dais covered with rare carpets as he received a group of 250 American women and children, being the families of employes of the Arabian-American Oil Company with the big new development at Dhahran near the Persian Gulf.
LITTLE AMERICA, Jan. 28-- In leas thin one week the United States Navy's Antarctic explorers have filled in roughly 800 miles of unexplored coast.
LONDON, Jan. 28 (AP)--A great winter storm blanketed Europe with snow and cold, spreading more suffering over the fuel-rationed Continent tonight.

Two outstanding characteristics of the collection of hats shown by Erik Braagaard yesterday at 17 West Fifty-seventh Street were the youthful three-quarter silhouette and the exquisite use of coloring. Soft moss greens, gray blue, pale gold or pink, his tones were delicate and used with a fine sense of artistry.

Ulysses Kay, Negro student at Columbia University, and Earl George, a student at the Eastman School of Music, Rochester, N. Y., have received a joint award of the $1,000 prize in the third annual George Gershwin Memorial Contest, conducted each year by the Victory Lodge of B'nai B'rith.

Miles F. McDonald, Kings County District Attorney, went before Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson yesterday afternoon to ask for an additional $188,000 to run his office during the coming fiscal year because "there has been a large increase in the commission of crime" since the end of the war.

A three-day sightseeing tour began here yesterday for the "cream of the crop" of South Carolina 4-H Club boys. They were eight members of the Sumter County 4-H Club, which won the sweet potato championship in a State-wide contest.

Representative Vito Marcantonio, incensed at the arrest Monday night of fifteen card players in a club in his Harlem Congressional district, threatened yesterday to institute a Supreme Court action against Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander to force the police to stop "harassing such clubs in my district."

TRENTON, N. J., Jan. 28--The Republican State Committee today streamlined its executive committee. Observers saw in the move evidence of new enthusiasm injected by election of Alfred E. Driscoll as Governor and general optimism over the national political outlook in the next two years.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Jan. 28--A succession of witnesses, including Karl Severing, former Prussian Minister of the Interior, and Oscar von Hindenburg, son of the late President, were called by the prosecution today to support the classification of Franz von Papen as a major offender under the denazification law.

BRUNSWICK, Me., Jan. 28-- Adam Walsh, who recently resigned as coach of the Los Angeles Rams, will return to Bowdoin as football mentor, it was announced tonight by Malcolm B. Morrell, director of athletics. Morrell made it clear that George (Dinny) Shay, who served under Walsh as assistant coach for seven years and last fall was elevated to acting head coach, will remain "a very important member of our coaching staff and department."
Frank Glick, whose wartime service included various manpower posts as a lieutenant colonel, has joined S. Klein on the Square, Inc., as director of personnel and labor relations.
CHICAGO, Jan. 28 (U.P.) -- The Montreal Canadiens defeated the struggling Chicago Black Hawks tonight, 4 to 2, to cut Toronto's National Hockey League lead to three points.

Franco Mannino, the young Italian pianist of 22 years, made his American debut yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. Very properly, Mr Mannino put on his program two modern Italian compositions not hitherto known here --the Sonata of Pizzetti and an "Ostinato Etude de Concert" by Porrino. His other offerings were two Chorale-Preludes of BachBusoni, two Scarlatti Sonatas, the Beethoven "Sonata appassionata," Debussy's "Soiree dans Grenade" and Liszt's "Funerailles" and "Campanella."
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 28 -- India's political prospects hang in the balance for a few days as the Moslem League working committee convenes tomorrow in Karachi.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28--Twin drives in Congress to improve aviation safety today assigned responsibility for recent air accidents to a wide variety of factors, including human error, Industry and labor problems, unwieldy relationship between the two Federal air agencies and lack of funds.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 28-- Steps were taken todayt by immigration authorities here, to expedite the release of Chinese-born wives of American citizens who fought in this country's armed forces, according to Richard Goggin, local chairman of the American Veterans' Committee.
LONDON, Jan. 28--The British Government is beginning to be seriously annoyed by the recent barrage against its foreign policy by the Soviet press and radio, it was learned authoritatively tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28--The conditon statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended Jan. 22:

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Jan. 28 --Henri Hauck, French representative in the Social Commission of the United Nations Economic and Social Council, proposed today that, in view of a world shortage of 100,000,000 dwellings, a special unit should be set up within the United Nations to collect and disseminate data on housing needs and progress in experimental building.

The United States has come out of World War II with a tremendous deficit in all classes of passenger carrying ships that is particularly evidenced in the highly competitive transatlantic runs, J. Lewis Luckenbach, president of the American Bureau of Shipping, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28--While pledging cooperation "to the fullest extent" in a bipartisan foreign policy, the House Foreign Affairs Committee voted today to make a detailed study of the State Department's organization, personnel and policies.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 28 (AP)--Miss Peggy Kirk of Findlay, Ohio, scored one of the most startling upsets in the fifteen-year history of the H len Lee Doherty amateur golf tournament today when she eliminated highly favored Miss Louise Suggs of Lithia Springs, Ga., 2 and 1, in a first round match.
Emil Schwanzer, 11 years old, of 362 Third Avenue, bought a hobby horse yesterday by pledging to work four weeks to the Madison Square Boys Club, 301 East Twenty-ninth Street.
PARIS, Jan. 28--Premier Paul Ramadier obtained a solid Vote of confidence for his Cabinet today after a no-confidence motion had been defeated. 544 to 47.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28--Sitting on one of the hottest spots in the United States, if not the world, is Frank A. Picard, judge of the United States District Court in Detroit, Mich., and the capital community in common with much broader areas has become greatly interested in him for that reason.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: IN THE NEW YORK TIMES of Jan. 18 you printed a letter from John Fischer, a former UNRRA employe, regarding an interview by your Moscow correspondent with Paul White, present chief of the UNRRA mission to the Ukraine. Mr. White was reported to have commented blisteringly upon recent writings of Mr. Fischer's and concerning Mr. Fischer's limited experience in the Soviet Union.

New York City is about to start the largest public school building program in its history, Andrew G. Clauson Jr., president of the Board of Education, said yesterday. He spoke at ground-breaking ceremonies for two new school additions in the Parkchester area of the Bronx, where the construction will be the first undertaken there in five years.

An aggregate of $32,005,000 of temporary loan notes of seventeen local housing authority agencies maturing from Aug. 26, 1947 to March 2, 1948, were sold yesterday at bids ranging from 0.70 per cent to 0.90 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28--Price controls over domestic and imported blackstrap and beet final molasses were revoked effective at midnight by order of John R. Steelman, Assistant to the President.

Supposedly under constant surveillance, Dave (Pete) Krakauer, ex-convict, gambler and key figure in the attempted fix of the National Football League championship playoff, has disappeared. The District Attorney's office requested yesterday the broadcast of a nation-wide alarm for the arrest of Krakauer, one of three men indicted Monday by the grand jury for complicity in the attempted bribery.

Mayor O'Dwyer's annual message to the Council yesterday became in effect a report on his first year of stewardship, and the picture he sketched in was, for the most part, favorable. When he took office many post-war problems were confronting the city. The progress made in solving some of these has not been satisfactory, but a beginning has at least been made.

After reporting that the United States Steel Corporation had realized a net profit of $88,683,530 in 1946, Irving S. Olds, chairman, said yesterday that there has been little, if any, let-up in the huge postwar demand for steel. He estimated the current volume of unfilled orders at five months' production.

STUART, Fla., Jan. 28--To the hunter, retrospect often is more pleasing than reality, but we have found that one of the most consistent exceptions to this is the quail shooting on the palmetto barrens behind this fishing town.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28--President Truman will fly to Mexico City early in March for a three-day visit with President Miguel Aleman of Mexico, the White House announced tonight.

The middleweight championship fight between Champion Tony Zale and Rocky Graziano is virtually certain to be called off, it was learned yesterday, because Graziano failed to report a $100,000 bribe offer.
The volume of commercial loans made this year may be expected to increase, Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the board of the Chase National Bank, said yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders.

Magistrate Raphael P. Koenig, who was appointed to the bench seven years ago by former Mayor La Guardia and who recently served a term on the Special Sessions bench as an associate justice, announced yesterday he had tendered his resignation to Mayor O'Dwyer, to become effective Friday. He is to return to the practice of law.

The stock market yesterday enjoyed another bulge after indecisive and narrow movements had ruled earlier in the day. The rally left the composite rate higher by approximately 1 1/4 points. The motors again provided the spark and a good part of the volume.

The All-America Football Conference, beginning its annual meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday, failed to elect a new commissioner to succeed James (Sleepy Jim) Crowley, who resigned recently. It was stated that the choice might not be made for a few days, possibly not until after the meeting, which is scheduled to end tomorrow.

The Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo, who resigned recently as minister of the St. Nicholas Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, after a long fight over the proposed sale of the $4,000,000 site to real estate interests, was named president of the New Brunswick Theological Seminary yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 28 (Reuters)-- The Moscow radio today broadcast a denial by Tass, the official Soviet news agency, of Egyptian reports that the Soviet Government had promised assistance to Egypt In her attitude over the Sudan question.

Buyers' Total Lower Visiting buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,464 compared with 2,174 in the preceding week and 1,470 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

LONDON, Jan. 28--The Arabian side of the Palestine conference has recessed until Thursday and the British Government planned today for conversations with the Zionists, who are boycotting the meetings.
LONDON, Jan. 28--End of account influences restricted business in the stock markets here today.

Emile Baume, French pianist, who made his debut in this country more than ten years ago, has become one of the most mature, rewarding recitalists. His playing at Carnegie Hall last night was always serious, concerned with the music rather than with display of virtuosity. Not that he doesn't command as much virtuosity as the next man, but that commodity has become almost a normal ococcurrence, while searching musicianship has not.

LONDON, Jan. 28--Great Britain's house building program for 1947 calls for the completion of 300,000 houses, 240,000 of them permanent structures, Aneurin Bevan, Minister of Health, disclosed in a White Paper published today.
Spurred by strong spot prices in the South, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 18 to 43 points yesterday, closing not far from the best levels of the day.

Independent bicycle dealers and jobbers who now sell only one-third of their stocks in this country are starting a drive to increase cooperation from bicycle manufacturers, H. E. Short, president of the Jobbers Association of the Bicycle Institute of America, disclosed here yesterday.

MADRID, Jan. 28--The Spanish Government took one more step in its efforts to bring home political exiles with the formal publication today of a decree extending the amnesty period six months, until June 28. The decree says:

MOSCOW, Jan. 28--The refusal of Gen. Douglas MacArthur's staff to allow a representative of the Moscow Patriarch to visit the Consistory of the Russian Orthodox Church in Japan was attacked today as an "unfriendly act" and a "brutal interference" in church affairs.

The American Smelting and Refining Company yesterday raised the price of copper 1 cent to 20 1/2 cents a pound, the highest price commanded by the red metal since 1929. Other producers reported they were maintaining the 19 1/2cent level for the present.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Jan. 28-- Full debate on the United Kingdom's charges that illegal minelaying by Albania had cost the lives of forty-four British sailors was postponed today by the United Nations Security Council until the arrival of a representative from Tirana.

ALBANY, Jan. 28--Two proposed changes in commercial rent control laws applicable to New York City today produced a sharp split in the Joint Legislative Committee on Rents. Both amendments are being pushed by Democrats with some Republican support.

Splitting the atom was demonstrated for the first time yesterday before a business convention. Dr. John R. Dunning, one of the atomic bomb scientists and scientific director, Cyclatron Laboratory, Columbia University, showed the process before the thirty-fourth annual meeting of the Compressed Gas Manufacturers Association at the Waldorf-Astoria.

The Pittsburgh Ironmen, with Colby Gunther who held the alltime freshman scoring record at St. John's University, will face the New York Knickerbockers in the star clash of the professional basketball double-header at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory tonight.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28--A bipartisan group of Senators set out today to end paralyzing filibusters in the upper House by changing the rules so as to make them "impossible."

Federal and State legislators moved quickly yesterday to expedite bills in Albany and Washington that would clear up tax problems threatening to delay or upset John D. Rockefeller Jr.'s plans to give $8,500,000 to the United Nations for purchase of its six-block site on the East River in Manhattan.
Douglas fir producers are aiming at 1947 output of 7,000,000,000 board feet, an increase of 400,000,000 over last year, Joe Blunt, secretary of the West Coast Lumbermen's Association, said yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28-- With a group representing the issuers of securities, the Securities and Exchange Commission today held another of a series of informal conferences to explore the possibility of drawing up a coordinated program for Improving the Securities Act and the Securities Exchange Act.
Eight varieties of blue off-duty uniform that may make America's 1,070,000-soldier Army the world's best dressed were shown yesterday to troops on Governors Island for their selection.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Jan. 28 (U.P.)--The mystery of the plane crash that killed Grace Moore, Prince Gustaf Adolf of Sweden and twenty others Sunday deepened today when the acting master mechanic of Kastrup Airport testified that he did not believe the tail assembly of the plane was chocked while it was serviced there.

Successful termination of the London negotiations between the British Government and six Burmese leaders launches another Far Eastern nation on the road to independence. Though Winston Churchill calls it a "dismal transaction," the Labor Government frankly recognizes the irresistible pressure of the Orient toward freedom.
Commercial bankers here are faced with a sharp curtailment of their consumer credit operations, it was learned yesterday.

Beata Malkin, Russian soprano, gave her first New York recital last night at Times Hall. It was not her first appearance in this city, however, for she visited this country during the 1934-35 season, singing here with the Boston Symphony Orchestra and in the Art of Musical Russia's production of "Eugen Onegin" that was conducted by Efrem Zimbalist.

Bernard Docusen, 145, New Orleans, won an unanimous decision over Johnny Williams, 144, Montgomery, Ala., in the feature bout of eight rounds at the Broadway Arena in Brooklyn last night. In the semi-final scheduled for eight, Vie Amato, 162 1/2, Brooklyn, knocked out Art Robinson, 162, Pittsburgh, in 2:08 of the second.
An international record for a book auction was believed to have been set last night when "The Bay Psalm Book," the Puritans' interpretation of the Psalms in verse, went under the hammer for $151,000.

Transportation and zoning of existing buildings in the vicinity of the six-block Hast River tract to be used as the United Nations headquarters are among the problems confronting the City Planning Commission, Newbold Morris, a member of that body, declared yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 28--Lawrence Tibbett, Metropolitan Opera baritone, apparently held the fate of the United States Opera Company in his hands tonight after the American Guild of Musical Artists, of which he is president put a crimp in the opera company's plans just as the company had solved its financial difficulties.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28--The possibility that the whole structure of Government sugar rationing might collapse was temporarily averted when the United States Circuit Court cf Appeals today granted a stay until it can hear arguments Feb. 7, on whether the "historical use" formula for distribution to industrial users is unconstitutional.

The woolen jobbing company of Morris Kaplan Son, Inc., 222 West Fortieth Street, and four individuals were named yesterday in a nine-count indictment charging the evasion of $210,000 in Federal income taxes for 1940 and 1941. The defendants will be arraigned for pleading on Friday before Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe.
JERUSALEM, Jan. 28--One of the two hostages kidnapped by Zionist terrorists was released tonight about five miles from Tel Aviv.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., Jan. 28-- The theatre has a "suicide complex," Richard Maney, theatrical press agent, said here today in answer to the question: "Are the critics killing the theatre?"

LONDON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- British racing circles said today that an American turf emissary here to sell Britons on a $100,000 world championship race in New York would find few buyers. The dream contest, personally pushed by James Butler, president of the Empire City Racing Association of New York, was widely publicized upon his arrival, but press comments were negative.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Jan. 28 (Reuters)--South Australia and the English touring cricket team in Australia drew their match which ended today with England batting a second time and having 152 runs on the board for two wickets, when bad light stopped play.

The city's 1947-48 tax levy budget probably will be $105,600,000 more than the current one, Mayor O'Dwyer told the City Council yesterday in his annual message. This increase would bring the tax levy budget to $819,468,000 and the total expense budget to at least $970,800,000, a record high.

GALVESTON, Tex., Jan. 28 (AP) --Secretary of Agriculture Clinton P. Anderson said today that the Government hopes to be able to return to private shippers the exportation of cotton to Germany by July and to Japan by October.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today dismissed, without prejudice to later renewal, an application of the Western Pacific Railroad Company, to issue $10,000,000 of first mortgage bonds, Series B, due on Jan. 1, 1981.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28--President Truman plans to ask Congress for a bill restricting the withdrawal of state papers for personal use by public officials, including the Chief Executive, department heads and all other members of the Federal administrative family.

One of the most useful appurtenances in a kitchen is a meat thermometer, and fortunately at a time when meat and poultry are abundant, the supply of this utensil is improving. During the war it was almost impossible to obtain, but now at least two stores, Gimbels and Macy's, boast adequate stocks.
Three of the biggest days the game of racquets has known in this country will be launched today at the Racquet and Tennis Club on Park Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP)-- Francis J. Curtis, vice president of Monsanto Chemical Company, St. Louis, expressed concern today over Russian control of much of Germany's chemical industry and the effect this may have on the American industry.

Anatol Kaminsky, violinist, who was a pupil of Kochanski, Zimbalist, Persinger and Hans Letz, made his New York debut last night in Town Hall before a large audience that was cordial in its response to his excellent artistry.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29 -- Grain markets continued on the upgrade under the leadership of wheat on the Board of Trade today. March wheat was up 2 1/8 cents, at one time selling at $2.12, a new seasonal high. Although there was a fair amount of profit-taking on the advance, the finish was about at the top, with gains of 1 to 1 7/8 cents, March leading.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The way was paved today for withdrawal of virtually all American forces from China as the State Department announced abandonment of the American effort to mediate between the Chinese Nationalist and Communist forces.

Wage and salary increases offer the only logical means at this time to absorb industrial output at current prices and bolster the national economy, Dr. Lazare Teper, director of research, the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, asserted yesterday.

Housewives are under fire nowadays because of their insistence on culinary "quickies." Their critics, the gourmets who practically make a profession of eating, say that a modern cook's criterion of a good meal is not how it tastes, but how long it took to prepare-they imply that the achievement of flavor takes time.
Dr. Lewis W. Chubb, director of the Westinghouse Research Laboratories in East Pittsburgh, received yesterday the John Fritz Medal for notable scientific achievement in 1946.
Formation of the Fellowship of United States-British Comrades, a new international organization of veterans, was announced here yesterday by former Lieut. Gen. James H. Doolittle.
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 29 (AP) -- Cosmic Missile, a filly from the Circle M Farm of Edward S. Moore, today won the $11,900 Jasmine Stakes to thrill a crowd of 15,828 racing fans at Hialeah Park.

Already hardened to the vagaries of the elements, the army of skiers in the Northeast was buoyed by last night's reports that snow was visiting many of the popular ski-lands in the North. The enthusiasts were hopeful that temperatures -- and snow -- would continue to fall and that the Weather Bureau's optimistc report that "skiers could look forward to a pleasant week-end" would materialize.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The House Labor Committee, in close accord with Republican leaders, decided today to begin hearings Feb. 5 for the preparation of an omnibus labor reform bill intended to reach the floor not later than March. 15.

RFC Opposition Reports that legislation which may permit the Federal Reserve banks to displace the Reconstruction Finance Corporation as a major guarantor of small business loans had won the endorsement of Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, were received here with considerable interest in banking circles yesterday.
ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- A joint legislative investigation of the fiscal affairs of New York City was proposed today in a resolution by Senator Robert E. Johnson, Republican, of Richmond.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 29 -- The United Kingdom has decided to join the International Refugee Organization without reservations and without waiting for the lead of the United States Congress to vote contributions, it was disclosed here today.

The proposed $20,000,000 Madison Square Garden at Columbus Circle will bring an unpredictable amount of business to New York's merchants and also may aid in solving the city's present traffic problem, Brig. Gen. John Reed Kilpatrick, president of the Garden Corporation, said yesterday.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Franz von Papen denied today that he had any part in the alleged forgery of the last political will of the late President Paul von Hindenburg, which was used by Hitler to clinch his grip as German Fuehrer.

It is fitting that this year the John Fritz Medal and Certificate -- outstanding award in engineering -- should go to Dr. Lewis W. Chubb, director of the Westinghouse Research Laboratories. This award, sponsored jointly by the American Institute of Electrical Engineers, the American Society of Civil Engineers, the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers.
There were no major developments yesterday in investigations by District Attorney Frank Hogan into gamblers' alleged corruption of professional football and professional boxing through bribes.

ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- Strong sentiment for coupling the proposed $400,000,000 State veterans bonus with the imposition of special taxes to finance it developed today among Republican legislative leaders as a sequel to Governor Dewey's speech at an American Legion dinner.

Moves in Washington for a rise in rents brought from labor leaders last night a declaration that any increase in rents would imperil efforts to arrive at peaceful settlements in current wage negotiations.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 29 -- The United States Government proposed today to the United Nations that it write an international bill of rights guaranteeing: "economic, social and cultural well-being."

NANKING, Jan. 29 -- The United States decision to withdraw from Executive Headquarters in Peiping terminated one year of heart-breaking effort by 2,000 American officers and men to implement in the field the Kuomintang-Communist peace agreements.

The Netherlands' merchant marine, which suffered severe losses during the war, is recovering rapidly and is now approaching 75 per cent of its pre-war tonnage, H. van Ramshorst, head of the Dutch Ministry of Traffic, said yesterday.

New York City will demand that city orders for War Assets Administration surplus products be accepted at a discount of 12 1/2 per cent from fixed prices listed in WAA catalogues. Albert Pleydell, Commissioner of Purchases, disclosed here yesterday.
Two young men were injured yesterday in Brooklyn when they were pinned against a building by an auto whose driver apparently lost control of it while suffering a fatal heart attack.

An arrangement by which residents of Halletts Cove in Astoria, Queens, will be able to remain in their homes while new housing is built for them was announced yesterday. The neighborhood, which is visible from the Manhattan site of the United Nations, is to be improved with twenty-three low-rent apartment buildings.

Eddie Conwell, Barney Ewell, Tom Carey and Billy Mathis have been seeded at the top of the four heats in the invitation 60-yard dash at the Millrose games, it was announced yesterday by Fred Schmertz, meet director. Harrison Dillard, Haakan Lidman, Lloyd Duff and Ted Sparrow received honor rating in the draw for the 60-yard high hurdles.

Rural areas are the "educational slums" of this country, Dr. John K. Norton, Professor of Education at Columbia University's Teachers College, declared yesterday at the fifteenth annual meeting of the Save the Children Federation at the Hotel McAlpin.

The merging of the Israel Zion Hospital, 4802 Tenth Avenue, and the Beth Moses Hospital, 404 Hart Street, both in Brooklyn, will become effective as soon as the State Legislature adopts enabling legislation, it was announced yesterday by the presidents of the two institutions.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 29--In a pair of releases, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today the adoption of amendments to Rules X-16B-2 and X-16C-2 and to the instructions for Form 10-K of the Securities and Exchange Act.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Top Government officials, it was learned today, are engaged in negotiations of a most complex nature to open the overdue Western Pacific airways by rehabilitating military air bases and stations.

ABOARD THE PORT OF BEAUMONT, Tex., at Sea, Jan. 29 -- After months of planning and weeks of hectic last-minute work, the blue waters of the Gulf of Mixico now surround us. We need to make good time in our race against the Antarctic's winter ice, particularly after time lost during the past three days.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Although I can sense and sympathize with Miss Struther's indignation in her letter published in the times of Jan. 12, nevertheless she is not in a position to say "I want to state emphatically it is not true," for let me relate experiences which are not preposterous but true.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The White House denied late this afternoon a reported Administration move to authorize a general increase of 10 per cent in rent ceilings.

THE sport of speed skating rarely attracts the slightest bit of attention except when Olympic competition is involved. Perhaps that's why the case of Johnny Roukema has been generally regarded as little more than a tempest in a teapot. Yet there seems to be a basic element of unfairness to the incident and therefore it should not be dismissed without comment.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 29-- Deerfield Packing Corporation of Bridgeton, N. J., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $2,500,000 of 3 3/4 per cent sinking fund debentures, due on Feb. 1, 1962, and 3,750 shares of $100 par value 4 1/2 per cent cumulative preferred stock.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Jan. 29 --Warren R. Austin, chief United States delegate to the United Nations, will begin an intensive series of conferences tomorrow with other members of the Security Council in an attempt to find a way out of the procedural deadlock that has been holding up disarmament talks.

Moving suddenly last night for a compromise arrangement on city operation of the three city airports, Mayor O'Dwyer said the city would maintain and operate the fields if the major airlines financed and built their own hangars at the new Idlewild Airport in Queens.

The American Federation of Radio Artists and the four national networks signed yesterday a new contract providing for increases of 20 to 30 per cent in the pay rates for union members. The pact is the result of four months of negotiations in which a national strike of all artists on the air had been threatened by the union.

The condition of Mrs. Frances Coover, 51 years old, of Ames, Iowa, struck by a man who leaped to his death last Sunday from the observation tower of the Empire State Building, has shown "marked improvement" and "danger to life now seems passed," her husband said yesterday. She is in St. Vincent's Hospital.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange turned strong again yesterday and closed 10 to 24 points net higher on the day, with the strength most pronounced in the near months.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The current sharp debate in Congress on the nation's economic foreign policy illustrates one of the purposes of the recent reorganization of Congress.

LONDON, Jan. 29 (U.P.) -- Less than twenty-four hours after one of the biggest American-British film deals in history had been signed, the Film Industry Employes Council today violently attacked Hollywood-London motionpicture combines and demanded nearly complete socialization of the industry in Great Britain.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, stated today that Henry Morgenthau Jr. should use "his own discretion" about returning papers accumulated during his service as Treasury chief. He emphasized that all the Government wants are documents essential to its file.

Robert R. Wason, chairman the board of the National Association of Manufacturers, expressed that organization's first public criticism of the new Republican Congress last night. He charged with a "sell-out" to organized labor in the hope of winning the 1948 Presidential election.

The return of $1,075 to a veteran who had been obliged to pay more than the ceiling price for a home was directed yesterday by Justice James J. Conroy in the City Court, Queens. The court held that a broker from whom the veteran purchased the building was bound by the same ceiling price as the builder, but that he might be entitled to certain fees.

A three-cornered battle for the $27,200 left in a taxicab on June 14, 1944, and subsequently turned over by the driver to the Police Department Property Clerk, loomed yesterday when forty talesmen were examined before a jury of eleven men and one woman were selected to decide the issue at ownership.

Retail prices of eggs and poultry are expected to break today after having been bolstered for several weeks at higher levels than were warranted by falling wholesale prices. One of the large food chains, according to reports in the trade last night, is expected to announce price cuts today and set a pattern for other retailers.

WARSAW, Jan. 29 (AP) -- The Government Bloc parties controling Poland's first post-war Parliament issued a manifesto today promising the Polish people freedom of speech, freedom of the press and the right of public assembly.
The Radio Officers Union, AFL, announced yesterday the signing of new agreements with forty-five ship lines, providing for salary increases ranging to $21 a month.

Out of the long deliberations of the United Nations Assembly at Flushing Meadow a month or so ago there came nothing finer or more inspiring than the decision to establish a new agency of human brotherhood to be known as the International Refugee Organization.

Florence Quartararo seems destined to make her way through the Metropolitan Opera repertory the hard way. She sang Violetta here for the first time last night as a replacement for Bidu Sayao, who was indisposed. Some weeks ago she pinch-hit as Desdemona.
LONDON. Jan. 29 -- The French Ambassador, Rene Massigli, had talks with Foreign Secretary Bevin today, that can be considered an informal beginning for the proposed Anglo-French alliance.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 29 -- The Greek Government has officially denied Yugoslav charges that Belgrade's representatives to the United Nations' Balkan inquiry commission were not allowed to get visas to enter Greece, it was announced today.

LONDON, Jan. 29 -- The British Cabinet has finally decided on the partitioning of Palestine and now seeks definite suggestions for the lines along which such a program can be carried out, it was learned authoritatively today.

TOMS RIVER, N.J., Jan. 29 -- Spotted from the air by one of three Navy helicopters searching for her, Barbara Jean Black, 2 years old, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Black of Ridgeway, near here, was rescued this afternoon by a ground party of State police and neighbors and taken to her home suffering from exhaustion and fright.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 29 -- The six European countries that were hardest hit by the war will require $583,000,000 in outside help this year to supply their minimum requirements on food and other basic essentials.

DURHAM, N. C., Jan. 29 (U.P.)-- The 1946 Houma (La.) team in the Class D Evangeline League was pictured by the minors' National Association of Professional Baseball Leagues office today as a combination baseball club and bookie hangout where the players did everything except stop in the middle of a double play to rush off and play the daily double.

LONDON, Jan. 29 -- With the opening of the new account -- due for settlement on Feb. 18 -- the stock markets today were more cheerful. The fairly big volume of money awaiting investment out-weighed the poor coal outlook and other adverse factors and equities were in good demand.

Early Spring Lines Do Well Weather conditions in several sections of the country have permitted a favorable response to early spring offerings of women's apparel by retailers, it was reported yesterday. Some buyers here believe that if there should be a spell of spring weather early next month stocks of medium to better grade coats and suits will be inadequate.

Despite the handicap of a pulled muscle in his hitting arm, Edward C. Oelsner of the University Club, the No. 1 seeded player, gained a five-game decision as play began yesterday at the Harvard Club in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association's Class A singles tournament.

While the owners spent the second day of their annual meeting wrestling with such problems as a new commissioner to replace Jim Crowley, transportation, guarantees and schedules, the coaches of the All-America Football Conference went into a huddle yesterday and named Glenn Dobbs of the Brooklyn Dodgers the most valuable player of the year.
Commemorating the sixty-fifth anniversary of the birth of Franklin D. Roosevelt, the local March of Dimes drive will sponsor several large special events this evening.
TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 29 (U.P.) -- Harold E. Stassen of Minnesota, the only avowed Republican Presidential candidate, called on his party tonight to become the champion of small business.

The New York County Republican Committee acted yesterday just like any other tenant. It sat back, waited for a formal dispossess notice--hoping it wouldn't come--but prepared to fight in the courts if the notice did come.

MOSCOW, Jan. 29 -- The industrial part of the war booty seized by the Soviet Army in Manchuria was worth $95,000,000, according to Izvestia, Government newspaper, which assailed the Pauley report as "slanderous." It charged the United States had embarked upon a unilateral, illegal policy of allowing General MacArthur, without Allied agreement, to determine the level of Japanese industry and to define the reparations program.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Jan. 29 -- Strong evidence was produced today that a blocked elevator caused last Sunday's crash of a KLM (Royal Dutch Airliner) Dakota plane at Kastrup Airport here. A trustworthy witness told the investigating commission that he saw a lock placed on the elevator of the Dakota while it stood on the airport, it was learned.

Former Gov. Ellis Arnall of Georgia declared yesterday during a one-day visit to New York that he intended to speak "five or six times" in all the forty-eight States in the interests of furthering democracy at home.

Estimated consolidated net earnings of United Merchants and Manufacturers, Inc., for the six months ended with last December amounted to $11,546,732, or more than double the $4,544,344 earnings for the corresponding six months of the previous year, J. W. Schwab, president, reported yesterday.

The Federal Communications Commission closed its special hearing yesterday in this area on television, after a day-long session at the Princeton, N. J., laboratories of the Radio Corporation of America. The RCA all-electronic color system was demonstrated and compared with the same views reproduced over several black-and-white sets.

An extension of the forward movement on the Stock Market vas negotiated yesterday under the stimulus of a greatly enlarged demand, with gains of 1 to 2 points liberally sprinkled through the list. The return of investor confidence enabled the market to bridge a four-month gap and carried prices to the best levels since last Sept. 6.
LONDON, Jan. 29 -- Britain was struggling to keep transport and essential services going today as the cold wave of unusual severity continued.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 29 (AP)--Deliberately paced contract negotiations between the United States Steel Corporation and the CIOUnited Steelworkers adjourned today for a week and when conferences resume streamlined committees will take up the work.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified. The programs follow:
ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 29 -- The Georgia House of Representatives approved the Democratic white primary measure late today, 133 to 62.

TRENTON, N. J. Jan. 29--The State Unemployment Compensation Commission reported today New Jersey payrolls during 1946 were maintained at approximately $2,600,000,000, only 8 per cent below 1944, the record war year.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 29 -- The Executive Council of the American Federation of Labor, opening its winter meeting, appraised labormanagement relations today as "constantly improving" and said the chief disturbing factor was Congress.

Proof that in spring's broad fashion picture every woman can find those fashions best suited to her individuality was given yesterday by Arnold Constable in a showing at the Waldorf-Astoria. It presented styles for the older woman, the teen ager and tots in addition to those for the young woman.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29--Warren R. Austin, chief United States delegate to the United Nations, went before an extraordinary gathering of old Congressional colleagues responsible for national defense today for what he called a discussion of "how to prevent World War III."
NANKING, Jan. 29 -- The United States announcement that it had ended peace efforts in China removed another barrier, however slight, to all-out combat in the civil war.

The Moore-McCormack Lines have taken formal delivery of the new cargo-passenger vessel Mor acsaga, last of seven modified C-3 type ships to be built for the company by the Ingalls Shipbuilding Corporation at Pascagoula, Miss., Albert V. Moore, president of the company, announced yesterday.

Mrs. Katherine Johannson, daughter of the late Lady Decies and a great-granddaughter of the financier Jay Gould, denied in Federal Court yesterday that a payment of $9,500 she made above the rental price of an apartment at 935 Park Avenue was for furniture.

Naval aviation is not interested in long-range strategic bombing but in its own task of long-range anti-submarine warfare and sea-lane protection, Rear Admiral L.C. Stevens, assistant chief of the Bureau of Aeronautics in the Navy Department, declared at meetings of the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences at the Hotel Astor yesterday.
LONDON, Jan. 29 -- The Soviet Union made an unsuccessful effort today to get the Foreign Ministers' deputies to Invite Albania to present her claims and views on Germany.

A division of authority over the material and spiritual activities of the Broadway Tabernacle Church, Congregational, Fifty-sixth Street and Broadway, which had existed more than 100 years, ended last night when the former Broadway Tabernacle Society, composed of holders of pews on a rental baste, was merged with the congregation under a new constitution and bylaws.

A group of top-ranking actors, directors and stage technicians have banded together and formed The American Company for the purpose of producing plays that "will have something to say." The new outfit, which announces it will apply for a charter of incorporation as soon as possible, plans to offer at least two shows a season.
Hank Greenberg will go into a huddle with Roy Hamey, general manager of the Pirates, to discuss salary arrangements some time during the week-end, the former Tiger star said yesterday.

Urges Retailer Consideration Too many manufacturers are guilty of preparing their advertising and promotion campaigns entirely on the basis of what they think retailers should have instead of finding out what retailers actually need, it was said yesterday by Alfred Katz, vice president of Stylepark Hats, Inc., Philadelphia.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The best news a long-suffering, subway-riding public has had in many years is contained in the addresses made by Chairman Gross and two engineers of the Board of Transportation about the 500 newly designed subway cars now on order, the stainless steel "dream train" recommended for experiment and the many new features in these plans for the greater safety and comfort of the public.

PARIS, Jan. 29 -- Andre Philip, Minister of National Economy, told the National Assembly's Economic Affairs Committee today that France could not return to normal before two years. He added that the return to general freedom of trade would take considerably longer.

But economy cuts in the 1947 fiscal year forced the suspension of work on all ships under construction in naval shipyards during the year ending July 1, 1947, and work was slowed down on naval vessels in private yards to spread out the costs.
A two-day outlaw strike last April by 300 truck drivers led to the imposition by an arbitrator yesterday of a fine of $4,161.88 on Local SOT of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL.

An on-the-spot consumer survey of the Buenos Aires market, the first study of its kind made in any South American city, was presented yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Export Advertiising Association, Inc., at the Hotel Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Members of the Federal Reserve Board endorsed "strongly" today legislation proposed by Senator Charles W. Tobey, Republican, of New Hampshire, to authorize Federal Reserve Banks to guarantee loans to businesses.

The Hercules Powder Company, in its annual statement issued to shareholders yesterday, shows a net income for 1946 of $8,409,843 after all charges, including $5,917,254 provision for taxes and $600,000 for contingencies.

Abraham Brotman, 73 years old, of 1965 East Sixteenth Street, Brooklyn, wearer of an artificial lower right leg, escaped serious injury yesterday morning when he was dragged more than fifty feet along a station platform by a Brooklyn-bound BMT subway train.
Techniques to Insure for gardeners the greatest success In the growing of flowers were described yesterday by Dr. Conrad B. Link, horticulturist at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

Every physician is familiar with the patient who carries his own thermometer around with him and takes his temperature and his pulse at regular intervals throughout the day. Are we, as a people, developing a similar morbid anxiety about our health? Are we becoming a nation of hypochondriacs?

A further increase of 1,788,000 barrels last week in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum institute. At the close of the week they amounted to 99,801,000 barrels, compared with 98,013,000 a week earlier and 101,783,000 on Jan. 26, 1946.

The general executive board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, AFL, closed its quarterly meeting yesterday with a warning that bills now pending before the Senate Committee on Labor and Welfare would provoke 'bitterness, resentment and discontent" and jeopardize peaceful labor relations in this country.

ROME, Jan. 29 -- Lieut. Gen. Sir William D. Morgan, supreme Allied Commander in the Mediterreanean theatre, told Premier Alcide de Gasperi today that Allied troops would remain in Pola until next April, when it will become Yugoslav territory.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29 (AP) -- A wage increase of $5,000,000 annually has been ordered for more than 100,000 workers in the country's major meat-packing plants, the Meat Packing Commission, of the Department of Labor said today.

The Protestant Film Commission will sponsor the production of seven 16-mm. motion picturees for distribution to churches, clubs, schools and community groups, Paul F. Heard, executive secretary, announced yesterday at the end of the second annual meeting of the commission, held at Presbyterian headquarters, 156 Fifth Avenue.

Well under the 160-pound notch at which the bout was signed, Pete Mead, Grand Rapids (Mich:) middleweight, and Harold Green of Brooklyn, finished hard training yesterday for their ten-round battle in Madison Square Garden tomorrow night.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Cyrus S. Eaton, Cleveland financier, said today that "from now on you can count New York Central as a Robert R. Young property," following an announcement yesterday that Alleghany Corporation had boosted its holdings of New York Central stock from 162,500 to 250,400 shares.

BABYLON, L. I., Jan. 29-- Money invested by veterans in building plots in the belief that their contract called for the early construction of homes will be returned in full by Lindenhurst Shores, Inc., under an offer made to District Attorney Lindsay R. Henry of Suffolk County, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- A warning that radar devices or other instruments to assist airplane landings under conditions of low visibility are far from "foolproof" was given to a Senate Interstate Commerce subcommittee today by tear Admiral J. W. Reeves Jr., commander of the Naval Air transport Service. Committees in he Senate and the House are holding hearings on the general question of air safety.

BOSTON, Jan. 29 (AP)--The Boston Bruins lengthened their third place National Hockey League lead to three points over the idle New York Rangers by defeating the Detroit Red Wings, 4-1, before a crowd of 13,000 at the Boston Garden tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The Senate's recent unanimous approval of O. Max Gardner of North Carolina as American Ambassador to the Court of St. James was cited to that body and "the world" today as further evidence that American policy was national policy and not that of a political party.

BERLIN, Jan. 29 -- The arrival of a Czechoslovak delegation here to contract a trade agreement similar to the one concluded by United States and British officials with the Netherlands last week has reawakened discussion of the imminent establishment of a definite value for the worthless mark.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Witnesses before the Senate Committee on Labor and Public Welfare attacked today the "monopoly" aspects of unions and called the National Labor Relations (Wagner) Act the "root of unsatisfactory labor relations in the United States."

"Fixing" the Athletes Rocky Graziano, it was stated in these well-informed news columns the other day, is known as the hardest hitter in the middleweight division, "with a knockout punch in either hand."

The Right Rev. Charles Kendall Gilbert steps naturally into the place left vacant by Bishop Manning's retirement as head of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York. The convention which elected him could have chosen no one more familiar with the duties of his new office or more fitted to carry on the traditions of the diocese through his experience during the last quarter of a century.

ANCHORAGE,' Alaska, Jan. 29 -- Maj. Gen. Howard A. Craig, Commander in Chief of the Alaskan command, which includes the Navy, praised the work of the Task Force Frigid today and said its findings would benefit private industry and civilians as well as provide military data.

Banking is essentially a business of human relationships and good public relations policies for banks are "as necessary and as profitable as good bond lists," Swayne P. Goodenough, president of the Financial Advertisers Association, declared yesterday.

"THIS IS THE STORY,"* by David L. Cohn, is a bread-and-butter letter to the Army Service Forces that sent him to Britain, France, Belgium, Corsica, Italy, Egypt, Palestine, Iraq, Iran, India, Burma and China on a magnificent junket toward the end of the war. It is also much more than that. It is a rewarding travel chronicle filled with briskly written remarks on half the things under the sun.

MOSCOW, Jan. 29 -- An article in Pravda today charged that the United States and Britain were aiming at the political and economic division of Germany in the hope of transforming their merged zones into a private estate for Anglo-American capital.
Kenneth Chantler of Montreal wrested the American open racquets championship from Robert Grant 3d of New York yesterday at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Social Commission--Debated French proposal to bar the International Penal and Penitentiary Commission from consultations because of Spain's membership. French delegate resigned as rapporteur in protest on delays and criticized three Latin-American representatives with postponing decision that would "hurt the Franco Government." Meets at 10:30 A. M. and 2:30 P. M. Open.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29--Senators Robert Taft of Ohio and Lister Hill of Alabama announced today that they and four other Senators would introduce on Friday a bi-partisan bill for Federal aid to education.
A resolution recording the deep sorrow of the Metropolitan Opera at the death of Grace Moore was adopted at yesterday's meeting of the board of directors.

No request for either a Coadjutor or a Suffragan Bishop will be made for some time by the Right Rev. Charles K. Gilbert, Suffragan Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of New York for the last sixteen years, who on Tuesday was elected to be head of the diocese.

PARIS, Jan. 29 -- In a long speech on the evolving French policy toward Germany to the Foreign Affairs Committee of the National Assembly today Foreign Minister Georges Bidault refrained from any allusion to the plan he has long advocated for separating the Ruhr and the Rhineland from Germany.

Rivaling the "experts" on subjects varying from politics to poetry, Ellis Arnall, ex-Governor of Georgia, appeared here last night on the radio program "Information Please" and stole the show from such old-timers as Franklin P. Adams, John Kieran and Oscar Levant.
ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 29 -- Dr. John D. Clark, economic adviser to President Truman, declared today that unless prices drop there is going to be a recession in this country.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Immediate consultations between the United" States, Great Britain and Russia, to determine "exactly who's who and what's what" in responsibility for the "rigged and terrorized" elections in Poland Jan. 19, were called for today by Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 29 (AP) -- China's sixth airliner tragedy in five weeks killed twenty-five of the twenty-six persons aboard -- eleven of them members of foreign-mission families. In the six crashes, 140 persons were killed, nineteen are missing and twenty-one were injured.

Detroit yesterday announced that it would accept bids until Feb. 18 on $12,000,000 of transit revenue bonds dated Feb. 1, 1947, and due on each Feb. 1 from 1948 to 1960. Interest must not exceed 4 per cent.

Lumber prices are now at a peak and will drop at least 10 per cent by the end of the year, Frank W. Whitty, newly elected president of the Northeastern Retail Lumbermen's Association, declared yesterday at the fifty-third annual convention in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

STUART, Fla., Jan. 29 -- The "ill wind" proverb usually proves true for the sailfish angler, and the strong winds and low temperatures of last week have moved the sailfish inshore and provided some real sport for the anglers sailing out of this fishing port.

In his first major decision on policy, Secretary Marshall announces that the United States is ending its efforts to mediate in the smoldering civil war between the Chinese National Government and the Communists and is withdrawing its representatives from the truce machinery which General Marshall himself created in the hope of halting hostilities.

An unusual experiment in the punishment of juvenile delinquents has met with moderate success, it was said yesterday as five youths in Queens rounded out a thirty-day period of confinement in their homes for allegedly stoning a Long Island train.
JERUSALEM, Jan. 29 -- Former Maj. H. A. I. Collins, abducted by terrorists last Sunday, appeared shortly after 11 o'clock tonight at the Hadassah clinic in the center of Jerusalem.

The threat of a towboat workers' strike, which has been hanging over the city for four months, was lifted yesterday as tug workers voted nearly two to one in favor of the final contract offer made by the employers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 29 -- Charles R. Rogers, United Artists producer, today announced the purchase of screen rights to "Hollow Triumph," a first novel by Murray Forbes, published last year. The price paid for the property was $50,000, according to Rogers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Henry Ford 2d and Charles E. Wilson, president of General Motors Company were among fourteen new members named today to the Commerce Department's Business Advisory Council for 1947.

Secured liabilities totaling $14,271,466 were disclosed in preliminary schedules filed yesterday at the meeting of creditors of Motty Eitingon, Inc., held in the United States Court House. No schedules were filed on unsecured liabilities.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 29 -- Henri Hauck of France resigned today as rapporteur of the United Nations Social Commission in protest against its failure to take decisive action, and accused the Latin-American members of trying to postpone a verdict that would "hurt the Franco Government."

DUBLIN, Eire, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Austrian-born Dr. Erwin Schroedinger, Professor of the School of Physics in the Dublin Institute for Advanced Studies, asserted today that he had "solved a thirty-yearold problem: the competent generalization of Einstein's great theory of 1915."
BERLIN, Jan. 29 -- A new and extremely severe denazification program appears to be in progress in the Russian zone despite the Russians' repeated assertions that they completed the process long ago.

Five Army privates, all of whom were being held in Governors Island's historic fortress-prison, Castle Williams, as a safeguard against their pronounced disposition to escape military confinement, hacksawed their way to freedom early yesterday.

The vanguard of sixty married veterans and their families, who will occupy four-room apartment in houses under construction by the Federal Public Housing Authority on the New York University Heights campus, began moving into the sixteen completed units yesterday afternoon.

Bankers headed by Lehman Brothers and Lazard Freres Co. will offer today to the public 1,342,192 shares of $5 par value common stock of the Central and Southwest Corporation, a newly formed merger of Central and Southwest Utilities Company and its subsidiary, American Public Service Company.

Adolfo Odnoposoff, 'cellist, gave his first New York recital last night at Town Hall. He is the second member of the family to enter the local recital field, for his older brother, Ricardo, a violinist, has given two Carnegie Hall recitals and has appeared as soloist with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- By a vote of 373 to 35, the House passed today a bill to peg excise taxes on furs, jewelry, liquor and a number of other "luxuries" at their present wartime rates.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 29 (AP) -- The favored Mrs. Babe Didrikson Zaharias turned back Miss Jean Hopkins, Cleveland, Ohio, city champion, 2 and 1, today in the second round of the Helen Lee Doherty golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29--President Truman plans to view the Spring maneuvers of the Atlantic Fleet in the Caribbean from the navigation bridge of a battleship or heavy cruiser. He would leave Washington soon after returning from his good-will mission to Mexico City set for early March.

Edmond M. Hanrahan, member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, appealed yesterday to securities dealers to help "streamline" the securities laws and carry out their intent by pointing out to their customers the salient data contained in stock prospectuses.

With the production of "All My Sons," at the Coronet last evening, the theatre has acquired a genuine new talent. Arthur Miller, who wrote "The Man Who Had All the Luck" in 1944, brings something fresh and exciting into the drama. He has written an honest, forceful drama about a group of people caught up in a monstrous swindle that has caused the death of twenty-one Army pilots because of defectively manufactured cylinder heads.

Decrying "defeatist conversation" about the inevitability of a depression, Walter D. Fuller, president, of the National Publishers Association, said last night that a depression can be avoided if the American people will seek better facts, wider understanding, and greater tolerance and will be less selfish and work harder.

Pittsburgh is one rival New York's entry in the Basketball Association of America seems to be able to beat consistently. The Knickerbockers turned back the Ironmen, 64-60, for the fourth time in as many meetings before 3,419 spectators at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory last night.

PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 29-- Planned in accordance with Princeton's emphasis on individual instruction and independent work, Princeton University's new Harvey S. Firestone Memo ial Library will contain 660 individual cubicles and have seating accommodations for 1,875 students, according to detailed plans released today by Dr. Harold Willis Dodds, president of the university.

The urgent need for continuing overseas Catholic war relief was stressed yesterday at a luncheon and organization meeting in the Hotel Roosevelt of sixteen diocesan directors and their assistants who will have charge of the Bishops' Relief Compaign for Victims of War in their respective areas.

The Board of Education approved unanimously yesterday a resolution granting emergency pay increases of $300 a year in State funds to more than 35,000 full-time teachers and other employes of the New York City public school system.

The concert of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony last night in Carnegie Hall was a brilliant and memorable occasion. Its climax was Charles Muench's matchless performance of the Berlioz "Fantastic" symphony.
Edward MacGuire, formerly with Reynolds Co., has been appointed manager of chain store operations for the razor blade division of the Marlin Firearms Company.

DUBLIN, Jan. 30 (U.P.)--James Larkin, 69-year-old labor leader in Ireland and the United States, who once served a term in Sing Sing for criminal anarchy after the first World War, died today after an illness of several weeks.

The Florida-like warmth of the last few days and the fact that fishing vessels are more numerous than they have been since the Government commandeered a large number for war use have resulted in an abundance of fresh fish that was not expected by the industry till the first of April.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan announced yesterday that he was widening his investigation of fight-fixing to uncover and root out of boxing gangsters who exercise the real control while they put up managers-of-record as "fronts."

Sam A. Lewisohn announced yesterday his retirement as a partner of Lewisohn Co. in order to devote his time to his expanding mining and corporate interests. The firm, which was founded in 1893, will be succeeded today by the new Stock Exchange firm of Dreyfus, Jacquin Co.

The political situation in the western zone of Germany is deteriorating day by day, and unless it takes a turn for the better, the zone will fall into the hands of the Communists within a year, Dr. George N. Shuster warned yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 30 (AP)--James Butler, president of the Empire City Racing Association of New York, tonight was "encouraged" by British reaction to his proposal of a $100,000 international horse race in the United States.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 30 --President Truman is expected to send a message to Congress within the next ten days asking it to appropriate more than $70,000,000 for the International Refugee Organization and a larger amount to supply food and other basic essentials for war devastated countries.

LONDON, Jan. 30--A new problem was presented to the Big Four Foreign Ministers' deputies today when Yugoslavia filed a protest against the appearance of the Austrian representative, Hans Piesch, Governor of Carinthia, on the ground that he was Nazitainted.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 30--Bids for the electrification of the great Aswan Dam--a project that has been under consideration for nearly three decades -- were received by an Egyptian Government commission today. Three American firms or groups were among bidders, which also included British, Swedish, Swiss, French and Czechoslovak firms.

Four hundred employes of the Ira Bushey Sons shipyard, Court Street, Brooklyn, walked out yesterday morning in protest against working without a contract. The men are members of Local 13, Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, CIO.

Dr. Vannevar Bush, atom bomb scientist and chairman of the newly-created Joint Research and Development Board of the Army and Navy, received yesterday the Hoover Medal for 1946 for outstanding public service.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 30--With the return of thirty-three boys from Austria to their families a few weeks ago, a story that goes back four years was revealed today.

Profit-taking was encountered yesterday by the stock market, which pared or eliminated morning additions. Prices were irregularly lower at the close in terms of the averages, although the issues to show gains slightly outnumbered those to give ground.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The editorial on the portal-to-portal cases in your issue of Jan. 4 contains a suggestion that Congress now clarify its original intention as expressed in the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938. I have not seen this elsewhere discussed in the press, nor does it appear to have been considered by Congress.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--The official Republican policy on fiscal affairs in the House was revised today to emphasize that any reduction of personal income taxes this year would depend upon ability to balance the budget and start payments on the national debt.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--Sales of surplus war property up to the end of 1946 netted the United States slightly less than one-fourth of the cost of this material, the Department of State informed the Congress in a report submitted today.

ALBANY, Jan. 30--A bill was introduced in the Assembly today designed to prevent the Black River Regulating Board from constructing new reservoirs in the State forest preserve. The measure opposes construction of the Higley Mountain dam.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Jan. 30 --An appeal to the United States and associated democracies to set aside or qualify the results of Sunday's national election here appears certain. The electoral machinery is firmly in the hands of the Government party of President Anastasio Somoza, and the Opposition has no hope of winning under existing conditions.

The Truman Administration, seeking to counteract the political effects of an "all-white" Democratic primary in Georgia and the notoriety that attended the Bilbo contest in Mississippi, has decided on the appointment of a Negro to the United States District Court in the Eastern District of New York.
The second step to clear the financial and commercial areas of lower Manhattan of parked automobiles was taken yesterday by Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30--Plans for the first comprehensive study of what needs the social services are trying to meet and how to adapt the services to them and prepare workers to do the job, were outlined tonight at the annual meeting here of the American Association of Schools of Social Work.

See Fewer Coat and Suit Units Prospect of incomplete deliveries of worsted fabrics to manufacturers of women's apparel by April 1 will cut down units manufactured for spring, it was pointed out yesterday in the trade. Mills have requested a thirty-day extension of delivery dates on some worsted fabrics, and sixty days for gabardines, according to cutters.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--Robert B. Barker, former Dies Committee investigator, told the Senate Public Works Committee today that his 1940 inquiries had revealed nothing to connect Gordon R. Clapp with communistic activities in the Tennessee Valley Authority.
A new apparatus to prospect for atomic bomb ores and an atomic water boiler are among the secrets in 270 papers released by the new Atomic Energy Commission and the Manhattan Engineer District.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Jan. 25, 1947, totaled 821,964 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 6,096 cars, or 0.7 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 113,410 cars, or 16.0 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year, and 62,339 cars, or 8.2 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.
BERLIN, Jan. 30--The first contract of the new bi-zonal exportimport agency is with a Norwegian company wholly owned by I.G. Farbenindustrie or its affiliates, it was learned today.

More than 2,500 persons attended a memorial service for Grace Moore at Riverside Church yesterday afternoon in which Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, pastor emeritus, paid a glowing tribute to the Metropolitan Opera star. An equal number, many of them members of the church congregation, were turned away.

SYDNEY, Jan. 30 (AP) -- The United States Lawn Tennis Association has recalled Gardnar Mulloy, Bill Talbert and Tom Brown, three members of its Davis Cup squad still in Australia, who have been playing in tournaments and exhibitions the past month.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--A very important economic and social issue in this country was chosen by Harold E. Stassen for the first formal speech he has made since he announced his candidacy for the Republican nomination for the Presidency. It involves the question whether laws and administrative procedures are to be directed to encourage that enterprise called small business on which some of the foundations of the United States were laid.

As local politicians assailed police for harassing law-abiding citizens, eight men seized in a raid Wednesday night in an East Harlem club were dismissed yesterday in mid-Manhattan Magistrate's Court.
Developing some irregularity yesterday, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 4 points lower to 15 points higher.

Individual steel distributors have offered to take off the hands of the War Assets Administration the entire remaining steel surplus-disposal problem, Morris Rosoff, general counsel, Association of Steel Distributors, Inc., disclosed here yesterday.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 30--Lee Pressman, general counsel for the Congress of Industrial Organizations, denounced tonight most of the labor control bills introduced in Congress as "unjustified" or unnecessary.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (U.P.)-- Adolf Hitler, enraged because his surface ships refused to fight, ordered the German high-seas fleet scrapped early in 1943 and tricked the Allies with a "shadow fleet" until the war ended.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--Ludwig Teller, New York lawyer, warned Congress today to adopt a balanced labor policy, administered by a labor court, which would be limited to passing on controversies but which would not have compulsory arbitration powers.

WARSAW, Jan. 30--The Polish Government's deliberate campaign to rid itself of the British Ambassador, Victor Cavendish-Bentinck has succeeded with the Ambassador's reassignment to another post. He has represented Great Britain here since August, 1945, during what is generally described as one of the most difficult periods in Polish-British relations.

A proposed substitute for UNRRA begins to take shape in the report of a ten-nation special committee just submitted to U.N. Secretary General Lie after seventeen days of discussion. The committee was instructed to stick to relief--in the words of the General Assembly resolution which created it, to outline a program to prevent "suffering or economic retrogression."

Stresses Local Public Relations "Public Opinion Is Local," a new color slide presentation stressing the increasing need of vigorous public relations campaigns by American industry on the community level, was shown yesterday by the bureau of advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association at a preview luncheon at the Hotel Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--A dozen nations, including some that had never complained before, testified before the International Emergency Food Council today of food problems so bad their emergencies would not end with the close of the council Dec. 31, 1947.
