Curtail Saturday Staffs As a prelude to the time when securities exchanges decide to forego Saturday sessions, the New York Stock Exchange will experiment with skeleton staffs in four key operations beginning tomorrow. The 875 employes of the departments of floor operations, administrative offices and quotations, as well as the quotation company, will have every third Saturday off.

LONDON, Jan. 30--A proposal to return to Germany part of the German territory now occupied by the Poles is being studied in United States circles, it was learned today. This territory would include those portions of Brandenburg and Pomerania allotted to Poland in the Potsdam conference, as well as Northern Silesia.

JUST as all the expert observers had come to the conclusion that Gilbert Dodds would sweep every mile race this season, the Flying Parson up and announces that he'll run the mile for the last time in Boston next week and then will shoot for longer distances. Since the Perambulating Teacher is an amateur athlete he can do as he pleases, even though his decision will cause great mental anguish among the meet directors.

The Crowell-Collier Publishing Company, publishers of Collier's, is going ahead with plans to issue a multi-lingual international magazine to be printed and distributed in various parts of the world, it became known yesterday.

Fully aware of gambling's gnawing threat to professional sports, Baseball Commissioner A.B. Chandler said yesterday he would take "appropriate action" in the Evangeline League scandal as soon as the final minor league decision it known, The Assoicated Press reported.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--Former President Herbert Hoover conferred today with Secretary of State George C. Marshall and William L. Clayton, Under-Secretary of State for Economic Affairs. They considered the necessity of integrating Mr. Hoover's mission to Germany, including his observations and the results of his study, with the department's over-all policy for bringing about an economically integrated Germany.

Two electronic computers that will handle complex arithmetical problems faster than earlier models were described yesterday at conference sessions of the winter meeting of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers at 33 West Thirty-ninth Street.

A portrait of Franklin D. Roosevelt by the late Ellen Emmett Rand, not hitherto shown to the public and only recently discovered in her studio, is being exhibited by Helen Hacket, art dealer, at the Babcock Gallery, 38 East Fiftyseventh Street.

A resolution urging Averell Harriman, Secretary of Commerce, to postpone removal of the statistical section of the Customs Bureau from New York to Suitland, Md., until a Congressional investigation can be made, was passed yesterday at a protest meeting sponsored by the international trade section of the New York Board of Trade.

Senator Charles W. Tobey of New Hampshire has introduced a bill which would liberalize the present authority of the Federal Reserve Banks in the field of guaranteeing bank loans to business enterprises. The proposed legislation would empower any of these twelve regional institutions to underwrite such loans up to 90 per cent, with the original lender required to assume a minimum of 10 per cent of the risk.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 30 --Henri Hauck, French representative, agreed today to reconsider his resignation as rapporteur of the United Nations Social Commission after the eighteen-nation board in a burst of speed resolved four of its major items.

Rejection of inferior quality merchandise by the consumer brought about a 100 per cent increase in dollar mark-downs for his company in 1946 over the preceding year, A.W. Hughes, president of J.C. Penney Company, Inc., declared yesterday.

NANKING, China, Jan. 30-- Communist guerrilla troops continued their merciless harassment of Nationalist communications and collieries as Wang Ping-nan, Communist spokesman here, declared tonight that Yenan was confident that it could impose its political demands on the Government by force of arms.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., Jan. 30-- The sixty-fifth anniversary of the birth of Franklin D. Roosevelt was marked at the Roosevelt family home today with the dedication of a granite bust of the late President.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 30--The American Federation of Labor, which preferred to walk alone internationally rather than associate with Russian labor organizations in the World Federation of Trade Unions, is considering a new liaison that may have significance in the politics of world labor.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--Lower prices for agricultural commodities, hides and leather were responsible for a decline of 0.4 per cent in primary market prices during the week ended on Jan. 23, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

LONDON, Jan. 30--A joint committee of British officials and Arab League delegates to the Palestine conference will be created tomorrow to study solutions to the Palestine problem suggested by both Arabs and Zionists, it was announced tonight.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30--The Commodity Credit Corporation asked elevator interests to offer spring wheat today for prompt, March 15 and opening of Lake navigation shipment to Lake Superior ports-- the requests for offers were for three dates as stated--and started a buying movement in wheat futures that carried prices up at much as 1 1/4 cents before profittaking checked the advance.

Cranston Williams, general manager of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, said last night that the association would welcome an opportunity to testify in the newsprint investigation, The United Press reported.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--Fordham's basketball team notched its seventh straight victory tonight downing favored Georgetown, 58-- 42, at the Uline Arena, Herb Clann with 21 points, paced the Rams who led, 26--20, at the half.

Construction of a new $17,500,000 bus terminal by the Port Authority on the square block bounded by Eighth and Ninth Avenues, Fortieth and Forty-first Streets, was sanctioned yesterday by the Board of Estimate.

Dr. Martha M. Eliot, associate chief of the United States Children's Bureau, called yesterday upon representatives of education, welfare and service organizations to extend their field programs for preventing "the tragic loss of life among children" from accidents.

Combined net assets of $70,676,107 at the close of 1946 were reported yesterday by United States and Foreign Securities Corporation and its affiliate, United States and International Securities Corporation. The combined assets of the investment companies amounted to $79,610,747 on Dec. 31, 1945.

ALBANY, Jan. 30--Up-State Mayors, considering additional sources of revenue for municipal needs, showed a marked preference for local surcharges on State income, corporation, motor fuel and alcoholic beverages taxes at a meeting here today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The recent series of air disasters, the many spectacular crashes such as those in which planes struck the Empire State Building and a building in Wall Street could, in the vast majority of cases, have been prevented. The fact that a preventive exists but for the asking and is not utilized is criminal and certainly foolish, to say the least.

While New Yorkers basked yesterday in spring-like temperatures, a large section of the nation from the Central States eastward was beset by freak weather. Tornadoes ripped through five States, heavy snow fell in five others and freezing rain, accompanied in some instances by lightning, was reported in three more.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--Senator James E. Murray, chairman of the expiring Senate Small Business Committee, charged today that a free competitive press was being menaced by "three groups of corporate giants" which, he held, controlled the newsprint industry on policies of production, price and distribution.

C. Vann Woodward, Associate Professor of History at Johns Hopkins University, who was an intelligence officer in the Office of Chief of Naval Operations, has written an account of the greatest naval battle of the war, entitled "The Battle for Leyte Gulf."

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Jan. 30--The Swedish cruiser Oscar II carried home to Sweden today the body of Prince Gustaf Adolf, who was killed in an airliner crash here Sunday. Two Danish icebreakers opened the way through the icebound Oeresund.

As the result of a survey made by Fire Commissioner Frank J. Quayle, Mayor O'Dwyer announced last night that he was sponsoring legislation in the City Council to tighten the city's administrative code so that rooming houses, lodging houses and hotels will toe the mark on fire regulations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--The Navy Department announced today that dead and missing in the Navy, Marine Corps and Coast Guard from Dec. 7, 1941, to Jan. 1, 1947, totaled 88,939 men and women. Of this total the Navy lost 62,548, the Marine Corps 24,479 and the Coast Guard 1,912.

With all the space and attention commanded by the mile, the 600, the 880, the two-mile and the other glamor events of the Millrose games the relays form the real backbone of tomorrow night's track carnival at Madison Square Garden. The elaborate team schedule announced yesterday is rich in its promise of stirring action.

TUCSON, Ariz., Jan. 30 (AP)-- Jimmy Clark, 29-year-old freshman in the professional golfing ranks, posted a 63 today to tie the course record and lead a parshattering assault in the first round of the 72-hole $10,000 Tucson open tournament.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (U.P.)-- With a smile and a hearty "you did a mighty fine thing," President Truman decorated Comdr. Richard N. Antrim, 39, of Peru, Ind., today with the Congressional Medal of Honor and the Bronze Star Medal for offering to submit to Japanese whipping post torture to save a comrade from being beaten to death.

Events were held last night throughout the city in commemoration of the sixty-fifth anniversary of the birth of Franklin D. Roosevelt and also as a climax of the 1947 March of Dimes Campaign of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis--the organization formed by the late President in 1938 to lead the fight against poliomyelitis.

Preparing for the impending smoke abatement campaign, Mayor O'Dwyer called yesterday upon forty municipal agencies, civic organizations, medical societies and idustrial groups in the metropolitan area to set up a "citizens' committee" that would help clear the New York air.
SECURITY COUNCIL Meets at 3 P.M. (open) to mark retirement of Norman J.O. Makin of Australia from the presidency under rotation policy requiring a new chairman every month.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30--Mrs. Robert W. Macauley, assistant chairman of the Republican National Committee, and Mrs. Addison B. Green, president of the National Federation of Women's Republican Clubs, asserted today that "there will be no recessional of women in politics."
